reviews.review: Thailand break & Pilgrimage. What can I say except, this is one Temple you just cannot afford to miss. A must, otherwise you've missed everything.

Unbelievable!!!!!!. The entire grounds (Grand Palace) is almost beyond belief.... bring plenty of memory cards because all you will want to do is take pictures!!! This is a MUST SEE while in Bangkok!!!!

Jade Buddhas . I've seen this twice. It's pretty much a glorified statue but how it's been set up is unreal. You can't take photos of the Buddha but as always you can buy a postcard with its likeness on it.

Amazing ..Temples and Park. Was so nice walking in, thai buildings in gold color make a scene so great with reflex of the sun on it. The place where is situated the statue of the Emerald Buddha is so beautiful and a great mistic energy inside there.

Beautiful temple. If you visit Bangkok whatever you do do not miss out on seeing this temple it's magnificent and beautiful, not seen anything like it!
Just make sure you don't turn up in shorts or a sleeve less top, otherwise you won't be allowed in!
One of the top 10 places to visit in my opinion!
Wonderful. marvelous structure. The temples and statues are amazing. A real piece of ancient history in the heart of Bangkok.

Good. We had a private guide through Destination Asia who was excellent with knowledge of the temple, the backgrounds of the various buildings, dates built etc. We went around 1pm and it was busy but not excessive.

Amazing Wat Pra Keaw, Thailand.. Amazing Thailand with Wat Phra Kaew or the Temple of the Emerald Buddha located in the center of Bangkok. This is the most important and beautiful temple of Thailand. It crowded with tourists from around the world. The highlight of Wat Pra Kaew is gracefully decorated with intricate carvings and golden architecture.
Highly recommend when you visit Bangkok !!!

An impressive Buddhist temple. I took the self-guided audio tour for the temple and the palace. The lion share of the tour is within the grounds of the temple, and for a good reason. the temple area is rich in Buddhist decorations, statues, and other small buildings. The emerald Buddha in the main building is very impressive. I do recommend the audio tour, as it provides a good historical perspective on the different elements of the temples. Sometimes it is a bit boring, but you can skip to the next section.

Beautiful, but overcrowded and too many tourists. I went there with a travel agent, who brought us around etc. Go there is you woild like to see the history of the palace and the temple, but be prepared for the crowd and the huge number of tourists all jostling to take that one shot with the statues etc.

Worth visiting everytime !. This is part of the Grand Palace in the N.E corner and with a blue tiled roof. Not so well posted like everything in Thailand. They are not so touristy savvy like the Americans in marketing their places of interest. Even trying to get decent fridge magnets was not possible.The entrance fees for both the Grand Palace (250 bahts) and Emerald Buddha ( 250 bahts ) can be bought together.They are open from 8.20am-12 pm then  from 1pm-3.30pm.It is better to go early and make it the first port of call since the crowd builds up afterwards. The so called Emerald Buddha is actually made of jade and no one is allowed to take pictures or videos inside.Dress code is strictly adhered - no shorts or sleeveless clothing and hats or sandals/slippers when entering.The king is the only one who can dress up the Emerald Buddha during occasions.The various gifts given to the King by visiting dignitaries are also displayed in this place.A must see place whilst visiting Bangkok.
Beautiful. Every temple is a work of art worth seeing, such a site to see the emerald buddah. ive never seen such a large piece of work made from emerald. it is not huge but it is gorgeous.

Emerald Buddha . Within the Grand Palace grounds this is a must see. Be prepared in terms of proper attire, the grounds policy is strict and deviations will not be allowed. Long pants (not capris), over the shoulder to mid arm shirts are required. Only Thai nationals are allowed to the very front of the temple, but you'll miss nothing being 10m back.
A must see place. The place is really impressive with the craftsmanship. The ambiance is peaceful regardless of the many tourists.
Very nice. The grade plaze very beuatiful veryone come to bangkok they must to come this for take photo and very nice experien

Exquisite!. By far my favorite temple. The details are immaculate!! The Emerald Buddha sits atop a glorious shrine and is dressed for the season -rainy when I saw it, but also for summer, spring, and winter. Very crowded and no photography allowed inside the temple. The outside courtyards were difficult to get good pictures in as they were packed with tourists and visitors. But so worth it!!
pray time. the main reason i went was for praying, after this the location has many things to do around it, big mall across the street and metro is right there
Beautiful temple. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is located within the grand palace complex and both can be explored together. Its a must place to visit Bangkok.

'Within the grounds of the Grand Palace'. The Temple of the Emerald Buddah is within the grounds of the Grand Palace and is so beautiful, this was the first place I visited while at the Grand Palace.You must remove your shoes and place them on a rack before entering. There were so many people in the temple that you could barely move, but it was worth it, Phra Kaew was stunning to see, even though he was quite small, the temple in which he is housed is huge. You cannot take photos inside the temple but I was told it is ok to take photos from the outside if you have a camera with a good zoom, so I tried and the photos are not that great but at least you can see him.Even though I am not religious I felt overwhelmed, it really was amazing to see.Make sure you show respect and dress appropriately with your shoulders and knees covered.

Vacation . Omg so amazing beautiful place to much things for doing for seeing veery colorful all the temples beautiful good to know about others Coulter.meet people around the world..it was good experience in like be there

Stunning complex of temples, although hot and busy. This temple is part of the Grand Palace complex, and like most temples in this part of the world is an assortment of different structures. The main 'Wat' houses the Emerald Buddha - surprisingly small, but high up and well lit, and with a lovely deep green colour. The rest of the complex has lots to see - golden chedis (tapering towers), jewelled temples, roofs with curled gables, statues of demons and mythical creatures, and even a scale model of Angkor Wat. It is a very busy place so don't expect to have it alone, even if you're there in low season. Getting there early might help (I didn't, so can't say for sure). The crowds were generally good natured, but even so a big press of people all trying to photograph each other in front of the same monuments, in high heat and humidity, is never the nicest thing. Take patience, a sense of humour, and a water bottle and try to give yourself plenty of time so you can relax.It is a religious site so you need to dress modestly (this is enforced) and remove your shoes before going up to the Wat itself. It's fine to take photographs apart from inside the temple with the emerald Buddha itself, although you can take a picture from outside. Many Buddhists consider 'selfies' with Buddha images to be disrespectful, therefore I avoid taking them (although you'll see plenty of people who do).
Cannot Miss. Absolutely amazing! This is a MUST SEE if you're visiting Bangkok. Golden temples, history, beauty on every corner.

Gorgeous temple but very busy. We were at the Grand Palace by 10am and although we didn't need to queue to get in the grounds were extremely busy will tour groups. Many individuals in these groups were rude and pushy, my 12 year old daughter felt like she was pushed out of the way by these people on several occasions.Take the long route around thd temple grounds, crowds are less and you can enjoy the site. Be prepared for it to be busy entering the actual temple.
Awesome Experience. This place is very hard to describe. Everything there is very spiritual. The art, the sculptures even the visitors, all combines to an awesome experience.
at least once time in your life. a must being in Bangkok. amazing everything, so nice to be here. spend at least 3 hours to visit well. the grand palace.

Absolutely gorgeous...can be very hot & croweded. Stunning building within the grand palace complex. Absolutely do not try to take a picture inside. The front of temple appears to be reserved for praying Buddhists, back for tourists. Which is just fine. The statue is quite small no matter where you stand. But gorgeous display. Remember to bring hat umbrella sunscreen and water! At the clothing rental building there is a little cafe selling water, juice & coffee. Water is 15B.

Hot and busy but great experience all the same. We visited in the morning early on in our visit to Bangkok, and were not very acclimatised to the heat so we struggled a bit with the heat and crowds of large loud tour groups. Add in the security guards with their whistles and it's a full on assault! However, I was pleased to have read up in the Lonely Planet guide first and had it on hand to tailor make a highlights tour for our family of the Grand Palace which worked very well.We particularly enjoyed the murals and the weapons room. We spent about an hour and a half there over all.

Must visit !. I always take my friends who visiting Thailand to visit this temple !! You can experience the Art and culture, history, glamours and so on. Walking around there could take half a day if you are interested in history of Thailand. I could be very hot and crowded so make sure you have plenty of water.

Must go! Amazing . This temple is huge and amazing, you must go! In a hot day, like every day here, could help bring some water, umbrella or hat and even with high temperatures you cannot go inside the temple wearing short or small skirt or without cover your shoulders. So come with a little bit more clothes at this day and enjoy! You will never forget this experience!

Not to be missed . Visited with friends , what an amazing place this temple is. Has an amazing feeling about it and truly calming. Still wearing the string bracelet off the monk. Should not be missed.

Ok - very busy Emerald buddhe is tiny!. My husband and I visited in Jan 2016 as part of our honeymoon, we had an idea of what we wanted to see in Bangkok, the emerald Buddha being one of them. Neither of us had any idea how tiny it would be! It is worth going to say you've seen it and we did this on a day we used the River boat so was all in all part of a good day.

Landmark of Thailand. Wat Phra Kaew is Thailand's most important and sacred temple, so you're expected to act with due respect inside it. It houses the tiny (between 60 and 75 cm) Emerald Buddha, which is located high above the heads of the worshippers and tourists. Not much is known for certain about the statue, except that it isn't actually made of emerald but rather of green jade or jasper. The 'robe' that it wears is changed 3 times each year by the King himself, at the start of each season: A diamond encrusted gold robe during the hot season, a solid gold robe in the cool season and a gilded monk's robe in the rainy season.There are also many other Buddha images inside the temple. Round the interior walls are murals depicting the jataka stories. These are located according to the typical Thai conventions inside temples. The ones facing the altar depict the victory of the Buddha over the evil demon Mara, as he subdues her and achieves enlightenment. As is normal for Thai temples, shoes must be taken off before entering into the temple.

An Absolute Marvel.. Wat Phra Kaew, along with most of the other Buddhist temples in Bangkok, is a marvel of architecture, culture, and detail. The emerald Buddha image is one of the most incredible in the world. There are many, many other smaller Buddha images of various styles throughout the temple grounds. The mosaic details throughout the temple and its grounds are incredible. If you only visit one Buddhist temple in Bangkok This is the one to visit. This will be one of the many highlights of your trip to Thailand.

Something that must be in on your bucketlist. The temple is very impressive and is definitely worth visiting. A lot of culture, history and traditions... all in one place.You can take guide (must pay for his/her entrance 500 Baht = 15 usd) and also us have long pants (the guide can borrow you a pair for the duration of the visit).I would advice to double check (test) the guide 's English level since due to their accent you might have difficulty in understanding their English.The tour takes like 45 min to 60 min. You can take pictures outside the temple but not inside. However, with a good camera (good focus) you can take pictures of the inside from outside
A must visit in Bangkok. A must visit place when you're in Bangkok. Wat Phra Kaew or the temple of the Emerald Buddha is one of the long history temple. Better to visit in the morning.
breathtaking. This was my favourite temple. I loved the colours, detail and history in the architecture as well as the faith.
fascinating and smaller than expected. love the way the emerald buddha has seasonal attire to change into! it is smaller than i expected but being pure gold its understandable.

The Temple of the Emerald Buddha. This temple is more commonly known as Temple of the Emerald Buddha; it is one of the city's most historic temples and is located close to the Grand Palace. The temple's claim to fame and main attraction is the Phra Kaew Morakot, the Emerald Buddha which was carved out of a single piece of jade. The Buddha is located in the main prayer hall or ubosot.

A must place to visit. The first attraction that you must visit when a you visit Bangkok A long history temple combination with architecturesComplimentary tour staff available for tourists upon arrival

A highly decorated temple. Grand Palace and Emerald Buddha Temple are close to each other. If it's your first visit to Emerald Buddha, you will be captivated by the gems and stones on the decorated walls of the temple. You have to make a full circle of the temple, then only you get a chance to enter. Crowd there, is a huge one. You have to put off your shoes at the entrance. Such a large number of people and the sunny weather will make you tired. Besides them, when you enter inside and have a closer look at the statue, you'll find it worth visiting.
Great site. Amazing place to be because of the history that this exudes. Just be respectful since this is Temple and not just a tourist site.

Rich in history . Arriving in Bangkok sometime 1782 this rather impressive Buddha is now on show for everyone to see and appreciate.The Buddha himself is impressive dispite being only 65cms tall, however the mural surrounding the outside of the adjoining buildings are as equally impressive. Tour guide, whilst informative is not essential and you can happily navigate your way round this attraction quite easily.It's next door to the Grand Palace so doing both in and few hours is easy.

Exquisite. It is inside the Grand Palace premises and the two can be combined...architecture is unique and amazing.... very intricate work on the walls and everywhere around... must see while in Bangkok. the inside of the temple is very beautiful but photography is not allowed. Be appropriately dressed before visiting this place.

Awe inspiring. True insight in the thai culture...a must see for bangkok. Beautiful carvings..intricate art...majestic buddha....most other buildings in the complex are closed but are still worth the visit. Free english tour available at around 1:30 pm
Super!. Love History. Excellent place to visit and to learn a lot about Buddha. Worthy to visit. Important to have appropriate cloths to visit all temples and pagodas
a true work of art... just stunning. this was the first temple I visited and wow did it set the bar high. it is absolutely stunning. even on a really hot day it was enjoyable.

BEAUTIFUL MUST SEE. This temple is on the grounds of the Grand Palace. It is Thailand's most holy place. You are allowed to photograph the holy Buddha statue but only from outside. As it is a small statue, don't forget your telelens. Three times a year the Buddha gets a new dress. This is done by the king. On those days you are not allowed to enter the building, but you can watch the statue from outside. As far as I know, you are not allowed to enter the temple compound when the king is there.

Beautiful temple. The temple of emerald Buddha is beautiful and sort a day trip. Entry fee is 500 baht (combined ticket with grand palace). Audio guide/personal guide services can be bought at the entrance for an additional fee (which is advisible if you want to know more about the culture). The statue of Buddha in itself is majestic and if breathtaking beauty. Open from 8:30 am to 3:30 pm. Caution: Touts and taxi drivers outside temple can try to fool foreign visitors by saying temple is closed till 1:00 pm so as to take them to other places which is not so. Fortunately frequent announcements from authorities advise you that temple is never closed between 8:30 am and 3:30 pm. It also gets very hot during noon. So it is advisable to carry enough water, sun block , cap etc.

Amazing temples with so many unique ornaments and details. I was really fascinated by the beauty of the amazing Temple of the Emerald Buddha ( Wat Phra Kaew ). This temple is very different from the temples in Indonesia. Temples in Indonesia was made of stone structure, while the Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew) was made of ornaments such as coating metals such as gold and colorful glass. It was look so beautifull. When you enter Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew), you can simultaneously enter the Grand Palace sights thereafter. Foreign travelers only need to pay a ticket for 250 bath (in 2014) or almost equivalent to 100,000 IDR (Indonesian Rupiah). while for domestic tourists do not need to pay the ticket. We were lucky to get in for free because my husband was studying at a university in Bangkok, and our faces to look like the people of southern Thailand.I'ts amazing, beautifull, and unforgottable..I highly recommend you to visit this temple if you come to Bangkok, Thailand.

Temple of the Emerald Buddha Thailand. This was the most interesting place I have been to I was nearly 5hours there as there is so mush to see every thing is gold, the statues are beautiful and you just want to study how they have made them beautiful place to visit

Wear your sunglasses. This cannot be reviewed, what a great place to go.
At sometimes crowdy, so go early or after 15.00 hrs.
Be aware to wear long sleeves/trousers. Although you can rent some. The temple is so beautiful restored. A lot of gold and with a lot of details. Defeneitely worth the visiy

Warning: No pictures!. This temple is located inside of the Palace, as many other people have helpfully pointed out. I would like to remind everyone: THERE ARE NO PHOTOS ALLOWED INSIDE. We saw a security guard physically take a camera away from a tourist who violated this rule. He wouldn't return the camera for about 15 minutes.Snapping a quick photo for you may seem okay, but it is not okay for Thai people. Don't risk it! Enjoy the lovely murals and the gorgeous temple with your senses not your camera.

Absolutely stunning, quite crowded. By far the most dazzling temple we saw in Thailand. Enormous, modern, glittering statutes and structures in every direction - it's clear why this is the national temple of Thailand. Absolutely swamped though - I'd try to go either in low tourist season or at a low volume time of day (e.g. super early in the morning).Also, get a guide, there's too much to miss if you go on your own or with a book.

Must visit site in Bangkok. This is an eminent temple in Bangkok, which is located within the compound of Grand Palace. Bad thing is nowadays too many tourists throng this temple, making it not a relaxing trip when visit this temple.

Very humbling. This was a very humbling experience. The jade Budha is surrounded by all the dead kings statues. The Budha has different season coats made of gold. Only the King can change the coats, however the now the King is older his son changes them. Your not allowed to speak but that adds to the experience. A must see
Beautiful. It's a very beautiful place and must be amazing to stay there for longer than we did. It has too many people, so it's robbed of the peace and good energy it clearly has...
Beautiful architecture. Its a beautiful place to visit with sheer divinity. The art of this place is the most beautiful attribute. You see a glimpse of divinity blended with art. Must for art lovers.

No1 visit in BKK. By skytrain to Taksin-Bridge-Station, then by boat to Sanam Luang, and walk across to the entrance. To enter Wat Phra Keo and the Kings Palace, you Need to be dressed decent.bring enough time, to see the whole RAMAKIEN -Story,painted an the walls.This is the Thai-Version of the RAMAYANA.:

Emerald Buddha. This is a place of worship so you're not allowed to take pictures and you need to take off your shoes. The Emerald Buddha is not that big and so you must go inside to see it. You won't need to stay too long inside if you won't worship or pray. Some feet smell too LOL!
Must Do!. A great cultural experience. The Emerald Buddha was smaller than I thought but very beautiful. An absolute must see while in Bangkok.

A taste of Siam . A trip to Bangkok would not be complete with a trip to see the emerald Buddha after all it's where the city gets its name ( Google the longest name of a city in the world and you will be surprised by the answer ) . This palace is a real taste of old Siam , simply a must see attraction

Wat Phra Kaew. Regarded as the most important Buddhist temple in Thailand, located within the grounds of the Grand Palace, it enshrines the Emerald Buddha, the highly revered Buddha image meticulously carved from a single block of jade. Entering the main hall, one has to take off shoes and hats (as any shrine would have make you) and no photography is allowed inside the area where the emerald Buddha is located. You must also be properly dressed to be allowed to enter.It is so small from our view because it was hoisted and I learned that only the King of Thailand is the only one allowed to go near it.Upon paying the 500baht ticket when going inside the Grand Palace, you will be guided to this temple next. There are information guides in different languages that one can get for free when entering the temple.

It was good..... So, it's really really beautiful, amazingly beautiful. But I found expensive and so so so full of people.... You can't take pictures inside and, I don't know if it was because was so hot, the clothes you have to put was making me really annoyed. If you have to choose a temple I would definitely choose the reclining Buddha and leave this one only if I had time.

It's inside the Grand Palace!. 1)Trip Advisor, stop showing this item as a separate place to visit! It's one of the items inside the Grand Palace.2) Emerald Buddha: very beautiful and worth to see ; can't take photos3) Visit all 3 places in 1 day: A/Grand Palace (incl. Emerald Buddha) + B/Reclining Buddha + C/Temple of Dawn ~ because they're near each other geographically. But need to start out early because of traffic, time to que, and early closing hours. Grand Palace closes at 3:30 pm and should spend the most time there among the 3 places. The other 2 places close at 6:30 pm.By geography, you should visit B, then A, then C.However, by closing time, you should do A, B, C or A,C,B. But you will have difficulty with transportation because traveling by boat or by car is restricted to one-way traffic. Also, these 3 places are in a triangular location on the map so any sequence / route planning is difficult in itself.4) beware of dishonest taxi and tuk tuk drivers. Taxi might not be willing to use meter. Need to negotiate fixed amount. Consider walking to avoid the hassle.5) Bring lots of water.6) beware of dress code. If you don't want to rent clothes, can buy new ones from street vendors nearby 7) buy tickets from official box office, not street vendors8) if take boat, there's tourist boat (40 baht per pax) and normal boat (14 baht per pax). Both offer similar service. Don't get tricked to take private boat, can cost up to 1500 baht per boat
Emerald Buddha. If you are visiting the Grand Palace, you should not miss this Temple. A must visit while you are here in Bangkok.
Enjoyful. the site is interesting with beautiful surrounding temples. Everyone should wear pant covering your legs. Very peaceful. When our visit the day was hot but still nice experience

A must visit. This is a must visit place to see the religious significance plus the grandeur of the place. It is decorated with precious stones hence the name unfortunately no photos are allowed. You can combine this with the palace visit and a tip, try to come in the morning due to the crowd. Security is tight but that's to be expected.

sight seeing. Emerald Buddha is in the Grand Palace and there are number of statues which represent characters in Indian Mythology. For example Hanuman, Ravan, Apsaras, Bhima etc. On the walls are lot of drawings depicting events from Ramayana
mesmerising emerald buddha. was completely mesmerized by the stunning grand palace n the emerald buddha. i would suggest anyone travelling to bangkok to visit this awesome sight
awesome. Beautiful culture in all its splendor. A bit far out of the city but worth the ride and great insight.
Not very impressed. The Emerald Buddha was so small after seeing the Golden Buddha we were not very impressed. Would not recommend this but is part of the temple tour.
Amazing Experience. Held in high faith there is a sense of peace you feel once you step into the temple despite all the crowd. The Architecture is just exquisite.Very well maintained.
Nice. The complex is very beautiful, a lot to see. Entrance fee is not too high. I would recommend it as a tourist mustsee.
Wat Phra Kaew. This temple is very huge it takes around 1 and half hour to complete the same. Need to reach by boat ride for the same which will cost you around 20 bhat.
Must Visit for 1st Time Visitors. This place is located next to Grand Palace and I would recommend this place to any first time visitor

small but hihly valued. It is housed within the Grand Palace grounds.
A one way system is in operation for tourists, it works so be patient, no photography allowed.
A small effigy but held in high regard - another must see.

Good to See. The Emerald Buddha is located within a short distance from the Grand Palace. It is worth seeing when there. Unfortunately no photos are allowed to be taken and shoes must be taken off. You also must be dressed appropriately, no tank tops and short shorts. It is worth a visit!

Average place to visit. 24 carat Gold plated temple.The emerald buddha statue is just too small to feel the real worth, but its worth seeing once. We felt peace inside the temple where the statue is kept.This place is too too crowded. Be aware accordingly. You have to walk a lot and dont forget to take umbrella and hat. You dont enter the grand place area. Only museum is there which is of old swords and all, which is so common for indians.The ticket 500 baht, way too pricey.

Crowd always. The temple is very crowded and always a big line to get in, you erally have much time to see the Buddha. The Budha stays on top very far and you can not even see it properly. But anyway, you can not go to Bkk and dont go to this temple.
The Beauty is in the details.. The statue of Emerald Buddha is quite small. Always take a guided tour and look for the artistic walls around the temple.

Our favorite temple so far. This temple is our favorite one we've seen so far on our trip to Bangkok. The 500 baht ticket gets you into the temple and the grounds of the Grand Palace. Be aware that visiting hours ends at 3:30pm.
If you only have time to go to one temple this one is it!

Gold overload!. Amazing temples covered with 24k Gold! Shining shimmering splendid indeed! Everything you see around are made of pure gold. You have to remove your shoes, hats and clothes should be covered before entering the temples. Respect is a must, no capturing of pictures when inside the temple.
Worth a visit. Another temple of the same kind. Worth a visit . Crowded and people traffic not managed well. There isn`t any info
Stunning. The emerald buddha is a must to see at the Grand Palace. It was much smaller than I though but worth visiting

one that stands out above the others. this is an amazing temple and included with the palace makes for a full day set in beautiful grounds really looks wonderful on a sunny day well worth the entrance fee although entrance is free for Thai

Beautiful temple, many tourists. This temple is really beautiful. I love visiting temples as I am a Buddhist believer but as many other well known temples in Bangkok it's many days overly crowded during peak tourist season. Tip as always is to get there early. As soon as the doors open. The light will also be much more flattering for any photos and you will not suffer the heat as much. Please wear respectful clothing inside the temples and speak quietly. Covered knees and elbows are custom for both men and women. Preferably long sleeves and pants or skirt /sarong but as long as you wear shorts covering knees, a t-shirt will do as long as you wear a scarf over your upper body. Also do not sit in front of a statue or monk with the palms of the feet facing them. It's considered an insult and poor manors. Otherwise feel free to walk around. Talk to the monks. They like to talk! Remember though Always greet them with palms together as in prayer with the thumbs in front of your nose and make a slight bow. Then talk away and ask any question! :-)
amazing temple. It´s a must to do in thailand. You need time to do it, it´s big. so colorful, plenty of peolple.you must respect all the sings. I´ll do it again.
Magnificent!. Worth a visit. Posh architectures, beautiful sculptures and Emerald Buddha is a sight to behold. Must go if you are in Bangkok.

Beautiful (yes, it's crowded). You definitely need to go here, even if it's extremely crowded. It's just gorgeous and a Bangkok must. It's a big complex, and you must buy the 500 baht entry that includes both the palace and the temple. So, you might as well check both out. Some important details:-Wear clothing that covers your shoulders AND goes well past your knees. Skip the leggings even if they cover your knees, I saw the staff tell 2 ladies in leggings to cover up. Cover ups are free of charge, not sure what this extra charge other people mentioned was about??-before you dive into the center to see the temple areas, take a walk on the edge of the entire perimeter (where the paintings are along a walk on your left hand side). There are some beautifully detailed paintings worth seeing here, plus less people up there. ha! -It was really hard to take photos of the beautiful architecture when there were hundreds of people trying to take the perfect selfie (I think some people actually dressed up in gold to match the temples for better selfies!!) in every nook and cranny of the area. Really, the selfie thing is out of control in general. Do we go to these historic sights REALLY just to post photos of ourselves on FB? This makes me feel disheartened. (sorry, I digress).-LOVE LOVE LOVE that they are not really selling anything (minus some juice and water)! Hooray, a place that keeps it really about paying respect to the Buddha. What a concept! I am sincere when I say this. It's very nice.

See it when you go to Grand Palace!. You must go see this since you will already be at the Grand Palace! I have to say I thought the statue was much larger, but it is not. Nevertheless it was still beautiful and worth the effort to see it.

Amazing but PACKED. I hate to give this an average review. While simply amazing, the place is thronged just as heavily as the Colosseum and Chateaux Versailles, which never makes for an enjoyable experience.Pro tip: Take some time to sit down in front of the buddha and regain your energy and sanity while other tourists file in and out around you. You can't be forced to move if you're praying ;)
Dont miss this when you are in bangkok. Temples are a must visit when you are in bangkok. The details and historical of the temples going to vow you.
Really beautiful, but very crowded with tourist. a must visit in Bangkok, but very crowded even I visited on a Friday afternoon. entry to the palace is 500 Bhats and 200 more for audio guide.
Amazing and Serene. A must visit to feel the serenity of the place and the presence. Architecture is typical very well maintained and looked after.

Impressive palace, tiny Emerald Buddha. I have never been to the Louvre, but everyone I know that has visited always mentions how surprised they were about the size of the Mona Lisa: It's much smaller than the hype would have you believe. This is how I felt about the Emerald Buddha. Don't get me wrong: it is really beautiful and the building that houses the statue is impressive, but the statue itself is minuscule compared to its reputation. And you're not allowed to take photos inside this particular temple. That is not to say that it isn't worth a visit. The various buildings in the temple complex are works of art and it's a great place to learn more about the Buddhist faith if you're interested.
A must see. Not a place to miss, do go during the week and early in the morning. Do not wear shorts and sleevless and wear shoes you take of easy. It is an amazing temple.
Fully detailed.. It's beautiful, full of details. One of the best temples I ever visited. The down side is that pictures are not allowed inside.

the Buddha is smaller than expected. I love the gaudiness of Thai temples and went to all the main ones on my visit. However the Emerald Buddha is perched right on the top of a large structure and is much smaller and less impressive that I had expected.
Can't miss when in Bangkok :). It is part of the old part of the Royal Palace where you will see so many temples. Great historic site. I enjoyed learning about Buddhism from the tour guide

too many people. unfortunately tourism is such that everywhere is just overcrowded.the place in undoubtedly beautiful, but the shear number of tourists made it unenjoyable. make sureyou have trousers on,shorts not accepted and just more hassle to queue for the loaned items. 200bhat deposit required and no change give - so make sure you have exact.
AMAZING. This place is simply outstanding. I really think I could spend a day there examining all the architectures and sculptures, observing the constant maintenance paint work going on.
Wonderful. Enjoyed this temple most of all. I can't describe the beauty so you better go and see it on your own. But be fully dressed.
Good. Pretty good, not the same as all the other temples but is pretty much what it says on the label. Take water
Well . Personally disappointed by this temple compare to others not just for cost (which is high) but for atmosphere and the surrounding grounds ! Overall overpriced but worth ticking off the list !

Peaceful and beautiful. Loved this temple, been here twice already. The emerald Buddha is beautiful and very peaceful to be around. Also, visit the Thai Royal Museum just next to the temple. The astounding Thai history can be witnessed.

Such a beauty & a must see when in Thailand . I was in awe when I went to go visit this temple. It holds such beauty & it's such a historic moment to go look at. This temple is adorned with lots of precious stones & gold. The bad thing is that you can't take pictures of the inside of the temple but you are allowed to take pics outside of it. Because if you try to be defiant if the guards catch you doing so they will confiscate your phone/device as I saw this happen to several visitors. Also make sure that you are appropriately dressed if you want to go inside of the temple, they follow strict Buddhist guidelines. So no shorts, tank tops, or skimpy revealing clothing; you won't be allowed in. Also they will ask you to remove your shoes before entering so make sure your feet are clean & well looking haha... One recommendation is that since this is a temple make sure that once you are inside that you are on your best behavior (especially kids), try not to talk & definitely do not be loud. Lots of tourists go in there thinking that it's just another building but do remember that it is a temple & there are monks & others in there worshipping their god. But overall you'll be so impressed on how beautiful this temple is & how clean & elaborate it is. This is definitely a must see when visiting Thailand.
Unique. Worth the wait to get in. The emerald Buddha is a unique item to see. No pictures and no shoes. It's a single room so the visit is quick.
This place is a must. Just do it. Keep in mind of all the traditions. Take shoes off before entering and make sure you had a t-shirt not a wrap. You will be pulled up.
Great!!. Great!! one of the most beautiful temples in ThailandDon't forget to wear the proper clothes. Short plants and Dresses are not allowed.
Expensive. Tourist need to pay 500 Bahts to visit.It's a very big complex but you can't really enter any buildings (at the exception of the temple hosting the Buddha).The Buddha is also really small.
Top attraction . If you in Bangkok you must make a visit here. If you can go with a tour guide you will learn so much

Busy but worth it. When I went here it was so full of tourists... however it was worth battling the crowds. Don't forget this is a place of worship so respectable clothing is a must... long skirt/pants and long sleeve top to cover shoulders. Do make the time to wander around the whole complex and not just to the Emerald Buddha.

Awesome temple. The temple and the architecture around was so colourful and well maintained. It was worth each penny you spent. The place was overcrowded though which spoils the peace and serenity of the place.
Beautiful, must see. This temple was beautiful. Lots of wonderful architecture and art, and a great way to spend a few hours and get some nice pictures.

Last visited aug 2016. I went this time one on now with one of the old guides at the temple. Paid a little and got a lot in return. Fantastic way to do this did not have to wait for queues anywhere amazing. He found all the best spots for pictures.This temple has so much culture and architecture also colour outstanding.Be carful outside always pay inside for tour this way you will miss all queues and I promise there are a lot of Chinese tourists there.Please remember how hot and humid it gets there and always wear long trousers or you will not be aloud in.

Must visit when you in Bangkok. Beautiful temple with a lot of art details. You can visit this temple along with Grand Palace because of the location basically inside the Grand Palace complex. Ticket at the entrance including the temple is 500TBH. The line was not very long, the visit can be short or long if you on your own and not coming with a tour group. There are map inside for self guided tour. It just beautiful and lots of art detail that you just have to come and see it yourself. No pictures allow inside the Emerald Buddha temple.
Very pretty. This is a marvellous and beautiful temple. Photos were not allowed.Shoes are not allowed as you one would expect to be the case.

Breathtaking!. This is a must see sight! Make sure you have enough memory and battery power on your camera as every glistening inch is worth capturing. Do make sure you dress respectfully as this is a place of worship.

Smaller than you might think - harder to see. This was my least favorite Wat - hard to see the Buddha. Still worth the trip.I did a day tour and stopped to see many of the Wat's in Bangkok on a Saturday. The grounds are very pretty and the craftsmanship is incredible, It is fascinating to see these temples and Buddhas - make sure to dress appropriately. You are outside and it is hot and humid. You will sweat - a lot in August.

Beautiful, but prepare yourself!. We should definitely preface this by saying that we visited on a very hot and humid day, and as Canadians, we are not built for that kind of weather.We arrived around my midday and passed a security guard who was pointing out people who needed to cover up more. Since she didn't point out either my partner nor I, we joined the long line for security. There were a lot of people, many pushing, and most of the time we were in the scorching sun. Then we walked to buy our tickets (which was 500 bahts a person) and then tried to enter the temple.That's when a security guard pointed to my fiance's shorts, which covered his knees. "Not allowed!" So we had to go back to the front and line up to put down a fully refundable deposit for a pair of pants. This line up took about 15 minutes. As an aside, as a woman I had read that we are supposed to cover up shoulders and knees, which I did. The security guard never pointed me out, but when we went to borrow the pants, the people behind the desk said I should probably borrow something too. My pants are a capris-length and go lower than the skirts the staff women were wearing, so the temple would prefer women to wear over the knee skirts (or full pants).So... by the time we actually entered the temple, we had been in the sun for around 45 min. The temple grounds are very beautiful but expect a lot of people taking a lot of pictures holding a lot of umbrellas. Also, be prepared to take off your shoes and given the hot day, unfortunately a lot of temples smelled like feet. Apparently this temple is an important place for practising Buddhists and while the grounds were a sight that we don't regret seeing, we found that the Wat Pho suited our interests more.So overall, it's a beautiful temple but expect a lot of people and strict rules.
The most expensive ticket. One person 500 baht just to entering the the grand palace. Full of tourist and free tourguide provided.

Beautiful. This beautiful statue is a very busy tourist attraction in the Royal Palace grounds in Bangkok. Very many tourists so you don't get a long look at this if you're a tourist. Make sure you wear appropriate clothing - shoulders and full legs must be covered at this temple, and it's strictly enforced.

Drop by the Temple when you visit the Grand Palace. The entrance ticket to the Grand Palace would include the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. The temple grounds have lots of gold elements just like the Grand Palace.

This is a do not miss . The most amazing sight in Bangkok !! The Buddha is not made from emerald but from Jade and we learned so much from our guide Nina from YTG Tours. I would definitely recommend a private tour for the temples (Wats) and for a great full day of sightseeing

Impressive tourist attraction. Although it's very impressive and beautiful the amount of tourist does downgrade the experience a little bit. And especially the amount of umbrellas that are almost sticking your eyes out can be very annoying. It feels like you are part of a major photo shoot session.That having said I have to admit that we did enjoy our visit, because the level of beauty of this temple is extremely high.

So Beautiful!. We feel like we could write the sames riviews on all temples we visited. hahaha, this one is one of the most beautiful next to the Grand Palace, all the little details and painting, just stunning. It gets very crowded, but who cares, enjoy the moment and the peace you feel when next to padogas and buddhas.

Exquisite Emerald Buddha. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is beautiful and the statue exquisite and carved from a single block of jade. Housed in an ordination room and raised on a platform, it can only be viewed from a distance. No photography allowed and appropriate dressing is required.
Lovel place. Used a tour guide and glad I did as there was a lot to learn about the contributions from each king and how their own interests changed the look of the temples

Amazing!!. One of the most beautiful things that i have seen around the world. Have been going to Thailand for over 20 years but never got an opportunity to visit this Holy temple, I was astonished by the beauty of the entire place and the way the entire place which has so many visitors is managed, hats off to the management . A must visit for all tourist to Bangkok.

Amazing details, blinding gold. This is one of the major temples what you must visit is you are in Bangkok. The emerald Buddha is inside of a seperate building on the top of the altar. You can't really go close to it but you can still see cllearly. As all the other temples, you have to dress properly (shoulders and knees covered) but in case you are not dressed like this you can rent pants or skirt at the location but the line is usually quite long so try to dress into your own clothes (maybe this is the only good use of the baggy elephant print pants). The area of the temple is quite big with lots of overdecorated sparkly buildings. The details are truly impressive. It's easy to get overwhelmed by all the details and sparkly decorations so take it easy and take a break if you can't take more or don't spend too much time with one building. You will still probably end up taking hundreds of photos. The way to the exit is quite tricky but just follow the singns for 5-10 minutes and you will be out while seeing even more temple buildings. The dress code is the most stricked here and this is also one of the most expensive temples. I am not sure but I think around 400 baht, but it worth it.
Nice goodness temple . Hello we are visiting every monthly watpho temple very nice and goodness my family are happy thanks we recommend kindly.

Beautiful temple on the crowded grounds of the Grand Palace. The temple is known for the Emerald Buddha, which is actually not very big. The Emerald Buddha is placed very high up inside the temple and is difficult to really see. The temple is beautiful with intricate detail and is located on the Grand Palace grounds which is packed with buildings and throngs of people (tourists and locals). There are small garden planters around the temple which are really very well done. As in all temples, you must take off your shoes and dress appropriately.

Just breath taking! Hire a guide. . We loved this place. Initially we were in the wrong clothes do had to wait in a LONG queue to hire some trousers - be sure to take your own to avoid the q. Just before we entered a guide came up to us and asked if we needed a guide. It was £10 for over an hour and was well worth it. He was very knowledgeable and made sure we didn't miss anything. Very interesting and beautiful place.
Visit in the morning hours. Worth to visit, but children might get tired if caught up in the mid day. Keep a water bottle and umbrella
buddhist Asia. If you are first time in Bangkok and haven't a lot time to visit all buddhist temples - come here and see all the best - the Emerald Buddha. Grand Palace is located near Wat Phra Kaew,

Beautifull but WAY to overcrowded.. beautifull temple (really worthwhile) but far to many visitors, especially large groups of tourists/locusts. Crowd control is highly unfriendly with a megaphone and loud whitsles IN the temple. They should sell a limited number of tickets, with a timeslot and reduce the number of tourist groups. For 500 bath per ticket, it feels like a Thai themed funpark, with the inevitable tourist traps/taxi's outside. Such a shame.

Part of the tour with the Palace. Included with the Palace tour you'll be amazed at the workmanship and wonder at the time it took to build these buildings that house the Buddah's. This buddah was found in 1434 in Chiang Rai - covered in plaster to disguise the stone underneath which is in fact Jade, not emerald. Long history ….

very busy. very busy palace,long walking involved but well worth the visit,try to get there early and if not on a tour just ignore everyone and walk through gates and buy ticket as alot of scam taxis and tuk tuk around there.
stunning. Absolutely stunning temple- very busy and so hot to walk around. A lot to take it but got some great photos. one of the best things we saw in Bangkok!
Beautiful and so much intricate detail!. Loved this place. The amount of detail is insane. So much to take in but not enough time with everything else to see.
Visit this as one of main attractions. Would seem strange to visit Bangkok and not this site. A beautiful Buddha which is surprisingly green!

Emerald Buddha visit. Make sure you have enough time for a visit, the Grand Palace gets really busy. It is a big property, lots of walking, lots of people moving in all directions. Make sure you are dressed correctly. Long trousers, and shirts with (short) sleeves are allowed. A scarf wrapped around your shoulders does not count (for foreigners only it seems though). If not dressed correctly you have to go all the way back to the entrance to borrow an item to wear.

Crazy but fantastic. This is a MUST see when visiting Bangkok!!! Allow yourself enough time to get in as there are lots of tourist groups. You feel a bit like you are in a sardine can to get to the Emerald Buddha but its hard not to be moved when you see him and his temple. The rest of the Grand Palace is beautiful and there is so much detail to take in. Well worth the fee you have to pay to get in!

Crowded and tiny. The place was soo crowded. Felt like a market. Too many chinese people. Small emerald buddha in top of a pillar. Has gold clothing and jewellery. Again a one time see and out of there.

Wat Phra Kaew. Wat Phra Kaew is the main temple in Thailand - therefore, it should be visited. The temple building shines in the sunlight, which can be dazzling on the human eye. There is a valuable emerald Buddha statue inside - the most sacred in Thailand. Surrounding the temple are murals that tell the story of the Ramakien, which is the Thai version of the Ramayana. It might be worth hiring a guide to explain the story, or you could read about it before you go. Understanding the Ramakien will give you a much better understanding of Thai art and culture.

More Emeralds than you have ever seen. A trip to Bangkok is synonymous with multiple visits to Temples and the fact that they are located within the same area makes it extremely easy to be immersed in this rich cultural experience
Bucket List Item. This is a must see, must do, must go while in SE Asia. The water taxi makes it accessible,BE cautious of pick pockets and thieves!!!!

Gold Gold Gold. Probably the most exquisite place I've ever seen all in gold, thing is to be respectful you have to queue up to wear a long sarong to cover parts of your body for the girls and for the guys you have to wear a long trousers in the heat. There are a lot of photo opportunities here, make sure you wear slip on shoes because when you enter certain temples within the palace you will have to take off your shoes and leave it outside in public.

cool but too crowded. very cool but go it in off hours, late in the day. also be careful of the scamers saying it's closed. remember to bring your coverups. way to may tourists with umbrellas that will poke your eyes out early,

Dress appropriately for this crowded venue. We hired a tour guide for 300 Bhat, definitely worth it because she guided us around crowds, ushered us into the shade, and told us the history of this area. I wore a long skirt (came to mid-calf) and a short-sleeved T shirt and sandals. That was fine. There were definitely folks stopped for their clothing.Seeing Buddhas isn't my thing, so while I'm sure this is necessary to learn what Thailand is about, not my favorite.

So beautiful & felt like a real place of worship. So many of the temples are almost like tourist attractions with so many, many visitors. This was the one that seemed most like an active shrine with worshippers having the opportunity to have their moment without the crowds pressing in.
Hire a guide!. You will be absolutely clueless on how to navigate around if you don't have a guide here. But definitely worth the visit!

Emeral Buddha. Located inside the Grand Palace, the temple is magnificent inside, unfortunately your not allowed to take a photo. You need to leave your shoes outside and avoid making a noise. You only need to spend a few minutes because the place goes too crowded.

Crowded. I visited Bangkok often and been here many times.It always crowded and pack with tourist and local.A good place to worship but some privacy and local cultures need to be respected.Dont talk loudly and no mini skirts. Dont use your selfie stick and grab all the attentions. Respect the culture even when taking a picture. Give those who are sincere in worshiping a chance. You will definitely have your chance to take picture.

Most revered site with a lot of history. If you are a history buff, this place has plenty to offer. It is also the most revered Buddhist site in all of Thailand. This temple lies within the Grand Palace complex. Full length pants and covered shoulders are a must for every visitor. There is no photography allowed inside the main temple.

Stunning!!!. Even it's a hot day, the beautiful of temple is very attractive. Moreover, it's a MUST place for tourist to visit. I recommend to visit it in the early morning or at night. You will get a different stunning view of the temple at night!
Worth a visit. We spent whole day here and Grande Palace, the Buddha surrounding were stunning in gold, nice architecture. It was crowded, hot but should visitYou should prepare umbrella, cold water.
Small but scintillating!. Well worth a visit of you are in Bangkok. The actual statue is very small but located in a spectacular temple in the grounds of the Grand Palace.
Artistic. Beautiful , picturesque. Colorful. Needs detail visit to adore intrinsic work. Each work is unique. Can take the help of guide if interested. 1-2 hours needed.

This is the best part of grand palace visit. Grand palace has Emerald budda inside. Same ticket for Grand palace works. First of all , it ia amazing to see and must visit.. you cannot take photos.. very peaceful. Budda temple has Ramayana drawn on walls. I would highly encourage you guys to see that. Ticket prixe 500 Bhat that includes grand palace , emerlad budda and museum of queen jwelery. Every one must wear pant ( covering legs ) and tops qith covering shoulders.. no sleeve less. Incase you forgot to wear pants, you can get it for free with a deposit 200 bhats. Will be a bit crowded since this is top attraction.
Stunning. We had a great day, really enjoyed this and the other surrounding attractions. It was busy and hot, but worth the effort.

Disappointing. As a non Buddist I found this site very disappointing. The surrounding temples are really beautiful but the emerald buddah itself disappointing. If short for time in Bangkok skip this and see the reclining Buddah

So much gold. Only accessible as part of the grand palace. You need to remove your shoes to enter and no pictures are allowed inside. Most people do a quick circuit and exit, however, if you want to spend more time move towards the alter and you can sit on the floor.

Amazing. This is a NOT TO MISS in Bangkok. You would remain breathless admiring the colours of this place.It's a tough place in sunny and crowdy days.They will ask anyone to wear trousers/skirts below the knees (including children), and a tshirt. They will borrow long trousers or shirts free (200 Bat deposit required), but consider that hygienic standards are not at all taken into account... so, of you can, come prepared with your cloths.Ticket is 500Bat cash, no credit cards accepted.Better to come early in the morning using the public boat (40 Bat per person): it's cheap and fun.
Awesome. awesome experience in Bangkok. This temple is fabulous. That s my first temple in asia and when i saw him i was very happy.So many people in this temple.

Lights, Camera, Action!. Great photo opportunity. Forget the postcards, make your own and capture memories in person. Live the moment and capture it with locals, tourists, and the wonderful surroundings.,

Beautiful temple. This temple can be found within the Grand palace grounds. Like many reviews, it is mentioned that there are a LOT of visitors and tourists. Especially coming into the main entrance, so many tour groups and it is so hard to get pictures with many people crowding and jostling. As advised, we arrived early, but alas, everyone had the same idea and we were swept along the tide of people. There is almost no shade, so I would still advise to go early morning so it will be slightly cooler. Might be nice to have a guide if you have a big group of people just so you would have an idea what you are looking at, but mostly it is nice to wander around the structures and marvel at the opulence of this temple. It is a working temple. You cannot take pictures inside the temple where the emerald Buddha is housed, but you go in one door and exit on the other side. As with temples, knees and shoulders need to be covered and shoes are taken off. After a visit to the Buddha, just wander around and enjoy taking pictures. The emerald Buddha is place high up on a pedestal and you cannot really get close to it and appreciate that it is made of emerald. Might be tough with small children but bring plenty of water and bribe with coconut ice cream after.
Nice. This was amazing for us to see, Emerald was just. Looking at me if only I could of taken it home. Maybe next time.

Cultural tour. Excellent temple with gold Buddha. Must see in Bangkok to understand their culture and history. Please be reminded to wear long jean with shoes, no short for men and women, very strict rule!

Rip off all around. It is a national tragedy that such a beautiful site can be ruined by mafia like touts , double pricing and shouting screaming tourists. The TAT allows this !!?? Guess they do. People like me spread the word around and it's no good!
Amazing Thailand. Most beautiful ever I can see before every detail very very fantastic unbelievable that there are on the earth strongly recommend should come attests one time in your life

Excellent. A must visit when in bangkok. The day we went it was very hot and the number of people was immense.
Was tires very soon cos of heat.
Saw the monks come in to say the prayers. It was a good day spend well

The emerald Buddha sculpture is not that impressive.. The decoration of the room that it's in was actually more interesting. And the grounds. But by the time we got there, it was hot, it was crowded with tour groups, we were struggling to enjoy it.

Magical. This temple is very beautiful, and regardless of whether you are spiritual or not you will definitely feel amazed. Remember the dress code! No legs and no shoulders can be exposed. Prepare for this in advance with loose fitting thin clothes, you don't have to be uncovered to keep cool.
A Must see in Bangkok. This temple is a true gem. The temples are beautiful from the outside, so you can imagine how beautiful it is inside.

Grand buddha temple in the palace complex. This is located in the palace complex. Gets very crowded with tourists on a daily basis. Recommend going early. The building and the art and architecture is just magnificent and lovely to see. Cannot take a picture inside the temple. But taking pictures outside is okay.

WOWwwwww. Unbelievable, don't need to imagine abount paradise any more
come here and see paradise by yourselt it beyon to....

A must seen though very crowded. Without a doubt this is a center piece of Bangkok tourist tour. But, it is also a very crowded place - with a very strict rule around dressing which forces you to go borrow some clothes while it is 30+ degree C outside. No issue to respect the local traditions and the Thai have made it very efficient and simple to borrow the clothes, nevertheless this needs to be taken into account in your visit. Unless you bring your own clothes. The visit itself is a bit long with a lot of tourist groups. The architecture is amazing - the context makes it sometimes less enjoyable.
Very nice. Seeing these temples is a must for tourist who should be armed with a camera. I loved the sights for these ancient places.

Absolutely Stunning. The Emerald Temple was absolutely magnificent. No matter what your faith you truly feel in awe of the temple, the monks, the prayers you are surrounded by. We arrived a little late so we only got around 45 minutes, I advise to plan this trip early in the day in order to gain most time possible. Also never go there in short shorts or skirts or anything revealing as the temple is attached to the Grand Palace and there is a strict dress code there. If you do by mistake forget to then no worries, they will provide you with a simple sarong or pants to wear for your visit.
Thailand trip 2015. Beautiful temple, pictures do not do justice to all the beautiful colors. There are many temples in Bangkok but this is one that should not be missed.
Gorgeous . A must see if you are in Thailand. It's beautiful as well as all the Buddha around it its a magical experience, especially for a Buddha lover like myself
Amazing. WOW Amazing unbelievable unbelievable that have something wonderful like this in the word here, very very. Beautiful

The same as everything else. We visited during low season and it was still incredibly busy. The temple is found within the grounds of the Royal Palace and is the resting place of the Emerald Buddha (actually made of jade). Maybe because of the crowds, I was not so impressed with this temple. Don't get me wrong. The temple is magnificent and it is an incredible place to visit. However it doesn't have anything different to the rest of the buildings within the palace groundswhich are all magnificent. Everything together is a marvelous sight to behold, but by itself this temple is nothing special. Definitely worth seeing for the experience but don't expect to be overawed.

Thought it would be more inpressive. I did the incorrect thing by not documenting myself properly before visiting, so obviously after enduring a very intense summer weather and long queues, I couldn't help feeling disappointed when staring at a little and far away placed green Buddha. My visit was merely cultural as I'm not a Buddhist, but to truthfully squeeze sense of out this, I recommend reading a bit about the story behind the monument and Buddhism in general, otherwise, the meaning of the visit will be lost and there are simply much more impressive sites out there.

Amazing. If you have never been - GO!!! I have been to Thailand 6 times now and I always make an extra effort to go.. It is amazing. Try to get there when they open at 8:30 - because it gets seriously busy!

So busy it was hard to appreciate!. I visited mid week in the afternoon and the place was absolutely heaving. I walked around the complex taking pictures and taking it all in. When I got to the emerald Buddha there were masses of people inside, so much so that you couldn't really appreciate the splendor of the place. I was in and out quickly just to avoid the crowds and to rifle through the mounds of cheesy shoes that had been left outside to find my own!

Shuffled through with a seething mass of others. Whilst beautifully decorated this temple unfortunately had none of the serenity that other temples had. We dutifully removed our shoes and joined the queue to go up the steps into the temple. I use the word queue loosely - it was a mass of people jostling to get in - we Brits know how to queue this was not a queue. The good natured mass propelled us into the temple and slowed only momentarily as we went through one door and out of the other. There was a roped off area where one could pray if one wished but it didn't project serene thoughts to me and whilst sumptuously decorated I didn't have any desire to hang around.Overall for the most revered temple in Thailand a disappointment.
Good trip. I must say its a nice place to visit for one time.... you can click some great photos and before going just check with your guide about dress code

Impressive. Not what we were expecting, actaully it was quite smaller than what we thought. Although impressive when you actaully see it, if you dont, you won't miss much. If photos are on you mine then you should visit it when in the Grand Palace.

A must see in Bangkok. You cannot come to Bangkok and not see the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. A fair warning, it's going to be crowded. You'll observe many pushy person stereotypes, however once you get past this, the beauty of the architecture will take over! It's hard to get over just how detailed everything about this place is. The monuments, structures and statues are just mind blowing. A couple of tips, remember you are in a temple so wear respectable clothing. Do not point your feet at the Buddhas! Finally, smile and have fun, the place is amazing!
Excellent . You can see what you not seen before. Amazing construction. You need to go early Morning because it's closed at 3pm. Its amazing and can't believe how could they build it.

Breathtaking. Incredibly impressive, but sadly always crowded. Ten years ago there was room to breathe, now, because of China's newish-found prosperity, it's always over full. The buildings are worth seeing though despite the mass

Great place to visit. I am a girl and I had a long skirt on before going in. I also had a tank top and I had taking a shawl with me to cover myself. The guard didn't like that and made me get on line to rent a proper shirt. Make sure to bring proper clothes with you to change into, otherwise you'll waste 30-40 minutes waiting to rent some clothes.
just beautiful. It is just something you need to see. It is beautiful, it is very thai. Gives you an insight of Thai believes, where it comes from. It is very well maintained.

Ornate and Fascinating. We arrived early to get a jump on the crowds, but It was still bustling. The intricate and ornate details really wow. They were getting ready to change the outfit on the Buddha. Quite interesting.

Emerald Buddha is the center of the show. In the very busy Golden Palace complex, entering the temple of the Emerald Buddha is central to the visit. The Emerald Buddha itself is very small and is actually "dressed" by the king himself at the change of the seasons. It is required to take off shoes and have respectful dress (cover knees and shoulders - if you have not dressed appropriately, you will be required to rent clothes at the entrance of the Golden Palace).

Gorgeous and serene. This temple is exceptionally beautiful. The story of the emerald Buddha is intriguing so get a guid or read up ahead of time. The temple is so crowded, so go early. And the Buddha is quite small so adjust your expectations. Lovely though.

Beautiful. This was part of an organised tour and I wasn't sure how to react when my guide said the Buddha's clothes had been changed from Summer to Winter. However, the temple was beautifully decorated and the Emerald Buddha looked upon us all as we sat before him. Please be respectful and do not show the soles of your feet to him, it is considered very impolite. Certainly recommended as a good experience.

Something you need to see if you're in Thailand. The entire room and temple is quite a site to see, but I also was in awe of how those who follow buddha were in awe of it. An overall interesting experience.

Bangkoks main attraction-very intresting. Take your time here. Before entering there is a small musuem on the left hand side. Here you have a short introduction to Thailands histors - to be recommende. Please take your time to look on all the wall paintings -here much more can be learned about history and culture.

Awesome architecture, but extremely hot and humid sogo early in the morning.. Very interesting and beautiful architecture and can see people lighting jos sticks and praying. Tip - where closed shoes as the health and safety is not up to Western standards.

absoultley stunning. This is a must see. The buildings are so ornate and beautiful. Gold and colored glass are everywhere you look. The emerald Buddha is actually Jade and only a foot tall. It is a bit hard to see with all the gold glittering around him. The place gets crowded so go early and make sure you are wearing long pants and your shoulders are covered.
Beautiful place. Beautiful place to see. But be prepared for the crowds of people. It was very hot, very crowded but still a must see.

Beauty among the crowds. The complex is amazing with much to see.But so crowded. Thousands of tourists all armed with selfie sticks cover each and every square inch....Best to come as early as possible. Dress as required and enjoy the fine art
It is magnificent. You should take the free 30 minutes walk with a guide. It will help you orientate yourself inside the palance and temples.

Beautiful. The Grand Palace and the Temple of the Temple of the Emerald Buddha are one location separated by a wall. It is out of this world. You will finish it in less than 2 hours, but if you plan to get there at opening, you will have the place to your self for 30 minutes. Worth doing to get great pictures.

Hot, humid, must-see stop. Did I mention crowded? Good thing we were first in the gates since this place is a mob scene. Go early and just to save us all the embarrassment, read up on the dress code. This is the holiest spot in the country and you need to be covered and this includes socks you flip floppers. The story of how the Buddah was found and how his outfits were changed was special. Get there early, get in and get out.

Beautiful place. This place is very busy, so be prepared. There are lots to see and loads of photo opportunities. You will need a good tour guide as we find it very informative. Require trousers to get inside the temple. This is definitely a must visit. Apart from the temple, there is also the palace in the gounds which is beautiful. But you need to have time and be patient as it is very busy.

The Emerald Buddha "is" Thailand. If you have not seen the Emerald Buddha, you do not know Thailand. Thai people have always revered this small "emerald" sculpture as the true symbol of Thailand. It is small (smaller than you might imagine), but it is beautiful. I was glad I read about this before my trip to this palace, so I was sure to look for it when I entered the room. Just seeing something that is considered to be the symbol and treasure of an entire country is amazing. It was one of the biggest joys of my trip.

Awesome place. Emerald Buddha is a must see for those visiting the Grand Palace Complex, for this temple is located inside the palace complex. But long pants/dresses are required to enter the palace-cum-temple complex. Scarves or dress covering the upper body and shoulders for ladies are also required. No photography is allowed inside the temple of Emerald Buddha, and it is an active place of worship.

#1 Must Visit Temple in Bangkok. This is the Grand Daddy of them all. If you only have time to see one temple (although Wat Po - Reclining Buddha is next door and you should see both) this is The One. It is the most iconic temple in Bangkok. It is where only Royals used to be allowed to worship. It was basically the King's private temple in the old days. A lot of history here. Admission fee includes a free audio guide. And also you can see the Royal Palace on the same premise. Very unique building that combines Western and Thai design. Worth the visit....

Historical . Advise to visit early in the morning to have a more quiet & slowly study all the details of this beautiful temple. I particular liked the walk thru the big field on the way to the temple. It's worth a visit.

Busy but worth the visit. . Situated within the Grand Palace grounds this temple is well worth the visit. It's busy! Fantastic murals and incredible attention to detail. No photography within the temple. Remember to check the dress code policy although appropriate clothing is available to rent on-site.
near to grand place. it is one time watch place and they charge 100 Bhat per person as entrance fees and closes at 6 PM and check for holidays and cheaters before your visit.

Beyond Amazed. The intricate details of the place was really amazing. You might wonder how they did that. Though it was very crowded it is understandable since it's Bangkok's must see sites. It was worth every cent that I paid. I hope they can maintain the place for generations to come.

Stunning temple . The Emerald Buddha is much smaller than you would anticipate but the history of how it was rediscovered is interesting, it is within a stunning temple but we visit d when quite busy so you could not really stay inside to look for long.

Brilliant. The Grand Palace and Temple of Emerald Buddha remain in the same huge compound and is a symbol of brilliant Bodhic architecture. The cost of entrance is around THB 1000 per adult and if you need a guided tour with voice recorder pay THB200, if you are group of 3 or more there is a guide service at THB 600 who would take you around the complex. Please also note if you are closer to Temple of Emerald Buddha the Tourism authority also have free guided tour for a minimum number of people where you could become a part, this tour is more limited to Emerald Buddha temple and they guide you around the vicinity. Overall a great experience. On a hot humid day you can struggle and keep water at disposal , water is available at outlets at twice the cost.Don't miss this as it is the one main attraction when in Bangkok.
Unique. A tantalizing experience and rare to see the Emeral Buddha. I'm not a Buddhist but the beauty of these temples is worth seeing.
A must see. A must see. What an awesome sight of the Emerald Buddah carved into tall block of Jade. Perhaps the most visited and famous temple in Bangkok.
Stunning - shame about the crowds. . Go early to avoid the crowds. And cover up shoulders and knees. Stunning temple. The best in the grand palace.
Fascinating. Honestly, it was really amazing see all the various temples around the city. It was interesting because they are similar yet each is unique.

Beautiful. MUST SEE !! This is should be one of your list when you travelling to Bangkok.Dresses polite when you visit here if not you can rent for free from inside temple. also you have to pay 600 baht for ticket but if your are Thais its free for you.

Nice, but WAAAAY too Crowded. Amazing, as all of the temples are. But it is stiflingly crowded and stuffy, and I was there during the low season, non-holiday. It's worth going but tough to stay long at all.

Breathtaking. Not only was the temple and other structures beautiful, the respect that the local worshipers had for their religion was inspiring. The murals on the walls tell stories without words, they were one of my favorite parts. The buildings themselves look as if they belong in the heavens. The overly-ornate style and detail awe-inspiring. The Emerald Buddha is right next to the grand palace and the ticket you buy will gain you admittance to both. Normal tickets are 500 baht per adult, a little less than $15 USD. It is definitely worth it. The area is very large and there is a lot to see! You will need a couple of hours to make it though everything. Make sure you have some water and use the restroom before you enter, as toilets become scarce. Remember to be respectful. You may not enter if you are not dressed properly. No exposed shoulders and no shorts. Wear shoes not flip-flops. There is a rental shop right outside where you can rent a wrap to cover up if you need to. Overall it was an amazing sight and an interesting look into the culture and beliefs in Thailand.

Beautiful temple . Visited here on my first trip to Bangkok. Really beautiful and peaceful place to spend some time. 500 Bat for entry to the palace and emerald Buddha. Expensive to buy food and drinks in but this is not surprising

Significant site in BKK. Part of the Grand Palace complex, a significant part of Thai history and heritage. Impressive buildings, statues and culture. Wear clothing that covers the legs, otherwise you will be delayed with the process of booking out some long pants with a deposit. Easy to remove footwear would be also wise on the day.The day I visited the area was very packed with tourists, including large tour groups. There was a lot of pushing and shoving in tight areas getting access to the temple. Noisy and less peaceful than I remember from previous visit some years ago. Crowd control was needed to view the Emerald Buddha.Although somewhat uncomfortable at times this is a major site to see in Bangkok and worth the hassle if you can manage it. Perhaps ask around what are the best times to visit crowd wise.

The place is huge!!. I went to visit this temple with my friends. Being a Thai girl, I got in for free but had to pay 10 baht to get in to the museum. But one of my friends who is a foreigner had to pay 500 baht to get in. It was so unfair. The ticket covered everything such as the museum etc. We came early in the morning because it closes at 15:30. However the palace was still packed with groups of Chinese tourists. Couldn't see much of anything because too many people blocking the view.

tourist attraction. This was one of the must-see attractions on TripAdvisor, but honestly we found it too crowded. The temples and structures in the main compound are really beautiful but it was packed with people and it was very, very hot when we visited during July. Also, my boyfriend was wearing shorts, so we were not allowed in until he had rented pants. There's a long line to do this, and once you get in, it is exact change, 200 baht, only. We didn't have exact change so had to go find a store that would accept larger bills as payment to get change. Then we had to wait in line all over again. This took away from our enjoyment of the attraction a bit because we were over the crowds and heat before we even started. I wish we had gone to one of the lesser known temples instead.

Beautiful. This was a beautiful site. Amazed at the intricate mosaics covering the statues and structures as well as hand painted tiles. I missed the last English speaking tour at 2pm. It was very crowded and I was fearing I'd get an eye poked out with a selfie stick.

Must see. So much grandeur!!. You cannot come to bkk and not visit the buddha.Buy a ticket at the grand palais for 500 baht because the emerald buddha is in the grand palais complex.Be prepared to get hot and to fight the crowds and bring a water bottle that you can refill for free on the grounds.Get dressed appropriately with covered shoulders and covered legs (pants must be loose so no leggings and no ripped jeans). Otherwise you can borrow clothes at the entrance with a refundable 200 baht deposit.Marvel at all the amazing gold, exquisite details and grandeur... There is so much to look at its overwhelming So many ohotos to take!
Interesting . ss most wats itvis very Decorated. The workmanship and dedication is amazing. You really not just see the sern. But whatn is unseen. And how much detail there is.
