Still busy!. This was part of our Grand Palace tour and therefore super busy, suggest a quieter time of year for best viewing.
Must see . We visited the emerald Buddha, the Buddha was in the rain season costume, it was great to see the traditional Thai architecture & culture!

Extraordinarily Magnificent Temple. . 'Why didn't I come here before?' that's a question I kept asking myself when I first came here. Even though I am Thai, I didn't want to come here since I love travelling aboard. But now everything has changed. The temple filled with gorgeous Thai-style architecture makes me forget everything outside this place. The place surprisingly brightens itself and gently captures your two eyes.While I was walking back to a bus stop, I thought 'A magnificent place can be found under my nose, all I need to do is just turning around and look what stand beside you'

Beautiful. What an amazing place. Worth the trip for sure my only compliant are the tourist that are noisy and talk in such an important space for Thai culture. Go earlier in the day to avoid huge crowds

Thailand's most venerated Buddha image.. Once inside there is no photography allowed and you must have removed your shoes. No matter what your faith, just be silent and respectful and do not point your feet in the direction of the image. We were told that the statue is made of jasper and not really emerald and it is also very small and up high.

Very impressive. This is probably the highlight of the Grand Palace. It does get very busy with tourists but this is a small price to pay for such a stunning statue. You have to dress appropriately or queue for a gown to cover up with.
Beautiful temple and emerald buddha statue. This is one of the must see temples in Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha must be seen when visiting the city.

Worth it, but prepare for tourists.. My timing was poor as I went on a Sunday afternoon. It was just a SEA OF PEOPLE. The place is so massive you wouldn't think it would be that crowded but it was. It felt like Black Friday just trying to get into this place. Not to mention it was hot. Wasn't sure what to expect so but you definitely need a whole afternoon if not a day to visit this place as its packed full of history, museums, and buildings to see. Wish I went on a weekday and in the early morning to avoid the heat and crowds. Also be warned you must be appropriately dressed including guys! But if you forget they do have clothes for you to borrow.

It's getting really really crowded, taking away from its beauty and aura. I realize that this is a holy site for Thais, so this may be blasphemous, and I apologize for that. And the site itself is beautiful, and in the past (I've been visiting for 12+ years) there has been a sense of holiness and peace there. However, in recent years, it's been completely overrun by tourists. It's already hot, but when you're surrounded by thousands of tourists almost shoulder to shoulder all trying to take selfies, it's unbearable. Forget trying to see the Emerald Buddha; Wat Phra Kaew is so crowded that you can't even fit in. And so many of the tourists seem to have so little regard to the fact that this is a very holy site; they treat it like it's Disneyland, and it really pains me to see this. I hope that the Thai authorities do something to limit the number of visitors so that everyone can enjoy the breathtaking beauty and aura of the Temple.
Nice to See. I was glad to visit this temple once, probably would not return. It is very hot and very crowded. The emerald Buddha is very beautiful. Remember to cover your shoulders and knees.

Worth seeing, very busy! . This temple is massive and costs more than others at 300baht each. We arrived at 1pm and it was super busy. You must be wearing long trousers with shoulders covered just to enter the grounds, you can borrow something to cover you up but the queue for this was ridiculous! Impressive temples and tiny solid jade Buddha!

Very Impressive. As you can imagine this is a very popular place to visit. You cannot take pictures of the Buddha inside the temple. The story of the different coloured coat depending on the time of the year is fascinating. Many people miss this.

The most important Temple for Thais, Visitors Must go. The Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew) is the most important for Thai people. In the past it was not this crowded! But now it has been packed up with visitors around the world. My suggestion is go in the morning about 8.30 am before many visitors will go there. I feel so peaceful when I go there in the morning. No monks in this temple. Inside the hall of the temple, the architecture is so beautiful. A must to visit Temple for visitors.It is the temple where the King would go and change the dress of the Buddha when season changes. Therefore, visitors including Thais( no exception) have to wear properly (no shorts, long sleeves, no short skirt) in order to be allowed to go to the temple. Those who do not wear proper dress will be asked to put on the clothes that will be provided at the temple. It is Thai culture that one has to wear proper dress when we go to the temple.

Small, but impressive.... Tiny in comparison to the Reclining Buddha, the Emerald (actually Jade) Buddha was impressive nonetheless, and it's history is fascinating. The entire palace area is worth the crowds.
Emerald was smaller than expected. We saw monks from all different places, that was the most excited. We got to hear more about the history of the place, so that was great.
Very beautiful. We spent a great moment walking between the different parts of the temple. It is very beautiful and historically interesting.

Very nice temple, but extremly overcrowded!. This temple is very nice and shiny. But it is extremly overcrowded. It would be such a nicer place if the kept the numbers of visitors down a bit. But it is a moneymachine...Been there, done that!
Pretty impressive. The emerald Buddha is pretty small and it was closed off to us. The surrounding architecture is cool. We bought a guide at the front which was nice to have.

Beautiful, but heavily touristy and pricy entry.. The entry was really pricy, and was really packed so it was difficult to enjoy the place as such. It's a very touristy place. It took us a second round to see where the Buddha was actually.

Takes your breath away. Even at peak season with elbow to elbow Chinese tour parties elbowing their way through you this is worth irt.To me the Emerald Buddha is the most mesmerising of all and the spiritual feeling is extraordinary.Do try to go at a quiet time maybe very early one weekday morning.

A jewel in more ways than one!. Seeing the Emerald Buddha was one of the most memorable experiences we had in Thailand. It is absolutely beautiful and you will feel a calm serenity envelop you as you gaze at it.
This is a very crowded site, made even more so by the hordes of Chinese visitors with selfie sticks.
A must go in Bangkok. Like the Grand Temple, Temple of the Emerald Buddha is another place visitors should definitely visit during their stay in Thailand.

Beautiful. The emerald Buddah of itself was beautiful but not the most captivating aspect present in that temple... I have to say that the atmosphere of the chanting monks left me mesmerized and gave me the opportunity to see another culture and way of life... great experience!

Breathtaking, if a little expensive.. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the Grand Palace come as a job lot under a single ticket. It gets busy, so try and go relatively early to avoid crowds. Remember to dress conservatively, although if you do stumble across the site and are wearing short shorts and vests you can get shawls at the entrance. This is Thai culture at its most opulent, so be prepared for lots of gold. If you get too hot, there is plenty of shade and drinking water on tap.

Worth a visit. We took our 4 year old twins to this temple and the adjoining Palace, and they loved it. The architecture and religious figures are interesting, beautiful, and fun for grownups and children. This attraction is crowded, but that did not detract from the visit.

Brave the crowds - Beautiful. This is a very hot tourist spot, but even ex pats go and are overwhelmed by the architecture and sculpture about the grounds. Although you must see all the buildings, I recommend taking some time with the enormous, beautiful panels that line the perimeter - a story of love and treachery that must be viewed carefully. Watch especially for when the monkeys arrive!

Amazing Bangkok. The emerald Buddha is very beautiful that was making me feel peace and clam inside the temple. My Thai friend taught me how to pray in Thai but it was really not easy even I followed every words after her. The problem was too many people outside and they took photos everywhere which I had to escape not to be in the flame all the time.

Beautiful but crowded. The place is stunning, and I had to focus to not letting my jaw drop all the time. Wonderful art and building details. But this must be the most crowded temple I have visited in Thailand. It is obviously not the temples fault, but the experience was somewhat affected by the massive crowd inside. And people should show more respect. I am not a buddhist, but I always do my best to respect places of worship in general. The staff did their best to keep people quiet, not taking pictures where not allowed, and stay off lawns. I don't know if there is a time when it is quieter, but would recommend to go there anyway.

Amazing architecture. This Wat is full of storeis and pictures that take you easily a day to soak it all in. We enjoyed walking through and looking at the statues and pictures. It is very clean too. It can be a bit crowded but it is bearable. A must do!

The detail is amazing. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is inside the Grand Palace grounds. There will be a ridiculous crowd but it's worth fighting through. The detail and design work within the entire complex is really a sight to behold.

Super crowded by spectacular. The detail work and the pure massiveness of this complex is a sight to see. The place will likely be MOBBED but even my husband, who HATES crowds, thought battling the crowd was worth it. Wat Phra Kaew is a complex of more than just the building with the Emerald Buddha -- take time to walk around it all.

The only "must see"-attraction in Bangkok!. This is just something one must visit when travelling to Bangkok! (quite frankly the only attraction of that sort). The temples are extraordinary, and The Grand Palace is beautiful! Too bad tourists are not allowed inside the palace itself.Remember to bring appropriate clothing. One should wear long pants or a skirt/dress which covers the ankles. Also the shoulders must be covered. Gym clothes are not allowed. If you travelled to Bangkok without bringing such clothing you can buy appropriate clothing outside of the temple area (from carts on the sidewalks just before the main entrance).

Respect. This visit to the most sacred Buddha temple in Thailand is a must.It is a beautiful temple where people come to pray ... it is strictly prohibited to take pictures and visitors should cover their shoulders and wear long skirts / pants .The "Emerald Buddha" is displayed in a glass box high above the altar...sit on the floor and take some time to absorb the beauty of the temple.One last piece of advise,please show respect when you're in the temple.

Great temple but very busy. I have visited this temple a few times, the last being 10 years ago. This time it was very busy and quite overwhelming. A lot of the groups seemed to be very rude and lacking in queuing and general courtesy. However the temple and royal palace were both lovely, but we did leave much of the palace as it was too busy,.
Beautiful temple in Bangkok. This temple is a must. Not only is it gorgeous but there is also all the history that goes with the emerald buddha and the traditions. Don't miss it while in Bangkok.
place to go. Architectural work at it's best.So evident that a lot of thought and hard work went into the construction of the place.Lovely monuments, great people.Great family outing

Overcrowded but worth it. We went in April during a Buddhist Holiday and oh my god! It seemed the entire population of Thailand was there to receive the monks blessing. It was a scene as i have never witnessed one before. We got the monks blessing and visited the beautifully decorated temple. As a tourist avoid going to these places on Buddhist Holidays.
A must see!. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is a must see; it really was an amazing experience and also seemed a lot calmer than The Grand Palace.

A must. When doing the rounds of the palace complex you must take in this temple, one of the most important sites in thai Buddhism, warning dont take pictures inside or answer your phone though!
nice to spend a quiet moment of contemplation inside.
Stunning temple. Really enjoyed visited this temple - the architecture and colours are just amazing. Beautiful within the grounds of the Grand Palace.

A bit of perspective, please. After being in Bangkok for a few days, plus
in the past, any metropolitan city which has so many sights to see 5 * to me has to be given to something extraordinary or different!!!
Albeit it beautiful it's nothing special. Sorry everyone.

Must see. Very special płace, full of spirituality. Impressive craft art.
Take your time by visiting it. Crowded.

Amazing in every way. The long line, the heat of the sun, and the crowded grounds - these are all worth it when you see how amazing the entire area is. The main focus isn't only the temple itself, but the statues, the structures and the overall architecture of the area. Again, be sure to wear easy to remove footwear, bring a water container with you if possible, and wear light clothing. Be as modest as possible, as there is a dress code to follow.
Beautiful. Went early on a Sunday morning witnessed the ordination of monks ceremony really good the rationale and process so interesting Lots of steps but well worth a visit stunning buildings

If you have seen the Golden Buddha, this would be underwhelming. Inside this temple you will see an Emerald Buddha. I was un-impressed by it since I saw the Golden Buddha already (Wat Traimit). For one thing, it is smaller than the Golden Buddha, and not as stunning. There is no question that a 5 ton Buddha made of pure Gold is stunning. :)You should really be quiet when you enter this place as there are a lot of people praying. Also, you are not allowed to take any photos inside the Temple.
Must see place when in BK. Amazing architecture and you will see different temples at one place. Be sure to wear proper dress and carry water

Great visit but construction . Was a good visit, very beautiful and spiritual place. The monk inside got shouting at some people for something very bad, not sure what they did but it was enough to make monk get angry which was very surprising. Still beautiful place. No shoes must wear sleeves and have pants
amazing thailand. again an amazing place to visit, well worth going there. Everyone was friendly and helpful. Great for photos.

Just Amazing. When you walk around in this place, you will feel a since of peace. Every corner had a temple and a place to enter for prayer. The temples were very colorful and ornate. The architecture and the shape of the dome that graced the top of the temples made my jaw drop. I was there on a weekend so expect large crowds and remember to wear a blouse or shirt with sleeves. Shorts and skirts above the knee are not allowed. Enjoy!

A great setting. This is an absolutely gorgeous temple for a relatively small centerpiece, the Emerald Buddha. Not very easy to see from where they've roped off the temple but I found it to be an appropriately respectful setting for an important piece of Thai culture. When you visit, please respect the rules that are clearly posted. Way too many visitors disregard the rules for whatever reason. You are a guest; follow their rules.

Wow. This temple kept me speechless for hours and is probably my favorite temple or site in all Thailand. I cannot do real justice to this marvelous attraction and collection of artifacts with such a few words. Go,look and then write your own review to try to describe this wonderful place.

Stunning . The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is on the site of the Grand Palace, you have to go into the Grand Palace to get to the temple (see my review of the Palace for more info). The temple building is quite spectacular, bejewelled and beautiful. The jade Buddha was smaller than I was expecting but at about 2 ft high it is a big lump of jade! The Buddha is fairly high up on lots of golden plinths and it is possible to get quite close to look at it. You are not allowed to take photos in the temple though. On your way out it is also worth going into the museum of the Emerald Buddha as there are a number of interesting artefacts in here and it is also a welcome reprieve from the sun!
Always better to go for group tour. We went on a group tour with other places its always better as groups are more interesting...Be sure to carry sun block.Must visit if your go to bangkok.
Wow!!. Wonderful place to visit.First trip to Bangkok and I was so surprised by the beauty of the temple.which is really amazing to me.Let's include this temple in your travel list

Beautiful temple. Within the grand palace, which has an entrance fee. Remember to bring something to cover your shoulders and knees, or else you can borrow I believe, but you have to wait in line. Must remove shoes to enter the temple. Gorgeous temple, gold painted everywhere. Very impressive work. Would recommend :)

Must see in Bangkok. If you find yourself in Bangkok for a weekend like I did, you must go see this temple. It is arguably one of the most beautiful temples in the world. It was hot in the spring, try to avoid the crowds. Even if the crowds and heat are inevitable, it is definitely worth the visit. There is much to see so grab a map and be prepared to walk around and take a lot of pictures! I would plan to spend at least two hours here to fully enjoy every part and especially if you like to take pictures you can easily spend an entire morning or afternoon here. I visited with my Thai friend and she recommended wearing long pants and not shorts or dresses to be respectful, so I would pass that message along too. If you can, get a local guide to explain the stories behind the art inside the room with the Emerald Buddha.
Landmark . It's hard to remember qualities and specific details of these temples as I visited last year in August 2015. I had a guide who told me about details of these budha.

Well maintained but crowded. We went on a hot day, but the entire setup was really good - royal and glamorous. The Emerald Buddha is in a glass cabinet on top of a shrine. Wouldn't call it mesmerising, but can visit if you have time to spare.
MEMERISING. VALUE ART!!!Immensely articulate.This temple symbolises Grandeur.Like putting worship at highest pedestal

A Little bit of gold leaf goes a long way. We went, it was hot, the walk was long, it was very crowded and of course, the portion with the Emerald Buddha was closed, but you have to pay the 500baht fee anyway. The temple is pretty, perhaps gaudy in a way. The monks lined up sitting to meditate but talking on their cell phones was curious to us.

Absolutely Beautiful Temple. It is speechless to see such beautiful temples, amazing, must see place.Been to many places in the world, the temples here are so different, the art work and design of the building, just fabulous. Just a suggestion for the management team, if you can control daily incoming numbers of tourists on daily base, currently so many tour groups in the temple, I wonder if the Buddha is happy. Imagine if we can visit the Temple with peaceful surrounding, it would be so nice and wonderful.
Peaceful. Although there were many people kneeling in the temple it was very quiet. Tourists were respectful. Worth a visit.
Beautiful. But don't make the mistake we made on our 1st trip here.. We all agreed to meet at the Buddha.. lol..we all ended up at different Buddha's that 1st time in Thailand

Sight to Behold,. This is one place that must not be missed on a visit to Bangkok! I have never seen so much gold and precious stones around and inside a temple. The courtyard is amazing with various gold statues, towers and amazing buildings placed in strategic positions all around and all. The Emerald Buddha is a sight to behold, even as it is perched high up. You can just stare and imagine the workmanship that went into creating it. This is a popular attraction and therefore it is always crowded. When visited, there were people sitting, kneeling, praying or standing so you need to be mindful of this. Please note that you have to take your shoes off before entering the temple and be appropriately dressed as well - No shorts, mini skirts or spaghetti straps or you would not be allowed to enter and no photos can be taken inside the temple. However you have plenty opportunities to take your photos outside the temple in the courtyard.

worthy of visiting. This temple is the most famous in Thailand and a lot of tourists visit it. It opens 8:00 to 15:30. I think you should visit it as early as possible, because not only hot wheather but also there are many people in the afternoon. The tempke is very beautiful and I recommend you to visit it.

One of the best temples in Bangkok. Admission is 100 baht per adult or child over 120 cm. You will receive free bottle (350ml) for your ticket inside so don't bin it. Its advised to come with appropriate clothes but I saw many tourists dressed in shorts. Nice temple to see but can be a bit busy.

Disappointed. Really quite disappointed with the emerald buddha. The building was lovely, there was not much really to look at and the Emerald Buddha was so small, they had also dresed him in rags, you need 10-20 tops to look around this place
Beautiful. Another must see. Just wear respectable clothing but cool clothing it gets so hot! And take your time, I know temples can get tedious but make the most of this gem!

A must see for the "Thai"experience.. Combine this with a visit to the Grand Palace next door.The actual "Emerald"Buddha is fairly small but the temple itself which houses it and its surrounding areas are quite an eye opener and for those who have not visited Thailand before ,there is quite a cultural difference--- this is the Thailand you see in pictures (not the smoky,hot traffic jam that is Bangkok).Make sure you dress appropriately as the Thais respect their temples and have shoes that you can take off and put on easily.It is a must see in Bangkok.
Of course you are going. One of the must sees in Bangkok. Classic Thai temple. The Emerald Buddha itself is small and kind of a let-down...but that's ok...have fun.

Special Occasion visit. Do not miss when you arecin Thailand. The temple is a very respectful and amazing place in Thailand for sight seeing. More than 200 years old you can see Thailand historic story there.

He's tiny!. Ok, I was expecting one of those huge buddha statues again, because there is one in Chinag mai that is supposively a replica and is about 2 m tall; nevertheless this one is beautiful too! It has 3 different seasonal outfits, that can be seen in the museum. The temple is really crowded tho, and this is a part of the grand palace complex, so in order to see it, you must go through all the crowds in the palace too.

Must watch place in bangkok with great cultural values. One of the best temples in bangkok one can visit with great architecture, one can just hold ones breath there just seeing the marvels. Its easily accessible from the river boats, and one can catch the connecting BTS train. One of the largest golden buddha statues is located there which is just marvellous. a must watch place

Another must visit in Bangkok. Just few meters away from Grand Palace, Tuk tuk will take 40 Baht to get there from GP. 100 Baht is entry fees, please do take part in candle offering ceremony, you just need to choose ur Zodiac sign candle mold, then stand in Que to get your turn to offer melted candle as part of blessing. Beautiful architecture, I love the colors on roof tiles, very beautiful. Remove ur shoes to go inside the temple to see the "Lying Buddha".
Worth visiting... As part of our time visiting the Grand Palace we joined the crowds to view this amazing spectacle. It is a great experience.
The only one to visit. In the premises of the former royal palace, it is to visit when you are staying some few days in Bangkok.May be overcrowded due to its worldwide reputation.
beautiful, beautiful, beautiful.. Just remember to cover up or you wont be admitted and you will have to buy from the roadside stalls.
Very nice indeed. If you are at the Palace you cannot miss this spot. The architecture is fantastic asian style and worth a visit for sure.

Was that the Emerald Buddha?. Beautiful temple (especially on the outside) but a bit of an anti-climax in regard to the Emerald Buddha! It was tiny (couldn't see it well at all) AND no photos allowed (disappointing). The interior is breathtaking. Guards on duty were a bit abrupt and rude to some people when telling them what to do with their shoes.A guard on duty was also fast asleep which raised a giggle:) When in Bangkok......

Finest amazing Temple of Emarald Bhudda. After visiting the Royal Palace i headed to Temple of the Emerald Buddha m the temple itself is adorned with intricate craft works and paintings and decoratins, and i was really wonded struck on seeeing the amazing Stupas around and the Chedis. The golden color of the Gods Surrounding the temple pillars and the deities and vimanas are extensively crafted and amazing with spectacular creativity. Inside the inner sanctum the Idol of Emerald Bhuddha is kept in the middle and its really a heavenly feel to see the sanctum of Buddha and the mural paintings portrayed on the walls , depicting the life and teachings of Buddha. The pedestals and the Chambers were glittering in golden color idols and deities.

Beautiful Temple but never a quiet time. Inside the Grand Palace site this is one of the most important things to visit but be aware if all the scammers outside the Grand palace telling you its closed. The palace is open everyday. Do your research and don't believe anyone who wants to tell you something different! The better their English the more likely they are to relieve you of your cash!! They pose as security men policemen even undercover cops anything to scam the innocent Westerner out if his or her holiday money..be warned!!!

Very nice and very crowded but you simply can not skip.. The temple of Emerald Buddha is adjoining the the Grand palace. It was beautiful and was worth the visit. Lots of local architecture which was very pleasant to the eyes. The Temple of Emerald Buddha is the holiest of the temples and photography was prohibited inside the temple compound. The place was packed with people. Ticket price was 500 baht per person.P.S There is a dress code and bare legs or sleeveless clothes are not allowed.We did not take any guide or translator, didn't feel the need to do so. FYI we covered four temples in one day with ease:1) Wat Pho (The Temple of Reclining Buddha)2) Wat Traimitr (The temple of Golden Budhha)3) The Grand Palace & The Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Pra Kaew)4) Wat Benchamabopith (The Marble Temple) - The The marble temple was the smallest and least picturesque though the Budhha Idol inside was equally mesmerizing. It can be skipped if you are time constraint.We paid 1500 Baht to the taxi driver who stayed with us for the whole day. You need not hire any tour guide to visit the temples, just a reliable taxi driver will do ( we were 4 adults and 2 children, so hired a Toyota Innova). We were free by 1600 hrs.
Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra. Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phrawe visited and very spiritual and full of tourists from all over the world

True Beauty of Asia. Going here makes you really breathe in that you are in Asia. The imperial architecture and the Asian style of color really pulls in any trip to Thailand. You will see the true Asian style of building and worship. The buildings are many but most are not open to go inside which is understandable, but do note that most of your visit will be outside in the hot. The place was definitely crowded but it was not too packed. The Buddha was beautiful. I recommend a visit here as it is inexpensive and well worth your hour or two.

Stunning palace - beautiful traditional decorations!. Must visit in Thailand - the large reclining Buddha is housed in amazingly decorated room and the side temples must be visited.The detailing / decoration here is very different from the rest of Indochina and gives you a good grounding in the principles of Buddhism!

Crowded but a nice place for a quick visit. Something you have to do while in Bangkok. I liked seeing the respect afforded to the Buddha by the worshippers. Do go if you don't want to take off your shoes, or if you're dressed for the beach---they won't let you in.

Must see!! . This is one of the main attractions of Bangkok and a must see for everyone visiting the city.However, beware of two things:1) Everyone who tells you it's closed and wants to take you somewhere else. They are liars and will take you on a tour to 8 family owned shops.2) Make sure you're dressed appropriately. No shorts or naked shoulders for males and females.
Crowded. Very crowded and no pictures allowed. Not all what it is hyped up to be but the history behind it is awesome.

Beautiful Temple. We went with our family of four and a tour guide. I highly recommend a guide to tell you about the significance of all you're viewing. It was a hot day, and very crowded, however, our tour guide planned ahead and knew exactly where to get cold waters along the way. I love the fact that the King changes the Buddah's gold clothing each season. Something I would not have known without a tour guide.

The premier tour site in all of Thailand!. Dress code is required... no shorts, no cut-in shirts or T-shirts, etc. The site combines the Grand Palace with the most revered Buddha image in all of Thailand - the Emerald Buddha.The place was teeming with loads and loads of tourists though. It's almost impossible to find solace and have a private moment for oneself

Beautiful. Very beautiful temple, with an, I guess, unique architecture. A lot of details and a feeling of power from this temple. Except the people and the price, the temple and the other one around was nice, but in a very small area.

Fantastic!. Absolutely beautiful! Love how its just one piece of jade. The prayer hall is so peaceful and the entire temple complex itself is fantastic. Come dressed appropriately - also beware of silly conmen outside trying to tel you the temple is closed!
Serene n calm. Such the place of calmness amongst the chaotic exterior of Bangkok. Come in the morning to avoid the crowds. Get a private tour if possible and make sure you visit the museum

Crowded and expensive. First of all, a ticket for this Wat is $15. That's almost as much as a day in Angkor! Even in off-season, the place with overrun with buses and buses of Chinese tourists. Once you push past the pastel umbrellas and selfie sticks and elbows, you wait in a long line to give the money to an unsmiling clerk. After passing the dress code, you are ushered in through designated paths to take through the palace and temple. You can only walk in the certain way, and if you stop hordes will push you or push past you.Several of the water fountains were broken and there were incredibly long waits for the bathroom.The murals are beautiful and yes, the tiny Emerald buddha is worth seeing. However, what was once a sacred and beautiful symbol of Thai Buddhism and the Thai royal family feels like a money-grubbing roadside attraction. Just know what you are getting into. If you do go, I recommend going here first and then relaxing at the serene grounds of nearby Wat Pho.
Meditation. Its a very good place for meditation. Shoes not allowed. Better get a guide to explain the rituals being done in the temple.
Beautiful temple.. must visit. Buddha carved out of a single Jade stone was definitely worth visiting. Beautiful temple. Very ornate.
Beautiful!. The place is beautiful. The temple is studded with stones. The emerald Buddha and the prayer hall is just so peaceful.
Together with grand palace. Your grand palace ticket includes admission to temple of emerald buddha. Cant take photo inside. Since its on the way, u can visit it
Go early in the morning. Small beautiful temple set inside the grounds of the Grand Palace. Go early as possible as it gets very crowded, but still worth it so see the beautiful Emerald Buddha.

Nice architecture. This is inside the Grand Palace grounds. The architecture itself is amazing but when i went inside I couldn't get my eye on the emerald buddha you need to concentrate and look for it.
Very busy but beautiful site.. The Temple is beautiful and the Emerald Buddha is inside - you need to take your shoes off at all temples. No photographs are allowed inside this temple.
Very Nice Building. The temple very historic and unique, you may find out there are combined different country art of buddha. Mostly they using GOLD to build their God Statued. Is good to visit .

Excellent visit. Temple of the Emerald Buddha is such a stunning place. The whole place is glitzy. Although the place is tiny and super crowded, we still enjoyed it although i had to take a 30 minute break since the heat was unbearable. Did not take away from the experience though. Overall i'd say it is one of the essentials place to visit in Bangkok.

easy to find on your own. i bought a one day river pass for 150 baht and it was the best thing i did all week getting off at the temple of the emerald buddha was the second best thing i did the sheer beauty that awaits anyone is beyond words its absolutely fantastic and the workmanship in creating the buddha is beyond belief it would rate alongside the grand palace which is only one stop upstream on the river taxi
Very nice to see.. A good sight to see, very busy inside and out, temple is beautiful, be wary as you are not allowed to take photographs inside and will be made to delete. Lovely temple
The most famous place in Thailand. Thai prince comes to change the buddha image' dress every season. Bike lane is blocked by buses and people. Walk a lot ib this place.

Small size emerald buddha. It is located inside the Grand Palace. When you come here and want to take a photo, take it from the outside of the temple since it is forbidden to take the photo inside. The Buddha is relatively small and it is located in the center and high above the pedestal. When you come here, please be prepared for a big crowd. Watch the weather channel and come here when it is not raining.
A stop on our tour of the major temples in Bangkok.. Another world class historic spot that must be seen! This was one of four locations on a guided tour package for myself and my travel companion.

Beautiful ! Must visit for every tourist.. Without a doubt, Bangkok visit is incomplete without a visit to this temple.
It is really amazing.
Hot, crowded, but definitely worth it.

Small and Green. First, it's on the grounds of the Grand Palace (500 baht). Also, it's hard to get close to the Buddha because of the crowds and the Buddha sits really high up. It's also hard to appreciate it because of the crowds and people trying to sneak pictures and guards shouting and... yea, you get the idea. I gave it 4 stars because it should be impressive. I think I was just hot and over the crowds. I don't know how peopled do this, the palace and Wat Pho in one day without murdering someone.

Even not a Buddist. We booked a tour for temple of the emerald and grand palace to have a sight for thai culture and religion. Its our first time at Bangkok and even we are not a Buddist its still worth the visit at temple of the emerald. Buildings were nicely created. Although a little bit hot and crowded. Be prepared with a dress code. A great experience for a Christian like me.

Not as great as I thought it would be.... The Emerald Buddha is very tiny and it is very hot here. There are many tourists, the bathrooms are infested with mosquitoes, and the security is very strict on having your pants/skirt go down to your ankles. I would have rather spent my time exploring the rest of Bangkok.

A bit disappointing. An emerald Buddha sounds like a really interesting thing to see, but it is fairly small and kept at a great distance and height from where you are allowed to view it from. Thus, you get very little in the way of a good look at it.

Amazing Buddha . It's one of the must-go sight-seeing place in Bangkok. You may see lots of tourism groups flowing especially Chinese. Better go there in the early morning if you can't bear the heat from afternoon.

Rip off. Totally pissed me off! I visited the palace 30 years ago, free and just wandered in, followed the dress code a lovely experience..,Returned to show my teenage daughter the palace and what a let down. Millions of people rushing, yelling and that was before we got to the 500 baht entrance fee office. We was in a que for ages finally got to the front, there was a male office staff member arqueing with a customer about her ticket and she had a few kids with her. She was trying to be reasonable but he was very rude and alpha male. The staff in the office were rude and uninterested. Our clothing was then checked ( we were both fully covered as per the dress code) we were then told we had to rent more clothing at 100 baht a piece and go next door to put it on. The scene next door was a ruckus of people grabbing clothing. The extra clothing was going to cost a further 500 baht! At this point we walked feeling very pissed off and grumpy.. Not the feeling of peace and love I got from my earlier visit ... There are many more beautiful Wats and temples to visit in Bangkok mostly for free I suggest go to them :)

Be respectful. It is incredible to imagine the wealth behind this Buddha, it is a large gemstone designed as a Buddha. However, most visit it just to take pictures and forget that you should be respectful inside the temple, please don't be this type of person.
Beautiful. Exquisite architecture. Amazingly beautiful place. Lots of people enjoying it so very crowded. Make sure your shoulders are covered, and you're in appropriate attire.

The most amazing sight in Bangkok. This entire complex is gorgeous. This Emerald (actually made of jade) Buddha is very special to this country. Be sure to remain respectful while visiting this beauty.
Beautiful. Quick tip: NO shorts for ladies and man. And no bear shoulders. So buy a simple airy long pants the day before, and avoid standing in a long line for the free clothes.

Crowded, but don't miss it. Sometimes places are crowded because they are just that cool. This is one of them. The Buddha itself is tiny, but when there is a swarm of people, look up just a bit more, he's there in all is Jade glory. It's crowded, but definitely worth it both for the Buddha and understanding the cultural narrative of Thailand as well as the architecture and statuary in the area.

Brilliant. Gorgeous twinkles of gold and jewels. No pictures inside. (A couple goobers tried and second guy received a swift swat from security guard.) Remove shoes and leave outside. Many people praying and homage near front. Donation boxes available. 3 different Buddha statues that King changes throughout year: summer, rainy, winter season. Today was still summer. According to guide, emerald Buddha is actually made of a solid piece of Jade. You can also use flower provided at entrance to viewing to dip in water that is considered holy and tap top of head to receive blessing and send away evil spirits.

Emerald is really jade, but the complex is amazing.. A MUST in Bangkok. It was very, very crowded at our last visit but worth jostling all the tourists. Many photo spots and classic Thai guardian figures and garuda. Take time to wander and appreciate the paintings from the Ramayana legends.

Don't forget to visit Emerald Budha Temple while you are in Bangkok. When your are in Bangkok, this temple is one of attraction you must visit. Located in the center of Bangkok you can go here everyday.
Beautiful. This was so incredible to see and to know people built these temples with their hands. It gets very hot though so be prepared.
Pure gold!. One of the most beautiful places ever. It just shows the beauty and richness of the Buddhism history in Thailand. The temples are impressive!
crowded. Probably a must see. Beautiful, everywhere you look. The mass of ppl make it unbearably hot and uncomfortable so go early.
Why bother. It costs a small fortune to get into this temple that as Buddhist temples go offers possibly the worst wow factor imaginable.

Crowded but worth visiting.. You can't come to Bangkok without visiting The Grand Palace and the Emerald Buddha temple complex. Unfortunately not able to photograph the Emerald Buddha but the temples will give you enough gold and glitz to photograph.

Stunning temple. Hard to tell which temple is which. Must admit had to go back to this one again only because the first time I went into the temple I went in and sat and gave thanks to Buddha there was so much gold inside and a little dark I did not notice the emerald buddha way up high on top. The temple itself outside was probably more spectacular architecturaly for me.

Beware of closing time! . I'd love to say the Temple of the Emerald Buddha was amazing.... But unfortunately we got there just as they were closing for the day- much earlier than I would have anticipated. Our fault- we assumed the temple would be open until dusk. So we did not get in. A word to the wise- don't put off some of these Bangkok must-sees until later in the day as they have some early closing times.

Beautiful but crowded. It is possibly the busiest tourist attraction in Bangkok. The amount of people (and parasols) are distracting. You are probably better off get in in the early morning, the tour buses usually arrive around 10am.You can rent an audio guide for 2 hours for a small fee, which is actually very useful and took you to less crowded viewing points.If you are not properly dressed, there is a room at the entrance where you can borrow clothes (for a tiny fee + deposit). But there could be a small queue if it is busy, so it is probably more sensible to where suitable attire in the first place.
Nice temple . Temple looks nice enough, we've also been to the original temple in chiang mai from where the Buddha came from.

Truly gorgeous!. Wat Phra Kaew or the temple of emerald Buddha is beautiful . The place is very noisy since it is a popular sight seeing destination in Bangkok. Despite the crowds there is a sense of tranquility in this place. Highly recommend this place.

glitery glitery buddha. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha or Wat Phra Kaew (officially known as Wat Phra Sri Rattana Satsadaram) is the most important Buddhist temple in Thailand. It is located in the centre of Bangkok, within the grounds of the Grand Palace. The Buddha image is carved from a single block of jade.The temple of Emerald Buddha is beautifully decorated.Each gate of the Balcony is guarded by the five-metre tall 'Yaksa Tavarnbal' (Gate-keeping Giants),

Might be a great temple, but it's managed and manned very badly. The grand palace and the emerald buddha grounds are entered from the same entrance. I was hoping to get an audio guide, but you can only rent one if you leave your PASSPORT or CREDIT CARD behind as a kind of insurance. Even a driving license is not accepted. It's a policy that is hard to understand. I find it high suspicious and cannot help but think that those documents are asked for only because there is something to be gained from it - that is, either an identity or money will be stolen. The horrible attitude of the lady at the window made me feel that that is exactly what is intended. The map provided was useless and there are no signs to tell you what you are looking at.

Nice looking temple with lots of cool wall murals.. I have been to this temple 3 times now and I must advise visitors to dress temple appropriate. There are vendors that rent and sell temple attire. Maybe even recommend buying some of those thai pants as souvenirs. The entry fee is 500b for tourist. Cost is too high as this place gets tons of visitors everyday and where does the money go. However I do love the wall murals all along the temple and if you get a guide they can tell you about the stories behind the murals. This place is outdoors in the middle of the city so its really HOT!!! be prepared. I love taking the chao praya river cruise boats to this destination. Also a few cool riverside restaurants not to far away (The Deck is walking distance).
Stunning temple. Stunning temple which takes the breath away. The awe in which the Thais hold this temple is a fascinating onsite to the Buddhist religion. A must see.
Very beautifully designed. Gracious and extremely glittering statues inside the temple. Worth visiting. Very popular tourist point
It's not emerald . It's amazing but crazy busy and noisy despite the signs to be quiet. It would have been nice to sit and enjoy the space but only standing room when we visited.
Love the arquitecture!. Is a MUST visit if you are staying in BKK for a couple of days. Love it. I had great memories and beautiful pictures from this place!
amazing sight. wonderful experience and so incredible to see such buddhas - enjoyed our visit and would recommend it to everyone

Must see. Well, there is no much to write here - the Gran Palace facility is a place you probably would like to visit. Beautiful, Thai architecture is worth every penny (entrance ticket isn't expensive). Beware of being cheated !! There are some local mobs, that are trying to take in tourists for Tuk-Tuk sightseeing. If You want to visit the Palace just go there. Dont mind suspicious individuals who will try to convince you that the object is closed. The most advantageous way to get to the Palace is using BTS and public river transport, which is cheap (be aware of ppl trying to sell you a sightseeing trip)

Should be number 1 on your list to see in Bangkok. The very Beautiful Temple Of the Emerald Buddha (made of jade), the Temple Grounds, and Grand Palace are full of amazing sites and history of Beautiful Thailand that one may experience through its many sighs and sounds. In just a few words, Thai people can enter free - it's regarded as one of several temples considered as a Sacred Pilgrimage. Save your Ticket Stub and visit Vimanmek Mansion another day. Wat Pho (Reclining Buddha) and Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) should be also be include in your day's journey of amazement. I have visited Wat Phra Kaew over 300+ times and have always found something new, something to see again, something to fell in its beauty. Your first time will give you a sense of awe. But during each visit, scam artists will tell you the Temple and Grand Palace are closed for an hour. They have at most times convinced my first time Thai residents friends, but believe me, it is not CLOSED. The scam artists want you to take another 1-2 hour not worth the time and expense. You will be doing a lot of walking all day and Wat Pho, were King Rama I built the temple for the Reclining Buddha, is also the school were Thai people obtain their Massage License. I would avoid getting a massage their and pay just $1-3 more at the many Massage Parlors close, but away from Central Bangkok. It will add to the days experience.

Break from Shopping. A 5 minute walk from MBK shopping centre is this museum. A 35 minute guided tour is included in the price and was a lot more interesting then I thought it would be. My 2 teenage children were both interested in the subject. We had a meal at the restaurant which was very good and reasonably priced and of course there is the obligatory gift shop as well to look around.

Very nice architecture but again, all the same. I cant stress enough after seeing 3 or more temples, they are all becoming to look the same. While its very nice and magnificent piece of art. Some of the temples looks exactly the same and no history behind it.

Terrible experience. No guides available, no audio guides available, no details in English.. Only in Thai language.. We never understood the significance and hence couldn't appreciate it. Entry fee was 500 baht per person and it was expensive considering we didn't understand the history of the statue. Also, the audio guides were additional cost
Too many Chinese tourists!. Since my last visit to this amazing iconic temple, the Mainland Chinese tourist industry has found it. The whole experience was spoiled by the overcrowding.

Erawan Shrine. Even though we are not buddist we found the shrine very peaceful.The golden buddha has 4 heads facing to all sides.It is believed that both tourrist and locals come here to make wishes.People sponsor the dance and other offerings when the wish gets fulfilled.We could see a lot of people offerring wood and metal carved elephants etc.However we spent time watching all of these there, inspite of all the noise and commotion you could feel very peaceful in the temple.

Spectacular!. A visit to Bangkok is considered incomplete without a visit to this beautiful Buddhist temple.When King Rama I established Bangkok as his capital in 1782 he added the Temple of the Emerald Buddha in the Royal Grand Palace.The Emerald Buddha is a statue of Buddha in ameditating pose, made of jade & not emerals as is commonly thought.There are many stories about the history of the Emerald Buddha, one being that when lightning struck the Wat Pa Yiain Chiang Mai, a statue of buddha was revealed which was covered in stucco. Later on a bit of stucco pealed off revealing a green color inside. The priest removed all the stucco and lo behold-the Emerald Buddha was revealed. It remeined in Chiang Mai for many years and then was removed to other places before finally being installed in the temple in the Grand Palace.Like most other Buddhist temples there is a dress code- no shorts or revealing clothes. Women rent a long shawl & men fisherman pants near the ticket counter. The Temple is located within the Grand Palace & is located on Na Phra Lan Road, Old City. It is open daily, tickets sold from 8:30 am to 3:30 pm.

Way too crowded. There is no question this temple is very VERY beautiful but you cannot even take it in because it gets way too crowded. We arrived here early in an attempt to avoid crowds but everyone is also thinking that too. We stayed under an 45 minutes and headed out. Not enough time to really see the place, but for our sanity, we had to get out.

Expensive. It cost 500 bht per person. Looks nice but It's nothing special. For me laying buddha is more interesting. But it's important place in Bangkok for sure. If you want to go there you need to go by boat taxi. It costs about 40 bht per person for one way ticket.

The best Thailand photos are taken here. Must see.. This is one of the must-see places in Thailand like everybody else has said.  Keep in mind this is a Buddhist Temple of significant importance. Rude behavior and inappropriate dress have no place here. Pants (or skirts below the knee) should be worn. Shoulders should be covered. The temple provides pull-over clothes if you don't want to dress for the visit or bring a change along.  There are some places where photography is not allowed. Placards are clearly placed.  Each time I have visited Wat Phra Kaew I have been mesmerized by the centuries of work. I have also felt offended by Westerners who were loud, rude, and obnoxious. Still I hope for the day when I will only leave the site having been mesmerized.
Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Must watch in Bangkok. Oldest and most worshipped statue of Buddha in Bangkok. Its a part of Great Grand Palace.
Don't miss the Emerald Buddha.... ...as it is very tiny but so amazing! Of course, the only place in the whole area where you should not take photos...

Must see. This temple was perhaps the highlight of my time exploring Bangkok. Though disappointed that I could not enter it, the reason was because the royal family and other dignitaries were worshipping on the occasion of a major Buddhist holy day--seeing them present was a real enhancement.I'd go again on a future trip and get a guided tour that explains the artwork (which had amazing gold gilding) in the storyline throughout the temple... And of course, to get an up close view of the Emerald Buddha!

Awesome Complex. Firstly: this is the most sacred place in Thailand. The most venerated Budha, the Emerald Budha, is right there too. So, secondly, yes, it is incredibly crowded! You will find not only hordes of tourists but also pilgrims. Observe respect and pay attention to dress code.Others highlights of the temple are the maquette of the cambodian Angkor Wat just in the back of the library building and the amazing Ramakien Gallery, the painted wall that contour the entire temple and depicts in more than 170 pannels the Thai version of Ramayana, an ancient Indian heroic and epic poem.Probably the best time to visit the complex and avoid the crowd is right after it opens to the public.

Hot. 200 baht deposit (you get it back) if wearing inappropriate clothing. 500 baht entry into temple. Lots of long lines. Minimal shade, get water prior to going in the the temple walls. Get a map inside the temple many different languages and follow around three different types of path. Temples are amazing. The emerald buddah is amazing to see. Mansion in the palace area is closed on weekends.

Ug. This is a must see, but the problem is the volume of Chinese tour groups. There are a LOT, they're unaware of their own physical space, and although there are signs telling you what the rules are none of these groups are following. While it is a must see destination, you may find like myself that the other people make it nearly impossible to stay long. With so many wats in the city and around, it won't take you long to realize you're glad you went, but it's time to find some peace elsewhere. I gave 5 stars for the attraction itself - but not for the experience.
Interesting sights but very busy. Amazing place to see, but incredibly busy and quite difficult to see everything you wanted because of crowds. But still an incredible place to visit

Too crowded. We do not suggest going on a Saturday morning, but if you can find a less crowded time to go, I'm sure it would be better. We thought the emerald Buddha was a bit small for all the hype, so don't be too disappointed.

Wat Phra Kaew a real place o+f+ peace. This temple of Buddha is the most religous and holy place regarded by Buddhists in Thailand. People from round the globe come to visit the temple and carry back the peace and serenity in their minds from here. The cleanliness and the peace that it carried in the hall of the temple is amazing.

The rich culture of Asia is observed here!. Thailand is not only known for cuisine that is truly unique and filled with warmth among its people.... its land speaks of its rich culture as well....its a breath taking experience to see its gold architectural designs... a must see attraction!

Worth it.. Yes, it's crowded, like everyone says...it's the holiest site in all of Thailand. So yeah, surprise! Crowds! Its amazing to see, and amazingly understated though it is carved from a single piece of Jade.

So many tourists!!!. there are so many tourists, then you can't see nothing propperly! The Emerald Buddha is small and far away. The complex is big and you can lost yourself in the middle of the people, and the maps don't help at all.
a must see. Stunning and beautiful. Even my 23 year old son loved this temple. Amazing workmanship. Take the time to look around. Low entrance fee that also gets you into the palace

Spectacular. Firstly, don't be tempted by the guides outside the entrance who try to advise you to go with them to another gate. Once inside, the spectacle is amazing with temples and gold everywhere. Would recommend guys wear flip flops as to enter the temples you must be barefoot and to keep taking socks and shoes off on a very sticky day is arduous

Lovely. Albeit smaller than expected, the Emerald Buddha is a must for any visitor to Bangkok. The essence of Thailand is captured by the intricate sense and appreciation of beauty in this marvelous country. Whether it's the temples, the markets, the flowers, the fragrances or the infectious smiles and warmth of the people, Thailand is indeed a VERY special place.
Crowded. Too many people who are very unpolite .The temple is amazing but I prefer to go to YouTube as the quantity of people makes it annoying

Too crowded, commercialized, and hot. I did not enjoy coming here. First of all, their free English tour guide was a little rude. Second of all, there were too many people and it was hot. The place felt commercialized rather than sacred. There was no space or time to appreciate the place, the artifacts, or their significance. If you will come here, I recommend the following tips: 1. Book a tour guide in advance. 2. Wear pants. (They won't let you in if your legs aren't covered.) 3. Wear socks. (You will often be asked to remove your shoes before entering a sacred place.) 4. Wear sunscreen on hot days / bring umbrella on rainy days.

Beautiful but SO crowded. Undortunately, my friend and I arrived right at the start of a downpour which last over an hour and made for a dreadful time trying to find shelter among thw hundreds and hundreds of other tourists there. The emerald Buddha was stunning, as were all of the other buildings and structures there too. Be sure to make time for this one.

Amazing temple and the great palace is awesome!!. Make sure to give this visit at least 3 hours to get to see everything, is worth it. Be prepared to wear long pants and a Tshirt but if you dont have one, they will borrow u at the entrance for a 200 Bath deposit that will be given back to u at the end of the visit.
unbelieveable. will do this again.an experience to undertake.the place was serene and spiritual.the crowds can be a bit much
Stunning. Such a very outstanding creations... Very easy to locate and near to famous other attrations... Great

Main attraction on the Grand Palace area. Although not as huge as the Reclining Buddah this Buddah statue and its temple are so beautiful and well kept that you don't want to miss it! Wear jeans and a shirt or blouse with sleeves or you won't be admitted. Or you have to borrow at the gate. Although free, you don't need extra clothes in the Bangkok heat!

Most Beautiful Temple. The temple is located within the Grand Palace grounds and is a must see. It is full of gold and jewels that are so ornate, I have never seen anything like it. You cannot take pictures but believe the reviews... it is magnificent. If you are a Buddhist it will have even more meaning, but everyone should see it.

Sardines. Although I had seen this before luckily, my husband wanted to see it and it was terrible! Mass crowds made it literally wall-to-wall people so we didn't even try to get close enough to take a picture. Went in one door and immediately out the other. Our guide was surprised when we reappeared in less than 2 minutes. If you can figure out a time when it is not simply swamped, might be interesting...though it is NOT emerald, but jade.
Worth a visit. Definitely worth visiting.We booked through viator before we went - you get guide who comes with you and explains everything..

Fantastic but Crowded. The complex is vast and elaborate. It's filled with large temples, statues and stupas with intricate carvings topped off by the sculpted emerald (really jade) Buddha. this is a must-see for anyone in Bangkok.

Very impressive. The temple is part of Grand Palace visit. It has amazing interior with painting, sculpture and glamorous statue. I just cannot keep my eye off the statue here, so detailed and well-made.

The Emerald Buddha Temple Bangkok. One of the most Sacred Temples in Thailand, The Buddha statue is entirely made in Gold & Semi precious Emerald stone. Must visit for the first time traveler and very close to the Reclining Buddha Temple.

Beautiful temple with photo opportunities on every corner. Very glad that we came here to visit, along with the Grand Palace. The grand splendor of the temple amazed me, and all the walls and ceilings are beautifully adorned with golds and crystals. Love it. Do visit this temple!!

Highly overrated and overcrowdrd. Waste of time and money! Been there, done that! It's all about milking the tourist and less of the meaning. Was looking forward to a traditional & meaningful visit (everything but!)
Beautiful Temple . It's really beautiful. Photography is not allowed inside. Can learn lot about this from the museum at the entrance of the Grand palace.

Magnificent!. This temple was absolutely magnificent! The grounds were huge and the temples themselves were absolutely beautiful and intricately designed. There were so many small details in the architecture. We spent a long time looking around and taking in all the details. Make sure not too miss it when in Bangkok!

Unique statue of Buddha. This temple comes with the same warning as all others in Bangkok, ignore the scammers. Just go in and check out the beauty and serenity. If it isn't open, the temple personnel will let you know.The temple was great, but getting through the gauntlet of "tour guides" and tuk tuk drivers was annoying. The emerald Buddha was beautiful, but small. Still, a unique depiction.

Simply beautiful. Note that there is a front entrance, which is the only way you can get in. You'll have to leave your shoes at whichever entrance you take. At the back, you'll be able to get up to the temple floors, but the entrance to see the Buddha is all the way in front. Floors can get quite hot, so try to wear socks or bring socks with you to wear whenever shoes are prohibited. Also wear shoes that are easy to remove and slip on :)

Must see. Wonderful. Very crowded.. Buddha is small but the whole temple from inside to outside is absolutely great with wonderful decoration and art work. The temple is located in the grand palace complex. There is huge crowd all the time. No photo and no shoes.

Magnificent architecture . Visited the Royal Palace in Bangkok It's Architecture is worth visiting and emerald Buddha is beautiful though place is very crowded full of tourists but still manageable . Magnificent architecture takes over everything.

MUST SEE!. This is an incredibly huge grounds with the most intricate details that lend it it to be truly incredible. You cannot leave Bangkok without seeing it. I agree with the other reviewer that said the emerald Buddha is much smaller than you expect, but you won't care because the rest is so amazing! Do prepared that it is an incredibly crowded place with a billion tourists. So be ready to deal with a crowd! Oh and this shouldn't be a surprise in Bangkok, but oh boy was it hot! I would also highly suggest getting a tour because they were helpful in navigating the grounds and providing a little history of the place. It's worth the money!

Highly talked about temple. A must see in Bangkok, In side the grand palace. much crowded as it is a place of worship so need to respect that and must not take photos. It is one of the most important temples of Budhists

Crowded but don't miss. Everywhere in the Grand Palace is crowded but the Temple of the Emerald Buddha should not be missed. Pay attention to the Buddha's clothing because it is changed seasonally by the king.

WOW. The Buddha is smaller than you think, but the whole experience is amazing. Would recommend pairing with the Reclining Buddha Temple to see some differences. Hire a guide to explain everything and you won't regret it.

Great experience. We visited here in March 2016. It was very busy, maybe a little too busy but was well worth a visit. It's very ornate and had shaded areas to keep out of the heat. Remember you need to cover shoulders and legs though, I wore a t-shirt and sarong so was nice and cool.

This is the must see in Thailand. Coming from a country which has many temples and Buddha stupas, I still found this place extra ordinary. The temple, the palace, the gardens, the general area is all so amazing.

A Bangkok highlight. One of the must see places in Bangkok and the highlight of any visit to the Royal Palace.The Emerald Buddha is dressed according to the three seasons.No photos allowed and remember that it is a place of worship

Beautiful but choose a good time to go!. Firstly, dress appropriately which means sleeved shirts and lengthy pants/skirts or you will have to pay a two hundred baht rental fee for clothing. Love this location and is within where the grand palace is. Expect plenty of sun do would recommend hats or umbrellas as shade since a friend in our party suffered a heat stroke. Definitely beautiful and recommended must see but try to go later in the day to avoid hordes of tours.

Simply amazing. . Wow !!We must have said that 10 times in the first 10 minutes. As you enter this huge area of temples in Bangkok the view that hits you is simply stunning and it just gets more and more impressive. We went round in 37 degree heat and high humidity but it didn't make us cut short this visit by 1 second. I'm not sure what constitutes a wonder of the world but this has to be one. Photos don't do it justice, you need to see and experience it, you will not regret it and it is cheap to get in. I can think of more expensive attractions back home that are nowhere near the quality of this. It is very busy so you need to be patient if there is a particular photo you want to take without a forest of selfie sticks in the way but it is worth the effort. Take plenty of water with you as there aren't any shops inside the temple complex. If you are in or near Bangkok then go visit, it's a must.
Holiday in Bangkok. Beautiful palace grounds. Beautiful and peaceful temple premises. Had taken an english speaking guide from within the palace complex.

Nice, crowded and no photos . This is an amazing temple, Wat Phra Kaew is located within the Gran Palace. As all Wat there is a dress code that you need to follow to enter the My family went with our Thai friend who wants to pay a promise and do some good deeds but it was in a Thai Buda day, a big Holiday and most of the Wat were packed.Wat Phra Kaew was super crowded but people is very respectfully of the sacred place you can "flow" with the human river...The emerald Buda is a fantastic piece of art and is considered the most powerful and important sacre Lord Buda image .If you are in Bangkok and are planning to visit some temples, this is a must do it. Just check the calendar and avoid any Buda holiday or change of season...
Be prepared to dress properly. It was a really sunny day, the temple was really amazing!!! I like it ! Also prepare to pay about 550 bhat , and also be prepared to wear t shirt and at least jeans :)

bring a good camera. the temple is one to go into but you can't bring a camera in it is not permitted to take pictures inside but if you bring a great zoom camera it works so much better then an ipad or iphone.
Spectacular. Love the experience. Very beautiful architecture. Do bring your hat/umbrella/fan. It is hot, but worth visiting. Oh and get our camera ready!
Very shiny Temple. Beautiful temple with lots of statues to see. The place is huge so get a map, It is free and you can pick up the map with your own language on it.Expect the place to be crowded!

Busy but overwhelmingly beautiful. It's all too much to take in. You could spend days wandering around the Grand Palace complex and this temple is one of the first places on entry. It's overwhelmingly beautiful - which obviously means it's jam packed with other tourists! Inevitable. It is a trousers only entry, and you can hire trousers for free inside the Grand Palace complex. Ignore the ticket touts on the street who insist the temple is closed. Tickets are available in the complex. Another 'must see', but there are other temples which have more modest serenity about them.

Interesting. If you're the type of person that does whatever it takes to savour every detail of a historical place (even if it means drowning in streams of people and their chatter), do come here and look at how marvellous the temples are. Yes, it was terribly hot and packed but the sight of perfectly constructed temples with walls of jewels compensated for the inconveniences. Guide (audio or book I don't remember) is available for free within the compound of the temple. I would say that paying 500THB was worth it.

Beautiful but busy Buddha Temple. This temple had so many people on the day we visited that I was overwhelmed. Also when I finally got inside the temple the heat and the humidity got the best of me and I was not able to spend as much time as I had hoped. I had to find a little shade and a cold towel to help me feel better. The temple is amazingly beautiful but it is really popular so be ready for large amounts of people gathering around.

Buddha Temple. This temple is part of the Royal Palace or Grand Palace and regarded as the most important Buddhist temple in Thailand. It enshrines Phra Kaew Morakot (the Emerald Buddha), the highly revered Buddha image meticulously carved from a single block of jade. I spent whole day in Palace and this temple. Photography is not allowed inside the temple, so please do not try to click the picture inside, Security Guards and native people don't feel it as good. Also make sure that you are not wearing the skirt or mini skirt which is above your knees, else you are not allowed to enter.

Crowded, but worth the trip. This is a must see, when you travel to Bangkok. Not only the temple, but also the Royal Palace and the grounds around it. There is enough to see, to fill a 16GB chip in your camera.
A Must See. One of the best Wats to visit in Bangkok. This awe inspiring little statue can be the most profound of experiences !!!

Too bad you can't take pictures!. This is a beautiful temple inside and out! The Emerald Buddha is a highly prized piece of the Thailand culture and only the king can touch it. I love seeing all the guilded deities and the awesome colors!

Be aware of dress rules for men and women. The Wat and temple were amazing. After all we had seen we were dazzled by this whole compound.Be aware that men have to wear LONG pants (not wraps), short sleeve shirts are ok. Women have to wear long skirts or pants (ankle can be free) and middle sleeve shirts over the elbows or some scarf over the arms.The clothes can be borrowed at the entrance (currently 200 Baht deposit that is returned with the return of the clothes) - different from the Teak Mansion.Opening hours are currently until 4pm (last entrance at 3:30pm). You need at least 1.5 hour because there is a lot to see and there are a lot of people even in the lower season.In the entrance price which is currently 500 Baht is also the museum included. There was some confusion because there were lines for the express, middle and long tour. These don't apply for individual visitors. We were able to walk everywhere and explored the whole place.
Beautiful temple. The statues of this temple are very gracious and the amount of details is tremendous. It is one of tea places you should put on your visit schedule.

Overwhelming!. Absolutely amazing! We went early in the morning to avoid the crowds. However, after 20 mins it got very busy and crowded. We managed to see the Emerald Buddha and walk around . It was very hot about 38c but it felt like 48c. If you are planning to visit take plenty of water with you, wear a long sleeve top to cover your shoulders and long skirt or trousers. it is a lovely place to visit!!
Too many tourists!. Too many tourists visiting this attraction. Attraction itself is nice and beautiful to look at. Entry price is too high at 500 baht.

Beautiful!. While there are so many beautiful temples in Bangkok, this one should definitely be on your list of must-sees! All of the attention to the stone work is stunning. My group visited this location with a tour guide, which I'm glad we did because we learned so much about the history of the temple. There is so much to see it would be easy to over look something! It's very crowded but worth taking the time to wait in line to see the Emerald Buddha.
Precious Stones. You will be amazed at the precious stones that come out of the mountains in this mysterious place. The precision at which the people cut and polish gems as well is an art.
Crowded but stunning. The temple was very crowded and difficult to enter. Be sure to comply with regulations posted when entering the temple. The statue of Budda are astonishing.

Makes for an incredible photo album!. A breathtakingly beautiful experience visiting these buildings with such intricate and stunning architecture. Taking the time to take pictures is a MUST. Never seen anything like this.

Beautiful place. Temple is located within Grand Palace, so when you are buying the tickets (quite expensive for 500Bht- about 15usd), you will have access to both places. We went as soon as the Temple opened and it was still a zoo with huge groups of Chinese tourist all around. It was hard to move around and take a pictures, but there is nothing to be done about it. It is an exquisite place despite the crowds, even though statue of Emerald Buddha itself was rather underwhelming.Beware of very strict dress code, your knees and shoulders have to be covered, so no shorts, spaghetti straps etc.Worth seeing despite the crowds.
It is real???. Yes it is!!!!! amazing place with Budas everywere! shining floors like marmols and goldens budas that invite you to keep peace in your mind for a moment
Amazing statues. There are some truly stunning pieces at the temple, it's well worth a visit although it is quite expensive. Not open between 1 and 3 and you must cover your legs.

Get in Early. You need to get in early because this place is very popular. There were a lot of chinese tour groups there, and despite the signs saying please be quiet they made a lot of noise due to the number of them. The Emerald Budda part was very quick and as there is no photography inside the shrine and there are people praying it was hard to see the detail of the Budda. Take a walk around the edges of the complex and you will see a lot more than most. There is a great coffee shop with drinks and ice creams towards the end of the walk.Also be aware of the scams of entering and leaving the complex. The taxis will try to rip you off. Always use the meters. It will save you money even in heavy traffic

Beautiful Place but way too many loud tourists. This place is beautiful. It really gives you a close look to royal Thai architecture. Don't bother coming on shorts that show your knees. You can come in a T-Shirt but ladies beware that they wont let you in if your shoulders are not covered. (had to go back to the hotel to get my jeans) You can borrow stuff there but there was a massive queue. The gift shop at the beginning has some of the most beautiful textiles I've ever seen.
review. amazing buddha temple with 3 seasonal changes in outfits of god by king family we visited during summer but very peaceful n holy atmosphere

Wonderful . The temple of the emerald Buddha is a must-see of you visit Bangkok. The different buildings are incredibly colorful, and all the statues are amazing. I loved walking all around, and discovering this sacred place and its history with my girlfriend. Be sure to have long sleeves and long pants (even if it's very hot, yes!) otherwise you will have to borrow some clothes (for free, with a deposit) at the entrance.

Nice but small and far away. . There are a lot of Wats to in Thailand. While this is a nice one it was not my favourite as the Buddha was relatively small, far away and did not afford any good photo opportunities. It is worth a look but don't set your expectations too high.

I couldn't stop staring.. I don't know what it was about this temple. I found myself unable to stop gazing at the Buddha. There is such an intense positive energy vibrating within it's walls. I just wanted to stay a while and feel it. Be a part of it.

An all day visit is not enough. 21 separate buildings to see and all magnificent. As you enter on exibit is the statue of the hermit doctor, the Father of Thai medicine. In the cloisters are 178 different murals from the Ramakien epic. The Phra Sri Ratana Chedi houses relics of Lord Buddha. it is covered in gold and built in Ceylonese style. The Hor Phra Monthien Dharma has exquisite mother of pearl doors! Guardian Giants, all six of them guard the entrance to the temple, Thai children enjoy stories of these giants, but they also scare them before going to bed!! The Royal chapel of the Emerald Buddha is superbly crafted and holds the most revered Buddha image in Thailand. Check out the murals inside too. If you visit during special occasions you may hear the bells from the bell tower. Lots more to see and wonder at. You are able to purchase the use of an audio recording to guide you around the exhibits and explain what it is you are looking at. I was fortunate my wife is Thai and knew all the history from studying at University.

Gorgeous. It is a beautiful temple situated in the premises of the Grand Palace. It has intricate paintings and a small Buddha idol. The only issue here is it requires people to be silent but the excessive tourists that visit this place do not remain silent.

so little. you'd expect a giant bUDDHA STATUE worth of the many asian wars between Burma, Laos and Siam. Instead, the emerald buddha is a modest small statue. Be aware on NOT shooting any picture inside as the guards are really keen on keeping the rules.

It was worth going to the Palace to see the Emerald Buddha. The main tourist attraction of the Palace was closed to the public when we were there and we felt cheated of having bought tickets for this, but on following the crowd through we ended up in the Temples. Well these were magnificent. It was like being in Disneyland. Each Temple was so beautiful in colour and jewels - never seen so much gold! But the highlight for me was going into the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. It was breath-taking. unfortunately we were not allowed to take photos but so much gold on so many pillars and then at the very top the Emerald Buddha sat. it was worth going round just to see that alone, so don't get disheartened if you are disillusioned by what you are allowed to see at the Palace, especially if you need to cover your shoulders and knees (pay a deposit to hire long items of clothing) but so glad to persevered to see what else there was to offer.
STUNNING BEAUTIFUL. Must see - you can also meditate inside the room extremly intense energy - highly reccomended - with a tour guide even better
Best place to go in Bangkok. It's the most beautiful temple I ever see. Inside the temple with the Emerald Buddha is so peaceful. I love sitting there and meditation for a little bit.

Beautiful tiny jade Buddha. At the Grand Palace, there's plenty to see.
