You won't be disappointed but avoid the tour guides outside along with the guys touting b.s. 20 BHT all day Tuk Tuk tours--they just want to take you around to get you to buy a bunch of schlock.The Green Buddha is beautiful, albeit rather small. The Grand Palace is indeed grand, and you should not miss this sight; however, I prefer the Wat Pho (see other review). Wear shoes that easily slip on and off because you'll be taking them off to enter every temple.
Beautiful.... No words to explain. Is in the same campus as the Grand Palace. Huge, ornamental building. Need a proper guide to explain the architecture and the sculptures.

Impressive temple. My family loved to see it and experience the atmosphere it has. The history behind it, and the annual rituals that take place there and its importance to Thailand can be easily understood .

Another great day out whilst exploring Bangkok. This is a tremendous exhibit, interesting and amazing sculpture and architecture. Located within the Grand Palace, the Emerald Buddha is well worth the time and energy. We had an excellent guide, his knowledge was excellent.
Beautiful, beautiful places!. Besides The Grand Palace, this temple is also a must visit! It is next to The Grand Palace so you would not miss it. Extraordinary architecture and design. Must go!

This is a place you must see!. I cannot begin to describe this place. You can almost feel the royalty at this place. There is just so much to see. I recommend that you read the signs in this place, because there are some areas where you must take off your shoes or do not touch at all. Drink allot of water!

It's an impressive place. Despite the number of tourists, it's worth the visit. The grounds are very nice and interesting to see but don't expect too much from the Buddha. Very popular and can get crowded. Go early!

Must-see in BKK. No trip to BKK is worth without getting to its temples. Its interior are heavily decorated in wonderful, bright colours, depicting the stories of the life of Buddha on its walls. My favourite detail? There a holy lotus water font just outside the temple where you can bless your head with a lotus flower as a kind of Thai "christening". Delightful!

You have to zoom ! . Very famous buddha because he is the one that represent the country. In fact there is three buddha. The King son (the father is to old) is the only one that can replace one buddha for another when there is a change of season. The buddhas are not emerald but jade. Bring your zoom because the statue is 60 cm high sitting on top of a big monument. Another problem, you can only take a picture of it outside of the temple. It is definitly worth a visit. Like all temples the workmanship of the artisans is exquisite.

worth to see. we went to the temple on sunny day in the afternoon. lots lots of tourist and the weather was so hot. The entrance was strict and checked by officer, by partner wore shorts at knees still needed to change to long pants but they provided for free only deposit 200 baht and will get money back when return the cloth.The place is beautiful and full of thai architect which reflex the beliefs and culture.
Good to see. Busy place but was reasonably quiet when we went early in the morning. Lots of beautiful pictures to take so don't forget a camera.

Spectacular – but once is enough. Wat Phra Keo, the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, is one of those must-see sights of Bangkok – but once should be enough. It’s a truly spectacular temple (and the Royal Palace, which shares the site and is covered by the same ticket) impressive, but it’s not a very pleasant visit. Spectacular and with plenty of photo opportunities, yes, including for the Emerald Buddha image itself (you can’t take pictures in the hall, but shooting through the open windows seems acceptable), but once you get past the almost airport-type security and get your expensive ticket (currently 500 THB) it’s wall-to-wall tourists and brusque staff policing them with a marked lack of Thai smiles.Go, take your pictures, tick it off on the list – but then get a tuk-tuk outside (declining any “special offers”) or just walk the block to Wat Pho, the Temple of the Reclining Buddha. Every bit as spectacular, but with an entrance charge of only 100 THB (and they give you a free bottle of water), and far fewer visitors.

Ok tour in Thailand. There was a lot of build up by the tour guide to see this statue etc. Once we finally got in between the hundreds of tourist, we were surprised to see that it was only an 18" statue about 20 feet in the air and not easy to see. Not really worth the hassle for me to sweat my butt off to see.

Not much interesting. I visited on June 2015. Not interesting attractions. It's worthy if you choose to shopping rather than any attractions in Bangkok. Bangkok is only worthy for shopping sex & clubbing.

A must see in Bangkok ! . This was really beautiful . We were a bit over run by very large groups of loud disrespectful tourists but the vision of this Buddha overcame that nuisance . Go ! Sorry no photos allowed inside but here's some of the outside ... Amazing
Emerld Buddha. Another wonderful sight to see inside the Grand Palace, and well worth the visit. Free once inside the palace

Magical Place - Serene & Otherwordly. Part of the whole Grand Palace complex to be enjoyed at the same time. Be aware that women must not wear shoes open at the toe or heel, sleeveless or low cut blouses or dresses, shorts or even pants [depending on who is checking you thru]. A long & not too sheer skirt is the safest bet. For some reason, the bare heel & exposed toes prohibitions do not seem to apply to Thai visitors. Go as early in the day as possible, both to avoid the tour groups & the heat of the day.

Temple - Emerald Buddha. Visited this temple while having a visit to the Palace and the Reclining Buddha as they are all quite close. Dress code is strict - ensure that knees and shoulders are covered, shoes and head gear to be removed at the door.The Buddha is quite small and dainty compared to others and is not made of emerald but jade. Be prepared for the crowds (as usual), photographs are not allowed however postcards can be purchased.
Serene and beautiful surroundings. Heavily crowded and hot and humid conditions. A hat is a must. Cool off with a freshly squeezed orange juice just outside the gates.

Beautiful architecture and artistry. This is a must-see if you're in Bangkok. Make sure you reserve several hours to walk around the complex because this place is huge and there are so many intricate details to take in (colourful rooftops, stunning mosaic walls, detailed statues, etc.) The temple is very well-maintained and when I visited there were also some free drinking water taps set up.

Beautiful Palace but very crowded with tourists. We reached in the opening hours at the palace. The place is filled with many many groups and is too crowded. Make sure you wear long pants or skirts and no sleeveless allowed. There was so much chaos and loud noise that we couldnt even hear our own audio guides. Palace entrance us THB 500 per person. But the Palace and Emerald Buddha is very beautiful so was worth all the pain

Most beautiful . The painting and depiction of Ramayana on the walls were too good. But the prices were too high for the guides. We procured the audio guide which is 200 bahts for two hours. It was too sunny and was on Sunday and was too crowded even at 9.30 am. It was tough for us with two kids. The sculptures were nice. Emerald buddha- no words to describe.Definitely needs more time to enjoy the beauty of this place. They lure the tourist in the first place. They ask 700 bahts for guide. I guess that is too much. But it's worth a visit

Great attraction; This was combined with a city tour.. Such a different way of life; so interesting. We were there during the "cool" time ofyear and it was hot and humid. It was during various celebrations for Chinese NewYear, so very intriguing. I wish I could have spent more time here. It was over 12 hourson a bus trip, so was an extremely long day, but well worth it.
Get a Tour Guide. The tour guide will explain to you the history of this Emerald Buddha. Bangkok has a great culture, this is one of their great pieces of history.

Not allowed in on Sundays . I don't know why they thought this was only something that is told on the door after the half an hour trek in 35 degree's that was made to get there. But anyway it might have been nice in the inside. I guess I will never know.

Next to grand palace.. It is 1 of the must go places of interest, since it is next to grand palace and within walking distance of wat pho. But it is getting very crowded nowadays with tour groups. Try to go as early as possible to avoid the crowd and unpleasant experience that might occur.

Very crowded. Great sight to see with several temples to check out, however, was extremely crowded. They should limit the number of people they allow in because it detracts from the experience greatly.

Amazing place. This temple situated in side the Grand Palace.The Emerald Buddha looks really awesome.Photography inside the temple is strictly prohibited.We can't go inside with short dresses.You should wear long dresses.it's worth to visit .

Stunning!!!. This temple complex is next to the Grand Palace. You buy one ticket (~$15) to see both the Palace and Wat Phra Kaew. You'll need at least an hour, but more likely 2 to see everything (and make your way through the crowd!). It's incredibly beautiful! You must wear long pants and a shirt with sleeves (short sleeves are fine) or you will have to rent clothes from a kiosk to the right of the entrance. A scarf around your shoulders is not sufficient, but you can wrap a sarong around your legs.Don't miss the silk shop located right next to the clothing rental area. It's not well marked so it's easy to miss. They sell all kinds of gorgeous things made of silk for actually very reasonable prices. If you go out of the clothing rental area, look right and you'll see glass doors. It's also extremely well air conditioned so not a bad place to catch your breath before leaving!Two tips: 1.) There are about 5 million massive Asian tour groups. They tend to move as a one, like schools of fish, so never assume you need to wait in line for something just because you see a huge group of people...they are probably all just standing there!2.) Beware of selfie sticks and umbrellas. Nearly lost an eye on several occasions.

Great Buddha Statue. This temple is part of the Grand Palace areal- It is one of many things to see at teh Grand Palace. The temple looks amazing and also the statue is very beautiful. You should visit the Grand Palace early in the morning as there will be not so many people around.

Mesmerized by the grandness. The temple was extraordinary structure in itself which even with its all grandness and overwhelming structure, golden colors and grandeur was able to bring peace in us as soon as we enered inside.
Within the Grand Palace. This temple and the museum was wonderful to visit. It is within the Grand Palace. The temperature was very high (over 103f) so be sure to come with umbrella and water.
Beautiful. Beautiful temple to visit. Definitely worth seeing. Be sure to have covered shoulders and long pants when you visit or they won't let you in.

Emerald/Jade Buddha.... Breathtaking Temple . Definitely a must go temple . Detailed architecture with gold, pearl, mosaics. Lot of history. Breathtaking Temple You need to dedicate a minimum of 1 hour to visit this temple. ⭐️⭐️

Important historical landmark.... This is the most sacred place for Thai people. Photos cannot be taken within the temple. The Buddha statue is dressed according to the season and only the King/Prince can do this.

Definitely worth a visit!. We visited the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, and the Grand Palace next to it, on our fleeting visit to Bangkok. It's in the old town, so wasn't close for us to get to by foot, but hopping in a taxi was easy. We were dropped off by the entrance archway, and just inside, luckily for us, was a dressing room off to the right where you can borrow clothes if you aren't wearing temple appropriate clothing. You need 200baht but this is just a deposit.The temple is worth walking round, to see all the intricate designs worked into the walls, and inside is wonderful, a very calming room with lots of gold and jewels.It took us about an hour of wandering around both the palace and the temple, as there are a lot of temple buildings, and paintings on some of the walls which were really beautiful and intriguing!

incredible temple. I wouldn't have missed it for the world. I found that sightseeing in Bangkok was not at all as I thought it would be. This temple is a huge incredible riot of glittering gold and color. Pictures on the internet cannot do it justice. Definitely a must-see in Bangkok
Mesmerizing beauty. This is a beautiful temple with rich sculptures .. everything is golden and ornamental. Grand and Royal
Amazing. Deffinatley worth a visit when in Bangkok ,it's a must see in Bangkok .for me this city has the best temples
Different from the others. Being part of the Grand Palace, it is tricky inside. But the emerald statue of Buddha is a difference experience altogether.
Jade Buddha is beatiful. Its not actually emerald but made out of a solid piece of jade. Brought to Thailand from Ceylon in 457 AD.
The must-go temple. Wat PraKeaw is the royal temple for thai people in Thailand. It is used for Thai royal ceremony. Center that holds every Thai hearts.

Beautiful temple - but SO many mainland tourists. Cover your legs if you want to go in! Or you can rent something across the temple (i rented something but it felt dirty).The temple is breathtakingly beautiful and a must see. However, lots and lots and lots of tourists. like LOTS. So you'll end up with people pushing you to get a better look at something, shouting at the top of their lungs to speak to each other… that wasn't particularly pleasant and ruins the whole thing a bit. but sight itself is wonderful

Crowd Outside and Inside too, But a Wonder.. This is inside the Grand Palace, that is once you have taken the entry for the grand palace. The place is unbelievably crowded. And you can take my word for it because I am used to seeing crowds being an Indian. But it was still a lot of crowd. However, once inside the main temple, it didn't feel so crowded, also because people were mostly sitting down. The look inside was wonderful. The idols shone like anything, and it seemed an organised jungle of beauty. The paintings on the walls were interesting too. Since we were not allowed to take pictures, we just sat down and observed the statues peacefully, while having some respite from the heat and crowd outside.
Wat phra kaew . stunningly beautiful, very busy tourist attraction, well worth a visit, the workmanship that went into the creation is amazing

great day out but busy!. i loved seeing all the temples in thailand and soaking up the history and culture. however, the temples are only opened to tourists at certain times (other times exclusively for locals for prayers etc) so make sure you do your research and go at the right time. or like us, we went at the wrong time but theres plenty of eating places around for you to go grab a snack and pass some time.also take note that you MUST be covered up when visiting. legs and arms need to be covered. but if like us you didnt know that- the staff at the entrance of the temple direct you to a small building that supplies women and men with shirts, trousers and long skirts that you can borrow for the day in exchange for a refundable deposit.the temple takes about 1 hour to walk round and see everything. however we were in a hurry so we ran round it in 30 mins. it was over all a great day but its absolutely heaving with tourists so be prepared to me bumped into a lot by rude people with selfie sticks that dont apologise haha.

Very nice temple but beware of the crowds!. We reached the temple on a hot, humid day and found hordes of tourists shouting and jostling. We found it difficult to find the place for the tickets. This is part of the Grand Palace complex. We wanted to see only the temple and told that to the person at the counter. We paid 500 Bahts each only to read that the temple itself was closed to the public on that day. From what we could see from outside, the temple looked very nice.But it was very crowded and very hot. Recommend that you go as early in the morning as possible to avoid the crowds and to have a pleasant visit.

Temple of Emerald Buddha. We like the temple and the architecture around them is really interesting. This Buddha in specific was so small that to a certain extend it was almost hard to see. These temples are so crowded with tourist and propel that are actually there to pay their respect that sometime I think that the tourist should stay outside and let the people paying respect and that actually practice Buddhism have their time. They won't seem to be bother but it's a little too much with both group.Anyhow it's worth the visit but be ready for a huge crowd.

A very popular temple. A temple which is on top of the list in tourism pamphlets . Amongst all the pagodas I visited I found this to be most commonly visited by all tourists. There is an entry fee of 500 THB and there are lot of tourists here. The temple is very beautiful and the emerald statue is also quite impressive.

Quite Nice But!. I found this Temple a little disappointing. I believe it is primarily because it is part of the Grand Palace. By itself it is very beautiful and in my opinion would have shown better as a stand alone. The entire Palace ad Wat sites is extensive and demands some time to see it all. When I visited it was extremely hot and that possibly be the reason that I wasn't so excited about it. Try to a lot at least 3 hours or more to adequately see it all.

Incredible Temple. This is a must see when you are in Bangkok. There are tickets to get into the entire complex and you can walk the palace grounds. In addition at certain times you can see the impressive changing of the guard.

w. this temple is in the royal palace. The entry fees is too high @ 500 thb, The entry fees will cover the royal palace sight seeing as well .. but they should have fees just to visit the emerald buddha. But yeah .. it is an awesome visit to see the emerald Buddha.

Stunning temple inside the palace. Loved this temple in the city. Its beautiful inside and definitely worth going into despite being a little extra and super crowded but this is to be expected as this is a tourist spot . The decour inside and out is amazing and worth taking the time inside to view and outside take some stunning photos

Crowded. Since this temple is inside the Grand Palace, it is very crowded and definitely not peaceful. I was not able to enjoy the inside as i kept being pressured by people making their way inside. The intricate details of the outside are nevertheless impressive.
Vacation . You must see as it's the most important Buddha of all. Very busy and remember to follow the rules no photos of videos . They will catch you.

Pretty cool!. This temple is INSIDE the Grand Palace. You need to buy admission to see both. EXTREMELY crowded, but it is a temple and proper respect towards the religion should be observed at all times. A wonderful site!

beautiful, peaceful, and awe inspiring. If in Bankok you must visit this temple. There is a huge reclining Buddha, all in gold, and it is a fully functioning temple too, so you can really get a feel for the peace and tranquility of the place

The best tourist attraction in Thailand . It's just amazing place...stunning...take the whole day to enjoy it fully...and camera to make beautiful photos 😍 So much gold and art in one place and such an amazing architecture!!! Big wow!!!

NOT TO MISS!!!. This is within the grand palace, meaning you get the ticket for Grand palace and you can see 2 attraction! There again, please come in proper attire. No worries even if you didn't you can get a "sarong" to wrap yourself :)Actually, before we went, i always thought i will get to see a huge statue of Buddha Emerald, but its' was actually a standard statue placed inside a room, so we can only view from Far. It's interesting to know that if you go there during different season, you will actually see the change in costume for the Emerald. Hot season - a stepped, pointed headpiece; a breast pendant; a sash; a number of armlets, bracelets and other items of royal attire. All items are made of enameled gold and embedded with precious and semi-precious stones.Rainy season - a pointed headpiece of enameled gold studded with sapphires; a gold-embossed monk's robe draped over one shoulder.Cool season - a gold headpiece studded with diamonds; a jewel-fringed gold-mesh shawl draped over the rainy season attire.
Great place. Undoubtedly worth seeing. Real Buddhist atmosphere, architecture and style. You can really feel the spirit of this relligion.

Wat Phra Kaeo. The temple is inside the Grand Palace vicinity. You buy the tickets of The Temple and Palace together. The ticket can also be used in Vinmayaka palace which is valid for 1 week. The Buddha statue is very ornate and beautiful.

It's a place that that's nice to visit. It's a must see. It's amazing so totally different from anything in Europe or US. All the ceremonies around it is also a new experience, putting small money in a lot of jars to pay respect.

At the grand palace . Such a magical temple. Take the time to bless yourself for good luck with lotus flowers out front. Then go into temple and feel the magic of this beautiful temple. Very ornate. This is at the grand palace.
Nice interesting place. This place was so beautiful, very busy but a great place to visit. Was on an organised tour which made it better.
awesome palace. they are all in the same area. Was Pho and Wat Phra. So, don't miss it. The architecture of this one is a must. The richness in details worth to see more than once.

The emerald Buddha is quite small. Photos inside the temple are not allowed. People do it but the security really frowns on it. You can get a photo from outside, it won't be terribly clear unless you have a decent camera with a zoom lense.

Very beautiful. Its a must when in Bangkok. A very beautiful architectural designs. Went around 10am and it was crowded with Chinese tourists, they are everywhere. So better be early or before it closes so you can get a good photo of the place.
A must go.. Try and go on a week day where you can sense the vibes of this awesome place. The Buddha holds you in your place and makes you want to revere him even more.

Twice in mylife here and will be more. I always love to come here when I've been Bangkok. Even it really crowd with tourist but i still feel peace when sitting in front of Emerald Buddha. Please remind not to wear short pants or short skirt, also must be shirt not singlet as you must buy or rent shirt outside then they will allow you to go in. Wear socks is helping you walk easily on hot floor.

FYI PLEASE READ. The Grand Palace itself was stunning. They'll give you clothes to wear for 500BHT deposit. IMPORTANT! Several Thai locals told us the temple was closed for a 'holiday', one said it was closed until 2 pm for 'lunch', another said it was closed till 1:30 pm for prayers. These are all LIES! They lie to keep you spending money on the outside of the complex. A man standing outside of the wall with a brown security shirt told us it was closed as well, locals BUY police/security uniforms to ward away the tourists. So rule of thumb; LISTEN TO NO ONE. SEE FOR YOURSELF, walk up to the entrance, ignore everyone, and see if it is closed with your own eyes. The Palace and Temple do not close! They hold the same times every day. Thanks for reading, and please click the 'Helpful' button so no other tourists get tricked like us! Also eat before you go, food is expensive around this area. And as a rule ALWAYS research a tour before you go on it, we were conned into spending 800 BHT per person for a "boat tour" that was nothing but driving up and down the canal. Don't spend too long in Bangkok, you only need a day, and then go somewhere nice like Chiang Mai (the people and city are wonderful there)!

Historic. What our guide told us was this is the temple all Buddist want to visit in their lifetimes. The history is fantastic but know that the crowds are very large. Legs and shoulders have to be covered to enter.

Very interesting!. This site is very historic and important to Thai culture. The importance of this will be clear when you see the great respect with which the Thai people tray this temple. You should definitely go see this if you have time!

Fabulous. fabulous place to visit go and find out for yourself you will not be disappointed ,everything about this place is not to be missed ,weather is very hot and humidity is high ,suggest you carry a face cloth at all times and plenty of water
I expected more. When I went to the temple of the emerald buddha, I thought that Buddha will be bigger than other buddhas, really is a wonderfull place but I expected more.
Gorgeous. The temple is amazing . There are lot of vendors and people nearby and its too crowded but once you are Inside you forget everything as its simply gorgeous

Visit in the afternoon. Wasn't able to enter the temple - unsure if this was due to it being Buddhas birthday- visited in the morning and couldn't even get near the entrance due to tour groups! - visit in the afternoon. I have been many years ago and it's is a subtle but spectacular temple:

Lovely. Beautiful structures and statues. The hand-painted walls are amazing! After visiting so many others, this particular Buddha was somewhat underwhelming. The price is also high compared to other sites.

Peaceful, Beautiful and Awesome Temple !!!. Clam and Quite, The place is with So many Buddha Statues ( Golden) its Emphatic to see. Do not Miss this Place. Tranquil Place to be. Peaceful and huge statues that surprises me. Well Maintained and Clean.

Crowded, loud, hectic and expensive experience. At £10 per ticket, you would expect to enjoy at least a little bit the compound of the temple of the Emerald Buddha... But nothing is done for the visitors' comfort. There were hords of loud Chinese tourists and their even louder guides everywhere. It's a temple, but it didn't feel peaceful at all because of them. Why not having a maximum number of people allowed to visit simultaneously and agents making sure that visitors remain quiet? We weren't given any map so were left wandering around, not knowing what we were seeing and being so overwhelmed by the crowd, the noise and the heat that we probably left without having seen everything.
Beautiful temple. All the temples are beautiful to be honest. This is definitely in the top places to visit whilst in Bangkok. Not one to miss off the list

There are so many Wat.... Of all the Wat I visitd this is my favorite. The size is perfect and the emerald Buddha is beautiful. But it is like everthing else, when you see too much of one thing you get fed up so see this one first.
beautiful murals and very spiritual. But our experience was spoilt by throng of noisy China tourist who were shouting, pushing and didn't respect others
Another spectacle. Again an amazing spectacle and well worth the visit, please respect advise on dress code and honour the Thai reverence to this spectacle

Hot day but totally worth to visit . Beautiful sacred place full of tranquility and peace. Such a contrast to busy streets of Bangkok. Colorful architecture makes it even more appealing. Though it was vet very hot there at the time of our visit- we thoroughly enjoyed visiting the marble temple.

Highest respect. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is viewed by many as one of the most respected temples to visit. Take the time along with a visit to the Grand Palace to enjoy this beautiful place and take in a part of Thai and Buddhism culture.
Crowded. Crowded like you would not believe with tourists. Especially Chinese tourists. A lot of bumping and jostling so watch your personal items carefully.

Along with Grand Palace.. It is in the same complex as Grand palace both make an excellent day trip . Combine with nearby Wat Pho and Wat Arun. Beware of Touts trying to sell you a canal trip - it sounded good but I would prefer to see Grand Palace than do a canal trip if I have to choose one.
Very Very beautiful. This was a great stop - if you only visit one temple complex in Bangkok the Grand Palace and related temples are the complex you need to visit.

Beautiful temples but way too overcrowded. The temples are beautiful and if you like this sort of thing they are worth a visit. I however found it quite expensive and way way too overcrowded. With swarms of people and their selfie-sticks, to the point we had planned to also go to the reclining Budha temple and gave up on the idea.

The Emerald Buddha. Placed in a temple inside the Grand Palace, Wat Phra, the little statue of the Emerald Buddha commands reverence. Placed amidst an elaborate pedestal, the prayer hall is an ocean of silent meditation.

Stunning temple inside the Royal Palace grounds. A highlight of a visit to the Royal Palace, the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a gorgeous temple and can be peaceful if entered between tour groups. No photos are allowed in the temple, but many people come to pray, so the experience is more 'authentic' since you don't risk being clocked with a selfie stick. The temple walls are covered in historical paintings (not dissimilar from Italian frescos in St. Peter's) so it's worth having a gander all around the temple. The emerald Buddha itself must be viewed from a distance, but is still spectacular. It's one of the best temples I've visited in SE Asia.

Fabulous private tour . Booked a tour through the Anatara riverside hotel, just for the 3 of us so we got really looked after. Reclining bhudda, wat poh and grand palace only a half day tour but worth every penny..
Worth a look.. 100 baht entry free, includes small bottle of water. I was ok wearing knee length shorts, girls needed sarongs provided for free.

Breathtaking but too Crowded. Well, actually everything you need to know has been already posted in all of the reviews below. No sandals, no shorts, no tanktop.It's very hot, very crowded, and there are so many tourists from Asian country. It's almost impossible to take a good picture.. There were so many people crossing, and it's hard to tell them to give you just a little time and space to take a photo.But, since it's a landmark, and the temple is beautiful, it's worth to visit.

Beautiful and most important Temple .. The Emerald Budha is carved from a single block of jade. There are tour guides from 10 am to 2 pm. You have to walk a lot so wear comfortable shoes.No shorts, sandals, revealing clothes are permitted. You can either buy long shorts or rent it from a facility.The temple closes at 3.30.You have to pay to enter but its worth it. You feel very peaceful in the temple.Please keep hydrated as it can get very hot.

One of the best. Please know that this is actually located in the same entry fee and location as the grand palace, so you will be able to see both on one trip. Also be warned that it is very busy and can be a bit overwhelming but the grounds are absolutely incredible. Maybe the best temple in all of Bangkok. You must wear long pants as a man (no long shorts like at other temples) and no tank tops. For women you must have a long dress or cover up. If you do not they actually have a nice little rental set up. You give 300 baht and when you're done and return the clothes they refund your money which was very nice. Make sure you see this in Bangkok!!

Beautiful, but SO crowded.. The Emerald Buddha was surprisingly small but very beautiful, though you are not allowed to take pictures once you pass the threshold. Pictures from outside were fine though and I was glad my camera could mostly compensate for the lighting difference and zoom for a decent picture.I am not very big on crowds though, and a thick pressing crowd made a quick poke inside the building and near crush to get back out, not so fun. I actually enjoyed the buildings surrounding the area a lot more and managed to get a picture or two that didn't include dozens of people.Remember, especially if you are going in the hot (is there any other?) season... pack lots of water where you can (or buy it right after the entrance for the few places that don't allow you to bring in water), and have a sun-hat and fan. Heat stroke is a high risk.

A Must Go when in Bangkok. If you are going to Thailand and not visiting the What Phra Keo you haven`t been in Thailand. The only negative are the very loud speaking chinese groups. 20 Years ago it was a square of silence!!!
Brilliant twmple. Such an amazing place to see. Need at least a couple of hours to see it properly. Read up about it before you go espeixlly the story of the emerald Buddha.

Amazing hysterical . Visited Bangkok was not completed if we are not to be here ... amazing culture in Bangkok and as we know mostly religion is Budha We can go there by water transportation or by taxi but we choose by ship and wonderful experience that we here

A-- for Amazing. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a wonderment to behold. Visiting the temple and the Grand Palace is a great compliment to each other.Tip: have your camera ready to snap many photos. You can get gorgeous pictures at many different angles.
Peace...... With my brother N Sister we had a great time out here. planning next one with our new member to the family Will be back soon Bangkok

Bangkok must see. This is one of the must see Bangkok tourist attractions. Very large area and can be very busy. The Emerald Buddha is a lot smaller that I imagined and sadly visitors are not allowed to take photos. The B500 charge for Wat Phra Kaew and The Grand Palace I thought was quite expensive although it is free for Thais.

Cannot take photos inside and it is very very far away and crazy crowded. I was a bit disappointed with this one but glad it was complex with the grand palace so it did not waste a trip. The Buddah is made of Jade and wears gold clothes that are changed with the season. However, it was so crowded on a Wednesday that you get pushed and shoved up the stairs to the room it is held in. No photography allowed so I didn't know that it is set very far back and very high so it is really difficult to get a good look. I wouldn't waste my time unless it is not crowded or you want to see it for religious reasons.

Beautiful. The largest reclining buddha is the world, it's just a magnificent view. Every part of the temple is detailed as well with intricate decorations. You can buy a bucket of coins to throw along the corridor of the temple for good luck.

Beautiful but crowded. The Emerald Buddha normally gets included in trips to the Royal Palace. The Buddha is beautiful if small. It has different robes depending on the season. It will be crowded as it is in the Palace and is inundated with half of China complete with selfie sticks and umbrellas. But if you can avoid such weapons then it is worth a visit.

Very beautiful. The temple is inside the Grand palace. The grandeur of the temple catches the eye. The golden shiny buildings all around made us feel like we stood in a different era. Emerald Buddha shrine was stunning. They close at 3:30 PM everyday, so should go in the morning hours to see the place. Entrance fee for this is included in the ticket to Grand palace. Some days when they have official ceremonies, they close down the sanctum and insides of palace without notice. I got to know when I was at the gate to buy tickets, but I attempted to go the next day and enjoyed my visit.

Beautful- a must see!. This temple is udderly amazing- a must see when traveling to bangkok. It can get very crowded, so the earlier, the better, which will also help if it is hot too since you must be covered esp if you are a women. I recommend bringing an umbrella if its going to be especially sunny!

An amazing experience in Bangkok. The lines can be long and hopefully one is able to find their shoes upon exiting the Temple. Never-the-less, the wait was worth it since the splendor of the temple is awesome and a must see for the visitor to Bangkok.

Can't see!. Was looking forward to seeing the Emerald Buddha having read so much about it. The history was fascinating and I was expecting it to be well within sight of a camera shot. Unfortunately so were hundreds of other people. It is on-high and unless you are very tall, or have very sharp elbows it is difficult to see. Fortunately I had an official guide who was very determined for me to see and photograph, actually pushed the tourists aside for me to get through, I was a little embarrassed but really appreciated her brisk approach. Hope you have a better view than I, perhaps you should either go early in the morning or later in the day, do check opening and closing times before you go or you may be disappointed!

Great place to go instead of the Grand Palace.. A far more relaxed and less busy place than the Grand Palace, you'll love it here. It's far cheaper to get in too, and you can relax in these beautiful surroundings and take your time.

amazing thai experience. It is definitely worth the visit in order to learn something about their culture and religion, but you have to consider the clothes you wear because there are strict regulation about that, if you are not dressed properly, they provide clothes for free (you need to pay a deposit, but they return it back after you return the clothes). Also, it is very crowded and could be really hot depending on the weather.
NICE TO SEE. Nice place for a person to see which is just in-front side of Grand Palace. Really interesting place.
absolutely beautiful!. such a magnificent complex - with the temple and palace. a little bit pricey to get into, but overall worth seeing as the temple is so impressive!

Beautiful statue. We came early in the day when it wasn't as crowded. The whole complex is more impressive when you know the history behind it. We had a guide with us to show us around and so we discovered a lot that we would not have known otherwise.

enchanting. one of the best temples i have ever seen in y life.
The Buddha is really small and u will se only from far..but doesn't really matter cause everything around is incredibly beautiful.a MUST see

Amazing Architecture. I went to Wat Phra Kaew a few months ago as a school field trip with my friends. I was amazed by the architectural design of the Wat (temple). The temple was a bit crowded, but it was totally worth seeing.  What I like about the Wat is that there are many paintings inside the Wat. You can see the stories of Thai legend that were told from century to century. When I visited, there was also a guide who would lead us from place to place. That made it easy for us because it allowed us to visit the important ones and the guide also gave great explanations about each place. For example, when we visited one of the Wat with lots of paintings, the guide explained what the paintings were about and what the stories told. I found these stories very interesting. I would recommend you to ask for a guide so that he or she could explain the architecture to you. What I disliked was that it was crowded, so you might find it a bit irritating walking around with many people blocking your way. Another thing was that it was very hot on the day I visited, so I was sweating all over. We had to occasionally hide in the shade before visiting each new section. The most important thing to remember when going there is that you should bring an umbrella because it gets very hot in the afternoon. Other than an umbrella, you might bring hats or sunglasses to protect you from the UV of the sun. I would also recommend you to apply on sunblock because the ray of the sun might cause you to have sunburn. Other than that, you should be able to enjoy the amazing architecture of Wat Phra Kaew.
Amazing!. Amazing! So beautiful and worth the lines to see! It is a shame how the poor people live, while the rich have great treasure!

Don't enter if there's lots of chinese tourists. Make sure to wear long pants (no rips jeans) & tshirt. We went there on saturday, there's a bunch of chinese tourists. It's a very hot sunny day (almost 40 degree) We have to queue very long line & We couldn't see anything but only ppl's head. There's lack of explanation of the directions n building history.
Superb serenity. Superbly seren and gives an amazing feeling when one visits such places in this era of hustling & bustling lifestyle
Awe-Inspiring!!. Unbelievably beautiful. My only complaint was that the weather was uncomfortably hot & humid (late April 2016).
Gorgeous Architecture. Stopped by in June, definitely a sight to see if you're interested in Thai culture. There are a lot vendors nearby also if you're wanting to buy souvenirs.

Quite Stunning. As with all the attractions and my comments on all of these sites to visit, do it with a guide. We hired one before coming to Thailand but you can hire them cheaper at the gate. Either way for us it was inexpensive way to understand what each of the sites are, what they stand for and when they were built. Dress sense continues here, as you will find that all these attractions are within walking distance and when it comes to going inside the actual temple where you are not supposed to take photo's you not only must be dressed appropriately but also remove your shoes and hats.You can marvel at the detail of the jeweled statues and painted gold designs but to understand what they are doing you need a guide.
Amazing temple. Love the architecture. It's great and awesome with glowing gold everywhere.Note: wear polite clothes, or you nees to rent a fabric or clothes to cover your body
Breathtaking. Its just fabulous, but you MUST go there at opening time. Tours busloads arrive 9.00 on & soon gets v crowded.

Definitely worth a visit but be ready to fight your way through crowds. You can't really come to Bangkok without seeing the Emerald Buddha, definitely worth spending a day seeing all the sights in the area.
Unfortunately, this attraction draws large crowds at all times so be ready to push your way through all the selfie taking tourists.

Beautiful temple, unimpressive statue. Central structure in the Grand Palace, beautifully decorated both inside (murals) and outside (artistic bling). The Buddha statue itself is fairly small and difficult to see.

This will blow your mind. The Temple of Emerald Buddha or Wat Phra Kaew is the pinnacle of Thai architecture and the richness of its culture including inspirations from different religions and such as Hinduism and not just Buddhism. The 112 Garudas on which the the temple stands tall, the adjacent buildings such as library, the replica of Siem Reap temple and the murals of Ramayana on the wall are simply one of its kind and reflects the essence of Thai culture especially Buddhism in Thailand. Being part of the Royal Grand Palace premise, this temple is in a small area yet very well maintained. Inside the main temple of Emerald Buddha, the precious stones, the statue of Buddha dressed up as per the season, everything shows the grandeur of this temple and richness of the culture plus tradition. A must visit for anyone visiting Bangkok, irrespective of their religious beliefs.

An absolute must. An amazing walk around a gem of historical buildings and for a very reasonable price.... I would suggest starting early in the morning when it's a bit cooler.... Shoulders and legs must be covered when entering and they have a changing facility where you can also borrow the odd shirt etc... Be warned the clothes they lend out will have been worn by many visitors and can pong a bit :-pWe stayed in riverside so got the water taxi over and then it was a few minutes walk ..... There is a lot to see so allocate enough time and a Camera is a must.Take plenty of water it gets very warm in and around the buildings and the buildings are very reflective and amplify the heat .

so much detail, be sure to plan a few hours here. This was a must see for me. There are over 25 buildings to explore in the Grand Palace complex. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is towards the beginning of the complex, and no photos can be taken inside. You must also take your shoes off to enter, and the ground will be hot outside so take care. There is so much beauty in the detail of this temple, it is almost overwhelming. Also, be sure to be respectful of the monks that are worshipping inside.

Well worthwhile, but very busy.... The Temple is in the same complex as The Grand Palace. We certainly recommend you take the time to visit this attraction. Allow at least two hours for this.A few words of caution: ladies you need to ensure your shoulders are covered, and men also need trousers to below the knee, Shorts of knee-length don't cut it! Folk with visible tattoos may be prevented from entering - no body art permitted, although this didn't seem to be vigorously applied. There are many areas within the complex to visit, but all are enjoyable and certainly worth the cost and the crowds. The Emerald Buddha is quite small, but is a work of art. We never got to the Reclining Buddha.And our return journey to our hotel in a high-speed tuk-tuk wrapped up a pleasant day.
Amazing place to visit. A visit to the Emerald Buddha Temple located in the heart of Bangkok is a must. It is one of the master pieces in idol making and is a beautiful piece of art.

A sight to see. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a Buddhist temple in Bangkok. You can see the Emerald Buddha quite clearly. It is not really an emerald but it is jade, which is considered to have magical powers. Please remember tat you are in a house of worship and pay due respect. By the way, if any tuk-tuk driver offers you a ridiculously low fare to take you to the attractions, do not accept the offer he is a tout

the largest and beautiful thai temple. Temple of the emerald Buddha is an iconic temple! very beautiful decorate, Thai richness in design. A bit crowd the day we went. a lot of chinese tourist I would say. But this attraction is world class. Everyone must come here to see the Thai culture.

Excellent. Highly recommended. . Fantastic temple, one of the most beautiful temples I've visited. It's 100% better if you hire a private tour guide at the front door. You learn so much and get much more out the trip. It's a set price per person, I think for two we paid a coupe of pounds for a hour tour. Without a guide you miss out on lots of the meaning and sentiment behind the statues and buildings.
Good attraction. Good attraction and one of the many attractive Buddhist temples in Bangkok. Admission fees (inclusive of Grand palace) make this a expensive visit.

"A lovely palace"". This is a very busy attraction because it is very small and I would advise going early in the morning. The Budda is actually very small and photos are strictly not allow. But you can buy postcard outside.

Worth a visit. Definitely a must see in Bangkok. It's crowded and you will burn your feet after taking off your shoes. But when you enter the temple it is quiet and calm, and everyone - tourist or local - sits on the floor and prays, takes in the surroundings or just enjoys the cool air and decorative building. After you exit, sacred water will be dribbled onto your head, and you will walk away with a new experience in your pocket. Don't forget your shoes, the stones are like fire on a warm day.

Beautiful must see as part of the Grand Palace Tour - needs a guide. Can be very busy so be prepared. This is a sacred sight so you must dress appropriately as you must for entrance to the Grand Palace & any of the buildings in the complex. This is one of those tours that are much better with a guide as otherwise you would miss a lot - please note no photos in here

One could not stay inside too long.... It was a city tour after our conference in last October. Part of the wonders in Thailand was the temple visiting. It was a hot and humid day when we visited. When you were at the entrance you had to take off your shoes. The place was packed and guess what the smell was like when we all took of our shoes. It was not a pretty smell...I just stayed for about 5 mins with a quick tour and got out. Sorry to say the hygiene was not too good...

Amazing. We have been all over Thailand and seen many stunning temples. I think wat phra kaew is possibly the best, it is certainly in the top 3. The grand palace's admission fee is worth it just to see this temple.

Stunning building, but extremely crowded. The temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew) is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple in Thailand. The construction of the temple begin in 1785 and is housed in the same complex as the Grand Palace. Only HM The King may approach the Emerald Buddha (which is actually made of jade, the term Emerald being used to describe the colour rather than the material from which the Buddha is made). The Buddha is a lot smaller than you think, the room containing it is beautifully decorated but this doesn't take away from the Buddha being of central importance. A visit to the Emerald Buddha should certainly be on your tour plans if you are going the Grand Palace but can be incredibly crowded.The room gets incredibly hot so have lots of water available and please dress appropriately, this is a religious site, so crop tops and shorts are not acceptable. Photos are not allowed at this site.

My third visit - still amazing!. It is my third visit there, and every time I discovered something new! Wat Phra Khew or the Temple of Emareld Buddha is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple in Thailand. Located in the historical center of Bangkok within the grounds of Grand Palace, it enshrined the Emareld Buddha - the highly revered Buddha image meticulously carved from a single block of jade. The Emareld Buddha is a Buddha image in the meditation position dating from the 15th century A.D. This temple is actually a building complex covering an area of 234 acres, have over 100 buildings with more than 200 years of Royal history. The main building in the center is Phra Ubosot where the image of Emareld Buddha situated. There are other interesting structures such as Angker Wat, the Balcony where murals tells Ramayana epic in its entirety, the Gate keeping Guards etc. Reaching there is either by taxi or boat. Tickts are available from 8-30 AM to 3-30 PM daily, cost of which is 500 THB. This covers the Grand Palace and the Temple of Reclining Buddha as well as Dusit Palace. An early morning visit would beat the heat and crowd as tourist buses uaually comes around 10 AM and the place becomes very crowded specially on holidays. A dress code is strictly followed - shorts and open shoulder are not allowed in the temple. Cloths are available for hire. It is possible to visit all these places in half day on your own. Free english language tour are available from inside the temple four times a day. Audio guide are also available in different language @ THB 200. Please keep a bottle of drinking water with you.

Dazzling. A very popular pagoda. I rate it as a must do. The atmosphere inside is charged and impressive. The gilded tiles, tinkling bells, milling crowds of devout devotees and inquisitive tourists, the dazzling mirror work, the Angkor Wat replica and the guarding Yakshas all make for excellent photography subjects. Loved my visit here.

A very religious place. The Buddha itself is quite small but the atmosphere is great. Again, you have to visit the place taking your shoes off, so bring socks if you don't like to walk barefoot. No pictures inside...I saw a security guard beating a cheeky tourist with the sign 'no pictures'....
Beautiful . A great experience although I warn you the Buddha is pretty small. So don't go expecting a giant statue. It's also fun to employ a guide. Information aside ours was really entertaining!

Magnificent. This is a must see when in Bangkok. Make sure to come early to beat the crowd and the sun. The entrance fee is 500 baht but it's so worth it. The architecture is breathtaking.
Wear something comfotable and conservative (no sleeveless shirts, plunging necklines and shorts above the knee). Don't forget to bring water and sunscreen.
Gorgeous. So colorful and magical, a must see in Bangkok if you are into temples. Gets very crowded and hot so wear light clothes. Wear long pants too.

Busy everyday go early. The entire area is busy with tourists everyday and can be crazy busy with tour groups. Best to get their early when the doors open and make sure you wear long pants and cover up your arms. Otherwise you they will not let you in and you will need to buy or rent clothing which is cheap and close but you will need to re line up.

Stunning Emerald Stone Buddha. This temple is inside Grand Palace complex so the entry is 500 baht.It's very crowded and noisy and photography is prohibited inside the temple but I saw some people taking Pictures which I found disrespectful.The statue is at a distance and fully made with Emerald stone which I found stunning.

Very interesting. It is good to visit these temples on a small group tour. We were a party of two with a private guide. It is much more interesting when you have a great guide that can take you around and explain things. Take foot cleaners with you as you have to take your shoes off to enter the temples.
Beautiful!. Worth a visit, beautiful temple. As with all the temples it is important to demonstate respect to Buddha

Good Place and must visit!. This is a place where you can be at peace with the Lord Buddha at many corners. Dress appropriately is expected by the authorities and they are very particular about it. No sleevless and clothing below knee length. In case you have not dressed so, you can hire them for free for a deposit of THB 200 and return the same once you have completed the tour of both Grand Palace and Emerald Buddha. Reach the Grande Palace at 8.30am so that all the temples of tourist attractions can be covered on the same day as they are very close to each other.

Beautiful and memorable visit . Absoluely stunning temples and an amazing opportunity to see the unique design and the beautiful materials used in the construction of the sacred temples. Another example of the deeply spiritual and beautiful nature of the Thai people and their history. One of the many highlights was the miniature Angkor Wat replica.

This temple is a vision of great beauty. I was delighted to see this, although the public are kept far away from the emerald buddha itself. My visit was made more interesting by my guide's commentary.
Another beautiful wat. The emerald Buddah is really made of jade. Beautiful, peaceful building. The incense and fresh flowers made this a sensory highlight.
Beauty of Buddhism can be seen here.. A wonderful art & architecture can be seen. The golden & glowing colours catches ones attention and you can not take away your eyes from every piece of marvel.

"Really nice experience". This is one of the most beautiful temple in Thailand,I have been to. and one must visit it if you are on a tight touring schedule of Bangkok. However, I would recommend to go to other provinces to see other majestic temples, and this one was very touristy and crowded. But it really worth it.

Worth seeing but be ready for crowds. This is a very famous site and well worth seeing. But to do you must brave the bot sun and large crowds. Also, remember where you left your shoes when you took them off or you will search quite a while for them.
Beautiful Buddhist Temple. Every Buddhist temple we visited in Bangkok was incredible. It is impossible to pick one over the others. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha was exceptionally beautiful!

Magnificent temple. The emerald Budha was placed at the top. People was not allowed to take picture or touch it. Only His Majesty the King may touch the emerald Budha. The architectures outside and inside were indeed remarkable. The temple located inside the grand palace and entrance fee are included in the 500Bath grand palace ticket. Open everyday 8.30am to 4 pmbjt last entrance allowed was 3.30pm.Proper clothing should be use, no shoes, no hats, no sunglasses were allowed inside. Shoes should be placed at the shoes rack outside but they dont guarantee its safety. So if you travel in pair or groups, you can take turns going inside whilst the other guarding the shoes or you can bring your own shoe bag to carry it. Oh and no worries if you dont dress properly, at the main gate they rent you proper clothing and there were also changing rooms if you bring your own clothing for thia visit.

Awesome . We went on a guided to see this temple which is located on the same property as the grand palace. There was huge crowds and very difficult to get around. There was so much to see .we first saw the the ramakien murals, then the huge golden chedi. We also saw the mythical creatures and the model of angkor wat.we then went into the temple of the emerald buhda which is the most sacred image in the Thai Kingdom, the enamel and porcelain decorations on the building and the intricate carving and the woodwork was really awesome, worth a visit .

must see in Bangkok. No pictures allowed inside , but still amazing atmosphere. Dress appropriately when visiting this great place. Can get crowded at times , so be prepared , but still very worth it!

Very hot, very crowded, very very beauiful. The Wat Phra Kaew is an over 200 years royal temple of national significance. It is located in the Grand Palace complex in Rattanakosin district, the historic part of town on the East bank of the Chao Phraya river.Visited the spot in a hot sunlight day (38 C ~terrible!!). Got there by BTS and boat. Starting point (Central pier) of the Tourist boat is located at the exit 2 of the BTS Saphan Taksin Station. You can spend 40 Baht to get the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew, or buy a one day pass (150 Baht ) to get multiple spots along the river.The temples were built in the Rattanakosin style, with a very elegant and splendid decoration. The roof is embellished with polished orange and green tiles and the pillars are inlaid in brilliant mosaic. Gorgeous temples!!There were so many tourists. Very crowded. Be noticed that the opening time is from 8:30 AM to 3:30 PM.
Good temple, must to see in once time in life. Good temple, must to see in once time in life, it is one of the must look location in Bangkok for real family visitors.
Stunning!. Stunning! Remember to wear a long sleeved shirt and pants or dress below the knees out of respect for the buddist religion.
good. good place and one of the holy places for the Thais.Situated inside the Grand palace so quite crowded when we visited.

Wonderful palace. We arrived early in the morning, but the place was already packed with large tour groups making it difficult to navigate. But it was well worth the trip if you could find a space to separate oneself from the mass groups. We did invest in a personal and authorized tour guide who spoke in English for us and divulged the history and details of the architecture. Again, it was worth the investment unless you have done research before visiting.

Gorgeous Temple. Wat Phra Kaew also known as the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is only one small part of the Grand Palace complex. By far the most expensive temple Thai I visited, but at a cost of approximately $16 it was well worth the price of admission. This is a must see. It is very crowded and takes quite a long time to see the entire complex. I made a day of it by visiting Wat Pho and Wat Phra Kaew on the same day. Big mistake. Do yourself a favor and visit each temple complex separately, you will be glad you did. A lot of tourists combine both temples into a single trip because of their close proximity, but I will hold fast to the opinion that you will get more from your experience if you visit them separately.Also, be sure to visit the museum before you leave the grounds. Crowded, crowded, crowded. Prepare yourself mentally for a huge crowd and very long lines, and you will enjoy this delightful temple with all of its rich ornaments. Almost every inch of the exterior as well as the interior is adorned with shiny, sparkly, lavish, faux jewels of some kind. Simply Amazing. Allow yourself to get lost in the splendor.NOTE: There is no photography allowed inside the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Please do not be the obnoxious person who gets caught taking photos. Trust me, it really distracts from the tremendous spiritual experience. Put your camera down and simply bask in the aura of the atmosphere. Great place for a quick meditation and or prayer. You will blend right in.This temple is stunning to say the least.

Beautiful but too much for me.... I will begin by saying that I have been to Japan twice and though this was our first time in Thailand, we had already visited many temples as part of our travels. From Tokyo to Nara, Kyoto, Phuket and Ayutthaya... we have been to a number of very famous temples and thus I feel travelled enough to pass comment on the temple. Unfortunately, maybe through no fault of its own, Wat Phra Kaew ranks towards the bottom!We visited here with our two boys (6 and 2) at the end of March and just found it VERY stressful to be honest. Firstly, it was just insanely busy and full of groups of Chinese tourists pushing and shoving. Secondly, one of the ladies who works there was very aggressive and rude to my wife in demanding she covered her shoulders. While we respect tradition and customs, the manner in which she was told was horrible. I know one person cannot be held accountable for the whole site, but it was still poor. What ensued was a LONG queue to pay a (returnable) deposit for appropriate robes and then another VERY LONG wait to receive our money back. The whole system wasted time (not good in the sweltering heat, especially with young kids) queueing like cattle for robes and people pushing in the queue etc. Many of the other temples in Thailand just have a box of clothes and operate on a basis of trust (i.e. you will return anything you borrow) so I am guessing that given the size and popularity of the place, it has been a victim of its own success. Nevertheless, the system needs reviewing. I estimate over an hour was spent (in total) queueing.The temple and grounds itself was impressive; lots of gold and flamboyance and perhaps on a quieter day, we might have been able to enjoy it, but on this occasion, especially considering it was the most expensive temple we have visited (some are just 50 - 100 BHT) it failed to deliver, sorry. I would therefore advise travellers to try and avoid the traffic and get there earlier (we went around 2pm) or maybe even later. Traveller tip 1 - see above (re: times of arrival)Traveller tip 2 - Wat Pho (5-10 mins walk) is close to Phra Kaew and I found this to be more enjoyable.Traveller tip 3 - be careful outside and avoid the con-artists. We were approached within seconds of getting out of our taxi by a "friendly" localler wanting to know where we were visiting. When we told him, he told us that it was closed. I assume he wanted to take us to buy jewels or a tailored suit or something. Fortunately, I had been clued up beforehand but the more naive or trusting of travellers might have fallen victim to it.
Somptuous temple!. A great monument and temple to visit. A lot of history and one can see all the devotion one may have for Buddha. This place is unique and by far the place to visit in Bangkok.
Quite lovely but small. Certainly something not to miss when visiting Bangkok. No photos allowed of the buddha but postcards available for purchase.

Stunning!. By the time I arrived it was incredibly hot and crowded, but completely worth the visit! The detail on each of the building is absolutely amazing, and I loved the history associated with the entire place. Allow a couple of hours for exploration - you will be rewarded.
Interesting but way to crowded. It is the main temple of Bangkok. Really nice and impressive.But it is way to crowded. A lot of tourists, making the experience less valuable.

Breath taking. Make sure you visit the Temple of the Emerald Buddha when you visit the Grand Palace. There is no photography allowed inside and make sure to dress properly; no shorts, tank tops or flip flops

Eye opening but very busy!. We were outnumbered by the Chinese tourists the day we visited, and so found ourselves dodging umbrellas in the eye and shoulder to shoulder shuffling around the temple. It was a shame really, maybe they need to limit the amount of tourists they allow in at anyone time to make it a more pleasurable experience to view this amazing place.
Must see. Temple of the Emerald Buddha is unique and great place to visit. The statue itself is small and you can take pictures only from outside so be prepare with your tele lens .

Amazing site to see. The Buddha statue is very far away and high up, so the Buddha itself appears smaller than one would expect. Like many temples…no pictures allowed. While the Buddha status is the focus pay attention to the art on the wall, ceilings, and doors. All are ornate and beautiful. Walking around the facility is fantastic…so much to visually absorb. It is a busy place with worshippers and tourists, but well worth the time. Absolutely gorgeous to see and experience.
Beautiful. This is a very busy attraction and I would advise going early in the morning. The Budda is actually very small and photos are strictly not allow. Why??

Amazing. Once you enter the temple, you will felt peaceful and calm, its a feeling that cant describe by words. the design there is amazing stunning .Strongly recommended a must place to come when you visit BANGKOK
Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew). Beautiful and interesting Temple that I have visited twice.Can be crowded at times, but take your time, its worth it.

Breath-taking. The Emerald Buddha itself is quite small but the temple is overwhelmingly beautiful. Make sure you take the time the absorb the extravagance of this temple, though easier said than done with the crowds.
Impressive. This was very impressive. The Buddha gets a different outfit for each of the four seasons. We saw the winter outfit.

Cultural Awe. The one place that if you don't visit, you'll kick yourself forever. We took a tuc-tuc there whom patiently waited for u. The ticket queue was nit long, just one person on front of us. So after a slow entrance, we 'hooked' up with an English group tour guide and listened to her whole explanation and history lesson. We felt privileged to learn so much about Buddhism in a lovely session. Be prepared to take off your shoes and observe local custom - no shorts and no open shoulders. After all it's a holy place of offering and serenity. Spectacular architecture and lot's of attention to detail. So much GOLD!Put this on your Thailand 'bucket list'....
You must visit the Emerald Buddha in BKK. This is one of the most beautiful temples in BKK. The emerald Buddha is just impressive.. there is no other word to define the emerald Buddha. Don't miss it!

Peaceful temple. This temple is located within the grand Palace complex and you need to pay a 500 Baht entrance fee for the entire grand palace. Be sure to be dressed respectfully. No shorts, sleeveless tops etc. The architecture is stunning.

Visit the Emerald Buddha and Gain Understanding. There's nothing like praying with a polyglot crowd to put you in touch with your membership in the Human Family. Definitely worth the trip up the river to see this famous icon.

the best place to visit in bangkok. I spent my whole day in here analyzing the history and a moment of patience inside the Emerald Buddha temple. There's a lot of people but the peaceful palace will make you forget all your worries. i highly recommend to anyone who is visiting Thailand. This is what makes Thailand so popular.

The place you must go !!!. Other name " Wat Phra Kaew " is the most respective and important of Thai People. Wonderful and fabulous place that you can have a lot of beautiful picture ther.Have very shiny emerald Buddha stay there. You must to dress yourself very polite and lady must not to dress trousers.

Visual delight. This temple is a collection of buildings that are visually stunning and a must see for any visit to Bangkok. Beware the guys who try to get you into a tuk tuk for a couple of hours, via the usual tailor or gem store, only to end up back at the temple. They will con you but ignore and make your own way into the temple.

Amazing architecture. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is located inside the Royal Palace. It cost $500 baht to get into both. The architecture is absolutely amazing. The details of the workmanship just blew me away! I could just stand there and take in all the sights. The only draw back are the hoards of Chinese tours there. It was almost 100 degrees F, and tons of people. They were so loud and annoying. We got there when the place open, thinking we will miss the crowd.....wrong! BTW....the dress code is strict! Women have to cover their legs to the ground and shoulders. I read on trip advisor that bringing a shawl was ok, well it was not. I had a tank top maxi dress with a shawl, and I had to go borrow (you leave a deposit and you get it back upon return) a thick cotton button shirt....did I say it was 100 F! Do yourself a favor and wear a dry fit type of shirt with a short sleeve. You can get there by taking the BTS to Saphan Taksin, follow the sighs to the pier and catch the ferry to Tha Chang. You follow the crowd and walk about 2-3 blocks.

Unique Buddhist Temple. There are Buddhist temples all over Bangkok (Thailand and SE Asia for that matter); however, this one is a little different. Of the various temples, this is the only one that I know of that has an "emerald Buddha". They actually dress the emerald Buddha in 3 different sets of gold clothing which is changed for each of Thailand's 3 seasons (i.e summer, rainy, and cool). The actual emerald Buddha statue was a lot smaller than I anticipated though. Also, our guide indicated that emerald is just the color, it is actually made from a jade or jasper material. The temple is a large compound beside the Grand Palace. The temple is well maintained/preserved with other interesting architecture features and statues. Another feature that they have is a miniature model of the famous Cambodian temple complex Angkor Wat. Since I had actually been to Angkor Wat, the model was not all that impressive to me. My ticket was for both the Grand Palace and Wat Pra Keaw; so combing the 2 attractions, this has to be one of the top attractions in Bangkok. Maybe even the top one.
Simply superb . Grand and beautiful temple. Great architectural design and style. Too much crowded when I visited. This temple is inside the Grand palace. Minute details and design, great work.
If you have time for only one , then it is THIS temple only. one of the most magical places in Bangkok, where I do kep coming back trip after trip. beautiful, peaceful, do not miss it !
Awesome tourist attraction. Honestly it's a bit to get it but well worth it everything is well preserved and taken care of in the Grand Palace where the emeral buddha is located

A really neat experience and stunning, unique place. I shared in my Wat Pho review as this was part of my tour; two temples; Wat Pho Complex and Grand Palace which has the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Photos of the complex, both complexes, are on that review site
t
Amazing. Amazing place.Just feels peaceful the moment you enter.The statue is beautiful.Nothing like it anywhere else.If you're in Bangkok,you shouldn't miss out on this one.

It's a 'Don't Miss' on a Bangkok trip!. Very hot and very busy, as other reviewers have also said and I almost gave this a 4 star rating because of that, BUT get there early and you're in for a real treat!! We had a private tour guide which was WELL worth paying for. She arranged our tickets, bought us drinks and was extremely knowledgeable about everything we were looking at which makes it SO much more interesting! And I just love the reverence in which the Thai people hold their King... Dress code wasn't quite as strict as we'd expected. Open sandals were ok but must cover shoulders and have at least three quarter length trousers on. When visiting the Emerald Buddha, all shoes must be removed. The buddha is up quite high and fascinating to hear that his 'clothes' are changed season to season, and that it is the King himself who does the change (or his son if his health does not allow it!) Details from a tour guide (and MANY more) which we would've been unaware of if we'd visited alone! Thoroughly enjoyed this visit, would highly recommend as part of any Bangkok itinerary!

Beautiful with lots of golden buddhas. This was one of the best temples that we visited as far as being accessible and not crowded. You can get up close to the buddhas and photo shots are easily available.

Stunning!. This is part of the Grand Palace compound, absolutely stunning. A compound filled with mythological figures statues, pagodas, temples, chedis, a very varied mix of architecture.Highly recommended.

smaller than expected. the temple is located within the grand palace complex so you would need to have a ticket to enter. the ticket costs 500 bhat and you would need to dress conservatively. (long pants and covered shoulders). if you don't have it you can leave a deposit and collect the items from the entrance. the complex is a extremely crowded and packed with heaps of tourists and tour groups and selfie sticks everywhere! once inside there is a lot to see but very little signage. the temple is located quite close to the main entrance, you will see everyone leaving their shoes outside. inside it is cool and lovely. there is not much to see but the building itself is beautiful. the emerald buddha is quite tiny for the size of the place but you will not be able to stay for the long as the crowd will generally push you out. but overall the complex is quite a highlight of any trip especially to admire the magnificent architecture and handiwork.

Beautiful, big, touristy. This is a beautiful temple in Thailand and a must go if you are on a tight touring schedule of Bangkok. However, I would recommend to go to other provinces to see other majestic temples, and this one was very touristy and crowded.
Too modern. Well, i expected a huge buddha statue but its small one. of cause its emerald..you have to remove shoes and socks to enter.

Quite good but no pics allowed. Good pictures from outside of the building and with zoom can see the wee fella.The rest of the buildings add more to this experience which is part of the Grand Palace 10 quid ticket
Pretty cool. It was pretty darn crowded and can be overwhelming with the sun beating down on you, but quite a site to behold.

Golden palace!. My first impression of this palace is "WOW" you can see golden things all over the temple, it was too pretty, the main palace itself is a piece of extraordinary art. the paintings on the ceiling, and the small tiles they put to create such a beautiful wall and floors. when you planned to visit this palace, or any other palace in thailand, make sure you wear polite clothing, no short skirt, pants, and sleeveless shirt allowed, but don't worry they provide a scarf renting for you to cover you body parts.

Finest place to visit in Bangkok on a Day Tour. For the culture of Thailand and the glittery temples, this is one of the must visit places in Bangkok. So be it a day tour or a stay on an On Arrival visa, i would recommend.

Fabulous. Jaw dropping lay beautiful place, definitely go with a local guide otherwise you would not be able to know what it's all about. Go in the morning its do hot in the afternoon. Ladies shoulders and legs must be covered and men must have at least 3/4 trousers on.

Take a deep breath and enjoy. This temple is gorgeous. Can get extremely crowded though, so try to go early in the day as others have suggested. Once there, even if it's crowded try not to get swept away in the sea of people and just enjoy the sights. It's easy to get overwhelmed by the hoards of tourists, but just wear your bag on the front of your body (to avoid any potential pickpocketers) and let your eyes, body, and mind wander. Oh yeah, and drink plenty of water. As for the Emerald Buddha, it's smaller than you might expect, but still amazing.

A wonderful experience - just try and avoid the crowds!. This is my second visit to Wat Phra Kaew and the Grand Palace (this temple is part of the complex). It's an amazing visit and so beautiful, you mustn't miss out on visiting if you are in Bangkok. One issue we had was how many thousands of tourists were there when we visited. It can get a bit overwhelming trying to deal with the crowds to really enjoy the experience. We asked our hotel concierge who suggested if we make another visit we aim to be there for the very first two or last two hours of the day to get away from the crowds, and to have a little less heat to deal with. Nonetheless, it was a wonderful experience and so very beautiful. Make sure you're clear on what to wear when you go - it's easy to find out, but we saw so many people turning up in sleeveless T-shirts or shorts that needed to cover up. Worth knowing is that for a deposit, before entering you can use a locker and change from your shorts into long trousers which will be lent to you.

Nice cultural sightseeing but very crowded. the Temple of the Emeraldd Buddha is a highly touristic sightseeing opportunity.As a temple itself, it's one of the less impressive complexes I have seen.However, the sleeping emerald Buddha is am impressive sight to see and picture to take.It features an adjacent museum and offers lots of knowledge and information to absorb for those who want to indulge more deeply.The big drawback is that the place is very crowded and it's difficult to enjoy the experience.My recommendation would be to go as early as possible to get a better view and less waiting times.Bring a little time with you in any case to explore the temple fully.

its the main temple so of course you gotta go. very beautiful temple! its inside the grand palace so you most probably will visit anyway if you are in bangkokbut i recommend taking a tour and an audio guide, otherwise you might be missing out on all the history of the place! also try going early in the morning because it gets real hot around noon and that just takes the joy of it all

Go early!. Beautiful temple. We hired a guide and found the information to be very useful and very helpful for only $25CAD. However, we went in the middle of the day and would recommend that you go very early! During the day, the temple was extremely crowded and full of tourist groups. It was difficult to walk around and see anything between the massive hoards of people. Definitely go early and beat the rush.

Beautiful day out. The place is beautiful.Make sure you come prepared with clothes that cover your knees and shoulders for any gender.If you forget there are people outside who sells things and they are very pushy...
