Otherwise you can borrow some clothes after you've both your ticket.There are guards there that make sure you're dressed accordingly.Make sure you take plenty of water with you because there are only few places outside that sell water but it gets sold out very quickly. In the mail room of the grand palace (The Emerald Buddha) not pictures to be taken inside and shoes off.There are Garda there to check everybody compline with the rules. It's gets very busy every day of the week but it's not to be missed. It is amazing.
Beautiful experience. This is a most beautiful temple so take your time visiting every aspect of the complex even find a shady corner and watch the world go by.

A must temple if travel to bangkok.. Inside the grand palace lies the temple of Emerald Buddha. Wat Phra Kaew. A visit is a must for 1st timers. There is also a Wat Phra Kaew museum to show the artifacts & old artifacts on the temples & also some history of Bangkok & Thailand which is interesting.

Very cool. Don't get me wrong you will feel the heat and the crowds are big. The experience though is worth it.
We are glad we went, and happy to have waited, staff are organised

Impressive must see!. Included inside of the The Grand Palace in Bangkok, this temple is one of the most venerated. It very ornate and impressive. You can expect to compete with large numbers of tourists for viewing spots, but I think if you show patience in the crowds it will be a worthy experience.

Must visit place. We went there in the morning and bit crowded with locals who are celebrating new year.. Very clean place and it was so nice place with lots of statues. Everything is colourful and ornate.
Entry fees is bit expensive
Amazing!. The outside of the building is magnificent. But the interior will take your breath away. So richly decorated, it is fabulous!
Interesting to see emerald that way. It was beautiful to see how emerald is shaped into such beautiful statutes. Everything is very ornate and colorful. A must see if you're in Bagkok.
Must visit temple in bangkok. It is simply awesome......excellent architecture. Located within the compound of grand palace.downside is that entry fee is somewhat expensive.

Good View for Night Time. If you go to Wat Pra Kaew or Grand Palace in night time. You can see different view from day time. And also if you have a great chance to go by boat or any Cruise Service at River City Port, you can enjoy both International Food and Good View from Wat Pra Kaew or any other nice place night time.
Have a must. The place that every travelers have to go. It's one of the most important place for Thai people. We go for sacrifice the emerald buddha.

Song Kran visit . Love everything about this Buddhist Temple. Monks are here to help you pray or make an offering. The temple is one with many locals as well as tourists, and you feel the culture like your right at home. I highly recommend this temple.
Over hyped. Very nice, but see Wat Pho and the National Palace first, as they're 10X better. Were it not for the religious significance, this would just be another very nice temple.

temple of buddha emerald. this building part of Grand Palace area , this building has many temple , and story about buddha in thailand, many temple buddha in here ,for especially in here have 3 buddha emerald. Have many story about buddha emerald .

Stunning temple and amazing mosaics . The temple is located in the Grand Place complex. The architecture is beautiful but it's the mirrored mosaics glinting in the sun that make the temple so stunning. The emerald Buddha is stunning. Though he is very small and quite high up so best seen with some binoculars if you have some. To get in go early in the morning to miss out on the crowds as it gets very busy with loads of tour groups. Dress respectfully (long pants, long skirt, long sleeves) and bring hat and water as it gets hot out. There is a small cafe and toilets.

A must see for any Bangkok tourist!. The temple and Royal Palace are definite must-see sights for all Bangkok tourists! They play an important role in Thai culture and love of King and country. We took our teenagers, who enjoyed the experience.
Beautiful temple.. This is another must visit temple. Close to the Grand Palace and really worth a visit. Lovely pictures can be taken.

Get there early. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is quite spectacular and deservedly popular. Entrance fee for foreigners is 500 THB (Thai are free), which is expensive but well worth it.The architect and art is just wonderful and it is a large complex with a lot to explore and see.You have to wear long trousers - anyone wearing shorts or short dresses are turned away.And get there as early as possible. The grounds open at 8:30am and by 10:00 there are huge crowds.

Worth the visit. Really loved the temple and it's surroundings. will visit again. So much peace and quiet. Very scenic and inspite of so many visitors had all the time to see the temple and still so clean and well maintained

" Grand Temple". I,a Buddhist visited on April 13 th. During Song Kran days,crowded place. No peace and calm. Over crowded people walking to and from. I didn't get the chance to visit Royal Palace. Fees for entering 500 Bahts. For those who want to find peace and calm at Emerald Buddha,avoid visiting during festival season. A little bit complicated history for me. . I like those Nuks,Ogres.
Just wow!. There weren't many temples I wasn't impressed with in Bangkok. They are all equally beautiful and have so much to see!

Amazing temple, but VERY crowded. This temple was amazing and you definitely shouldn't miss it, but try to go on a cooler weekday. We went on a Tuesday and thought it was CRAZY crowded. Our guide told us that it was MUCH more crowded on the weekends.Don't set your expectations too high about the actual Emeral Buddha. It's relatively small and is located at the back of the temple, so it's a little difficult to see.
Impressive. We did this on the same day as the Grand Palace. Was impressive and very busy. Took loads of photos and our guide was very informative.

Great temple....overcrowded. As part of the Grand Palace, the temple was also crowded with tourists. WAY TOO MUCH. Could not take a good look when there're too many people around.
No photos allowed inside the temple.

So much detail - sparkly even on a dark, rainy day!. The day I visited, there was a huge thunderstorm and it was crazy dark, rainy, cloudy... yet the temple was still sparkling with all its mirrored decoupage and gold leafing. It was beautiful. If it's raining, don't be afraid to visit. There are many pagodas to stand under to take photos, and the long exterior hallways provided rain cover to walk around the complex.

The emerald Buddha. The way inside was so crowded and everyone was pushing you forward. A lot of tourist and hot outside. Inside you have to walk bare foot. There ate staff inside that controls the crowd. The emerald Buddha was on top of the altar or whatever it is. No taking of pictures inside.

Magnificent. The grand palace which houses the magnificent temple of the Emerald Buddha is one of Bangkok's main attractions and despite the crowds is worth the visit. Although no photos are allowed, shoe removal and conservative dress code are mandatory a visit to see this beautiful emerald green Buddha is a must see for any visitor to Bangkok.

Crowds. The temple itself was amazing, and would definately be 5 stars if not so crowded. The crowds at this temple and the Grand Palace are crazy, lots of large tour groups that just push their way through everyone. Again I think it is worth a look, but can be a very frustrating visit.

Visit with caution. The temple and its surrounding structures are wonderful, however the heat makes it very difficult to have a great time. Not only was it terribly hot when we visited yesterday, the place was also swamped with noisy, unruly Chinese tourists.
It is absolutely amazing. The inside of this temple is very, very, very beautiful. Full of details, art, and decorations. It is a must-see in Bangkok.

Inside the Ground of the Grand Palace.. Ensure you are properly dressed and show respect. Do not take pictures and again be respectful of this, there are plenty of signs asking you not to do tis, however, we witnessed ignorance to this. Security will make you delete your photos.
Beautiful & peaceful !!. The whole area is beautiful & peaceful.Tourists should respect the Holy place & maintain silence in the premises. The whole area has a very positive energy.

Grand palace . First time I visit this was -98. And it's still one of the most visited places in Bangkok. I needed to visit this place one more time. It's a fantastic hand made jade Buddha, amazing craftsmanship to made this of just one pice of jade. Still a must see when you are I Bangkok.
Great Thai architecture . The palace and emerald Buddha are worth a visit. Loved the architecture and grandeur. Takes atleast four to five hours of time to go all around the complex.

Inside the Grand Palace complex. This is actually inside the Grand Palace complex so you should also read the reviews about that. It will be very crowded and you're not allowed to take photographs inside, so will have to try to get a shot from outside the relatively narrow door if you wanted a pic. The actual Buddha is quite small, and very high up at the top of the temple, so quite difficult to see clearly. This is more about imagery,symbolism and meaning than taking pictures.

Underwhelming. I like to be a positive traveler. The new site. But I have to be honest in this case, that despite the fact that this is a primary site Bangkok, I must advise skipping it. Quite frankly by the time you fight the hordes of tourists through the grand Palace and the temple grounds, take off your shoes, and get into the temple of the reclining Buddha. The most exciting part of your experience will be getting close to one of the standing fans to get a cool breeze and break from the heat. It also does help alleviate the smell of the hundreds of shoe tourists who have been walking on those stinky feet all day. It may sound harsh, and it's nothing I've seen in any of the reviews but I'm going to tell you honestly that the most overwhelming thing about the temple of the Emerald is the stench of sweaty toes. For me if I had it to do over again I would definitely skip this site

within the palace. This temple is located within the grand palace. Footwear to be removed and strictly no photography. The buddha statue made of emerald is lovely. Prayers can be offerred by sitting within the temple by anyone. Once outside there is the holy water with a lotus with stem inside it which is used to sprinkle the water onto the devotees.You can even light an incense outside.Must visit.
nothing special to write. It is another temple of Buddha in Bangkok. Normally included in the itinerary of your package tour. I did not find this as a must visit destination.

Another great must see in Bangkok . This is an important Buddhist temple within the grounds of the royal palace. Your ticket to the royal palace includes this temple. Be sure to not miss it while touring the grounds of the Royal palace. Remember to respect the local customs so one will not get in trouble.

Another great temple in Bangkok. All the little figures and statues were very impressive. All the gold, colors and paintings. Unfortunately, there were too many people around. Maybe check when it opens and then try go at this time.Make sure you are dressed properly and maybe don't wear your most expensive sneakers, as you have to take them off before entering some places.It definitely worth a visit.
stunning. Bangkok temples are stunning. all of them are worth visiting. you may find crowd but the vibe is gorgeous.

Tourist must do . Another great day out whilst out exploring Bangkok. Definitely recommend to go see this beautiful site xx book and organise the day yourself rather than expensive excursions. We saved lots of money booking things ourselves

What a shame. After visiting the second time, I feel so saddened to see yet another amazing cultural of thai history being distroyed by far too many tourist who doesn't appreciate or respect the thai culture. How could someone steal from a spiritual and religious place. However 5stars for the actual attractions. It's a must see. Please respect thai people and culture.

Emerald Buddha. This is a tremendous exhibit. Full of culture and history. Bright colors, interesting and amazing sculpture and architecture, I did not know what to expect, but this is wonderful place to visit. Many photo ops.
Summer Holidays. Worth Visiting a Place on tour to Bangkok. Can be reached via Boat ride and getting down at Tha Tien Pier.
Extremely Busy. What is a trip to Bangkok without visiting this Temple? Felt like too many people were let in with no restriction.

The most beautiful temple in Bangkok. One of the most iconic Thai architect can be found here. But since its so famous, on the day there were quite a lot of tourists, would recommend to go on weekdays.

Great experience, too many people. One of the most beautiful, serene places I have ever been...but there were too many people. In particular, too many people taking photos of themselves and ignoring the beauty. The longest painted mural in the world is worth taking the time to fully take in.

Very overcrowded . As already stated by others, the Buddha often doesn't meet the expectations. The statue is indeed very small, but for me this was not the problem. The place was just way to overcrowded. You haven't had the time to even look properly because you were pushed out by the other tourists.
Nice to see, but so don't expect too much.
Beautiful.. There are a lot of Buddha temples in a radius of 1 km in this area. Each temple looks so different and has different versions of Buddha. Very calm and peaceful.
good but not amazing. Little bit desapointed by this small buddha. This temple is not my favorite in Bangkok. If you don't have enought time, run to Wat Pho !

Busy. This is a beautiful awesome temple. I just wish there was no one else here. It felt like I was an ant among many other ants just walking around lol. I reccomend going on a Tuesday so it is less crowded. We went on a Tuesday and it was disgustingly busy but supposedly that day is the least busy lol. Some photos belows...

Situated in the Grand Palace complex. Clothing can be borrowed here for a deposit. Ask for a map so you can find the Emerald Buddha. They only had ones in Chinese left on the day we went. Very hot and exhausting, but worth visiting.

Dress carefully, go early to have a comfortable visit. Avoid taxi in front of the gate, may need to pay 500 to SIAM. If you don't go early, you will face a massive crowd of group tourist. If you don't dress carefully, you have to borrow shirt/pants and need to stay on a long-long line. The attraction itself is gorgeous. Must see. Entrance fee is 500 THB per person.We visited here after the Wat Pho, planning to go Wat Arun, but we gave up and went back to the hotel because of the heat. We took the taxi because we couldn't walk anymore under the intense sunlight, but needed to pay 500 THB. We tried hard to discount it and asked him to use the taxi meter, but he knew our weakness. He didn't listen to us.

Small but Beautiful. I have to say that the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is amazing. The only downfall is not being able to photograph inside the hall. I loved everything about this adventure and the tour guide we had hired to see it and to explain what were experiencing.

Temples are all the same. Cannot tell any differences between temples coz they look all the same to me and I am not interested at all in the religious stories so just some nice photos would be good enough for me. So crowded so hot and won't come next time.
Crowded af. Really cool structure with lots of detail but chock full of tourists. Got pushed multiple times. Good but temple of reclining Buddha is better IMO

amazing. Thailand has so many Wats (temples) more so up north in ChiangMai region they are all eye openers but some stand out more than others this Wat is one of those, make sure you have room on your camera card

Must visit temple - 46 m long reclining Buddha inside. Buddhist temple complex in the old town of Bangkok. Great time for visit is earlier morning or later evening (we were there approx. 1/2 hour before closing) because of tourist traffic and of course nice light for pictures. In the complex you can find the Thai Massage School (first public university for Thai Massage) and get a real Thai Massage here.
Breathtaking!. No pictures allowed inside, no shoes allowed.Strict clothing, no sleeveless and no leg bearing. They rent clothes outside if needed by the people.

Iconic site, crowded but worth it. This was terribly crowded, but all of Bangkok’s top sites are terribly crowded. You just have to see them anyway. We were with a tour group so we got there along with the rest of the hordes. If you have a choice, go early in the day. If not, go anyway. It’s hot. Take water, wear comfortable shoes that you can slip on and off easily, and dress in a way that’s appropriate for temples in Thailand so as not to be embarrassed by the guards not letting you in.The Emerald Buddha itself is fairly small, sits up high, and you are not allowed to take pictures of it, but it is clearly visible, and the whole temple complex is amazing.This was one of the first three sites our tour group took us to - the other two being the Temple of the Reclining Buddha and the Grand Palace. To me, they were all equally impressive and almost equally crowded, but all were must-see attractions.

Fantastic. more than expected, the wall paintings in a prayer room with the emerald statue are amazing! Just hope there can be better tourist routes with professional guides--to make the beautiful temple a more tranquil sanctuary.

must see. The most iconic place in Bangkok, and the most expensive temple in thailand: 500 bahts ( 14 U$D), CROWDED. Even though the people and the price you have to go there. There are comments that there are plenty of temples around bangkok better than this, that's a lie, this is the most iconic place in thailand, you have to go there. I'd recommend to go there in the morning and in the noon go to the Wat Pho (reclining buddah)
Beautiful.... Must visit. Mostly crowded through out the day. Avoid weekends. Dress appropriatly or you will be asked to leave by the guards at the entrance.

impressive but crowded. blown away by the impressive architecture. everything was beautiful. my only regret was not arriving early enough to enjoy this place better. do yourself a favour and be there even before it opens
Beautiful. It is the typical beautiful temple, but no photography allowed. The emerald Buddha sits up very high above an altar. You can't get close, but Buddha remains clearly visible.

Part of the Royal Palace, a must see. This is an amazing work of art. ifficult to see sometimes, because it is so busy, but when in the Royal Palace, go and see. Don't take pictures inside, it's not allowed. We've seen unfriendly armed guards forcin people to wipe their photo's off their smartphones.
Very beautiful but too many tourists.. It's a must, and do it in combination with The Grand Palace which is nearbv. Make sure to come early before the crowds invade the place.

Impressive architecture, but massive crowds. This temple is inside the larger Grand Palace complex in Bangkok. We arrived there roughly at 2:00 PM. The site is simple marvelous. You will be amazed at the craftsmanship that went into building these temples. The colors mixed with the gold leaf are vibrant. It is also a place of worship for Buddhists. The only drawback, and this may have been a result of the time of the day we were there, were the massive crowds. At times is was even rough to take a picture. Make sure you are well hydrated before entering the temple! Between the crowds and the heat you will need it!

Pretty, but crowded. I made the mistake of not going as early as possible in the morning. I arrived at 10 am and the place was already packed with enormous tour groups (packed to the point of being uncomfortable). It was very beautiful and totally worth the trip, but do yourself a favor and get there right when it opens to avoid the crush.

More temple. Great history with this temple. Fit this visit in the same day as the Grand Palace. Again I warn you there will be a lot of walking in the heat. Where comfortable shoes and dress respectful.
Beautiful but busy. Try and go as early as you can, otherwise you just get swamped with other tourists, and it gets too hot in the day! Well worth a visit though.
Excellent insight into classic thai architecture. The gold will dazzle you and amaze you. The detailing is exquisite. And once inside, the silence is bliss.Awestruck
Awesome. A must when you go to the Grand Palace. Like always fir these attractions, better to go early in the morning (less people and cooler).

Don't missed!. It is very beautiful. I think this is the best temple in Bangkok. The fee is 500 baht but it's included the teak wood palace (Vimanmek mansion) which is in a different location. It is a very busy place, lots of tourists. Better t visit early morning (8 am) because it's very hot and to avoid the crowd.

Beautiful. The temple is anasing, but you have to go inside and pay attention, this Buddha is little....
Is full of people at this time of year....
A must visit!. Went to visit this place as part of the Grand Palace tour. The place is crazy busy but still well worth the time and effort. Amazing structures and history. Loved every minute of it!

Kind of Awe Inspiring. This Temple is part of the Grand Palace complex. It's pricey to enter the complex (500 baht) but there is a lot to see. This temple was just inside the entrance and is impressive from the outside but even more so on the inside. It's very ornate and the "altar/shrine" with the emerald buddha inside is spectacular. Don't expect the Buddha to be as large as others which go for quantity rather than quality. This is fairly small but very ornate and set in a beautiful surrounding.

Holiday . This is busy place so if you can get there when it opens it will help, it has an awe about the place, one can stand and reflect back at the amazing craftsmanship, the emerald Buddha has a calming effect and one can pray.
Impressive Architecture. This temple is much small than Wat Pho, but with impressive architecture just across the river in a boat from Wat Pho. you can also buy some souvenirs at cheep price here

A must in Bangkok. This place is probably a compulsory item for everyone who visits the city. Rather high admission fee (500 Bt) but it is worth it. Be ready for absolutely overcrowded place. Does not matter if it is morning or afteroon visit.

This is a must do while in Bangkok - but extremely hot and crowded. It was very hot and crowded (of course we went in the middle of the day). It was our 1st temple, and it was beautiful. No photos of emerald Buddha allowed. All temples in Thailand require covered knees and shoulders for all visitors, but most will rent or loan wraps.

Well Worth the Visit. It will be crowded so you should be prepared for that. This is apparently one of the most popular attractions especially for Chinese tourists. We attended with a guide and this gave us a much deeper perspective of this site and statue which we would not have got by just visiting.

The Emerald Buddha. I enjoyed the tour; but, it was so crowded and I felt rushed. It was also very hot out. The temples were magnificent and I would recommend going there in the morning when it isn't so humid and hot.
Beautiful!. But go early or late in the day to have any chance of enjoying the spirituality that the hoards of rude tour groups will destroy during the peak of visiting hours.
Famouse place. Make sure you do not miss it when visit Grand Palace. One of the most popular "mast see" in Bangkok.

Interesting, historical and quite beautiful. We had an excellent tour guide who was very knowledgable about the history and meanings behind the tour. What was not particularly great was the truck loads of Chinese tourists. The temple was crowded to the point of overflowing. If you don't like BIG crowds, I'd suggest going somewhere else.

Do not let the crowds stop you. A beautiful and almost unbelievable place visit and spend time just looking and enjoying this wonderful treasure. I do not care when you go there will be crowds of people but there is plenty to see and enjoy. Take your time and wander the area.

Historic site. I liked the tour of emerald Buddha temple and Grand palace. Although I had to deal with waiting on a long line to pay and go through security, the experience was rewarding. The guards were very nice and friendly, and I even took pictures with them.

MUST DO IN BANGKOK. Let me start off by saying I want everyone to have a great trip so please message me if you have any specific questions! I just to Bangkok March 12-20, 2016.Wat Phra Kaew is the most important Thai temple. It is located in the Grand Palace Complex BUT these are in fact different things. The main temple grounds are IN the Grand Palace compound. So there is more to see, if visiting the Grand Palace, than just the temples.This temple has so many buildings within it. We did a tour which was well worth it because we got to see everything important. We spent most of our tour time here (1.5 hours out of the 4 hour tour) because that's how much time you need to see everything. So many temples within this temple and such beauty! This is a must! While there are hundreds of temples in Bangkok alone, we visited the top 5 and this is definitely on the top of the list.Time: We did the tour in 1.5 hours because we had a guide. But if you are on your own, I'd say you could do this tour in 1 hour.Tip for ALL Thai Temples (some may be different but generally all are the same). I did my research before, knowing how religious Thai people are. Clothing: I cannot emphasize how important clothing is for all temples. You WILL be turned away for inappropriate clothing. They have a strict code for both men and women but I think it is best for everyone to stay covered. -No shoulders showing (absolutely no tank tops for men or women)-Nothing above the knee (I wore athletic pants and a t-shirt for all my tours and had no problems. Some websites prohibit athletic wear but I just went 2 weeks ago and found that that material doesn't matter at all because they are only looking for coverage. I think for women maxis are the best way to go, making sure your shoulders are covered! Shoes or sandals are fine to wear. They will tell you when you must take off your footwear)Do not touch anything. Everything in the temples is obviously old and historic and hand done. Also, do not try and mimic what the locals are doing. To you, this is an attraction, but to them, it could be their main place of worship. Be mindful of that and don't follow what they do since they will take offense to someone who isn't Buddhist or Hindu following their actions.They will tell you when photos are acceptable. This temple didn't prohibit photos anywhere, but there will be signs posted. They aren't kidding around. We witnessed a security guard taking someone's phone and deleting photos.I also read that it is considered disrespectful to turn your back to any statue of Buddha. Thai people will definitely appreciate if you follow rule.At the end of the day, these temples are sightseeing attractions to us. Look around and appreciate the detail. There is so much to see. If you are on a tour, your guide will take you to everything you need to see so don't worry. If you are not on a tour, go at your own pace, but remember that if you rush through everything assuming it's the same, you will definitely miss some stuff.

Avoid ... Wat Pho and Wat Arun are better. Expensive, disorganised, noisy, and lacking any resemblance of peaceful religious sanctity. Few areas are off limits due to large groups having priority. Having experienced bad behaviour from so many different nationalities (including my own) over the years, one nationality (which travel in large groups) has now ruined this beautiful place, with their antics, yelling, and worst of all spitting. Visit Wat Pho and Wat Arun they are less crowded, a little quieter and most importantly has a sense of reverence about them.

Large complex = take your time. The massive number of tourists and small groups indicate immediately that this is one of the must-see places in Bangkok. Be prepared to have your bag searched if it is larger than a small daypack and to feel like a sardine on entry (my group went early before most of the tourists arrived) - and take some water with you. Many beautiful buildings with their intricacies to view; great for those keen photographers!Be prepared to lose the shoes and hat when going into some temples and make sure you are appropriately dressed to respect the location.

Very lovely temple. We visited this when visiting the Grand Palace.It's a very very lovely temple. I love how the outside walls were affixed with little mirrors, making it glitter in the sunlight.As with all temples, I think the best advise I can offer is to bring a plastic bag so that you can keep your expensive shoes/slippers in rather than leave it on the shoe racks outside.

Well worth a visit . So much to see, this place located within the national palace is well worth a visit. It can get very busy so it's advisable to get there early if you can, Don't let the crowds put you off and take time to soak it all in. We thoroughly enjoyed looking around - the murals and decoration are stunning

Too many people. Amazing architecture, stunning temples structures. Unfortunately all the experience as been ruined by the many tourists.It has been impossible to enjoy it because you constantly had to pay attention to avoid selfie-sticks or sun umbrellas. They should put some limitation about the number of tourists can enter, otherwise the "experience" will be completely ruined.

Ok - but Wat Pho is better. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha was ok. The actual Buddha statue is smaller than I originally thought and pictures are not allowed inside the temple so it's difficult if you want to get a picture of it. Also, it was very crowded, which made it hard to get up close. Wat Pho was much nicer and not as crowded.

Beautiful temple.. It is very beautiful, colourful and with good architectural value. The visit into the temple is permitted and if one wishes to pray there is a separate enclosure. We were there by 11am and it was already very crowded. Try to be there before 9 am. The entry ticket to this and Grand palace is a combined one. The entry into Grand palace is through this temple. If not crowded it is a place to stay for a while.

No.1 attraction with tourists to show. This is bangkoks most famous tourist attraction (apart from the ever so enjoyable ping pong ball shows offcourse...) and results in endless rows upon rows of tourists trying to enter the sacred grounds. With an afmission fee of 500B it is also rather pricey (for Thai standards). What you get however is a good look at the most impressive temples Bangkok has to offer, just know that you will not be the only one visiting this attraction.
Quick Peak. Another one for the temple tours. Small emerald buddha located high up on a golden pyramid in the temple.
nice temple. This temple is nice, but problem is very crowed, a lot of Chinese tourist, you need to remove your shoes. cannot take photo inside. Very hot weather, be prepared.

A pilgrimage for every Thai Buddhist. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a must visit for every Buddhist in their life time. That plus the throngs of tourists keep this temple very crowded. The statue itself is not very large but is mounted on a high pedestal and is easy to view. You can only photograph it from outside. The clothes on the statue are changed thrice a year by the king or the royal prince in accordance with the weather. The clothes - if they can be called that- are made of gold and add a grandeur to the statue. Do sit down for a while and take in the beautifully painted ceiling, doors and walls of the temple
Amazingly beautiful. This is an amazing place to visit. All the details everywhere were breath-taking. The site is very well maintained.
Fantastic. Definitely worth a visit, absolutely stunning,easy to get to from the river taxi,s and they are great value

In the Grand Palace complex. Be prepared to remove your shoes. The Budha is maybe only a foot tall but he has one of the largest temples. Many people bring flowers and money for offerings and pray. It's sort of a come and go thing. You quietly slip in kneel and pray and slip out. Stunningly decorated room. No photos inside but if you have a good camera you can catch it all from the doorway. If you only wanted to see a few of the many Budha temples I suggest this and the reclining Budha.

A must see site in Bangkok. This is one of the chief places to visit in Bangkok the temple holds one of the most revered Buddha's in Thailand. It can become very crowded and hot especially as due to respect you can not wear shorts or bare feet. But this is well worth the discomfort so you can visit a truly beautiful Tempel

The Granduer. Its just amazing. Hugely structured temple complex. Get a map and see the Emerald Buddha. The area is quite big and so you need to identify the spots you would like to visit first. Try to get in early to beat the heat and crowd.The easier way to reach Grand Palace complex (Phra Kew is a part of it) is by the ferry. Catch-up Orange-flag (15Baht) / No-flag (10-20Baht) boat and get down at Ta Chang pier. Walk through the market around the pier and out onto the plaza flanked by old shop-houses. The long white wall of the Grand Palace is across the street on your right. The entrance is the second gate in the wall.P.S: Must carry Water. Inside the main Phra Kew Temple, photography is prohibited. Entry fee is 500 THB. There is a strict dress code but you can get wrap around in case of defaulter.NOT ALLOWED DRESSES: Shorts, mini-skirts, short skirts, tight fitting trousers, and tights / See-through shirts and blouses, as well as culottes or quarter length trousers / Sleeveless shirts or vests / Sandals (without ankle or heel straps) / Rolled-up-sleeved shirts / Sweatshirts and sweatpants, wind-cheaters, pajamas and fisherman trousers

Beautiful temple, crowded, "proper" attire annoying. A beautiful impressive temple in the palace grounds. The statue itself seems rather small and unimpressive but as whole it is woth visiting. As in all temples, you have to leave your shoes outside, so socks are highly recommended. Very crowded. The ticket to the palace is quite pricey costing about 15 euros. The attire is being controlled before entering. Having heard of this I wore long, wide pants and my shoulders were covered, so I could go in without problems. My companion, however, was stopped, because he wore long pants, from which the lower part could be removed (with zipper) because the guard considered it "impolite", so beware.
Good to see but go early. An amazing place but go.early s it gets very crowded. Make sure you wear appropriate clothing. Men in long pants and ladies in long skirts. They 're. Very strict.
Absolutely Gorgeous. Really worth a visit, the details are incredible!Please be respectful and don't take pictures and don't be loud, as the signs say.

They really are strict about photos. The temple is magnificent but if you try to sneak a photo like me, you will be approached by a guard then slapped on the hand with paper while the guard reprimands you in Thai... Be more sneaky, I guess!
Amazing buildings. This is a fabulous place - I was expecting one temple but it is really a monastery with the temple in the centre and surrounded by incredibly ornately decorated buildings.

One of many temples, but you need to see it. You must see it but it does not leave an overwhelming feeling afterwards. You have to struggle with the many unpolite Chinese visitors. They never heard the word respect.

Done in 5 mins. The Palace tour guide told us that if we were afraid our shoes would be stolen at the entrance, we can carry them inside instead. I did this, walked inside barefoot and got hit by a guard on the shoulder because he saw me carrying shoes. No use explaining to him that I was following the palace tour guide's instructions because he didn't speak English. Leave your shoes out front. Brave the line and get pushed around while trying to go inside, take photos and walk out. Done and done in 5 mins.

Beautiful but gaudy.. Too many rude Chinese tourists with selfie sticks to really enjoy the beauty of the place. There must be some way of limiting the hordes that are there all at once. It really is an unbelievable place even with the pushy people. Everything is either gilded or covered in something sparkly.

Start your Bangkok Visit from here. Out of over 40,000 plus temples in Bangkok , this is where your journey starts. The Emerald Buddha is a part of Wat Phra Kaew, The statue is made in green emerald stone. Be respectful when you visit, Skirts and sleeveless clothes are not allowed. Photography is prohibited inside the main temple and no caps please.The statue perched on a huge Golden is a visual delight. Pray in the temple gives you so much peace.

Overcrowded temple. Very nice temple, interesting ornaments, of course a lot of gold. Plenty of people inside and outside. It is forbidden to take photos inside the temple. It is a part of sightseeing the Grand Palace in Bangkok.

Beautiful place but really crowd. The place is amazing full of beautiful architecture and the Buddha is small in comparison with the reclining Buddha but is beautiful full of jewellery. The only problem was that the place was full of people so we couldn't stay there in silence to contemplate the Buddha, a lot of people coming in so we just looked the emerald Buddha and quickly went outside.

Avoid the crowds but don't miss this. One of the most sacred places in Thailand , the Temple of Emerald Buddha doesn't fail to impress. Despite the heat and the crowds this is one the Palace's main highlights. Make sure to wear long pants and try to go late in the evening.

Nice temple!. Pictures are not allowed within the main temple. There are guards that make sure no one records a video inside or take a picture.Depending on the season of the year you'll see the Buddha wearing three different suits. One for rainy season, one for summer and a last one for winter. The king personally dresses the Buddha at the start of each season.
peaceful place. it is quite a peaceful place if people know how to prepare themselves well, place to see and capture all well wishes
dont miss. This is part of the Grand Palace. You will need some time to take all of this in. A cant miss on your first visit to Bangkok.
Magnificent!. A great place to see. There is tremendous beauty and lots of gold! It is easy to get to on public transportation.
Excellent Temple ... Must go to in Bangkok.. Very fine Buddhist Temple to go to without many tourists. Very good place for great pictures. Just go and you will enjoy.
At the grand palace. Take the time to pop in regardless of the crowds ... as always must remove shoes and the Grand Palace requires a strict dress code - knees covered and sleeves required.

Excellent but very overcrowded . Arriving before the gates were open and being the first people through into the area of the temple still didn't allow us to have too much of a peaceful visit. The temple is stunningly beautiful and is so spiritual it is a shame that within 20 minutes this is spoilt by bus loads of tourists swamping the temple. Who are rude and very loud with apparently no respect for the area they are visiting. It is a shame that no crowd control is used by delaying the crowds into the area. The temple and surrounding area is beautiful but it is ruined by the crowds. It is definitely worth a visit but the only way to do this is to go very early and rush through before your visit is tainted by the crowds
Stunning. A spectacular temple and another must see attraction in the same area as the Grand Palace. Always astounding at the detail and time it must have taken to create!

If you visit Bangkok and don't go here for here is something wrong with you!!. Unbelievably beautiful and holy place. The actual emerald Buddha is so beautiful it is hard to credit. There are lots of temples here and very very busy but so worth it. So many beautiful temples and buildings. Make sure you wear appropriate clothing. Long sleeves and no shorts. You can rent stuff but that is painful and who wants to wear trousers that other sweaty tourists have worn? Ha ha.

Small but amazing!. While at the Grand Palace make sure you see the Emarald Buddha as the symbolism is very moving.The Buddha itself is much smaller than we thought it would be, but it is there, watching over everyone in the temple.
A Must See. A must see attraction in Bangkok. Its stunning inside and your trip in Thailand won't be complete till you visit here. Too bad photo is not allowed inside.

Excellent but over crowded. Best go a bit early in the morning or late in the evening to avoid both hordes of tourists and the heat. Some part do need some renovation, but overall, a great place to visit.

Breathtaking. A must see at Grand Palace. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha will take your breath away. The beauty of this temple is like no other. Grand Palace is a very, very busy place, but please don't let that put you off.
Amazing statue. Crowded is the only negative to this otherwise amazing temple. The statue is one of the masterpieces inSE Asia.

Stunning. I loved visiting the Temple. It was really stunning and the history of it was amazing.
It was very busy, but this is normal in Bangkok so you just have to go with the flow. I would highly recommend a visit.
I would recommend seeing the exhibition from the Queen of Thailand around her silks, it's really interesting.

Beautiful & Crowded . The Emerald Buddha is just beautiful. As all tourist attractions, it's crowded and very hard to take a picture.
It's a good place to see buddhist traditions.
The temple and the buddha themselves are gorgeous.
Amazing. Although i went on a very hot day, it was totally worth it, amazing architectural designs and brilliant murals all around the temple, what a sight

Beautiful. This place was beautiful, both on the exterior and the interior.The massive crowds were kept in order by some rather surly security guards, in order to make the place available to devotees to perform their practices. There is a separate cordoned off area for Monastics, which means that lay people are a little distant and tourists, rather than Buddhist practitioners would likely find it disappointing to be so far away from the shrine.Anyone can enter the lay-people's prayer area, so long as they are respectful and silent, but do not attempt to enter the monastic area, as it is very heavily policed and the guards (not the monks) will make sure you are prevented from entering and they will NOT be polite or understanding. Monastics are given extreme respect and are treated almost like gods in most of Bangkok. Any perceived disrespect is not tolerated by the public, let alone by the police!Also, ensure you dress modestly, no knees showing, no sleeveless tops, not even if covered by a shawl or scarf.

The Best Thai Temple, but completely packed with Chinese tourists. What Phra Kaew is the premier temple in Bangkok, so I like to visit it each time I'm in town. This was my third visit over the past twenty years, and I am sad to say this time was quite unpleasant due to the huge crowds of Chinese tourists. To understand how crowded it was, try to picture being shoulder-to-shoulder with a moving mob and being pushed from all sides. I was appalled at their rudeness...We arrived at about 9am in an attempt to beat the mid-day heat and the crowds. As mentioned above, we certainly did not miss the crowds. By the time we left at 11am, the crowds at the entrance seemed to decrease a little. It may be better to arrive late morning or afternoon. Personally, I would rather deal with the mid-day, Bangkok sun than thousands of pushy tourists.Please read about the dress code before you go! You must wear long pants and your shirt must cover your shoulders. Woman can wear a sarong as a skirt over shorts, so that you don't have to wear long pants during the rest of your day. My wife and her friend both wore sarongs. However, I saw several men (including my friend) refused entry for wearing a sarong over shorts. The guard said that a sarong is womens' clothes, and men must wear long pants. The dress code was definitely enforced more strictly than in the past... In general, I would recommend that everyone obey the dress code as you are visiting Temple that is of great importance to the Thais, so you should be respectful of their culture.Unfortunately, there is a lot of corruption in Thailand. I recommend that you read about the various scams before your visit. There are many scams that are repeated over-and-over, but are easily avoided. A typical scam at Wat Phra Kaew is for someone to approach you as you are just outside and tell you that it is currently closed. When this happened to me a few years ago, the scammer offered to take us on a tour over various sites in Bangkok (of course, for a fee), and then he would bring us back to the Wat in the afternoon when it "opens". I was suspicious, so I told him that I would just walk inside to check on the opening hours myself. It was open! I later learned that this is a very typical scam. Ignore them! Just keep walking!In general, if you are in a tourist area and someone approaches you and starts asking where you are going or giving you suggestions, it is best to ignore them and just keep walking.

spectacular. the temple is very amazing , with is amazing Design and all the spectacular gems and gold details.the temple is very crowded with tourist,and the entrance is no free. you can't enter the tample with shoes and short pans.
Worth visiting. Great feeling , you are not allowed to do photos inside but you can do it outside, very beautiful statues, with small details, simply amazing

Beautyfull..but too many groups. This is a beautiful temple with a lot to see. Only downside is that there are too many groups visiting this place.This will prevent you from seeing everything relaxed and at your own pass, since every 5 minutes a hoard of Chinese is walking by, making hundred of pictures and screaming to one another. :(Non the less..would recommend
Magistic. This temple was my favorite of all of the temples I visited. It was so magical. All the details were so impressive. I didn't want to leave and took my time exploring every inch of it.
Historical journey . Experience ancient times and historical journey. Amazing and mysterious architecture. But very crazy crowded of tourists.

Within the grounds of the Grand Palace. The Emerald Buddha is housed in such a location that it is difficult to appreciate. It sits up high plus the fact that it is not very large makes it hard to see any great definition of this buddha made of jade. Lighting is not optimal either. Since it does sit up high you don't have to worry of someone blocking your view. Our guide told us that with every seasonal change the King of Thailand applies a set of clothing onto the Emerald Buddha. Some of the clothing is housed used is in another building on the grounds. One can certainly spend more time checking out other things within the room than looking at the Emerald Buddha.

Amazing temple. It's a beautiful temple with so much to look at. you cannot go inside with shoes and you cannot take pictures and they mean it. security is very strict. Take off your shoes and put them in a back pack. What takes away from the pleasure of being there is the huge number of tourists trying to get in.
Prepare to meet every Chinese person in the world. Place was packed with bus loads of tourists from China. Short tempered guards are constantly yelling at people but just laugh at them.
it still temple. i love the architecture of this temple. Im not a budhist but when i enter this temple i found peace in me

Buddhist temple. Alot of people... The joy of the visit was being there, but the vast hordes of tourists spoiled the visit. Take a long tailed boat from Saphan Taksin, around 100 baht per person and speed up to the temple, that is worth it!
So beautiful. My second visit and the increase in the number of tourists is Challenging. Remember to dress appropriately.

STUNNING!. This is definitely one of the most amazing and detailed temples I've ever seen. So incredibly beautiful, I couldn't believe it. The temples are covered in precious stones and gold, everything literally just shines. I was speechless - it's a must-see!

i recommend it very much. this temple is not free , and you should pay 500 baht as entrance ,men & women couldn't enter by short , you should wear a long pant or jeans ( your feet must be cover) if not, they give you a pajamas and you should pay 200 baht as deposit for that ( its refundable , you'll get it back when you exit )this temple is very beautiful and big , I'm from Iran , Iran is a very artful country , so i know art very well, as an Iranian i recommend you to visit this temple if you like art , i assure you that it worth the 500 baht ;) have fun

Crowded Temple Complex. Stunning complex and absolutely a must-see. But the crowds are horrendous, and we were there in low season! Take the reviews about arriving early seriously, because I think we accidentally hit peak group-tour-time and unfortunately the aggressive and gigantic clumps of people really took away from the serenity of the gorgeous surroundings. We did find a few quiet corners, and overall absolutely still worth it, but plan well! Ticket includes Grand Palace and a couple museums, and easy to get here by metro plus water bus. Quick tip - guards were really strict on dress code when we were there, some women with scarves covering tank-tops were turned away, no shorts for men, and leggings have to be covered by a skirt/scarf wrapped as a skirt. Footwear was more lax.

Pretty temple and crowded. This is part of the Grand Palace experience- really busy and power packed day of sight seeing, so wear socks and good walking shoes (don't want to walk barefoot with so many other travelers from different countries when you have to walk into temples). Really pretty temple- a must see.
I love to go there.. Wat Phra Kaew is so amazing and beautiful place in Thailand. I really like to go to visit and see architecture.

Hated every second of it.. This is part of the grand palace complex, so if you're visiting there you are sure to go here as well. The temple itself is beautiful, HOWEVER the experience of visiting it is one of the most unpleasant things I've had to endure in 5 months travelling. It is so overcrowded that it is impossible to enjoy - it's not a case of trying to take a photo without other people in it, but trying to take a photo without someone elbowing your camera into your face. Add the Bangkok heat and nobody taking care to avoid making noise as per the rules of entry, and it's just not enjoyable.

Wow. Amazing buildings. Definitely need the audio tour or a guide to get the most of it. Cannot express enough how incredible the buildings are, but so so crowded which spoils it a bit. However if in Bangkok, you cannot miss this

Absolutely Beautiful - Not To Be Missed. Loved the exquisite beauty of the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and lingered there quite a while. The whole Grand Palace/Temple complex is not to be missed and I cannot recommend it highly enough. Fun to arrive there by boat on the river.

Great Temple!. The only negative about this place and most tourist places in Thailand is that it is very crowded and wish the tour operators would "control" they tours better by asking them to follow the rules better. Its a temple so please respect that and don't yell!!!!

Great experience. The Temple of the Emerald Budha is inside a big complex so be prepared to walk and to the crowds, my first recommendation is: use the "proper" clothes (women covering shoulders and legs and men with complete t-shirts and no shorts) otherwise will get you problems at the gate (be yelled at and moved to the cloth renting area). Have plenty water with you and don't throw the bottles because you will find free fountains with cool water (for refilling). Have your eyes wide open because you will find amazing details everywhere!

A must . Part of the Grand Palace entry. A must if in Bangkok. Lots of people but the shrine is spectacular.Very calm inside and a chance to reflect. You must leave your shoes outside so muke sure they're cheap.

not to be missed. if you only see one wat in bkk, this is the one. the mosaic works are on a mind blowing scale. the temple itself has the history of the Buddha and his path to enlightenment. the palace is in the same complex

Wow..... Definitely one of the best places in Bangkok. Beware of locals trying to tell you attractions are closed or telling you about a lucky Buddha. You need to know where you are going when you get to Bangkok.
very good. amazing architecture and attractive temples . must be visited as it is one of Bangkok famous attractions

A must see. The Temple of the Emeral Buddha is a must see when visiting Bangkok. Be sure to visit with someone knowledgeable about the temple, or hire a guide. There is so much to see that the details get lost.The display of the Emerald Buddha is moving. Even for a non-Buddhist the chamber has a sense of the holy being present.The temple and its grounds are very busy. There is a strict adherance to dress code so be sure that you are within expectations before visiting. You WILL be stopped if not.
Great experience.. The culture, history and heritage in these places is amazing. You may need to arrive early but other then that it was a great time.

Part of a Tour group. We went here as part of a tour group that was going to Cambodia and Vietnam. It was a stop included by the tour company as a "must see" and it was. It is beautiful and well worth the minimal effort required to get there.
Must visit in BKK. Temple of Emerald Buddha is a MUST see place in Bangkok and it is well worthy to visit. It was a nice experience.

Nice place but no English translation.. Place full of tourists mainly from China. Most were friendly and orderly. The place was big and magnificent but I have no idea what's going on because there was hardly any thing written in English. I wish there were translation of the temple's history in English. Unfortunately it's all written in Thai. Most importantly..do go there early in the morning about nine and avoid the crowd. Afternoon is a chaotic situation with tons of tourists flooding in.Must be properly dressed and show respect to the Thai people. Temple not the place to wear your transparent shirts and skirts. Rental and sales of outer wear is available outside the entrance across the streets. A simple top is only 100 baht.While there, do try their promegenate juice. Very nice. In fact, try all their juices...
Nice temple. It is a nice temple, worth visiting. They dress Buddha in the temple in three different dresses, according to the season. All complex is worth visiting as well.
Nice temple. This is quite a tourist trap and I found it expensive and not as impressive as other Thai temples. Very hard to get reasonable priced taxi home.
Amazing. Beautiful, amazing, grand, and all the other synonyms I could think of. If you could visit just one place in the city, I think this should be it.

Enchanting. From the architecture, to the intricate details each pillars of the palace to the emerald buddha everything takes to the olden days of the royal Thai kingdom. Its preserved very well. We loved the tour, it just a little crowded with it being a major tourist attraction in Bangkok. Other than the crowd part, we enjoyed the temple tour.

Another good temple to see. You can certainly overload on temples in Bangkok, but this and the reclining Buddah were great ones to see. Having a guided tour, with other or private makes the whole thing clear and gives you a good basis for anything else you happen to see. Spend the money and get a guide

A must visit. It's my second visit to the temple after several years, and I found that I appreciate it more. This time I read more about Thai history and culture and I found that it helped a lot. And ignore those guides or kids that chasing you. A true gems of Bangkok.

Emerald Bhudda. Do not miss this location. A little Bhudda statue dressed in gold. You will see a different dress for each season: dry, wet and cold. The temple offers fantastic view of excellent decorations. Remember that you will need to take off your shoes before entering the temple.

Bit quieter but just as good. Much easier to walk around than its bigger rival but plenty to see and some great pictures to take! Also cheaper to go in although you need correct money. Well worth a visit.
A 'must see' sight.. Gorgeous Wat, got to be seen - the actual emerald buddha figure is tiny though, - notice the wall paintings.

Combine with Wat Pho (Temple of the Reclining Buddha). A little less striking than the Reclining Buddha, this temple is nonetheless a must-go if you're visiting the temples area. The temple inside is preciously decorated with many golden buddha statues, sitting beyond the Emerald Buddha and surrounded by colourful paintings of the live of Siddarta Gautama all over the walls. When exiting the temple, make sure you take a lotus flower from the temple basin to bless your head with its water!

Emerald buddha. Eventually arrived at the grand palace after being tricked by every tuk tuk and taxi in down. The 500baht to get in is a little stiff. Lots of people without shoes. You're not allowed to take pictures inside but you can see the buddha from outside. He's really small. Guess this is a thing you just have to do when you're in bangkok. Would never go back...

The Emerald Buddha building was closed. A wonderful experience never the less, interacting with the monks observing their daily routines. great photography opportunities, although, if you are unable to visit an area, your ticket price should be discounted.

Emarald legasy. The legend of the Emarald Buddha lives on. The story of the Emarald Buddha is a wonderful tale of history and myth. The story is known throughout the county and Laos, and you will be glad you saw its birthplace. Although beautiful work of art itself, the temple is not the as spectacular as its history. A wonderful expression of Thai architecture that you'll not be dissatisfied with.

It's far from center and it's amazing . We met an old guy on last metro station, which plan to go this temple. We are join him. We took a bus and ride 15-20 minutes. It's really native awesome busses. It's was a holiday, so we met a lot of people. You obviously have to go there. We up to the Buddha, we explore nice museum on a second flor. We drink Saint water and feed a lot of fishes. I recommend everyone to get this place (free).
Large crowded temple. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is one of the most visited places in Bangkok. Very crowded and is loud too. Entry: 500 THB

step back into history. To visit this site will help to understand Thai culture.
Having visited many times over the years showing friends the wonders of Thai culture, I have always discovered something new. Highly recommended

Gorgeous Architecture!. The temple of the Emerald Buddha was so pretty! We spent a solid hour and a half taking pictures and exploring the temple grounds. The interior of the Buddha temple is like nothing I've seen before! Photos are strictly prohibited which is too bad. Must see if you are in Bangkok!
really old statue. you can find this temple in the palace courtyard and you can visit it to see a statue that is over 2000 years old. a beautiful place to visit when in Bangkok.

Inside the Grand Palace and a special place for Buddhists.. We went ere for 9am but the Grand Palace grounds were incredibly busy.In truth we enjoyed many other Wat's we visited last year more.The entrance fee is 500 baht including the coin collection.If you have not been to any of the Wat's before the Golden Buddha is worth seeing near Chinatown

Beautiful architecture and paintings, lovely coin museum, but crazy crowds. This temple is in the grand palace complex - it's included in the ticket along with a couple of museums. It is beautiful with lovely stone - based architecture, and definitely worth a visit. We also visited the coin museum and really enjoyed our visit. There is a lot of walking to do on this visit, so please be prepared. There was only one downside to the temple complex - it was jam packed with people when we visited (in the afternoon and early evening). It did get stuffy because of that, so please carry water as well. I am assuming that it is not as crowded in the mornings, so those wanting to avoid the crowd can try their luck then. But do visit, you're sure to like the statues around the complex, and of course, the emerald Buddha statue itself.

The temple to visit if you have time for only one. This is the most iconic temple in Bangkok, with an amazing mural of the life of the Buddha (with a Thai interpretation) surrounding the main temple which is itself held up by golden garudas holding nagas. The Emerald Buddha is of only modest size and elevated well above the visitors. His robes of woven gold are changed three times a year, marking the main seasons. The temple is, of course, very popular so it is advisable to come early in the day and avoid holidays. We usually visit via the river "bus", which offers interesting views of riverside life.

Incredible but a 2 price system rip-off. I have been to Wat Phra Kaew a couple of times, always on free entry days as I dislike monks ripping tourists offIt's very impressive, it's incredible actually, it's an architectural wonder and it's one of the most impressive places there is in Bangkok. You will need a whole lot of superlatives to describe Wat Phra Kaew It's a place that you absolutely should NOT go to in the middle of the day, plan your day and go in the morning. A nice combination is to be at Wat Phra Kaew pretty early and go to Wat Arun which is a bit shadier or perhaps a boat trip when it gets hot mid day A English speaking guide is interesting and you will learn more than what 95% of all Thai's know about Wat Phra Kaew. It's is a bit pricey but well worth itA jewel in Bangkok for sure

Words Fail Me. Within the Grand Palace grounds. Breathtaking. See reviews on the Grand Palace as a whole for a better idea. The Temple OF The Emerald Buddha is one of the holiest places in the Buddhist faith.
Must visit!. This temple is a definite must see. The temple itself is gorgeous with intricate gold, mirror, and tile work, and the Emerald Buddha is beautiful.

Do you like visiting historical sites?. Take this review with a grain of salt. I am the type of person who prefers being active to visiting a monument.When I do go to a monument, I typically want to get in, take pictures, and get the hell out. The exception would be when I have a really good, fun tour guide.Unfortunately the first time I went here my tour guide was really boring. And the second time I went I skipped getting a guide.I'd recommend getting a guide and hoping for the best. Otherwise get in and grab your photos.By the way, the crowds are insane.

Must visit. Great temple,
One of the must visits in Bangkok.
Make sure to come with a professional guide as there is a lot of stories behind.
Wear comfortable shoes.

Beauty of Beauties!. Another must in for the temple goers and history seekers!
But again, be prepared to confront the hordes and the heat (as always here in Bangkok). Enjoy!

Amazing. It is definitely one of the best arquitectural pieves I have encountered. We were amazed by the beauty achieved in the different buildings of the place and it is definitely one of the highlights of our trip to southeast asia.

Architecture wonder. What a history everywhere. ..
Everything is just sparkling in the sunlight
With the little gold and mirror reflections in every little tiny details
An architecture wonder
Incretible place to visit. I won't not say about this place . When you have time to visit, make a first choice to visit this place. I say that one of the best place in Bangkok .
Only a statue. The main objective is a statue of buddha, that you cannot photograph. A lot of thieves around the temple!
Another place you need to go. . We did this on the same day we visited the Grand Palace, it was just a good to hit as many places in Bangkok on one day.

Amazing statue but don't miss the massage. The statue itself is HUGE and lovely to see as are the temples and gardens but the highlight has to be the massage school. It was my first Thai massage and being wary of the 'extra' on offer in the tourist areas I was glad to go to this school.

Impressive temple. First day of our tour in bkk we visited the Emerald Buddha temple. It was just impressive, sooo beautiful. If you are in Bangkok must see it, one of my favorite temple!!!
PS; every day full with turist!

Thailand 2016. This temple was beautiful as well. Though for some reason we were not allowed to take pictures. The emerald buddha was smaller than expected. Hard to get a good view of it as there were a lot of people. It could have been because we visited on a weekend instead of a weekday. Very crowded.
Small size. The wall art is more impressive than the Buddha. Be prepared to contend with large crowds. A short look is all that's needed.

Impressive and glitzy. Everything is shiny and sparkly! It was unlike anything I had seen in other countries, but reflective of some of the other styles of temples we saw in thailand. The craftsmanship is very impressive with all the stones and gold work. Worth a visit.The only downside are the crowds of tourists. I don't think you can avoid them. We went on a week day and it was still ridiculously busy. It's also not that cheap in terms of the entry fee, but you also get access to the Grand Palace.

Thanks Security team. I have visited to Emerald Buddha for 3 times. Last time in Nov 2015, I lost my wallet at the ticket counter. Fortunately the security staff took and kept my wallet.I received my wallet.Thanks a lot ...

Must see if visiting Bangkok. They have one of the 3 emerald buddhas in the region, according to our Cambodian guide, this is the original one stolen from Cambodia, the ones in Cambodia and Loas are replica. They look the same but only the one in Bangkok has seasonal clothing.
Very busy place!. Do not miss this lovely and very important stop in Bangkok.The crowds are heavy but take your time. Shoes have to be removed here as well.

Keep Calm and Sawasdee. No. 1 Thai Temple which is the royal temple where has no monk stay at the temple. This is a place for Royal Ceremony only. Must come to see the true culture and Architecture of Thailand

Amazing and Impressive. The Grand Palace is really best attraction to visit in Bangkok and the Wat Phra Kaeo is really beautiful and despite the name, the Emerald Buddha is in fact made by jade. Only one stone of jade. Because the daily crowd, schedule your visit for the first time in the morning.
So beautiful!. Take time to view the Emerald Buddha and also go to the museum to learn more. My daughter found it fascinating to watch the children singing.

Magnificent architecture. One of the best temples to visit in Bangkok! Admire the minute details of the design in every corner. It's best to go there early in the morning to avoid crowds later in the day. Respect the religion, respect their place of worship; wear decent clothes inside the temple and taking of photos is not allowed inside.
A visual feast. I agree with a previous reviewer - a photo opportunity to rival many! So much to see and learn about. Another 'must-do' in beautiful Bangkok.
Beautiful Temple. The architecture and the artwork is stunning, we got here in the morning in the hope to avoid the crowds, but is was packed. However I'm sure it gets worse the more the day goes on
A little hard to find. The emerald Buddha was very small, its nothing shocking. But the complex it is in makes it worth to come and see.
Over the top. There is so much gold and glitter it is amazing. So many angles and different views and structures and roof lines make this place photo heaven
Just Amazing!. One of the best places you can visit in Bangkok! Beautiful temples and museums! Try to get there as early a possible because there are many visitors coming every day.

Beautiful temple . Contained within the grand palace , a beautiful structure .
Once within , only quiet reflection. No photographs .
A small Buddha , clothed for the season. Surrounded by elaborate ornaments, a beautiful arrangement.
Tiny Buddha. too small and too far to really appreciate the Buddha. But it was an experience and know that the Buddha changes its covering by the season.

Definately worth a visit. The Emerald Buddha compound, which is situated within the Grand Palace grounds, is a dense concentration of astounding and vibrant buildings. The architecture and artwork is stunning. It's definitely worth seeing, but be warned it gets jam packed during the afternoon and can be draining in the midday heat. Get there early. There's a strict no photography rule within the Emerald Buddha temple itself.

Magnificent!!!. This temple is very welcoming to tourists as long as you follow their rules like keeping silent and removing your shoes, no one will apprehend you. It's ok to take pictures but make sure you don't bother locals who pray. As a respect, you can buy beautiful and fragrant flowers to the vendors outside and offer it. I don't see anything wrong with it.

temple within the compound of the grand palace. right within the compound of the grand palace. paid an entrance fee of 500 baht and was quite crowded. strict as to proper attire and they do not allow photos of the emerald buddha. but photos outside were worth it.

Bangkok's most sacred temple. Wat Phra Kaew, also called the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, is Thailand’s most sacred temple. It has a famous emerald Buddha that probably dates back to the 14th century, though there are many legends about its origin. The complex has many impressive structures and statues.

Beautiful - definately worth a visit!. Amazing and such beautiful and intricate architecture, the grounds actually cover quite a large area, this temple is one of the most (if not the most) important temples in Thailand, apart from being home to the Emerald Buddha it is also the temple where members of the Thai royal family sometimes stay and is where the king is crowned when he ascends to the throne, you are allowed in to see the throne where he is crowned. Both men and women must wear long clothes, although men are allowed to wear t-shirts. Locals go in for free and foreigners pay around 500 baht (if I remember correctly). It us around 1hr 30 mins to 2 hours to go round the whole area, this included to stop a couple of times to pay our respects to the Buddha (foreigners don't have to do this, Thai ppl most likely will do it, but as my gf is thai I wanted to pay my respects too) The grounds also include a museum which displays elephant bones and architectural relics found under the temple, so there is a historical element to it too and also a café where u can sit and have some refreshments. Def worth seeing.

An amazing compound. The Emerald Buddha compound, which is situated within the Grand Palace grounds, is a dense concentration of astounding and vibrant buildings. The architecture and artwork is stunning. It's definitely worth seeing, but be warned it gets jam packed during the afternoon and can be draining in the midday heat. Get there early. There's a strict no photography rule within the Emerald Buddha temple itself.

Crowded but Amazing!. The sights of a temple like this are just incredible. The ornate decoration of every little thing you see is astounding. The smaller museum buildings aren't very exciting, but can be a cheap (free) way to pass the time and cool off. It's a crowded place but still one where you won't be able to resist the urge to linger taking photo after photo. Paintings, sculptures, architecture... this place is a nucleus of arts to gaze upon and the admission price is reasonable.
golden color all the eyesight. so many complicated deco details and gilded gold gates, statues and walls. nice place to take a photo in the sided aisles.

Heat and crowds. Lovely to see, but come in cooler months when maybe less people. Big tip - if on a tour your guide will take you to rent shirt or sarong if inappropriately dressed. These are available For Free once you get inside.

One of the most amazing things.... So much gold! It was a truly amazing experience and I spent a good few hours looking around. Lots and lots of people, it felt like the whole world was there. There is a free tour in English at 1000hrs and 1030hrs and also in the afternoon at 1300hrs and I think 1330hrs which is surprisingly long and very informative.

Amazing place but not a cheap place to go. The architectural building and painting inside are totally amazing. Out of words. I hope the entrance fees could be cheaper as paying 500 baht just to get inside to see the building which restriction in photo taking is kind of expensive thought.

Wonderful & Beautiful BuddhaTemple. It's amazing temple and rich of ancient architectures which show the history of Thai culture and history of our kings. I'm proud of being Thai to present and promote this place is a must for both Thai and foreign tourists to see and appreciate the beauty of heritage architecture.

Crowded but worth a visit. It was well maintained despite the mass of visitors. You won't be allowed to enter the temple, if you wear exposed clothes. I would say it was a good sight to see all tourists dressing up nicely without flipflop, tanks or shorts. I only wish there should limit number of tourists to visit at a time. It was too crowded to pay attention to the surrounding and architecture.

Not really emerald. You really have not experienced Bangkok until you can add this to your list. It is a very important part of the life of Thais and you will feel that as you visit. They will not let you take pictures but the image will stay with you.

Beautiful, but Crowded. Beautiful architecture and cultural murals/art. Lacked English guided tour, but booklets were available. Be prepared for the huge crowds, especially in February (Chinese New Year). Ticket was 500 Bhat per person for foreigners, but included admission to the Grand Palace.
out of this world. this is a must see spot for any tourist, it is absolutly stunning , the attention to detail is amazing, we loved every moment of it.

Amazing temple . The temple it's absolutely amazing ,great architecture and the jade Buddha it's amazing. The only thing that you need to know it's that it's really busy. The best thing will be to hire a tour guide and this will make things easier as you don't need to queue for tickets and they can tell you more about the place.

Emerald Buddha. The temple of Emerald Buddha is a great place to learn about Thai culture and heritage. The temple, like many other in Bangkok, is a beautiful structure. What particularly drew my attention are the golden figures along the walls. Each figure is the result of lot of detailed artwork and there are countless such figures along the walls, presenting perfect photo opportunities to shutterbugs. The Emerald Buddha is placed deep inside the temple. The image is displayed (dressed) differently depending on season, viz. summer, rainy season and winter. A must see temple in Bangkok.

Grand and Impressive. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is located inside the complex of the Grand Palace and is one of the most beautiful temples I've ever seen, with its golden facade and grandeur. The temple has been renovated and has been painted over, as well as in constant care of the palace. The Buddha is elevated on top of the other structures and is an extremely impressive site. Inside, people are told to keep quiet and pay respects to the Buddha, and the feet cannot face the direction of the Buddha. Surrounding it are mythical creatures from Buddhist scriptures, protecting the faithful inside. It is truly a worthy site to visit.

KitChan...Biking Bangkok. Bangkok is a city with a rich culture. Cycling allows us to see and experience more. I like the lens Bangkok for bicycles, even a short distance. It keeps us spinning very happy and feel safe. Temple of the Emerald Buddha in the New Year.กรุงเทพเป็นเมืองที่มีวัฒนธรรมหลากหลาย. การปั่นจักรยานทำให้เราไปเห็นและสัมผัสได้มากยิ่งขึ้น ผมชอบมากที่กรุงเทพมีเลนส์สำหรับจักรยานแม้จะเป็นระยะสั้นๆ แต่ก็ทำให้เราปั่นได้อย่างมีความสุขและรู้สึกปลอดภัย ปั่นไปวัดพระแก้วไหว้พระแก้วมรกตในวันปีใหม่เป็นการเริ่มต้นปีที่ดี
Extremely crowded and expensive. To make the most of your visit, go early before the tour groups come in. The ticket is too expensive.

Very crowded!. I enjoyed visiting this temple but did not love the huge crowd of people that were also visiting. Many were pushy (the security was also physically pushy). It was difficult to take anytime to look at things or to take unobstructed photos. I would recommend to use a guide to get the history and facts. Be sure to cover your legs and shoulders. I saw several people not admitted as they were wearing shorts.

Nice Temple. This is a nice Temple with good architecture and, obviously, the famous jade Buddha (which is much smaller than one may think). I personally prefer to visit the Temple of the reclining Buddha, but this Temple is a classic.

A Bangkok 'Must'. The small (66cm) green jade Buddha is the centre attraction of the Wat Phra Kaew. The architecture of the buildings, the golden mosaics, the museums and the sandstone model of Angkor Wat all make the visit very interesting. We rented the audio guide - very informative and value for money as the guide to The Grand Palace Complex is included as well. Bring water. It is a long walk around the whole complex - almost two hours.What we didn't like:The 1000s of mainland Chinese tourists who were pushy, rude, disrespectful and obnoxious: Laud when the signs asked for 'Silence Please', took photos when the signs said 'No Photo', climbed barriers to touch and have their photos taken with statues when the signs said 'Do Not Climb/Do Not Touch'. Without the mainland Chinese tourists it would definitely have been a 5 star attraction - but only 3 stars after having been poked in the face by their umbrellas (sun), pushed in the back, and loudly yelled at for not moving quickly enough. Try to get there as early as possible - to avoid most of the busloads of Chinese tourists. And no, I am not xenophobic - I live in Hong Kong.
bangkok amazing temple of the emeralda buddha. if u at bangkok u really get t visit this temple, just make sure t b wearing long pants anyway u can borrow some for 200baht,.

Try to avoid peak hours . I would recommend going there really early in the morning or if you can't make it that early, you may start exploring the palace and other temples in the complex before you rush for the Smaragd Buddha.
