The enormous amount of tourists determined to see the Smaragd statue of Buddha might spoil your experience and you might also find statues of Buddha in adjacent temples are bigger and more adorable. The ticket costs 500 baht and can be bought once you are in the complex.While there try to catch the change of guards in front of the palace - we caught one at 12:00.
Spectacular and part of the Palace grounds. I can say lots of things, but it's just the most spectacular thing I saw on my visit to Bangkok. GO!
Jade not Emerald. The buildings surrounding this historical Buddha are much more interesting. It's small. But it gets clothed by season. It is all very interesting.

Iconic!. One of the iconic destinations of Bangkok. It's right up there in the must visit places of Bangkok. But be warned it can get extremely hot and crowded so bring a lot of drinking water as there is quite a lot to see and walk around. The emerald Buddha itself is a sight to behold. Good things come In small packages and this Buddha sure does pack a punch. Majestic and grand.

Very Grand Temple and very crowded. 1. have to visit this temple for 1st timer ... its nicely maintain with lot art and the buddha really grand with all expensive gems on it. 2. lots building to explore, there also lots ast piece with the story on the wall 3. everywhere are bling bling with the gold colour and the reflection of the mirror pcs of thingy on the building/ wall. 4. super crowded ... try to make it as early as u can to avoid the crow. 5. bag will be check before going in too. foreigner will have to pay for fee to visit but local no need. 6. the fee is included to visit grand palace ... but it was not open during my visit :(
Within Grand Palace. Located within the premise of the Grand Palace, it is a beautiful temple with the usual grandeur of the Grand Palace.Not to be missed.

Beautiful. Beautiful architecture and design but please be reminded that a lot of people including locals come here to pray and worship so proper observance must be in effect. Also the place is a bit stinky because people remove their shows to go inside.

Loved it!!!. The temple happens to be one of the most sacred sites in Thailand, which shows in it's architecture. As it resides within the grand palace, you should try and get in as early as possible as all those crowds don't give you a chance to appreciate the beauty of it.
Hot day!. Very crowded, one of the smaller buddhas, get a map of the grounds at the entrance to navigate the whole complex.

Visited with Friends... It's wonderful to visit the grand palace. I recommend to bring your umbrella when its super sunny. Our day inside the palace wonderful, we enjoyed all the fascinating views and displays.
Amazing place. You can plan this place along with the Grand Palace visit. This is just back side of the palace. You should see it to believe it.
Amazing temple. Worth the crowds, this is one of the out standing temples in Bangkok. But be prepared to que, almost too many people to fully enjoy.

Great visit from Chao phraya boat. Always interesting to visit this huge Buddha and Wat. Take off your shoes, put them in the plastic bag provided and walk around. Lovely architecture, great way to spend 15 minutes or so

Main sight in BKK. this is the main tourist site in Bangkok and well worth a visit....BUT it gets very very busy so get there before 8.30 when it opens because by 9 there's thousands of tourists trying to get in, mostly Chinese tourists in big groups
Beautiful but Crowded!. It was very crowded here but it's definitely worth checking out. Many photo ops, beautiful architecture.

Not an emerald . Many people think the Buddha is made of emerald because of the name but in fact it is actually jade. Small in scale, it is far from the crowds and no photos are allowed. It is worth seeing while you are visiting the Palace, but don't expect much.

nice tiny buddha. some crowd at the front so I have to stare from afar. It is only a few feet in height. I thought initially it was a black
buddha but it actually look like Jade.

Signs posted that pick pocketers work in teams??. Beautiful building if you don't mind the close crowds and moving through the site like cattle. I don't know any workaround to seeing it except with a lot of people. We got there early but so did 80 tour busses. The funny part comes at the end when you must squish through a narrow opening to leave as others are pushing in. Comical for me but sad for small children. Just be prepared with your patience and enjoy it.
Very impressive. One of the top sites to visit in Bangkok. Do it with a guide or on your own it will be very enjoyable. Then jump into a tuk tuk and head to the Grand Palace for a great day out.

Another Temple, but its on the list. Wife wanted to go here, and to see this temple she had read about, and with this in mind, we followed the crowds. The temple itself is fantastic, the man hours put into it must run into years, and at the centre is the Jade Buddha itself, but be warned, it you have bad eyesight like my wife, you may need a good camera to see the face of the Buddha itself

A MUST see!. You cannot visit Bangkok without including the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Keow. However my advice would be to avoid Chinese New Year and the weeks surrounding as I have never found it as busy as it was on this visit. It was just a sea of people which in this degree of heat and humidity was exhausting! For me it isn't the tiny emerald buddah which is the highlight of this complex; it's the fabulous wall paintings depicting images of the Ramayana. Don't listen to touts who will tell you the temples are closed to drag you off to a"sponsor" - often a tailor or gem factory- the Palaces open every day and close only if there is a member of the Royal family visiting. Don't let the weather put you off either, I had one of my best visits when the wind blew through the chimes hanging around the eves, creating the most amazing atmosphere. Do try the express ferry from one of the piers, getting off at Tha Thian, but this option is a complete no go for those with nervous or very small children and older people with less mobility, as you need to be fleet of foot to get on and off the ferries quickly.
such an efficient way to get around Bangkok. The BTS is clean, fast and efficient...we only use this form of transport whilst in Bangkok and usually buy a rabbit card.
Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Don't miss this. We did a tour with a tour guide who brought us around and gave us all the info we needed.
LOVED IT!. Could have spent the day! Totally amazed! Crowded but perfectly organized Tour! a must see in Bangkok!
Prodigious temple. All the temple is really stunning. The sculptures are quite impressing and I just loved the architecture.
Go see. When we went to see this Buddha I was expecting to see a huge Buddha, be prepared it is small. Still go see it you won't be disappointed.

A must see when in Bangkok. Plenty to look at and well worth seeing, all the colours and buildings are fantastic. You could spend an hour or so wandering about or all day there if you are interested in the history and tradition of everything far more. The temples they have there are something you will not get to see anywhere else to quite the standard and extent of the ones here. Definitely recommend going!!

Mind blowing. The most jaw dropping amazing inspirational place I have had the privilege to visit.Plan to spend a lot of time there it is vast and you will not want to rush round. Words cannot do justice to the splendour of this place, I loved it.
Most Sacred Buddhist Temple. It was super crowded and hot sunny day, the Golden Temple was shinning in the sun and it was amazing to watch. It is a must attraction.
Small Buddha large impact. A venerated Buddha and living cultural icon for Thai Buddhists. Beautiful and well worth a visit. Easy to reach and good on hot steamy days and rainy days alike.

Charming temple but small Buddha . My husband and I took a day tour and this temple was part of the package.Braise yourself as it is very crowded compared to other places. Maybe it was the time of the day but queueing u set such heat was draining but worth it.Ensure you visit the museum first to understand the history and role of the Emerald Buddha. Our guide did a great job at bringing it to life!The Buddha itself is located in a temple and looks very small elevated right in the centre. You will need to remove your shoes, have covered legs and shoulders so ensure you have the right outfit for the visit.It was nice to see but could have done it faster with the crowd.

Small statue at the top of a pyramid looks tiny. This is really the same visit as the Grand Palace, it just located in the next section.The Buddha is 66cm high and made of Jade (not emerald - there's a surprise). It is underwhelming because it sits on top of a huge plinth/pyramid.The carvings, inlays and decorations are, however, spectacular. Again, the health warning is that this is not an "ancient" site. More 19th Century decorations. Very pretty though.
Beautiful Buddha. This was very nice to see but super crowded. We were here during a holiday weekend and it would be better to visit during a less crowded time.
Amazing. So much splendour to this Buddha, the jewels are unbelievable along with the rest of the exhibition, another must see.

Worth visiting even for experienced Asian wanderers. Contrary to the Grand Palace, this wat is warm, authentic, and home of very, very impressive Emerald Buddha statue. The entry fee is very affordable. Your must-do in Bangkok.
Crowded!. The crowd is so huge at the time of 9am! Basically, you have no space to take photos and stop to observe the architecture. Without the guide, you may get lost being jam in the crowd.

Beautiful glittering temple. This was my second visit to Wat Phra Kaew, and the statues and construction of the temple is still as majestic as ever. The admission price for foreigners is 500 baht, but free if you are a Thai national (some staff are lenient if you look Thai). Make sure to take plenty of water as you will be doing a lot of walking around and Bangkok is known to be very hot. Please note that if you are wearing shorts (men and women), or ripped jeans, singlets or anything not covering your shoulders or knees, you will have to rent clothes from the front at 200 baht per item. If there are a lot of people on the day (and there usually is every day), this can take a lot of time, so be prepared and pack something extra to put on in your bag. Also, we found the ice cream stand after you exit is very very expensive! We paid more there than in Australia, and we won't be having ice cream there again. The day we went, there were a lot of Chinese tour groups who disobeyed the signs asking for silence, and were yelling out to their friends and family. Please respect the temple as it is a sacred place for Buddhists. Also, they kept hitting us with their selfie sticks, but thats not the fault of the temple in any way.

Nice and big. I was there during a hot day and it was challenging, man it was hot! It cost 500 THB to go in and you can't wear shorts, you can borrow clothes (200 THB a piece as a deposit), they are very strict with dress code.

Most Beautiful Temple. Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha) is, in my opinion, the best of all the temples in Thailand. I have been here a dozen times in the past and I try to visit every time I get to Thailand - as I did this trip. I could write a book about what there is to see and explore here - I'll just say that you absolutely MUST visit this temple. Almost every time I go, the entrance price is higher. It started at 40 baht back in 1971 and this time I had to pay 500 Baht. Recently it is getting more and more crowded and this time was no exception - the Chinese tours are everywhere. As part of the admission you can visit the Grand Palace. Actually, you must see the Grand Palace as it is on the way out via the only exit. Also, at the very end of your journey you will be able to go into the Queen Sirikit Museum. This is also included in the temple admission so why not check it out? I'd plan on a minimum of 2 hours here, unless you are a photo fanatic - then you'll need much more time!

Definitely visit. This is in the palace complex and worth going to. It was very crowded when we were there. The King changes the garments warn by the Buddha every season. The Buddha is actually jade not emerald.

Beautiful. A great temple that was beautiful as expected. There are lots of people but that was also expected. We saw this temple, the reclining buddha and the grand palace in the span of several hours to make a great day of it.

I expected more from all the hype.. This temple's admission is included in the 500 baht cost of entering the Grand Palace and I'm glad because I would have been a bit annoyed if I paid an extra fee. Though the wat is beautiful and clearly painstakingly kept in tip top shape it was a let down. This was the only wat I encountered (so far) in Bangkok that pictures were not allowed inside but I could get over that. What was more surprising was that the emerald buddha is tiny; maybe that's why pictures are not allowed, because they don't want people thinking they may have wasted their time before your baht is in their pocket. I was literally jaw dropped at the tiny size of this buddha and, unlike most temples visited, quick to leave.Do not allow this to detract you from visiting the Grand Palace though, it is beautiful. Just don't be shocked when there's not much to see at Wat Phra Kaew.

Buddha complex in Bangkok. I visited it 2014 January and it's a must visit for culture, art lovers. It's massive complex so take your time to walk around. Shoulders and knees must be covered. If you don't have anything they will give you long sleeves. Many temples inside and really big Buddha. It's a great place to spend your day in Bangkok.

Popular, but worth it.. You get the opportunity to get fairly close to the Emerald Buddha as well as seeing other people pray/the opportunity to pray yourself. I felt like this place was a lot more cultural than other temples, even with masses of tourists there was definitely a more serene energy and respect to those who had come to worship and while that part wasn't for me, it definitely added to the experience.
Beautiful!. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a must see in Bangkok and one of the first places we visited. It was a bit overwhelming with the crowds but part of a great day.
Great option. It is a very nice place to start your trip... it gives you a clear idea on temples architecture and their culture.

A beautiful and serene and peaceful temple.. A beautiful temple and a highly sacred place or Buddhists people. Ladies please ensure you wear long dress and covered shoulders and hands. Leave sandals or shoes outside. for the gentleman long trousers, long sleeve shirts and no shorts allowed. Likewise leave your sandals and shoes before entering. Pay respect even though its not your religious beliefs. It's the same thing you would do if you entered St. Peter's in Rome without taking off your shoes, a little difference. It's a great thing if each worldly religion pays respect to the other as one is being watched carefully. There is no harm in that.
One of the best places to see in Bangkok. I would say that this place is the most beautiful in the Bangkok and highly advised to see! The architecture is breath taking.

Essential. One of the most sacred and certainly lovely temples in Thailand. A must if you are visiting the Royal Palace area, easily included in your itinerary. Interesting history behind the "emerald" Buddha.

This temple is worth the trip with a good local guide. We visited this temple in the afternoon, there is a stillness inside and the building is lower in temperature when you enter the temple. You can have your fortune told here by putting a coin in the slot and getting a number and then collecting the fortune that goes with this number. This place has an amazing spiritual energy if you understand those kind of vibrations. Even if you don't you will still feel the special atmosphere of this location.

Just unbelievable. Thais really went all out when making this place. It's not easy to describe. You just need to see to believe. In all my travels this is some of the best detail I have seen in everything at this temple.

excellent. Bautiful and well maintained . Ancient history kept in tact . Loved the building architecture and the story of the temple . Please hire a guide who can explain the art and artifacts around the temple worth every penny.

Could Have Passed on This One. The Emerald Buddha was beautiful, albeit small, in a very big temple room. I appreciated the sense of reverence and respect permeating the room. Our visit took place during Chinese New Years however, and the visitor traffic was not managed well. It reminded me of COSTCO on a very bad day - times three. If you are visiting Bangkok during any kind of busy season, this is one sight you can see on-line with much less headache.

Its tiny!. Another temple can be such a drag especially on the feet!But, this one is worth seeing too!!However, the emerald Budda is not in fact made of emeralds! But if Jade. It is situated up high on a shrine. Difficult to see any detail. No photography!Very busy. Remember your temple clothes! Cover shoulders and knees!

If you have only one chance to visit Bangkok, don't miss this!. It is the most valuable place for Bangkok culture in term of architecture and culture. But sometime they closed for the grand place which you could see together with the Temple. So double check the day first before you go.

beautiful and magnificient. the temple is one of the most unique ones I have been to. We sat inside the temple for 30 mins and it was calming and peaceful. the grand palace is sitauted right next to it. It was very busy on week days as well.
A must on your first trip to Bangkok. Stunningly beautiful with amazing murals depicting life of Buddha as well as scenes from the Ramakien from where the current Royal dynasty draws its legitimacy.

top attraction in Bangkok. Easily accessible by road as well as boat, the temple is a must see on every tourist's itinerary. One gets a common ticket along with the ticket to the Grand Palace for 500Bahts.The place is crowded practically at all times and one must be decently dressed.
No. 1 tourist attractive place. Don't miss!!! This is a no.1 tourist attractive place of Thailand. You can see an excellent architecture, It has over 100 buildings with 200 years royal history.

Extremely Crowded. Extremely crowded. It's very hot and hardly any shade.
Difficult to see everything well as there are too many people at any one time

Visit in rainy season. we visited in winter season, hence buddha was covered entirely with a golden shawl. To see the actual emerald buddha visit in summer or rainy season. Rainy season attire is mesmerising

Many faithful are attracted to the Emerald Buddha. The emerald Buddha is truly magnificent and well worth a visit. It is located in a very crowded tourist area so plan on crowds and heat and drink plenty of water. Also be prepared to take your shows off. Be properly dressed with covered shoulders and pants that go close to your ankle. Several from our party were given pants or shawls to drape over so they could enter in a respectful way.

A Highlight of the Grand Palace Complex. Religious significance aside, the Emerald Buddha is famous in Thailand and a must see if you visit the Grand Palace. The Buddha is fairly small but lavishly decorated and the surrounding ornamentation is impressive. Apparently the Buddha's attire changes; I noticed a postcard featuring several different outfits, including the one I saw. Very interesting!

stunning. This temple is over powering with history and beauty. You must remove your shoes before entering, so wear shoes that are easy to take off and on. The temple is an active place of worship where silence is showing respect.

Go early!!!!. Wonderful temple but so crowded and hot that you must go early!!! You need to wear long pants and tshirt or you have to buy loaner clothes there. Definately a must see on your trip to Bangkok!!!

A lot of work for a little Buddha. With so many Buddhas to see and so little time it is nice to see a variety since most of the other Buddhas are gold. However, to get in to see this Buddha does take some work and patience. It was extremely busy and difficult to maneuver getting in and out. It is a must see though.
Very crowded. We went in the afternoon and it was rammed. Of course it's beautiful and seeing the emerald Buddha was on the tick list. It wasn't what I expected but beautiful all the same.

Crowded . Long dress /pants or shirts Hated the crowds .also taking a taxi from there . Rip off. They try to cheat you .do be careful when you get in . Bargain first .bad experience. .Unless you book one before you go.

Well worth a visit. With was well worth a visit. Although as with everything in Thailand I would suggest going early in the day before the weather gets too hot and the crowds too unbearable. Unknown to us we went during the week of Chinese New Year and the place was exceptionally busy.

Sparkling, Colourful and an Absolute Delight.. Suggest buying a ticket ahead of time and wearing long pants/skirt no vest tops. We arrived early morning and already the queue was probably 60 long and people in shorts were being tuned away at the ticket booth Allow plenty for time when visiting this Temple so much worth seeing but very crowded and noisy despite the 'keep quiet' signs. The most crowded being the Temple where the Emerald Buddha sits, we got pushed and shoved and a little hot and bothered but it was worth it. Sadly no photographs allowed inside for sacred and security reasons.It takes time to wonder around to cover all the things you want to see, cold water is available for purchase.

Amazing. Get there early, opens at 8.30. By 10 it is packed, and hot! Do wear long trousers, both sexes, and long sleeved top, girls, otherwise you will have to join a big queue to borrow some. You can buy dirt cheap stuff outside if you forget mad don't want to queue.

Too much crowded. As this is the most famous temple in Bangkok, we decided to visit it. I would not recommend it... too much people that make you lose the spirit of the site, and the price is very high (500 bath to see the temple and the grand palace).

Best temple to visit in Bangkok. Among all of the historical sites and temples, this one is the prettiest and worth a visit! It can be crowded but the lines to buy tickets move quite quickly and the place is large, so even during peak times (I went during Chinese New Year) it is manageable.

Amazing temple, intricate architecture. Located inside the Grand Palace, this houses a large statue of Emerald Buddha. The ambience, while outside is chaotic, becomes serene. You can see intricate and beautiful architecture on the walls and corridors.

Gorgeous. I cant believe there is such an experience. Also make sure you come in low season. Feels like all royal art history of Thailand is there in the Wat Phakao. Ticket for 500bht, included admission to other great. Photos not allowed, which also makes the experience a cool, precious one.
Absolutely amazing~ Do not miss this!. This was one of the most amazing things I have ever seen and I travel a lot! Amazing place! Amazing!
Enjoyed every corner. It's a amazing place, all those beautiful crafted statues, sculptures and temples, wall paintings to fountain. A must visit place in Bangkok.
Amazing!. It was a truly great experience. Learning the history behind it and seeing it! Something to file on your must do list.

Crowd control. After taking off one's shoes and entering the temple, one waits until a guard allows a group to enter and kneel before the Emerald Buddha alter before asked to leave and another group comes and kneels. No cellphone photos permitted!!!

Stunning architecture, and a very spiritual experience. Well worth the visit to this one of the most ornate Temples and a memorable one.
The many years of work and artistic creation is truly something of a true dedication to The Buddhist religion.
Too far. The Emerald Buddha was too far away - it is not big enough to see from that distance. Not that much interesting to me. (I would rather visit the gigantic golden Buddha twice.)

Beautiful temple inside palace. Ticket is included with palace entry, it's a must see, even with the crowds. No pictures inside, but you get the chance to pray to the emerald Buddha (don't point your feet toward the Buddha!)
beautiful!. Very interesting to see, was lucky to get a chance to visit such a beautiful place. Would love to go back again

Nightmare. Went to visit this temple but was accosted on route by someone we thought was a gateman who told us it was closed for half a day. He proceeded to tell us where else to visit one of which was a special export centre which was open to the public for just one week a year and today was the final day. It sold expensive jewellery to the trade normally but one week a year opened its doors to the public and was run on behalf of the Thai government (so he told us). He flagged down a passing Tuk Tuk and told the driver where to take us and that because it was a "special" week he would only charge us 100 baht for the whole afternoon showing us temples and the export centre. He told us the government paid Tuk Tuk drivers for their fuel on this special day so tourists can enjoy the delights of Bangkok. We went to the first temple where there was only one guy in there. He started chatting to us, and he told us he was on holiday from the UK but his family were from Singapore. He asked where we had been and where we planned to go for the rest of the day. We mentioned about the export centre and he got very excited telling us he had just come from there and bought lots of ruby gems at a huge discount as there were no taxes to pay so these pieces were upto 200% cheaper than normal. He told us we must go and showed us photos of the items he said he had bought. Eventually we got to the "export" centre which was called "Mannee Thai". The "Manager" there repeated the same line - that it was government controlled and they were open to the public just this week only and that we could each buy 3 pieces of jewellery at huge discount without paying tax. The pieces they showed us looked really good but we know nothing about jewellery. My wife is recovering from life saving surgery so I thought it might be great to buy her some special jewellery if we didn't have to pay then taxes on them. We ended up buying 2 pieces for quite a lot of money and filled in some forms to confirm they were for personal use and not for resale or business. We came away from there feeling happy and a little later on called our daughter to tell her the story. She immediately became suspicious and told us to research the "export" centre on Google. We couldn't believe what we read - we had been the victims of a sophisticated scam involving the "gateman" at the temple - the Tuk Tuk driver - The guy who pretended to be a fellow tourist from the UK in the temple and of course the store itself. The stories on google from other tourist "victims" of this scam told a very similar tale of how they ended up in the same place. We called the police the following day and went down to the nearby Police Station. The officer there was helpful and took us to the store but the staff there were completely different to the previous day. There were also a couple of "heavies" who came out from the shadows who were a little intimidating. The Police officer told the Manager we wanted a refund but she said we were only entitled to 80% refund because of the "contract" we had signed. She was very brazen and didn't seem concerned about the police officers presence. We told her we had been told by her colleague the previous day that the store was government run and there were no taxes to pay but she disputed this and said we must have misunderstood. Eventually, after a few heated exchanges, the police officer phoned the local "tourist police". I spoke to an interpreter who explained this "scam" was well known to them but there was little they could do because we ha entered the store of our own free will and purchased the jewellery at a price we agreed. I explained that was true but we had been misled by the claims of there being no taxes to pay and reassured by the statement that the store was controlled by the government, so we believed we were dealing with a reputable and safe merchandiser. We were told this was not a criminal matter but rather it was a civil dispute, unless we could prove the jewellery was fake. The interpreter also told us the store operating this scam made their money from the 20% it retained after refunding most tourists the 80%. We refused to accept the 80% and instead contacted our credit card provider who put a hold on the payment pending an investigation into the "dispute". We have no idea how things will finally work out but the message we send here is that if you are approached in a similar way please don't fall into the same trap that we did. We are educated people and normally very cautious but were thrown off our normal course by the amount of people involved in the operation of the scam. Put a huge cloud over our stay in Bangkok, which is a real shame.

Overpriced and Overrated. It costs 500 baht to get in if you look foreign (even some half-Thais get charged because they look white) and free if you're Thai. That wouldn't be a huge deal except it's really hard to figure out what the hundreds of thousands of baht are going towards. You get to the temple and you aren't even allowed to take photos and the emerald Buddha is far away from the viewing area. The outside architecture around the complex is cool, but you can see the same elements by going to Wat Pho and Wat Arun, which combined only costs 200 baht. I'd seriously recommend skipping this place.

BEAUTIFUL & AWESOME. The Wat Phra Kaew is certainly "the" must-see place in Bangkok. Beautiful and colourful combination of different architectural styles, glittering under the sun. Hordes of tourists though anytime of the year, almost anytime of the day; more quiet from 3:00 p.m.
Look for the clothing!. Located on the grounds of the Grand Palace - this small Buddha (26 inches tall) is made of jade or jasper (not emeralds). No pictures are allowed on this temple

out of this world!. I am not going to bore you with details you can easily find in any guide book. Just practicalities:1.Arrive early, preferably before the gates open at 8.30am. Start your day of sightseeing with this particular attraction! There will still be a crowd but at least manageable. Besides, that early the heat is less. The ticket is 500 Bahts per person but is well worth every Baht as this is the most revered Thai temple and consequently most visited . The temple compound is rather crammed with numerous fabulous buildings, statues, stoops etc, all dripping with gold. Further more reason to come early to avoid the maddening crowds later. We needed 1.5h for the Temple and another 1.5h for the Palace and finished just before mid-day including some break for a drink. At the time the crowds at the entrance and ticket office nearly prevented us from leaving. See what I mean?2.To get there best use a taxi but make sure they use a meter. Taxis are cheap and reliable plus give you a moment of respite in their air-conditioned, cool interior. Tipping welcome(10Bahts perhaps?)3.Observe the dress code: long trousers, covered shoulders and knees or you won’t get let in. Can use a sarong if you like and after fold it for the rest of the day. Taking photos of the inside of the buildings is not permitted. The place simply takes your breath away and briskly transports you to the fairyland.

100% must visit!!. This is definitely the number one attraction in Bangkok. I believe it's open from 8am-3:30 pm, and you'll probably spend 1-2 hours there. It's 500 baht per person but well worth the price. I arrived at this place in the afternoon and there were loads of people getting out of their tour bus. It was packed with people taking picture at the entrance. It's best to get pass these people as quickly as possible and spend too long fighting for a spot to take picture at the entrance. As soon as you enter you'll find many places that give you better pictures than the entrance.

Amazing place. This is one of the finest temple/ palace i have visited, and a popular place to visit when in Bangkok, do ensure you find some guides to explain the history of the place which will make you respect and enjoy the place.

Missed the Emerald Budda. Didn't realize that the ticket to enter the Emerald Budda inner sanctum was attached to our entry to the Grand Palace. We didn't see the Budda but enjoyed all the arcetecture around the complex.
Well worth the effort. Very crowded the day we went, we got a guide who was amazing. Spend the money and have a real experience

Despite the number of tourists, it's worth the visit.. It's an impressive place, so many things to see, so many details to pay attention. You don't need to be a religious person to admire and contemplate the place. Don't go there in a rush, it worth every minute you spend there. Of course sometimes you need a little bit of patience because of the number of tourists.

A smallish temple inside the Royal Palace complex. Inside a highly decorated small worship house, the Buddha is beautiful, but smaller than expected. It appeared to be a place of great significance to many prayerful visitors. No inside photos allowed.

Beautiful grounds, tiny buddha!. The best thing about this place is the place itself, the grounds are very nice and interesting to see but don't expect too much from the Buddha - it is tiny and not that impressive!

Family Vacation. This temple of Emersld is most Important Emerald Buddha worshipped
And carved from single block of Jade.Fascinating temple and a must to visit and appreciate what has been done in the 15th.century

A Bangkok Must. I have lived in Bangkok part of the year off and on since the 1970's yet still this week I ventured once again to view and respect the Emerald Buhhha. I seem to be drawn over there every now and then. It is a Bangkok "must" and something very unique.

Must see. Wanted to go here as didn't want to go to Thailand without seeing this
Amazing place with astounding beauty -the temple is absolutely beautiful
Managed to go fairly early so missed the majority of the crowds -and would recommend this
The beauty of this place will stay with me forever -so pleased I have seen it
Magnificent Architecture. Beautiful artwork and intricate detailing to be found everywhere you look. Require a ticket to enter.

A must see while in Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha is a wonder in itself. Beautiful and changing with the seasons it is set in a magnificent altar in a magnificent temple. Join the crowd,take off your shoes and be amazed at the splendor that awaits you.

Good Place to learn Buddhism in Thailand. Majority of Thailand citizen are Buddhist. There are a lot of temples are available in Thailand, however the God (Buddha) in
this temple is excellent, no other word to apply. Must see.

A top site in Bangkok. This a just see when in Bangkok - the beauty of the building and the stories which surround it are amazing and interesting. The king is the only one who can touch the emerald Buddha - so a very special monument for the city and I felt honoured to experience this temple.

Be prepared for the crush . Despite the heaving crowds, this was an amazing site. I hired a tour guide in the end- she was knowledgeable and gave good advice on where to stand to photograph or video vistas in the palace complex. She also lent me a very colourful shirt to hide my ' bare arms'! Beware the strict dress code. She threw in a bottle of water and provided shade with her umbrella. A useful trick by the guides was to have pre-purchased tickets to beat the queues. Very useful lady. Don't try and photograph the jade Buddha - I witnessed the officials dragging offenders bodily over to instant 'fine' boxes to atone for the disrespect. That also applied to zoomed photos through the open entrance but was clearly harder to police.
Very beautiful and very crowded. Very beautiful tempel, but too crowded. We went in and out, too many people everywhere to enjoy our stay very much.

If you like lots of gold, this is the tempe to see!. The Emerald Buddha is quite small but the alter that it is on is truly impressive! The guards usually ask visitors to kneel and to be quite. No photos allowed.
Beautiful. Beautiful building and lots of picture opportunities outside. The Buddha itself you can't get too close to however worth a visit

Awesome beyond belief. I visited with friends and the beauty is beyond belief I have seen many temples but the size and beauty of this one is fantastic. It's very close to Bangkok CBD so easily accessible by taxi at very low cost
Crowded on New Year's Day.. The temple was very beautiful, the New Year's Day crowds prevented us from going inside. We had a guide who explained many of the features.

Crushed by Crowds of Tourists. We toured the temple and adjacent grounds starting at 8:40 -- just 10 minutes after the grounds opened. There were hordes of people from tour groups and the worst crush of people I have ever seen other than watching TV pictures of Times Square on New Years Eve. There was virtually no crowd control -- no organization to the process of removing and storing shoes before entering the temple -- and people were packed so tightly that it was impossible to go anywhere. I would suggest trying to go to this temple in late afternoon, when (perhaps) the hordes of tour groups have left. Or go to Wat Po, which is far less crowded, and in my view has more interesting buildings and the very good massage center.

Very popular attraction, very interesting architecwand wall murals, the emerald Buddha can only be photographed. Very popular attraction with interesting architecture and wall murals, crowds of people milling to this popular attraction, the emerald Buddha can only be photographed outside the building. A note! only long trousers are permitted, a shop opposite the entrance will rent you same.
Impressive. A lovely temple, the emerald Buddha is something else. It's a must see in Bangkok and definately worth an hour of your time.

Beautiful. Try to arrive when it opens to avoid most of the crowds. We got there before the tours and the school trips got there and had plenty of space to roam and lots of pictures without other people in them. Plus it gets hot mid-day and one free bottle of water isn't enough with the heat and many people.
Great. I saw the emerald buddha during my first week living in Bangkok and greatly enjoyed it. It is interesting to see and there is a lot of great history there. I recommend it for tourists.

Beautiful jade Buddha . Part of the palace visit The small jade Buddha is located right on Top inside the temple and has a certain mysterious aura about it given the size and the distance - when we visited the Buddha had a winter coat of gold (apparently the King changes the attire of the statue around 3 times a year)Well worth it - and in any case this is the main highlight of the palace

Beautiful.. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is located in the Grand Palace. Its an small statue of Buddha and it's the most important icon for Thai People.Make sure your clothes cover your arms and legs, as the queues to hire a cover up for your body are very long.Its a must see building , as its absolutely stunning. My tip on this place would be to arrive early as it's usually very crowded.

Don't mi d the crowds, it's worth it!!. Be prepared to visit this place with thousands of others. Makes taking pictures a bit challenging; you have to be quick! Truly beautiful architecture!! Do enter the emerald Buddha hall, it is spectacular: murals, decor, jade Buddha, all of it! Must enter barefoot, so it can be a bit smelly in there because of the crowd, but worth it!! We visited on a Sunday morning, but not sure it makes much of a difference regarding the number of visitors.
Unbelievable Art detail. The detail and beauty of the Temple is breathtaking. This is a can't miss stop if visiting Bangkok. Combine with the Royal Palace.

Amazing. I went to this Temple as a part of Gate 1 Travel. It was a really nice temple, lots of gold temples everywhere. It was my first time and I was in total ahh. Everything was so beautiful and I felt so great to be in the presence of good aura. I would definitely recommend visiting this temple if you are in Thailand. It is a really good experience. I truly loved it!
Beautiful temple, different from others!. it worth to visit thanks to its Italian marble floor! Behind the main entrance the large chiostro give you another perspective of temple life!

Beautiful but very crowded. Me and my husband enjoyed this visit, such a beautiful Temple but so crowded specially with Chinese tourist and understandably because this Temple is the most famous attractions in Bangkok and a very amazing architecture, this is the furst time fir us to visut the Temple and the last.
First time In Bangkok . Wasn't Emerald! Very blingy though. Shame can't take any photos. Very busy which was a Friday. Apparently busier at weekends! !
Very Nice. I really enjoyed the period of meditation I experienced at the Emerald Buddha. It is beautiful to look at and leaves you feeling peaceful

Stunning, but very crowded. This place is one of the biggest attractions in Bangkok, and understandably so: the architecture and statues are absolutely gorgeous and nothing like anything I'd ever seen before. However, before visiting I would recommend everyone to take a deep breath, and brace yourselves for the massive amount of tourists and shouting tourguides you will encounter. It is definitely not peaceful or quiet, but once you manage to see past that, it will likely be one of the highlights of your trip to Bangkok. Tip: definitely take some time to look at the murals! There were quite a few interesting and even funny scenes.

Full of chinese visitors. Photo inside the temple it's prohibited. We visited near the Chinese new year and was packed with Chinese visitors. The entrance at 500baht it's quite expensive but it's a must to do in Bangkok. Be aware that you must dress appropriate, else you can not enter the temple. You can borrow clothes at the entrance with a deposit of 200baht per person.

Amazing but crazy.. We went early and there was mobs of people. Because it was nuts and the site doesn't provide a great map and info, we waited for a guide to take the tour. I lasted about 2 minutes on the tour because his English wasn't good and he was very repetitive. The cost of visiting is also rising quickly, it is now 500 baht.
Buddha Extreme. A must see. One of the main sites for a fascinating religious experience and another highly ornamented temple.
Nice experience. This was a very nice experience as we were there on Friday where monk were praying.No photos allowed inside the temple.

A Thai holy place. Although crowded with tourists, there were many Thais praying to the Emerald Buddha. The Buddha itself is quite small, elevated and illuminated. Removal of shoes is required to enter and photos are not allowed.

Arrive Early. The temple complex and Grand Palace open at 830, best to go early. Although busy at first, it gets really busy after two hours. Gobs of tour groups. Clothing needs to be modest, long pants, shoulders covered. Otherwise, further delays to rent covering. Backpacks are inspected upon entry. Tickets are not sold at the gate, but at a booth following security check.Remember this ticket set also covers Dusit sights such as Vimanmek Mansion and Ananda Samakhorn Throne Hall. Best way to arrive is via express river boat, use Tha Chang pier to disembark and walk straight down the road to the opening in the huge white wall. Once into the temple grounds, murals line the walls. Many fine Buddha depictions, and of course in the ordination bot is the most prized, the Emerald Buddha. Great spires and detailed workmanship abound. After touring the temple area, proceed around the grounds to the Grand Palace. Allow at least an hour, but you could spend up to four hours to really see everything in the complex.

Part of the Grand Palace experience.. Interesting to see, but you can't get close enough to the "emerald Buddha to really see it. It is actually made of jade and very small. The rest of the Grand Palace and temple areas were much more interesting.

crowded, but worth viewing. expensive to visit, around 12euro but very beautiful, can be done in an hour, the emerald buddha itself isnt very impressive, its very small and theres literally a crush to get into it so not a pleasant experience, worth checking out in all though
Too crowded and too hot!. Thousands people flooded into the Grand Palace and Wat Phrakaew made them too crowded, too noisy and too hot! I honestly could not enjoy them all :(

Just stunning a must see in bangkok. what a fantastic place to visit,yes crazy busy but so well managed it was a pleasure and as a Thai made me so proud .will definitely come back again with friends from overseas to show them our beautiful thai culture.
Easy to visit. The Temple is not large and you can get in easily. The Emerald Buddha is very small, but you can see it! It's a one of a kind!
Must see. This is the best temple in thailand and all tourists should visit this place. This is nicely built and is 250years old. Thid temple is full of crowd.
Beautiful. Beautiful temple in the heart of the Grand Palace complex. The whole site is very unique and special, a must see when in Bangkok.

Worth to see. The top place to see in Bangkok...
Xclnt work of sculptures ... Models ... Very reach in colors... Huge place to explore

Vast and colourful. Its close to the Grand Palace totally worth seeing both in one tour. It would take a minimum of an 2 hours to complete the area as there are alot of visitors. Its architecture is amazing and takes your breath away.

Really nice temple containing a precious artifact.. The temple is a glorious structure with a lot going on. The actual Emerald Buddha inside is a sight to behold considering it's history. It's housed within the Grand Palace so you can combine the two sites in one trip and it's well worth visiting. Make sure you wear clothes that cover your shoulders and legs.

The architecture is more impressive than the Emerald Buddah. Despite the crowds and the small size of the Emerald Buddha, this attraction is still a must see in Bangkok. The sparking temples are so beautiful that the Emerald Buddha almost feels like an afterthought.

STUNNING!!!!. This was my favourite temple in Bangkok, inside the temple is absolutely stunning! You're not allowed to take pictures inside and you must sit down once inside. I highly recommend a visit, the atmosphere was very peaceful and the statues are beautiful! Don't forget to cover up!

Amazing Palace, but avoid busy times.. I would think to go in the mornings on weekdays would be better; I visited this palace on a Saturday afternoon, there were so many tourists. I arrived around 3pm, so I had about an hour to visit the grounds as I learned they ended ticket sales at 16:00. You need to get tickets to enter, so be prepared to cue up for this.I highly recommend visiting this place, its beautiful, but if you want to take photos its best to avoid the times when there are so many tourists. Many of them walk around with their selfie sticks and its difficult to appreciate the palace properly. I think they should ban selfie sticks here.

Most visiting place in Thailand. It is my favorite place every time when i visit Thailand. You can enjoy a wonderful scenery from its building and surrounding area. I learn a lot of Thai culture and history from the art wall around the temple. So excited.

Temple Temple. One of the many temples we visited and it was amazing again to see so much gold and the structures are astonishing. Mind you, we had to remove our footwear in respect to their religion in going in the temple. Everyone did it but sad to say,there were other tourists who couldn't follow simple rules though.

A dream come true. This is one of the must-see stops in Bangkok. But be warned, you must dress properly when visiting this Wat. . Many blogs on the internet tell you that you can simply throw a scarf over your shoulders and be admitted. If you are wearing a tank top this is not true. Be sure to wear a proper shirt or t shirt that covers the shoulders and tops of your arms. Also be sure to wear proper clothing on your legs that go down to your feet. We had to buy clothing from a vendor outside the Wat to make sure we were properly covered. Other than that it was a great experience and I highly recommend visiting this location.
Wow ... Loved the emerald Buddha temple..And it's historyRecommended if you traveling to bkk for first time..

Don't miss it!. One of the most beautiful temples I've ever visited. It's just amazing, if you go to one place while in Bangkok make sure it's the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew! Just make sure you dress properly (long skirt/trousers, and covered shoulders).
Amazing wonder. The one downside to this attraction is its popularity...well deserved but expect huge crowds which can be a bit uncomfortable. Other than that this is a must see when in Bangkok.

Marvellous place to see. We went on a Sunday, close to Cinese New Year. It was packed, a lot of pushing and sun umbrellas I would now class as semi lethal weapons.It made it very difficult to enjoy what is undoubtedly a fabulous site. No shorts and shirts must have sleeves or you will need some form of cover up.Our guide kept reminding us to be aware of our personal possessions.Well worth a visit but be prepared for the crush.
Must visit. One of the must visit places for first timers to bangkok. Very interesting and beautiful.The place is extremely crowded but it just tells the significance of the place.
Don't miss. This is a really interesting temple. I thought the Buddha would be bigger bit never the less still impressive.

Loved it. Very good and would recommend anyone going to Bangkok to go there. people are very friendly but you need to respect their religion.which is Buddhism. - don't buy any Buddha's as you are not allowed to bring them out of the country.
Beautiful. So many temples and so little time. This is a do not miss temple. Easy to reach. Hire a tuk-tuk driver to shuttle you to the various temples.

An out of the world experience. While the grandeur of the royal palace may leave one starry eyed as the massive garudas shine in the morning sun, the calm and quiet serenity of the emerald Buddha carved out of a monolithic jade doesn't cease to amaze you. The tiny thing like the golden angavastram corresponding to each season reminds you of Buddha's humanity and at the same time the elevated pedestal from which he looks at you is a reminder of your own insignificance. A humbling experience.

The History Monument of the Buddhist. This place is really amazing, and most the place is covered in emerald gold and really and there are many great monument and the atmosphere relaxing.i really suggest you take your time and enjoy the place and hour or two, relax, walk slowly and enjoy the things around you.

visitor must go. Thai Temple , the best one in Thailand that you shouldn't miss.Most tourist like it, including my friends from Belgium. Beautiful Thai architecture. There are also many places around there for tourist visiting.
Amazing !!!. Spectacular experience. One temple is just more beautiful than the other. There are lots of people there and be sure to take water with you

Most popular in Bangkok city area. The beautiful architecture over 250 years old, this place was beginning build together with Bangkok capital city in 1782. The Emerald Buddha over 2,000 years old was moved into main building and enshrined in the present. The belief of the most of prayers place and then successful as you wish.

Go early...and wear long pants. It's hot, go early. And bring or wear long pants because shorts aren't allowed. The temple is mobbed with Thai and non-Thai tourists an hour after opening. We enjoyed arriving early and enjoying what must have been intended as a peaceful and introspective space.

Beautiful but crowded. We started with Wat Pho around 10, and then went to Wat Phra Kaew at 11:30 by walk. It was already too crowded. The architecture is impressive and all the sculptures too. The small temples you can visit (with pants and shoulders covered) are all very beautiful and seems peaceful even with the crowd there. (There is a good respect). Don't answer to anything people tell you outside of the temple, it is taxi drivers that will tell you its closed, or can't go with pants, and than will drive you somewhere else to buy things from them. We however passed by the Grand Palace that is not really worth it (this explains the 4 out of 5 on my review)
Beautiful but there is so much around that is the same. The entrance fee is affordable so it's worth a look if you're there but it may not be worth it if you've been the the Grand Palace

Mesmerizing. Have a half day tour at this place since the complex is huge and has a lot to see. Do carry your water bottle and some food. Entry fee is 500 Baht per person. Ideal to visit in second half of the day. Expect a lot of crowd. Please read dress code before visiting. Timing: 9:30 - 3:30
Worth even the news years day crowds. it was sardines getting in on new years eve, but the whole grounds were so beautiful and each component/temple so unique. So may great photo opportunities.

A must see although prepare for many people. Very crowded but despite that a must see in bkk. Try to read about the not so busy days during your stay to really enjoy it. Dedicate half a day to a full day to see everything and admire it
Beautiful. Actually quite a modest Buddha, but surrounded by so much exquisite art. A beautiful temple that is unmissable.
More gold than Jade. The drawback of the "cold season" is that the Buddha is nearly completely covered by his garment so it is difficult to see, how special he is...

Very calm atmosphere. One of the most amazing things about this Buddha is how small it is compared to others. However it is incredibly and ornately lifted up to a high position of immense respect. Beautiful sight, remember no photographs here.

Beautiful but expensive. The entry ticket at 500baht is pretty steep. Also you need to wear full sleeves and knees covered. If you go in afternoon then full.sleeves can irritate you due to hot weather. The architecture is beautiful and also the model of ankor wat temple of cambodia also very impressive. We had hired a guide for 1000baht but their english very poor so couldnt understand most of what they said. Must watch in the morning.

So beautiful. It's a bit of mission getting to see this a lot of pushing and shoving and getting very hot but once your in, you'll be pleased you've seen it be warned though no picture taking inside... not that this stopped a lot of the tourists but if your being respectful to the thai culture then you don't take photos.

Must see. Over the last 30 odd years I have visited Bangkok a number of times and try to visit this temple in the grounds of the Grand Palace. It's a lot busier than it used to be and go as early as you can to avoid the heat and tour groups. Having said that, using a tour may be the best way to understand this complex and it's history.Basically, if you have been to Bangkok or even Thailand and not this site that is Thailand, then you haven't really been, if you get my drift.

Worth a visit. The Buddha itself is impressive, but found it very diffcult to photograph, you walk down one side & back up the other, can be quite crowded dont worry about the dress code, they provide a gown & shoe bag which will save you dressing in long trousers all day in the heat.

Beautiful temple. Tourists driven in like cattle.. This temple is regarded as a holy temple by a lot of the believers. For non believers maybe it is better to respect from a distance and not walk in and out as cattle. Just my opinion. There is really not that much to see (and no photographs) are allowed inside other than people praying.

people on top of each other basically. I can't really say my rating is fair because I never made it in. At 10am the grand place was already a frackin zoo. The emerald Buddha was even worse. With the temp near 100 F, the crush of people, the annoying tourists who don't believe queues/lines applies to them, taking off the shoes along with the giant piles of other sweaty shoes I didn't even want to make the attempt in. If you want to see this I suggest this being the first thing you do as soon as the grounds are opened.

Oy the crowds!!!. The Buddha is very small in comparison to the room and you cannot photograph it so that is a bit disappointing. it is part of the enormous and extremely crowded Grand Palace complex. It is no doubt a must see but to say it's enjoyable or even moving would be a stretch. Everyone is hot and bothered from the heat of Bangkok as well.
The beautiful colours!. I could not leave after a few hours walking around in circle looking around. It was absolutely beautiful and worth taking hundreds of photos!

Duel Pricing Causes Friction. With a 500 baht admission fee for foreigners I was not in a hurry to visit Wat Phra Kaew again, but I had visitors from Australia so it fell to me to take them there.Thais are admitted free to this temple, the most sacred in Thailand, and it is a cause of controversy and commentary that foreigners are charged 500 baht. There are frequent letters on the subject to the editors of the English language press in Thailand.Having said that, Wat Phra Kaew, or the Temple of the Emerald Buddha as it is more commonly known, is a "must see" for any first-time visitor to Bangkok.The Emerald Buddha is probably the most sacred item in Thailand and only the King or his son, the Crown Prince, are allowed to touch it, which they do when they change its seasonal robes. Although it is called the Emerald Buddha, it is in fact carved from jade.The temple grounds are a kaleidoscope of mosaic walls, murals, giant guardian demons, apsaras (angels) stupas and smaller wats.Wat Phra Kaew is still plagued by scam artists at the entrance gates who rush to meet you when you approach the temple to tell you it is closed to foreigners today "because of a religious ceremony". They then offer to take you on a private tour of Bangkok, which inevitably includes stopping off at jewelers shops and silk shops where you are under heavy pressure to purchase something.Don't be taken in. Proceed to the gates and check out for yourself whether it is closed or not.Modest dress is obligatory, which means below the knee dresses and shorts, and no exposed shoulders or plunging necklines.
Temple of the Emerald Buddh. This was a nice visit for history buffs, My daughter is one such person. She loved it. My son in law...too much information.
Must see.. Yea it's touristy and crowded, but the site tells a great story. The Buddha itself is relatively small but the rest of the site is larger than life.

Beautiful. This temple is inside the grounds for the Kings Palace. Packed with people but definitely worth the visit. No photos are allowed inside, which is a shame but understood, as it is just too opulent to explain to others.

Famous and protected. I was glad to see the Emerald Buddha somehow protected from photo opportunists. They really struggled to ban people from taking pictures, although many pretended they did not see, hear or whatever. They made them delete the pictures if they were caught.Otherwise, it's an impressive shrine, on top of which Buddha stands. In fact, legend says the priest who found the statue thought it was Emerald, yet it is made of Jade.

Worth the trip . Theology aside, the architecture and history make this place worth the visit. There are many subtly different styles in the surrounding buildings which are reminiscent of various periods in history...it is an education.
Must to see place in Bangkok. visit it when you are at the grand palace... but always crowded, lot of people, and a big mess. but need to visit, when you are in Bangkok

Beautiful temple. Visited in dec 2015.The ticket to the grand palace and the temple are clubbed together. And as everyone else has mentioned ,there is a dress code.Do keep that in mind or be prepared to be fleeced at the shops outside, which rent or sell clothes but at an exorbitant price.While on the subject do carry a hat esp for the little ones. It gets pretty hot and there is very little shade .The architecture is beautiful.Seeing the entire place can take close to two hours.If you start early the crowd is less.There is a nice ice cream shop at the back, in case you need to refresh yourself after all the walking.Once you finish the palace and temple tour you can walk down to the Wat Pho (temple of reclining Buddha).It is close by ,a pleasant walk .Tuk tuks charge a lot .

very beatiful, but way too expensive. +very beautiful buildings and paintings on the wall-500 baht ist way too much i think-too many people there -> better visit other tempel/nice buildings which are cheaper , e.g. wat pho

PACKED like sardines..... It was new years day so the place was PACKED.... but once squeezing inside after about 20 minutes, the grounds were lovely and we were amazed by how many different parts there were to the whole complex, each being so detailed and unique.
Temple of the Emerald Buddah. Great place to see Thai history. You can feel the spirit and history. Beautiful architecture. They do have a dress code so look it up before going.

A must see temple. You visit the temple on one ticket as this is inside the Grand Palace. One disadvantage - the place is crowded. Any way – must see beautiful temple and one of the most important temples for Thai people.

One of popular BKK temples. There's really not much to do in the temple, other than telling a short story to your friends that you've been to the place. For Bangkok first-time travelers, just give it a try though if only to complete your itinerary by going to popular tourist attractions.

Gold. The design of the structures are breath taking. The amount of details from the pillars to the roof of the pillars are amazing. Don't bother with a tour guide you don't need one for they give you pamphlets of your language inside. Takes around 2 hours but worth it. Be sure to dress accordingly for since it is the Grand Palace where appropriate clothing no shorts or booty shorts ahaha.
Amazing . Great temple worth seeing just for the clothes change!!!!!! Follow it up with visiting the museum above the ticket office
Another site to visit.. Not baad not great. Its pretty small but has history. Good way to spend an hour or two. Just check it off your list when youre done. Dont need a guide just go in.

Fabulous buildings. Worth a visit.. Located in the royal palace grounds which are huge. Fabulous buildings. Worth a visit. You can't take photos inside of the Buddha. Buddha has three sets of gold clothes , one for each season..

Amazing . This was the first place that I visited in Bangkok that really made me feel I was in Thailand... an impressive construction full of gold and beautiful mosaics... everything there was so big and impotent, except the Emerald Buddha that is very small but still amazing. It is very touching to see all the respect and worship that Thai people have on it.

Emerald Buddha. One of the sites at the palace it is pretty spectacular As with all temples dress appropriately have some one keep an eye on your shoes when going in. Was told sometimes they are stolen. No pictures or pointing at the Buddha. They have guards inside to monitor. Also there are a lot of people praying so one needs to be mindful of that.

Beautiful temple. This temple , which is located in the grounds of the Grand Palace, is home to one of the most revered images of Sri Buddha in Thailand.The statue itself is diminutive but more than makes up for it with its beauty.Adorned in attire and ornaments which is changed with the different seasons (summer, monsoon, winter), the statue sits in a grand hall surrounded by wooden tapestry and gold ornaments almost like a throne.The whole atmosphere is one of peace and tranquility in contrast to the milling crowds outside!Fabulous.
Incredible place to see... Apart from the large crowds it was worth a visit and see this amazing place! The detail of the Temple outside and in is immense.

Quiet and tranquil. Walked here and was beautiful. We were lucky enough to see a group of monks I meditation which was really special. Hardly anyone there when we went which made it a really personal experience.
EMERALD BUDDHA. Every time my Thai wife and I are in Bangkok we go to this Temple. She likes to visit it and loves to pray at Wat Phra Kaew.

Over the Top!. Over the top on many levels. The opulence and artisan is magnificent. Every corner of the building is covered with royal grandeur. Also, over the top with the crowds. This place was a madhouse at 10:30am on a Friday morning. If you forget to put on long pants and a shirt to cover the shoulders then they rent to you with a full refund for 200 baht per piece.

VISIT . This is an another temple here you must visit.A beautiful temple.The temple is full of Tourists and locals.
Worth the visit.

Fascinating. best visited via the river on either a private long tailed boat or river bus from the pier near the Shangri LA and this way one can also take in Wat Arun.The complex is rather muddled in terms of signage but they do provide maps. It's also usually extremely hot and humid although water is available on the premises.From the river to the temples thee are some very cool coffee bars and cafes.

Don't miss this. Went very early, then crows of people started to arrive. This temple is actually in the middle of the Grand Palace. Take your time to visit, many details to observe.TIP if you don't want to chance of loosing your shoes, bring a plastic bag or back pack and keep them with you, instead of leaving them outside of the temple where there are hundreds of pairs of shoes!Many tell you that you are not allowed to wear flip flops, there were at least 50% of people wearing them, wish I had worn mine,it was so hot.Enjoy at least once in your life, very impressive.
Small, but still impressive. Included with the Grand Palace visit - this little Buddha draws a big crowd. The statue is quite small, but the shrine he's built up on is amazing.
A must see in Bangkok. It's always packed with tourist so go early when you can, I always take first time visitors to Bamgkok there and all of them are suitable impressed

Beautiful. The temple is beautiful. The Emerald Buddha is not made of emerald. You are not allowed to take pictures inside of Wat Phra Kaew. One fun fact: the King of Thailand changes the outfit of the Buddha three times a year in accordance to the three seasons of Thailand (cool, summer, & rainy).

Tourist hell. This place is beautiful but you cannot appreciate this as everywhere you look there are people. EVERYWHERE. And the groups we encountered were particularly rude - we got barged (actually barged, not just the polite shooing-out-of-the-way kind) out of the way several times and found ourselves exhausted and stressed after the whole experience.
The hearth of Thai culture.. The hearth of Thai culture. Make it happen at least one time in your life!!!!For sure if you make the first happen, the second will be follow

Very Beautiful and Important but MEAN security gaurds!. This is an important spot for Thai art and history for the country in general. But the one place you want to take pictures is of the emerald buddha. NO pictures! A guard took my phone and would not only NOT give it back to me, but wouldn't even talk to me to tell me how to get it back! One of my worst travel experiences.

Very busy. We are not huge temple people but it was nice to see. They will provide you with clothes to cover up with if they feel that you are not appropriately dressed. They only take cash for entrance fees.

Magnificent architecture and suggest to visit early in the morning. The architecture is absolutely breath taking. I have been to many of the palaces in the world, this has to be one of the most beautiful I have ever seen. If you go in early in the morning, you can avoid the crazy crowds of tourists and get a chance to think quietly how these pieces of arts were architected and built in Thailand's history. Even though most part of the temple are not open for visit, but by just taking a glimpse of it, you will sure be impressed.

An exceptional chamber. It's lauded as the most sacred Buddha in Thailand, but some of the reviews suggested it was very small and underwhelming.We certainly didn't find it so. It was magnificent as was the rest of the Wat in which it resides.Well worth the crush and the heat to see it

Most amazing spot in Bangkok!. The Grand Palace was huge and crowded. I had to ask around before finding the Emerald Buddha. What a gem! I meditated there for quite a while, while the crowd swirled around me. It was the highlight of my time in Bangkok. Be sure to dress and act respectfully at all temples in Thailand (and elsewhere)

Beautiful BUT..... This is an incredibly beautiful place, right up there with St. Peter's in Rome. However, it was so uncomfortably crowded I just wanted to get out of there. They really need to have some sort of crowd control - timed entry perhaps? My suggestions- maybe be the first person there when it opens, or last person when it closes, otherwise be prepared to suffer with rude people, selfie sticks in your face, and most unbelievably - people climbing and sitting places they should not.

Beautiful Architecture. Despite the horrendous crowds of Chinese tourists (we did go in high season, though), this temple is magnificent. You can't walk more than two feet without finding something beautiful to take a picture of. Absolutely gorgeous. Ladies, be warned: my girlfriends and I wore long skirts and tank tops but brought light shawls that completely covered our shoulders and arms. Not good enough--of course the guard wouldn't let us in because we "didn't have sleeves on." Conveniently, there was a shop right next to his station... with tshirts for 500B. Just be warned...

Jan 9th 2016. From Wat Arun we could see the roof tops of Wat phra kaew from across the river, it looked spectacular under lighting at night. We took a taxi ride because the river crossing was closed. I like walking and i walk miles with dogs but I don't think I would of wanted to walk from Wat Arun to Wat Phra Kaew. Distance and safety, Bangkok is a dangerous city, this isn't just my opinion it's from someone who lives and works in Bankok. We knew the Wat would be closed but we enjoyed the walk around the outside and taking photos of Wat and surrounding area, It must of taken around 30 minites or more, if you try it in the day time I can imagine you will get very warm, It was still busy along the pavement with people selling things. We didn't walk through that area for safety reasons. Probably ok but not worth the risk. I would love to see this place at night from inside the grounds, just to take some photos of the building. It's a wow factor. This is my second trip to Bangkok and a must see next time. I hope it's spectacular in the day.
Amazing place. Just an incredible place, with so many beautiful buildings/things to look at. A must visit while in Bangkok.

The Chaos of Humanity. I suppose if I were a dedicated Buddhist I would feel differently, but given the jostling of the crowds involved in entering this shrine, I did not enjoy the experience as much as I might have. One walks in a preordained path around the temple, before entering and encountering the Buddha (smaller than one might think) clothed seasonally. No pictures inside, and silence is requested, although with the mob that was a lot to ask.

A must see in Bangkok. This is for me the main tourist temple in Bangkok. It's beautiful, many details and not as huge and overwhelming on a hot day as the grand palace. Here you can see everything and enjoy it. If you have a limited time, choose this one instead of the grand Palace!

A dream . It is the third time I have visited the temple and palace in the last ten years and always my senses overwhelming with the magnificent of the temple and everything. You just don't know where to look as it is like been inside the most perfect jewels

Nice temple and surroundings. Its a very popular temple where it can get crowded. So being able to take a pick without anyone else in the background can be difficult. Oh, you can't take any pics inside the Emerald Buddha temple either. If the the guards see you pull you camera out they'll shine a laser pen at you. When inside, it can be rushed as people are trying to get in constantly. You have to take shoes off outside.Be vary of tuc tucs and taxi drivers - some will try to trick you on paying more to get there or also try taking you to other tours. Ping me a message on twitter @jassv_ and I can tell you watch to watch out for!

A key place to visit. It seems that you really need to get here as soon as it opens at 8.30 am. We did, and it was initially not too busy, but by 10 am the whole place was full of people, making it difficult to get around and see properly, let alone take photos.

Breathtaking. This is a unique and wonderful experience. The opulence is dazzling. Not to be missed. That said, this place is very crowded with hordes of pushing your groups and selfish stick carrying idiots. Detracts from the experience but should not keep you away. The rude crowds made me like Wat Pho better.
Just ok. It was nice but not great. I guess after the reclining Buddha I was expecting something majestic. A bit of a let down.

Fantastic history and Buddha images.. This is a perfect place to visit. A lot of Buddha images to see and the area around the pagodas are very interesting and full of life. You will see a lot of history, mixed between Thai and Chinese history and statues. Remember the dress code before you go there. No shorts or sleeve less t-shirts.

Try to avoid the mid-day heat. I would definitely say this was on the "must see" list. I would definitely recommend not going at the peak heat times though since there is very little shade and whew, it was hot! Also be sure that you have clothing that covers shoulders, and your entire legs.

A must see!!!!. Grand Palace really is a MUST SEE!!!! just be ready for the crowds..... its just teeming with people,,,,,,,,, best thing is to have a private tour guide in a small group its easier to get around go at your own pace rather than struggling in a big crowd.

Amazing but very busy. The place was amazing as the buildings were breath taking, words cannot describe it as it was nothing like anything else I've ever seen. You get a good insight into life of the royals in Thailand. The only downfall was that there were a lot of people, apparently it's busy all the time with thousands of tourist coming everyday. Overall, it's definitely worth a visit. Just a bit of warning, bring a hat, sunnies and water as it can get really hot, especially when you're surrounded by hundreds of people

Beautiful but expensive . Costs 500 Baht to enter and I would say that is far too much. The temple is beautiful and it's definitely worth seeing. And even though it was super busy when I went it didn't prevent me from seeing everything I wanted to. But you can see many other temples for free which are also very beautiful. I definitely think it's over priced. As they are strict about what you must wear they provide suitable clothing, for 200 Baht, which you get back once you give the clothes back, and this was useful. Was good to have done. But wouldn't pay to do it again!
Amazing. As an artist, it was very much inspiring and helpful to think more of my work. I think it really is great and amazing how Thailand kept it in a good condition.

Expensive Grand Temple. at least for once remember to pay a visit to the Grand Palace. Entrance is 500 bahts per entry and you will have to fight with the crowd as there is really no such things as a slow day at the Grand Palace. There is no access to view the Emerald Buddha these days and I think this is very much due to the crowd.Stunning Architecture indeed but there are just as many stunning temples in Thailand that cost nothing to visit. Please be respectful when visiting no shorts, no baseball caps, no shoes allowed in the temple premise. Sarongs are provided free inclusive in your entrance cost. No photography is allowed especially on tripods.

Breathtaking!. The Jade Budda is truly one of the things that I wanted to see before I die. My daughter and I visited in June and we were not disappointed. It was located on the grounds of the Grand Palace. We had a guide which helped tremendously. The temple follows a very strictly enforced dress code. Women must wear long skirts and men must wear long pants. However, you may rent appropriate clothes items at the entry area. Shoes must be removed before entering the Temple. Your feet must not be facing the Budda but tucked in towards the back. The perimeter of the Temple complex has 12 beautiful pavillions. Arrive as early as possible to avoid the crowds.
Over the top but worth it. Mind boggling experience. Get there first thing in the morning to avoid crowds. Emerald Buddha is the main attraction so just go there directly following the signs.
Interesting. You pay 500 TB for both palace and the temple. Beautiful Emerald Buddha, you see all 3 emerald Buddhas. You can lots more so a good day out

You haven't truly experienced Thailand without it!. I arrived mid day and it was a FULL house. Yet although the place was a circus people remained respectful and everyone has a chance to enter the temple. Although before doing so you must remove your shoes and hat(if wearing one) and no photography is allowed! That last rule is vital to your stay.

Emerald Buddha - Beautiful and Disappointing. This temple is absolutely stunning. Definitely up there with the top 5 temples in Thailand. Architecture is beautiful, the (tiny) Buddha is carved out of emerald, and the grounds are gorgeous. This temple is also located on the grounds of the Grand Palace, and that was really why I went to Wat Phra Kaew. For 500 Baht, I thought the public got some access, even be it limited, to view some areas of the grand palace. No such! So as beautiful as this palace is, for 500 Baht I was disappointed. There are many beautiful temples in Thailand that you can roam around to your heart's delight FREE.
The best place you should be Visit in Bangkok. This is the best place in Bangkok you must visit when you arrive here.it is a nice place and i think it's stunning you with beautiful templs
Green. An obvious thing to see while visiting the grounds of the Grand Palace.Having seem some fairly large images of Buddha, this one seems quite small but majestic sitting on high.

Old history and the most important landmark of Thailand. In the past this area is the community of Chinese people and Vietnamese who emigrated from their own countryLong time ago Kind thonburi live in Ayutthaya palace.
