He dreamed the old king of Ayutthaya come to in his dream and said you cant live here because Ayutthaya was destroy so much and cant rebuilt again so he decided to come to Bangkok by boat Bangkok at that time was the city of trading center When he arrive to Wat Arun in the early morning at that time the sun is rising he established this temple to be the royal temple and he built the palace near the temple and called the new kingdom is thonburi kingdomBut thonburi kingdom its not good location at all. It was a capital city of Thailand just only 15 yearsWhen King rama the first access to the throne and established the chakkri dynastyHe thing Thonburi kingdom has many weekness such as  • the location is located across the river so it hard to protect the city from the enemies • the west bank of chopharya river was erosion by the current but in the east bank of chaophaya river the land will grow • the Thonburi palace was brace by the two important temple so he cant expand the city anymore • he want to built the new palace like a architecture plan in the former Ayutthaya kingdom like a ons side close river and the otherside is a wall around the city so he give the community of Chinese people moved to สำเพ็ง. And the community of Vietnamese move to NangleangAnd order to built the grand palace and the emerald buddha on 6 April 1782. The grand palace constructed work took 3 years This place was so many attraction and The admission fee for thai people is Free, for the foreigner 500 baht per person to see both of the emerald Buddha and the grand palace.
Stunning. The temple and surrounding temples are absolutely breathtaking. Be sure to bring water as walking around can get extremely hot and do wear easy slip off shoes!
Not to miss. One of the many great places you must visit in Babcock so much gold and great carvings it's another great experience
Emerald Buddha. we visited the temple on a Monday it was very busy you had to take off your shoes when entering the temple lot's of locals praying the Buddha was exceptional

Another Temple Another Buddha. When traveling through Thailand there are many opportunities to visit temples & see Buddhas. This one is gorgeous & the Buddha is emerald rather than the traditional gold colour.

Amazing!!!. Simply amazing! A must see if you are in Bangkok!! The grounds are spectacular. The temples are of such beautiful architecture, and the Buddha is carved from solid jade. What more do you need?!
Beautiful site. The temple is very beautiful and ellaborated, we thought the Buddha was a little small for the temple but you must considered that it is made entirely of Emerald.

Beautiful, otherworldly architecture. This ornate, varied, beautiful temple really is a must see in Bangkok and words really do struggle to do it justice. Situated within the Grand Palace, there are numerous buildings all with their own styles and beauty and there's something new to see everywhere you look. The Emerald Buddha itself was impressive, but the surrounding buildings are breathtaking and I thought the various statues and wall paintings were sublime. We visited mid-morning but it was still very busy so getting there early would be recommended. The dress code was also very strict - trousers and sleave shirts were a must and many people (my partner included) had to rent clothing to be allowed in.
Beautiful . Very busy with tourists. .wear long trousers and cover shoulders. Absolutely a must...incredibly beautiful. ...never seen anything like it

Green with envy. Forbidden to take photos of this magnificent monument but I noticed some sneakily did! There were guards inside watching but not outside. Anyway a peaceful place from where one can connect spiritually with a higher being, irrespective of one's faith. I did exactly that and I am not a Buddhist.

Needs more selfie-sticks??. A stunning complex of beautiful buildings/ temples literally teeming with tourists, many from the East it seems, frantically photographing themselves /family/friends as though today was the last day ever to take photographs. Few seemed to be taking in the beauty of the site or complying with requests for silence and respect. The site was extremely busy although it emptied out towards closing time, which was nice.Watch out for tuk-tuk touts who try to befriend you and then explain the temple is closed for prayers until 4pm (and can they get a tuk-tuk to take you somewhere else?) when in fact it CLOSES at 4pm. Unscrupulous liars - simply ignore them and their fake charm evaporates!

A Bangkok must see, but he prepared for the crowds and above average price. I don't think you can visit Bangkok without visiting the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, but be prepared for the crowds; it is very busy. However if you're on a budget and need to choose between the Emerald Buddha & Grand Palace or the Reclining Buddha, I would most definitely recommend the Reclining Buddha; behind the initial reclining Buddha is a lovely template with array of Buddha's all around. Its soo much quieter than the Emerald Buddha & Grand Palace, not forgetting its 1/5 of the price. Clearly if you can afford both, go to both. Note: Men must cover there legs and women legs & shoulders; however if you arrive uncovered they do provide you with clothing to cover up for a small deposit.

A bit of a let down as it was and is so small. Re read lots and lots about this place before going so we knew as much as possible, but although we knew it wasn't a huge statue, we didn't realise it was quite as small as it was in real life. This was a bit of a let down as we could hardly see it from inside. The place does represent Thailand very well though and the tale about how it was found is quite interesting
Emerald Buddha. This is one of the Royal temple in Thailand and is inside Grand Palace. Amazingly beautiful Buddha statue.

Beautiful and ornate. Very busy tourist spot, justly so because it is very well maintained. The emerald buddha is small, also really is jade but interesting because when it was found it was covered in plaster. The details of all the buildings are really something to see. A wonderful gem for the people of Thailand to be very proud of.
The representative of Thailand. This Temple is the symbol of Thailand. One of the most famous temple and the tourist place to pay respect the emerald buddha.

Beautiful. Another temple you must visit at least once in your life. But be aware this "Emerald" Buddha (which in reality is made of Jade) is not very big and high up - so you'll only get a glimpse on him. Film and photos strictly forbidden !!

Breathtaking. The Emerald Buddah is one of the most beautiful manmade things I have ever seen. It was a very emotional moment when I first laid eyes on it. Many people were in worshipping. No photos allowed inside. This is a must see in Bangkok.

A Must Visit Destination . Well I must tell you that if you do not visit this place, it's like you've never visited Bangkok. This place is the heart of the city and the heart of the all buddhist. You will see the marvelous neatness of the architechture and the Grand Palace too. Once you buy the tickets it is included the 2 places. The dress code id very strict. No shorts, no mini skirt and sleeveless shirts are considered inappropriate.

Interesting. The emerald Buddha is not very big but is remarkable in that it is made out of a single large piece of Jade. The coat he wears is pure gold and is changed by the King of Thailand once for each season. The winter cloak was simply breathtaking.

Special significance. This Temple holds a special place in my memory. Apart from being one of the main Buddhist places of worship, it attracts royalty and commoners alike.40 years ago on my first visit, the King of Thailand suddenly appeared with his entourage and the then few Westerners were obliged to kneel in deference. As in the King & I, no-one is allowed to be equal height with the king. It was a defining moment.On subsequent visits I have sat with the serene and peaceful faithful in the limited space before the small emerald Buddha.If your search is for tranquillity and human understanding, you will not leave this temple without a sense of spiritual uplift.

A spectacle you must visit . This was one of the attractions that was at the top of my list. I chose to visit on an incredibly hot and busy day so there was little time for reflection, however it is still breath taking.

Don't miss it !. It's a wonderful temple that has to visit absolutely when you are in Bangkok!
Very crowded but it worth.
Some tricks: no shorts allowed for men and women and no sleveless!

A great deal to see on a large site.. A large site with a great deal to see, it is difficult to say which part of this large complex is best. We had a guide, and it was very worthwhile, to learn about the history and the relevance of each building. It can get very hot as the sun reflects off the buildings and pavements, so it is advisable to take a god supply of water with you. Also there are rules to abide by, dress modestly covering shoulders and knees, take off shoes when entering temples, do not drink in the temples (we witnessed a lady being escorted out of the Emerald Buddha temple for taking a sip of water) and do not take photographs if it is forbidden. This was the case in The Emerald Buddha temple, our guide informed us that not only would the offending photograph be deleted but the memory chip would be wiped clean.
Nice to visit. Recommended for a short visit if you are in Bangkok; Quite crowded but good to fill up some time. Well-maintained.

Mic of art , religion and architecture ! . The temple and the grand palace are situated in the same area . We paid 500 Thai baht per person for entry but was worth it ! The temple is big with good architecture and the essence of Buddhism !

Stunning . This was absolutely stunning. There was so much to look at, we were overwhelmed. You cannot take pictures inside but outside everyone seemed to take it through the open door so we did the same.This is a highly spiritual place, people are bowing to Buddha and meditating so respect is key. Incredible, never seen anything so beautiful before

wonderful. big place with lots to see, amazing architecture and a great place to look about. pre warning, make sure you are dressed modestly otherwise you won't get in! (e.g. trousers/floor length skirts and covered shoulders
Beautiful and Serene. Well worth a visit . The Emerald Buddha is beautiful. Although the temple was very busy, the atmosphere inside was peaceful and serene.

Awe-inspiring!. If there is ony one temple that you have time to visit in Bangkok, I think my vote goes to the Wat Phra Kaew. This is inside the Grand Palace complex itself. Take the time to absorb the details. Tips :Be prepared for the crowds!It is very hot. Carry a hat for sure. I think we need to take it off only when we go inside the temple. We forgot to pack ours :-(
not Emerald but something special!. Beautiful temple with one of the most special sights in Bangkok. It was full when we went but well worth the effort.
Stunning!. To be honest, it is not my favourite place in the world, but if you get in Bangkok you must visit it
too crowded extravaganza. too crowded less impressive maybe very importand for some budistic religion not so impressive for sight seing...could spent quiing in other places

#1 "Must See" sight in Bangkok. Visited the What Kaew temple in conjunction with the Grand Palace. It is not as impressive as in Yangon, Myanmar (which is much older) but for Thailand I would consider it one of the top sights. Make sure you come early and visit the temple before the palace, as it is the most popular sight and it seems like all on China is on vacation here. You save a lot of time going with a tour and avoiding the long lines. Bring a wide angle photo lens and select a meeting point in case you get lost int he crowd. Truly magnificent.
Small, elegant Buddha to be revered. A wonderful chance to see the Emerald Buddha is a highlight in Bangkok. Spend some time contemplating the Buddha, the temple and the devout who visit.

Another beautiful Wat. We saw this Wat towards the end of a busy day of guided sightseeing, including four Wats, and so while it was beautiful & interesting, with a superbly decorated interior and fabulous demon figures, we were feeling a little overwhelmed and found it hard to differentiate it's finer points from the other Wats we had seen.Deserved to be seen earlier in a busy day.
Impressive Buildings. I visited the Temple of the emerald Buddha in Bangkok and was impressed by the structure of this attraction and would recommend my friends to visit it.
Beautiful temple . A beautiful place to relax and contemplate... The emerald Buddha is impressive and the story behind is very interesting.

Very cool temple in an incredible palace complex. The emerald Buddha is small compared to the other Buddhas but then it is made out of emerald and that is a lot of emerald. My favorite was actually the painted scenes from the Indian epic Ramayana on the outer wall that were intricately detailed and worth quite a bit of time viewing just by themselves.

Worth the crowds, and it is open all year!. This is a busy place all year long. If you are interested in history and seeing temples, do it anyways. You can rent audio guides to get more information but still move at your own pace.We went there on January 1st. The place is open every single day of the year! Don't trust people telling you otherwise. They are just trying to take you somewhere else to get commissions.

Traditional worship for New Year Blessing. Do you know other than party countdown overnight on Dec 31st, what else Thai people do for celebrating their new year ? Talking on religion related, some of them may do chanting across between old and new year. Some of them do a temple tour for worship for 9 temples. Why 9 ? Nine in Thai word is "Kao" which is short representing "Kaona" or progressive in the meaning. And one of hot spot among those 9 temples is of course the Emerald Buddha (Grand Palace). I went there yesterday for the same purpose but I did 1 only. It's always great to be there eventhough this time it's pretty much fulled with tourist. Of course, majority is from China (again) for apporx. 40% and the rest are from other countries including local Thai. This time of the year the Buddha will wear the winter clothing which is a real gold allover. The Buddha will gets change next time a summer clothing and rainy season clothing respectively - which will be in different style too. Buddha clothing will be changed by the Royal Crown Prince only on behalf of the King. It's only small story sharing here due to a limited of comment space. By the way, I wish everyone visiting Thailand a prosperous year and whatever you guys wish for may come true. Happy new year 2016 !

Excellent Buddha Temple in midst of Bangkok. I visited Bangkok quite a few times and I think I been to Temple of Emerald Buddha or Wat Phra Kaew as they call in local language. Really nice place to visit when you visit Bangkok. This temple is one of the other few good temples around Bangkok, namely Wat Arun and Wat Pho.There is entry fees for foreigner. The Temple is situated within the Royal Palace of King of Thailand.I strongly suggest you to visit this :)

Disappointing. Upon arrival to ticket purchase, they informed me that the temple was shut to tourists at 2 that day due to a private prayer. I found these events to be very common and unpredictable. As a result, I had to move around it only from a far distance, and take a glance at the emerald Buddha from far. The size of it is disappointingly small ( about half a meter X half a meter). I couldn't even take a decent photo from that distance. Anyway, since the ticket is included in the grand palace tour, definitely go in if you can and take a look!
Overrated. Adults and kids were least impressed with this guy versus thenother ones atbnearby temples. 1000s of tourists too. Grand Palace is a must see but come early or late.
Under renovation. What a disappointment all the way to Bangkok and we were unable to see the Emerald Buddha after all the hype we had heard.
A Place to Relax. Bring some small change so you can change it for coins and fill the pots whilst walking behind the resting Buddha then take a moment to relax in front of the emerald Buddha.
Beautiful place. I was in awe, most important Buddhist relic in the world. The energy in the room was unbelievable. The look in everyone's eyes was beautiful. Highlight of my trip in Bangkok.
Amazing!. So awesome to see all the different styles! Loved the ones made out of ceramic. We really enjoyed walking around the grounds and taking it all in.
Small statue only. If you are not a Buddist, dont come here on New year (Jan 1-2). The temple is very crowded with tourist and Buddist that come to pray. You barely cann't move easily.

The Majestic Temple. The temple of the emerald buddha is part of the grand palace complex, it is probably the most beautiful, historical and majestic temple I have been. The Emerald Buddha is kept in a nice building around the palace grounds. You are not allowed to take pictures from the inside but sometimes you can see the Buddha from the outside and you can take the pictures. The Buddha is not very big as the other Buddhas but it certainly is emerald green and beautiful. When the season in Thailand changes the Buddha will be dressed in that season’s theme. It is called the Emerald Buddha but we are not sure if it’s real emerald or not. The other buildings in the temple are amazing too! The architecture is superb and gold is everywhere. The buildings are usually tall and mostly in gold color, some buildings have small colored mirrors and plates on them to create an image or pattern. There was an area where the walls are painted too! The old pictures on the walls are all made to tell stories about the history and the mythical events. The paintings are very detailed that it almost look like real trees and buildings. It was a great temple but it sometimes get very crowded during the afternoon. So it will be very hot when we can’t show many parts of our skin. There are sometimes pick pockets too so don’t bring too much stuff. And don’t take too much pictures or it will not be respectful to the temple’s property.

Wonderful . We enjoyed it. It was a pretty temple to see. Again respect the temple and do cover up as well. We saw many temples too before so the all became quite the same unfortunately. So pick a few you want to see, so you don't get bored.
jade buddaha. This was a bit of a surprise as the Buddha is small on top of a complex decorated display which is quite high. Remove shoes before entering.

Emerald Buddha superb. Emerald Buddha was beautifully decorated.when we saw he was in winter attire. As he is always dressed in for 4 seasons. We were blessed as soon as we got in it was time to close after going in. We had a lovely view and magnificent Buddha and positive energy was great.

Too crowded during high season. The emerald buddha is not what you expect, is tiny in size, and the vision is far as it's at the top of a golden mount. But still good to learn more about buddhist culture.

One of Most Interesting Part to See inside complex. This is the part of Grand Palace visit that worth to visit . The inside design is very beautiful, ancient - historical and religious . Unfortunately no camera allowed to take picture inside. And beware with pocket lifter .
Great architecture. Great architecture. Good to see that its not merely a tourist attraction, but is also actively utilised by locals for religious purposes.

Need To See!. This temple is part of the Grand Palace complex - we visited during a weekday around 1130am and it was incredibly packed (it was also during New Year's week, so higher crowds than usual I suspect). The temple is gorgeous with high pillars and lots of colored glass (I think); the architecture is stunning. You have to take off your shoes (but you don't need to wear socks, although the tiles in the sun obviously get scorching hot) and leave them outside, but don't worry about anyone taking your shoes. Once you get inside make sure to point your feet away from the Buddha to show respect. No photos or video allowed, although if you want a photo of the Buddha you can take one from outside - there's a space to see in, although your photo won't be that great. People are meditating and praying inside, so please be respectful. I've only visited in December, so it's the 'cold' season, so Buddha wears his cold season jacket - I find it fascinating they change his attire for the seasons! The statue is not made of real emerald but rather jade or something like it, but it's still amazing to see. It's also pretty hot inside as there are a lot of people jostling for a view and only a fan or two. Definitely a must see while you're at the Grand Palace!
well worth the visit. going by water taxi is an easy way to get there. go early & you avoid the crowds & it's a lovely peaceful place to wander around

Impressive, Diminutive Buddha. The Emerald Buddha is housed in a building on the palace grounds. You are not allowed to photograph the Emerald Buddha from inside. But if you have a camera which zooms, you can photograph the Emerald Buddha from outside through an opening/window facing the Buddha using the zoom. When entering the building, you must first take off your shoes. Inside, you will see beautiful murals of the life of Buddha and lovely tributes to the Buddha. The Emerald Buddha will be dressed according to one of three seasons.

Breathtaking. This is not to be missed. The site has such awesome and amazing beauty. Culturally and artistically significant. Seeing locals there making prayers gave this temple a mystic feel that must be experienced.

FANTASTIC and Beautiful. This was one of the best tours of our trip. We did get the audio guide and gained a lot from it. The temples and structures are so beautiful, by far one of my favorite temples. The added benefit of seeing the palace was interesting. I do highly recommend. I had on long pants and sleeves to be respectful, but you could borrow a sarong/big oxford shirt if you didn't wear them. It was very hot! I recommend something cool like the light pants sold at every tourist shop. The bathrooms were free, air conditioned and well kept. There is a spout with potable water on the inside, but I do recommend bringing one as well as the spout water does not taste very good.

A lot of tourists! . Granted the temple itself is very beautiful, just be forewarned that you feel as you're herded along as the number of tourists is innumerable! It is very conveniently located within the Royal Palace complex!

An Amazing Experience. This is a site not to be missed in Bangkok. Dress properly and prepare for heat and crowds but be ready to see stunning colours and architecture. Don't be put off by the line-ups to see the statue. And please respect the rules- remove your shoes and stow the camera.

Spectacular but very crowded. Almost too much to take in from the dazzling display of buildings and their finishes. The centre piece is the incredible Emerald Buddha.
Go early to avoid the heat and - almost impossible - the crowds.
Be respectful. Watch for pick pockets. . Fabulous. Word of warning though. There are lots of pick pockets. Be respectful and don't take photos.

Emrald Budha .. must see. The temple is within the area of the Palace. We visited in last week of dec15 and it was flooded with tourists. Very crowded ...Thai style buildings are amazing. Palace campus is big and beautiful trees around. Nice place for photography.At 10.30 AM and around 2 PM there is free guided tour. We were lucky and got tour 1t 10.30. The guide was friendly , fluent in English and gave nice information.Must see attraction when you are in Bangkok.
Interesting architecture. Visited this place together with the Grand Palace. Very interesting place to understand Thai culture and their beliefs.
Amazing. Beautiful site to see, wonders of Thailand. Very crowded though, be prepared to be pushed around by crowds multiple times.
Important to See. Another must see temple to better understand the culture and history of Thailand. Our guide pointed out many unique points of interest here.
Small utimpressive. Much smaller than anticipated. No pictures are allowed in this temple but worth seeing. Part of the former palace grounds . Very tight security.

regal temple. it is a very regal temple and hence rightly placed within the grand palace. Do try all the crazy food outside. I fell in love with this Roti bread made with banana, sugar and egg (i know it sounds weird but it is awesome)

Emerald Buddha. The Emerald Buddha... Thought he'd be bigger. :p. Kidding, however displayed in such a stunning monument it's all very visually pleasing. It was very crowded and the ability to relate to a herd of animals being ushered through doorways etc was an experience we can now say we've had. Haha. However, it was beautiful and we would do it again. @2travelers1backpack

Amazing detail but unfriendly guards. Trouble getting in as there is only one gate for foreigners. We followed the crowd and got yelled at and pulled aside (physically with pinching involved) by one of the guards and made us walk against the flow out, which was a terrible and invasive experience.Once inside, the temple is beautiful! Amazing detail from wallpapers to statues and embezzlements from floor all the way up to the roof. Remember to bring sufficient water, sunscreen and hat/umbrella though as it is crowded, hot and claustrophobic with the masses of people visiting here.Tickets are also misleading as it is 500THB for the grand palace / emerald temple (which is actually within the same area). So you're visiting 1 site rather than 2.Overall - amazing experience and would recommend!

Beautiful, but so far away. Beautiful, but can't get too close to see the detail. The opulence of the temple is incredible. We probably picked the busiest day of the year (Dec 31st) to visit so all a bit of a procession and scrum. Highly recommend using a guide (we used Gift who was fantastic, see separate review) to smooth the ticketing and explain all the detail
Magnificent Temple. One is in awe seeing this most beautiful and sacred Buddhist temple (wat). It is so sacred that only the Thai King can touch this statue.
Bangkok tour stop. Visited as a family of four with two teenagers and the services of an excellent tour guide with great local and historical knowledge. A must see monument in bangkok

All in all not a great experience. It is obviously a *must to see* sight in Bangkok, and the temple is undoubtedly beautiful. However, the strict rules make it very difficult to enjoy it. My family was denied to enter due to inappropriate dressing, however both my dad and brother wore shorts that covered their knees. We were not aware that they need to come in long sleeve trousers, so prepare to be rigorously checked (some people passed the first control, but then they were returned at the second control after they bought their tickets). I understand the several security checkpoints and the strong presence of soldiers and police, however I do not get why is it necessary that they shout with the visitors for any reason. It is so crowded that probably it is challenging to keep the order, but after paying 500 baht (which is crazy much compared to other temples where you pay around 100 baht) you want to have a relaxing time and enjoy your visit. I personally could not enjoy the visit, despite that the site is breathtaking.

A place to visit!. We visited the place with my wife on the 1st of January. We went with our guide and the good thing is that since it was the 1st day of the year,entrance was for free. The bad thing was that everyone knew about it! So..the place was full of people and long queues. But nevertheless, it is a very nice place and a must!

very crowded and this is off-peak???. The crowds were very bad and progress slow and crowds pushing through temple. What it must be like in "busy" days is beyond comprehension. Impressive but to be avoided if you don't like crowded places.

Family Adventure. The temple is within the area of the Palace. The architecture of the buildings are amazing. It's tradition to wear long pants, long dresses and cover your shoulders when visiting the Palace and the temple. Please be prepared and show respect to the tradition. It's best to visit early as it's very hot in the area especially with continuous crowd.

Amazing!. Really enjoyed coming. Really thought the emerald Buddha was larger than it was but wasn't disappointed for sure! Lots to see but very busy during the holiday. Good way to spend a couple hours but be sure and bring your own water and a hat. Still amazed by the people that tried to come in not wearing proper clothing.
Simply awesome. If you have time this is place to hang out for peace, tranquility and meditation. Every time I visited I felt empowered.

Ok. After a while you get tired of seeing so many Buddha. I thought the emerald Buddha would be more impactful, but it wasn't. We paid 500baht to get in and it was too full. It was almost impossible to walk without bumping into someone which made the experience bad. Not worth the money. The staff was mostly worried about 'order' but not 'comfort'.

Beautiful, but be careful!. Inside the Grand Palace grounds, do not talk to ANYONE outside of the main complex. "School girls", "tour guides", "taxi drivers", they are all trying to scam you. Head directly in. Once you're in though, the sites are wonderful. Just be aware that the crowds are enormous. We went right at the end of the day and it wasn't too bad.

Less impressive than expected.. We are not a Buddhist family so perhaps we missed the true significance of this Buddha. The Buddha image was much smaller than we expected. It was hot and crowded on the day of our visit. You must remove your shoes before entering this temple. The smell of people's feet was overpowering needless to say we did not longer too long inside this temple.

Huge place, good scenery. Went there around December 2015, need to make sure that you are wearing decent clothes as the security there are very very strict. You can't go in with shorts, sleeveless, and short skirts, if not u need to spend some money to buy something from the shops just to cover yourself. The entrance fee for me was a bit pricey, 500Baht. I did not go inside the palace/temple, but from what i heard it is huge and nice things to see inside. Very near to Wat Pho as well.

Must See. During our stay in Bangkok we took the tourist boat up the river to this great place. We spent a good part of our day taking pictures and taking in the beauty and history of the Temple of the Emerald City. The colors and details of the tens of thousands of Emeralds were astounding even after hundreds of years of wear- simply WOW!

Hot, busy and another, albeit ostentatious, Buddha . The title says it mostly. The trip to the grand palace was eventful as we were scammed outside and offered a boat ride as the "palace is only open from 3-5"... Beware, it's open for last tours and visits to 3:30pm.The Buddha is small, hidden in one of the buildings in the grand palace, sits up high and is surrounded by gold leaf.No photos allowed and within 5 minutes you're putting your shoes back on having exited the hall. Yes it's impressive / gaudy... Made of jade and obviously well restored / maintained. Go visit but don't expect to spend hours there.

Impressive!. The temple was very intricately decorated and was impressive to see. The emerald Buddha is not large but I'm sure it must have immense influence in the lives of the locals. Be prepared to battle the hordes of people that descend upon the temple.
Crowded and completely unexplained. See my review of the Grand Palace.Apologies: in it I called it the Jade Buddha: a further proof of the total lack of interpretative material

Gorgeous. The temple was absolutely Beautiful! It was clean and colourful.You are not allowed to wear shoes inside the temple so you have to leave them outside.It is possible for your shoes to be stolen so do not wear your best shoes when visiting.

Magnificent - if you can get in. For the first time in my life I have visited Bangkok but not been into the Emerald Buddha Temple because of the crowds. Early this year I queued for a long time to get through the huge throng of people after having bought a ticket (which simply used to be just a minute's walk up to the entrance) but this time it was simply impossible. All the way up the road opposite along Sanaam Luang, there are lines of tourist coaches bringing hundreds of (mainly Chinese) tourists to the Grand Palace complex.There is a tourist information office where I enquired if there was any time of the day or week that was quieter. I was given a very Thai reply which didn't make sense but I interpret the answer as no! You may have more luck than me - if so, see this magnificent site.
Beauty. One of the must see places.Please take time to enjoy the architecture. Do not visit on peak times. The best place I have visited in Thailand.

Amazing Temple. It has the best exterior among all the temples in Bangkok. It is huge from the outside and can be seen from far too. Also, it is linked to the Grand Palace so it can be a side visit. However, its admission is charged separately from that of the Grand Palace.

Beautiful, Shinny, Crowded. Its quite pricy to pay 500B (foreigner price) to enter. The place was packed with tourist! Its a great place to take nice pictures. Visiting there at noon can be hot and uncomfortable.

Must see buddha temple . Known as wat phra kaew among the local public , must see place . suggest to start early for this temple as it gets crowded in the afternoon and becomes hot and humid . carry a hat or umbrella, get a personal audio guide machine for 200bhat which explains what a tourist guide will do , personal audio guide machine is better as it gives you freedom to re listen if you miss something , you can buy a ticket for this temple along with coin museum and grand palace for 500 bhat. It will take 2 hours to cover all three places . be ready to walk through these places . suggestes time to visit is before 10 am on the morning

Impressive - with a guilty conscience. Carved from solid jade supposedly dating back thousands of years, cloaked in gold and supremely revered -- I was in awe!! However, learning that this was originally in Laos and was stolen during one of the Siam invasions of Laos, and eventually transfered to its current Temple in the Royal Palace grounds with no intention of returning it to Laos seems contrary to the practice of Buddhism.

Golf gold gold. This is a tinny little green Buddha on top a mountain of gold. It is just crazy amazing and beautiful. This is part of the grand palace tour and a must if you are visiting Bangkok. Make sure to wear pants and selves.
Beautiful. Really liked the Emerald Budda, something really unique and must be seen. A famous tourist spot in Bangkok, not to be missed

Awesome and peaceful. The temple is very colorful, shimmery and beautiful. Buddha is quite spectacular to view and not to be missed when touring the other important sites eg. Grand Palace, Reclining Buddha.Beautiful craftsmanship & intrigue details make this one of the most beautiful temples in the world.

Too many people. Must see for Bangkok tourists, but be aware of all the scam outside the palace. You seriously don't need a tour guide, unless the person is really qualified and can explain a lot about the history, craft and art of the Wat. If you prefer to explore on your own, try to be there very early to get a chance to visit the temple without too many people. You typically only make it into the Wat Phra Kaew. Call yourself lucky, if you are admitted to step into any other building on site.
Worth for visit. Nice and must visit. Located in Bangkok PalaceEntrance ticket 500THB per personThai culture and historical buidling

dazzling golden temple. This most sacred Buddhist temple in all of Thailand is almost more than the eyes can take in. First of all, we were among throngs of people walking inside Wat Phra Keou. School groups, masses of Asian tourists, and a handful of westerners were all enthralled by the incredible display of gold and man-made beauty. The Emerald Buddha itself was much smaller than expected even though we'd read it measures 45 cm. The temple was dark inside after coming in from a blazing sunny day outside. A worship service was in progress, and no photographs were allowed inside. Considering it nothing unusual to find groups worshiping at Christian holy places anywhere in the world, we should not be surprised at similar devotions taking place here. The devout are everywhere in the complex, not just inside with the Emerald (actually jade) Buddha.
Soo Beatiful!. It is such a nice temple! Everybody is very respectful making it an inspired place! People leave the gold paper on the Budda so I did hope to go back one day!

Sucked in - almost. Despite reading about scammers only the night before, we still almost fell for it. Approaching the Palace entrance (across a busy intersection) we were stopped by a gentleman in an authentic looking security uniform. He told us that the Palace & temple were closed for 2 hrs for the monks prayers (that should have raised a red flag) & recommended an alternate itinerary that included 2 free entry Wats a tuk tuk ride away, with a visit to BB Fashion sandwiched in between. He was very slick, very good patter & magically, a tuk tuk pulled up just as we were thinking about taking his advice. However, when we said we'd go to the 2 Wats & not BB Fashion, both tuk tuk driver & "Security Officer" disappeared in a blink. Of course, nothing was closed! Temple of the Emerald Buddha & Palace were very hot & crowded, but absolutely stunning. A definite must-do in Bangkok. Amazingly well maintained & beautiful.

Fair for the price paid. Compound is very big and the structures within the Grand Palace is worth a visit. However if you wish to rent the audio guide, your visit is limited to 2 hours only as there is no re-entry and you will be charged extra if you dont return the guide within the timeframe.

CROWDED BUT WORTH SEEING. I actually expected the emerald buddha to be much larger but it's still beautiful. He is dressed in various clothes according to the season and is actually jade, not emerald. Can't take photographs inside and have to leave shoes outside of course. Place was packed. All the buildings in this complex are wonderful. We went there as part of a overnight cruise tour so I don't know about the cost of the visit, or accessibility by public transportation.
Spectacular . This is probably the number one place to visit as a tourist in bangkok. Take a guide as it's more fun to understand the culture and stories behind the temple.

Over crowed!. Thisbwas a chaotic place. Too many people if you decide to come at the end of the day. It is best if you come early morning. Be aware not pictures allow in side. Amazingly architectural building and painting inside.I would have given more starys if it was more cordinated the tour.
Expensive but nice.. Close to the Royal palace, though its a bt expensive and crowded, it offers a glimpse into Royalty. Avoid it on hot crowded days.
Very beautiful. The temple is very colorful, shimmery and beautiful. I recommend checking it out. It looks a bit different from other temples.

Australian travellers. Another temple important in the Thai faith. The emerald Buddha is quite spectacular to view and not to be missed when touring the other important sites eg. Grand Palace, Reclining Buddha. It is not a place where you would spend a long time. Be prepared for the hawkers who are very evident at all these places!

Wat Phra Kaew and Grand Palace - Visual Feast but Too Crowded. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha, although a feast for the eyes, is crawling with tourists that somehow adversely affects your overall experience. Entrance is 1,500 baht which includes entrance to the museum of textile and museum of royal items. It was a weekend when I went there and it was cramped, literally shoulder to shoulder (there were several tourist buses). It was noisy, with tourist guides shouting to get the attention of their groups, spoiling the sacred atmosphere of the temple. (In other temples, tourists are required to be quiet). I thought that maybe it would be a good idea to limit the number of tourists at any one time to preserve the temple atmosphere. You are required to take off your shoes prior to entering the temple and you wonder if your shoes among the sea of footwear would still there when you come back. The Grand Palace facade was beautiful and provides wonderful photo opportunities if you know how to erase the numerous posing tourists. A must see, but not enjoyable.
Beautiful as promised in travelogues. If visiting temples is your thing, this one is definitely worth seeing. The art is beautiful and there is a true variety.

Good. I expect This Buddha is Bigger but first i saw it looks simple but its spiritual.something on it when you go inside you feel it. also its from green Jade stone which is rare found. And out fits are changing every season..and there is very very very crowded plc..the weatheris also very hot .must drink liters of water ...Some.people are praying also at visiting area ..so be quiet and respectful for them.
beautiful. a bit expensive but beautiful temple ...a must visit if you like to see temples and sculpture .still the charge is high.
Mesmerizing. It is really a mesmerizing experience to watch the Temple of Emerald Buddha and the Grand Palace. Just have around 3-4 hours and carry water. A great place to click memorable pics.

An Extensive View of Wealth. We visited this temple when we seeing the Grand Palace.Wat Phra Kaew or the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is regarded as the most important Buddhist temple in Thailand. It is within the grounds of the Grand Palace, it enshrines the Emerald Buddha, the highly revered Buddha image meticulously carved from a single block of jade. It is a Buddha image in the meditating position

Fascinating. This is more for the art & architecture lover. The interiors were amazing, the intricate design and the time & effort to put into a certain piece is impressive. One of the Bangkok's top tourist spot so expect a lot of people.

Stunning Temple. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a must see. Beautiful craftsmanship & intrigue details make this one of the most beautiful temples in the world. Truly spectacular. Can be a bit busy & hot

Amazing Wat Phra Kaew and the Grand Palace. Do not miss this Wat it is a must see. The grounds are amazing the artwork is beautiful. BEWARE of scammers lurking outside of the Wat. Know the hours and days it is open. They will try and tell you it is closed because of some non-existent Thai holiday and then try to talk you into taking a tuk tuk ride. What they really do is rush you through other nearby Wats and take you to gem and textile shops until you buy something. If you don't mind doing those things than it is a good deal, but if you are limited on time DON'T GO.

missed the point!!!!. The Temple of Emerald Buddha is within the ticket price of Grand Palace.To me this was very much overhyped and maybe has more significance to those of the Buddhist Faith. A 'green race's figure in a temple did not do it for me,however the grounds were very fetching.
In the grand palace. Visited with family and friends and had an enjoyable interesting historic visit. Recommended for those interested in history and religious faith.

Amazing architecture, history, and beauty. Imagine finding an architectural documentation of the evolution of a capitol city. Preserved, easily accessible, and all inside a city block. This is the temple of the Emerald Buddha and the surrounding area.In the hands of a knowledgeable guide, you can walk through the history of Thailand, from the belief in Animism, the incorporation of Hinduism, and the eventual combination of the two with Buddhism. In addition the Chinese and European influences on the shrines' and stupas' inside the Temple and the Grand Palace.We spent three hours there and easily could have spent a day.

Crowded and expensive!. Fleecing the tourists. Such a ridiculous amount to charge to visit a religious site. Plus it was so crowded and you are pushed around that there was neither time nor space to worship the Buddha. Skip it!
Part of the Grand Palace complex. The temple lies within the Grand Palace grounds so the 500b ticket to the Palace includes this.It was very crowded on the day we went.
Architecture is amazing. Fantastic architecture. Well worth the visit. The setback is that there are too many visitors jostling for place to take photos.

Excellent place to visit early morning. We were not hoping for much given the recent reviews. We got their early morning and took a tour guide at the gate. She quickly got us through the tour bus crowd. She already had the tickets and we were able to skip that line too.We took plenty of pics before the crowd got in and were able to get time to absorb the beauty of the temple. Inside the temple, the emerald Buddha room was a bit crowded, but we were able to sit down for a while and take in statues and paintings in the walls.We then had plenty of time to get the history of the place and get some fun stories from the guide.The Emerald Buddha visit was the highlight of our trip.

Really nice!. Beautiful temple. A must see. Cost I think was 500 baht. That gets you into the entire grounds. There is a place to get water and snacks on the grounds. There will be crowds at the main temple, but it is well worth it.

Well worth. A great visit next near to the Grand Palace part of.A huge great Mural pictures the walls of part and tells the story of Thailand?? Apparently school kids need to study learn it as part of Thai history. No easy??
Amazing!. If you're into temples, this is one that you should not miss. Sprawling premise that somehow is able to still create a sense of peace from within.
Cool. Nice temple. Great detail but lots,lots of tourists. With so many people it is hard to experience the temple. Tourists from China were prevalent.

A very good attraction.. Have a lovely time there. A few tips, wear a t-shirt which cover you shoulders and long dress/ skirt. If you don't want to or have any, there are available free of charge with a deposit of 200 bath per person. You get your deposit back when you bring back the clothes. Be aware of any person at the entrance or along the street telling to go to buy some clothes before you enter the attraction. I wouldn't recommend to use the Tuk Tuk or taxi nearby on your way back as they will over charge you which is common in front of all the main attractions everywhere you go. No guide is needed too visit.
่jewel of bangkok. there is no reason why you miss it! the temple is like a jewel of bangkok old city; do not miss it anymore!!

Nice to see. We took photos from the outside because there are no photos allowed inside. The Budda was a little smaller than expected but perhaps because it's so high up.Be patience as many people want to go inside and don't always know how to behave once inside.

Breath taking. Simply amazing! Unbelievable beauty! I had seen photos but nothing can prepare you for what you'll see and experience. The details and colours are unbelievable! And on a lovely morning or afternoon it makes for an enjoyable stroll but beware it could get very crowded with tourists.

Hordes of Tourists.... The beauty of this site is marred by the hordes of especially Chinese tourist groups with the flags and megaphone.. Sacreligeous and pushy as can be! If you can find a time when it is vacant, the wall murals are magnificent. The small Emerald Buddha not very impressive.

The best sight of Bangkok. I can estimate this sights as the best and # 1 in Bangkok. To my mind Temple Emerald Buddha more interesting than popular Wat Pho. The buildings and monuments here is more variously and attractively than Wat Pho.

Too many people but a must visit. Basically, The Grand Palace is swarming with tourists, but it's a must see in Bangkok. There's a lot of photo ops and even after seeing pictures of it, you will still be awed by how amazing these temples were made.
Beautiful and unique. It is a beautiful, different temple and the emerald statue is magnificent. it's a pity we are not allowed to photograph it.

Would be excellent without all the. There's busy and then there's this! We were also told that we visited out of peak tourist season so I hate to think what it's like during peak times. Often we had to fight our way through huge crowds of tourists to see anything and the massive downpour of rain didn't help but obviously that couldn't be avoided as it was monsoon season! It may considerably help matters if they limited the number of people entry at one time. The majority of people were very respectful during their time and wore the appropriate clothing (which was checked at entry) but sadly there were a select few people that weren't and they did make a poor impression. We have a responsibility as tourists to leave a good impression of our country as undoubtedly, people will make generalisations. Beware the market stall sellers & tuk tuk drivers as they will try and tell you all manner of stories en route, such as 'the temple is closed exclusively for monk worship today', 'you are not dressed appropriately and so they won't let you in' (they offer you alternative clothing for a returnable deposit on entry at the temple so there really is no excuse) & 'it's going to be too busy today, come back another day and we'll take you to another site'. All of this sounds quite negative at the moment but I have still given the attraction a 'very good' rating as sadly a lot of this you will experience anywhere in Thailand and as a visitor to the country, you should prepare and adapt to it.All of that aside, the buildings were magnificent and at times when the crowds dispersed for a brief second I did get quite overwhelmed with the beauty and atmosphere within the temples. If you are open-minded to the different world that is Thailand you have entered into then you will reap the rewards of this beautiful attraction.
A must see in Bangkok. We went on weekend and there were too many tourists. But we were happy to see that they managed the crowd very well.

Beautiful, expensive and overcrowded. It is beautiful but get ready to deal with the crowd. Typical Asia! 500 THB is spendy for this but it is what it is. Lots of other options out there, just saying.

The Jade Emerald Buddha. If you want to see some amazing gilded temples, one after another, in a very inspiring setting in Bangkok, then this is a must see. It is easy to get around in the complex and you will get a very good feel for Thai handicragt.

ginormous and VERY crowded. Very nice and huge BUT: way too many people, mostly Chinese people w/o any manners. We went there when it opened at 8:30 and already a living ton of them there. Wat Pho is very close by and I liked this better b/c by far not that crowded and the emerald buddha for which this plce is famous for is tiny....
Very beautiful. I took loads of photos here. Got a bit carried away to tell the truth. Will need to sort through them as like everyone else I was taking pictures of everything.
Go early. Absolutely a splendid temple but I found it very hard to take it all in with the sheer number of people mulling about. Easiest to tour as early as possible to avoid the mad rush of people.

The temple is impressive but the guards very strict and not consequent. The temple complex is impressive. They built nice structures with wealthy decorations.The guards however need training about the entrance regulations. My wife was not allowed to enter as she was wearing trousers over her knees and others with mini skirts could just pass. So if you want to visit without hassle wear long trousers or skirts (to the ankles) and a shirt with 'long' sleeves.

Beautiful and Crowded. The Temple is located on the grounds of the Grand Palace, just near the entrance. This and it's prominence result in the temple being very congested. The building itself is beautifully adorned, both inside and out. No pictures are allowed inside, and guards will actually take your camera and delete the photos. The Buddha statue itself appears smaller than one would expect, but it is very far away and high up. Regardless, it's beautiful and not to be missed.

Meditative and peaceful. Peaceful place basically for Buddhist worships and meditation. Very splendid temple and even more splendid is the story related to the establishment of emerald Buddha in this place. One must either should have a guide along with or should read about it while going to know history of the place, otherwise it may be passed just like any other temple.

Wonderful temple in Bangkok. The temple area is quite large, but we had no problem with crowds. The actual Emerald Buddha is not Emerald, but Jade. Unfortunately you cannot take pictures inside the actual temple where the Buddha is, but you can get a pretty good picture from outside the entry with a telephoto lens.

Without the suffocating throngs, this should be a five star.. Splendid of course, but we almost gave up, and had a half minute to see the Emerald (tiny up there and supposed made of jasper) before the crowds forced us to retreat.

Colorful temple. This temple is part of thai royal palace. it also establish the longest wall pointing in the world.
Architecture is thai style but some part is available of western style.
I can see it is best travel attraction in Bangkok.
early morning is the best time for a visit. If you don't like to be canned in a pool of people, go early in the morning to avoid that. It's worth a visit here, definitely.

Not for relaxers.. We were very amazed by the golden buildings that stood before us. Very cool but very noisy and we were crowded very tightly by locals. Very elaborate for example, the pillars are very well decorated and the temples inside are very clean ( Don't be barefoot).

Awesome. Awe inspiring and ornate, this extremely beautiful temple is a part of the Grand Palace. There is no separate entry fees (included in the Grand Palace Fees), but keep in mind that pictures are not allowed inside the temple.Although the temple itself is large, the Golden Buddha statue is small and seated on a large decorated seat. Apart from being a tourist attraction, this is also a place of worship, hence prayers are being continually offered by locals. Expect a large crowd all the time.The exterior of the temple is also highly decorated and is flanked with equally impressive pillars on each side. Including the Grand Palace, the entire trip will easily take 3 hours.
Don't miss. If you travel in Thailand. You must visit this place. This place is very beautiful. It's near the Grand Palace

A Glitter Dome - well NOT a Dome but all a Glitter. All part of the tour within the Grand Palace Grounds - don't miss this. Unfortunately photos are not allowed but you will be impressed by the sparkle and detail of the works on display.
A part of the grand palace. Interesting to see how the Emerald Buddha will be dressed. Photos not allowed. The Buddha is suite small but is on an impressive golden pier.

Tons of colorful towers- many pictures to take. It is totally worth the $500 baht for this temple. I probably spent two hours there than in the actual grand palace. So many towers and tons of Buda's It is a little crowded and everybody wants to take pictures of each tower but architecturally is awesome.

Still as breathtaking.... I first visited this temple many, many years ago and was filled with awe. Revisiting it again this time filled me with awe. However, the overall experience wasn't as inspiring as my previous visit : much too crowded these days, with too many loud, noisy and 'rough around the edges' visitors - especially large, tour groups.

Amazing site.. The Emerald Buddha is the nation's treasure located in the temple complex. The Buddha sits on top of a huge display of golden objects and angeles. The Buddha himself is not as large as I expected, but the spiritual feeling you get entering temple is beyond words. As with other temples in this complex this is a major tourist attraction and I would recommend getting there early to avoid large crowds. Another reason for getting there early is the heat and humidity which becomes worse later on in the day.
Just what you imagine it to be!. This Wat is a gorgeous compound filled with temples, pagodas, and a previous royal palace for His Majesty the King of Thailand. This is a MUST SEE while in Bangkok!

very impressive. the emerald buddha is smaller than i imagined and you can't photograph it.
the complex itself is very impressive but i found the place too crowded.
watch out for tourist guides trying to convince you to hire them, you don't really need them/

One thing you shouldn't miss when in Bangkok. Temple of emerald buddha along with other temples in the area gives you complete picture of what Budhdhism means to Thai people. You will experience truly to be one with god.
Amazing!!. This place is incredibly beautiful and special. There is a free guide in English, (just sign up in the information point). The hightlight of our trip to Bangkok!

Stunning! But dress appropriately. This temple is stunningly beautiful on the outside! Pay attention to the intricate details that adorn this temple. Pictures and words cant do enough to describe it so you'll just have to see for yourself. However, MAKE SURE YOU DRESS APPROPRIATELY! There are plenty of street vendors selling sarongs or coverups outside. So ladies, you can wear your shorts in the heat and humidity, while using the sarong to cover up (sarongs are sort of like long beach wraps), and also make sure your shoulders are covered. Don't make the mistake of wearing long pants thinking you're covered and will be allowed into this temple. There's a sign saying only women with skirts are allowed in and if you attempt to go in while wearing pants you will be whipped. Not seriously whipped, but there's a little dude who will appear out of nowhere with a few thin sticks and whip you a few times so you get the message. It's actually a bit comical. Also, no pictures inside the temple, you'll get whipped for that one too. So even with long pants, you'll need a sarong to wrap around yourself. Gents,your knees and shoulders have to be covered as well. Street vendors sell a light material pants that the guys can use to cover up. But don't let the dress rules deter you from visiting this temple because it's worth a visit. And like most temples in south east Asia, you have to cover up anyways, so just be respectful.

Beautiful and Historical. What a must. I wasn’t going to go visit any temples at first because of the price. But I am so happy we went. It was amazing and so worth it. You can literally spend hours and hours here walking around and looking at the beauty.

LOVELY BUDDHA . I had to go in two times because I didn't realize what we had seen the first time. I was so distracted by the glitz and glam and peaceful Monks. We didn't hire a guide nor did we rent audio equipment and neither of us speak Thai so in hind sight we probably would have done one or the other. It's definitely worth a look see.
A Gem!. In brief: This is a must see when you are in BKK regardless of whether you are a fan of temples etc.
Great Ancient Temple. Amazing Temple, A must to visit and offer the prayers. The Emerald Idol is amazingly beautiful and nicely maintained. Must visit.

The best in Bangkok.... If you miss Wat Phra Kew you simply do not know Bangkok since it is the best temple ever... everything around this place is incredible. You can hire guides at the door or get inside the rent an autdio guide.
Temple. They should visit the temple which we hope faith Buddhist teachings, a harmony between nature, objects and people, very nice and spiritual place

Stunning, stunning stunning....oops a Chinese tourist bumped me.. Breathtaking! But lots of Chinese tourists!! Aack!! After struggling to get your selfies taken with the entire landscape of the place, visit the museums. The artifacts and relics in those museums are sooo WORTH IT. Plus, there aren't a lot of people inside and a chance to cool off.

Small but beautiful. The temple is elaborate like so many in Thailand. The Buddha is perched high on gold platforms which elevate him. The actual Buddha is small in comparison to others in the area. It is one that should be seen as part of the highlights while visiting Bangkok.

Lovely Jade Buddha. This temple and the Buddha it contains are part of a very expansive temple and palace complex built by King Rama 1 in 1782 . The Emerald Buddha is in fact carved from a piece of green jade and has a very interesting and long history going way back before this complex was built. It was discovered in 1434 in Chiang Rai,spent 226 years in Laos and was brought to Bangkok by King Rama 1 when he made Bangkok his capital.This is a must place to visit, very beautifull and learn all the history about the Emerald Buddha. Admission is included in the Grand Palace ticket.we enjoyed our visit very much

Exceptionally beautiful temple. If there is only one thing you want to visit in Bangkok, the Temple of the Emerald Buddha must be it. It is exquisitely decorated, as are the other buildings, chedi and gallery surrounding the complex. And of course the emerald Buddha is beautiful. But be prepared for the crowds!

The Most popular structure on Grand Palace. This is the most crowded area inside Grand Palace Complex!Emerald being a soft stone, it's not possible to make Buddha from Emerald Actually. So, u got it right, that this Buddha is not of Emerald, but some type of Green Stones. But still it's popularly known as Emerald Buddha!Photography is prohibited inside, but still found lots of people taking snaps.The Temple is a live one, so you need to pay Respect to Thai Culture and Devotion, they show towards Lords Buddha, Like Do not Spread your Legs Toward Buddha and always sit inside the inner arena and don't remain stand up.As a whole, if you are in Grand Palace, this one is a must.

Beautiful temple. Beautiful temple, little crowded as it is in the premises of royal temple. It is Photography is not allowed inside the temple. So cant click good pictures . It is temple of Gautama Buddha.

Must See in Bangkok.. On a sunny day, this complex literally pops with color and a multitude of photo opportunities. So much to see, and a surprise around every corner. The golden chedi here contains a piece of the Buddha's breastbone and the Royal Mausoleum is situated here. Near the Upper Terrace is the Wat Phra Kaeo which is Thailand's holiest shrine. On the upper terrace, you can admire the mini stone Angor Wat, the golden Aponsi (a mythical half woman half lion statue), and the beautiful colors of the Royal Pantheon. Around the corner is the Bot of the Emerald Buddha.Simply breathtaking.
Beautiful temples. Many beautiful temples with gold cover, a great place to visit if it is not over crowed. Too many tourist, unsafe security, no place to rest.

expensive but a must see. There is always a big croud, and the guides are shouting all over the place which is bothering, but once you get over it, is a very nice place to visit (together with the Grand Palace). You can only enter in long trousers (even for men, 2/3 length is not enough), and with top that covers your shoulder. If not, you can rent decent clothes for a deposit of 200 Baht. At the entrance there are guides who offer you to take you around in different languages in 1 hour, but 1 hour is not enough! take the Personal Audio Guide (PAG) for 200 Baht for 2 hours, because of the locals english accent, its a better choice. 1 is enough for 2 person if you use 1 headset each.

Emerald Buddha. A serene, peaceful and majestic temple with magnificient paintings and art works on the walls and pillars. Definitely deserves to be among the wonders of the world along with the grand palace. The statue of the Buddha is breath taking and superb!!!! Entry fee for the temple and palace is 500 Baht and closest pier is no.9. Proper attire is a must but clothes can be hired if need be. Plenty of shops outside for food and refreshments.

Absolute must see!. Located in the royal Grand Palace compound, this Temple is the most prominent amongst the numerous smaller temples in the compound adjacent to the Thai King's official residence.The elaborate golden art work and serenity of the Temple leave their mark in your memory. It's Thai Buddhist culture at its pinnacle.Within the compound there are numerous other smaller temples, of significance that are all superbly maintained and accessible. You'll be photographing non-stop.Once you've seen the temples, then visit the gates of the Grand Palace and see the royal guards on sentry duty and some of the grand royal buildings nearby within the compound.Situated right next to the Reclining Buddah compound, it's best to put aside a day and see both attractions. They are the principal Bangkok Thai cultural attractions.If you only see these two sites, you can leave BKK having seen the best.

great landmark. A beautiful and historic representation of lord buddha. The place was very crowded but a good I liked the management there. Proper presence of water coolers, shades and washrooms made it ideal for long stay. We sepnt over 3 hours here.

Next to the grand place.. The temple of emerald Buddha is inside the grand palace. A place of worship inside the palace, which is normal since the old days to have temples build near the palace. The emerald Buddha is said to be Built in India 43 BC and went to Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Laos before ended up in Thailand.
Gorgeous.. Well worth a visit whilst in Bangkok... Absolutely beautiful and worth working your way through the crowds to see it.
Very Interesting. Pay attention to all the detail around the shrine and temple. It helps to have a knowledgable tour guide.
Amazing sight.. Amazing architecture. Really good attraction. I highly recommend going. Lots to see in the area nearby.

Must See Place !!!. Make sure you plan one full day trip to Wat Pho, Grand palace and Emerald Buddha as all are located nearby. Catch the BTS Skytrain to Saphan Taksin, take exit 2 and go for the Government operated ferries. The view in the early morning and late evening are stunning in the river cruise.

Hard to see and veery crowded. We were disappointed by this part of the Grand Palace experience. The crowds were such that it was difficult to move further into the temple where the Buddha sits and the security people were trying to move people through without really allowing a chance to stop and see for any more than a brief glance. Rather underwhelming.

You have to go!. Another place in Bangkok that you must visit. Amazing palaces and temples on a big area to cover on foot. Again, get there early (8.30am) to avoid heat and crowds. Lots of pictures to be taken there.

While in the Grand Palace. Since they are all a step away from each other you should make a point of visiting Wat Phra Kaew. Yes, it's "another" temple, but hey, you are in buddha central...
You can do this temple in 20 minutes if you really don't want to spend too much time...

Wonderful architecture - must visit. This is a must visit while in Bangkok. To avoid traffic suggestion is to use BTS to central pier(#1) and take the public boat ( with orange flag) and get down at Pier#8. For private snake boat they charge THB100/200 per head compared to THB30 in public boat. From the pier it is 10 minutes walk to Grand palace to see Emerald Buddha. We felt the entrance fee of THB500/ person irrespective of age a bit exhorbant as credit card is not accepted. During our visit it was hot and humid, drink plenty of water. There is a small snack / ice cream bar inside the compound. It is a huge compound, with a couple of museums also. Be prepared to walk a lot among jostling crowds. It is recommended to dress properly otherwise you may have to rent the dress @THB50-100.

Emerald statue was very impressive.. . Definitely worth a visit but I was left wondering what it has to do with Buddhism and the goal of uprooting greed, hatred and delusion? Its interesting to look at the temple and the statuary as a manifestation and in support of the state and its power. Closely aligning religion and state seems to come from an international playbook for monarchs.

Amazing temple full of golden cupolas and statues. A must see for every tourist at least once.. This is one of the biggest attractions in Thailand, so every tourist must see it at least once. There are dozens of various temples, many plated with gold cupolas. Some are stone, some are wood, and most took years of manual labor to carve out all the amazing details. The whole palace tour could take about 2 to 3 hours. I forgot the entry fee, but it was roughly $10-$20.
beutiful temple. we were on a bangkok temples tour and that was one of the best of them regarding the amazing art and the amazing statues there

Breathtaking. Being there I realized that when Europe was in the most dark ancient times, Thais build impressive and rich culture. Skills of their craftsmen were unbelievable. Beauty of the complex is overwhelming. I was on my knees.

emerald Buddha interesting but templed out. emerald Buddha interesting. You can't go to Thailand without seeing all the Temples. They are amazing but eventually you can become templed out. Just too much
changes every season. its quite interesting to know that the emerald buddha changes clothes every season, during rainy season the buddha will put on more clothes!

Gorgeous. Wee worth a visit. Amazing place. Very busy. Remember that legs and arms have to be covered whilst visiting as a mark of respect. I loved the time we spent here and well worth the little we had to pay top get in.
Beautiful to see the many positions of Buddha. Really nice peaceful and amazingly beautiful. Loved seeing the different positions and the statues from Japan, Myanmar, India.
Must Must Must Visit!!!. Coming to Bangkok and not see the Emerald Buddha cannot be considered as being to Bangkok. The male Royal Family is the only people who can dress the Emerald Buddha.

A lot of tourists there. The temple is part of the large Grand Palace building so it will take time to reach there especially with a lot of tourist there. Avoid during peak seasons like the King's birthday and other long holiday celebration as a lot more of tourists local and foreigners will come there. Hire a local guide for a good briefing of the place.

Amazing!. It is a very nice visit. Advice do not visit on the week ends because it is very crowded and you get pushed around. You are not allowed to take photographs which is a shame. It is worth the visit.

Too expensive. Not worth the $30 to get into the area to see it. Just look up some pictures online. You also have to wear long sleeves and long pants (even men), so be aware of that before you go. It closes at 4pm.

Another beautiful temple. The crowds take away from the serenity and beauty, but worth it.. There are many beautiful aspects of this temple. As with most of the top sites in Bangkok, the crowds and heat make the site less enjoyable and it ends up being simply an obligation that everyone must check off their list of things to do.That being said, I'm glad I went. Try to take your time and actually look at the detail of the work and the views around the statues.

A nice place but not the best temple we visited in Bangkok. The emerald Buddha is in a nice temple and is really good to see. We preferred the reclining Buddha as an attraction so I would recommend visiting that before the Emerald Buddha.
Incredible temple. Located in the Grand Palace, it's the main attraction of the tour (not the Grand Palace). Very incredible works the Thai has done, really nice and sophisticated
Worth a visit. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is in the same complex as the Grand Palace and is offered together as a package trip. The Emerald Buddha is actually a very small statue.

Nice Traditional Thai Temple. We visited this temple in the middle of the day, bad timing on our part! It was very hot but it was well worth a visit. The ticket office is a little difficult to find as the first queue is for people who need to borrow a sarong. There is a strict dress code enforced, so make sure your ankles and shoulders are covered to avoid waiting in line. The ticket includes access to the palace, which although impressive does not offer more than an outside view and a weapons museum. The temple itself is absolutely stunning and features a variety of styles for each building. It is very popular and so of course it is quite crowded.

In Love With This Place. Where can I start?...It's beautiful. It's so very beautiful.It's everything you expected Thailand to be and then much more. It's jaw-dropping, especially if you have any interest in the complex details of architecture, history and spirituality. It's all here. Years and years of pacient attention to detail, carved in magnificent almost impossible ways.As long as I can remember, this shall remain as one of the most beautiful places I've set step on.It can be challenging on hot days, as so many tours in Thailand, but it's one you can't miss out. We did this straight out of the plane and I regret I didn't have more time in Bangkok to dive deeper into this one, at a more relaxed, rested pace.It's a must-do, must-visit kind of place. It's one of them lifetime, unforgettable visits as it will take you to all the Thailand you've always dreamed of and feared it wasn't there after being devoured by the modern world - it hasn't, it's all here!

Beautiful place. Amazing to see the intricate wok done a the temples.
ery organised and safe to walk through. The colours are great!!!

awesome place. I love this place. it's a very very beautiful temple. just be careful with scams around the temple. don't give attention to anyone who tells you that the temple is closed and wanted to take you somewhere else.
Amazing architecture. This place is beautiful so much to see. You need to take your shoes before entering the temple all you need to dress appropriately.

Amazing and Beautiful!!. Here, at this temple, the time that I recommend you to go is around November to February, because the weather is not that hot. For Thai citizens, they can go in for free, but for the Foreign people, we need to pay for 500 baht, which is really worth to pay. When you go in, there will be lots of people and it will be so crowded. So it’s not that convenient to bring big bags. I really prefer for you to go to this temple, even though it’s quite hot and crowded but it’s worth it.

No Longer a Proper Temple To Pray, But Still Beautiful. This was my second time visiting The Complex of Grand Palace. As you all are aware, this complex consists of a few attractions. The entrance fee is 500 baht, quite expensive, but totally worth it, if only the place is more quiet. Wat Phra Kaew is a temple, which has The Emerald Buddha inside. The place itself was very beautiful and exotic. The walls were drawn, the ornaments was put one by one. And what I really loved was the miniature of Angkor Wat, the details are awesome, and since I've been longing to go to the real Angkor Wat that made it special. But the bad things are, this place is too crowded with so many tourists, so we couldn't really enjoy the beauty of this place. So many people in and out the temple (though I believe that every temple is sacred). They just stomping around, taking pictures, even littering everywhere. Maybe it would be better if they prohibiting the crowds into the temple, or maybe put up some quota.
worth a visit. great to wander around and look at the intricate tile work and sculptures. you'll want to make sure you camera is fully charged for this one. just be sure to wear appropriate clothing.
Beautiful Structure. One of the highlights in Bangkok and very peaceful. Try to stay there when the chanting is happening, it adds to the atmosphere.
Beautiful. It is so beautiful with lots of history, again we had our guide who told us all the local history, she was fantastic.Loved it here.

Good not great but expensive (in Thai money)!!. The issue is to see the emerald (actually made from jade) Buddha is you have to pay to see the palace for 500baht which is around £9 which isn't much but is a lot for Thailand. Men and women also need to cover legs (women shoulders too) which is a bit of a faff in 40° heat. The Tuk Tuks will tell you that it's closed...they are lying they are trying to take you to another temple where they probably get a kick back. If you're going to see the reclining Buddha then you might as well see this one but there will be a queue. When you're in there are many beautiful temples and wall paintings.

Beautiful temple, yet very crowded. Pay 500 baht and you may enter the Palace and view the emerald Buddha. A rather hefty price for attractions that are more than crowded with tourists. The emerald Buddha is definitely worth a visit, as the temple is beautiful. I would however not recommend a visit if you are travelling with an infant.
Interesting. We visited The Emerald Buddha with our tuk tuk driver, great spot and worth a visit. Very relaxed atmosphere and helpful people everywhere.

Skip this crazy chaos!. Yes the temple and the Buddha is beautiful but the whole area is overcrowd, hot and loud. Unless you enjoy being shoved stepped on, listening to tour guides yell in Chinese stay away. There are so many other Wats that are just as beautiful and more serene and interesting to see that if I was to go to Bangkok again I would definite skip this and go straight to Wat Pho

Beautiful temple. Definitely a must see in Bangkok! The temple is so intricately decorated with colorful tiles and different patterns, you wont stop taking photos. There is a strict dress code for men and women so come in pants/ long skirt and a shirt or bring a cover up. This temple is located within the Grand Palace complex and it is HUGE so be sure to have comfortable shoes and water. Tickets are sold together for both temples at a pretty expensive price of 500 bhat. But its worth seeing the beautiful temples for!

Must see. This is a great experience if you are looking for original type of excursion. Good people watching too... so grab a cold & fresh coconut & take your saved change, there are a lot of places to drop donations!

recommended, you must visit. It's highlight of Thailand. It's located at central of Bangkok, which close chao praya river.Getting this palace, bus, taxi and boat are available whatever you see fit. Taking off chao praya boat at Tha chang pier is convenient way to reach the palace. Every tourism must dress up proper clothes for paying respect to the palace. Not allow short, camisole and tank top. The painted wall is very beautiful It's history of buddha. I recommend to visit the Emerald buddha. His seasonal customs was changed 3 times per year by The king of Thailand.This is a place you must see

Beautiful Buddha but the tourist madness was overwhelming. I wish they controlled the number of tourists. It was madness. I felt really bad for the pilgrims. there was so much noise and so many people. It was so crowded. And there were signs warning tourists about pickpockets. The buddha truly was beautiful.
