I just wish we had a chance to really enjoy the sight in peace.

More beauty in Bangkok. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is located inside the Grand Palace grounds. Once you have entered the Wat housing the Statue, you will see the 2 foot high Jade image of a seated Buddha well above eye level. The Buddha dats back to the 1400's and has been housed in this Temple since the late 1700's.By tradition it is clothed in gold robes-- and the Kingor Crown Prince comes here 3 times each year to change the dress at the start of the seasons ( Summer, Cool and Rainy).Definitely impressive, as is the entire Grad Palace complex, and yet another 'must see' for Bangkok

The most impressive temple in banglok. This is by far the most impressive temple in Bangkok! The most sacred place for the believers, so you have to be respectful.. The buildings are so excessively decorated, it impresses everybody
Splendid Place to Visit!. Magnific place to visit with a lot of interesting emerald and golden statues. It's a must see sight if you visit Bangkok, Thailand. Very beautiful and colorful!
NICE PLACE . Best place in Thailand. Buddha is really small but unique. You should stay a little longer because after you pass one gate they don't allow you to come back.

Impressive. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha as well as the Grand Palace is for sure one of the most beautiful complex we have seen. The colors are blended in such an amazing way and there is a sense of goodness around it that you can take your eyes off.

Amazing place to visit!!. Amazing place to visit! Huge statue, temple, huge area too..
You should wear sunglasses also hat to avoid high sunbeam
very good. This is part of the Royal palace complex and is a very busy attraction. The temple which houses the Buddha is magnificant.

Be Respectful. An excellent place to visit as there is so much to see and photograph. the historical significance and royal connections especially interesting. Use a organised trip to learn so much more

Incredible!. This place is absolutely mind blowing. An absolute must see when you go to Bangkok. It was extremely overrun with tourists but even still, the sheer beauty of this temple is incredible. Such craftsmanship has gone into every single inch of it and it's breathtaking. Go with a guide so that they can explain every part to you so you understand its history and significance.
Awesome Place . Yet another wonderful place. Close to Reclining Buddha. Better to have a Guide at this place. Again don't forget to carry your camera. You will definitely get some wonderful clicks.
Good place to visit. The temple is huge, but can not see clearly of Buddha image. So many tourist. Can not take photo inside the temple, which is not so good for our souvenir.

This building is absolutely magnificent!. The temple is beautiful, It is located in the palace complex and so when you buy admission you get to visit all of the grounds. It was a calming, soothing experience, though crowded. No photos allowed inside temple, but with a good zoom it's easy to get photos form outside the temple entrance.
Stunning! . So much detail and beauty at this temple. Make sure to get a good, close look at everything you pass by. The Emerald Buddha is one of Thailand's most prized artifacts.

One of the few must-see temples. As fellow Tripadvisor reviewers have commented, there's a limit on how many temples you can visit while in Bangkok. This is one I would put on your must-see list. There is, as noted, a fee is charged to non-Thais to enter, but it is worth it. The Emerald Buddha, located high atop the alter of the main temple building, is beautiful and is attired by the monks for each season. Please do not fail to visit this temple while you are in Bangkok.And, as others have noted, pay attention to the presence of pickpockets. Don't carry a wallet in a rear pocket. Keep purses closed and zipped. Think defensively and avoid problems.
Unfortunatly no pics allowed. If you have been to Bangkok and you did not visit this place, you have missed something. Great experience and not too crowded at the beginning of November.

must visit temple in Bangkok!. Went here with three friends after visiting the Grand palace.
The word spectacular is an understatement . Truly a feast for anyone's eyes.
MUST, MUST see temple in Bangkok. Wow just mind blowing architecture!!
Amazing temple. The place gave me a very calming feeling. The Emerald Buddha statue seemed physically smaller than what I anticipated but still it was an amazing place. I really liked it.

beware of pickpockets. there are signs warning you to be careful and while I was there, I overheard a tourist talking about how his phone was missing.Also regarding temples in Bangkok. They are nice to see and I would encourage you to visit a couple, but 2 or 3 is good enough. You do not need to see more than that, it starts to feel repetitive by the time you get to your 4th or 5th temple.

Beautiful artwork. This is beautiful artwork of Emerald Buddha. Entrance ticket for local Thai people are free and 500 Thai baht for foreigners. You need to take your shoes off while entering the Temple of Emerald Buddha. Inside is a beautiful temple.

More Impressive when you Know the History. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is beautiful. The artistry and details are breathtaking and have to be seen to really be appreciated. Taking a few minutes to learn about the 'travels' of the Buddha and its history before you go will increase your appreciation. It is part of the Grand Palace so plan for 2-3 hours to see everything. It is always open so ignore the tuk-tuk drivers or others that try and steer you away with tales that it is closed until later due to a special ceremony. I went around noon and it was crowded, but not unbearable. There were no long waiting lines to see anything.
Beautiful temple. Very beautiful temple. In a wonderful place.Ten minutes for the visit of this rich and luxurious places, included 5 minutes for reflection...

Must See!. No trip to Thailand would be complete without viewing the Emerald Buddha at Wat Phra Kaew. Magnificent temple with incredible beauty. Fascinating to witness the immense respect the Thai people show for their sacred temples and to experience such beauty. Definitely recommend taking the time.

The Place you must visit either tourist or Thai!. This temple is an in-house (Grand Palace) royal temple. The most highest holy Buddha Image in Thailand. So the temple outside and inside are the most highest traditional art / architect / decoration in Thailand.There is no monk staying in this royal temple. Only royal ceremony could be held over here. Visitors should check if there is any royal ceremony scheduled before coming. Since this place is holy and part of Grand Palace, polite wearing is a must. Tourist ticket included Grand Palace too. And because of China boom, please note that you might meet a several big groups from China. Please be calm and sip some water during hot air high crowd. ^^

Know before you go!. This is a beautiful temple and crowded with tourists and local Thai - but knowing little details will help the visit be more enjoyable 1. Non- Buddhist must wear closed shoes or sandals with a back strap. No flip flops if you are a farang (foreigner ), 2. If you son is tall (over 5 ft) and looks like an adult? He must be in long pants/ no shorts. If you don't come dressed for entry they do have barrels with pants you can borrow but they tend to be one size fits all .3. Women cannot enter with bare back (no halter tops or bare midriffs can be exposed...regardless of the heat. 4. Shoes do go missing ! Don't skip this temple ! Despite the additional requirements it's something you must see!
An impressive location. This temple is adjacent to some ruins and makes for a pleasant hour or two of cultural exploration. There is a market immediately beside it.

Don't forget to see this on your Grand Palace visit!. This must-do is easy to miss as you soak in the awe of the grand palace but remember to pay a visit to the temple inside the grounds! Its beautiful!

Beware the pickpockets!. This is a temple within a temple at the Grand Palace. Beware of pick pockets it gets incredibly crowded and people can lift things off unbeknownst to you till its too late. You have to take your shoes off to enter this temple, so perhaps wear shoes that don't require laces and be mindful that your shoes may be stolen. No photography inside the temple but there is a spot from the outside where you can take photos if you have a good enough camera.
Most beautiful. Do not leave Bangkok without seeing this most beautiful temple. Very popular and can get crowded. Go early. Don't believe tuk tuk drivers who say it is closed!
Beautiful. This Wat (Temple) was very beautiful. Well worth the visit though you don't need to spend a lot of time here to see it all.

Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew). This is an amazing temple. The buildings and contents offer excellent photography opportunities. The Buddha is a figure meditating seated in a yogic posture clothed in gold. The temple is on the grounds of the Grand Palace. Legend has it that it was created in India in 43 B.C.

Within the Palace complex.. Well worth going early to visit the palace and the temple complex. The crowds can be a bit overwhelming. Do not listen to people outside the palace complex telling you the palace is closed,.
Beautiful temple. Wish we could go inside.. This temple is set inside the grounds of the grand palace and is stunning. If only we could have viewed the inside, I would have given 5 stars.
Beautiful. Although the actual emerald Budha is small, this is a beautiful place to visit. Do not miss it. Use a guide as they impart interesting information.

Religious spot turned tourist frenzie. I am all for respecting heritage sites especially religious ones but with the volume of tourists and loud tourist guides competing with each other to be heard, the sanctity of the place is often overlooked. On the bright side the temple is well maintained and accommodating for tourists. They have cover-up rentals by the entrance for those in shorts or sleeveless shirts. Avoid the hassle of queuing by dressing modestly. They also offer drinking stations in some parts of the temple but drink at your discretion.Eateries and souvenir shops around the Temple and Grand Palace area are more pricier being a tourist area. These establishments close early a little before 5 pm, the same time the temple closes.

Great to visit!! The temple of the Emerald Buddha is very beautiful. Great to visit!! The temple of the Emerald Buddha is very beautiful. Peoplevery crowds but valued to visit the highlight palce of Bangkok's attraction.

Its OK for Bangkok. Yes, visit if you must. But be aware of its fake context. Hardly that you will be impressed if knowing that unless you are a believer wishing to pray in those plastic 20th century made-in-china-like temples and shrines.
Beautiful Temple. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is beautiful! It is breathtaking! Do not miss this Temple! We are so happy we visited it !

Amazing historical site. The whole temple complex is beautiful and is a must see for everyone visiting Bangkok. If you plan on going make sure you take the time to truly appreciate the beauty of everything there. The amount of detail that went into each and every nook and cranny of the buildings is astounding.  When I went apparently there was some 20,000 people visiting the entire complex and let me tell you, it was rough, being shoulder to shoulder in the Bangkok humidity was brutal. So if you can try to visit on a low key day.
Review. Worth visiting, but the crowds can be overwhelming. Suggest picking days and certain times to avoid the masses of people.
A Treasure.... One of the must visit in Bangkok. One of the reason why people go to Bangkok. Impressive. Awesome. Been here three times.
Amazing Budhha Temple. most important Temple in Thailand and Bangkok. very nicely decorated and designed. very crowded all time. must visit.

A must see temple in Bangkok.... I have been here many, many times and am fascinated each time. This is one of my favorite temples in Bangkok and the culture and history here is amazing. Just be careful as this is a popular tourist spot.. keep an eye on your valuables.
A great experience. Such a great place, beautiful design, architect is amazing and feel blessed to be there. Despite of full guests but it is very well organized.

Interesting. I expected the Buddha to be huge, but it was way smaller than I expected. Nevertheless, the temple was spectacular, considering the details of the walls and surroundings of the temple. Take not that you should leave your footwear outside before entering the temple (shoe racks are available near the temple), and taking of pictures inside the temple is illegal. Also, strict dress code is implemented.

Amazing. Take the time to see this attraction. There are so many beautiful things around it that you have to take your time to really realize its beauty. Try to get there early in the morning. Is very crowded.

Small but beautiful. . I don't like to watch people worshiping like in some kind of zoo.
Cameras are not allowed at least.
The Buddha itself is very small and far away on a throne of golden stuff.
Terrific venue. Not too many tourists when I visited and entry price was very reasonable. Highly recommended to anyone interested in Buddha

nice but. temple itself is fantastic. can't describe it. should see it. but so over-crowded with noise. I understand the place being over-crowded but noise level was unbearable. so many guides explaining this and that and the crowds yelling out here and there. these may interrupt you enjoying the atmosphere. FYI, when you get there by the boats, please be aware of scams.  I took Chao praya express boat? from the closest marina to Saphan Taksin. only 10 baht per person. you pay on the boat.Fares are different by the boat (eg.blue 40 bht red 10 bht). still cheap which ever you take. but so many random calls around there with the sign 'information' (of course there is proper information centre on the street but not in the ferry). so please be carefulbut this attraction is still 'must-see' attraction.

Fantastic Temple.. I thoroughly enjoyed my time there! What was expected to be a quick trip became a 2-3hours visit, simply because the place was just so beautifully decorated that you can't help stopping every few steps to admire its beauty and craftmanship.Like many have stated earlier, there's a lot of chinese tour group there. But don't let the squeezing that is needed to get into the place deter you from going in. Once in, most tour group immediately visits the main emerald temple at the centre. While they does that, simply walk around the perimeter of the ground and believe me you won't be disappointed. There's just beauty everywhere (definitely lots of instagram worthy spots!) and most importantly it's quiet with no tourist group in sight. After exploring the perimeter you can then slowly explore the center portion where all the main architecture are found, which by then the number of tour group should have lessen as they head out for lunch.Definitely a must-visit place in Bangkok. Although the entrance fee is a tad too expensive, but it was definitely worth it. There's water refill point around the temple too to quench your thrist.

A Nice Temple Among A City Full Of Them. We enjoyed our many temple visits in Bangkok and this was no exception. At some point inur touring, I got templeitis and just could not see another without getting itchy. They all begin to look alike after awhile. This one is very nice as average temples go but it lacks the memorability of the Big Buddha in Phuket, the glittering magic of the White Temple, or the authenticity of an out of the way temple at a Buddhist monastery such as you can find in the North. But if you are an enthusiastic temple tourist, The Emerald Buddha temple will not disappoint.

Nice place to visit. We were unable to access the Grand palace due to a special service so a few of the local guides recommended a visit here whilst we waited. A short but mad tuktuk ride from the palace this was an interesting place to visit and I would recommend to others

Worth the wait. queues were abit long but once in its worth seeing.do not take photos inside as its against the law.very small considering the statue base is 25 foot high.lovely colours and great smell of incense coming from inside

Emerald Buddha a prized object of devotion. As one might expect, the Emerald Buddha is green. However, it is almost certanly not an emerald, but it is made out of jade. It is an object of deveotion for Buddhists, which includes most Thais.By all means take a look, but remember that you are in a house of worship. You should act accordingly.
Emerald Buddha. Well worth battling the crowds to see this beautiful intricate buddha in very glamorous surrounding's
Emerald Budda. The temple grounds are very nice. There are lots of people so going early is better. Surprised at the actual size of the Buddha itself. Interior is very nice.

What Ayutthaya Once Was. You get an idea, entering the Royal Palace and Wat Phra Kaew, that the Burmese sack of Ayutthaya in 1767 didn't put as much a dent in the coffers of the Thai monarchy as it's usually assumed. Moving to Thonburi across the river and then onto Bangkok, Wat Phra Kaew was built to house the Emerald Buddha.You notice immediately that Gold. Is. Everything. Every building, every sculpture, and most importantly every roof is adorned in gold leaf mixed with crystal panelling. The Ramakien is told along the wall of the external shaded pathway, and even that is painted in gold.The temples soar. You see them for a mile crossing the field from the north, and are visible as far away as Wat Pho to the south. There are so many pagodas and stupas there that once you enter you find it impossible to count them all. Some are gold, some purple, some blue and white, but all of them are a thing of majesty.Remember: long pants (they will give you some for a deposit) and covered shoulders - this is the king's palace still, and it's considered a form of lese-majeste to not obey the dress code. Touts outside the gates will tell you that the temple is closed and will try to take you to the "Big Buddha" temple (aka the Grand Extortion) - don't listen. The palace and Wat Phra Kaew have loudspeakers warning tourists about this. It is open every day! Enjoy it every day!
Fascinating. Brilliant experience!!! Very interesting to get to know a little bit of history Thailand and Buddhism!!!

Temple of the Emerald Buddha. This is a very important shrine in Bangkok. Be aware that you must treat this p;ace in a respectful manner. That means taking your shoes off before entering and no photography is permitted. The Buddha has different clothing, depending on the season. The Buddha itself is rather small as compared to its surrounding, but is magnificent nonetheless.

Underwhelming . I stopped here after Wat Pho and unfortunately my visit was ill timed. I passed through the entrance with approximately 40 coach loads of Asian tourists. They swarmed through the place, taking away all of its charm for me. I was underwhelmed by the Emerald Buddha. But it's a must see so box ticked

Awesome and Fascinating - a real Thai experience. One of the most beautiful places with intricate and extensive work. Suggest you get there early at 9am to avoid the crowds and no need to hire a guide and just wander around taking it all in at your own paceDo cover your legs, respect their customs and rules, don't take photos of sacred places (guards will and have take phones/cameras away) and soak up a wonder of the world!
Emerald Buddha. This is one of Thai most treasure ion. It is a bit far to see clearly but it is still worth seeing when you are in the neighborhood. Most of the attraction is near by.

Calm in chaos. Jade Buddha, smaller than I expected, high on an intricate pedestal, whose apparel is changed every quarter by the King or Crown Prince to match the season. It is said to be the Mecca of Buddhists who must come at least once in their lifetime to pay respects here. Devotees bowing and meditating even in the crowds of tourists. As you leave, there's a large urn of holy water with stems of lotus flowers near it. Dip the lotus flower in the water, make a wish then sprinkle water from the wet lotus flower on yourself for the wish to come true.

Beautiful architecture; Highly crowded place. We went to the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew on a Sunday. The ticket for the Grand Palace visit encompasses the visit to Wat Phra Kaew as well. The day we were there, there were huge crowds of tourists, mostly Chinese. Getting into the Grand Palace itself took about 30 mins. The dress code for entry is very strict - only long trousers /full skirt below the ankles for women (no capri pants / cropped pants / tights). For men, full-length trousers (no shorts, cutoffs). If you do not conform to the dress code, you will have to stand in another queue to go to the changing room where you will have to pay THB200 for a sarong or trousers. The money is refunded to you after you return the clothing.The temple is one of the highlights of the visit to the Grand Palace. Photography is not allowed inside. If you have very little time and want to do a quick tour of the Grand Palace, the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a must see.

Much to do over very little. I understand that the Ermeral Buddah has significant cultural and religious signficance but really.... a 2' statue? Was not aware that men are required to wear pants in 90 degree weather. There was a huge line for men to rent pants. It is better to go across the street to the entrance of the palace and pay 140 BHT to purchase pants. The whole palace and temple came across as a huge tourist trap.
Another temple to visit. This is another excellent place to visit. Again dress appropriately and you'll have to remove your shoes. It can get very busy so go early as possible to avoid the crowds.

Do not miss this temple. Wear comfortable shoes , be patient and go early in the morning.
To view this sight it is worth the endurance

Incredible . One of the most stunningly beautiful places I've ever been to. I was lost for words at how incredible it is. Such intricate and extensive work and a very special place.We arrived early at 9am as suggested and were through the gates and tickets bought within 10 minutes. We didn't hire a guide and just wandered around taking it all in at our pace. It is huge so we took about 3 hours there. In hindsight I would have hired a guide though.Only downside is it was rammed packed by 11am and a bit unpleasant at the main attractions so definitely go as early as you can!!Do cover your legs, respect their customs and rules, don't take photos of sacred places (guards did take phones/cameras away) and soak up a wonder of the world!
A must : Crowded. Very crowded. There are lots of tourists visiting this place. Also bring an umbrella with you in case to protect you from the sun.

Amazing history and architecture . Visited here and had a wonderful time looking at the beautiful buildings. You cannot photograph the Emerald Bubba itself but as this is a religious site it is completely understandable. You must come here if you visit Bangkok!

Interesting. It was interesting tour full of history and intricate carvings. Need to wear appropriate clothing. Ladies and men must wear pants past the knees and wear t-shirts with sleeves or else you may be turn away or you can borrowed one of their clothing with refundable deposit of $200THB. You need to take your shoes off before entering the temple. We ere fortunate to witness a young man ordained to be a monk. Worthwhile visit.

Another Bangkok "must see' - it's not far from other nice places and definitely worth seeing. If you don't have enough of buddas go ad see this one. Small one but surrounded in nice atmosphere. It's not very different from others but still worth seeing :)

Way Too Crowded. Imagine hundreds of people in a confined area and 90 degree weather all taking their shoes off and walking up the same small stairs to see a super small JADE buddha. This site would have been okay minus the people. However, the heat, the people and it's general unimpressiveness makes this site a pain to see. I'd almost skip it and just go to Wat Pho.

The Shrine Room of Kings in old days. The Buddha statue supposed to be made out of Emerald, most valuable statue in Thailand though it is only about 75 cm tall. Originally this temple was used as kings private shrine room. Later it was opened to general public. This is located in the premises of Grand Palace itself. Very crowded place with tourists. The temple premises is very beautifully made.

A Bangkok must see. A no expense spared example of Thai Buddhist temple architecture. The beauty of the temple and its compound are exquisite. If you're short on time, or just not interested in this sort of thing, but feel you should do some kind of cultural visit during your time in the city this would be a good choice. Best to visit early in the morning and on weekdays to best avoid the crowds.

Worth the visit. The temples look so similar but some of them do offer something unique. This temple has a green Buddha image. This Buddha image is not really made of emerald by the way. It just describes the color. You are not allowed to take any photos in this temple.
Not quite what you expect. Awe inspiring, adjoining the Grand Palace. Dress appropriately, follow the guards' directions and be respectful. A remarkable spot.
Interesting temple in Bangkok. Like the reclining Buddha, this is a guaranteed stop on any Bangkok tour and is a top Bangkok attraction. It's a must see for any first time visitor to Bangkok.
Amazing. Very educational and a must see when at the palace. It's architecture is mesmerising and it's worth seeing.
Crowded. Massive crowds. Huge emerald Buddha, a cultural must. Maybe less busy in the afternoon? Our kids were a little claustrophobic in the crowds, but it's a quick enter and exit situation.

Unfogettable.. A revered Treasure ,the vestments are changed seasonably. Beautiful jade Buddha housed in a lovely temple. Spend enough time to digest the impact of this one of a kind artistic creation. Usually visited as part of a Temple tour. Excellent guides will leave you with lasting memories.

Must see ... but be ready first. It is a very nice place with many places to visit inside, but it was very crowded and i felt very hot.
You should take a cold water with u, also to wear a comfortable shoes.
Try to go at early morning.
U will find an amazing architecture from old nation.

A Must See Grand Palace!. We visited Wat Phra Kaew during the peak season in BKK. There were lots of tourists from all around the world coming to see the beautiful architecture of the pagodas and temples. With peak season, taking photos was very hard and frustrating as everyone was pushing each other away from their photos and etc. However disregarding other unwanted tourists, as we all do, the Temple was amazingly built to tower all of us humans. The palace was massive, walking around can take at least a minimum of 1.5hrs, not included how much picture perfect photos you want to take. There were thai art painted on the interiors of the temple, which told the mythical legends of Heaven and Hell, surrounding the human world, of course in a Buddhism context. There were also huge statues of the protectors between the gateway from human to the spirit world. Additionally, the Emerald Buddha was a highlight, worth seeing, unfortunately no photos was allowed inside the temple, taking the photo from the outside wasn't enough to describe how the Emerald Buddha looked, I guess you all will have to go to visit him yourselves!
Hard to really see.. It is there, but at a distance. So it is really hard to get a close up look at this attraction. So had to depend upon my camera lens to assist.
Must see in Bangkok. Beautiful temple. Emerald Buddha is amazing. Architecture of buildings provides great photo opportunities.
Interesting insight into Thai culture. Entry to the Grand palace is 500baht, with a guide another 100baht. Well worth it to have a guide to actually learn what this massive attraction has to offer.

Don't miss it. The architecture, the art, the building techniques are phenomenal. Sure, you can't take pictures inside, but still worth going past all the demons, dragons, snakes to get there. Avoid 8 am rush

Just ok. I don't get want the fuss is about this, I probably should have read up on its history. It's within the Grand Palace console which is handy but it's just a small green Buddha. The reclining Buddha for me
Was the most impressive.
Most do . Very good easily combine with grand palace. Lovely detail. And amazing way to get some insight into Buddhism.

Worth it. If you only visit one temple in Bangkok it should be this one. It is an outstandingly beautiful and majestic temple. Best part of the Grand Palace. No photography allowed, it is also teeming with tourists. Definitely an experience to be remembered, may outshine most if not all other temples you might visit.

Little buddha. Dress code is appropriate here. Remove shoes before entering. Large room, beautifully decorated. Emerald (or rather Jadeite) Buddha sits aloft and surrounded by further Buddha figures clad in gold. Photography is not permitted inside (security guards pounce if you try), however, it is possible to take a photo from the outside looking through a door at the front of the building. Large urns outside filled with water to anoint yourself with a lotus flower - seemed quite a popular pastime with visitors!

Incredible. . You won't truly believe any review until you see it. Nothing I or anyone else can write will describe how amazing this temple is. Make sure you read the story behind it before you go as well. Makes for a better understanding of how important this buddha is!
Decadent. This was beautiful and opulent. I enjoyed seeing the temple and the other shrines. Lots to see in the area as well

Worth the visit. This is definitely worth a visit but anticipate large numbers of people. For women it is important to remember to dress appropriately covering your shoulders, upper arms and knees. This apples to any of the temples and wrap around sarongs are provided for a deposit if you need one.It is moving to see the locals praying inside the temple and the stunning decoration
Nothing fastantic. Very crowded and many had to go through the trouble to get covering clothes for their too revealing dresses or shorts.

Smaller Than Expected, Part of Grand Palace Ticket. The temple was nice, but crowded. For as much as you pay to get in to the Grand Palace the guards should not push people through who want to take it all in. Seeing this is included in the price if your ticket to the Grand Palace.

Must see. Bangkok has MANY things to see and do. I don't understand people who feel that you need to escaped the big mango ASAP. This is a must see and the Chao Praya River Express is a great way to commute - right down the visually interesting Chao Praya River. You can get off at China Town, Yaworot - and take it to the Sky Train at Saphan Taksin.
little but beautiful. Worth a visit, beautiful and not really emerald actually jade, history interesting, dress appropriately out of respect.

Little Tiny Buddha.. I've seen better though the rest of the complex is a MUST. This place is just huge! Plan at least half your day here and a brand new SD Card to take loads of Photos! so much to see. The Audio Guide was really very informative and you can skip along as you like and learn all the history and "tales" of that time. The emerald Buddha is not very interesting for it is way up and you cant get close to see it nor can you take photos... so just a quick walkby I think is enough. There are Buddhas of all shapes, sizes, colors etc. to be seen everywhere else.
Nice but busy. The Emerald Buddha is quite small and high up, so the view isn't great, and the hall is very busy. It is worth visiting, but it wasn't a special experience for us.
Beautiful. Located inside the Grand Palace this is a beautiful piece in a brilliant Temple. It has a fascinating history too. Very interesting
stunning. maybe the most beautiful temple i've seen in thailand, and i have seen some of the best. just try not to get bothered by the loads of disrespectful/rude chinese

Inside the Grand Palace, the Emerald Buddha awaits!. This was extremely exciting to see! Yes, it's inside the grounds of the Grand Palace, which you have to pay an entry fee to get into. But once you're in, you can walk into the Temple to see the Emerald Buddha. ***FYI - you are required to remove your shoes before entering, as well as having shoulders and knees covered. If not, you'll be denied entry into the temple. Also, NO PHOTOS allowed inside the temple. But there were people snapping pics from outside thru the little window/doors to get in. The building is beautiful. Lovely architecture and details all around. You shouldn't rush this, there is too much to take in. Would go back again and see.

“AMAZING. The temple and mainly Ceilings, roofs, statues.”. Don't miss it. In my opinion the best temple I've seen in Bangkok! Just admire the detail and thought that goes into every single square inch, the different styles it means that you miss something.. but as a Thai people , this place is extremely crowded and very hot , but sure ! it is beautiful and full of Thai arts and cultures to explore. A must visit for anyone visiting Bangkok.

Beautiful (but very crowded) temple. My advice is try to bring an umbrella or wear a hat, because the weather here is quite hot. There's a cold water refill station inside, so don't throw away your empty bottles! Also, to go inside you need to pay 500 THB/person and wear appropriate clothes (no pants or short skirts, no open shoulders etc).The temple itself is big and very beautiful, with lots of ornaments and statues. Tourist are not allowed to take pictures of the Emerald Buddha, however you can take photos from the outside.

Located inside the Grand Palace. Combine this visit with your entrance to Grand palace. We actually almost missed it our first time through because it sits high and in the back of the temple. Don't forget to look up! This is the most crowded spot of the Grand Palace so try and go early in the day.

Cultural Wonder. The only bad thing about visiting the temple is the amount of tourists in this place, we were lucky to find a tour within the temple that's English guided free tour (but please tip afterwards) Our guide Jeffrey is very knowledgeable and he know all the history about both the Grand Palace and the Temple, which we learned so much about everything here. I'm not sure if there's a slow tourist season, but if there is one, come visit during that time.
The history of this is simply amazing.. Do read up on this before a visit...it is very special to the Thai people and is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple in Thailand.
Beautiful. This houses the most sacred Buddah and the building is nice but it's more about the Buddah than the building or setting.

Really hard to find. We wanted to visit this temple but we could not find it and when ever we asked for the Emerald Buddha no one could help us ( maybe ask for Wat Phra Kaew and you will be more successful than us ).
Wow. So pretty and very culturing of Thailand this is a must visit in Bangkok so much to see how beautiful of the Thai's temple in the busy city

Go in the morning, but do not miss!. Our tour guide took us here before 9 am and this is the best time to see this wonderful site. Do not miss if possible, but try to go in the AM before it gets hot and crowded.
Nice!. This is nice temple to visit, but very anoying with alot of disrespectful chinese tourist group around!
Cultural icon. A must visit when in Bangkok. Stunning artistry, incredible history, and classic thematic expression of the Siam of antiquity. One of the great places to visit in Asia.
Too crowded. Too crowded, almost impossible to visit, no way to even walk through the grounds.The buildings are very beautiful but we didn't enjoy it due too the quantity if tourists...
Sightseeing . A good place to visit while you are in bangkok. Take pictures and enjoy the scenery. Don't forget sunscreen!
Rich detail. Plan to spend a few hours and bring an umbrella to protect you from the sun. Beautiful, at times awe inspiring, with an amazing amount of detail.

A wondrous temple, but overrun by disrespectful Chinese tourists. For first-timers to Bangkok, this should be the first spot on your sightseeing itinerary. I was just floored by the architectural detail and beauty of the temple's various buildings. However the atmosphere was spoiled by the unruly crowds of Chinese package tourists who were shouting even though there were signs posted around the temple asking people to remain quiet. That doesn't take away from the fact that it is a gorgeous place, but try to go early in the morning before the big tour groups sweep in.
Nice Tample. When We Visit emerald Budha there any rules that we can take a Photo when we inside the tample. its beautiful budha.. made from Emerald.. and he wear clothes as same with the wheather.
A Bangkok must see!. A must see on the list of attractions while in Bangkok. Temple grounds are well kept and well worth the visit for those wanting to view the major temples.

Worth a visit!. If you are ok with swarms of predominantly Chinese tourists and the 500 Bhatt entry fee then this is thoroughly worth a visit - beautiful structures and art - take a moment to reflect in the emerald Buddha's temple. I also advise the coin museum for an air conditioned break from the heat. Note: completely ignore any friendly local who is claiming it is closed or free later on - they are just trying to divert you somewhere else for a small profit.

Emeral Buddha. The Royal Palace and the adjoining temples are a must see on any trip to Bangkok - I never wary of visiting this phenomenal place, although you cannot take photo's inside the temple which is a shame

A Very Sacred Place for the Buddhists. The temple is very solemn... its solemnity gives you the air of reverence! Taking photos ad videos are not allowed inside the temple. The emerald Buddha is quite small than expected and you are not allowed to go near it. You can see a lot of Buddhists praying inside and you need to take off your shoes before entering the temple.
Amazing. Amazing to see. Interesting facts related to us by our tour guide, Air from BKK. It's a lot to take in.
Beautiful. Photography is not allowed inside / Try to go early in the day so you can enjoy and take it in! Gets over crowded otherwise.

Extraordinary! A place not easily forgotten!. I was in Bangkok in 1986 so it has been awhile. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha was an awe inspiring lesson in history, art and culture all at the same time. While we were not allowed into the interior of the temple near the buddha itself, it was easy to feel the silent reverence of the entire atmosphere and the sparse sculptures and, huge exposed empty floor and the feelings were unmatched anywhere. I was happy to be there, outside, gazing in. Definitely a must see on your trip to Bangkok

Extremely grand. It is one of the most beautiful monument I ever saw. It takes lot of time to absorb all the beauty of the place. Lot of rush here. Better dress in short sleeve and a pant or long dress. No sleeveless tops or short pants.Rental covering dress are available too near the shrine.Reaching here is much easy by boat than road. It is part of Grand place premises.

Unique!. The Emerald Buddha temple was very cool to see! Unfortunately we weren't allowed to take any pictures of the Buddha but it was quite small in size especially compared to the huge reclining Buddha.

Must visit. You cannot leave Thailand without visiting this place.. This place is a feast on the eyes. Be there early. We went there 7AM, had filling breakfast near the back entrance. It was so much lovelier, no busy people walking in the sidewalk yet. Went inside and bought our tickets for 500 Baht. - the most expensive ticket we purchased but definitely the most worth it. Suggest you go to The Grand Palace by the Chao Phraya River and just walk towards it. Of course you have to remember the basics when travelling in Thailand:1. Wear or bring soft cotton pants. You cannot go inside if you're wearing shorts. But it so hot so better bring those cotton pants.2. Bring LOT OF WATER. There are water dispensers available in the area, so don't throw away your bottle.3. Wear nice socks. You will be exposing them. lol.4. BRING A CAMERA. If you like pictures, and you forgot your camera, just go home. You'll regret not bringing a camera. :P5. Respect the Thai tradition. If they say no picture taking, so please don't do it. it's plain simple.6. Visit the coin museum. Not only it is cold there, but it will give you a change to see some of Thailand's royal family's history. Very interesting.

The Emerald Buddha of Bangkok. The buildings are beautiful but the Emerald Buddha seems rather smaller than expected. Crowded inside the Temple. No photos to be taken. I saw some girl taking photos and the security asked her to delete the photos immediately. The walls around has beautiful paintings but I didn't see any description about them. Some part of the paintings are painted in gold making those part embossed and beauitful. Seems like some history but no hint at all. Better go early so that you can spend more time in the compound. The Grand Palace is not much. Spend more time taking photos in the Buddha Compound. The entrance fees was 500 baht when I visited in September.
impressive details. the details and sculptures are amazing.. the place is always crowded, and with hot weather it is difficult to enjoy it... but it is still a must see landmark
Awesome. Excellent temple. You need to go through grand palace entrance to visit this. You cam observe that the emerald buddha idol has different golden clothing in different seasons.
must visit. Buddha is actually quite small and far away, but beautiful. Very crowded temple, covered in decoration. What would the Buddha have thought of all this? Stunning though

The most astonishing temple to visit...... Wat Phra Kaew. Wat Phra Kaew is a marvelous temple to visit. The buddha that is inside is amazingly beautiful. The temple wall is decorated with patterns and pictures that are interesting. The painting on the wall and buildings is breathtaking. Wat Phra Kaew is a very popular tourist attraction so during the high season people would be very crowded. People from many country would come and visit the temple and it would be really packed and hot.  If you have a Thai national you don’t need to buy the ticket but, if you are foreigner you need to buy the ticket in order to visit temple. The price of the ticket isn’t that high and it worth the price.  Overall it was a nice and fantastic temple if it wasn’t too crowded and hot. So I recommend you to come to Thailand and visit the Wat Phra Kaew because you wouldn’t be disappointed in the nice view and the gorgeous temple.

Emerald Temple. wat phra kaew is the best place to visit in bangkok if you are on tourism purpose. you need to pay the entry fees to enter this temple more than local pays it. i really liked this place and highly recommend it to all.

Beautiful temply but smaller buddha than expected. Very crowded and pretty expensive. Also felt unorganized in the entrance area. Ignore any strangers who tell you it's closed!!! Women and men must cover knees and shoulders (scarves do not count, actual sleeves required) or you have to stand in a long line and pay a 200 baht deposit to borrow clothes. Would have gotten more out of this with some sort of guide, because it was so hot and crowded we couldn't enjoy reading any of the plaques to learn about the history and significance of the Wat and Grand Palace.
Beautiful temple. This is a beautiful temple in Bangkok. Visiting this place makes you feel peaceful and calm. Lots of happy memories and beautiful colours very vibrant and bright all over.

AMAZING. The temple and mainly everything around it. Ceilings, roofs, statues.. Don't miss it. In my opinion the best temple I've seen in Bangkok! Just admire the detail and thought that goes into every single square inch, the different styles.

Take binoculars!. The temple grounds are large and there is much to see. Statues covered with gold, Pillars painted gold, lacquered gold, inlays of gold, crowned by a gilded gargoyles and monsters. Read up on the symbolism of figurines. But do not expect to actually "see" the Emerald Buddha. No photos are allowed inside and there is a bright light behind the tiny figure. I think I saw it, or perhaps not, because there was a bright white light surrounding the figurine
Mesmerizing feel. There is a positive feel inside the temple. Richness all over. Photos must not be taken inside the temple; there are people watching.

Thai Signature attraction... with big crowded and heat !. I can tell that if you come to Thailand and miss visiting this place , it means that you miss something.. but as a Thai people , this place is extremely crowded and very hot , but sure ! it is beautiful and full of Thai arts and cultures to explore. by the way , if you are foreigners , you need to pay for entrance fee and please dress formally if you don't want to pay for clothes rent fees
Must see. Gaudy golden Buddhas... Who can resist? Splendid .. Tucked away in a remote area but easy to find as it is well marked from the local buses.

Small Budda. Lao. Cambodia and Thailand all claim the Emerald Buddha. Each country has a different story as to how it ended up in Thailand. That being said, there is a lot of history behind this small Buddha. If you are willing to put up with crowds and struggle for a glimpse of the Buddha the trip is worth it because there is also a lot more to see at the temple.

Absolutely stunning!. A must if you are in Bangkok. The whole ground of the temple are gorgeous and a welcome escape from the city. Remember to dress conservatively if you are paying a visit, though clothes are available for rental if you forget. make sure your camera is fully charged!
Blessed temple . The Emerald Buddha temple is probably the most holiest of all the Buddha temples in Bangkok. A must visit for anyone visiting Bangkok.
Wat Phra Kaew.........must visit once. Very crowded place..........inside Grand palace . Dress code apply to enter Grand palace. Worth watching
Meh. He's so small. You expect much more, but you've paid and get to see more than just him inside. Go early so as to avoid crowds.
Serene place. Inside royal Place premises only. Here no skirt no shorts allowed. Photo inside temple not allowed. can visit royal palace and temple in single day.

Very Interesting!. It is not true what they saw about Emerald Buddha's, they are not all the same...In fact actually it is at times quite hard to even tell if it is real because of how far away they are from the crowd, granted though (people would touch and grab it).Again, it can be crowded during the Spring Festival, don''t go in busy travel times...
Nice!. This temple has a great architecture and good taste of art in every detail. You just need 1 hour to explore this place
Visit along with Grand palace. You can visit this along with Grand palace. Better take hats if you are going in Summer, it very hot climate.

Beautiful.. Not an inch of the walls isn't decorated in some jewel. I was expecting a huge Buddha, initially disappointed with it's size but it really is beautiful. This temple is on the same grounds as the Grand Palace, so if you visit one you should see the other too. Remember it is a temple so please dress appropriate and no photography.
Amazing. All I can say is it is amazing. It is for sure a must see. It does get crowded but other than that it was awesome. The details on the buildings is breathtaking.
Very nice!!. This is one of the places not to be missed in Bangkok. Lovely experience but beware of the touts just outside there.
Beautiful, a must see of Bangkok. Beautiful temple and atmosphere. The emerald buda is smaller than I expect but still amazing. A must see in Bangkok

Nice temple. Def worth seeing but don't prebook. Almost any trip you take in Bangkok will be cheaper to book when here with more choices of itenaries. Most of the local tour operators do 2 or 3 temples in 1 day for approx £20.00 to

Covered in gold all sides.. It is a place not to be missed when visiting the Palace. The decorations are outstanding. However, it is a place for worship and photography is prohibited. Sit down for some time and pray and relex.

Nice Temple. I've visit this place during Thailand Public Holiday, but its still not croowded yet because i came early as 8am. The temple has a beautiful design, with shiny gold everywhere. Just dont forget to bring water or buy at any store or stall before you come here. Bangkok weather is very hot.

Impressive but where's the Buddha?. I went to the Grand Palace just to see this green Buddha. Went through all the hassle of taking off shoes to get inside - where is the Buddha? Did someone move it?
It must be very small. Look carefully.
Must see. If you go to Bangkok, you must visit this site, the whole Grand Palace Complex is stunning. Wear long shirt and trousers!

Beatiful!. Beatiful temple, must see if you like to visit temples. Lots to see. Be precise of what you are wearing. They have shirts for rent, but you may want to respect the culture and wear proper clothes for your self. If you don't, you wont be getting in.

Astonishing, Marvelous, Beautiful. Another beautiful temple in Bangkok. Bangkok is home of many temples all extremely beautiful. You have to make time to visit all of them. Each one has its own beauty.

must to see. One of the main touristic places. Golden walls are designed with mirror and gold and they are highly shiny. As a total, interestic and ethnic architecture. No shoes are allowed to get in temples inside. There is an entrance fee.

Go early. Go early to avoid the heat and tour bus crowds. There's a decent recorded guid you can rent.
Dress appropriately, no bare shoulders, tight leggings or exposed knees.
With many of the temples you will have to take you shoes off to go inside. I suggest comfortable shoes you can get on and off easily.
A reverent and important part of Thailand's Culture & History. An amazing place to visit, the temple housing the emerald Buddha is a must see for it's intricate detail and wall murals.
My memorable experience in Thailand the land of happy people.. I've been to Thailand twice and it is amazing. The Emerald Buddha was magnificent and beautiful. I would recommend this as a must see.
Worth to see this temple. it is worth to see this temple, architecture, artwork, well maintained it is good to be here for while.

Another main attraction. After seeing in one day Golden Buddha and Wat Pho, the Emerald Buddha looks less impressive then two of the above, or maybe its too many in one day. But another a must on tourist route.
Gold everywhere . Great place to visit, you need to wear long pants but you can borrow them there for a deposit. Expect a lot of people though!
Beautiful. It´s a amazing Temple. The esmerald buddah is impressive. However there are many tourists, the heat is intense and you can't take pictures inside the temple.

Nice place to visit, but keep in mind you have to take your shoes off. This was a treat! Be prepared to take your shoes off. It's a nice and relaxing temple, many of them all require you to take your shoes off.

Magnificent temple. This place is truly one of the most beautiful traditional building experiences I've had. The details of every single part of this place is truly remarkable and it's also really a huge place of a variety of structures. Please note that this temple is visited with the Grand Palace. The negative side of it is the huge amount of tourist flooding this place thus please visit early morning before it gets real crowded and hot.
Good place to visit at bangkok. You can enjoy Thai culture and history here.I enjoyed with my guide this place very much.The Buddha monument is very beautiful as well.

The great temple of Buddha in Bangkok.. Many beautiful royal buildings in the same place or nearby such as royal palace.Its beautiful porcelain mosaic, gold leaf art and also mirror mosaic art to be seen.Give yourself a moment of calm and peace, you'll find inside of the temple (except in festival!)

Sacred for those who practice Buddhism, may underwhelmed those who don't . The palace was a gorgeous place to walk through and within it lies the Emerald Buddha. It is a sacred place for those who practice Buddhism but maybe underwhelming for those who don't.

Must Visit Place in Bangkok. This is the Temple of Emerald Buddha and its a must visit place in Bangkok and lot to see here.
I would recommend taking a guide coz they will explain you everything as this is a large place and everything has a story behind it. the value comes when we knows the story.

Think twice! Be prepared and don't get conned. Very hot, very crowded. We had just been conned by a tuk tuk company that the gate was closed so we would have to come back... When we finally came back after being dragged from shop to shop (of their choice), we discovered an open gate around the side. The Police help these guys rip-off tourists, so ignore suits and uniforms... Now to get back on topic... Due to the crowds inside we could not see a thing! The outside temple was lovely... Wish we hadn't bothered and I'm usually a "look for the silver lining" person!

Marvellous Thai traditional temple. Beautiful Thai traditional temple with statue of lord Buddha in Emarald..decorated in 3 different precious stone studded gold dress in 3 different seasons i.e. Summer, Winter and Rainy seasons. A must see attraction of Bangkok

Part of Grand Palace admission - Emerald Buddha temple. The Emerald temple is located in centre of the Grand Palace. There was a large crowd of people trying to get into the temple when we were there and just a hand a peek at the Emerald Buddha at the temple entrance as we were bare foot and our feet were getting hot!

Part of the Grand Palace. 500 Baht admission to the Grand Palace also includes Wat Phra Kaew. This is the most significant temple in Thailand since the ceremony of changing seasoning garment for Emerald Buddha is performed by the King or the Crown Prince.

Amazing. With only a one day stopover in Bangkok we were pleased we arranged a tour here with a guide. Incredible history and beautiful buildings architecture made for a fascinating day. Well worth a visit
Just BEAUTIFUL!. Well worth the 500 baht to enter the grand palace complex. Everywhere you look is wow! Don't forget to cover your legs and upper arms. And no leggings allowed!

A MUST. Main Bangkok tourist attraction. Expensive for foreigners as the entry ticket is 500 bahts whilst it is free for Thai citizens. Beautiful murals all around and great architecture from different periods. Very colourful and picturesque.
Beautiful. Temple is huge and impressive, if you are in Bangkok than you must visit the temple. It is definitely worth a visit.

Stunning Architecture in the Heart of Bangkok!!. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is something that cannot be missed in Bangkok! The architecture is out of this world, and you will be amazed at the intricate detail with which they have crafted the temple and the surrounding buildings! The Emerald Buddha himself is not that impressive as he is quite small. The cool this is that they change his clothing based on the season!! Quite cool!

Beautiful History. Beautiful temple. The Emerald Buddha is very revered, and protocol is adhered to. No shoes, no hats, on your knees unless entering or exciting the temple. It's a magical place. Stay quiet and just soak it in.

Beautiful for a short stop. The Emerald Buddha is included in the 500 baht entrance fee to the Grand Palace. I highly recommend getting the map so that you can find your way around and know what you're looking at, as otherwise it just looks like a lot of beautiful buildings grouped together. You aren't allowed to take photos of the Emerald Buddha so keep that in mind as it is enforced. Inside the temple is absolutely beautiful and I found it really peaceful and calming to sit for a couple of minutes and check out the inside and just sit with all of these people from all over the world coming together to pray in front of this statue. The Buddha itself is not that interesting, it's pretty small and you have to sit at a distance from it. I was really impressed with the level of upkeep of the temple though, and there is a box where you can leave a donation towards this but that is optional. Just make sure you dress appropriately, wear shoes that are easy to take off, and take water! It is seriously crowded and gets really, really hot, especially with that Thai humidity.

Tuk Tuk . I visited a lot of temples in Bangkok, and I talked to a lot of locals. What I found out is that the Tuk Tuks, those tricycles that transport tourists, they make their money by bringing tourists to different shops. So all of the Tuk Tuks around the Temples will offer to drive you around the city for practically free, but their true intentions are to take you to shops that pay them commission for bringing in tourists. Nothing wrong with that, except that is good to know what is going on. This one time I tried to hire a Tuk Tuk because it was raining, I offered to pay him good if he would take me to the Skytrain station, NO STOPS on the way. He refused. He insisted on at least ONE stop, the suits factory. I refused. I said NO stops, straight to Skytrain station. He insisted on at least ONE stop or there would be no deal..There was no deal! I don't know how much commission they get, but must be a lot for them to put it as a condition for a ride. Nothing wrong with that, just be informed.

Beautiful!. This is a must see attraction along with the grand palace! Make sure to dress appropriately - that means no tank tops or short shorts/skirts! You can easily spend a few hours walking around and there are some great spots for photos.Something else to keep in mind - this place is HOT. seriously no joke hot. It is open to direct sun, with almost no shade/trees, and the buildings are gold and sparkly which means the heat just radiates off the structures. I've been all over SE asia and its the hottest one place I've ever been. Do yourself a favor and bring water and spend the $1 for the ice cold washcloths for sale around the outer palace area.
Very beautiful buidling. This is one of the major attractions within the Royal Palace. The Budda was much smaller than anticipated.

Interesting but not that spectacular. In a country with many spectacular sites, this one fell a bit short. While the temple is lovely (and yes, once again you have to take your shoes off!) the Bhudda is small and quite frankly, I am not sure that it is made of anything but glass. However, that being said, we were in the temple with two monks who were sitting and chatting and praying so that was interesting.
Also must see. If you come to Bangkok and you skip the Grand Palace and the temple of the Emerald Buddha that's mean 'you'll never arrive to Bangkok'. Stunning Palace and resident of the Thai's King
Must see. The emerald Buddha wears a different coat for the 3 seasons and the coat can only be changed by his Royal Highness the King. Well worth a visit

Small But A Must See. The Emerald Buddha is wonderful to see, but you will probably be surprised at how small it is. To get the best view, you have to see on the floor near the front. You do not have to sit in the lotus position, but you cannot sit with your feet point forward. Depending on the season, the Buddha will be dressed accordingly. The inside of the temple is very spectacular, almost overwhelming the small Buddha

wonderful temple. the temple is within the grounds of the grand palace, so the entrance fees "500 Baht" allows you to visit both places. Dress code applies for visiting this temple. No photos is allowed inside, but you can get a photo at the entrance, to remind you of the temple. the lovely details inside the temple deserves that you spend a good quality time there.

The color of the buildings blew us away. This tour is combined with the grand palace tour as they are in same campus. The buildings in the campus are all beautifully maintained. When we visited a scale model of Angkor Wat was on display and it looked fantastic. Not sure if this is a permanent fixture.
Wat Pha Keaw. The Temple of the Emeral is very beautiful and a lot of people I love this place that wanna pray with Buddha you should visiting to Wat Pha Keaw

Interesting but not to be repeated.. The architecture is BEAUTIFUL but the area is overcrowded and there is no chance to stop and admire any of it because one gets swept along by the crowd. I think the authorities need to implement some form of crowd control.

Worth the heat!. Both the inside and outside of the temple are amazing! Be patient taking a picture because it was so crowded there, make sure you bring sunglasses and hat because it is very hot your eyes and head will be burned as soon as you step inside!

Beautiful temple for the Emerald Buddha. Be certain to wear appropriate clothes for temples. Women must have upper arms covered and modest skirt or long pants. Crowds are large because it is so popular. Another priceless Buddha temple.
Beautiful Temple!. Wat Phra Kaew is one of my favorite temple in Bangkok .This temple is so beatifull and colorful,very recommend!

Impressive . It is really really crowded and full of tourist, that take photos all the time and don't even stop to look around. Also 500 baht is expensive compared to other attractions in Bangkok, food and tours around Thailand.
All in all it is beautiful and impressive, but I liked Wat pho better.
Awesome and a lot of people.. Beautiful... but many people.. it's better to be there in the early morning.after this place. you can see the sleeping Buddha.

Amazing!. Beautiful temple! Make sure you wear pants and a shirt if visiting, or at least a skirt that covers past your knees and your shoulders are covered - otherwise you will have to hire clothes before you are allowed to visit (although they require a deposit they fully refund this). The design and time spent with decorating each building is astounding!
Worth a visit. We visited a few days ago. It was very busy. Stunning to look at and there was such tranquility inside. We wouldn't visit again but well worth seeing once.

Good two for one - Emeralds buddha and the royal palace. It is crowded, but the Emerald buddha and the royal palace are a one stop attraction. The grounds and temple are gorgeous if not crowded. Wear appropriate clothing or be ready to buy some ridiculous looking baggy elephant pants that scream "tourist who failed to do their homework".
Peaceful experience. Huge place!! Very difficult to cover entire temple and the grand palace if the trip is during afternoon. Can sit inside the temple for some peaceful time.
Stunning elegant and beautiful. The temple is inlaid with many mosaic tiles and beautiful designs, it is so beautiful to see and nothing measures up to it
within the grand palace. this is amazing and within the grand palace so it is a must... bring something to put your shoes in... it can get chaotic outside... you can't take pictures...

Emerald Buddha what po. A beautiful,peaceful complex of vibrant temples. Interesting history of Thai massage and the home of the main Thai massage school. Visiting the emerald Buddha is busy and crowded but worth the time. A Thai massage at the school is an experience. A bit more expensive than you can find in other places but you will certainly get a good intensive massage.

Yes yes yes! Must see !. If you only have time for one attraction in Bangkok, this has got to be the one! The Emerald Buddha is indeed the palladium of the city and a sight to behold. Remember to read up on the history before you go. Also go to all sections of the Grand Palace that are open to the public - each one has a story to tell. Do sign up for the free tours every day - we got an awesome guide who helped us navigate the place and took us to all open areas. Note that photography is not allowed in all areas, especially in the area of the gold throne used for the King's coronation. Do go to the museums (tickets included in the overall price) to see the gold robes that are not used on the Buddha at the time. Overall, it's a sneak peek into a culture that is very different from most others - absolutely must see !
Worth a visit. Worth the money and the visit. Having seem other temples before didn´t help as it becomes less spectacular. Even though, this is one of the best "wat" to visit in Thailand.
It's tiny but magnificent. It's small, but its beautiful. Just a shame you don't get really close to admire it's beauty. You can't take photos or videos inside which is disappointing.

Absolutely a must for travellers to Bangkok . Peaceful and serene. The Emerald Buddha temple is a must on every travellers list when they come to Bangkok. Located in the Dusit Area. The temple and the courtyard are amazing.

Busy but a must. This is included on entrance to the grand palace 500 baht which I thought was reasonable. However photography is not permitted within the temple and shoes need to be removed. You will need to be dressed appropriately but if like me and my friends you do happen to be wearing shorts then you can hire some clothes for 200 baht each (fully refundable) before entering the grounds.

Another Wat not to miss out on while in Bangkok. The entry to Grand palace and Temple of Emerald Buddha costs 500 baht.I started with the premises around Temple of Emerald Buddha and did not regret the money spent.No words would do justice to describe the beauty of the temple.Only drawback in comparison to Wat Pho was the large number of tourists which made photography really difficult.This is one of the places which a traveller ought not to miss out on while in Bangkok.
Nice place ❤. Enjoy weekend here ❤many people here. Some places can't take photos ......must go there early big place can take many pictures

The Emerald Buddha. This is very famous temple. Everyone in Thailand would know it , also the tourist love to visit Wat Phra Kaew. The status is made of jade. Also the door is painting by famous people.They were lots people went to visit this temple. The best and famous thing in the temple is a emerald buddha. It made of a real emerald. A buddha is so shine . But when we go there we need to wear a long pant and t shirt. If you wear short they won’t let you go inside the temple. On January I went there with my family. We wear a long pant and t- shirt. We went inside the temple and then we went to pray a emerald buddha . But they don’t let us taking a photo because someone could copy emerald buddha.  Lastly, if you go there you will miss this temple so much. It is very pretty temple. Thai people also love this temple.
Brilliant. It's a striking piece of work. It's the first stop when you enter The Grand Palace. The architecture, the pieces of art - spend some time and enjoy.

Check it off the list. The Buddha is small and you can't get close enough for a good viewing. We went on New Year's Day and the crowds were oppressive - we got moved along in a sea of visitors tourists - so only got a brief glimpse.
Impressive!. Wow! Well worth the trip. First visit there for me on my 11th trip to Bangkok. Do not miss it. Follow it up by a river boat trip not too far from site.

Singular temple that is worth to visit!. This is a singular temple, that is worth to visit. The statue is made of jade, not Emerald. The statue is very beautiful and has a different green glow that really catches our eye! Very nice place!

Magistic. This is the temple where the Royal family prays ......... its inside the Grand palace complex and is bustling with people, however if you want to get a real feel of the temple try to go early so that there are less tourists.

A must see landmark. I went there after Wat Pho, as it's only a 5 minute walk. it is marvelous place to see. beware not to fall for the scams if anyone told you that it is closed for the day, just ignore him and go right away. remember to bring something to protect you from the sun.

Not a huge fan. After having visited Wat Pho which managed to maintain a calm, peaceful and serene atmosphere even with the large numbers of tourists I found Wat Phra Kaew to be a bit of a disappointment. It was incredibly busy and operated on a one way system which meant that if you missed out on anything then there was no going back as you were greeted by stern looking guards. Probably worth a visit but I wouldn't expect to find any enlightenment there....

Holiday. The temple of the Emeral Buddha is one of the important landmark that you have to visit when you come to Bangkok.The temple is really showing the history of budhism and as same as Siam country.It is really nice and beautiful place. for the Buddhist, the temple is very sacred and you can spend your time to visit and pray.The Grand palace and Wat Pho is also in the next door. you can easily walk to see all without spending any money on transportaion.Inside the temple, the Emerald Buddha will be on the highest center with the very beautiful Jade shape.You can walk and look around the temple and you will also see the wall painting with the Thai traditional paint And story around.Highly recommend for a visit.
Unmissable. I would say that its my favourite site in Bangkok, very impressive, where beauty exceedes expection, attention to details and man craft have met beauty!
Grand and Gorgeous!. Majestic and royal, this palace is one of the most beautiful places you would come across in Bangkok.

Beautiful Emerald buddha. Emerald Buddha temple is located within the grand palace and can be visited together with it. Beautiful buddha image made of jade and around 65cms tall. Sitting in a meditative posture. My tour guide told me that the costume for the buddha here can be changed only by the king 3 times a year. No one else have the authority to do so :)

Bangkok landmark !. I would say this is a highly recommenced place in Bangkok. This is like a signature of Bangkok so you should visit ! NOTE : Entrance fee for forefinger is 500THB and please wear polite cloth, no vest, slippers and short.

intersting site to see. The emerald BUddha is a temple hehind the golden Palace and easy walking distance. Th Emeralt Buddha is not a massive Buddha, but very important to the Thai people and the Royal Family.

Advice on greeting an Emerald Buddha. Get there early in the morning to avoid heat and crowds. Before entering the palace complex be aware of charlatans lurking. They will find any excuse to stop you, just keep walking! Tickets are 500 Baht. No shorts or tank tops should be worn or you will have to buy something to cover up. Definitely worth seeing!
Stunning. This is a beautiful temple. The work that has gone into this building is breath taking . A bit over crowded though.
Amazingly glittery. Do make sure you are suitably attired. You can't have your arms bare or wear shorts or short dress/skirt.

What a great piece of gem!. The emerald Buddha temple is filled with tourists and everyone is there for the same reason i.e. to have a look at the Emerald Buddha.If you have not seen this Emerald Buddha, you have not been to Bangkok!
A must visit Attraction. If you are planning a trip to Bangkok you must visit the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. It was a fabulous experience learning about the previous Thai dynasties.
Not to be missed!. Breathtaking views make you want to keep snapping photos! I urge you to pause and soak in the beauty and the spirituality of this place.

The Highest respect in Thailand. Our family just visit last Sunday, it's really hotest day. If you would like to go there better to prepare an umbrella with you.This place are the most special for Thai people because it has the most respect " the Emerald Buddha" also the grand palace in side this temple.If you love to see the paiting and read about the "Ramakien", here is the best place for it.If you lost the way in your mind, and you are Budhist, here is the place to correct it too.Better to come to this place on the weekend because the traffic around this place will be better, but anyway, inside the temple always clounded with the visitor.
Beautiful Buddha. This is a must see if you are in Thailand with one of the great treasures of the Buddhist world surrounded by fabulous architecture, history and ambience

Must see!. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the Grand Palace area were the highlight of my most recent to Bangkok. Anyone who has never seen this remarkable place should not miss it. Remember, dress appropriately or you won't be admitted.
Stunning. Again, one of the must do's whilst visiting Bangkok. Stunning building and architecture in amazing colours that takes your breath away.
Must see. Do not miss this temple and if you really want to appreciate your visit do not hesitatate to take a guide
Must do. This is a very impressive temple and the jade Buddha rather glorious to behold. However, it is very busy, so some patience is required. It is worth it!

If you visit Bangkok, this is part of your must itinerary. Awesome experience, let yourself inspire by the atmosphere and the respect Thais pay to this tiny statue placed high in the top of the Wat. Interesting and one of the most important for the people of this country, only the King can be part of the ceremony of the change of the clothes of this Buddha.

Yet another temple with a Buddha. There are very many temples here in Bangkok all featuring Buddha. This one was very busy on the day we chose to visit with many tourists and locals. I think it would have been a better experience if we had made our visit in the morning to avoid the crowd.

Fantastic. Fantastic and as expected - but huge crowds and not much opportunity to get close. We will visit in the off season next time as we are staying here a while. If you are on a short term visit Oct-Mar then try to get there early - before the hordes of tourists arrive in buses etc.

good story and much gold in nice location//. the tample in china town of Bangkok.it is recomended to strol .take public bus 73.
the tample has the Budha of 75 pure gold,many visitours coming.
Grand Palace. The Grand Palace was very beautiful! A little expensive to get in but definitely a must-do whilst in Bangkkok!
Worth a visit. A very beautiful Wat to visit, with sooo many gems, go early in the morning to avoid the heat, lots of hawkers there

Breathtaking. It is hard to describe the feel and the wonder of this place. It is a rather mystic experience. The beauty of the architecture is totally breathtaking. My group was in awe, after this experience. If you visit Bangkok, you owe it to yourself to see this marvel of Thailand.

Can give it a miss. We went in the afternoon and it was pretty packed at the time. Were stopped by security and had to purchase a shawl because one of us was wearing a sleeveless dress. It was strange as they were allowing some to pass right through but stopping the others. Lot of folks who didn't wear full jeans or pants were stopped as well.The architecture is pretty as usual and quite well maintained but overall, it was too crowded to genuinely enjoy the moment. The buddha statue itself was a let-down compared to the other statues I've seen in thailand.I actually liked the area outside the temple. It was pretty peaceful and there's a lot of vendors outside for some quick shopping and tasty bites.I suppose it would be better early morning.

Double check the opening times!. The Emerald Buddha sits in the complex of the Grand Palace. You need to be careful with the opening times, double check online because I think it's closed in the afternoon! We went at about 10am so it wasn't overly crowded! The Emerald Buddha is worth a visit, don't expect a huge Buddha but it is beautiful! The Buddha sits high in the room and looks small! However it is solid jade!
Secret Buddha. Supposed to be most secret Buddhist temple in Thailand, it is definitely divine. The temple is beautiful & the main statue of Buddha, also called the Emerald Buddha is amazing.

do not listen to cheaters outside the temple. A must visit. Many cheaters will be sitting outside the temple and telling tourists all nonsense. Do not listen to them at all. Keep ur ears closed and move to the temple main gate. U have to wear something which covers ur body in order to enter the temple.

Another Buddha depiction in Bagkok.. The Buddha is smaller then we imagined. It's very nice, not a long time to spend here. Nothing else to see besides the small Buddha. Ladies must wear long pants or long skirts and shirts with sleeves. Shoes are always removed before entering the room that contains the Buddha.

#1 must see in Bangkok. Part of the grand palace and houses the emerald buddah. You need to take your shoes off to enter and very crowded. Watch for pickpockets. No photos but you can sneak one if you want. Be respectful of those people who are there to pray. The actual emerald buddah is tiny but sits on top of a MASSIVE (40-50 feet high) pile of gold items.

On top of the list of places to visit.. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is located within the grounds of the Royal Palace and is a must see when visiting Bangkok. Do not expect a tall or large Buddha. It is actually tiny but highly revered hence its fame. You are likely to queue up and will have little time to admire the Jade statue. Taking photos is forbidden but from outside, with a long lens you will be able to take a shot.

Experience Peace and divinity. Emerald Buddha temple is huge and impressive, once inside Buddha is seated in a high pedestal showering his blessings, we were told that Buddha will be dressed according to the season. Temple is located inside the palace complex.
One of Many Nice Sites. A little steep climb, but worth the visit. Area around is nothing special. Short walk from bus parking, saw during escorted tour.

Overcrowded and overrated.. I did not expect this place to be teeming with visitors. It was difficult to find a spot to have a photo opp without people photobombing. The system is, you buy separate tickets to see the temple and the grand palace which are essentially juxtaposed. In a way it is overpriced. I suggest you come in the morning to avoid the crowd. Since this temple is just across the strewt from Wat Pho, you need to pace your visit accordingly to make time for both while avoiding the crowd. Bring suncreen 'coz you'll be out in the sun for at least an hour.

Great place to visit. We hired a tour guide from outside the entrance and she was brilliant. Full of interesting facts and something's we would have walked past if she had not pointed them out so we would definitely recommend getting a tour guide but do haggle the price as the cost to get in is a bit more expensive than other places.

This is one you can't miss in Bangkok. Yes, it's expensive. Yes, it's crowded with tourists, and yes, it's pretty hot and uncomfortable because you have to wear long pants to go inside the temple. But is it all worth it? Another 3 times yes. It's really beautiful and you'll learn a lot about Thai history!
