Manage your expectations. Everything about this place is big and ornate, but the Buddah is much smaller than you might imagine...but it's still impressive

Worth a trip to see. It was really hot when we went and not much shade so be sure to dress in conservative layers, (no shorts or sleeveless, but you can borrow clothing at the temple entrance like sarongs to tie or drape around you). We forewent a guide opting instead to take it slow and use our Lonely Planet guide to learn. This had a lost a few times, but there's a lot of interesting nooks to look around in, so I'm glad we did. The Emerald Buddha is amazing. Be sure to take the time to take your shoes off and enter the Temple. We sat there for a few minutes and kept discovering new wonderful pieces in the shrine. There's refreshments and souvenirs on site, as well as a post office and money changer. I can't vouch for the rates since we didn't use them, but I thought it was helpful to know. Be sure to get their early to avoid the heat and crowds.

Must-do in Bangkok. This temple is part of the grand palace complex and houses one of the most majestic statues of Buddha, carved in emerald. Even though the place is really crowded, it was peaceful and serene inside the temple and one could sit here in peace. The attractions surrounding the temple are all photo-worthy attractions with loads of history. A must visit.

Pricey but worth it. One word to describe Wat Phra Kaew, magnificent. Wat Phra Kaew is a great tourist attraction or place to worship Buddha, most of the architecture are covered in shiny gold and marble rich in old Bangkok style, also there's scene of Buddhist cosmology depicted on mural painting. Recommended lenght of visit is around 2-3 hours since the complex are huge enough, make it a must to take pictures or selfies.On the other hand, admission fee is 500 Baht for foreigner included Grand Palace and Vimanmek Mansion (the Vimanmek Mansion itself is too far away from Wat Phra Kaew and Grand Palace complex), which is too pricey if you compare it to similiar temples which cost you just 20-100 Baht or even free. So, multiple visit to Wat Phra Kaew is not recommended.Don't forget to dress appropriately when entering the temple, no shorts above the knee level and no sleeveless shirts. Prepare a lot of bottled water as you gonna deal with hot weather.
Must visit. If you are in Bangkok of course you must visit the tempel. It is definetly worth a visit. But a lot of tourist will be there all year round
Unique!!!! Must See. One of big and unique area full of attraction in each cornerThe way of the temple and the statue with many beautiful color
Stunning. Stunning - a must see - go early in the morning and make sure to have your legs and shoulders fully covered

Emerald Buddha- A must see !. An absolute must see temple, which is usually not included in the itinerary made by travel agencies. The Emerald Buddha is actually made of Jade, but looks awesome anyway, so go ahead and see it to believe it!

A Fantastic Experience. This was a special experience. It was beautiful. There is alot of history with the emerald Buddha. I learned that the King used to change the gold covering on the Buddha several times a year, however he currently does not. I highly recommend this.

Nirvana (disambiguation). See my review of Wat PhoFelt at peace here in the middle of a busy city an oasis of serenityRemember that foreigners pay more than Thai nationals to visit here and every other attraction in Thailand

Glowing in Green. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha, is all about opulence. Glowing in gold and green, it lets you step out of our mundane lives into a time and place which was grand and golden. the umbrellas are a recurring object in most Buddhist temples but the mirrors throw light on the growing Chinese influence. Take time to visit the museum next to it to understand the restoration process.

Don't forget to remove your shoes before entering!. A beautiful place to visit! I was so excited about getting in to see the Emerald Buddha that I forgot to remove my shoes before entering. I immediately noticed the stares of disapproval, and before long I realized the reason for the stares when a staff member came by to let me know that I needed to take my shoes outside.
Well worth a visit.. Beautiful temple, well worth a visit. This temple is great for photographs and there are other temples close by to see as well.
Amazing temple. This temple is found inside the Grand Palace compound and is one of the best made temples that you will see in the grounds.
Beautiful.. It is a landmark that is truly beautiful in such a dirty city. People are friendly and you might even meet a few monks.
Worth the Trip.. This was ok to see. Forget about taking pictures. The Emerald Buddha is covered in robes so it is hard to see the greatness of the Emerald. It's worth the trip.

Fabulous Temple. Our family visited this historic spot. It was very crowded, but they are very organized in getting everyone in and out, in an orderly fashion. Probably in other reviews here, but I do want to mention that women and men must have their legs covered to enter. We didn't realize this (Iots of jet lag...), so we purchased some skirts/pants just outside the gates for a very minimal price.
Beautiful place. Serene.... only when you close your eyes.... Sorry this is another tourist hotspot and if travelling with young kids you will have to be EXTREMELY careful.
Exquisite. This is the best representation of experience Thai art and culture. Just don't go on 1 Jan, this is all packed up for the whole Bangkok locals to wish for good luck.

Magical . It was one of the best experiences ever. I loved every minutes especially the museum, when you are there make sure to watch the videos when you don't have a tour guide it puts everything in context.

Picturesque and grand. The temple premises and the royal palace are picturesque and grand. You can go click click at this place providing one of best photographs. Carry lot of water on hot sunny day..

Another great Buddha. This is another fantastic temple to visit The jade Buddha is carved out of a single block and is wonderful to beholdAnother of Bangkok's spiritual places hope you are not to templed out and still have time to see this marvellous example of Buddhist art and worship

Don't worry about the crowds - it's worth the visit.. The day we visited this temple if was extremely busy but all the staff were still good tempered and helpful. It is a wonderful site, so be prepared to take loads of photos! Photos are not permitted inside the actual temple housing the Emerald Buddha but that's not a problem - there are lots of excellent guide books available at very cheap prices. You can even get cold towels, which are much appreciated if you are not used to the humidity.ONE WARNING - the ferry stop near the temple has one of the 'local attractions' you want to avoid. A smartly dressed middle-aged man complete w/ briefcase and 'Tourist Police' badge (which was flashed very quickly) approached us as we left the ferry and warned us to be careful of pick-pockets, etc. He then produced a map and gave us directions to the temple but told us it wasn't open for another couple of hours and suggested another place to visit. At this point a local young lady who had just left the ferry told us not to take any notice of what he was saying, that he was known in the area as a fraud (as was his Tourist Police badge) and he would just try to get us to the other attraction - probably a shop owned by him or his family. Not surprisingly he disappeared very quickly but was still hanging around the ferry waiting area when we returned several hours later. Be careful!
Green Light !. Not the Biggest in size, but one of the most revered Images of teh Buddha in Thailand. It is made of jade rather than emerald I have been told
Great Temple. Thanks for that opportunity to visit Bangkok and be here. It's lifetime experience here. Took memorable photos
Excellent. Very nice temple to see with many respect to buddhist traditions, this tempe is very big and need 3/4 hours for visiting

Absolutely amazing!!!. Amazing and sacred!!! It was a mind blowing visiting the Temple of the Emerald Buddha! It is an amazing venue and you feel very spiritual and involved with the Thai culture. Amazing friendly people and one of my favourite places to visit!
great place. very pleasant and worth visiting. the surroundings itself are divine and peaceful to just take a walk around the place

Beautiful. These famous temples in Bangkok are always crowded and although you cannot take photos inside, our guide was able to take a photo of us from outside with the little emerald Buddha in the background. Always a calming experience to visit a Buddhist temple and the Emerald Buddha although quite small is very beautiful.
great visit must seen. very fantastic visit must be seen , the best temple for budda in Thailand , u can take a lot of great photos there

Wish the Buddha figurine was bigger. Nonetheless a good wat (temple) to visit. Impressive in its own right. However, the Buddha's figurine is rather small and too far away for proper viewing while photography is not allowed inside. The usual temple protocol applies if you want to go inside the temple.

Worth visiting at least once. A fairly large complex close to the adjoining Wat Pho. There were many Chinese tourists when we visited, so I wasn't sure how to feel about that. The taxi driver did a very strange thing when he dropped us off next to them scammy tuk tuks who told us that the place was closed, but the gate was just a few steps away. There is an amulet flea market just behind the palace which you can visit just for kicks.
Simply Stunning. the grandeur and beauty of this place was simply stunning. Learning the history and origin was very interesting.

Awesome... Breath-Taking... Simply A Must!. You can find this temple within the grounds of the Royal Palace. Amazing venture! You will be doing a lot of walking so get ready. The splendor of the buildings, paintings, statues, will awe you.The murals on the grounds are fascinating depicting the story of Ramayana. There is also a miniature sculpture of the Angkor Wat (Cambodia) Temple in there. The highlight of course is the Buddha built entirely of Emerald... and thus the name.Simply a must if you are in Bangkok!
Beautiful little Buddha. One of the highlights of our trip! Just disappointed that we couldn't take more photos and there was no explanation as to why.Go early to avoid the queues!

Open everyday. Don't fall for the scams.. I am a Trip-Advisor junkie. so had read about the 'scams' folks do. The area is CRAWLING with scammers. We took the tourist ferry from the skytrain, (Really easy)and as we turned the corner a 'volunteer' was there to 'help us out'. My husband was in long shorts and he explained that he couldn't go in. He also said today was a Buddist holiday, so we couldn't go in until 1:00. He would however, recommend we went to see the Big Buddha. He chatted us up for a while and I said I just wanted to walk by anyway. My husband, who had been a cop for 25 years, didn't even realize we were being scammed! All that being said, it was a beautiful place. If you are not dressed appropriately, you can rent cloths. My husband had to pay 20 baht for a pair of loose pants, he got his deposit back when the pants were returned. No where else in Thailand did we encounter that. Women always have to have their shoulders and knees covered. It's a shame this beautiful day was marred by scammers all around.
Great tour to add to your Bangkok experience. Very interesting tour, the grandeur of the buildings is truly amazing and should be experienced by all in the area

Amazing stones. This is an amazing Buddha to see. The jewels are unbelievable. . It is hard to believe that so much wealth is put into these buddhas It is definitely worthwhile to take this in on your trip.

breathtaking architecture. It was a Tuesday when we visited the temple. It's closed on Mondays. We were there quite early as the temple shuts at 3pm. It was rainy day and humid as well. Seeing is beliving and you have to take your time to soak up the architecture and ancient drawings. The drawings had lots of stories to tell. It would be best to read up and have an overview before visiting this temple. Worth a visit.Avoid local school holiday term...

A beautiful place, also crowded!. It shows a collection of South-Asian arts, so I recommend to spend a few hours there.But be aware of SCAMMERS! Outside temple is full of people that even show you the wrong way for tickets! Just ask officials, go inside and buy tickets (500bht / adult)! DRESS PROPERLY! long pants for men and covered shoulders for women, even scarf on shoulders is not acceptable. Although both of them are easy to rent inside by 200bht deposit.

Best of the best attractions of Thailand. Nothing else to say but you MUST VISIT if you come to Bangkok. 500thb fee entrance is nothing if you see inside building. Thai ancestors had done great jobs for this. Specially it was the main temple for the royal family so it is so incredible.
Too many people inside. It was lovely but there were to omany people inside. I could not really engage in the details because of the incoming and outgoing people. It was worth visiting anyway! :-)
Fantastic Temple. Any person coming to BKK must visit ... this temple is really fantastic . Try to don't visit at Saturday or Sunday because its to full .

Huge place! Make sure you have time on your hands to visit this temple. The only disappointment I had from visiting the temple of the Emerald Buddha was size of the statue - I was expecting it to be bigger after having heard so much about it.But what the statue lacked in size, it made up in beauty - although the statue is placed little far from where visitors are expected to sit, its sheer beauty is still apparent and it is a joy to watch.The entire campus is huge and one needs good amount of time to see everything this place has to offer. I especially liked the model of Angkor Wat which is on display here.

Just beautiful and peaceful!. Just a beautiful and peaceful place where you can forget everything that's on your mind and just concentrate on your thoughts. The only downside... I thought it would be bigger :)

Lovely but very crowded, go early in the morning. This site is included on the tour of the Grand Palace and very popular. It is stop #10 and very popular with all the visitors. To go into the temple you must remove your shoes so you might like to wear socks for this purpose and don't wear your most expensive shoes as they might be missing when you come back. I found the crowds so large I chose to observe through the door and it was lovely. My guide showed me around so I could see everything and not get lost in the shuffle. I chose a personal tour guide for this day to do all the big things in Bangkok especially the temples and the palace. Because of the heat I was very glad I did, having an air conditioned car waiting between each tour was great.
Lovely. Love, love, love the Emerald Buddha! This was one of my favourite sites to visit in Bangkok. The architecture and decor in the temple is beautiful

Amazing. Don't miss it.. Exquisite cultural experience. Busy but special at the same time.Mind you don't point your feert towards the importanht little guy on the top of the altar. Do take time to observe with all five senses everything that is going on around you. The incense, the monks, the weird behaviour of fellow tourists. A very Thai place. There were lots of tourists there when we went and the sun-baked concrete burnt our stockinged feet, but we wouldn't have missed it for anything.

Part of larger complex. As part of the grand palace this is the highlite of the visit to the palace. Especially in the weekend as the complex is open but most buildings are closed. So be aware.... And you really can only go in once on a ticket...

Wat Phra Kaew. Amazing the temple inside. See decorations and details inside and outside temple.Ask to your guide or buy book that describe it very well, because there are a lot of details and stuff that need to be known.
Small But Beautiful!!!. You will be awestruck when you enter this temple and see the Emerald Buddha on the top. Place is soooo rich and beautifully carved.
One time visit. A very good Buddha temple, with different statues and plenty of space. Inner peace can be felt inside it.

Definitely worth a visit!. Another sight that must not be missed! The crowds can be daunting, but it's certainly worth paying a visit to Wat Phra Kaew, whether you're Buddhist or not. The statue itself is made of jade (NOT emerald) and it's rather small in size. You'll have to remove your shoes before entering the temple and no photographs are allowed inside.

Good for a half-day.. We initially planned for 3 temples, but this one place itself took half day. the more time you spend inside, the more awesomeness you will feel. Emerald Buddha temple is only 10% of the whole place, there is much more to explore and enjoy. When you fining seeing everything, you will land no a small eat-out place with short-eats, ice creams, beers and drinks..
Don't miss this. You can't go to Thailand and miss this amazing place. Set in an array of places, the emerald buddha is beautiful.

Lion's Sisiters Club Member visit !. Temple of the Emerald Budda is very good Buddha . You can prayed and wish what you can achieve in good course ! I have visit there with my Royal family friend there , with over 10 of my Lion's friends there . I can felt the Emerald is very spiritual Buddha ! There are thousands of thousands of visitors there ! On the day when we visit there we also met the King of Thailand near the temple ! I have shake hands with the King and Queen they and welcome us to be in Thailand for the visit ! Really that was our lucky trip !

A must see place in Bangkok. It's best to go by 0900hrs and be there by the time they open the gate, as towards mid morning its gets really crowded. We went in early and came out early, so we had time to do other sightseeing during the day.Do wear clothes covering your shoulders and knees, and be respectful as it's a religious place and important to Thais. Its best to have a guided tour, otherwise you need to follow signs to enter into various buildings. A must see place in Thailand, beautiful architecture and history.

Emerald Buddha.. after a long lond walk,we entered this awesome temple.The Main deity here is the Emerald Buddha who is sitting peacefull atop a pillar.just an awesome sight and innumerable people queuing up to see this wonderful Buddha.a must see,must visit on every traveller's list.there is a fee and dress code to visit this place.
Amazing. As a regular visitor to Thailand we have seen many monuments this is one of may favourites (the big buddah is the other) the sheer size is amazing.
Wonderful place to visit. Very beautiful and wonderful place to visit. Recommend everyone visit and take time with this place when you come to Bangkok, THAILAND.

dont miss it. spend some time in here and it will totally chill you out. its lovely. remember to remove your shoes and don't point your feet at the Buddha or point your fingers at anyone. that's a no no. you may see some of the monks milling around in their orange robes. they're not allowed to touch women so don't try to shake their hand or give them anything. it has to be passed to a man who will pass it to the monk. its polite to bow and greet with a smile but not necessary, just kind and mannerly. also just in general.

Stunning.... It is stunning and can get crowded. It is mandatory to cover up for both males and females, therefore shorts etc will not work. You can get clothes to cover up against a deposit though. There is no flash photography allowed inside the temple, because of the fear of damaging the statue. The statue has four clothing, which are changed based on seasons, the rest of the clothes are in the Royal museum when not used.The ticket is separate from the Royal Palace ticket, but included in the price.
EMERALD BUDDHA. The architecture of this temple is spectacular. It is an amazing sight to see on a visit to Thailand, and I would definitely return.
Beautiful Temple and History. Highlight of the Grand Palace! Nice place to get out of the heat and taken in the gorgeous interior of the Wat!
A top Bangkok landmark. As one of Bangkok's most significant religious sites, this is not to be missed. Be sure not to take pictures! They will get mad at you - don't ask how I know.
nice visit. Very crowded with rude tours, but worth the effort to push through. Recommend a locale private guide.
Must see. Crowded, suggestive of a thousand colors and a thousand reflections, to visit with respect for believers.

Beautiful - totally worth the queue!. Beautiful temple, so much detail in both the exterior and interior, the whole area is wonderful! Beware there are a lot of tourists and can get very very hot in there! Must wear long trousers and covered shoulders (men AND women) though you can use sarongs provided by them for free. I would recommend taking your own stuff as the queue was massive when we went and you can just go in to the changing rooms if you want to change into your own clothes!

Stunning!. The temple of the Emerald (or Jade) Buddha is on the site of the Grand Palace and covered by the same ticket. There is no access to the Palace unless you have your shoulders and knees properly covered, male and female. They will loan you clothes to cover up against a deposit which you get back when you return the garments but there is often a long queue, so it is better to go prepared.The site itself is absolutely stunning and well worth seeing. It is indescribably beautiful but you should remember that it is also an active place of worship and should be respected.

Take note of signs !. We visited earlier today and it's fantastic only spoilt by stupid people taking photos and showing their feet to the Buddha, I am not religious but am respectfull of other religion but when it says no photography and how to sit in picture form only stupid people can't understand

Beautiful Temple within Grand Palace. A must see experience while in Bangkok. Located within the grounds of the Grand Palace, the Emerald Buddha is a very special sight to see and well worth the time and energy. I highly suggest getting a guided tour of the grounds as they can explain quickly and efficiently all the history and meanings behind each and every statue, temple, etc. Be sure to cover up appropriately or you will not be let in and be vary of crowds as it can get very busy during the day.
Emerald Buddha Temple. Did this as part of an excellent half day tour with Buffalo Tours, the Grand Palace & Temples tour. We had an excellent guide (Nora). His knowledge was excellent.

Fund raising area. There was so many areas to put some money with different prayer request such as future ,long life,good luck,to be rich and for the orphanage and so on.So come prepared for genorasity.

Amazing Architecture. The building and its contents were absolutely exquisite. Was not too busy when I was there, so it was easy to walk around and take in all there was to see. Definitely worth seeing at some point if you're in the area.
peaceful and tranquil. Very peaceful and calm place to visit whilst being able to experience Thai culture outside this temple you can get very nice coconut drinks which keep you cool in the heat!

Crowded but a BeaTiFuL Temple so well worth it!. If you could only visit one temple in Bangkok, go to this one!! It is well worth the 500 baht ticket as there is a lot to see and you also get to go into the Grand Palace. It is advisable to cover your shoulders and legs on the day you go here but if you forget, wrap around clothing is available for free if you leave a refundable deposit.

Such an Amazing Emerald Buddha..... First time seeing a emerald buddha. Visiting it early Aug in blazing sun, we were all sweaty. But, the view of the Emerald Buddha was so beautiful and felt spiritual that all the heat were forgotten.We just went in and sat there looking at Him for long minutes and prayed for all. It was a splendid moment...just to sit there and admire the beautiful Buddha.The architecture of the temple created such a calm feeling. Worth the visit to see the amazing Buddha crafted in one single emerald.

Crowded but gorgeos architecture. Didnt stay here long as there wasnt tonnes to do but was definitely worth the 30-40 minutes out of our day for the guide to drop us off here. Gorgeous architecture but a little too crowded really. Similar to most places in Bangkok, they need to watch tourism numbers, especially at the entrance so it is more controlled.
Must be in Bangkok. The admission fee to whole complex is quite high when you compare with others but is worth it. Unless it is not so crowdy. Try early morning or late afternoon.
must see in Bangkok. The admission fee to whole complex is quite high when you compare with others but is worth it. Unless it is not so crowdy. Try early morning or late afternoon.
crowded but you must visit. Wonderfull hundreds of buddhas. even crowded but you still must visit. This place really historical. So be sure you learning something from the guide. Bring water and hat.

Must see. Visited it in 2002 and even then it was a must see in Bangkok. Thailand consists of temples, but this is arguably the most beautiful one. If you haven't visited this, you haven't been to Bangkok.
please watch if you are a traveller seeking the thai culture. This is very near to Grand palace.The buddha changes the gold attire based on the season, viz. Hot Season, Cool Season and Rainy season

Not to miss. Impossible to visit Thailand and not see this place.Very busy and bustling. We had a local guide which made the experience much better as he could explain the history behind the building and murals.Be sure to dress respectfully when you visit. For ladies this means either loose-fitting trousers or a mid to long length dress or skirt, and make sure shoulders are covered.

Sticky hot, very crowded- but worth it!. Stunning and wonderfully ornate temples. Hundreds of Buddhas. Really, really crowded and exceptionally hot. Get there early to try to avoid the hoards. Take water and a hat. The sights are worth the discomfort!
Must visit WAT PHRA. religious gorgeousness and landmark of wat phra is the best, at reverside, easy to come in and out and learning something with a guide

Great. Recommend to take a guide as well so you get to know the history.It's very crowded but it's worth making a visit.It's an incredible place. A must visit for tourists visiting in Bangkok.Recommend to take water bottles with you as it's hot and crowded.

Fantastic, you must see it. A must see place,located within the Kings Palace, the whole palace is a must see, but ladies please observe that shoulders and legs and bare parts must be covered up, this is a mark of respect after all you would not enter a Church in a Bikini would you? Please also be reminded that The Far East have there own cultures and are not always willing to accomodate your dress codes.

Incredible Place To Visit.. A "must see" for any tourist to Bangkok!What an incredible place to see and experience how royalty lived many years ago. Such an awesome place to learn about the history of Thailand and its many kings.Be warned that it is the most popular tourist spot in Thailand. It is crowded EVERY DAY! Be patient and drink a lot of water.
Big golden pyramid, small Buda!. Inside of the Grand Palace, you can visit the Emerald Buda, It sits on a glass box on top of a big gonden pyramid like sanctuary! Beautiful! Very crouded! Shoes off!

Very beautiful. It's worth pushing through the crowds. This temple is absolutely amazing. Every part of the temple is covered with glitter and gold. The temple is a compound with walls and buildings in the middle. We spent over an hour here admiring the murals and fascinating workmanship. The main place of worship is the tallest building in the middle of the compound. You must take your shoes off to enter. No photography is allowed inside the main temple building. The ceiling and walls are covered with murals. The outer wall of the compound has a covered roof that goes all the way around the interior walls. It is open to the inner court of the temple grounds. The interior wall of the compound is completely covered with murals documenting the history of Thailand in the Asian style. The mural was painted about 80 years ago and much of it has been restored recently. We spent about 1/2 of our time on the temple grounds walking around looking at the murals. The rest of the time was spent taking pictures, admiring the statues and buildings in the middle of the compound and then going into the place of worship to watch the Buddhists worship and see the curious workmanship there. My wife and I wore shoes, pants and button up travel shirts. I would visit this location again in a few years if I went with friends that had never been.

overpriced and overcrowded. Overpriced to get into the grand palace grounds and ridiculously crowded. Your rushed in and rushed out and as I'm sure you will have read before you go there the emerald buddah is TINY. Having said that, would be a shame to come all this way and not see it, I guess they know that, which is why they charge so much.
Pilgrim to Emerald Buddha. You are not allowed to take pictures from inside, but certainly from outside. One of the best pilgrim attractions in Thailand.

Great!. We visited this today, and was in awe walking around the buildings and monuments. The emerald Buddha is only small but is housed in one of the big buildings which is lavishly decorated. No photos allowed inside so no picture of the emerald Buddha itself...This is part of the grand palace. You need to cover up your legs and arms to the elbow (short sleeve shirt/tshirt is okay), ladies can't just wear shawl - this is not allowed. It's 500 baht each to enter the grand palace grounds. It was supposedly closed this morning (told by several locals) due to protestors. Double check when you can and can't go in as sometimes it can be used solely by locals for praying.The emerald Buddha was lovely, and very lavishly set.
Beautiful Temple. The size of this place is increadable and the detail and colours of the temples and statues is just beautiful. Well worth a visit

Taste of Thailand. This was a great place to visit. Full of history and colour. Worth going with a tour to get the history. Very crowded, hat and water bottles good idea. Cant really visit Bangkok without seeing this.

Not to be missed. This temple is in the ground of the grand palace it is included in the entry fee to the Grand palace if you only have a short time in Bangkok you must visit the grand Palace and the Temple you can do it yourself its easy to get around taxi are very cheap

Very average sight for sure. It seems that the most reviewers leave comments about overall (not only Temple of the Emerald Buddha, which is only one of) the complex, which is indeed very nice. But if reviewing just Temple of the Emerald Buddha (which should be), it is indeed nothing special even compared with remaining complex structures. Very crowded, I would say too much too enjoy any sight inside as well. Photos are not allowed inside too. Be prepared to hear "keep moving, keep moving..."

Crowded Famous Temple. If you do a one day Bangkok guided tour, this temple will almost always be on that tour itinerary. Enjoy the beauty, beware the crowds. There are many interesting temples around Bangkok that are not so packed with tour groups.

Beautiful Emerald statue. This is a temple I wanted to visit for a long time, inside is beautiful, the all Emerald statue of Buddha is a must see, only thing I would have to say is that I expected the statue to be a little bigger.
Very busy but unique. Inside the grand palace the place is packed and it is very hot but I would not recommend missing it, the buddha itself is 30 centimeters but it is in a stunning place
Amazing Place. Not as spectacular as Wat Arun. But interesting. We visited in the year 2004, and 2006. Very quiet, and beautiful.
Worth the visit!. When visiting the grand palace make sure you visit the temple of the emerald (jade) buddha. It 's a lot smaller them a thought but it is beautifull!

Beautiful Wat Phra Kaew. Temple of the Emerald Budha is a marvel of Thai architecture and serenity. It is located in the beautidul a Grand a Palace complex and is one one the most sacred places in Thailand. To visit it , you must be properly dressed and proper respect is demanded. . A must visit and see especially for students of culture, reliegon and architecture

Awesome landmark. This is a really beautiful site and contains many history. Very educational. However, it cost quite expensive and it is always packed with tourists that may be frustrating if you are a person that loves to spend time understanding the history.

A must visit. Breathtaking and just mesmerized by the architecture and all the hall decorations around the temple. It is always packed with tourists as it is one of the highlights of a must visit place in Bangkok.Remember to wear long pants for both men and women (is a temple) cover up. Make sure you have your shades with you as it would be very hot going around the temple and respect those visitors who come to the temple to pray.
Space for meditation. This place is beautifully arranged one. We spend two hours in the place. Area is very net and clean. Area is provided for meditation.

amazing experience. last week was in Bangkok... one of the most amazing days there i spent at the Emerald Buddha.i really like that king of temple, i never saw before something like this.this is massive and very important for the culture of thailand.i loved this temple!! its big, there's lots to see, and beautiful thing to admire
Wow.... Wow,wow,wow. This is a must for people who like culture. Amazing architecture everywhere you look, quite overwhelming!!!

Interesting but crowds and heat do not help. So this is a highlight of Bangkok, but it is a MAJOR tourist attraction so to get a 5 point rating:1) Go early - ideally when it opens - it is cooler and less crowds2) Wear right clothes - we were told that trousers down to the ankle were OK, they are not. See enclosed picture of what not to wear. An Italian had a huge argument with one of the guards, but ended up with us queuing for 30 minutes to get appropriate attire3) Get to the audioguides fast. We spent the B200 on the audioguides, but they closed after us as they had run out of machines.Worth a visit - the Buddha is a bit disappointing, small and a long way away for non-Buddhists not really inspiring although the building is.

Amazing temples. Amazing temples, but the emerald Buddha itself doesn't worth, nothing special. You have to let your shoes outside the emerald Buddha temple with no surveillance, you cannot take them with you even if you carry them on your hands, try to put them inside your bag

Take time out to see it properly. This is a temple! MEN TAKE LONG PANTS, WOMEN COVER UP!! not realising men need to cover up here aswell. We have travelled to many countries so we usually know the drill, I was prepared to change to cover shoulders and legs but my husband did not bring trousers to wear so we had to wait in huge lines to rent long pants to cover him up, it is free but a deposit is held. The line is massive and in sweltering heat so be warned. wasted 1.5 hours aprox cause we did not do our homework! Aside from this it is a beautiful and wide spread collection of temples and gorgeous interesting buildings. Take plenty of water and snacks, water stations there did not taste filtered, the icecream/snack shops on sight are hugely expensive even by western standards. Leave enough time to see it all, this is not a place to quickly get around but worth it. Also be aware of people approaching you off River boats at pier. Very dodgy guys, one even showing us a Tourist Police badge??? warning us of pickpockets then trying to get us to go to another shop and temple in the opposite direction??!! Make sure you follow your own directions on the signs off the boat. Just be sensible about things over there.

Temple of the Emerald Buddha. This is very close to the Grand Palace and is easily done together. It is the greatest Thai temple and of great importance. It is not emerald but jade, just about 50 cm high. No one except the Thai king is allowed to touch it!

The highlight of visiting the Grand Palace. A remarkable building, both inside and out. The lavish decoration and presentation of the Emerald Buddha are stunning and worth the visit to the Grand Palace alone. After seeing this temple, all others in Thailand pale into insignificance.

Absolutely BREATHTAKING . I loved this temple! It's big, there's lots to see, and beautiful things to admire. I've never seen a temple that is so ornate and beautiful. Stunning!!
**Make sure you wear pants and cover your shoulders/upper arms or they will make you rent appropriate clothes before entering the temple!
Great place. Great place. Amazing detail in the architecture. Remember to cover your knees and shoulders... It's too hot for 2 layers of clothes if you have to borrow some to cover up...

Awe inspiring.. I'm not a very religious person but this temple had a feeling about it. Just awe inspiring.
Must go and look. It's not huge but it's beautiful to see, unfortunately you can't take pictures so store that in mind.
Cheers.

Expensive yet Amazing. Entrance fee is expensive but since you are already in Bangkok just visit this place. The temple is small but has good architectural design. This temple contains one of the most religious artifacts for Thai people.

Breath taking settings. An awesome sight, temple with emerald Buddha.Popular tourist place,avoid weekends. Gardens of the temple perfectly manicured. The art work of the temple is breath taking. Ticket price is expensive for foreigners.

Amazed. Located inside the grand palace.
This is the original emerald Buddha.
Can't take photo inside but the building design amazed me

Nice but Crowded in the afternoon. Full of history. VERY CROWDED in the afternoon. I suggest you go early in the morning to beat the tours. Pay for your ticket at the entrance after passing security. Almost got conned into buying an over priced ticket from some random guy near the security line.

Beautiful!. before even setting foot into the Grand Palacet, this was one of our "must do" attractions in Bangkok. We weren't disappointed - it is stunning. However, the site was very busy and patience is needed to wait for the best view. It's worth noting that photography isn't allowed and we wanted to capture the memory so bought a postcard. Refreshments are on sale within the grounds but there are water fountains for a quick drink. I forgot to pack my hat and the sun was blisteringly hot! The admission cost iis relatively high so I'd recommend taking time to thoroughly enjoy the experience.

A must when in the city. Be prepared to with water and a parasol/hat/shade as it is hot here but definitely well worth the visit, it is the best example of Thai temple and leaves you feeling calm and cleansed.

Amazing detail. Spent a long time admiring all the work that must have gone Into making all the decorations on the buildings.
Not that there are free guided tours in English inside at a certain schedule, so you can avoid paying someone from outside.
Wonderful. Very beautiful temple with emerald Buddha. Popular place among tourist. Gardens of the temple also very nice.

Tour guide is needed!. Should be a lovely place who those temple/ architecture freak. Too bad you will need to bear with hot sun and the risk of getting sunburn. Don't choose to go on weekend as you will see crowds and umbrellas more than building! Would choose to go back again with a local tour guide that can explain the story behind every artifact, building, temple and etc.!
A must visit temple once in a life time.. No need to say, Wat Pra Keo is a-must-place to visit even though the entry ticket to foreigner is quite high. You should take an umbrella or hat to visit.
Landmark. The landmark of Bangkok, or whole Thailand. Most popular place. You must visit here, and thankfully, the entrance fee is not that expensive.

MUST VISIT. MUST VISIT IF IN BANGKOK. You can't say you've been to BKK unless you've been here. Yes the entrance fee of 500Baht is expensive but your trip to Bangkok or Thailand is a waste if you dont come here...

The Emerald Buddha. The Emerald Buddha is carved out of a solid stone. He has solid gold clothing for each season. The beauty of the temple and the respect that they show the Buddha is awesome. The art work of the temple is breath taking in its beauty. The fresh flowers are fragrant and transport you to a different time.

It was a beautiful temple with lots to see. It was a beautiful temple with lots to see. There was a very large military presence that was a bit disconcerting. It was a great experience, in spite of the overwhelming crowds
it was very beautiful temple.. It was very wonderful temple and, it was very clean.i like this temple so much.if i have a free time ,i will go back again.

Ornate and beautiful (and ignore anyone who tells you it's closed). This is housed within the Grand Palace grounds and never mind the scamsters who tell you that it's closed -- we were aware of the scam situation and STILL fell prey to this. Thankfully, we realized the trap after a 5-Baht tuk tuk ride. We used a map and did a U turn to come back to the place. On the way, we met more of these guys -- one of whom posed to be a science teacher from a nearby school. Stick to a fabricated story of wanting to go for lunch at a predetermined place and walk away.The temple itself is a picture of serenity. You can pray in a little area reserved for the visitors. We spent a few minutes here to take in the serenity.
Don;t miss this!. This is a can't miss site. So opulent and stunning. Take water with you. It's hot and not many places to get water.

Beautiful and Packed Full of People. I planned to go to this place right when it opened but accidentally overslept and ended up there around 10. It was already full of people and I got pretty overwhelmed very quickly. It was an overcast day thank goodness, but even with tolerable humidity and cloudy skies I started sweating immediately. It was hard to enjoy the beauty of the place with so many people there focused more on getting the perfect selfie and less on the gorgeous surroundings around us. I also went on a weekend so that probably contributed to the crowds. I suggest you get there early!Tip: regarding attire for this visit, you should definitely wear clothing that covers below the knee. Most tops with sleeves were ok, no need to wear clothing to the elbows. And despite the concierge at my hotel being concerned about my sandals they were fine. Note to women, just covering your shoulders with a shawl won't fly here you need to have a proper shirt to pass inspection.

Breathtaking Buddha Temple !!!. Its a beautiful Buddha Temple located in the heart of the city close to many more temples. It is rich in local cultural and religious value. Must visit place in Bangkok.

Beautiful. This is another beautiful temple of the Grand Palace. One you cannot miss despite the fee, the crowd etc The buddha is so beautiful, it is breathtaking, it's like its power blows you away !
nice place. good place to roam around and marvel the detailing on the wall and the terrace . Nice compound where you can see multiple other statues

Mesmerizing - bring water. The level of detail in the design and architecture of the temple is quite mind-boggling. Tips:Make sure you are wearing comfortable shoes and water because you will be doing a whole lot of walking in a blistering heat. Make sure to bring pants that wholly cover your legs as required by the culture (hence why if you see closer in the photos, you won't be able to see anyone wearing shorts!). If you don't have anything then don't worry! You can rent a pair of comfortable leg covers right at the entrance for a small fee, there are many individual vendors available.

Spectacular, but very crowded and expensive. The temple and the palace are really spectacular. However, the entrance fee is very high, and it is far too crowded to really enjoy the beaty of this place.

Crowded but really worth it. Well, maybe you are an european and don't much about the culture, cause that was the case for me, and as I was reading some guides and wikis about the culture, religion and people of Thailand the visit to Wat Phra Kaew proved rewarding. I was able to take pictures outside the temple, while inside the actual temple where Emerald Buddha is you, it is forbidden. It is about the culture and it is a sign of respect for them. You have plenty of places outside to do that. It was a bit crowded but ok.

Beautiful and Breathtaking temple at Grand Palace. Try to get there as early in the day as possible! It gets very crowded and very hot! Emerald Buddha is part of the Grand Palace complex, which cost us 500 baht per person to enter. You need to dress appropriately to enter, which means no shorts or short skirts, covering your knees/shins, shoulders, chest and mid-section. I would also recommend slip-on shoes since you need to remove them before entering any temples. The temple is beautiful with amazing intricate details - the entire grounds feel very peaceful and breathtaking, so take your time and enjoy it. But please be respectful of their culture. Don't point your feet to Buddha or turn your back to him. These are important religious grounds for the Thai people. Check out the rest of my blog about our trip including our tips for traveling in Bangkok. http://www.kandradventures.com/k-and-r-adventure-four-nights-in-bangkok/

Real Emerald Buddha. I came here about 5 years ago. It was relatively empty then. When I came back to visit it again this year, this time with my son, the entire place was filled with tourists! It was very hard to take good photos of anything when there were so many people around. It was so hot and crowded and the entrance fee was quite high so I really don't think it was worth the trip this time.
thank you. This was lovely and not crowed when we went which was early for Thailand at 10 in the morning. Lovely worth a visit

EMERALD BUDDHA. The history at the Palace is just unbelievable it is absolutely a must see do not miss place to visit, I was so taken with how the Emerald Buddha has a change of attire for each season - it is steeped in Thai History and a really worthwhile place to see

The Emerald Buddha. Apart from the heat and the crowds I enjoyed my full day trip here with other sights. Dont take pictures inside as it clearly states but I saw a few tourists get in trouble and were told to delete their pics. No respect really. But I love the Thai people and their culture such friendly and humble people.

stunning!. we went close to noon so it was super crowded and expertly hot. lots of tourists came in group and blocked the entrance. the ticket price raised rapidly within a couple of years and it's now 500B (free for local Thai people). which I think just too high. But the buildings-selves were stunning. It's worth going at least once if you visit Bangkok.

No doubt to be the most beautiful temple in Thailand. . Ok, I've seen temple in my 20 years in Thailand. I never went to the grand palace and then I decided to go with my mother as she was visiting, to the wat pra kaew. I've seen really exquisite temple in the north being build and the inside decorAtion was taking so meticulously that when I went to the emerald Buddha, I could imagine it when it was on its building period. Once again the craft employed to create such stunning structure from the tip of its roof to the bottom step of the stair. If you sit and look closely and calmly you will notice all the details. The best to appreciate this place is to seat and relax on your own or silently, and appreciate what it's been given to you.

Beautifully mmajestic. Go early in the day, before the heat, but be aware that it is always very crowded. Cover shoulder, no shorts, no mini skirts. Be modestly dressed to be respectful. Difficult to get photos without lots of people in your shot.

Peaceful and Breathtaking. Not only you will feel a little smaller in this temple you will also feel better and in peace with your inner self. Although this is a touristic area, this is a very good place to relax and have your moment. Enjoy it!
Photo opportunity. Get there when it opens to avoid crowds. Not that is overly busy later, but it is nice to not be crowded in the heat. Ensure you wear smart clothes, no t shirts.

Stunning!. Included as part of organised Kuoni trip with Nina(rep from Banyan Tree). As we were only couple on tour, it was a very personalised tour at a leisurely pace, which we needed in the high temperatures.

great temple. The Buddha image is made of a semi-precious green stone,[1] described variously as jade or jasper rather than emerald,[3][11] as "emerald" here refers to its colour rather than the stone.[12] The image has not been analyze to assess its exact composition or origin.The figure is 19 inches (48 cm) wide at the lap, and 26 inches (66 cm) high.[4] The Buddha is in a seated position, with the right leg resting on the left one, a style that suggest it might have been carved in the late Chiangsaen or Chiangmai school, not much earlier than the fifteenth century A.D. However,the meditation pose of the statue was not popular in Thailand but looks very much like some of the Buddha images of Southern India and Sri Lanka, which led some to suggest its origin in India or Sri Lanka

High recommended. The Grand Palace is beautiful, also very beautiful the temple where the Emerald Buddha is. Little disappointment for the size and the distance where the buda is. Although generally highly recommended a visit to the great palace.

Emerald Buddha Tour. This was part of our family tour of Bangkok and although the Temple was impressive it was extremely busy (and hot) to say the least. Tour guide excellent but crowd spoilt it somewhat.
In short take some advice on best time to visit if possible.

Thai culture at its best!!. This is one of the most amazing places I have seen, in Thailand and in the world. This temple is rich, rich in details, rich in uniqueness, rich in treasures....the architecture, the statues, the details, and above all: the hundreds of mts of wall covered with the most amazing paintings! The place is worth the crowd, the sweat, the patience you will need to have....the reward in culture and impressions is in my opinion very unique!Don't miss it!

Amazing Experience A Must See. Amazing experience, a must see, we loved exploring the Temple, the building is so intricate and fine detail absolutely awe inspiring.We went Saturday and was very busy, may not be the best day to visit??

So overcrowded it was thoroughly unpleasant!. We queued for half an hour just to get a ticket and this was on our second attempt at visiting. I think it doesn't really matter what time you visit, it is so incredibly popular and rightly so.When we went through the whole Palace area, we were constantly jostled throughout the whole visit to see the Emerald Buddha which I particularly wanted to see. When we finally got there, it was spoilt by the pushing and shoving.I could not bear the crowds, so we simply left. I imagine it is a beautiful place, but with so many crowds it is simply impossible to appreciate. Hubby had visited 20 years ago and it had been empty and he'd wanted to share his experience. Lucky him! Not so lucky me!

A must see but not brilliant. I would say that this is a must see destination if you have not been to the city before however it is overcrowded and you feel rushed due to the herds of people clambering around the grounds. This seems to have lost its charm a little and it took us more time to get there than we actually spent at the site.

amazing temple in heart of the Palace complex. Queen sirikit's birthday was not the best time to visit! Scores of schoolchildren were waiting with flags, numerous limos brining dignitaries. Felt like a fish in a shoal of other fish as we swam through the gates at exactly 8.30. The Temple is beautifully intricate and the Buddha is perched high up, genuine emerald and about 3 foot high!
Emerald Buddha. This is where they keep the Emerald Buddha. There are Buddhists praying in the temple. This is within few steps from the Grand Palace.
Rich and serene Buddha. What a beautiful image of Buddha! Emerald gives it serene richness and depth. And the sanctity and aura of the image is unforgettable.

Nice temple, but very crowded. This is the most important temple in Thailand and is included in the Grand Palace compound. The emerald Buddha is very small, but due to its importance, I'd say it's worth a visit to see it. Don't forget to dress appropriately and leave your shoes outside!

Beautiful!. Beautiful!
If you have time for 1-2 attractions in Bangkok, this should be on the short list. I was especially taken by the murals (should've taken a guide to explain their story).
Cons - very expensive, the dress code is tough on a hot day, no shade.

Though expensive but worth seeing once. Once you get inside the temple it's very beautiful. Please carry your own umbrella,water,glares and wear light coloured clothes to avoid tan. I think it's crowded throughout the year.
We really liked it's architecture.

Unique beauty and art at his best!. Bangkok must visited place and there is a reason for it. It is just a unique place where words are never enough. Just find 3 hours to assimilate all the beauty of the place. Go by yourself and rent an audio set.

A must in your visit to Bangkok. Amazing temple full of color and different to the rest. The garden is also incredible and you will feel that you are in another time.
It's a bit crowded but you have to find a way to feel the peace of this incredible place even though that you will be surrounded of people.

Very busy. This trip was spoilt by the crowds and the third world queueing system. It's very hot and thousands of people are trying to enter the temple. There is nothing you can do, but with young children it can be very distressing. Would I go again with young children? No, I would visit somewhere else where they could capture the same sort of historic and religious learning. We visited The a Grand Palace afterwards, and that was less crowded, still as hot, but a pleasure to walk around and learn its historic value. I must stress, however, if you are visiting without children, to see the Emerald Buddha, which is very small in comparison to the other Buddhas I've seen, is breathtaking. Take water! And an umbrella to shade you from the sun.

MUST GO. Where should I begin?VERY BEAUTIFUL!! The details, the architecture, everything is simple beautiful!I was not a fan of the crowd and the heat. But this place is a must go for tourist! You really have to see the details on those temples, I love how they shine under the lights. Too bad I couldn't catch it with my camera..

Overcrouwded places with Chinese tour buses, put trousers and coveryour shoulders and NO CREDIT CARDaccepted. Frankly' for 4 people, having cash of that amount for each entrance fee.... Credit card should be accepted. We quit to enter and visit the royal palace and emerald buddha..... after all hassles and wait. And enjoyed very much the nearby friend l'y and welcoming Wat Po.

Dont go during religious festivals or ceremonies. This temple is located within the Grand Palace complex. So dont go on week ends and try to be there early at the opening time.The emerald Buddha is actually not in emerald but in jade and was accidentally found in country side Thailand. It is worth a short stop and an offering.

Bleh!. Not the place it once used to be. If you are planning to go to worship- forget it! It's way too crowded, way too expensive to get in, and way too rude guards! Lots of rude groups of tourists from a certain large Asian country overtook the temple when we visited. Most horrible experience.

Small, Green and Similar to other Wats. The Emerald Budda is a small statue, I feel that I saw many statues of Budda and while pretty, you cant get close due to its position and there isn't the ability to see detail. After seeing one temple, others start to look very similar.

A must see.. As part of The Grand Palace, the Emerald Buddha was a high light. The architecture and story behind it all makes the visit worth while. Its not as big as you think though. Quick tip, don't queue inside for trousers to cover up. There are plenty of Hawkers outside that have pairs you can rent. Either that or just go in long trousers.
Best in the country. The BEST in the country , all arts around the area are amazing / wonderful with very well maintenance.

A must for every visitors to Thailand. Most sacred temple in Thailand. Very beautiful with Thai architect. A must see for all visitors to Thailand. Make sure you respect the 'no photograph' signs or your phone and camera might be confiscated. Ladies must wear long skirts to cover the knees and no sleeveless tops. Guys must wear long pants. There are vendors right outside of the temple who sell sarongs for reasonable prices. Please keep quiet when you walk around the temple and no climbing on any statues. You can be fined and jailed if you are not being respectful.

Detail detail detail . The temple of the Emerald Buddha was beautiful beyond words. Pictures do not give it justice, because you don't see how detailed the architectural structure is! It must've taken decades to build this phenominal temple.

Great but crowded!. The temple and the palace were great, clean and well organized. So many history and things to learn. Prepare 500 baht for entrance fee if you are non-Thai (free for Thais) and dress politely.Great and beautiful architecture, Buddha statues and painting but there were too many tourists , eps Chinese!!!
Spectacular. What an amazing place to visit. I certainly recommend it to anyone wanting to see a bit of the Thai culture. Would love to go back
Cultural Treat. To see such an impressive, religious icon at first hand is breathtaking. Although only 66 cm this beautiful statue of Lord Buddha is well worth seeing as indeed is the whole site.

Not to miss. A must see. But can get extremely busy as we found out which is not good on a humid day! we had to go twice as the emerald Buddha was closed for an official function. It is vast but beautiful. Lots of photo opportunities. Go early.
Solitude and peace. Great experience to be here, take off your chus and have a moment of peace and quiet to meditate. The little statue of the Buddha is beatiful.

love the history. is actually inside or next to the grand palace. Pls visit the museum/gallery to understand the history before entering the temple. You have to wear tops with sleeve & bottoms that cover your knees. And shoes are not allow if you want to enter the temple. Although they do provide some shoes racks (open type) for you to put your shoes, but I'll suggest don't wear expensive shoes because there are too many travellers or people there. Too many shoes...

Emerald Buddha is stunning. It will be crowded when you visit - visit anyway. It is inspiring to be part of a crowd of active worshipers.
The Emerald Buddha has a long history and is quite beautiful. Take the boat there and enjoy your experience.

Worth a visit. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is the most renowned temple in Thailand. It is situated in the Grand Palace compound. So you will also be visiting the Palace at the same time. There is an entrance fee for both together. Ticket cost is 500 Baht (over priced )One of the easiest way to reach it is to take a BTS Silom line to Sapan Taskin station and the exit will take you directly to Central Pier from where you can take a Orange flag boat to Pier N9 (fare 15 Baht per trip per person). Just walk of the pier and you will come to a cross road. Going straight along the white wall you from the junction will take you to Grand Palace.One of the easiest way to reach it is to take a BTS Silom line to Sapan Taskin station and the exit will take you directly to Central Pier from where you can take a Orange flag boat to Pier N9 (fare 15 Baht per trip per person). Just walk of the pier and you will come to a cross road. Going straight along the white wall you from the junction will take you to Grand Palace.DO NOT GET MISLEAD by self proclaimed English speaking guides or tuk tuk drivers who say the place is closed and will offer you a tour elsewhere. Another scam is that if you are not wearing the right attire. Your dress has to cover your knees and ladies will have to wear tops with sleeves. At the entrance they will provide with the proper attire FREE OF COST. Do not get mislead by some one from outside trying to sell you a dress to visit the palace.Palace is open from 8 a.m. Avoid week ends, we landed there in a week end and there was hardly any place for you to step without running into others. Also ideal will be to reach the place early as crowd builds up after eleven.If you want some one to explain take a guide who will charge you at least 100 or 200 Baht per hour but for just a visit follow the arrow marks.The temple itself is very good. The Buddha will be dressed as per the season - hot, rainy, or spring.

Emerald Buddha wears seasonal clothes^^. The Emerald Buddha is very very tiny, the interesting thing is people do dress the Emerald Buddha with seasonal clothes. I guess you will find it interesting^^ Remove your shoes and leave them outside before entering, so don't loss them!

Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Beautiful place to visit. There are a lot of tourist in the afternoon but it is quite worth the trip to see this enormous complex. Lots to see and bring your camera but cannot take pictures inside temple it self. Must take shoes off and wear appropriate clothing. A must see when in Bangkok.

An absolute MUST SEE if visiting Bangkok / Thailand. This is another of the MUST SEE spots for any visitor to Bangkok / Thailand. Beware and be aware that you must have proper attire to enter the Grand Palace / Wat Phra Kaew area: modest dress (below knee) / skirt & blouse and collared shirt (long sleeve preferred) and pants (I don't think jeans are OK). BUT all the dress up is worth it. Though the actually Emerald Buddha is not very large, the structure and facility around it is amazing and what it represents to the people of Thailand also makes it a MUST SEE as it will give you something to talk about to every Thai person you meet.
Cool Buddha. We ended up here after falling for a Tuk Tuk Scam, but glad we did as it was a very different Buddha and we wouldn't have seen it otherwise....

Spiritual and beautiful. Brilliant and amazing to see although may temples this was stunning but very busy. Worth a visit and seeing the monk and having a blessing was our highlight of the visit, truly beautiful.
Beautiful. Mesmerizing is all I can say... Don't miss the wall paintings they are fantastic too!, I enjoyed every moment there.

Must see place in Bangkok but way too crowded.. There should be a better entry system by not letting too many people in at the same time, otherwise, it will not only ruin the experience but it may also ruin the temple. For now, I would say avoid going there during Thai public holidays because there will be both Thai tourists and foreign tourists visiting the temple at the same time and it can get too busy and it is impossible to stop and enjoy the moment.
A must visit...... Temple of Buddha is amust visit for any visitor planning to visit bangkok it gives you immense peace from inside.
Basic tourist spot. It's part of things you need to have a look at while visiting Bangkok. Shows the culture and history of the city/ country
A must do in bangkok. Once you have seem a few buddha in Bangkok you have seen them all but the emerald Buddha is impressive

Amazing!. Truly amazing. Go with time, there's so much to see! Quick tip, while in Thailand make sure to cover your shoulders and nothing above your knee. It's always good to carry not only a scarf, some places like this one, demands you to have something with sleeves. They borrow at the entrance and you can also purchase if you forget. Respecting the local culture must be your top priority. Enjoy!

Temple of the emerald buddha. There are many, many temples in thailand in general and certainly in Bangkok. Nevertheless the temple of the emerald buddha is certainly worth the visit. If you travel by hop on hop off boat this is one of the places (out of quite a few) worthwhile to hop off for
Familly at Wat Phra. Nice but really overcrowded, make sure you all get trousers including men as they are really strict. kids under 120 cm enter for free. No credit card.
Interesting.. Although there are a lot of temples in Bangkok, I think this is one that you should visit. I thought the Emerald Buddha would be bigger.
Nice . Good one place for seeing in my life . Must visit once a time if u have time thanks u Wnt to go with separate as well as in group tour or sightseen tour.

Beautiful. You won't be allowed to enter unless you have proper dress code. No sleeveless and shorts. In the temple, u will be asked to remove shoes so bring socks if you are only wearing slippers. The emerald Buddha is just small but stunning but we're not allowed to take pictures.

A Wonder. If you wish to see what monumental buildings mean, this is a great to do that. Just make sure that you have enough time to visit all places. This is an incredible place and requires time to see!

It is what is says on the tin!. We went to see this whilst on the Grand Palace Tour as it was in the same grounds.You have to remove your shoes before going in.You are allowed to take photos from outside the temple but not inside.The Emerald Buddha is small in comparison to the temple which is impressive.

Must See!. Beware of scammers out front they are very convincing. Just go in. A very very hot day. Please bring water and a cooling towel like a frog toug. I could take enough photos. Amazing temples.
Ok. You already in the palace if you came to see this... it's nice but I think other temples have more to offer.
Fascinating. Just beautiful. Make sure you are wearing appropriate clothing, no bare shoulders or knees are allowed. Book a tour guide so that you understand the history, it really helps.

A beautiful Buddha. This is one of the most visited Budhha temple in central Bangkok. Best time to visit is before 10am as the place is not too crowded. Please remember to leave your shoes at the entrance and take off your hat when inside the temple. The emeral statue itself is quite small but beautifully made from a single block of emerald.
Royal. If you have free time in bangkok and like to visit places then visit this for sure. Those who just came for party , won't enjoy much.

Amazing temple. The temple is expansive, intricate and stunning, though it is crowded and absolutely roasting hot, and a little expensive it is beautiful. It is a must see if you go to Bangkok but wear or bring trousers to wear.

A must see. I definitely would come here early in the day as it gets very crowded. The emerald buddha is very small but beautiful. Besides the buddha there is a lot to see on the grounds so make sure that you explore them.

An Emerald Buddah. It's exactly what it says it is however were slightly taken back by the size of it as everything else is soooo big!!!
It is very busy so pick your time wisely

Bling to the max. We just visited the grand palace, and spend most of the time at the complex of the jade buddha. we spend like 2-3 hours at the buddha part and maybe an hour for the rest of the buildings (which makes the visit at 500 bhat pretty expensive comparatively to other thai stuff).. Basically the buildings are unlike anything we're used to, since well they are incredibly colourfull and shiny and vry, very intricately decorated everywhere. The buddha itself is, well actually pretty small, since it's made of a single jade stone. Small but very impressive. The part that we and especially my kids liked most was the mural all along the outer wall which we guess tells the (mythological) story of Thailand and its rulers. We didn't get an audio guide and apparantly there is no booklet for sale explaining it. Which we think is a greatly missed opportunity. But anything you spend more time on than you planned to must be a good thing.

a great experience. another of the things someone that visiting Bangkok must spare some time and see. it gets really busy so my advise is try to get a reputable local guide to do everything for you and save you time and frustration as believe you me you can get really frustrated with the amount of people visiting. and also he/she will be able to explain more things about the history of the place.

Quintessential historic Bangkok. Be here at 8:30 am before the tour busses flood hit this quintessential Bangkok location and disrupt the serenity and tranquility this location deserves. A must see for visitors.

Spectacular.. My friends advice was to go as early as possible. We arrived about 11am on a Friday and there were just too many people to even get to the ticket booth. I returned the next morning for the 8:30am opening. There were still crowds of people, but nothing like the day before. I've been to a number of temples around Asia, but this was definitely one of the most impressive. The detail was incredible. Each building was unique. Each painting was unique. Do make sure you are respectful of their rules. I saw a man begging a guard to return his phone as he was escorted out of the building for taking photos.The Emerald Buddha itself is quite small. As it's housed in such a spectacular room I at first didn't realise that I had seen it and walked around the complex looking for it. Another friend also thought she'd missed it, so it's possibly a common mistake.The fee of 500 baht is quite high, but includes entrance to the Grand Palace and, we found out later, Dusit Palace (definitely worth the visit) and probably some other places, but I didn't have time to see any more.

Magical Visit. It is a must to visit this temple if this is your first time in Bangkok. It is very historical and the temple design is beautiful. You get free cold ice water as well from the temple staff. Just respect the temple and don't take any photos inside
NOT TO BE MISSED. This is a wonderful experience and shows magnificence of Thia culture. you do not have to be Buddhist to appreciate the sights and scenery and all in the complex of the Grand palace
AMEZING!!. In Bangkok half day temple tour visit we can cover emerald Buddha.its beautiful & colorful.those who are visiting first time than its surprise for you !!!

Incredible architecture. Wat Phra Kaew is on the grounds of the Grand Palace in the ordination hall/ubosot. Appropriate clothing is enforced so be prepared. The mural paintings on the corridor walls depicts the classic story of Ramayana. Take the Chao Praya ferry boat to Maharaj Pier. More expensive than other Wats due to the Palace visit being included
lots to see and admire.. We visited with Tong tours, so our guide could explain the history, customs and beliefs. A beautiful temple with some incredible craftsmanship.
Top of our Must Do List. A must do whilst in Bangkok.Fantastic photo opportunities of ornate meticulously decorated temples that will amaze you.

Fantastic. Just fantastic!!! Be sure you have a full day to go around, it is not only this temple but you also visit another great palaces and monuments in the same visit. The Emerald Buddha temple and the Emerald Buddha itself are just astonishing! They wont let you in if you have shorts or girls are not "properly" dressed. It is a must see touristic complex in Bangkok.
free water. excellent. far better value then watt pho. small bottle of water included with entrance and fountains dotted around for refills
Little buddha. It s a part of the grand palace so is included in the ticket of 500thb. Nice and very little. You can't take photo bit with a good zoom from outside you can do it.

Great visit. I really like this temple, spent a lot of time there. I would say, don't get the audio guide, it is expensive in my opinion and with the map you are good enough (maps have explanations).. also, if you rent the audio guide, they give you 2h to do the whole visit (the temple + royal palace) so you can't really go at your pace. It is a great place to spend a lot of time there, but it get really hot, so bring water (and lots).You can't take pictures inside the chapel where the Emerald Buddha is, but everywhere else you can.
Bring your camera. Bring your camera and go crazy - A must while in Bangkok - Go very early to avoid crowds and plan on taking over 500 pictures if that's your thing.
Fascinating...... If ancient temples and architecture is what your looking for.... this will give you all that and much more... Extremely clean and well mantained..... this place is a must..

Amazing Experience - but sooo crowded. Located in the Grand Palace, the whole complex was an amazing array of temples and buildings surrounded by glorious statues and mural-ed walkways. Arrived in the morning and it was already filled to the brim with tourists and some of the Chinese groups were pretty distracting to put it politely.Be prepared to spend 3-4 hours looking around and it was very hot when I was there with little respite, so look out for the water stores and buy 2-3 bottles as they weren't easy to find.Got some amazing images and memories and very pleased I went. Big tip is to dress for the visit, wear long pants and a sleeved shirt - those who had to get clothes to cover up had a queue a mile long and they were forking out time and money for just being pretty ignorant.A must see with the Temple of the Reclining Buddha while in Bangkok.
Buddha. Many different Buddhas to be seen all with their own speciality , could not possibly see all of them.
Thumbs up. A spiritual location turned tourist destination. Worth a visit. Do spend some time in the area to visit the temples and try out local delicacies.
A great temple. Although Bangkok has many temples, I would recommend seeing if time permits. A great way to learn more about the culture and see the city.

Amazing. This is one of the most impressive and beautiful temples I have seen in Thailand. It is well worth the visit and the entrance fee to the complex. Of course, it is very busy, but if you only see one temple in Bangkok, try this one.

Very impressive. Visited early in the morning, we were 2nd in line to buy our ticket to enter the Royal Palace, where this is situated.We visited this temple first as we knew it get very busy and long queues form to go inside.Breath taking is the art work and the decoration of this temple.No photos are allowed inside this temple, a few monks were praying and we had room to walk about and absorb all the quiet, peaceful atmosphere, before all the crowds came.It is very hot in the grounds and no where to buy water , so bring some, and a fan!!The Buddha is a tiny emerald piece positioned high up in this very grand Temple, a must see.

The Hottest Day ever. The grand palace was the most absolutely stunning palace I visited when in Bangkok. The only sad thing was the amount of tourists present and the humidity was very uncomfortable. I can deal with a good amount of tourists, but it was very overwhelming with groups coming in by the bus load. Overall, the Grand Palace was worth the inconvenience
Busy. Part of a tour, this was the last temple we visited, very busy, so many people although we did go on a Sunday so not sure if this was why,
Underwhelming. Perhaps outsiders don't appreciate the significance of this "tiny" buddha. I would visit others if time is of the essence.

Real art. The temple is situated inside the Royal palace and you are overwhelmed by everything you see.
Taking photo is not permited inside but everything is real art: the temple, the exterior walls, the inside decoration and not the last the emerald Buddha.

Family visit in the Emerald Buddha temple. It is amazing temple! We found out that this temple is very important for local people. It was a great experience for us to see school girls singing there.All buildings and especially the Emerald Buddha building are very special. Although the Buddha is very small :-), but the perception from the place is grate!My children liked it very much. Worth time to visit it.

If anyone tells you that the temple is closed, don't believe them!. Beware of the tuk-tuk drivers who ask you to visit a giant Buddha image at another temple because they will take you to a FAKE jewelry shop nearby. The weather is usually quite hot, so you will need a fan, an umbrella, and a bottle of water.

Breath-taking Temple. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha was absolutely breath-taking! The details of the walls and the ceilings was stunning. I couldn't believe how much gold was in one place. I would definitely recommend coming here. There was also a very educational free guided tour that was available.
So overrun by tourists you can not enjoy it. An extreme number of people, pushing and shoving and carrying umbrellas to poke your eye out. and constantly taking selfies
Emerald Buddha. Went to visit this in 2010. Absolutely breathtaking. Stunningly beautiful. Make sure your dressed appropriately.

This place has to go on the Bangkok bucket list!!. You can say you've been to Bangkok without coming here, its an amazing place!! Puts any European royal palace to shame. But be wary of the local tuk tuk drivers, they'll stop and tell you its closed for a religious holiday and if you go with them they'll show you somewhere better. Thankfully we declined 2 very good offers and found the place to be open for business as usual. Be a religious temple rules of modesty apply so do cover up arms and legs, and that's for both sexes...

Wear long trousers....... Really busy and, even though we wore mid length trousers ( on a really hot day!), they were not deemed long enough so we needed to queue for the hire clothes which were even hotter and made our trip shorter than it may have been. Worth seeing but be patient as there are queues everywhere and it is really hot with limited refreshments available.

Great tour recommended by the hotel.. Part of an overall tour including the palace and the Golden Buddha. Very colourful and intricate tiling and mosaics and very impressed by the reverence shown by the locals.
. very beautifull. amazing one piece of emerald, i enjoyed the visit however there were many touts on the way but sucssefully diverted them and entered the amazing place and loved it
Temple at the Grand Palace. This temple is part of the Grand Palace. The Buddha is a bit small but is still a solid piece of jade. The temple architecture is spectacular.

Ignorant tourists. Beautiful temple but the guard had his work cut out. Many tourists showed a lack of respect for this place of worship. Many came to leave offerings and pray with tourists shouting and aggressively pushing people out the way. Indeed 1 female fell and injured herself (minor) when I was there. I nearly caused an accident when I was pushed and I nearly fell over individuals praying. The guard was good and making people be quiet but the amount of people crammed in there was ridiculous.
