I left after 5 minutes as I couldn't take it anymore.Maybe a guard at the enter ends would be good and limit the amount that go in

Not Emerald but Jade, but still well worth the visit.. The Emerald Buddha, is actually carved dark green jade. When the ancient kingdom of Ayutthaya fell to Burma, this religious object was moved to Vientiane in modern day Cambodia. The Thai king moved his capital to the East bank of the Chao Phraya River for greater protection and eventually attacked and captured Vientiane and recaptured this religious article and moved it to Thonburi. Later the capital was moved to Bangkok and a special temple was built on the grounds of the Grand Palace. The Emerald Buddha now sits there (Wat Phra Kaew). This temple has gone through several restorations since the founding of the Chakri dynasty, the last being in 1982. Go early to avoid the crowds.
Very Impressive. I would definitely recommend the audio guide that can be hired near the entrance. It provides a very helpful guide whice one can follow at ones own pace.

Awe!. The murals are fantastic! The detailing is simply amazing. There are faces with eyebrows, lips etc, elephants and all types of mythical creatures. The jade Buddha changes clothes thrice a year in a ceremony attended by the king. Absolutely no taking of pictures inside. The guards will ensure you delete it off your camera or phone. Dress wear also strictly enforced

Must Visit. You can not visit Bangkok and miss this, It is the country's prized Budda the palace and grounds are stunning and a must visit. We had a personal guide so we did the Leaning Budda First then the Royal Palace his knowledge was really good and explained everything and the reason for each building this is also were they have the ashes of Budda so you can imagine how important this place is to the people. top thing to do in Bangkok
A must-see in Bangkok. It is easy to get there and the place is beautiful. Take care about don't taking pictures where not permitted as well as the monks - they don't like it.

Stunning!. This is the most beautiful and important temple in Thailand. The Emerald Buddha is carved from a single block of jade and is absolutely stunning. A must visit but plan your trip for the early mornings so you don't have to jostle with crowds. As with other places of worship ensure proper attire. A must visit.
More beauty. Beautiful, beautiful! You are surrounded by stunning beauty on all corners.The day we went it was closed (to entry) but the outside was enough!

Huge, Shining and totally Stunning!. An entry into the temple of the emerald Buddha costs about 500THB. As soon as you enter the temple gates, be ready to be bedazzled by a huge temple with amazing intricate decorations. It is best to get there early, not only to beat the crowds but also to avoid the scorching heat. There are guided tours three times daily free of charge (need to register at a counter located on the left side as soon as you enter the temple premises). This place is totally worth the time spent there..

Be amazed and awed!. It was crowded, but once you're in, spend some time capturing the beauty of the geometries. It was amazing, the mural in the Walls of the Chamber depicting the histories of Buddha. Apart from that, it's best to get a sunshade as weather is always blazing. You may bring water, or any form of items essential. Do remember to cover your legs and arms. T-shirt are allowed, but not sleeveless, and certainly no shorts. Trousers or long skirts will do. Tourists are required to purchase an entrance and maintenance ticket for about 500baht. Reasoonable as I appreciate the cultural and holy place.
Hold your breath. Captivating statue of Buddha. Worlds largest gold statue. A must visit for all travelers. The temple is fantastically constructed. The work will take your breath away.

Absolutely stunning grounds and temple. Visited the Grand Palace and Emerald Buddha for 500 baht. At first we thought this was quite expensive relative to the prices of other attractions in Bangkok, but wow... It was absolutely worth every penny. The grounds of the temple are pristine and stunning. We were amazed at how beautiful and detailed everything was. It was personally my favourite temple that we saw in Bangkok. I would highly recommend going as soon as it opens in the morning. It gets very overcrowded with tourists and it can be hot and exhausting. We went first thing in the morning and it wasn't too bad.. We walked by later on in the day and it was absolutely insane! Bring lots of water. Nice bathroom facilities too.. Clean!

Beautiful. It's nice to see, but it's a fight to visit it, since tons of tourists cramps this place. Not allowed to make pic inside but many stupid tourists didn't respect the rules, just an advice, make sure you always obey & respect the country's law you live in despite you are tourists/expats

The most crowded tourist attraction, ever!. Yes, it is fabulous and, no, you can't visit Bangkok without visiting the Grand Palace ... it is without doubt the busiest, most crowded tourist attraction I have ever visited ... well worth it tho!

Highest revered buddhist shrine in all of Thailand. The is the most revered buddhist shrine in all of Thailand. Pictures are allowed of buddha, but ONLY FROM OUTSIDE THE TEMPLE. This buddha was found in the late 1400's and believed to be a solid piece of emerald. It was later determined to be one solid piece of jade. It is exquisite!

Beautiful Spiritual Place. The amount of details, the history.... amazing! Unfortunately we went in on a busy day, so the majority of our pictures came out with tons of people in it. Make sure you remove your shoes to go in... it is a sign of respect.

Its Smaller then expected. If you've seen the Golden Budha you will be expecting something large. It's not! The Budha is quite tiny and sit up on a high pedestal. What is interesting s the "dress" the Budha in different attire depending on the time of year and festivals. The room is nice to sit an linger inside and take pictures!
Tiny Buddha in a massive complex. This is a must to see what all the hoopla is about but I have to admit it was a pretty amazing the place.

Good but crowded. The Emerald Buddha itself was opulent and serene. Visited as part of Grand Palace tour. It was good but very crowded though. We took a guide. He explained good bit of the temple and its surroundings, origins and local practices. Best to visit in the morning to avoid crowd. Suggest a guide as well (It's inexpensive and worth it). Liked Wat Pho better than Wat Phra Kaew though.

Crowds were horrible. The Emerald Buddha is the least amazing of the three major Buddha images (Reclining Buddha and Golden Buddha are the other two). The crowds were horrendous. It is almost impossible to get close. No pictures are allowed inside but you can take one from exterior.
Must see and visit!. It is one of the top places in Bangkok. You must see and feel how great it is! We could not have been more satisfied!
My most travelled country. One of the best temples in Thailand. Amazingly well maintained, as usual, like most temples in Thailand

Too busy, disorganised and expensive!. First and foremost - TAKE YOUR OWN LONG CLOTHING! We visited here prior to visiting The Reclining Buddha. If you are to only visit one, visit the Reclining Buddha. The Emerald Temple is worth visiting but what isn't worth the hassle is borrowing the clothing. You have to leave a deposit of 200TBH per item (this was 800TBH for two trousers and two shirts) - clothing is light but still exceptionally warm and does not get washed between uses. Once finished you are expected to join a queue. However, hat nobody tells you is that you need to return the clothing, get your ticket stamped and then join the queue to receive your deposit back. This confused numerous people and involved people queuing twice! The whole process takes about 30 minutes. What's also frustrating is they insist on giving you back the exact notes you left, rather than just distribute notes from a till based on what your receipt says - this delays the whole process and is enough for me to say don't bother going unless you've got your own long clothing. Add to this the fact that tickets are 500TBH each and they let far too many people in at once, I'd save your time and money and visit the Reclining Buddha instead!

Highly disappointing. For one of the most religious shrines this felt like one of the worst bun-fights I'd ever experienced. I felt no sense of peace and calm after leaving there having had to contend with people pushing, shoving and shouting. Numbers should be controlled.

Beautiful Temple. This should be on your to-see list if you have a few days in Bangkok although it is not my favorite temple visited and would not be my first priority. The Buddha itself is small and hard to see, and like other reviewers noted it can be very crowded. Just be calm and respectful and quietly make your way through it.

A must see!. it is one of the places you have to see when you visit Bangkok. The temple is pretty much the same as most of the other temples in Thailand and the emerald Buddha itself is disappointing - very small.

Welcome to the Crowd. We are long-time residents of Thailand having lived in Songkhla for the last 14 years. When we have friends or family come to Thailand we take them to interesting sights. In June we took our family to the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. This has been a “must do” for all visitors to Thailand.We arrived at the temple about 8:30 AM only to be surrounded by masses of tourists. The walkways to the area to purchase the tickets were totally jammed but we were successful in purchasing tickets. Since the tours had already arranged their tickets they did not compete in this line. After obtaining tickets we queued to go in. My wife, being Thai, was in the Thai line but was unceremoniously shoved aside by a tour guide from another country so he could take his group in ahead of her.Once inside the place was totally jammed with people taking photos, selfies and talking. The serenity of a Thai Buddhist temple was not in evidence.We won’t be going to this temple in the future. It’s off our list permanently. We’ll suggest our friends watch a video of how it used to be and visit one of the many other temples in Thailand that are more representative of how a Buddhist temple should be.The Thai government could correct this problem but the temptations of mass tourism and money are so great. They could set a daily limit on the number of people that can visit this temple i.e. 25% of those presently. Also the Buddhist Sabbath which occurs every 7 or 8 days could be reserved for Thais only to practice their faith. Tour groups could easily plan around these dates. However in the days of money tourism neither of these changes are likely.

Amazing temple. The temple the emerald Buddha is housed in is amazing. The Buddha itself is quite small and up high so you cannot see much of him. Definitely worth seeing as is it the grand palace complex.

Real History. 6th Visit in 20 years and still amaziing. Took a guide for 500 baht and make sure you wear your jeans or long pants or you wil have to queue for 80 mins. A must do on your visit to Bangkok.
Arrive Early to Beat the Tour Buses. A must see in Bangkok. An unforgetable experience that is much better if you are not jammed in with thousands of others. Spend a few hours and wander around.

Must do when in Bangkok. It was lovely to experience this tour and share how proud the Thai's are of their palace and King. We just turned up here just after the grounds had opened and signed up for a free tour. Our guides name was Yard and he spoke exceptional english. He was very knowledgable and offered us a great insight to the grounds and the history, He also gave us lots of time to explore without rushing us along.

Great visit. Being on the Grand Palace grounds and a main tourist attraction expect very large crowds both inside the palace grounds and outside. The Emerald Buddha was smaller then expected, however still a very good experience, we enjoyed it. Note: remember to cover up, with long pants a day least 3 quarter sleeve shirt to be able to enter

He is a little small but the building itself is amazing!. Well yes, the Emerald Buddha is a little small, but the temple itself is extraordinary as are the surrounding buildings. Make sure you get there early as it is very crowded and can be very hot. Overall though, terrific.
Visitation to Buda Temple. A very beautiful place to visit.Very likely will never be empty, many tourists will always be there.The earlier you arrive for a visit, the better.
Attractive place to visit. Buddha made with real emerald, keep in the royal palace of Thailand, the palace full of Thai architecture
Of course, it is amazing.. This small jade Buddha has so much history. I've been here before and enjoyed, now enjoyed again. Was not as crowded as other places, which was a treat!

Must See. Its actually Jade and very impressive. Remember No Shoes and never point ur feet. Thailand is a winderful place.
I highly recommend that u go to this temple.its something to see and feel

Quite small but really pretty. The Emerald Buddha is one of the main attractions in Bangkok and visited by many tourists. He is smaller than expected and probably made from jade rather than from emerald. Still, it's very impressive and shouldn't be missed...

Beautiful. Even from the outside you can tell this temple is special; the roof was glistening in the sun as we approached and the beauty kept on coming. Fascinating paintings around the outer buildings and some of the most intricate architecture I have ever seen. You will not see decoration like it, the temple is absolutely breathtaking. You must wear long trousers/skirt (not leggings) and cover your shoulders but you can borrow sarrongs/trousers etc.

Unique and oppulent!. Fabulous to see and so much bigger and more extravagant than I had imagined. Amazing history and sights and Buddhas to see. Very busy but I did with a private guide which highly recommend as they know their stuff and can take you around different routes which are less packed. A must see in Bangkok!
Excellent!!. It is such a beautiful place. Be sure to take a guided tour so you"ll understand everything. It is best to go in the afternoon because early in the morning it will be too crowded.

Beautiful. This temple is inside of the Great Palace. Go early as it's normally crowded. I thought that the Emerald Buddha was bigger, it's not that big but it's in the top of the temple's altar. All the altar is very peaceful and beautiful. Totally worth visiting along with the rest of the great palace.

The Emerald Buddha. Like so many attractions in Thailand, this is another one that should not be missed but take your time here as there is so much to see and take in, astounding, beautiful and magical.

Worth the wait. When we were here it was crazy hot .That made it hard to stay at the grandpalace because there is no wind. It was really busy as Well we went there with the boat from the bts link that is really easy and fun the buddha itself is rather small but beatifull you can dit on the Floor and admire it my tip is go late because it is les busy and the mobks come out to pray

Ladies need a shirt too.. Liked everything and visited only last week. Advice: Dont let anyone tell you its closed and then take you somewhere else. It is open 365 days of the year.Advice: Take a private guide, once you are INSIDE the gates! The ones inside are all registered. Its slightly more than costly than a normal entry ticket but worth every penny for the historic information they provide. Ours, Tony, also took photos of us with our camera, provide me (female) with a clean, ironed shirt to cover my shoulders (Scarves/shawls/pashminas dont count). The site is beautiful, utterly beautiful and the Emerald Buddha is stunning. Ask your guide about his changing clothes.

This place you must visit once in your life if passing thru BKK. Its something that you must see while you visiting BKK. You must dress proper for this place which no short or spaghetti top otherwise you will waiting time to Q up for rent the cover. I brought all my friends who's visiting BKK in the past several years to this place and they were all enjoyed
Beautiful!. This is a great must see. It's refreshing because it's really calm and quiet inside amongst the chaos outside. The architecture and the art in this temple is simply stunning.
Jewel of Thailand. It is simply spectacular. Ornate facade in the center of town. Definitely a MUST see while visiting Bangkok.

Great temple but surprisingly small Buddha figure. Its a great temple with lots to see. When we were there the temple was full of genuine worshippers and the family was blessed by the priest. A must see
Spectacular!. Come upon a number of people out looking for this temple. It is located on the grounds of the Grand Palace. An entry ticket to the Grand Palace takes you right to this.
mind Peace. quite place and you feel peace of mind when you enter the Temple. kept neatly and very nice and good

Amazing but so crowded!. Wat Phra Kaew is just beautiful...awesome. BUT I just cannot believe all the disrespect from tourists! There are hordes of tourists all around, mainly Chinese people in this particular case. The problem is the noise! Why are not tour guides obliged to take their groups using a system of earphones??!! This system would reduce noise a lot. It is a temple! Even in the temple of the emerald Buda, the noise and pushing around of tourists was just incredible! I believe that technology nowadays enables us to be organized in a more civilized way. I hope this changes soon.

A powerful and peaceful temple. Very beautiful temple and Buddha. This is our most loved place in the palace. An early morning visit is recommended as the palace becomes very hot by late morning/afternoon.

Beautiful but Tons of Tourists. This place is crawling with tourists. There are a lot of temple structures here. Admission is a bit high but you can see the Royal Palace as well. It was extremely hot while I was there in late May. I spent a lot of time here though because the structures are so lovely and there is so much detail to look at.
cheap.... It was really nice to see that immense Buda.You must take off the shoes, because all the dirty things that we bring with them...

Another must see in Bangkok. A very crowded, top attraction in Bangkok. I suggest hiring a knowledgable private guide who will show you around and explain the history / significance / particularities of the place.
Dont miss this beautiful temples. A must see if u visit Bangkok. take lots of water and a tour guide makes life little easier when u visit such an extrordinary place.

Amazing and a must see.. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is a must see when visiting Bangkok. The temple is beautiful, It is located in the palace complex and so when you buy admission you get to visit all of the grounds. Reserve several hours for he visit; you won't be disappointed. Be care of the drivers who will try and tell you that the temple is closed; it rarely is.

Nice Temple. It's located inside Grand Palace. Reach early (8.30-9 am) to avoid long queues. Nicely decorated. A beautiful emerald buddha statue (though small) sits quite high inside the temple. It was a calming, soothing experience, though crowded. No photos allowed inside temple, but with a good zoom lens it's easy to get photos form outside the temple entrance.

Magnificent but crowded. A magnificent Statue of Lord Buddha made of lovely green emerald in gold outfit in which they change 3 times a year according the different seasons. Definitely worth seeing even though over crowed with tourist.Other useful tips: - Sunscreen is essential as you will almost certainly get burned without it- Drinking Water is essential on a hot day; as there is No Air Condition.- Bring your camera and probably another battery as you will take plenty of pictures!
must visit. must visit if you are interested to see the temples. everyone in our family liked the place and it was a memorable to see the Buddha.
Go for a massage if you get chance.. 2nd time back but just as fantastic. The most amazing temples and buddhas on show. I'd pay for a guide if you can.

Magnificent . This building is absolutely magnificent and can be seen as part of the Grand Palace tour. Housing the (jade) Buddha it is another extraordinary temple. No photographs are allowed inside the Temple and there is a strict dress code so don't turn up in shorts and singlet. The outside of the temple has hundreds of photographic opportunities!
A lot of walking.. An fast awesome complex. A lot of gold around You have to have a lot of time , to take it all in. But one should see it We loved it.

Must see. Big, so set aside enough time to visit. Expect to walk lots so bring water and snacks. You will need to adhere to dress code so shoukders and legs covered for women, but you can rent skirts at the entrance. Lots to see and usually busy so go early to avoid crowds and queuing.
Impressive. The temple is really astounding, and you should definitely visit it and leave enough time to explore. Make sure to bring water with, though.

A temple of energy. If you are lover of temples then this is the place to be though the entrance fee is a bit steep it 500 bahts per head and no shorts or sleeveless clothes not allowed it is open from morning to 4 pm there are lovely statues of Buddhas and good story behind every statue it is good to hire a guide who shows you around for two hours and explains every detail. And just next to the temple is the kings palace of king Rama 9th and outside the temple are small selling knick knacks we enjoyed eating the mango salad and guava fruit.

details. I try not to be biased. The lovely thing I personally like is the old-style decoration of Thai arts on all building, which are located at the same place with some modern and European styles building. What I dislike is to hardly find parking area closed to the temple.

disapoinitng temple visit. 500bath entrance to a temple visit to pay and contribute the Monarchy excesses. there was really nothing more than the emeral buddha, and a couple of other buidings.you better have the wat pho temple visit

Awesome sight. What an awe inspiring temple. Pity about the crowds and the snafu caused by Russian premier visiting. Did not know here not to look. If you think going to Disneyland is a eye fest, you ain't seen anything yet! Beautiful carvings, figurines, gold, emerald, intricate inlay ...
Spectacular. Gobsmackingly awesome, beautiful, stunning, something interesting to see around every corner...couldn't stop taking photos. The gold and glass ornate work glitters in the sunshine

Waste of time, skip this one for your own sanity. The emerald Buddha is inside this extremely small and overcrowded temple where the security guards shove people around and you feel like a canned sardine. Get ready to get pushed, shoved and stepped on. When you actually see the "emerald" Buddha (actually made from green jade), it is tiny and so high up you can't actually see any of the details, only the outline of the statue. Compete waste of time.

Overpriced!. Unless you are an absolut temple enthusiast or you have other important reasons to visit this temple, consider to spent the totally overpriced entrance fee of 500 baht somewhere else. It's really not worth it, especially when having in mind that there are hundreds of thousands of other beautiful temples in Thailand that you could visit for free.Or if you are lucky and look a little like a thai, sneak in from the back entrance for locals (it's for free and guards there are kinda lazy ;))

Beautiful temple with no spiritual feeling for me. Fabulous place so seren....remember ladies to cover up ..no bare shoulders or shorts...you can hire shirts but they are very small fittings xl didn't fit me am a size 20...

Too much for so little.. It was hot and for all the hype, I was unimpressed.The cost to enter the palace grounds was 500 B which was too much. The entry was very disorganized and clothing requirements strict for very little appears to reason. For example, they required no sandles but you had to take your shoes off to enter the Emerald Buddha area. Also, normally similar temples provide a simple wrap for you legs at no cost, but here they required you to go thru a long line and rent pants.I'm glad I did it, but won't do it again.

Temple of the Emerald Budda. This is fantastic to see you have unexpected veiws and understanding of the religion of the Thai people .The sight is fantastic clean and accepts you as you are .Well done Thai people

Awe inspiring. Really beautiful place to be. It is inside the grand palace, the entry fee is bit higher compared to other temples but free on King's birthday and some other occasions. You need wear full clothes and can't show your legs. You can rent paijama outside but they will fool you into paying more so put one extra pair of pants. I had one and wore it over my half pant to go inside :), you can try that too. The temple is really really really beautiful but the area has not only this temple but other things to see as well. It's very beautiful so keep your cameras ready for some click click.

A must to see. This is a very interesting Temple,we were lucky enough to have a private tour of the school behind, as we had hired a driver for the day can highly recommend this, as it cuts down on walking

Interesting and beautiful historical site..... Most importantly, regardless of the weather, please make sure you note the dress code! It is strictly enforced. If you arrive wearing shorts, they'll ask you to rent proper clothing while you are on the grounds. (Which will be hotter than your wearing a pair of jeans!) Also be sure to check out other museums in the area. It's a mistake I made by leaving and not realizing. Also... go early. It gets busier as the day goes on.

An impressive temple-set apart.. This was a very impressive place. Visitors will have the opportunity to learn about the relationship that this temple has to the rulers of Thailand, and the difference in "Normal" life amongst those in religious context at this place. A tour of the grounds is available and helped me to understand its' significance throughout time.
My favorite bangkok temple. Simply wow!! This temple is amazing. The emerald buddha is really small but the rest of the temple is just so detailed and shinny! The stone guards are amazing!

A Majestic Temple. Temple of the Emerald Budha is located in the Grand Palace compound, the entrance to which is 500 Bhaat. For those interested in history, beautiful monuments and Thai culture it is a must visit. The temple is very beautiful and majestic. Try to reach the Temple early in the morning to beat the tourist crowds.

Something to see and tick off the list. The palace as a whole for a first timer was amazing to see. So much gold and glitz in one place and the culture is apparent. What is missing though, is proper signs and explanation of what each building is and the significance. Even the guide pamphlets don't offer much explanation beyond the name. So if like us, you opted not to hire a tour guide outside, you miss out on the history etc of the place.The Buddha is just amazing to see. But I guess holds more significance for those that are Buddhists.Must see once.

A china tour group mayhem!. Only go to this place if you want to see the most disgusting behaviour of China tourists in their full glory. Bashful, loud, inconsiderate, pushy, rude... the entire works. It makes you forget that you are in Thailand and visiting an active palace anymore. Avoid this place. Google to look for pictures of this place instead of braving it yourself.Icing on the cake of this disastrous visit was the visit to the gift shop when the salesgirl rolled her eyes and let out an irritated grunt that I've interrupted her social chat with her colleague when I asked for help.

Amazing Budha temple in Bangkok. This our first visit to temple in Bangkok. The place is pricey since the ticket is being combined with Grand Palace but the temple itself is amazing. It's huge complex with so many building. The architect is complex and amazing that it's been built few years back. The level of detail and its colorful material used to build the temple is really unbelievable.

Peaceful but lots of tourists. Obviously there was a lot of tourist's, which can take a way the beauty of anything. If you can look passed that, you can have a spiritual time. I cried walking into the temple.

Dazzling. All of the glittering gilded glass tiles, vivid colors, and exotic shapes made this an overwhelming introduction to Eastern art, architecture, and religion. The heat and crowds diminished the impact it might have had, but well worth a visit nonetheless.
Beautifully made. it is a beautiful temple with the buddha statues made with emerald green stone. Thai architect with detailing is superb . A must visit while in bangkok.

An amazing site to see. The size of the complex was surprising and impressive. It was my favorite of the Wats we visited, the Buddah is a bit out of site and not the most impressive in my eyes, but great history

Beautiful area to get lost in. The temple and the surrounding are incredible! Absolutely beautiful and worth the trip to Bangkok! The entrance fee was 500 Baht per person and it gives you access to the temple, the grand palace and a museum. We did the temple and grand palace and then headed out to Wat Pho. They do have a dress code but they also supply you with a sarong if needed. We bought a scarf and a sarong outside for cheap since we knew we would be doing multiple temples. You don't have to do that it was just our preference. There are no time limits to visiting the temple you can do it in 1 hour or 4 hours. We took about 2 and a half hours to walk around. The surrounding architectures really make the place special, the emerald buddha is very small compared to the larger scale of the grounds but it is worth it to see it.

Temple of the Emerald Buddha. The temple was huge and amazing ..definitely a must-go for tourists..The temple was crowded with locals and foreigners...prayers were being offered inside the temple and taking pictures is not allowed inside the temple (I didn't notice and took 1 and the guard started shouting "Noo Pictureess No Pictureees..." ..ops sorry......felt really bad!

Too Crowded To Pray. The place is extremely crowded and hot but do take a look at the tiny Buddha placed high above. You are not allowed to take any photographs there. The place is so hot that we had to settle down for a long time under a shade to recover ourselves. Take enough drinking water.
Loved the temple!. The temple was magnificant, and as it was located in the palace grounds, was definitely the highlight of the city visit.
Small Buddha. If you are lucky enough to see the emerald Buddha then this temple is worth the visit. He is quite small and is located on a high platform. Well worth a visit though.
Not to be missed. One of THE most majestic temple not to be missed while at Bangkok. Please be mindfully that this is a temple and be wary of your code of dressing as a respect to the Buddha.

Great Architecture Work. The statue is really a major attraction however the total complex is a great work of thai architecture.There is a traditional Thai message Centre which is like a school for learning thai message which is not to be MISSED.

A Bangkok must see. Probably the biggest and most spectacular temple in Bangkok.
It's easily accessed by river ferry.
Beware the 3.30 pm last entry into the complex.

Good place to learn about Thai culture. It's one of the must-seen in Bangkok. I love visit Wat Pra Kaew at least one time a year. There are many history to learn about Thailand. It's such a good place to visit.

Stunning temple inside. The temple inside the royal Grand Palace is beautifully decorated on the walls and ceiling with the amazing solid jade buddha perched on high in the centre. Feels very spiritual even though very ornate.

Grand palace ticket required. Part of your Grand Palace ticket is the Wat Parakaew. The ticket itself is 500 THB (about $15 USD), plus 200 THB for the optional self-paced audio tour (available in multiple languages). I do not know if you can get into the Wat itself without paying for the whole Grand Palace ticket. This is an amazing temple complex that includes several buildings built over several hundred years of Thai History. This Wat is unique in that it does not have any monks living there permanently, but instead was initially intended as a worship place for the King. Now it is mostly a tourist location, but people are still expected to act with reverence and respect when in the presence if the Emerald Buddha who is inside the Wat.Around the walls of the Wat and the outer buildings are paintings from the Ramakian (the most famous Epic of Thailand), which I personally find to be the most interesting part of the temple. However, there is plenty of architectural and cultural attractions within this Wat and outer buildings to keep just about anyone interested. All and all this is a Must-see for anyone visiting Thailand. The audio tour itself is well worth the 200 THB that it costs. It will have you walk around the Wat Parakaew and Grand Palace in a specific order that takes about 2 hours. It tells the history and architectural features of many the buildings, and points out unique features to look for. Tips for traveler: Wear appropriate clothing! Sleeves must cover shoulders / mid arm length, and long skirts (for female) or long clean pants (for men), are required. It is possible to rent or purchase sarongs for about 100 THB if you do not have these. No shoes, cameras, backpacks, hats, etc are allowed within the temple of the Emerald Buddha if self. For this reason I recommend bringing any money or valuables in a separate neck or belt pouch. Additionally, you are expected to sit down I front of the Buddha and do not face your feet in his direction. All of this is described within the Audio Tour.

Royal Palace. Jaw dropping event. The Buddha was perched high within the temple and was easily identifiable. Very crowded so patience is a must. We paid for a guide and feel this was well worth the money.
Beautiful. Good points - very beautiful and very grand. There is a lot to see and take pictures of. Bad points - 500THB for 'farangs' to get in and it is so busy!
A touristic to do place. Very touristic with most of the time too many foreigners to get an impression of what is a Buddhist temple is about
Emerald Buddha. We were getting a little 'templed out', as we had been to see 4 others before this one, but we are so pleased that we continued our tour. This temple is exquisite.

Amazing. Despite the crowds and very hot weather conditions, we enjoyed our visit to this special place. The Emerald Buddha is amazing, do take the time to stay a while and reflect in the holiness of the space.

Amazing!. Brave the crowded masses and heat and visit the Temple of the Emerald Buddha! Mind boggling detail and visual display, must cover your shorts or sleeveless shirts but clothing can be borrowed with a small deposit. Again, the detail is amazing!

Beautiful...smaller than you think. The Emerald Buddha is probably the most important sight in Bangkok. The temple itself is similar to others, but the Emerald Buddha itself is beautiful....although be prepared that it is probably smaller than you think.

It is really a must go. We could see Thai traditional , how they believe and worship Buddha.
Clean
environment made us feel fresh. We can see many religious buildings in this area.
I wish to be there again.

Emerald Buddha. Conveniently located as it is within the grounds of the grand palace. The building has great architecture as with everything else on site. But the experience was over pretty quickly as I was in out pretty fast. By this stage we were all experiencing some temple fatigue. Is considered the most important Buddhist site in Bangkok.

Perhaps the most sacred Buddha-figure in Thailand. The Emerald Buddha (actually jade) is perhaps the most sacred Buddha-figure in Thailand, and the temple is perhaps the most-revered structure in the Royal Monastery adjoining the Grand Palace. No photography, no shoes, and I was scolded for not removing my hat while I was walking around the outer portico.

Revered shrine. One of the top attractions in Bangkok, this is a part of the Grand Palace complex, the Emerald Buddha is an extremely revered shrine in whole of Thailand. definitely worth a visit, the calm and serene environment is another plus.

A ming boggling statue of Buddha. Among gazzilions of Buddha statues spread all over Thailand, this one is most unusual as it is made of green stone. (Which i don't think is emerald, but it doesn't matter after all). It's just green color that makes the statue so unusual. Definitely worth a visit
Amazing. I visited here on a guided tour - crowded but definitely worth seeing. The buildings around are magnificent and the temple itself is amazing

Beautiful historical statues . Amazing fine artworks done in olden days on these statues at the temple
A great place for photographers for many beautiful historical shots
We spent 1 hour here but it's not enough but we have to leave as the tour guide was rushing us

Must see. One of the best places to see in BKK. Worth to go just cover shoulders and NO mini skirts or tooshort shorts.We used River ferry and tuc-tuc to arrived from hotel in Silom.Cheapest and a bit adventurous way to get there.

Grand palace. Visiting this temple is a must, i was amazed with all the details on the sculptures do not rush into tours to see this temple u need quite some time to explore one hour is not enough and make sure to wear proper clothes no shorts if u do not have a proper clothes before u enter the temple they will provide for you. U must see the golden Buddha as well it is amazing and listen carefully the story of the seven Buddhas. I highly recommend visiting this place.
Essential visit. As expected, the temple was a little busy, even just after opening in the morning. Still stunning, 30 years after my last visit

Breathtaking!. I have visited wat phra kaew twice now and it was equally amazing both times. Make sure you wear loose pants and at least a t-shirt out of respect for the temples. The grounds are bursting with colors both from brightly painted temples and well kept flower gardens. A must see if a traveler is in Bangkok for more than a day.

A must-see in Bangkok. The temple and the Royal palace form one complex so visiting both at the same time is unavoidable. The temple is fantastic, but it attracts many people. Get there as early as possible (I believe opening time is 8 am). DRESS MODESTLY (pants for men and skirts for women..the longer the better) or you will have to get sarongs or pants they can lend you (my traveling partner had to put on some hideous acrylic running pants, and the heat was horrible). Upon entering the temple per se, you will have to take off your shoes so if you don't feel that confortable going barefoot, put on socks as well or bring a pair to put on when taking off your shoes. The fee (the most expensive of all the attractions in BKK) includes the temple and grounds plus the Royal Palace AND entrance to the WIMANEK mansion across town, so keep the good half of the ticket safe if you want to visit the mansion and grounds (including the FABULOUS Throne Hall). Entrance to the reagalia room is included too but its entrance is so small it is easy to miss.

not to miss. One of the highlights of Bangkok, a must see. The downside is that it is always very crowded, especially with people who seem to take more interest in taking selfies than enjoying this beautiful temple.

Different from other Buddha statues. The Buddha statue is made from jade. Unlike most other Buddha statue here the statue is quite small and placed at a elevation. It is very holy for Buddhist and very crowded. It is within the Grand palace and worth a visit.
A big lying buddha.. Wat Pho you find near the Royal Palace and Chinatown. Its a nice templecomplex with a giant lying buddha. Don,t forget to take a massage. It is one off the best in Thailand.

All kinds of stunning temples. The best way to see the temples on the river's edge is by catching a train to the Piers and catching the orange Chao Phraya tourist boats, they are like a Hop On Hop Off bus, with English speaking guides.

Do Not Miss Wat Phra Kaew!. I was a little underwhelmed by the Emerald Buddha (it's actually jade and you can't get too close to it), but the rest of the complex is so beautiful. My #1 favorite site in Bangkok. Make sure you bring your camera and you MUST wear a shirt that covers your shoulders - shawls will not cut it. Try to get there early - your pictures will come out better with less people in them.

emerald Buddha. This temple is amazing, remember to listen carefully into you guide as shoes must be removed and though tempted to take photo's, only do so if your guide says OK,remember where you are and don't cause offence just for a photo.otherwise this is a wonderful temple.
must see. a must see the buddha is emerald they have different gold outfits for the buddha for eachtime of year

Temple of the Emerald budda. a most amazing place Be sure to have a guide so you know what you are looking at
really gives you a feel for the country and customs
WONDERFUL. One of the major attractions in Bangkok. Taking photographs inside the temple not allowed. The Statue of Lord Buddha made of lovely green emerald is splendid.

While in the Grand Palace.. When entering the grand palace area, you can get to wat phra kaew, a group of temples. the architecture is beatiful and you can learn a lot about culture and history. the place is too crowded though, so it's kind of difficult to move around sometimes.

Overpriced and overcrowded and overrated. Having read the guide books we made sure we arrived early at the Grand Palace, think we arrived around 9.30am but hundreds were there before us, if you are arriving by river taxi to Tao Chang jetty it is difficult to get there much earlier than this. We queued and paid our 500 Baht each and were then herded like cattle through a series of turnstiles, a relatively unpleasant experience in the heat. Once inside you must be prepared for the crowds of like minded tourists determined to photograph their loved ones in the best positions. This is not for the faint hearted and it's every man for himself. We tried to view as much as possible within a 2 hour period, the heat was overpowering and the crowds tried ones patience, personally I was not particularly impressed by the Emerald Buddha. By the time we left at approx 12 noon the crowds queuing to get in stretched a long way and there were a great number of visitors inside . Very popular but very busy.

Crowd /Cheio. Os Templos na Tailândia são MARAVILHOSOS e estão por toda a parte. o Great Palace, como é conhecido o conjunto de templos onde se encontram esses monumentos é sempre muito visitado e está sempre muito cheio. Cheque antes o código de vestimenta, mas se você não quiser tampar suas pernas e braços, você poderá alugar alguma roupa antes de entrar para a visita. Its always crowd, but is worth the visit, because the Great Palace has beautiful temples. Make sure to check the dress code before you go, but you can always rent something if you don't feel like covering your legs and shoulders (I did cover my leg and not my shoulders and later that day I was dying from the heat).

No words to describe it. It is an astonishing place, I was so amazed that I couldnt stop getting puctures of every single detail at the construction. Everything is so perfect, and in really good conditions, you can see that they take really good care of everything in that precint. I would like to say that no one can leave Bangkok without visiting!
Smaller But Stunning Buddha. There are larger Buddhas to see in Thailand but perhaps none as beautiful as this one. Really worth making the effort to visit.
Visually impressive. Interesting mixture of different architectural influences and styles. It was extremely hot though so we had to rush trough a bit more than I would have liked.

"Crowded". We went into the Temple expecting to see the Emerald Buddha right away. Actually, it is smaller than expected and we had to look for it among all the gold. Actually, a person next to me pushed past me to get a better view. This was not a very prayerful experience.
A Buddha that changes with the seasons. This interesting temple has the small emerald Buddha who's outfit changes depending on the season. It's quite nice and worth seeing.

Emerald Buddah. One of the coolest designed temples in my opinion. Different from the others. Definitely worth seeing. Lots of nice photos. Plus, you have to rub the emerald Buddah's belly for good luck!

Think emerald green not emerald gem. You can't take pictures of the Buddha unless you happen to have a good telephoto lens. While you are touring you learn that the Buddha is really jade, not emerald. That was a little disappointing, but the temple is beautiful.
Amazing temple... Travel to Thailand. Traveled to many temples in Thailand...and this is a must see but I feel that all of them were. Wear long shorts (capris) or pants.
Tourist trap. Great to see but so jammed with tourists we didn't stay long! Also made to buy a tshirt to gain entry AFTER paying for entry even though I was totally covered
Great but crowded. Had a good time here as the architecture was stunning, however it is crowded at times with tourists which can be slightly annoying if you are into photography.

Awesome. So breathtakingly beautiful and the history behind it is amazing as well. A must visit attraction. It's on the grounds of the palace so spend your time here since you can't go inside the palace anyway. Neat the way they change his clothes seasonally. You have to take off your shoes to go it, but it's not particularly clean. I ruined a new pair of socks, so wear old socks or go barefoot.

Beyond your senses. Absolutely incredible! The shimmering buildings, golden statues and greenery is like walking into a fairytale. You don't know where to look next and you can't believe how beautiful everything around you is! This is a must!!
Great, must visit. This is near grand palace and wat pho, its again not included in city tour/ temple tour. Kindly ask your travel agent to include it in itenary.

Enjoyed the experience. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a must see while sightseeing in Bangkok, It is one of the major attractions, so it is easier to find and get around. The wat itself is average, as Thai wats go, and the statue is an interesting piece.

Emerald Buddha. I particularly like the Temple of the Emerald Buddha as I had read up on its history. The Emerald Buddha itself is small; it was smaller than I had imagined and it is positioned quite high up which makes it difficult to really see it. However, it's worth visiting in my opinion and reading about its history.

A must visit. If in Bangkok, this has to be one of the top 10 places to visit. However, do remember the dress code, if you forget you can always get a pair of trousers to wear 'free of charge' inside the Temple, and Ladies, cover those shoulders. For an entrance fee of 500 Baht, it is a little expensive but it does not disappoint especially when considering all those phot opportunities, also it can be crowded in the mornings, l would suggest a visit in the afternoon

Simply Beautiful. You must visit the Grand Palace if you're in Bangkok! Stunning. I wish I had more time to explore but I'm so glad I spent some time in there. Would love to go back and actually get a tour guide to explain the history. Amazing!
Emerald Buddha. Another one of Bangkok's Buddhas. This Buddha is located inside the Grand Palace, this is a small buddha. Nice place but their are a lot of tourists visiting the area as well.
There is no Emerald Buddah there!. While it was many, many years ago for me I can still remember the thrill of seeing and sensing the importance of this beautiful shrine in the center of the City.
Number 1 Bangkok attractions.. This is part of the Grand Palace complex and if your are a tourist visiting Bangkok it is a must and I would allow a few hours to look round.

Beautiful. The emerald Buddha was situated in the grand palace bit so didn't have to move location to see it and it was breathtaking. Always enjoy the temples anyway as they are an experience to anything I see in other countries but this temple is up there with the best.
Must visit in Bangkok. Extraordinary place with 3 Emerald Buddha made from big jade.use proper dress to enter like trousers and no sleeveless.

A must visit when you are in Bangkok. Always worth a visit. Get past the hawkers outside and you are in serenity. Please dress appropriately and respect Buddhism - this is a temple not a tourist site.

Good and popular. Good but very very busy. Too many umbrellas being used as shade making the experience more of a preservation of eye sight, rather than enjoying the experience. You don't need a tour, just buy a guide book and follow the crowd
nice but small emerald buddah. was nice to see if you are in to buddhas and temples. but the emerald buddah is very small. lots of people, so helped to have our guide, dang.

Must do in Bangkok. It should be on the top 5 of every tourist in the city. Remember that you need to cover your legs and shoulders to get access, but also to take your shoes off to step inside the Temple. The audio guide is well worth it. Get some water as it gets very hot as well. Watch your backpack as there are pickpockets around the Temple and remember to never trust anyone who tells you the Temple is closed for a Buddhist or Royal holiday as it's a con and 99% of the time, never true.

More wow in Bangkok. There really is so much to see in this vast city but there are ess places that are quiet, less that are historic amongst the gigantic skyscrapers that define the skyline. Still best is the river boat tours,this way you travel splendidly via the long boats and get to your chosen destination with less hassle than the skytrains or road traffic. We went via the river and then walked to this site. It is truly splendid, like the palace this place exhudes a certain unique quality that you find no where else.A must to visit when you are in the capital

Small statured emerald buddha. To compare this Wat/ Temple to other temples with emerald buddhas is not so impressive. This emerald buddha is very very small. There is no cameras allowed, and many tourists filing in. Compared to other Wats I would say that this would not be in my top 5.

Emerald buddha. Seen as part of the Palace tour. You cannot take a photo of the Buddha inside the temple but there are plenty of viewpoints from which you can take a good photo from outside the temple....have a good zoom lens on your camera. There are 3 emerald Buddhas but only one will be on show, dependent on climate/season

A fantastic place but over priced at 500 baht. The collection of temples, painted murals and numerous statues make this a great visit, even if you have no connection with Buddhism and find the emerald Buddha "disappointing". However the 500 baht entrance fee is excessive.

Our Favorite Temple in the area. This place is very cool! My favorite temple in the area. Highly recommend it, but consider having your own driver to ensure you can navigate the crowds, and traffic better.Happy Travels,ExploreTraveler

Very interesting!. Cannot take pictures of the buddha inside but it's interesting to know the story behind this buddha! It took him quite a while to make it to Bangkok! I don't want to get the story wrong but if you get a tour guide you should surely as them, it's quite interesting if you ask me! The buddha changes outfits during each season which is pretty cool too.
Spectacular. Jaw droppingly beautiful from start to finish, The emerald Buddha is small in stature but housed in a temple that is exquisite in its detail and finish.

Size Does Matter. The experience was pretty mediocre; hubby and I didn't appreciate it much. I guess it has to do with the size of the Emerald Buddha - it seemed less significant after we visited the Golden Buddha and the Reclining Buddha. No photographs allowed inside the temple, but we still tried to sneak one shot (Lol).

A must see!. This is worth seeing - a collection of Buddhas and Thai artifacts. The Emerald Buddha is carved from a single large piece of jasper. When we visited the temple, the Buddha was set up high at the alter so when you enter the temple, be sure to turn your eyes upward.

A very advisable visit. This is a little statue , but it is quite attractive and it is defenitely worth seeing.Besides, its stroy is interesting. Recommend you to read before you go then you will see more of the statue value..
Worth the visit. Always a busy attraction, but still remember it is a religious site and to observe all rules about shoes, being respectful and no photos inside.

Worth the Visit. Well those in shorts and uncovered shoulders make provision before as they have a dress code, alternatively just hire the clothers at the entrance, the place is amazing and with the help of a paid guide we had a great overview about the culture and the King dynasties

Just Amazing!. This was the second time I visited the temple of the Emerald Buddha. The last time I visited was 10 years ago. It's still spectacular, but very crowded. Our guide, Tuk was amazing!. She was very knowledgeable, and informed us about the history and culture surrounding the complex. So beautiful, and a must when visiting Bangkok.

Interesting but small. I expected the Emerald Buddha to be bigger; that's what Wat Pho does to you I guess.
No pictures inside. This is packaged with the Grand Palace; one ticket gets you into both.
Must Visit!. Must visit place... amazing experience! We have taken a guide and he was very resourceful. He shared lot of insights about Palace and Emerald Buddha temple.

Good to see but not at the top of my list. We did not have long here when we visited but enjoyed what we saw. Lots of tourists as was holiday season and very hard to get any good photo shots. If you have plenty of time in Bangkok then I would add it to your list of must see's
Beautiful. Only 200BHT TO GET IN (£4) and well worth it. Restoration and upkeep but cost a fortune so good to know your visit must help do this

Lovely but crowded.. Its a lovely temple complex and the Emerald Buddha is beautiful to behold with a disputed history. Its not emerald and the guides will tell you it is jade (although neither is correct, it is in fact a type of ornamental jasper). This statue is a proud part of Thai culture and it is worth getting a guide to explain it to you. The drawbacks - its really busy, crowded with people and there are a lot of touts and crooks who will try to tell you that its closed and take you elsewhere. Beware!
A Little Buddha. Another gloriously decorated temple with intricate gold work. The Buddha is small but very special to see.

One of the must see !. One of the must see attraction in Bangkok. Nice architecture. Good collection of statues and calm and cool place to do prayers and concentrate on mind and body. Not rushy. Only devotees and tourists do come in disciplined manner. Emerald Buddha is worth seeing as you can see such things rarely.
Once a visit type place. Peaceful place which doesn't have the same grandeur as Wat Arun or Wat Pho but still a good place to visit.
A must see. Exotic. No pictures inside but area is lovely. Can be crowded with tourists, Buddha is small, but amazing it is one piece. Be respectful within.

The holy grail of the east.... The history and mystery of the Emerald Buddha is ingrained into the very fiber of all Thai life. It has moved throughout Southeast Asia during wars and invasions. It has been lost to antiquity and found again. It has been the central holy relic and images can be found throughout temples of all Southeast Asia. Along with the Golden Buddha of Wat Traimit, this is a must-see.

Stunnning and delicate. The temple is stunning beautiful and in the architure we could see the delicate touch of the design, unlike the building block of brick. Visiting this place and around, you would get the feeling like Bangkok oldtown, unlike the high rises in city part of Bangkok. Anyway, as this place is considered to be one of the important historical heritage, the visitor should dress up politely. but don't worry. They have Thai sarong flor ladies who wear shorts :)
Too far away. The temple is beautiful, outside and in. It would have been nicer if one had closer access to the Buddha, even with just the use of technology.
Why this little image? You are used to great Buddhas by this time. It is a great place to meditate but with a little buddha inside. They change its clothes according to year time. No pictures inside.

Beautiful and historic. This is a beautiful monument and wonderful place to visit. Be sure to allow yourself time for the queue, as it gets long from time-to-time. No photography allowed inside, only through the open doorways/windows.
Amazing!!!. Looking for something touristy to do in Bangkok? This place should be number 1 on your list. It's simply amazing, the most beautiful artifacts and grounds, it's well worth a visit.

Must visit place. Very proud that Thailand has a wonderful temple. Magnificent architecture, paintings, sculptures. Especially the Emerald Buddha. This is the must visit place when you are in Bangkok.
a beautiful place. One of teh best Buddha images i have seen. must visit. very peaceful and calming. a serene atmosphere
Certainly worth the queuing.. Magnificent place the Buddha was smaller than I thought it would be but the building is certainly worth visiting, no photographs allowed.
Another famous temple in bkk!. packed with backpackers and other tourist and also student who are on a field trip..nice place though.

Interesting but brief. The gem of this site is of course knowing the history and significance of the Buddha and the temple. It makes you appreciate it more and really soak in the moment you're able to see it.It's a little bit busy but that of course can be expected with both tourists and Buddhists visiting.Remember to adhere to the correct behaviour and all that. Shoes must be placed outside.Well worth visiting while in the Grand Palace.

much to do about,..... Lot of people,... and a very small statue,.... so much to do about,....It is still a nice day out,...just be aware off all the scammers and just dont believe anybody around this tourist trap,... just say no to everybody and visit the palace,...
A must for every traveller. Everything is amazing but is is crowded try to be the first into enjoy the place with less people and great light.
Must go. This temple shows Thai culture. you shouldn't miss this place because the temple are elegance and beautiful. good place to take photo.

Holy buildings, statues, and pagodas. Not only as a holy buildings, statues, and pagodas, this place is the most important Buddhist temple in Thailand. Old architecture with a variety of intricate detail decoration makes this building able to tell me about the maker skill in the first period.

Wonderful place for architectural fans.. It's a great place to learn about Thailand's historical background in architecture and about their royalty. Best to get a guide to take you around the place rather than just enjoying the view and take pics.

very busy!. Don't take photos, you will get in trouble! I had my camera in my hand and the guard wanted to look through my photos just to make sure I hadn't taken any! It is an amazing buddah - such a huge peice of jade that its carved from.

Amazing, simply amazing. Your camera will for sure run out of battery. The temple complex it's so big and so impressive that you'll be taking pictures all the time. The emerald Buddha represents so much for Thai people that you can for sure feel the energy at the place. The decor of the walls and the gold artifacts are absolutely unique. It's a must in Bangkok.
Must see in Bangkok. Great temple with ample area. A must see even if it gets crowded! Avoid the crowds and go in the early morning!
a good experience. a good and quiet place to visit with great relics of budha..carry lot of water as it gets hot and must have is a good camera..a nice place..
very nice. so many people in the place make sure you come it a jacket or long sleeve shirt. very unique experience
Beautiful. Beautiful temple with lots of shrines. Can be crowded in the afternoon so recommended to go in the morning. Some foodstands in the surroundings for cheap good food.

Great complex. The complex it is in itself is just amazing. The paintings, decor, architecture and the way everything looked was amazing. The buddha is quite small which surprised me comparing it to the leaning buddha but the mural and building its housed in is really breath taking. Wouldn't go out my way to visit but if you have time stop by, you won't regret it.

OK. We had already been in Bangkok for a few days before we went to Chiang Mai for the second leg of our trip. We had another day back in Bangkok on our way back, and as we hadn't seen the Emerald Buddha yet we made this a priority. By this time we had already seen quite a few temples across Thailand, and while the temples themselves were nice, we actually weren't that impressed with the Emerald Buddha. Maybe we are being harsh because we had seen so much already, but I think we had heard so much about it that it was a bit of an anti climax. It is probably still worth a visit, but if I was returning on a second visit I wouldn't go back personally. Be sure you bring water with you as it's very crowded and hot, and remember you can't wear footwear in to the temple so wear something comfortable that you can slip on/off easily

Beautiful Thai Architecture - A must see. Whilst the Emerald Buddha (actually Jade) is the main attraction, the murals detailing the life of Buddha around the outside of the room, and complex were what I found most interesting. The complex can get quite crowded during peak hours, but there are drinking water fountains dotted around if you need to cool down.

Beautiful but expensive and crowded. In fact is very beautiful, but I didn't like so much. There are to many tourist and the place gets crowded. And you need to pay 500THB.In Thailand, and Bangokok has a lot of beautiful and quiet temples, where you can really feel the Budhist tradition.Tip: if you really want to go, don't forget to get a pants. If you forget, you can rent in the entrance (you don't need to buy)

Stunning! Amazing mosaics! Must visit!. The Temple is fantastic. It is a must if you are visiting Bangkok. You can stop next to every single column and stare at the mosaic or Thai sculptures. It is beautiful. I spent there about an hour and a half walking around. You can go inside the temple and relax, meditate for a while looking at the tiny but impressive Emerald Buddha on his throne. It is an amazing place of Thai history. Don't forget to cover your knees and shoulders. If you forget, and you are wearing shorts, you can rent a traditional Thai skirt for a visit. The ticket is around 500 baht. The renting of the skirt is about 200 baht. Pictures are allowed.

Must Visit. You cant come to Bangkok and not see this beautiful temple. It's a fine display of oriental architecture and Bhuddist artistry. It's also not far from reclining buddha temple so you can visit both at a time. Must see .

Beautiful...just very crowded.. Beautiful and enchanting. Lots and lots of tourists so be prepared and it was a pity because it had lost that calm, quiet religious atmosphere but still something i wouldn't miss out on. They have booklets that will explain (i got hold of a korean one) but other languages also available. Next time ill visit the other temples.

Interesting. This is part of the Grand Palace which is seriously WOW! And this is the "jewel of the crown" so to speak and as such very busy so the crowds do detract from the experience but there's not much that can be done about that.
Big and beautiful. Very big and beautiful. Lots of people so might take some time before you get the clear view for your pictures. Recommend going early.

A must-see when in Bangkok. . The place is bustling with tourists. Visitors must follow a strict dress code. No sleeveless, shorts or skirts. You may borrow appropriate clothes at the shop just outside the gate. You will have to deposit 200 baht per person and will be refunded full once you returned the clothes. It's kinda sad that many tourists forgets that this place is a place for prayers and must treat it with respect.

Very special. The Chapel of the Emerald Buddha is very special. It is particularly important to Thais and the Buddhists as it represents a very sacred thing. The Buddha image is smaller than what I was expecting. However, one should show much respect as you visit this special place. This Chapel is part of the Grand Palace where the Kings of Thailand used to live. You will probably want to assign at least one half day to visiting Wat Phra Kaew and the Grand Palace. Try to visit Wat Po in the same trip. They are about back to back.

In the midst of Splendor, a Vision of the Divine. This temple is in the Royal Grand Palace grounds which are awesome and extremely luxurious with a huge stupa covered in gold leaf, a building supported by golden columns decorated with tiny mirrors, amazingly elaborately carved guardians that are at least three times life size and many other wonders, so entering the pavilion in the complex that contains this beautiful image is a surprise because you thought after wondering outside for a long time to assimilate all the details of the Palace that there could possibly be more left to impress you, but this Buddha, named emerald because it is actually one huge piece of jade will certainly impress. It is beautifully carved and fitted with elaborate gold crown and jewels that highlight the green color of the Buddha, and surrounded by the beautiful paintings of the hall, highlighted in gold it gives the impression of being in the midst of its own jewel casket, it is breathtaking.

Prepare for amazing architecture and enormous crowd. It is deffinietly something you have to see in Bangkok. Be careful for many people trying to get some money from you . Entrance cost 500 bahts and you can borrow clothing to cover up for free, or borrow them for 30 bahts before you enter in the shops. It was the low season in Thailand , but the crowd was still huge , so I can not imagine how it is in high season :) But still a must see ! And pay attention to brochures which says to respect Buddha and try to remember that Buddha should not be offended in any way, if you are not a Buddhist please respect other's feelings :)
Superb temple Emerald. Visited with family in May 2015. Pleased to see Beauty of nicely built temple and devine face of God Buddha.
Top Thailand Landmark. This is a proudly temple of Thai people, the most beautiful temple. It has art on the wall of great novel in Thailand, very very beautiful.

Beautiful example of a Thai Buddist temple.. This is another great example of the Thai Buddist Temple.
The buildings and the Buddha has been restored and maintained with love and care.
It's in the grounds of the Grand Palace so this is one temple you shouldn't miss.
No trip to Bangkok is complete without a visit there.

Very impressive. Lovely and well worth a visit. Spend at least a few hours here, there's a lot to see. Oh and don't forgret your camera like I did. I had to buy postcards. They're probably better than any photos I could take

Go early to avoid crowds!. This is well worth a visit and the grounds and buildings are beautiful. The emerald Buddha is extremely small, though, and one cannot see it well or take photographs of it, but it is worth visiting this icon of Bangkok.The temple complex is large, and I would strongly recommend going to this place as early as possible. We arrived shortly before opening time and found a queue of about five people, but upon leaving there were hordes and hordes of tourists, most of them on guided tours. I am very pleased to have come early and to have dodged the crowds!There are a great many things to see in the complex - there is a beautiful mural on the walls around the temple and it displays an interesting story. I perhaps should have hired a guide to explain the story to me! There are also souvenir guides on sale and, perhaps more importantly, some scented cool towels to help with the blazing heat. Go and see this temple - you will certainly not be disappointed.

Amazing - plenty to see!. It is quite pricey in comparison to other sites but is well worth it. The architecture is excellent, the colour is rich and vibrant (we were lucky to see it in glorious sunshine) and there was so much to see. It occupied a good few hours of our time and was great value for all that! Take particular time over the paintings in the corridors that surround the permiter - there's some great stuff to see there that otherwise might get overlooked.

Beautiful Buddha Temple. Amazing trip I had here when I visited this nice temple. Grand Palace has an entrance fee of THB500 (USD$17) , and it will take you 2 hours to tour around the whole place and one of the temples is the Temple of Emerald Buddha. Amazing temple to visit!Read my BLOG to know more about my journey here:http://olympusgirlinsg.blogspot.sg/2013/03/2013-asian-trip.html

Beautiful. If you can stand hoards of tourists and manage to survive the umbrella spokes in your eye and be able to navigate around the thousands of people taking photos and selfies, then it's a beautiful Buddha, probably the nicest I've seen on my short trip.

Temple of the really TINY jade Buddha. We must have done things in the wrong order. This is one of the top rated site in Bangkok, right? Did we miss something? The building are lovely. The palace grounds are very colorful (if not gaudy). Unfortunately, we visited the Temple of the Reclining Buddha first (which is HUGE!) so when we got to the Temple of the Emerald Buddha (which is really jade), it just seemed soooooo tiny. You walk into this room with a massive golden alter. You can't get even slightly close to it, and at the very tippy top of it is a tiny greenish figurine. It took me several minutes to realize that THAT was the famous Emerald Buddha. It almost made me chuckle. Sure for being a solid piece of carved jade, yes it was impressive, but why have it so high and far away? The alter itself was more impressive than the Buddha itself. I don't discourage you from going to see it, but if you have a choice in terms of which order you see things, go to the Temple of the Reclining Buddha second or else the jade buddha will seem even smaller than it actually is.

What an education. What a stunning Buddha easily found within the Grand Palace the pomp and ceremony surrounding this fellow is amazing! The change of costumes with the seasons means there is always something new to see here! Clean and well kept!

Very Interesting. I loved the story of this temple and the Emerald Buddha within it's walls. You need a very knowledgeable guide to fill you in on the background, otherwise you miss out on so much of what you're seeing.

Very nice place to visit. It costs 500 baths for one. You have to wear long pants or shirts, possibillity to borrow some clothes with 200 baths/cloth. For a better visit, come early (open from 8.30 to 3.30) because there is no shadow and more people visit it on afternoonswonderfull you can not leave Bangkok without knowing this enchantic temple awasome.
Beautiful. Beautiful albeit small. Stunning green colour which I found quite mesmerising. You cannot take photos.

Super hot and a lot of walking but worth it. It was hot but it was worth the view. I liked this better than my Grand Palace view. There were myriads of tourists. At least here, I could take a photo of me and the background without a lot of extras around. Haha!
Suggestion! Bring a fan and an umbrella. Wear hats and don't wear shorts or sleeveless.

Thailand's most sacred Buddhist temple. This and the rest of the Grand Palace is well worth a visit. The Emerald Buddha which was carved from a single jade stone is highly revered in Thailand. It is about 66cm tall and sits high up on a gold altar in this beautiful temple. There is an entry fee and a strict dress code: men must wear long trousers, sleeved shirts and shoes and women must 'cover up' and dress modestly. Shoes have to be removed before entering the temple.
Beautiful temple. One if the amazing temples of Bangkok very reasonable entrance fee. Emerald Buddha was beautiful and well worth seeing.
Beautiful Temple. We had a view of this temple from out hotel room and were excited to see it up close. This temple does not disappoint. Very beautiful!
Holy place. A beautifull temple with in the center the Emerald Buddha. It is a quiet place and the most hole temple of Thailand. I come regular to this temple to pray for Buddha and enjoy the people
Peaceful place. It's very peaceful beautiful place to visit with so many details. Move faster so you can see the whole place. Also spare a day & watch your step

Iconic must see!. The most important religious icon in Thailand. Very busy around the temple and through the palace complex with pilgrims and daily worshippers together with tourists; but worth the trip. Apparently carved from a single green stone and surprisingly small in size - about 2ft in size.
Museum. This has a great display of antique works. It is a relaxing walk around the Temple, minus the heat. The designs and architecture is full of detail and so amazing.

Too many people. But what is to be expected in an Asian country. The history behind this Buddha is very interesting. This is the king's Buddha. He changes the clothes on it with the change of the season's. Don't take photos or the police will take your camera. I didn't see the no photo sign and was taking a photo and the police tried to take my camera. I was able to hold onto the camera and show them I was deleting the photo and they let me keep it.

The only one in the world... The entire Buddha's image is made of emerald.Hence the name Emerald Buddha. It is crafted in one piece, and not assembled. As there are caretakers and security, no photographs allowed and has to be dressed proper to pay a visit.

Spoilt by Irresponsible Tourist and Touts. A very beautiful temple within the palace grounds. However its jam pack with tourist and very little organisation. Palace and temple grounds are littered with drinks and empty bottles. Tourist stepping on shoes placed outside the temple.BEWARE of scams! Many English speaking Thai locals will approach you with Alternative route to enter the palace or even says that the palace is close for the day and they will guide you to a tuk tuk that will scam you and take you for a ride.

Our visit to the holy tgai place. Really nothing to say splendit nice wunderfull interesting to visit full of history off budda and thai people relaxing take you time visit all places relax sit down no hurry and enjoy the artwork

Impressive -- Go early. Go early while still cool and before the crowds show up. Prepare for the folks selling things as you go from the street to the complex and also remeber you are visiting a shrine many come to worship at. If so, you will enjoy the temple.

Watch your Step! Move Faster!. Gear up those high optical zoom camera because you can take photo from outside. move faster when you are inside the temple and please do pay respect to the Emerald Buddha! please watch your step because others are offering prayers and its way too crowded.

The Number one important place to Visit in Bangkok. No visit to Bangkok or Thailand should be made without visiting the Most religious place within the "Land of the Smiles".the Emerald Buddha is considered the most holy of places and the buildings, monks and Buddhist devotees make this place an unforgettable experience.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

Amazing!. This place is amazing! There is gold everywhere, beautiful details. When I entered the temple I was touched with the beauty, it showed how they really respect the Buddha. A totally a must visit place.

Very nice. One of the major highlights of any Bangkok trip, this place is a must do. We didn't get a guide, but in hindsight its better to have a guide to tell you the background, context etc for the paintings and the statues. But even without a guide, we spent around 45-50 minutes to walk through the complex. Its beautiful and must see.
Most revered buddha statue in Thailand. Inside the Grand Palace this statue is NOT to be missed. If you only had one tourist place to see this is it.

A must see when in Bangkok. I have visited Wat Phra Kaew four times in the past 6 years and always find it fascinating. Each time I find new things to see and appreciate regarding Thai culture. There is so much to see that it is easy to get sensory overload. Although appropriate clothing can be obtained on site, it is best to review the clothing restrictions ahead of time and dress accordingly. Wat Phra Kaew and the Grand Palace are excellent for learning about Thai culture.
Beautiful . No pictures allowed, so get you memory ready to remember the beautifully handi-crafted emerald Buddha. Dress appropriately.

Emerald Buddha Temple great work of Architectural beauty.. Visited this place in May 2012. Its very beautiful place with spiritual air about it, great architectural ambience, peace and tranquility. Though photography of the Buddha is not allowed. Being a popular destination, it is crowded, but that is true for all such places anywhere. A must see destination when in Bangkok.

The visit in the temple is unforgetable. Thailland history and the significance of religion are manifested and demonstrated in this site. It gains another dimention just considering the amount of work and other resources dedicated to these rather than the well being of the people ...

Stunning but take water!. A must see. Stunning at every turn. Make sure you take water in with you as nowhere to buy any when you are in! Costs 500 Baht with entry to palace included (adjoining). You can hire clothing if you are not appropriately dressed (deposit returned). Oddly, I wore a short sleeved dress to the knee and was fine but husband had long shorts and had to put on long trousers!
Majestic. This temple has a large room filled with gold plated statues surrounding the Emerald Buddha sitting atop a golden pedestal.

Rich background but crowded. Went there in the morning, it is swarmed with tourist and even with cap and umbrella, you gonna still sweat all over your body! The architectures, statues and backgrounds are very rich and well maintained. The place is very clean. Remember to be respectful with the temple and statue.

Very hot and crowded. Even with a cap and umbrella you were still able to feel the heat. Can you even imagine that? The temple was very crowded with tourists from different places. But it was still nice seeing the statues of the Buddha and the temple

Most beautiful Buddha. what else I can say? I just speechless to see the Emerald Buddha. Pity that I cannot take pic of the statue, but I understand.
