Really necessary to make this heritage lasting forever. But, for the tourists of few Asian countries, they are horrible people! They're unmanned-selfish tourists that I even seen. Horrible!

Just Another Amazing Temple........ I can't say enough about Bangkok, beautiful temples and beautiful people. This was yet another beautiful temple we visited. Maybe we enjoyed it so much because there were not many tourists around and it made for a very relaxing experience. You really get to feel relaxed in the temple......Just another amazing temple.......

Lovely temple complex but busy. The actual complex is quite pleasant with lots of culture and architecture to admire. The emerald Buddha temple itself is naturally very busy. You are not allowed to take photos inside so you must get any snaps from the outside before you go in. The actual temple itself is very grand but you do get moved along quite quickly so eyes open! Worth a visit but be prepared for the crowds.

The Holy of Holies in Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha is said to be the most revered statue in Thailand and within this temple the sense of sacredness is almost palpable. If you visit merely as a tourist you will miss the point of being here. To get the best out of the experience, leave your shoes at the door ( a MUST), switch off the camera (another MUST) and quiet your mind before you go in. The experience is overwhelming.
Impressive site. Can be extremely busy and very very hot. So many hawkers and shops on the walk in.Wear pants and t-shirt - no leggings

Amazing but VERY crowed. It was a very beautiful site, but very very crowed and extremely hot. If I was to return I would make this the first visit of the day so not to be in late morning sun (I arrived at approx 9.45am)Some wonderful photographs and amazing knowledge now gained as I purchased a little book for 20thb (approx 50p) and i had all the info I needed.Highly recommended.Its 500thb to enter - this also give access to the palace

Worth seeing but spoilt by insane volume of tour groups. We went fairly early on a Wednesday morning but it clearly wasn't early enough- there were so many massive tour parties cramming in to the site in their droves we just felt like herded cattle.The emerald Buddha and temple around it was awesome as were the other epic buildings and monuments. We just wish we could've enjoyed them without being repeatedly poked in the eye by peoples umbrellas, shoved out of the way by crazed tour parties following their shouty guides or having people waving selfie sticks in front of them!It's relatively expensive to get in too and the staff at the front gate were incredibly rude and tactless in their dealing with people's dress for the temples. We found out men definitely aren't allowed to wear a sarong to cover their legs- 'skirts are for women only' we were told! Hmm.

Manic crowds. You have to see this little buddha, but be prepared for the hoards of tourists! Get there early to get temple clothes if you are not dressed correctly, as there is no queue for the garb early. Also getting off the beaten track in the temple complex you will find quiet cafes that are like oases that sell ice-cream, that none seems to be at except for a few westerners. There are also some interesting, very uncrowded museums at the periphery that are worth a look.

Too touristy. There are so many temples around Bangkok that this one fell a bit flat for me. I'd still recommend seeing it (along with the rest of the Grand Palace complex) but you can't get very close to the Emerald Buddha, there are security personnel everywhere telling you not to take photos, and it is crowded with tourists. The outside of the temple is beautiful but it's only worth a quick stop. I wouldn't spend much time there.
awesome. this is a must go place, there is so much beauty, hard to explain with words, this is one of the most beautiful religious places I`ve ever been to.

Get a guide!!!. I went there in early June 2015 and it was a great experience. I got a guide at the front gate of Grand Palace and he spoke good English and made the experience even better. Told us some interesting things about the Thai culture :)
The Best. This is the highlight of the Bangkok temple. The history in these building are vast with very good looking temples. Please go into the complex instead of just taking picture up front

Rude staff. The staff is extremely rude and unfriendly here.At entering the site a guard decided that i had to rent some pants. No problem.I entered the building where you can rent the pants, but there a woman said that my pants are good enough. I insisted and asked again if she was sure. She said "yes" and I bought a ticket in order to enter the site.Then I was approached by a staff member again who said to me that my pants were too short!!!I was wearing one of those that cover the legs until 5 cms above the ankle.But the female staff member next to him again decided that my pants were ok.I could go on and reached a turn style where one of the staff members said something to me which I did not understand.When I said: "Sorry, but I do not understand you.", he gave me a punch to the upper body and yelled. "Go!!"Completely unacceptable behaviour! I just did not dare to punch him back in a foreign country with apparently no respect for foreigners.They charge a huge amount of money, but are not welcoming the visitors.

Beautiful. Thai culture and history. An excellent place to visit. Beware of the scams and offers. Just go straight in and get a ticket/pass from the counter. Do not be swayed by people offering additional items. The entire complex is free to observe and appreciate. Make sure you have bottled water with you (if not there is a canteen where you can purchase water as well as some trinkets from).
Emerald Buddha. Didn't get too impressed with this one as the heat was so draining. But once you've seen the Wat Pho and Wat Arun, you've seen them all.
Emerald Buddha. the picturesquare area is good. What's distinct at this place is the emerald budha. its at little height in the altar and you can see from far. You cannot take photos/videos.

amazing temple and king palace. This temple is situated inside the grand palace of King of Thailand. but not used for residence any more . the palace is still used for king's family functions and guest house for visiting dignatories. The architure is awesome. photograph not inside the emarald budha temple but allowed outside the temple main building. place is a must visit.
Grate Temple. You can found a lot of Chinese & Indian.So crowded when we visit there.Very beautiful places,should go when you reach in Bangok.
must see. a great temple, but you can't take the emerald Buddha home damn, anyway another don't want to miss attraction like wat pho.
Surprisingly small fellow. Something you just need to see as you are in Bangkok. Just realize that it is quite a small fellow who you can easily miss, when you'r not paying attention :)

Looks amazing but incredibly touristy. I ended up bailing pretty quickly here. Massive crowds and it's quite a press, the ticket price is (relatively) high, and it's complete chaos. The staff are yelling into a bullhorn that "Buddha is not a tattoo, not a statue and deserves respect" but while it's a good message it only adds to the overall chaos of the place. If you go, go really early or really late.

Epitome of Thai Architecture. What a beautiful structure. The detail on every inch of the building is spectacular. If this is your first time in the area, this should definitely be one of your first stops. It's 500baht which includes the Grand Palace. That being said, once is probably enough. I would not pay again to come see this unless I was showing my friend around. This is why I say to get it out of the way early, so you have time to focus on other things while in Thailand. Be warned, this place can get extremely hot with the heat beaming off the floors, combined with the rush of the tourists piling off the buses.

Must visit. This temple is housed inside the Grand Palace complex and included in the ticket you buy to enter the Grand Palace (TB500).The place is just exquisite. The Buddha statue is mounted on a high platform and well lit.You need to remove your footwear to enter the temple and dressed very modestly. Photography is prohibited inside the temple. You can buy offerings at the entrance to the temple.Just fabulous !!!

Breathtakingly beautiful. I highly recommend this to be the last stop of your visit to the temples in Thailand as this could ruin all other temples for you. Keep a couple of hours aside for this. And a guided tour is recommended as there aren't many plaques elaborating on things. Also do keep hydrated and have sufficient protection from the sun as it can be very hot. Also please check the dress code (no sleeveless or shorts).

Gorgeous temple but beware of scammers outside the temple. The temple opens at 8:30 AM and the ticket is 500 Thai Bahts. Be sure to dress respectfully. Women can wear pants, skirt or a modest dress with below knee length and sleeves. The temple is a sacred ground, where people worship, so be respectful. The Emerald Buddha's robe is changed 4 times a year by the King or his designee. There are much culture and arts to appreciate. Shoes are not allowed inside the building. I have visited some other temples and lost shoes. Someone either wore them by mistake or had stolen them. i learned from that experience to bring a plastic bag for my shoes then put them in my knapsack rather then not having a pair of shoes to wear. The temple might be closed for official ceremonies, so be sure to check before going. The temple may be reached by boat, bus, or taxi. Beware of scammers lurking outside the temple. They seem to be polite and helpful and would suggest other temples and places to visit. They would tell you that the temple doesn't open until later because of some legitimate sounding reason。They would tell you about some government promotional sales that you don't want to miss as it was the last day. If you fell for it, they would help you get in to a Tuk Tuk (motorized trishaw) that would cost 40 Bahts to take you to all these wonderful places and back in time for the temple's opening. Once you get in to the Tuk Tuk, you are taken to see a few Buddhas. Another person would approach and help you go to the promotional sale. The Tuk Tuk would take you to a small clothing shop operated by Indians. There, they would try to make you have suits and shirts made for ridiculously high price. If you say you have no Thai money, they would say that any currency would do. They would go as far as having you show them the knid of money you have in your wallet. They would have someone take you to an ATM machine to show you how to withdraw money. If you have gone that far, you might be paying big bucks for junk stuff they claimed to have tailored made for you. If you realized you have been scammed and try to get out, they find every which way to hold on to you. Get out quickly as one never knows what might happen next. This is true as it happened to my friends, who were lucky enough to get out. If you do not want to be scammed, don't easily believe In strangers. Check legitimacy to avoid becoming a victim. Be prudent no matter where the place is as there are always scammers and pickpockets around.

OK. You buy your ticket for this attraction along with the Grand Palace and it's 500BHT which I think it's quite pricey for Bangkok. Apparently, it includes entrance fee for another temple elsewhere but we didn't get a chance to go so that portion of it is wasted. It's free for Thai people though. LOTS of people/tourists at this location. There are chedis and decently large grounds to walk around, but it just seemed much more commercial than the other top temples in Bangkok. You can't go inside the Grand Palace, just walk by outside so not much to see.

Glittering like Emerald !!!. Absolutely Blissful and so peaceful , we went to this pleasant temple on 19.05.15 , with 500baht entrance ticket we can visit 8 beautiful tourist attractions.1.Grand palace2.Emerald Buddha3.Coins museum4.Queen sirikit Art GalleryAll the 4 we have to visit on the same day of ticket purchase.5.Ananta Samakhom throne hall6.Vimanmek Mansionand 2 more places near by , I forgot the name, but it's there in the ticket, When we sit in silence after doing all the formalities inside the temple we will be very peaceful and feeling relaxed.Must visit for all age groups when you are in Bangkok.In one day we can visit this valuable place along with most important places like Wat Poo , Wat Arun and even we can visit Sriraj Medical museum.Thanks a lot for everything...Loving you so much...Peacefully yours.S M Bega Raaj.Happy travelling...

Worth a look. Beautiful place. Don't expect a huge emerald buddha though- it's actually somewhat diminutive, though it is made out of jade, so it's still pretty awesome. We went here and almost fell prey to the "it's closed today, but I can take you to another one" scam but kept walking- the wrong way of course around, but got inside and the whole complex was very nice.

Great temple not to miss. This temple is unique in the sense that it has green or jade Buddha statue. It is beloved to be very sacred to the local people so you will find lot of people if you go in the mid morning to evening time. The best time will be early in the morning to beat the rush of people.

Incredible. We took a taxi, a boat and we walk a lot in a 90 degrees , but worth all that. Was beautiful, the Buddha is small ,comparing with the Buddhas, You must dress very conservative.,They don't let you go inside if you are not cover your arms and no shorts.

A Must-See for Visitors to Thailand. Wat Phra Kaew was built to house the Emerald Buddha, bought from Laos to Bangkok in 1778.The temple is the most sacred in Thailand and is an epicenter of Thai religion, art and culture.Sometimes the temple is closed to foreign visitors for special or royal occasions. Check with your hotel before going there.Often you will arrive and scam artists will tell you it is closed when it is actually open. They then invite to take you to other temples with jewelry shop and Thai silk shop scams along the way.Politely tell them to get lost.The fee for foreigners is Baht400 (about) USD12.

Fairytale beauty. Very crowded by about 11.30 am, No cameras allowed inside. The building itself is so stunning. If you are looking to get photos be quick when you get the chance as the amount of tourists will mean a few seconds to get a shot without someone walking straight into the frame!
Must see. It's a world treasure. However, all the other tourists know this too, so you should go very early (or in the rain if you don't mind it)...

A must see temple. This is the first time I have saw a green Buddha. Excellent temple within the royal palace vicinity. Suggest to carry your own water bottle as you will not find cold water in the area.

Temple of huge hollow lobster filled with zilch. 2000 bats for a huge lobster and 50gms or less of very very tasty lobster meat. what more could i say about this exorbitant dish? So much for a giant calcium ball that you might fall for from the pics in the menu.

the not to miss temple when in Bangkok. Yes it is touristic but it is also local, the sights sounds and smells are mindblowing, the golden colours the fine masterpieces, a must to see, wear respecatble dress to avoid problems
The best temple ever. I see many stories of Raamakian on the wall around the temple... yes around the temple... it's very amazing... and you can see emerald Buddha here...
Another beautiful temple. If you love History, into Buddhism, you will love this temple. It is beautiful, high above the ground and easy to get to from Downtown Bangkok.
Amazing. Enjoyed learning the history of the historical landmarks throughout Bangkok. Highly recommend using a guide for your travels.

Thai massage at its origin. Definitely book a thai massage in wat phra medicine school. Best experience ever.
Apparently this is where the art of thai massage originated. Well worth it.
Very Pooor. The Thai people feel authentic veneration to this temple and this buda. It is nice to see but it is so far and is so tiny that we could not see very well.
Emerald buddah. This place was packed it was hot and you had to were long pants. However it was a good experience for me and I'm glad I went

Volume of people took away from quality of experience. I hate to give something so beautiful a 4/5 rating, but when i think of my experience, the first thing i think of is how overwhelming it was to be so crammed in with so many people--the beauty of the structures comes second. The main building is the most lavish building i have ever seen, and I was rendered speechless by it for a good ten minutes! That being said, i enjoyed Wat Pho and Wat Arun more because they were equally awe inspiring in their own ways and not overwhelmingly crowded.

a great piece of culture. Not an awful i can say about it, its a tourist spot nturally and a great piece of Thai culture.
Note to the more rowdy out there. This is one of Bangkoks most precious heritage centre. There are armed guards around the place, dont mess around

Emerald Buddha. We planned to visit this on a day when there was a ritual to change the cloths of Buddha. This happens twice a year. To much of the fun we were able to spot prince of Thailand. We waited for more than 2 hours to see the Prince of Thailand. Prince arrived with his set of guard, I think 7 layers of security and then he went to change the cloth of Buddha. Entire process took around 45 mins to 1 hours. Temple premises was awesome.
Overated. The emerald buddha is very small and not that easy to see. Photography is not allowed inside, so you have to snap through a window to get an image.

overcrowded. It is beautiful but just overloaded. Don't wear shorts and bring your own long sleeve shirt other wise you end up wrapped in a sort of curtain for the visit and you suffer from the heat and at some point stop enjoying the visit

Nice temple but the weather is hot. Please go in the early morning but the weather in afternoon is terrible.there hv 2 extra museum is inclusive coin museum and queensirikit museum,pls wear long pants to enter museum,beware of ppl outside the temple,don't trust them

Smaller than I expected. Take a bag with you as you have to take your hoes off to enter most of the temples and we were told shoes got stollen You must be covered up a well ankles and arms have to be covered up and no flip flops they are quite strict
Emerald buddah. Looooooooooooved it so happy we went would recommend it to everyone. Remember to wear long pants and no singlets

Unique but Crowded. This place was packed full of bus tour groups making it a very crammed place to visit. The buddha itself is not able to be viewed up close, and photos are not allowed. Compared to other Wat's in the area, this temple was my least favourite of them all, partly due to the immense crowds.

Crowded. There are a ton of tourists waiting to catch a glimpse of this 66cm tall (approx) jade Buddha. It was interesting to learn that they change its outfits every season (3 different ones in a year.) Worth seeing, especially when visiting the grand palace anyway, but be aware that you'll deal with shoving and crowding. (And also, no photos are allowed inside.)

You won't believe your eyes!. On a glorious sunny day the wat looks incredible, fairy tale like. Everything was glistening in the sun and looked amazing. It was very crowded even though we got there dead on the opening time. Even the crowds of tour groups couldn't take its magic away. A note though, PLEASE respect the no touching signs. The amount of people we saw touching the statues with "no touching signs" was so disheartening.

good for visit and sense of relaxation and serenity. the temple in itself is good and what makes it great is that the chao phraya river, the temples and grand palace make a good trip schedule for a day and tell a lot about the Thai culture
Unfortunate. As the temple was under renovation we could not go up side but saw it from out ward, it looked very attractive.
Very Nice - Amazing. This is very nicely crafted Emerald Buddha - amazing worth a visit.....queue will be there so be prepared and tae care of your belongings

A Highlight of Bangkok. From the religious and historical standpoints this is an important stop in the exploration of Bangkok. It is also an architectural delight distilling much of Thai traditional design in one general area. Be respectful as this is an actual place of prayer. Dress appropriately. Try to visit in the morning when it is cooler.
Marvellous Buddha. Must visit on temple tour of Bangkok. Whether you are on a honeymoon or bachelor outing it is a must visit. Emerald Buddha is the symbol of rich thai cultural heritage

Beautiful. a beautifully preserved temple with a magnificent statute.
dislike, the attitude of people managing the place. not many foreigners are aware about removal of shoes at temples and there should be proper guidance
Very Stunning!. Was great to visit the Emerald Buddha. It was a very packed day - be sure to take off your shoes before entering and do not take photos of it - you must respect their culture!
Outstanding!!!. Wow!!!! Wow!!!! Wow!!! you cannot imagine the details on this temple it is truly stunning... a must see!!!!

The REAL Far East!. Absolutely stunning! What everyone thinks of when they think of the Far East. Can get a little hot, but plenty of places to sit and relax in the shade. If you come improperly dressed, officials can supply you with FREE "proper" clothing at the entrance. Can be combined with a short walk to the Temple of the Reclining Buddha. Best way to reach it is by boat on the river
photographers dream. anyone going here for the first time stand by to be impressed and make sure there is plenty of space on the memory card
No pictures allowed. Worth the visit, but VERY crowded and no pictures allowed inside the building. Interesting point is the seasonal costume which is fitted to the Buddha!

Great experience in Thailand. Failing to visit Wat Phra Kaew on Na Phra Lan Road- the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, would be like missing out the Vatican and the Sistine Chapel in Rome. Let me offer two reasons for this. 1. The sheer scale of the glittering, soaring beauty of the Temple itself is...

Mesmerizing. The temple and the palace...the whole are is mesmerizing. Very beautiful.
Downside: very crowded with locals!!!

An important and unique temple in Thai Buddhist tradition. Experienced as part of a personal guided tour of the Grand Palace. The Grand Palace is a real must to visit for any tourist with the remotest interest in culture and history. Represents good value and as a solo traveller I found taking a personal guide, at an extra cost, offered a good way of seeing and learning something of the history. I'd recommend going during a dry day as the heavens opened and with thunder storms, it was not the best time to experience the majesty of this special place. I will re-visit again if I return to Bangkok there is much I'd like to revisit or see which I did not fit into my original visit.
a must place, near the palace. a must to visit. Can be combined with the grand palace, river cruise, wat arun. beautiful art work, impressive to witness the decoration, and prayers going on.

Temple and palace are fabulous - don't miss it. Go early or late as possible to avoid the huge crowds and tour groups.Make sure you cover up bare legs and arms and be prepared to queue a while to enter the temples.

Don't Miss This Temple or You Have Not Reached Thailand. This is the most famous and spectacular temple to visit...definitely a must visit landmark temple. If you just want to visit 1 temple this is The ONE! ...amazing size and architecture and a long history.

Amazing temple. This beautiful place has to be on the list of top ten things to do and see in Bangkok. I would recommend an early visit. The temples are busy and the earlier you can go the better as it gets too hot by lunch time. You will need to wear appropriate clothing. Tops that cover the shoulders and also make sure your knees are covered. no strappy tops or shorts. You can loan long legged pants if required.

A MUST Experience in Thailand. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is situated in the Royal Palace complex.Failing to visit Wat Phra Kaew - the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, would be like missing out the Vatican and the Sistine Chapel in Rome.Let me offer two reasons for this.1. The sheer scale of the glittering, soaring beauty of the Temple itself is beautiful. You can photograph and film to your heart's content - from outside the Temple. Wat Phra Kaew is the Holiest of Holy sites in Thailand. Thai Buddhists in particular will make a special visit to the Emerald Buddha - which many of them believe is endowed with 'special powers.'2. The second reason is because, as well as being steeped in centuries of myth and supposed magic the Emerald Buddha, the statue itself is lovely. Until the King of Thailand became ill recently he would ascend the steps around the bot and change the garments of the Emerald Buddha. Each change of clothing to reflect the season of the year - there are three in Thailand.This robing of the Emerald Buddha is now carried out by the son of the King, the Crown Prince.Before you enter the Temple, you must remove your footwear. There are lots of racks - just remember to note the position of your shoes. Don't worry - no person will take your shoes.From the blazing sunlight - you are cast into the muted light of the Inner Temple. Remember, this is a VERY Holy place - so be absolutely respectful. If you try to use a camera of any kind - you will be asked politely to leave. If you insist toclick away - your camera may be confiscated. Respect the rules.There are no chairs - people stand at the back or sit on the floor.When you sit - DO NOT POINT your FEET in the direction of the Buddha. It is a gross insult.The Emerald Buddha statue is very small - so don't expect a colossus. Also "Emerald" refers to the colour. The stone of the Emerald Buddha is Green Jade or jasper.Is it lovely - In its special setting, with Thai devotees and a huge sense of peace - yes it is very lovely.Once outside you can buy photos of the Emerald Buddha itself.How to get there?Cheapest and fastest? Take the Skytrain to Saphan Taksin station and walk a few metres into the Public Ferry landing. Unless you are very rich - skip the offers of a long tailed boat for 500 baht - go to the window and buy a ticket to Grand Palace for 11 baht. It is much more comfortable than the long-tailed boats and your fellow passengers are many monks on their way to the many Temples and Schools which line the Chao Praya river.Disembark at the Grand Palace Pier - ask - everyone will help you.Directly in front of you is the Grand Palace.Crooks will come to you and say the Palace is closed - it is a lie - they want to take you to a jewellery shop where they receive large commissions.The Grand Palace is big - make sure you have comfortable shoes.Bare shoulders, midriffs or mini-skirts are NOT permitted. It is a respect thing. For about 100 baht you can 'borrow' a pair of 'pyjama trousers' and a 'drape over blouse'. Enjoy your visit.
Peaceful Place. You can see the golden Buddha here and it is an very peaceful place and one temple which we should not miss.

The Sacred Temple. Whenever you go into temple of Emerald Buddha , you 'll be in peacful and happy feeling.
It's not only the most beautiful decoration and architecture but also the important treasure of Thailand Grand Palace. If you visit Bangkok , do not miss to realize how wonderful it is.

Go early before the crowd hits. Amazing to see but difficult to appreciate as the mass of people can make it uncomfortable to navigate. Parking can be challenging as tons of tour buses pack the surrounding streets. Don't think of trying to find a quite place to meditate - not unless you go during poor weather and off hours.
Bring your binoculars. A bit of a disappointment as you can't get very close to the statue, and can only take photos from outside the temple. Impressive building but bring a telephoto lens.
The most beautiful temple . You will take alot of time just admiring the small and magical details Infront of your eyes... A civilisation highly respected

One more temple not to miss. Depending on your itinerary you may already be tired of looking at temples, but this one isn't so much about the inside but more about the building itself and the surroundings. Also it's not that big, so just a look at least

Gold, Purple and Emerald - Splendid. Beautiful Ramayan inspired murals, temples plated in gold with colorful patterns I'd rarely seen before and wonderful statues - this was one of the places I used to identify Thailand with before I visited it. Must visit.

The Most Impressive of Temples in Bangkok. Without doubt, the most impressive Buddhist temple I have seen so far! The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is magnificent in terms of architecture, with plenty of history behind it. The pillars themselves impress on their own. Crowds are huge - so be prepared, especially when the Grand Palace is open. Also take a walk around the huge complex where there is a large Golden stupa, a prayers hall, and gorgeous stories of the Ramayana on the walls of the temples.

Hard to miss (and you shouldn't!) when visiting the Grand Palace complex. Absolutely beautiful. It does get very busy and is occasionally closed for religious ceremonies but these are publicised at the entrance to the palace - don't believe the scammers who tell you the place is closed! Don't try to take a photo - the military security will take your camera and delete the photos if you do - and that can be quite an intimidating experience!

a beautiful place. Wear proper dresses, half short and sleeves are not allowed. One of the beautiful temple in the Bangkok. It is in Grand Palace premises.Inside the temple photography is not allowed.
Budhdha Temple. This was very impressive. The temple is open everyday. A magnificant temple, neat and clean, peaceful. It was a right place fro meditation.

Very quiet temple. Not touristy. Liked the quiet atmosphere. No hawkers trying to get your attention. Go early in the day to avoid the heat and walk around to see the excellent architecture and history of the temple
Great temple. It is a great temple very crowded with visitors of different nationalities beautifully decorated you feel the luxurious of building and the encient history of Budha.

Be sure to admire Ramakien Murals around the temple. Yes, the temple of Emerald Buddha is a must see as thousands of reviewers have said. Surprisingly, I did not find that many tourists around the murals. You can start clockwise as soon as you enter. The mural paintings depicting the Thai version of the Indian Ramayana epic is wonderful. What intricate details and emotions expressed in all faces. Even if you do not know the story, you will eventually get it. On a hot day, it offers great shade. you can always take a detour to see the temple and other structures and get back to continuing the mural till you come back to where you started. Do not miss the jaw-dropping black-white painted door with at least 50 dragons. At first, it is easy to miss. It is on another temple building besides the Emerald Buddha. Not many walk around there.
Hot and jam. Good historic place and the templs is gorgeous. Besides are many tourist interested places. however， there is always so jam in traffic. It is recommended going there by ferry

Magnificent Temple. The Emerald Buddha is located in a beautiful temple on the Grand Palace grounds. Be prepared for the huge crowds of tourists trying to see the magnificent green, jade Buddha. You can go inside if you take your shoes off. Try to get towards the front so you can sit down and take in the spectacular alter with the Buddha at the top. It is rather small but with the lighting, it really stands out on the ornate alter. When visiting the grounds bring an umbrella because it is very hot and there is not much shade as you stroll around the grounds. Bring a bottle of water because I did not see any place to buy any and you will need it.

Be ready for a hot, crowded and touristy place. I went there early (09:00 am) in the morning and expected the place not to be that much crowded: wrong! Although the temple and the decorations are beautiful, the heavy crowd makes the visit less pleasant. Be ready to deal with many groups of tourists and people using open umbrellas to protect against the sun.

Most spectacular temple!. If you only have one day in Bangkok, this is the attraction you should visit! Very impressive! Be aware there are a lot of scams on the way to the temple. We were approached various times by 'random' people informing us the temple is closed that day. Do not trust anybody like this! The temple is open everyday and you will see at the entrance.There is a dress code for this attraction, but you can wear skirts and shorts and get something to cover up at their wardrobe in exchange for a fee. I also recommend an audio guide. You will get to understand more of the buildings in the area.

Early morning must. You must see this beautiful statue. Though small in stature, it's beauty is mountainous. Beat the crowds and arrive when it opens. Also beat the heat. Take the time to read or listen to a guide about the history of the Buddha. Quite fascinating. Small tip: When visiting temples, take a foldaway shopping bag and keep your shoes with you when you have to take them off. We do this everywhere we go and on this occasion were glad we did as someone had their shoes stolen.

Beautiful, wild style. Thai wats are so distinctive. I love to contrast them with Japanese temples because the decorative styles are so radically different. Wat Phra Kaew is one of the best examples of Thai religious architecture (not surprisingly). It's a riot of colour and statuary while also somehow being a place of contemplation. The Phra Kaew image is also special. I expected a giant but it's small and a clear object of reverence.
Must see!. This must be a part of anyone´s Bangkok itinerary. There are lots of temples to see, not only the emerald buddah. This is also the location of the Royal Palace.
You will not believe your eyes. This temple is amazing and as for the Buddha - its awe inspiring. What more can I say - visit this place - you won't be disappointed.

Go in the early morning. We went in the lat morning/noon and was extremely hot. Furthermore, it was a Sat and extremely crowded. Perhaps this was the reason why we didn't really enjoy the visit. Nonetheless, we caught a glimpse of the Emerald Budha after squeezing through the hordes of pple. There's also lots of wall arts that depicted the history of the temple.

Amazing!!!. When you enter the temple you are overtaken by the myriad of details and intricate craftsmanship beautiful gems used to adorn the altar and walls have exquisite depictions of Asian stories; the Buddha itself is not very big but the altar and all the surroundings of the temple itself will take your breath away, this Buddha is very dear to the Thai people and quite revered.

Must see!. With almost 400 temples in Bangkok it may be hard to choose which to see, but the Emerald Buddha is a must. This jade Buddha sits within a stunningly beautiful temple and the grounds are gorgeous. The buddha itself sits atop a multi tiered, several feet high golden structure that is equally beautiful. It is an iconic piece of Thai culture.
Beautiful Wat, but very crowded. One of the many beautiful things to see in Bangkok. Impressive and very sacred. The colours all gleam with life, the gold shines in a vision of beauty.
Nevr seen such a piece carved ina single large emerald. So beautiful and charming that you would like to leave. I felt peace radiating out of the statue. A must if you are in Bangkok
Favourite temple. No pictures allowed inside this temple so make sure to soak it all in! We sat down for a bit to soak in the beauty inside this temple.

Details are amazing - book with tour with tong. Great place to visit, but ensure you book a guide "tour with Tong" to get the best benefits of the beauty you are looking at.The same applies to all tours - Grand palace etc
good temple. amazing workmanship to see in the temple, and has a huge statue of lord buddha.lots of paintings of ancient stories of lord buddha.

Amazing and Superb!. I love the architecture and its detail. Its beautiful!I think it never runs out of tourists People everywhere.. really crowdedI don't mind to come back here once again when it's a little bit quiet so I can take a lots of photograph without being interrupted The weather was terribly hot at 10 am. Be sure to bring your beautiful/cool hat ot umbrella and off course sun glasses.Dress code's rule is quite strict: no sleeveless shirt, no mini skirt, no ripped jeans, no short.The ticket fee is 500 baht/person.
Breath taking. Worth every penny to visit this shrine. Its one of the best Budhha statues in the world. I enjoyed the visit thoroughly.

Sad and pathetic Emerald Buddha. There was no temple! just a very poor little room where the palace was..this whole thing is a sham. I went on this tour from the Nana hotel and was very let down, unless they took me on the wrong tour.
Nice. I really liked it, went there around 2pm and there was hardly any there. The temple is made out of marble and has some amazing designs.

Emerald Buddha.... This temple is within the compound of the Grand Palace and located at the center. Before you enter into this palace you need to take off your shoes. Ladies should not wear dress above the knee and gentlemen should wear pants - shorts are not allowed. If my readings are correct, the Buddha in this temple is coming from Laos when Thailand invaded Laos. Correct me if I am wrong. The temple is a bit congested if you want to see the emerald buddha inside.The entrance fee is quite expensive if you are from Southeast Asia except probably if you are from Singapore or Malaysia.Anyway, a nice visit to this temple if you are inside the Grand Palace. Actually, it's part of the Grand Palace visit itinerary.

TMV (tourist must visit). How could you go back home without seeing, one of the most beautiful temple of thailand or even southeast Asia? TMV!the decors are sumptuous and the cleanliness up to royal standards. such a peaceful and powerful place too!

MUST SEE. This is a must see. If there is nothing else that you do in Bangkok while you are there then you must go and see the Emerald Buddha. It is beautiful and the Temple grounds are amazing to see. When you are there you will catch yourself just constantly looking around just in amazement.

Too many visitors - no room to move. The Grand Palace has become an attraction for Chinese bus tours with a result of large queues, too many people and being shoved around. I am sure it brings in money for the maintenance, however it is no longer a pleasure.

Symbol of Thailand. Wat Phra Kaew full name was Wat Phra Si Rattana Satsadaram. It is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple in Thailand. With the Emerald Buddha, this temple became the attraction of Bangkok. No one is allowed to touch the statue, except the King. The King will change the cloak around the statue three times a year, corresponding to the summer, winter, and rainy seasons because Thai people believe that it will bring fortune to Thailand in each season. No one allowed to take a photo of the Emerald Buddha. Everyone must wear appropriate clothes such as long skirt and T-shirt, or else the soldier wouldn't allowed you to go inside. The area of the temple was huge and clean. Everywhere in the temple will have the soldier to guarded temple.

respect all religions. Learn about other religions and learn to respect by being dressed properly and listening to the guides who give good back ground and provide full details (depends on your interest)

Must visit. The temple is located in Grand Palace where you require to dress up properly. No short no sandal. If you can find one of this, there is a rental shop at the front of main entrance. Emerald Buddha is the incredibly wonderful. Recommended to visit

My #1 at Bangkok. While writing my review, there where 5,459 Reviews. Nothing I really can say that was not been written before.I can say it very simple. A MUST....... TRIP with The Grand Palace while in Bangkok. Try to do it by yourself and not with a trip, because you are going to need a time to really enjoy this amazing place. Give your self a few hours at the place and take an extra SD card for a lot of pictures..... :)My #1 with the grand palace while at Bangkok

Beautiful. a very large temple with many breath taking works.needs a whole morning to see everything.good for photography.don't wear short pants and sleeveless tops when entering the temple.although u can borrow a cover up for free, it should take a while in line.don't trust the people standing outside the place telling u the temple is closed for lunch, ceremony or anything.the temple never closes and u must walk into the front gate to get to the ticket booth inside.ticket price: 500 baht (including Grand palace and Wat Phra Kaew)
nice temple. Very busy, but a nice walk. Could be worth getting a tour guide to tell you lots of stories and facts.

Be prepared!. The glitz and glitter that is Thailand was on display, as well as the spiritual elements - I just wish that I was better prepared. I arrived not long after opening (a definite plus given the crowds later on) wearing a top that only just displayed my shoulders, that I had covered with a sarong. Apparently, a covering is not sufficient, and I still had to hire a shirt to wear! Oh well, it was only a minor inconvenience. A bigger inconvenience was trying to get a taxi to return to my hotel - I paid three times the price to return to my hotel than I did on the trip to the temple as all taxis refused to use their metre and I had to barter. If you have the time (I didn't) use public transport! Still, a great place to visit...I cannot emphasise this enough - get there early!!!!!

Again part of a tour. The temples are impressive, look at the amazing art work. I repeat my comments on the other temples. We were just outnumbered and it was a job to get close or see things due to being pushed and shoved by hordes from bus tours.

Go early and miss the crowds. As per the title go early before it gets busy and too hot, otherwise it's just unpleasant. Cover up from head to toe or else you will have to put a deposit down for clothing at the main reception, which you can get back upon your return. Very much worth the visit though, very beautiful.

Inspiring!. I was breathless when we entered the area. One is transported back in time. The restoration process has been remarkable. Go early before the heat sets in, or be sure to bring a sun umbrella and plenty of water to drink. Take your time and enjoy. This is Thai culture at its best. The extensive murals are reason enough to visit and absorb the history.

Wish they would do timed admissions. I was in Bangkok for a work trip, and made this my one touristy activity in the oppressive May heat. The Wat Phra Kaew grounds are stunning and well-maintained, and it's obvious why this site is such a treasure. I particularly enjoyed walking around the buildings surrounding the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, which itself was completed mobbed with people. You can find a nice spot to rest in the shade on the steps of one of the outlying mural halls. HOWEVER, as other reviews have noted, the overwhelming theme is the aggressive mobs of tour groups, seemingly often from China, who move like a battalion of soldiers, unafraid to mow down innocent bystanders who are unlucky enough to get caught in their path. It's really a shame that the temple's administration can't organize timed admissions, so that at least there is some regulation of the crowd. I arrived at 8am for the 8:30 opening, and by 8:15am there was already a queue of bus tour folk pressing against my back to get in. I know that different cultures have different understandings of personal space, but this was still extreme. I'm glad that I went, but be forewarned of this unfortunate aspect. Another tip: a lot of cab drivers around the site seem to want to take advantage of tourists. I went through 4 before 1 agreed to turn his meter on. Be careful!!
Wonderful architecture. It's a temple situated inside grand palace and a bit inside the palace area. Worth every penny to visit here.

An amazing spectacle. This place is a must for all travellers to Bangkok, but beware.People will tell you that the Temple and Palace are not open and will try to get you to go somewhere else, IGNORE THEM ALL. My advice would be to simply go to the entrance and see for yourself if it is open and go in.The buildings are very ornately decorated and in pristine condition, ensure your camera is fully charged with lots of space for pictures.The only downfall is the endless amount of Japanese tourists who walk around with umbrellas who will walk into you and hit you in the face on several occasions with these retched things.

Excellent.. Must see. Entry fee 500 bhat.Children free.Grand architecture.but it takes lot of time to view.Must have sufficient time to view everything .In scorching sun it is very tiring. Must have umbrella.

Emerald buddha- fantastic shrine!. The temple is part of the Grand palace complex & entry ticket costs 500 bhat. Start early & dress beautifully - cause ur brain would love to click hundreds of pics. Once your enter, Next to entrance gates are 15ft tall yakshis- huge & painted intricately. All sides of the temple hav corridors with beautiful mural painting with gold enamel. Golden spires & Ankor Wat layout- fantastic. When you take a walk around central shrine corridor- catch a glimpse of the long rows of garuda statues. Photography is not allowed inside the central shrine- Emerald buddha or rather Jade buddha is on a high pedestal surrounded by numerous buddha statues & decor. The whole sight is spectacular- take few moments to sit & enjoy it! Once you exit, next to the Golden spire, there are lots of building with intricately designed exteriors- totally photographers paradise!! They serve water right opposite to the central shrine for free, but would suggest to carry your own bottles n hats to beat the heat. Emerald buddha temple- photographer s paradise!!
Neat. Another amazing temple - they are everywhere in Thailand. The Emerald Buddha was smaller than expected, but still was beautiful. It is worth seeing!

A national treasure but sadly overcrowded and overwhelming. I have visited the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and Grand Palace during all my visits since I was a kid (my parents are Thai but I was born in the US). Its beauty never ceases to amaze. But I found the visit today to be exceptionally overwhelming and overcrowded. There were buses and hoards of Chinese tourists who appear to have taken over the place. It's impossible to walk to around and admire and appreciate the beauty of this historic and national treasure.Also beware of scammers outside the entrance. They tell you that the Enerald Buddha doesn't open until a certain time when free admission is offered for the day. They try to get you to take a tuk tuk to other sites until it's time to enter the temple. The temple opens daily from 8:30am - 3:30pm. Do not fall for these scams! I think they should do a better job regulating the number of visitors that can enter each time. What a shame! This amazing sight that has such significance in Thai history has become extremely chaotic and nearly impossible to navigate.
The Emerald (jade) Buddha. Again, worth seeing, but very crowded. The emerald Buddha is very small and hard to photograph. I think this is one that you can't take pictures inside the temple.

5 for the spectacle, 0 for the Chinese. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a stunning, must-see experience on the banks of the river in Bangkok.BUTDon't go if you can't get there within ten minutes of the opening time, because then it starts to get overrun with rude, arrogant, physically threatening Chinese tourists who think they rule the world. Others are meant to just get out of their way. During our visit, I was physically assaulted by two or three people who wouldn't let me stand in place of their photograph - and one of them actually spat at me!Memo to the operators of the venue: double the entrance fee (it's peanuts anyway!) and halve the number of people who you allow in....it would make a beautiful place that much more appealing for all.

Don't feel bad about skipping this. Oh my god this place was crowded. There is no shortage of amazing buddhas in Thailand, and this tiny jade buddha is not one of them. Feel free to skip and visit the more beautiful and serene Wat Pho.

Definately see this!. This Buddah is a beautiful jade sculpture and sitting high above the floor. It is much smaller than I expected and there are lots of crowds to see it. The King of Thailand has donated multiple gold outfits for this Buddah. Make sure you wear respectful clothing and to enter the temple you must remove your shoes. As others have said, bring water as well. There is no photography allowed in this temple. All that being said, go. The complex is also beautiful and peaceful.

Immortal Art. That was really shocking how gorgeous they are designed and builded up the castle and tmeples.GOLD! GOLD! GOLD! GOLD!Each piece has some of story...Like: everythingsDislike: when we enter into temple of Emerald Buddah the monks asked as to stay on knees. Buddah is not my God. I am tourist and Buddah for me just an experince in tourism.

Part of The Grand Palace. When we came to see the grand palace there is SO much to see including the temple of emerald buddha. Luckily the doors were open and we got to take a look. Really quite something. The whole place, the palace, the temples, the statues....all just so full of history and really impressive how it's all been built! Great day out!
Just a glimpse . Saw a glimpse of this bhuda ...left it too later, however got a real appreciation of how it is revered . Beautiful setting even when jam packed with visitors

Overcrowded and difficult to get s good view . This was my least favourite attraction on Bangkok
The place is nice enough but getting to see the main attraction is just too stressful
It is overcrowded and unpleasant
You can't take photos of it either which is a pain
Find a quiet day to go if you can
Part of Grand Palace. This wat is part of the grand Palace. Also a must see. Come early before the temperature rises and all bus tours arrive.

Unique!. This is a must see and visit place in Bangkok. The temple itself is stunning and beautiful. Tourists need to be dressed appropriately to enter the temple or the guards will not allow you to enter to the temple. The temple was crowded with tourists and you need to be aware that not all races and cultures are used to queuing - many people will just push you out their way. It is a temple and should be treated with respect. Recommend to come early to visit in order to avoid the sunshine and heat. Also recommend you bring a bottle of water with you. Overall worth a visit.

It's definitely #1 attraction but take water and wear the right clothes. The temple and the surrounding temples and Grand Palace are incredible, there's no other way of saying it. The most elaborate decor, gold on pretty much everything and sparkly jewels all over the show that my 4 yr old was bewildered with. It is however very busy and Bangkok is roasting hot so dress right (trousers for men plus something with a short sleeve as a minimum and then full length trousers or skirt for ladies and something to tops to cover your shoulder les and upper body. Kids they are more relaxed with so shorts are ok). Take plenty of water, there are enough little street stalls outside selling bottled water for 10bhat a bottle so just stock up before going in. You should be patient for the other tourists as they can get a little pushy and selfish but getting wound up won't help! We arrived on the water tourist boat which was a great way to see the river and the city. We left on a tuktuk despite a couple of them wanting to rip us off before landing a nice decent driver.

Unique.... Again I think that it is difficult to review a temple/religious item. The Emerald Buddha is very beautiful. It's on the grounds of the Royal Palace which is convenient. To enter the area you have to have to be dressed appropriately...which is reasonable given the nature of where you're going. As always you have to deal with crowds, but in April it wasn't too bad. Amazing architecture etc.

fine. While in Bangkok, Thailand to visit the main shrine - Temple of the Emerald Buddha. The temple itself is located within the Royal Palace, to get inside, you need to wear closed toe and closed-toe shoes. Those who do not, can be rented at the entrance. Thais are very sensitive to his shrine in the temple is always crowded, people come to ask the Buddha about the performance of their desires.The entrance to the street is a bowl of holy water and a vase with lotuses. Before entering the temple itself need to sprinkle holy water three times by a lotus, then removing the shoes go up to the Temple. In no case can not tread on the threshold, step over. Inside the walls of the temple are painted murals. Buddha statue itself is located at a considerable elevation, a golden throne. Each season, the King of Thailand Buddha disguises in new clothes. We were in November, it is winter in Thai Buddha was dressed in a gold coat, if you can call it that. Could see only green head, a small statue itself -polmetra wide and almost the same height. Pictures in the Temple of smoking, but coming on the street, you can remove the Buddha in the window. it is directly opposite and is always open.

Amazing, but overcrowded with pushy Chinese tourists.. As a chapel adjacent to Thailand's royal palace, this is pretty much a required stop. Amazing architecture, art, and history abound. Be advised, however, that the site is popular with Chinese bus tours and fills up early. The Chinese tourists seem to be extremely pushy and detract from the serenity of the site.

Choose a cool day. We both loved the reverence around this whole visit but golly it was hot. Try to go on a day when it is a little cooler. For western tourists you will need something to cover your shoulders with and skirts and shorts should be to around the knee - nothing too skimpy.

WOW. What an experience although it was very hot and crowded it is well worth a quick hour visit.Make sure that you are suitably dresses with no knees and shoulders on show or you will have to buy some cotton shirts and wraps to cover up outside which is very hot on top of your clothing

Very busy!. Temple is absolutely beautiful, just expect it to be extremely busy.
Handy tip - take a bag with you to store your shoes in as these are not allowed inside the temple and make sure legs are covered.

Small buddha statue. The temple of the emerald buddha is situated inside the grand palace. The build up is huge but the buddha statue is small overlooking everything below. The overall experience of the visit is good

More aesthetic than others. As far as we understood the Emerald Buddhas are kept in the museum at the Grand Palace territory. The temple is beautiful and worth seeing. There are also few more attractions at this huge territory.

Recently visited, wonderful experience. During my short 4 day stay in Bangkok, I was persuaded by a local tuk tuk operator by his ฿10 for 1/2 day tour around Bangkok. I thought it was too good to be true. Well it actually was - it was cheap but he did take me to many of his 'sponsors' where if you spend time at these places he gets a small commission along with commission on any purchases you make.Nevertheless, this was his livelihood and so I supported that. But he took me to places that I only saw in text books at school, and it was very overwhelming when seeing it finally with my own eyes.This temple was magnificent, you felt the power and energy and I was just in awe at the ancient culture and how strong it was still within Thailand. The people have never negotiated with any of their spiritual values and that's what makes it so special for me. Genuine authenticity.I would highly recommend getting out and seeing this temple in particular. I went on a Tuesday morning, and there wasn't too many tourists and basically had the place to myself to wonder around.Anyways, great experience.

The next building to the grand palace. As a non Thai you have to pay. I walked to the ticket booth expecting to pay quite a bit for three tickets and only had to pay for mine...Thai people don't pay. Loads of tourists and we were there around Songkran, very busy. Well worth a visit. The palace and the Temple of the Grand Buddha are a dual ticket as far as I can work out.The girlfriend and her son loved it.

A must see. A must see spot in Thailand. But a word of advice. Make sure you visit the temple between 8am and 9am so as to avoid the rush and tour groups walking over you and shoving you around. Make sure you save atlas half a day before the sun starts to make you sweat profusely. An official guide may help you appreciate the history.

Top-notch. This is one of the most impressive temple complexes in the world. Intricately decorated, beautifully presented with stunning statues and impressive monument, the whole compound is a work of art that must be seen by your own eyes. This temple should not be missed by any visitor to Bangkok, but it does however also mean that this place is incredibly crowded and usually packed with tourists. A minor detraction in an otherwise top-notch tourist destination.
Beautiful Wat. It was very crowded - last day of the New Year celebrations. But still worth visiting . Some amazing buildings - different architectural styles. Clean and well maintained

It's so peaceful!. The Temple of Emerald Buddha lies inside the Grand Palace complex. The temple has fantastic architecture and it's so peaceful inside. Photography is banned inside the temple. The crowd can be a big turn off sometimes.
Temples. A must visit for people interested in the architecture, a visit to as many temples as possible is recommended, the beauty of the buildings is amazing.
Go visit. Yes, this is one of top Bangkok sights overcrowded by tourists, and it is worth visiting. No photos allowed inside temple, but just a feeling of being there is amazing. Go visit!

Stunning. It's really hard to describe how beautiful this temple is. Every vista in this temple takes your breath away - from the Thai style architecture, to the Khmer style architecture, to the use of gold everywhere. PLEASE take a guide when you go in. Best 500 Baht we have spent in Thailand. The context of this temple becomes so much more vivid once you have a guide.
Stunning. Huge Buddha made from gold,they say is the largest golden buddha in the world!Very impressive,definitely worth a visit if in Bangkok.

Interesting. This is the central attraction in the Royal Palace complex and as such it can get very crowded. It is definitely worth a visit purely for its importance to the Thai people. the building itself is very beautiful and the buddha inside is wonderfully intricate.

Huge Indo/Buddhist complex.. The sheer crush of people and the heat means that you can expect an uncomfortable tour. There were too many "organised" tours from the PRC (China) whose tourists can sometimes be over-aggresive.
fascinating. The words are poor for describe the sensation to be on your knees admiring how beatiful is the temple with the emerald buda.
Photos. It is really something to see in person but I sure wished they allowed one to take photos inside the temple.

Impressive Temple. The Wat Phra Kaew is perhaps the centrepiece of the central attraction in Bangkok. It is the beautiful home of a delightful little emerald Buddha who sits atop an impressive structure. It serves as both a place of worship and a place to stand and admire.The exterior of the temple is beautiful. It is a large building with Buddhist-style design that speaks to the rising sun. Colourful and vivid, the temple is a joy to look at if it can be seen through the hordes of other tourists. It compares well with other temples and is the most important point to see in the Grand Palace complex.Shoes are removed before entering. This does mean the experience is not a pleasure to all the senses, especially inside the temple.Photos are not allowed inside but for anyone with a zoom of pretty much any description it is possible to photograph the Emerald Buddha from outside.The Emerald Buddha itself is fairly small. It is really quite hard to see any detail with the naked eye. It is a radiant green colour enhanced by the lighting effects that focus directly on its presence. The remainder of the interior has less focus but the structure the Buddha sits on is a gleaming and interesting pillar.For those who view Wat Phra Kaew as a place of worship it must be spectacular. For others, the exterior and the location are great though the small size of the Emerald Buddha itself and the impact of so many other people being around does have an effect.
worth to visit. Don't miss it although it is very crowded.It is one of the most famous places in Bangkok and it really worth to visit.

No doubt, go and visit!. Like all great tourist attractions Wat Phra Kaew is crowded, best is to wait in line before it opens at 8.30. If it is hot as well, take a deep breath and plunge in. Really overwhelming..
Beautiful and peaceful. This temple is spectacular and one that I really recommend. Take a moment to soak it all up. Even with the hoards of tourists try and take a moment to real enjoy this temple.
Amazing!. The detail in these temples are amazing! The Emerald Buddha is made of jade and quite small, but still an amazing site!

Crowded, overwhelming amount if gold but worth it. The temples and the surrounding area are amazing. The visit is totally worth the entry price, BTH$1000 p/p.The drawback: hordes of tourists. Be patient.Dressing code: no shorts for both women & men, and no tank tops for ladies. Is very hot so if you don't comply with the dressing code, they will force you to wear covering clothes over yours. You will be three times more hot then!

One of the great sights. Without a doubt, the most splendid single edifice in the Grand Palace complex. The exterior is a marvel. Do try to spend some time inside, without your shoes, seeing how the locals revere the temple. Do not be tempted to photograph the relatively small and high-up Emerald Buddha while you are inside. From outside, a reasonable telephoto will give you a great photo without the fear of being accosted by security.

Mandatory to visit if you are in BKK. I guess most of tourists would visit this place, and when I visited there, there were a lot of tourists from all over the world came to there.The entrance fee 500B would be one of the most highest level one in BKK, however, I felt Buddhism and Royal Family's greatness from this place for seeing the local prayers and their loyalties.Some guide book described beach shoes are prohibited to enter there.In fact, it doesn't matter to visit there with beach shoes (any staffs didn't decline to enter). Don't worry but take care of your clothes for paying respect.
Fantastic views. This temple, which is located in the Grand Palace, has some of the most stunning architecture that can be viewed in all of Bangkok.

It's a Little Guy with a Big Following.. Located on the Palace Grounds, the Temple is ornate and crowded. The statue is carved from a solid piece of emerald green jasper. You can't get up real close but you can see it's impressive. Many devout followers are there in awe and to venerate this most important relic in the country. Take time to walk the grounds.
HOW PUBLIC TRANSPORT SHOULD BE. Fast, regular, spotlessly clean and very affordable. This is how public transport should be.Most major attractions and shopping/markets are minutes away.
crowded. great site and intresting to visit but go very early as the waves of tourists all being shuttled around the grounds becomes overwhelming
Little fella. It was a bit disappointing to small to see and you aren't allowed to take pics we went during prayers wasn't a good time as we felt we were intruding

Excellent Temple but I don't like the new selective charging. I have visited this temple many times together with the Grand Palace where it is situated. But more recently they've started to charge people who are white of sub Saharan African decent. If you look like you could be Thai they simply let you in for free. So people from Loas, Cambodia, Malaya, Burma and of course Thailand then they let you walk in for free. But if you look different they ask you to pay 500 Baht. My wife's Thai and when we're in the UK we get treated exactly the same. If she pays then I pay. If it's free for me it's free for her. But! It is a nice temple, so if you haven't been then it's worth paying the 500 Baht to get into the Grand Palace and of course Wat Phra Kaew.

Not the usual size, but exquisite!. This is all part of the Grand Palace experience. The Emerald Buddha is exquisite. It is of quite a different size from most others, but you will go to admire the beauty inside. No pictures are allowed inside, but you can photo from outside. Remember about the shoe removal and bring extra socks just for walking inside the temples.

Extremely beautiful... But its a Chinese anthill. Or more an anthill full off Chinese tourists... If you do not mind making your way through packs of them, it's an incredible place worth the visit. If that is not your thing or the sweltering heat is too much, go next door to Wat Po.
Best Buddha in town.. Amazing place, historic bust the most expensive to visit for foreigners. 500 dollars for tourists. Thais in for free. But worth the money. Can be very busy.

nice. It was the first thing I saw when I came to Thailand. Wat Phra Kaew is also called the "Temple of the Emerald Buddha. He is considered the most sacred temple in Thailand. In my opinion, this is the most beautiful and important sights of Bangkok. To go to Bangkok and not visit the Wat Phra Kaew, like going to Paris and not visit the Eiffel Tower . It took me more than 2 hours to explore the temple. It is remarkable. Such beautiful and handsome. And the atmosphere inside was so magical. The Grand Palace Rama I contains a variety of architectural differences, European and Chinese. Bangkok busy traffic. At the entrance to the temple, do not forget to take your shoes off. This applies to all the royal temples in Thailand. In addition to the ruins. Much of the architecture gets certified Gold (gold leaf). It is a beautiful sight. My advice would be to hire a guide who will show you all the temples in Bangkok. It is better to take a Thai guide which will show you and tell you stories. Changing of the Guard pleasant sight. Protection must stand still for 2 hours.
Pretty. Another main temple to visit while you stay in Bangkok. Interesting visit and pretty. Lots of photo opportunities.

very beautiful. This is a crowded temple but the Buddha, while small is very impressive. Since you cant take pictures inside temple, make sure you bring a long telephoto if you want to take one from outside

Beautiful but busy. Stunning place to see. The detail in the buildings, temples and decoration was amazing. The porcelain tiles were stunning, to many people and a very hot day made it very tiring but will go back again in the off season

Just ok. This place was insanely busy, and they are serious about your clothing, before you even go into the complex you have to wait in a long, hot line to get pants (for men) and shirts/sarongs for women, even capris aren't okay here. The borrowed clothes require a deposit of 250bht per item, and they are sweaty and kind of gross and not very nice looking. Then you finally get into the complex and the buildings are incredibly beautiful, the most beautiful we had seen for sure, but you can't take pictures inside the temple, and the emerald Buddha is really small. It wasn't a bad experience, but I had a hard time enjoying myself as much as some other temples because of some of the issues.
Tiny Buddha on a Mountain of Gold. I visited this during the festival of Songkran when entrance was free so that it was very crowded. It was still a place of great beauty and reverence.

Beautiful place. An amazing experience, such beautiful & vibrant buildings, the Emerald Buddha is actually made from jade, it's very small but so intricate, the monarch changes the clothing on the Buddha each season, due to the fact that the King is unwell & the Buddha is on a very high platform the Prince now performs the duties. No photography is allowed inside but with a zoom lens you can get a good picture from outside. Please be respectful & dress appropriately. Garments can be hired if you forget.Bottled water is for sale, you'll need it. We went in the morning before it got too hot & it wasn't too busy, but you do have to remember it's a major tourist attraction & a place of worship for the locals so it's going to be busy!We found it useful to have a guide who could tell us the history.

Songkran 2015. We visited the temple on April 15th in the morning. Because of Songkran the enterence was free of charge and an other temple that is only open to the public 7 days a year was also open. The king visited the temple that afternoon so a lot of security and beautifull decorations. You can not take pictures and the statue is very small.

Amazing!. As part of the Royal Palace, this temple was just one more awe inspiring building. I loved the interior and the exterior is beautiful too. The whole Palace with its many buildings is not to be missed. Be prepared to dress appropriately or they will make you wear a sarong and jogging bottoms.
Worth seeing, but very crowded. A must-see in Bangkok, but better crowd control would help ( perhaps limit the amount of people at one time)

Amazing feeling. The Emerald Buddha was one of the best temples we visited. Even though the statue is small compared to other temples, the beauty and art work is truly amazing. The artwork surrounding the Emerald Buddha is so intricate and wonderful, words are insufficient to explain. Though photography is not allowed from inside the sanctorium, we took some from outside.
Worth a visit, better at off peak times.. We went at thai new year (April) which was very busy, squashed and rushed. I would like to go again at off peak to fully enjoy this temple
Must Visit Place. This is a must go in Bangkok. Read a bit about the place before going or get a guided tour, it's worthy.

Stunning and Shiny. We joined the tour which was available inside the temple so check out for their timings once you enter the temple. The guides will be standing next to the mural depicting a story about Ramayana (a monkey god and a princess, a similar story as to the one from Bali, the story is reenacted in UluWatu together with a kecak dance).The tour was great as it explained about the current whereabouts of the Buddha artefacts as well as the customs of the Thai people. The temple was in a very beautiful gold and blue shade.

too expensive!!. I agree it is a breathtaking buddha... just like the reclining buddha of gold!! 2000 bart per person to enter the site!! way to expensive and it is a very busy site, your not far off an ant in a trail to be honest and no hats or caps allowed in the hot sun of the day so be prepared for heat and you will need to buy lots of drinks and water

Not a long visit but the colors are beautiful. We went with Gate1 so not sure the cost of entry. They have just redone a large portion of it so it was in full color. The tiles on the roof, the ceiling paintings/murals all beautiful. Be properly dressed but if you are not they will wrap you in a robe / you also have to go in without shoes so if you dont like walking barefoot wear something that allows for socks.
Full of tourists but worth it. Putting all of the tourist groups aside this temple is stunning so much detail and amazingly beautiful
Nice place to visit. Great place to go. Again, definitely a NOT-TO-MISS place. A little bit crowded. Exterior are amazing. Interior, not so much to see.
A must see. Hmm just be cautious while entering the Temple you will be bombarded with stinky feet so keep a handkerchief in hand:)

Amazing but too, too crowded. We would not have missed this Bangkok landmark -- it was at the top of our list. And we are glad we went. But the crowds made the experience less than ideal. (We were there after lunch, probably not the best time of day.) In retrospect, observing the many different types of tourists and their energetic appreciation of this temple was interesting on its own. We didn't get close enough to the Emerald Buddha to really see it, but the temple area itself is a dizzying experience of color, stories, and energy. Are we glad we went, yes indeed! (Make sure you have water, sunscreen, a hat or parasol.)

Beauty and Elegance. Wat Phra Kaew is amazing and is attached to the Grand Palace in one complex. The temples and the palace are majestic and magnificent and just breath taking. There is a lot of walking to do and it was very hot which was tough on the kids. This is a must for a trip to Bangkok however.

Golden Palace Bangkok - breathtaking!. This site is a must - the whole palace is beyond words and truly breathtaking. As noted by other posts the Emerald Buddha itself is rather disappointing in size but none the less beautiful. Helpful hints; Shoulders and long trousers - psychodelic long trousers can be bought for 100bht just outside of the temple in the shops so don't hire inside or from guides; don't be fooled when an official guy says the palace closes for lunch...they don't! this is a ploy to bundle you into a tuktuk and take a canal boat ride - don't be afraid to say no at the river if this happens; take an umbrella to shade you from the intense sun as very little shade available, plus plenty of water; hire a guide (inexpensive) as they will cut you through all queues and bat away annoying selfie sticks when you are trying to get through crowds ( very busy with Chinese when we went). The guide gave a step by step history so you could look up whilst listening instead of reading from a leaflet - he also advised great photo spots from where to take best pictures. Be sure not to miss this temple and go as early as possible - a good couple of hours to do this site justice.

Concentrate or you will miss it. The building of Wat Phra Kaew - the Temple of Emerald Buddha started 1785. It consists of a group of very elaborate buildings, statues, and pagodas. The Ordination hall is a peaceful, majestic and beautifully decorated place. I am ashamed to say that I was so overawed by the building that I missed the tiny Buddha which sits high within the hall raised up on a series of platforms. It is carved from a single block of jade and is one of the most significant religious artefacts for the Thai people but it is very small compared to nearby buddhist statues.The tiny Buddha is covered in seasonal robes corresponding to the summer, winter, and rainy seasons. The ritual changing of these robes is performed only by the King of Thailand to bring continuing good fortune to the country. No other mortals are allowed near the statue.There are many other attractions on site including a model of Angkor Wat, which was built under the order of King Rama IV when Cambodia was under Siamese control. The Ramayana which considered to one of the great Hindu epics has been adapted and incorporated into Thai Buddhist tradition. Murals inside the balcony tell this story entirety and on the columns of the balcony are stone inscriptions of the verses describing the murals. Each gate of the Balcony is guarded by huge 5 metre tall gate-keeping giants called Yaksa Tavarnbal. These fearsome characters are taken from the same epic.To get the best from the temple arrive early and I recommend taking a guide or audio tour and remember that Temples are active and very sacred places. Remove your shoes and dress appropriately. Male and females should ensure that there is no exposed flesh between neck and knee. No shorts are allowed for either sex but trousers are available for hire if you have the correct money and can put up with the inefficient queues. Admission to the temple is 400 THB (£8) for tourists and it closes at 15:30.

Gorgeous emerald buddha. This statue looked very pretty and view from this temple around is heavenly. I poured oil into the little bowls following the rituals performed by other visitors. I found several temples around this temple of emerald Buddha. While I was there, the sun was out and the sun rays on the statues made the statues of Buddha look very lively and pious. I even asked my guide whether it is possible to migrate to this place for good.

Smells like feet. It is a beatiful temple with all its decoration, architecture and of course the famous Emerald Buddha. Don't expect to much because the Buddha statue is 2 feet tall and stands on an approximately 10m high pillar. Like in every temple you have to take off your shoes. But imagine Bangkok in April, 35°C and hundreds of tourists without shoes sitting in the temple. Not very pleasant and calm. There are some locals that come to pray and show their respect but there is at least 10x more chinese tourists that try to take pictures and are noisy. It is beatiful and well maintained but that's just for making money off the tourists. It's not a temple with the purpose to praise Buddha and his teachings and it really never used to be, because before it was a money making machine it was exclusively build for the King and royal family to pray in.

Eye opening. As you have already know, there are many Buddist temples in Bangkok and the rest of Thailand. This particular one is where the famous Emerald Buddha lives. The temple look like its made of gold. There are a lot of statues in the temple and a lot of locals. Emerald temple is one of the temple you must visit but make sure you are properly dressed as a respect to the Thai Buddism culture.
Go early -avoid crowds. The actual buddha is way up high on a pyramid of altars (no photos please). Incredibly ornate, but with mass of people by late morning difficult to take time to appreciate it

Manic! Get the audio tour. Amazing to see but incredibly busy. Absolutely get the audio your otherwise you won't understand anything (or pay a guide - but I thought the audio tour was good enough). Getting into see the actual Emerald Buddha was a scrum - not suitable if you can't cope with being squeezed in a crowd...
MUST good place. A place i must visit at lease 1. forever crowded with peoples and 1 landmark for bangkok. pray for 4 faces buddha.

Beautiful but much smaller than anticipated. The temple itself is beautiful as is the Emerald Budda. But it is ver small and hard to see very well as it is quite high up. We were there in the morning and it was just packed with tourists. I would recommend going later in the day once most of the large bus tour groups have left. That will allow you more time and fewer crowds to content with.
