You aren't allowed to take photos inside the temple, but if you have a good lens you can stand just outside the centre door and get a great shot of it.

bit overwhelming but good. Going without a tour guide, meant it was a bit of a guess fetting in and out of this complex. Fee of 500 baht included 3 things, but not sure if I did it all. Was staggeringly hot.

A must-see when in Bangkok. Temples...Thailand has plenty of them, but this is one definitely worth visiting! You'll see this temple whilst on the Grand Palace tour, it's all on the same grounds.The Emerald Buddha statue was found in northern Thailand and after being seized by Lao forces, it was recovered and settled in Bangkok.The temple compound is amazing, with murals covering inner walls.
Amazing. Should not be left behind in any Bangkok city tour. It is unique, different from any other temple I've visited. Organized entrance allows each one to have "your moment" inside this place.
Nice. Too crowded and the entrance fee for foreigner really expensive but all here nice and the weather really hot here

A very nice experience. this buddha statue is a big and impressive monument. Nested in specifically dedicated building one can only be impressed with the sheer size and beauty. The temple complex next to it is also worth a visit but the years have really made it more of a ruin

The temple of The Emerald Buddha,Bangkok. We visited the temple of The Emerald Buddha on 12April 2015.It is really beautiful.Photography is not allowed inside the main temple but one can click pictures from outside the temple. There are some things that need to be kept in mind before you go to this place. No shorts or sleeveless dresses are allowed.If you happen to wear them then you have to rent trousers and stole to cover yourself up. The rent is 200Baht for each garment.So please wear proper attire.It tends to get very hot so carry sunglasse ,hat and water bottle.The cost of entry fee for non-Thai person is 500Baht for The Grand Palace and the temple.

"Taste of Thailand" tour. Visited this temple while on a "Taste of Thailand" tour with a group of friends. There does not seem to be a "best time" to visit attractions in Thailand as it seems to always be busy and crowded. With that being said, having an awesome guide who expertly navigated us through each site allowed us to fully enjoy the experience. I initially thought that the Emerald Buddha was much bigger than it actually is, but now that I think about it - it makes sense as to the size it is, given that it is carved from one single piece of emerald. This attraction was a quick walk through as it was very very crowded. Beautiful temple, though.

very crowded place. one of those must see in Bangkok, emerald Buddha is not as big as the rest of Buddhas but is one of the nicest, been there in March and it was still very crowded and photos wasn't allowed inside, still worth the visit

The must-see spot in Bangkok. For sure the Wat Phra Kaew is a must-see in Bangkok. You will be stunned by the golden architectures. The entire temple is full of history and suggest you rent an audio guide to truly learn the history.

BEWARE .... Loved Bangkok but beware - always think about any information/advice you are given FROM ANYONE as it may be in the best interest of the person giving it but not in yours. An example ... Upon arrival at Wat Prah Kaew we were greeted by a uniformed 'policeman' (with ID lanyard and official badges) who advised us that the Temple was closed until 12.30pm for a special Buddhist day for the monks. He suggested a visit to the other temple over the other side of the river and started to lead the way to the river boat. Alarm bells started ringing after a couple of other similar experiences in the preceding days and sure enough it was a scam to try and get us to pay for a river boat trip. Very sad that the real Police turn a complete blind eye to this sort of stuff.

An Absolute Must. Probably THE tourist attraction in Bangkok and for good reasons. Pleasantly situated away from the traffic and noise of the city. Ideally one should prepare for the visit to make to most out of it - or get an audio guide. It covers a large area so it's not overcrowded even when there are many visitors. It can be diffcult to take pictures at times since numerous Chinese groups ruthlessly block the best motifvs. Be aware the shoes must be taken off at most temples or else the peaceful Thai's can turn rather energetic ;-) The entrance fee is very high for Thai measures (500 Baht) but justified and worth it.

Good, but there are better temples. Interesting to learn about the history with the guide, disappointed the original emerald Buddha isn't there anymore but still worth seeing the site nonetheless. If I didn't have much time I would drop this for the grand palace or Wat Pho.

i love panctuanya. and tell her i love the tour she took me on last year and. i love panctuanya. and tell her i love the tour she took me on last year and i enjoyed viewing the kings palace. i miss u thailand and its love and peace and many blessings. i hope to return soon. many greeting and may the king of kings and lords of lords watch over u. big kisses xxx. Its so winderful, ur head bows in reverence.the first place that i met my money here so great to me.
Emerald Buddha. Fabulous! You must visit. Very busy and difficult to take a clear photo. Make sure you have bottled water with you.
An important site. This is a large complex with lots of palaces, temples, monuments, and statues. It also has a model of Angkor Wat. Go early and be prepared for sun and heat.
Well worth Seeing. Impressive Temple Complex - but very busy, so pick your time to visit. Cover alls available for those not deemed to be respectfully dressed - no shorts, bare shoulders etc
Temple of Emerald Buddha. Glad we visited the palace. Must visit during your stay in Bangkok. Best to take a took took or taxi to reach the place.

A breathtaking temple. This place is my top 1 Bangkok attraction. The building are amazing. The colors and material the building uses are magnificent.
It is a must visit in Bangkok!

A must visit. This temple was once a palace where Thai King lived long long ago. It's really hot weather, so do prepare comfortable cloth but if you want to wear shorts, it must cover your knees and women must wear skirts.I saw many people take big scarf with them and when they reached some areas that require you to wear skirt they just tide the scarf around their waist as skirt.
Wonderful Site. Glad we visited early as the grounds opened for this temple was due to close at noon. As one tuk-tuk driver noted later, this Buddha is the best. Very ethereal.

Beautiful temples, Interesting Free English tour. There are two free English tours per day with one at 10 am, the other I can't remember. The tour which takes you around from Wat Phra Kaew, to the Grand Palace outside and end at the Coin Museum, is extremely well done with multiple interesting historical facts and a humorous Thai tour guide. Make sure you go around that time.The whole place is amazing. Love the architectures and the amount of details in each temple. Of course it is very crowded,seriously crowded like going to the subway train in Singapore during rush hour.Tickets include entrance to Vimanmek Mansion and some other places if you are keen to, in 500B bundle which I don't like personally. If you forget the wear long covered dresses you can borrow them, without having to buy from the street vendors outside.

Sooooo busy, but definitely worth a visit . Came here early on a Sunday morning in april. Weather was boiling and if you were dressed correctly you had to borrow clothes (Free if you returned them 200 baht deposit needed). Architecture wise, amazing!! So many people here but really worth a visit.

Best temple in Thailand. This place is one place that Thai people know and the thing that I think this place is good because here make everyone have more merit and when you come out it make you happy and some vacation you can going in the very old chapel, in there so beautiful. Some people say "No,I don't want to go in there have many people it so hot I don't like." It's ok because you can view and go to another place. You need to wear the skirts that cover the knees for women and pantaloons for men because if you wear the shot one the security will protect you out.  Please don't bring the food to this temple because it make homemade need to work hard for clean up. We can help them in the thing that we can because I look at this area I think that this temple have a little bit homemade. If you want to buy some small buddha image in there have a little shop you can go in to see and if you want to give the money you can give this shop too because this shop is the shop of temple. You will sorry if you come in Bangkok and don't going to this temple. Some where in this temple don't like you to take a photo because it make temple look like every old and they need to use many money for reconstruct. Last thing I hope you will happy when you see this temple.
very crowded. The place is inside the Royal Grand Palace. There was so many people going thru the place that it made it hard to really enjoy seeing it.
Beautiful. The whole architecture and the decorations are lovely. Not to be missed on your trip to Bangkok. try to go on a week day to avoid crowds.

Grand Palace. if you ask Thai people where should be the first place that be must,this is the first choice the all question.this is the place that we can study Thai architectural and Thai art as well.this is beginning point of your travel in Thailand.

Incredibly Stunning!. In my opinion, this temple is stunning and the statues are immaculately crafted. If you come to bangkok, you must visit this place at least once. Do try to arrive early before the tour buses arrive. Can get very crowded, but it is still worth a visit.

Take a river taxi. This is a site most easily visited by River Taxi. I am not an aficionado and cannot rate the excellence of one Wat over many. This is, none the less, a location you should visit on your trip to Bangkok.

A must see, even if you've seen enough temples.. This place is amazing. It is a collection of buddah statues and temples that are adorned with so much gold and other embellishments. The architecture is simply mind blowing. It does get crowded, but none the less you must see it.

Amazing place. This wat is one of the amazing temples you need to see when in Thailand.
The place may be cramped at times especially during peak time of visit. An early visit would be the best.
Wow. This is an absolutey incredible place. Unfortunately, on a Saturday in March, the crowds were incredible which somewhat detracted from the experience. However, this is not to be missed.

Wonderful and amazing place. it's so great to be here, nice place and so Safe and sound!
It's look very great temple, make me feel peaceful in mind, a sensation I have never feel before. Great place.
Visit Bangkok Visit Grand Palace. I Love The Royal Palace very beautifully and old time look you have to visit this place and better try wat po as well

Thailand's oldest temples in the capital city.. Temple ancient capital of central Thailand. Ancient architecture in the temple. I like this place because the statue of the ancient worship. You can watch a rare antiques. This place is like learning history of Africa in the past. A picture (Except for certain that there are signs prohibiting photography) to visit this place I feel merit and respect for the sacred Buddha.*** Do not forget to visit this place to comply with the rules of the site.- Wear long pants Or knee-length pants- Wear coveralls Or shirt modestly- Do not make loud noises- Do not litter- Do not destroy historicSome days the weather is hot and should bring sunglasses. And sunscreen.Prakaew Temple to visit throughout the year. I wanted to visit this place for yourself.

highly recommand to come in the early morning. The area opens around 8 and the temple of the Emerald Buddha opens at 0830. If you come early, you will have a quiet and peaceful experience to see the details of the temple.

Gorgeous temple. The architecture and facade of this temple is gorgeous. The inside was so crowded and the Emerald Buddha looks so small at the top of the altar that we actually missed it the first time through. We went back in and stood in the back to see it. The is a gorgeous temple as are the other buildings on the Grand Palace grounds.

Absolutely stunning. This is by far my favourite place in Bangkok. You can easily spend an entire day here and it's worth taking the time to fully explore all the different temple buildings. Regardless of your religious beliefs it's a beautiful and serene experience if you take the time to sit and reflect on the Buddha in the main temple.

Always love to come here.. Been here a lot on my own and with friends. Its a mazing feeling to be here.
Well maintain, clean, feelung great.
Also love to see the lighting at night its beautiful.
Making me feel calm and blessing too.
Thanks so much for have this temple in Bkk Thailand.

Unbealeavable. When you go , just know it gets very crowded and you are not able to take pictures inside the temple of the Jade Buddha, however you can take them from the outside. This is a very holy place and has many visitors a must to experience.

Beautiful, but HOT, get there early. Beautiful architecture and history stories. there are all kinds of tour guides when you walk in the entrance- prior to getting your ticket. SO WORTH it to negotiate a fair price with them to have them walk you through the area- as it is hot, and why have your nose buried in a book? Our guide was great, good price, and pointed out things we would not have seen. Plus the freedom of having someone else lead us through the maze of the area was priceless. For 4 people, we paid maybe $35 for the tour- including tip. Also, she watched our shoes when you have to take them off to go in the temple, and told us the best places to take photos.
Temple of the Emrald Buddha. This is a nice place near the Palace. Emrald Buddha is one of the best attraction. This is one of the best Palace to visit in Bangkok.

A must see in Bangkok....incredibly busy!. Went with a guide and were glad of that.....got loads out of visit....the grounds are huge....packed...both with artefacts and with visitors....and sorry but the Chinese particularly seem to have very sharp elbows....and not adverse to knocking 7 yr old girls out of the way for a better view of the sights!Despite...the heat ...the crowds...the selfy sticks.....this is a must for any visitor.....go early our late to avoid the crowds if you can

Packed with tourists, overly crowded, not worth it!. First of all, you need to purchase a ticket to get into the temple. With long wait in the line, you finally get to enter but had to squeeze your way around to get to the actual temple where the emerald Buddha sits. The emerald Buddha is not actually made of emerald, its made of jade, and the statue of the “jade” Buddha is a lot a smaller than expected. Honestly, it is a bit hard to see because they put it up so high that you barely could see the outline of the face. I would rather spend time in other temples! Such as reclining Buddha.

May as well see it whilst there. i was expecting something magnificent, however this is tiny and just didn't seem very special, after milling in the temple with the hundreds of others. May as well see it whilst your at the palace though.

Overcrowded with Chinese tourists and remember your clothes. This place was completely packed full of Chinese package tourists snapping thousands of the same photos on their iPhones. It was difficult to get a decent photo anywhere as there were so many people.Also make sure you are wearing long pants and a shirt with sleaves or you will have to wait in a long line to rent some. Considering the heat at this time of year, wearing those clothes in those crowds was not fun at all.On a positive note, the architecture was impressive and the painting and statues were nice.I would not go again.
Crowded but worth it. The place is overly crowded with many tourists and their selfie sticks, but the Emerald buddha is worth a visit.
Small but Peaceful. I enjoyed this visit because it was peaceful. The pleasant grounds are good to sit back and relax, do some people watching, and chill out.

Lovely Temple in Palace grounds. We didn't realise at first and had missed this temple and had to walk back. This temple is located in the first entry point when you walk into the palace grounds. I have preferred other temples but this one does have some history and given you are within the compound it is definitely worth seeing.

Beauiful. This is within the Grand Palace, well worth a visit. This attraction gets very busy so be prepared for the crowds of visitors. Dress code is long trousers and covered shoulders. Take a sarong with you to cover up.
Fabulous....the most sacred. Enjoyed visiting the Emerald Buddha as this is the most sacred. Magical and spectacular. This is probably the most impressive from all the others that we visited.

Crowded, but a must-see. It was hot. It was crowded. It was a little confusing. But it is still a must-see. The grounds of the temple are quite impressive. Dress lightly, but appropriately (see the dress code), bring water, tune out the crowd, and explore.
too crowded. too crowded and too many people and mainland chinese with no manners, otherwise nice place to look at sights

Make sure it is open - some days and some time of the day it is closed. I have seen more beautiful temples, from inside and outside, but this temple is special for Thai people so you will see cultural elements more here. And the whole area is magnificent! Also, the Buddha is not of Emerald but Jade, but anyway ;o)

Majestic Temple!. We were so curious about the emerald Buddha inside the temple after hearing about the stories. The temple was majestic, everything covered in gold (not sure real gold or not but still look charming). The good thing is, there were lots of water dispensers so neednt to afraid of being thirsty when visiting this place.
famous. We had to see this temple , the emerald buddha is spectacular , world famous , the site is peacful and well organised .

A must for every visitor to Bangkok. You are not going to see anything like this in the other temples - there is something unique about many of the big attractions. You will see lots of locals and Buddhists praying - very much like the experience of the Vatican city in Rome.

Thai Temple. We were here by Mac 2011. We bought Grand Palace ticket 350 THB each person and this temple is including in the ticket. The Thai temples seem almost the same, golden color, fascinating view and beautiful decoration.
Another must-do. Another excellent place to visit in Bangkok. You must ensure you don't get there too late though as the temple tends to close reasonably early ...
A Must. This temple is part of a day tour you can make to the centre. The story of the Emerald Buddha you want to read about in a tourist guide, or best to have a Thai national show you around.

too many tourists. A beautiful place to visit but simply too many tourist to enjoy serenely, i would highly recommend visiting early in the morning in order to avoid the crush. Despite many signs indicating no cameras i believe the actual rule is photos are allowed outside but not inside the temple buildings.
Crowded place. One of the highlight of my trip for visiting this. Unfortunately this attraction is too crowded at anytime. Couldn't spend much time inside because of the crowd.

Must see.... This is a part of the royal palace complex and should be the top thing to do in bangkok when youre not partying. Shorts and sleeveless shirts arent allowed but the temple authorities let you borrow a sarong and a shirt. There will be touts outside offering them for a fee, just ignore them.

Take closed clothes and harmony to provide you.. Interesting and beautiful place, very much willing to look at, but it's worth it. Necessarily need clothing that covers for all (man and woman) or pledge (200 Baht). Accept only cash, near cash machine (with it's commission).

Amazingly beautiful. Locate within the grand palace. Pay 500 baht to get in the grand palace and you will also get to see this temple. Inside is really pretty the walls cover with beautiful painting. If you like painting and thai traditional style this is the place you have to visit

Extremely busy temple - tiny Buddha. I was expecting a larger Buddha than the 24"H one that we saw...and it's not made of Emerald - it's made from Jade. So be prepared to be underwhelmed by the Buddha but overwhelmed with the amount of tourists in the temple. We were told that this temple complex gets 10,000 visitors on average a day. You'll be pushed and jostled around every time you turn around.

Amazing, but crowded. I suggest going early to avoid the Chinese tourists with their umbrellas. Nothing against the Chinese, but I'm 6'3 which means their umbrellas are right about the level of my face. It gets VERY crowded too. But the place is amazing regardless.

Very small statue and very crowded site - not good.. Part of the debacle that is the Grand Palace. Millions of Chinese/Koreans (south I suppose) and Japanese all waving selfi sticks and posing in front of any object that you may wish to take a picture of with out them in it! More enjoyable that the very small Buddha was photo-bombing the selfi takers. This is not hard when you get the knack which is keep close and move suddenly as the finger comes down on the button. It is harder than normal photo-bombing but such fun.Quite overshadowed the Buddha

Beautiful, decorative and worth paying the entry fee. the temple is beautiful, and the designs on the walls are mesmerizing, worth going there, only thing is that its too crowdy and opens till afternoon , no entry in evening, as in Bangkok heat its not easy to visit the place.
Peaceful and calming. No pictures allowed - but you can sit in the presence of the Emerald Buddha for as long as you need. It's a very centering experience.

Can be busy. Make sure you wear appropriate clothes although there are some to borrow. You put your shoes in a bag which is easier than leaving them outside with so many visitors.The site has so many beautiful buildings to see and just as interesting as the Buddha itself..There are lots of notices to be a ware of pickpockets which make you aware of the crowds. especially where people are trying to take full length pictures of the statue only possible at one part.The free bottle of water with your ticket fee was very welcome.
Beautiful Temple. A must see, amazing architecture, beautiful Budda Bangkok has so much to offer, but this has to high on the list of priorites.
Great temple. One of the big temples in Bangkok where is possible to see the faith of people to Bhuda praying. Religiosity is a characteristic of o Thay people.
Impressive. Worth seeing. Bring temple socks or wipes for feet. Helps to have read up on it or to have a good guide to explain the history

Must see if you like culture. This temple and grounds are beautiful. So many building, so many pagodas all with intricate inlays. Definitely worth spending 45 minutes there. I recommend arriving early as it will be crowded and it is hot.

Magical Place. This temple and the surrounding buildings are beautiful beyond words! Well worth the entrance fee. Be prepared for huge crowds of people. This was definitely a highlight to my time in Bangkok.

Worth seeing this Revered Treasure. Along with the other temple and scared pavilions, the Emerald Budda is a sophisticated stupa. You cannot photograph inside, but with a telephoto lens, shots from the outside are possible.

Beautiful. The temple of the emerald Buddha is in the palace. Make sure you give these enough time. Go as soon as they open and take your own time. Very beautiful. Do visit the museum in the palace too . Then have lunch . Nice restaurants opposite the palace. Then head to the teclining Budha and then to the flower market.

Love it.. the Temple is big and so many places and room to see. there are so many story about each of the building and decorations in the temple. it is very crowded and lots of steps to climb. need good walking shoes, wear cap/hat and sunglasses.

Beautiful. This temple is situated in the grounds of the grand palace, and it is a truly magnificent site, the temple is really busy, but it is definitely worth the time and effort if you have to wait a few minutes to get in.
Excellent Statue. It was made up of gold and about 50 feet long sleeping Buddha. facilities at temple were excellent, very aesthetically maintained. I have been impressed
great. We had been looking forward to seeing this for a long time , it is famous and awesome , the emerald buddha is beautiful , a top site .

Small Buddha Beautifully Displayed. Absolutely beautiful Buddha surrounded by decadent mirrored and gold decor. Bring your glasses, as he is small and hard to see, but it was our favorite temple in Bangkok!

Excellent Architecture.. The Emerald Buddha is enshrined on a golden traditional Thai-style throne made of gilded-carved wood,known as a Busabok, in the ordination hall of the royal monastery. Architecture of this monastery is excellent.

Detailed Buddha. This is one of the temple that we went in in grand palace, the rest are mostly not accessible and you can only view the building architect from outside. The weather is really hot so a short stopover at this temple helped to cool us down. Before visiting the temple, we went to the Musuem and understand that the Buddha has 3 clothes depending on the season. It is really a very good understanding before you see the real Buddha as it is displayed far top in the temple so you might not notice about the changes. It is crowded but I am impress of the interior of the temple as well as the Buddha statue. They are so great!

Beautiful. Quite expensive to get into compared to other things, but really something to see. Just be VERY careful when visiting that you don't take ANYONE's advice before you get through the doors - SO MANY SCAMMERS around here that want to take your money! One told us that it wasn't even open until 3pm (was 1pm then) and that we should go to x, y and z first, thankfully we had already found out that it shut at 3pm, so if we'd have listened to him we would have missed it and probably ended up paying a lot for a tuktuk ride we didn't even need!Inside is beautiful but take water and a hat as it's super hot and seriously full of tourists!

Well worth a visit. The Emerald Buddha is made from a single block of jade and is et in a temple of its own. Visitors to the temple complex must wear clothing covering shoulders, arms etc. You will not be allowed in wearing shorts but at the gates they can supply lightweight trousers for a small fee. There is now charge 400 baht to enter the temple grounds which also includes the Grand Palace, again well worth a visit. Highly recommended.

Part of Grand Palace - so don't miss it. Entrance is included in 500 baht charge for grand palace. Buddha is small, but surrounding tribute to the small buddha is huge. Worthwhile going in, although you must take your shoes off to enter the temple - no big deal. Note the buddha wears different "clothes" depending on the season - interesting.

So many people!. This is a really busy tourist attraction and, with that many people around, it's very difficult to see anything properly. If you do make it into the temple to see the Emerald Buddha, be warned that you can't take any photos, so there's no chance of trying to take a photo and then look at it in comfort away from the crowds - you're going to have to make your way to the front of the horde and then attempt to squint up at it and commit what you can see to memory!
Good. Nice to see the sculpture and other. I love the place. Plan accordinglr to go without rush. wat u like

Discriminatory towards tourist. Arrogant staff member of audio guide and discriminatory temple management whereby only Thai are allowed to pray closer and stay longer. We may be mistaken as mainland Chinese tourist but if the management or Thailand does not welcome Chinese tourist, it should be announced publicly and stop Chinese tourist from visiting, not mistreat tourist. Ticket is 500 baht inclusive of Grand Palace, plenty to see but get ready to be discriminated, especially if you look like Chinese
Wat Indaravihan, Thailand. This is a huge, giant statue of Buddha in golden color and you can hear the continuous chanting of prayer being offered.

Amazing temple and cloister. Amazing Buddha in an amazing Temple. I also very much appreciated the collection of Buddha statues (most of them in black (not in gold!), including an awesome Buddha fasting...), in the cloister behind the Temple

Beautiful temple. The emerald Buddha is not large but nor is the Mona Lisa. A quite superb statue well worth the trip . The whole settling was glorious as well close to the centre of the pleasant town of Chiang Rai.

Very small Buddha in very busy palace.. Disappointed by how much it cost to get into palace (500 baht), and then how small Buddha was, and that no photos possible. Rest of temple very attractive, but too many people. Many place buildings are closed at weekends, so if you're interested in seeing more of the palace go on a week day. Long trousers and shoulders covered are essential here.

Getting too crowded. I have visited this temple many times and this time was taken aback by the sheer number of people now visiting it. It is no longer pleasant as one cannot wander slowly around. Inside the temple, it is no longer possible to sit and meditate while looking at this beautiful Buddha. The crowd is not made to move in and out very quickly. A real disappointment. But still worth going to sit it.
Must do. Like all the temples / palace, history + jaw dropping beauty of the buildings a must see , must take a guide if you want the story behind it .ps don't expect a huge Buddha like other temples

Please be careful swinder 詐欺師に注意して下さい。. The temple was perfect!The emerald buddha was so beautiful.It was beyond my imagination.But please be careful to swinder.He stood between wat pho and wat plakeo,and pretending to the temple staff.He told the tourist ”Today,there are too many tourist in wat plakeo,so,you won't enter before 12'o clock.”And he reccomend to go another temple first and called tuktuk by himself.But ofcourse that was lie.Please ignore him!!ワットポーとワットプラケオのちょうど間位に立っているおじさんに英語で「今日はワットプラケオが混みすぎてて入場規制がかかっているから、12時まで入れない。先にワットアルンと水上マーケットを見た方が良い。」とかなりしつこく勧められ、「これに乗って！」とトゥクトゥクを呼ばれました。幸い途中で親切な人が真実を教えてくれましたが、ワットプラケオが入場規制をかける事はまずないらしいので、会っても無視して下さい。
Must Visit. When you visit Thailand, no doubt should be there!! Very busy by too many tourists but worthy... Please go and enjoy..

Amazingly beautiful. Very crowded, but worth looking at.I am very much into history, religion and architecture ---but all of that aside I think absolutely anyone would appreciate seeing this temple. The Buddha itself isn't big and massive or anything as some people seem to write about, but to me that's not the significance of a trip there. The tourists are very pushy, aggressive and sometimes treat you like you're transparent or something, but other than that it's magnificent.Just be prepared to take your shoes off and to be inside the not to quiet temple.

tiny ancient artifact. It's located at the very end of the tour. You can't take photos of it..and that's applicable to half of the temples in there. But that's not a problem. I just find it ridiculously hot and exhausted after a long tour. First time? You must check out. Second time? You're kidding eh?..Third time and onwards? You're craaaaaaaazzy
A must see temple complex. We went on a tour with a guide, which I would recommend, it is very busy though, we went in the afternoon, very interesting. Beware the chinese tourists!

Taste of Thailand. I do not know when is the best time to visit attractions in Thailand as it seems to always be busy and crowded. However, our tour guide Lek, expertly navigated us through and away from groups in order for us to fully enjoy the experience. I expected the Emerald Buddha to be much bigger than it really was though. This attraction was quick walk through as it was really crowded.

Unmissable Sight. The Way Phra Kaew and Grand Palace complex is spread over quite a sizeable area. We spent a couple of hours wandering around. There is so much to see and photograph, including several temples and the lovely garden area. This is the most popular tourist attraction in Bangkok, so expect to queue to get in.

OK if you're in the area. This temple gets pretty crowded. Lots of temple 'police' chasing down people to stop photos, so it's hard to enjoy any peace with the constant bustle of people. Not sure why they stop photos as there is a window that looks straight at the buddha where you can get great photos (good zoom required).Like most of the other major temples in Bangkok, worth a look if you're in the area but not one of the seven wonders.Visited February 2013.

What a surprise - the Emerald Buddha is neither emerald nor large!. It was a huge surprise to find that the Emerald Buddha was neither emerald nor was it large. It was tiny in comparison to the many temples that we visited during our stay in Bangkok. The Temples was ornate and beautiful and hundreds of people were visiting this special temple to see the Emerald Buddha. Of course, it is important to respect the local customs of taking off your shoes before entering the temple. It is my strong recommendation that you carry several plastic bags so you can put your shoes in a bag and carry it with you. For you never know, you may come out and find your shoes missing. It is good to be trusting, but why chance it. It is also important to be sure to get a guide before visiting the temple or purchase a small book to give you the historical context of the Temple and the significance of the Emerald Buddha. It is worth the crowds and time to visit the Emerald Buddha. Enjoy.

Very peaceful in a busy city. A wonderful place to visit , just be prepared for crowds, but even so it's very serene and peaceful. Be sure to cover your legs -even the men and ladies have to cover their upper arms, you can hire clothing but it's a bit of an hassle. But the experience was well worth the effort.

smaller than expected. wonderful place packed with beauty and history but also becomes busy very quickly, you don't get close up to this Buddha and you cant take photos inside the temple but this does not detract from the experience

Noisy, not good smelling..... Don't have the traditional incense just the smell of transpiration and feet odor .... Even people ask you to be quiet, the mass of tourists just don't care about these rules especially Chinese one. So you cannot enjoy and meditate the Temple. Also the Emerald Buddha is situated like at 10 meters from you, so you cannot appreciate this famous representation of Buddha tall only by 45 cm.
Interesting. Very interesting to see. It is rather dark inside the temple and by taking a few moments to acclimatize your eyes you will have a better view of the Buddha.

On grounds of Royal Palace. You will want to see this on your Grand Place tour. There is a dress code for Thai temples so make sure you are dressed correctly. Room along with the Emerald (Jade) Buddha is a must to see in Bangkok.

Awesome Buddha. The buddha and the history of it are quite interesting, but this is a major tourist stop. There were too many people to enjoy or get to see it up close unless you want to push and shove your way to the front, which would be disrespectful in a temple.

Bangkok Temples and Canals Tour with Bangkok Day Tours. The actual Emerald Buddha is small, high, and distant. Photos are not allowed in the temple. Luckily large photo cards are available to guides to show the Buddha and the seasonal decorations. The surrounding grounds are a must-see.
Bangkok. This Buddha is fairly small and so high up that one can barely see it. Compared to the Reclining Buddha I found it to be disappointing. It does not leave a lasting impression.

Rather Impressive. Located in the same compound as the grand palace, Wat phra kaew is a rather large temple that is very ornate and detailed. The group of buildings were also very impressive. In the main building, you can see the amount of tourists trying to get in. Definitely a must see.

Wat Phra Kaew / Grand Palace. Incredible temples to view and explore. The intricacy of the buildings is unreal - no photos will ever so it justice, a must see! There are LOTS of tourists. Just try and find a quiet little area to take it all in and enjoy and appreciate the surroundings. I tried to imagine how serene it would be if I were the only person in there! Magical!
Worth seeing. Definately worth seeing,but having been to the reclining Buddha first, nothing compares. Beautiful though.

Beautiful temple. A major attraction in Bangkok. very mesmerising temple both from inside and outside. Architecture, carvings, ornaments, gold, gems and many more beautiful things are the characteristic of this temple. Lord Buddha is seated on the throne high above made of pure emerald stone and pure gold.Though the face of lord is not very clear but the positivity around attracts lot of visitors. It is one of its own kind.
Impressive. It is huge. It is massive. The feet with all budda symbols. The building is imressive to. And finally it is crowded.But if you are i Bangkok, this is one og the "must see"

Excellent architecture but overcrowded.. For those who really appreciate architecture and enjoy history, this is the right place for you. Better to read on the history of the Wat and Hindu-Buddha before you come because there is no any information board available. If you would like to know more, you can hire a guide. It would be better if they have crowd control. Lots of tour there when I was there. I hardly stood still on a spot for more than 1 minute. Beware of scam. There were people offering a boat tour to go around the river. They will approach you nicely and do some sweet talk to you, trying to lure you into their trap. Don't believe them. If you would like to go to Wat Pho, just walk.

Too packed, not worth it if you don't have interest in it.. Way too many tourist. Basically its like a line ride, just slowly walking into the building and then walk out while being cramped by people around you.

Worth visiting. After watching various temples and statues in the heat and crowded touristy area you might feel a bit numb before the next statue. This small green Buddha did impress though. Something magical about it.

Not much to see.. The Emerald Buddha is not large (1 1/2 feet high, if I recall), and most of the Emerald is covered when wearing his 'Winter clothes'. Very impressive history, but you will fight massive crowds to catch a glimpse (and not take a picture of) a small figure, situated 15' off the floor and quite a distance away (depending on how many rows of tourists you fight through). If you enjoyed seeing the Mona Lisa at it's most crowded, this will be right up your alley. If not, maybe sneak a peak through the open door and read about it's background. I would give the Buddha itself a 5, but VISITING the Buddha a 1.
Very ornamental. The grand palace and this temple are very ornamental. Plenty of crowds. Don't go in hot sun. The directions to exit are not clear.

This place is a must. HUGE, very atmospheric place.In some places it is overcrowded and too noisy, in some it is very silent and worth just to spend some time there looking around or simply sitting down.The temple of the Emerald Buddha have very peaceful feeling inside, but it is too crowded...Despite the entrance fee being expensive it has an additional bonus as the entrance ticket allows to visit several other places within 7 days of buying the ticket, which is not obvious to those who can't read Thai. The pink ticket is the one for other places.There's a little food market on the left side of the exit: worth visiting after the temple.Warning: beware of numerous scam clowns who tell you the temple is closed till %some time today%. These are lies, the temple is not closed!

Good sight seeing. A good sight to see for cultural travellers. The ticket is included in Grand Palace's ticket. The whole complex is quite big and takes about 3 hours to visit including grand palace.
Impressive. Another must see location, but no photography allowed. Very busy on 'Buddha days'. If you have a camera with a good lens you can take a photo from outside looking in.

crowded. iw been there on a weekend completely full with tourists. Far too crowded to enjoy to be honest .
Is nice place to see and a great piece of work so you must see it but if any chance choose a weekday rather weekend.

Beautiful but crowded.. We thought visiting on a weekday would be best, but it was still filled with tour groups. We chose not to see the Emerald Buddha, since it was crowded and no photography was allowed. The buildings are ornate and very interesting. Even with the crowds we enjoyed ourselves.
MUST GO!. When in BKK this is the most beautiful temple to go and it is surrounded by many others around the grand palace

Too many people. It would have been nice...but totally spoilt by the amount of people...and I know I'm one of them, but it was absolutely horrendous and I've been in Florence in August which was nowhere near as bad as this. we had to leave early, too much pushing, shoving and total disrespect for my liking.

Emerald. I visited 10 years ago - but 10 years ago - it's much more solemn visiting this place. Today its too crowded and noisy.
But I thank the group who maintains the temple.
It is still a must to visit this place.

Breathtaking but busy. Hubby and I caught a boat to take us to the temple in the morning. The boat trip was a lovely experience in itself. The temple was heaving with tourists, but don't let this put you off. To walk round the temple you should be wearing long trousers and your arms should be covered. However, don't panic if you are not dressed correctly - you can borrow long trousers and shirts from a loan facility near the entrance, where you pay a deposit to borrow appropriate clothing then you get your deposit back. Make sure your batteries are fully charged up in your phones and cameras, there are lots of photos to be taken

a jewel. the rich decorations of the temple assembly, vvarious and fully coloured make this temple the representative work of art of a king. It seemed to me that the satue of Budha was too small for this rich temple.

The Emerald Buddha experience. This is in the grounds of The Grand Palace. Our visit was plagued by hoards of noisy Chinese tourists, which made the experience less than spiritual! Yes it's beautiful with the Buddha being cloaked - it looks quite tiny on top of loads of symbolic gold-work. Maybe if I could have visited with a lot less people around I would have appreciated it more.

Spectacular. Very glad that we went to see this temple. It was very spiritual and calm here in spite of all the other people who were coming through to see it. You just get taken away by the awe of this temple and everyone seemed to talk in a whisper out of respect for where they were and what they were lucky enough to be able to see and take part in. The history of the temples in Thailand has been well preserved. Great cultural tour of Bangkok.

Very Crowded and Difficult to See. The temple is located on the grounds of the Grand Palace and is one of the most popular spots making it extremely crowded. The day we were there, the king was sick so the temple was actually closed to the public while the monks prayed for the king's health. All we could do was look through an open door and catch a glimpse of the buddha. I was surprised that it appeared golden, not green but found out that it is shrouded in a golden cloak. The temple itself is architecturally beautiful. It was actually a very solemn and spiritual experience as so many people were lighting candles and praying for the king.
Great work, impressive statue. The Emerald Buddha it's a gorgeous statue full of emeralds, it is a temple that you should see before leaving BKK
spiritually moving experience. Wonderful and amazing decor. You can feel the positive energy entering this temple. Loved everything about it. Please, no video or pics allowed inside.

One of the must see sires. Like any tourist visiting Bangkok, this way came highly recommended. And we are very glad we went!Not only is this a very spiritual place to pray and meditate, it is beautiful to look at and in good condition. The free maps are a great help for getting you round and there is plenty of security around. It's a bit of a free for all getting in as you'll have to use the 'foreigners' queue but it's worth the pushing. Make sure you cover your knees, although to be honest, they didn't seem that strict on it and a lot of people just loosely wore sarongs. The only downside? The sheer amount of selfie taking Japanese tourists. In every area you can't really see for the amount of cameras twisted into awkward positions to capture them doing the peace symbol with every Buddha! But, it's not the temples fault so don't let it put you off.

Disappointing, but ticked off a list. The crowds at the entrances are manic so be prepared for that Take long trousers and something that covers your shoulders and a hat and water bottle. If you don't have long clothes you can borrow for free (deposit of 200B) There are places where you can fill up your water bottle inside. I thought 500B was expensive and considering the crowd, they sure are making some serious money at this place. I was disappointed with seeing the Emerald Buddha as it is so far away from where you are allowed to stand and it was shrouded in its clothes of a gold cloak, I saw no green at all. Around the temple that houses the emerald Buddha are loads of other temples which mostly you are not allowed in to see but the outsides are very photographic and despite the crowds, there are some quiet areas that you can find to sit and rest in the shade. I found some of the gold, coloured glass and bright paint that covered all the buildings and statues a bit tacky but it was nice to see all the same. Take toilet roll or buy at the toilets.

Im sure its nice but.... This temple is located inside the kings palace complex. Unfortunatly the Buddha is so high up in the air that you can't really see much of it. You also CAN'T take any photography. Understanding that this is a temple and place of worship I'm not upset that you can't take pictures it's just sad that I can't enjoy the Buddha because it is so far away.

Try to take your time. I visited as part of a small tour group, arriving at about 0930, if I had the opportunity to visit again I would leave my Bangkok hotel as early as possible by taxi in an attempt to find the area a little less crowded.Having said that the temple is yet another magnificent example of Thai architecture, art and craftsmanship

Three different sets of Gold Clothing. The Emerald Buddah was moved to its present position in March 1784 . It is made of green jasper or jadeite and the Emerald refers to its dark green colour.It sits atop a huge gold altar in the centre of the temple and is about 2 feet tall.Three times a year the gold clothing is changed with the seasons- summer (crown and jewellery), rainy (gilt robe and headdress) and winter(golden shawl). March,July and November. In this important ritual the clothing is changed by the King. The two sets of clothing not in use are displayed in the nearby Pavilion of Regalia.We visited in November and it was hot and crowded. There is no photography and any attempts and you will be asked to delete the photo.As part of the Royal palace a strict dress code is required.

Absolutely impressive. The entrance fee for the Grand Palace and the Temple of the Emerald Buddha now costs 500 baht and includes entrance to Vimanmek Mansion which is around 4 km from the palace. The overwhelming crowd is something one has to contend with. Do note that one has to be properly dressed to gain entry to the palace. Men must wear long pants and shirts with sleeves. Women must be modestly dressed with the shoulders covered. However, there is a booth near the entrance that can provide clothes to cover you up properly. It is best to observe the dress code before gaining entry to the palace as the queue at the booth may be long or they may run out of clothes. Free guided tours in English are provided at pre-determined time slots. We decided to visit the Coin & Regalia museum while queuing up to enter the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. It was educational and a cool respite from the scorching heat. Bring along lots of water, a hat and a camera as this temple will offer you lots of photo opportunities.

Bling bling golden escapade. This temple is a must visit. If you have limited time in Bangkok, just visit this will do. There are so many gold inside, you will be almost blinded, a truly truly magnificent temple that only a king deserved. Awesome.https://vinshengloh.exposure.co/the-grand-palace-bangkok

Not real emerald. A bit of a let down.. The name is deceiving as it is jadette and real emerald. Shame it shares the same grounds as the grand palace as the staff are unfriendly and impolite and the double pricing is too much in your face.

Crowded experience... Located within The Grand Palace, this temple was one of the most crowded ones and it was difficult to admire its splendor. Not only that, it was HOT!!!! Many people were attempting to take pictures and many succeeded. I cannot understand why tourist were so disrespectufl and not obeying the rules. Many locals were praying too and the temple was very full, so we decided to walk out. Don't forget to wear sleeves/covered knees. Try to enjoy this Wat!!!!

The Emerald Buddha is covered by your admittance to the Grand Palace.. We went to the Grand Palace and the Emerald Buddha. (Admittance is about $15.00.) The Grand Palace and Emerald Buddha are unbelievably beautiful and should not be missed when in Bangkok. You can spend a great deal of time looking around. We were there before the New Year, but it was still just crazy busy, even by mid-morning. There are masses of people trying to get into the temples so you really get up close and personal. That is not a reflection on the beauty of the Emerald Buddha, it is just that there are huge crowds.

Obey the rules. You have to put up with crowds of people for this site. It is very popular so if you want a special photo without people in it you will have to be very patient. There are many signs about no photos of the emerald Buddha in the temple. We witnessed one guy trying to sneak a photo and one of the mean looking guards was right on him. He wacked the guys camera with a device then made him erase the picture. Sometimes it's much less stressful to just obey the rules. It is really debatable if the cost and crowds is worth the look from afar of the actual Buddha. There is much more to see in the palace area though.

Too crowded to enjoy the experience. The temple was OK - not amazing but OK. The experience was spoiled by the overwhelming crowds which, together with the overwhelming heat, made the visit more of an endurance trial.

Busy, but beautiful. This attraction is included in the Grand Palace. When we went, it was Chinese New Year and they were admitting 100,000 visitors per day. So it was a zoo. Yet there were still locals praying at this temple, despite the hordes of tourists. While beautiful, unfortunately you do not get to see the Buddha up close, but it is still definitely worth it.
Awesome. This is another of those beautiful temples that Bangkok is famous for. After seeing this one, I felt like one of the life's main objective has been solved.

Massive Wat and beautiful design. We were amazed at the sheer size and spectacular detail of Wat Phra Kaew! The Emerald Buddha is only one of the many things to see there. We got an audio tour for 400 bhart each and it wasn't great. I would recommend reading about the history of the Wat the night before so you can fully appreciate it. Make sure that your shoulders and legs are covered or else they will make you wait in a long line to rent clothes for the day.

Amazing temple. This temple is quite amazing. Everything is so huge and well made, the level of details is amazing! This is a must if you are staying in Bangkok! The only thing I would say is that you should go there as soon as it opens so you can enjoy the place without that many tourists - it can get insanely crowded.
Intricately beautiful. The interior of this temple is amazingly detailed. I so appreciated being able to see something so beautiful.

A Must See in the Grand Palace. When you purchase your ticket to the Grand Palace, it also includes the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. A modest Dress code is strictly enforced - no shoulder, cleavage, bare midriff or legs showing. Capris on women are not acceptable either. If you do not wear the proper clothes, you will be required to "rent them or you will not be permitted inside the Grand Palace. While photos are allowed on of most of the grand palace, No photos are allowed inside the temple of the Emerald (which is really jade) Buddha. Shoes must be removed, they request that you step over the door lintel and no disrespect is permitted - pointing your feet towards the Buddha is you sit inside the temple. It is crowded and requires stairs to get inside. Photos can be taken from the outside of the temple of the Emerald Buddha inside, but no photos are permitted inside the temple. The Buddha will be wearing one of three different outfits depending upon the season. The King of Thailand personally changes the Emerald Buddha's clothes three times a year and tourists may be restricted during those ceremonies.

So beautiful. Wonderful and very revered so do not attempt to touch any part of the wonderful exhibits at any of the temples. Wear cotton slacks or a skirt ladies AND men. No 3/4 leg slacks. Ankles must be covered and shoulders and no tattoos on show. Remember the clothing bit at the temples or you are in a long queue to borrow slacks.

Beautiful Palace. Absolutely extraodinary place. The grand palace is huge and wonderful. The grounds are beautiful, the palaces magnificent and the statues incredible.A must see in Bangkok. Just remember to hydrate!

Spectacular - but get there early, it's crowded. Well worth the 500 baht (£10) entrance fee, and THE cultural sight to see. More bling than you've ever seen! It opens 8.30 am and it pays to get in early as then it is less crowded. Take water, it is hot. A weekday is best, because the palace - which is included in the entrance fee - is closed at weekends, though it doesn't sound as important as the temple complex. Allow 1.5-2 hours for the temple complex - many stunning constructions and exotic statues and wall paintings to see as well as the temple of the emerald buddha - and then maybe 45 mins for the palace (I don't know, it was closed when we went.) DON'T be put off by anyone outside who may tell you that it is closed, or that you are wearing incorrect clothes. They just want to take you somewhere else where they will get a commission. This happens so often that they now have a loudspeaker outside telling you this. You have to wear clothing covering shoulders and knees, but they loan you a free coverup inside if you forget. Wear old shoes, as you have to leave them outside the door of the temple itself, though you can wear them around the temple complex. I've never had a pair stolen but mine are deliberately old. You can get an audio guide in several languages. The hire is for two hours, and it was very good and gave you a guided tour of the whole place. There is a cafe. There is a river boat stop (no 9?) very close and tourist river buses (40 baht) and public river buses (15 baht) go there. It's a nice cool way to travel.

Beautiful. we have been to Thailand five times, although we have seen it all before this time we booked a guide and have to say it was fantastic to have a local person with us to appreciate so much more from all these wonderful temples. it does get really busy, if you can get to them earlier its worth getting up and having a head start. you won't be disappointed

a gem. This is part of the Grand Palace and therefore very busy. The temple itself is breathtakingly beautiful, amazing attention to detail.You take your shoes off and leave them on the side, once inside the emerals buddah sits high up, clothed in a gold garment, we had been to the museum as you enter by the payment desk, on the rightthis shows the cloaks the emerald buddah wears which change with the season, well worth doing first before you go through and hit the crowds !!
Another stunning temple. Detail, glitz, devotion. Evocative buildings. the calm of the Buddha pervasive over the clammer of the cram of tourists. Must see but after Wat Pho.
Best Wat. In a land of too many temples, this is one of the best. The Emerald Buddha is very enigmatic and you never know what it will be wearing.

Definitely a "must-see". With so many reviews there is nothing left to say more but Wat Phra Kaew definitely must be on your "must see" list when you are in Bangkok. First of all, beware of the scammers, if you are on your own and not a part of an organized group. Just ignore everybody approaching you and saying that the Palace is closed and he can bring you to other sightseeings. I was only with my wife and son and we encountered one of those guys.This temple was built to house an image of Buddha, made from a big piece of green mineral. King Rama I brought it from Laos at the end of the 18th century.When you enter, the chapel with the Emerald Buddha is just in front of you but it is its back. On your left is the Upper Terrace which is a little elevated. On it, there are a chedi and 2 other ornate buildings - Phra Mondop and the Raoyal Pantheon. You will see also a model of Angkor Wat on the Upper Terrace.On the other side of the Upper Terrace you will see 3 smaller buildings - one houses the ashes of minor Royal members, one has Buddhist texts stored inside. The exit will take you directly to the Central Court of the Grand Palace.It is open from 8:30 AM till 3:30 PM (so don't get there too late!). The fee is 500 baht and includes the Grand Palace, Wat Phra Kaew and the Vimanmek Mansion.Of course, you must be properly dressed for a temple.

The palace and the emerald Budda. I visit the palace on 17-2-2015, the palace is easy to get to by boot dok 8 cost 40 bath, after you arrived at dok 8 take the first street to the left, the walk is about 15 minuts to the head gate, be ware of all the people at the side gates who tell you that the palace and the Emerald Budda are closed for the day because they are cheaters that want to take you to a other temple where they try to get you into a shop were you can buy so called expensive stones very cheap, in best case they are one thirt of the value that you paid for. The palace is very Beautiful and the Emerald Buddha is on the same place, it is very special to see, I fond the wealth impressive, very nice place to visit.

Beautiful architecture.. Have visited Bangkok many times and have been wishing to see this temple for ages.But could not do so as it is not included in the Bangkok city tours being situated far off.One has to have at least half day to visit this attraction.Means of travelling are either by boat or by taxi or tuk tuk.Tuk tuks are more expensive than the taxis.Best time to visit is as early as possible in the morning as the entry closes after 2 or 3 pm. Wear a dress which covers your shoulders and knees other wise you have to spend time to borrow clothes from the attraction museum (free of cost).The architecture is amazing but it is very crowded and one has to be beware of pickpockets.

A Bangkok Must!. This was one of the first things we did in Bangkok and it was really enjoyable. The architecture and colors were breathtaking. We went midday and there were a lot of people but the sights surrounding you demand so much attention that you almost don't notice them. Definitely wear sleeves and pants with no holes. If you don't they will make you wait in line to rent some to wear. And there are a lot of scammers in the area who will tell you that it is closed. Don't believe them!

Intruiging and inspirational. Visited with a Thai friend, who enriched the experience with details about the Emerald Buddha. Unfortunate that we were not permitted to take photos inside the temple, but we did enter and soak up the special atmosphere and history.

Stunning but GO EARLY. This is the MUST SEE in Bangkok, but my advice is GO EARLY to avoid the crowds.I have been twice and the first time when we got there at opening time it wasn't full of coachloads of tourists. It is a far better experience like so many things with less people and cameras clicking.

really beautifull, but really human traffic. if i would know, i would never go there, there is so many people around... colours are fab, architecture is just psychedelic, but too many people! no chance to make a photo...

Temple of the emerald buddha image. It's history of the Siam country which date back from 18 century when king rama 1 was established Bangkok as capital of the country so, therefore the king 's palace was built at the same time , royal temple was built also ,and it's call the temple of the emerald buddha image . ofcourse it represents for buddist religion as the most important religion of the country. anyhow there are also Catholic religion, kongfushio o Chinese religion , Tao & ,etc. including islam religion too. In former time, most of the building was built by teakwood , lacquer , colour glasses , mother of pearl ,and solid gold ,etc. on the other hand , the royal palace stand for a residenced for royal family and It looks peacefully for the life along the bank of the Chaophaya river or the east of the Venice .

Excellent place & full of history. Beautiful place. The emerald Buddha with different costume related to the season. The temple wall telling the story. This is another place, I'd to take my foreigner friends to this place. The only thing is that the temperature is super hot in daytime and it's not easy to find the parking. The tuk tuk seems to overcharge wherever you like to go from this place. The best transportation, I love is by Boat.. the price is low and it's very good scenery along the boat route.

Best part of the Grand Palace Tour. Bit crowded though we went early. The wall painting (full wall covered) was amazing. It is a lovely temple and very peaceful inside. You would need to keep shoulders and legs covered, but if you don't they have vendors outside the palace selling wrap around skirts etc. for about 100 baht each.
Amazing. It was extremely crowded with large numbers of tour groups but still worth a visit. Ensure both women and men are dressed appropriately, long pants and no bare shoulders.

Very Spiritual. The Emerald Buddha was smaller than I had expected, but still a very spiriitual experience. The whole Temple complex where the Buddha is housed, is fantastically ornate and very beautiful.

Amazing temple. Nice and clean and superb location . The buddha was awesome and clicked some nice pictures. There were nice idols of the other gods and it is good to see the different cultures protected so beautifully thru the ages.

Beautiful. This temple is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple in Thailand. The King changes the cloak around the statue three times a year, corresponding to the summer, winter, and rainy seasons, an important ritual performed to usher good fortune to the country during each season. It's worth seeing.

Cultural but very busy and beware of scams. Great for culture, but get there very early as it soon fills up with tourists and tour groups from cruise ships etc. plus it's very big with lots to see. Do not listen to anyone who tells you it is closed and tries to take you somewhere else, they are scamming you! we saw this so much right outside the entrance gate despite the loud speaker saying repeatedly not to ignore anyone telling you it's closed. Enter through gate three, keep walking till you find it, again ignoring many scammers.You must have your knees and shoulders covered, don't be an ignorant tourist and think you can get into a holy place without being respectful and dressing appropriatly! This is strictly enforced on both men as well as women. if you aren't covered up you will be refused entry until you rent trousers/shawl onsite by paying a deposit. It is definitely worth the visit, put aside at least three hours. Don't miss out the grand palace too.
Unmissable. Part of the Grand Palace. This lovely Temple is within the confines of the Grand Palace. It is truly (a much over-used word) awesome. Don't miss it.

Impressive. Same location as Royal Palace area. Impressive to see as well as the other buildings and temples in that same area (only one entrance fee for all; remember to dress appropriately, covered shoulders and pants, but they will have clothing on loan if needed)
Amazing. This is a huge temple. Best to go in the morning at opening time. Went there at noon, it is so hot. N lots of people. Very interesting g how the people of ancient time built this.

Lovely. The whole complex of the Palace and Temples is fascinating and more than worth the visit. You need to bring water!!! And there is a dress code but they also rent longer clothes at the gate. Go early in the morning or late in the afternoon as then its a bit cooler and less people.

A must-see!. The Emerald Buddha is one of the "required viewing" temples such as the Reclining Buddha. It is peaceful and highly detailed, so take your time. Give it the respect it deserves and look for beauty everwhere - it takes a while to soak it all in. The Thai people are internationally known for being polite and friendly, so getting around is not difficult. Expect to pay a small entrance fee if you're not Thai - this happens at many places and is their way of taking care of their own. Most Thai are not rich and this is their heritage, so I think it's a good idea they can get in to their own temples for free.Also, a countrywide note about Buddhism, always treat Buddha with respect - you should never buy a Buddha or get one as a tattoo. Also, never make bad comments about the King or Queen, they are very loved by Thai people, you would be insulting their parents!

The Window of Thailand. The Grand Palace once used to be the royal family palace but now become the royal praying room in the special events. The most important thing in this gigantic praying room is "Emerald Buddha" that Thai people believe that he can bring whatever you wish in a positive way to you and others. Emerald Buddha is unique in Thailand and he has three costumes in three seasons (summer, winter, rainy seasons). Another important thing is the Ramayana story that is beautifully painted on the wall around the palace (please study the Ramayana story before visiting the place and you will find it very interesting). You can also see the Himmapayana animal statues around the palace (e.g. Kinnaree - a half bird half woman creature, Singha - a lion, Garuda - a bird, etc.). These animals are believed to be the guardians of the palace as well as Vessuwan Giants - a God of demon. The statue of Guan-in or Guan-im Bothisattva is here. Some believe that he/she will become the future Buddha. Moreover, this is the place to commemorate the previous Kings' goodness and has the former Kings' ashes inside. There're so many details in this sacred place that I can't explain all in this space and every small details are meaningful. For example, the Garuda (bird) statue that holds Naga (snake) in hand has a long fighting legend, some pavilions named after the heavens (e.g. Dusit, etc.), the pagoda that has many Giants at the basement holding it is also in Thai legend, and so many more for you to discover.Before visiting, please check the ticket price at the Tourism Authority of Thailand (TAT) online or at the official booths because there're many fake guides. Please respect the place and dress politely. There's the place to change your clothes if you dress improperly (I'm not sure whether you have to pay or deposit cash or not). The Grand Palace is the main tourist attraction so there're many tourists all year round.

Beautiful - a must see. You cannot take pictures inside, however you can from outside and with huge doors open, there is a lot of inside that you can see. The temple is so amazingly decorated that you could spend hours there inside and outside looking at all the details.
Enchanting and out of time. The location whithin the king's palace is fantastic, the decoration is superb and the Buddha statue is emanating a sense of peace.

STUNNING ARCHITECTURE. Well worth a visit especially at night time. See working monks in discussions in the main hall. Doesn't need a lot of time so a good 'filler'
We took photographs and nobody objected.
Has some scaffolding work at the moment, detracting from its splendour.
Wonder of oriental beauty. This temple is very beautifull with marvelous decoration artwork. Unforntunatly very crowded and not permiting taking photos.

A good experience. There is not I can say about the emerald Buddha. You should see it. It's fantastic.
The Buddha had been encased in plaster and was only discovered recently (early to mid 20th century. It's quite a sight.

The most beautiful temple in Thailand. If you visit Bangkok, Wat Phra Kaew is the amaizing place you must not miss. Not only the temple , but the surrounding area is very beautiful, you can see the Grand Palace. It' s very nice picture when the sunset . It makes my heart feel happy and peaceful every time I worship the Emerald Buddha. So I love to go there on new year day. There are many beautiful and wonderful arts and cultures you can see at Wat Phra Kaew. It' s worth to visit and don' t forget to bring your camera and hat or umbrella with you because it' s very sunny in Thailand.
nice and zen place. nice and zen placesimilar with wat oho but different style temple. with golden budda will make u be calm. with grand place, this temple is great place to visit

Wow factor. Just beautiful. Must see. The details from floor to ceiling is breathtaking. We could stay all afternoon in there just tracing each detail inside. The exterior is as beautiful. No photos inside. Watch for shoe snatchers. My wife and I bought a tote bag for 100baht on KSR just to carry our shoes,

Wonderful but over corwded. The temple is amazing just like any other in Thailand, however the usual problems apply, lots and lots of people. We had a guide who helped us beat the queues and also allowed us to take our time when we were in, never felt rushed.Great to see, but I don't think you will stay there for long!
Full but amazing . Full of course but worth it. A lot of wonders together. Take it easy and all the people around won't annoy you.

Very Impressive. In our travels we have been to many Temples, this is a very impressive one. The scams outside that most talk about are not a big problem any longer. They now have tourist police that watch for such actions and are very helpful. Once inside be prepared for some large crowds, the Temple and Palace area are very large. You need to wear long pants and your shoulders must be covered, they will provide garments if needed. I would suggest you go in the AM, as the afternoon heat, along with crowds can make for an unpleasant visit. Taking the tour on your own is very possible as once you get your ticket and proceed into the Temple yard you can sign up for a free English and other language tour given by one of their guides at no cost. The complete guided tour takes about 1 hour, you can then visit the museums on your own. There is a lot of walking, food, drinks and restrooms are aviable.
Was okay. Too many tourists and I expected it to be bigger. The building was gorgeous to look at but it was so overcrowded that I couldn't breathe. Only go if it's a light tourist day.

very nice, part of grand palace. this temple is part of the grand palace, entrance at the moment 500 Bhat...
very very busy place!!! but worth to see...
no pictures allowed inside the temple, only to look at the buddha or pray.

Yet another Temple!. For me all the Temples in Bangkok are worth a visit but others may tire of it. This one was particularly good as the Buddha was raised allowing an unobstructed view as it can get crowded,morning might be the best time to visit. Don't forget to dress appropriately.

Beautiful temple next to Palace. You need to be properly dressed. No 3/4th, half pants or short skirts. No sleeveless t shirts / tops.Otherwise you need to queue up and for a refundable deposit get a full pants/ tshirts/stoles.There is an entrance fee of 500 Baht for palace and temple.Temple complex comprises of many temples, you should marvel at the complex architecture and gold monuments.Temple of emerald buddha is divine. Buddha statue is so beautiful. Photography is not allowed for emerald buddha once inside the room. However you can take as many pics form outside. If they catch you taking pics inside, they will take your mobile/ camera and will delete all. Carry sufficient water and sun-shade, hats, umbrellas, glasses as it becomes really hot during the day.

Very Crowded, but a Must See. Everyone who visits Bangkok will go to see the Emerald Buddha which is actually made of green jade. It is a venerated statue in a beautiful setting. Be prepared to deal with the crowds of people and be prepared to remove your shoes if you want to go inside the temple.

Very interesting temple. All the temples in Bangkok are worthwhile visiting and this one is no exception. It is part of the Palace complex and should not be missed. It is very beautiful. Pictures are allowed but no flash please. Highly recommended.There is no fee for this attraction but you will pay a fee when you enter the palace grounds.

Time your visit. If you go around the noon time, you will be scorched! Go early. Look for a good guide. Or at least get a Audio tour Walkman thing. Difficult to get though! They "mysteriously" run out. Crowded place. So, you need to go early. Majestic Buddha though. Set up in a high place so you get a good view. But the distance means you only get a glimpse.This is of course not an Emerald Buddha as the material is Jade. Can't afford to miss this place though. A must see in BKK.

Beautiful EMERALD Buddha!!!. A must see...the intricate artwork...the colors...the splendor and the serenity of the Temple where the Buddha sits despite the hustle bustle of tourists is an amazing experience...the Buddha inspires devotion and well is a tranquilizing experience!!!

Another big temple. After visiting reclining Buddha, we visited this place. Try and go early in morning, so crowds are less. It can get very hot too. Do wear proper dress (cover everything except face); and be careful of pickpockets. Overall, a good place to go if you have extra day on hand.

One of the best Buddha Temple in Bangkok..must see. I visited Bangkok in my honeymoon trip.(Phuket-Pattaya-Bangkok).On second day we Visited Emerald Buddha Temple.Emerald Buddha Temple and the Grand Palace comes together and it is a must visit if you are on a short trip two Bangkok.This is an excellent architecture to savor with eyes.I am not so good in describing divinity of a temple like this,but I can assure it will drive you through an un-parallel world.I have uploaded some of the pictures,you can have an essence of its excellency from the snaps.

The emerald buddha is blissful... I didnt have a clue of how big the emerald buddha will be.. when I reached the place, it was an awesome and blissful sight to view the emerald buddha in his full glory. This is walkable within the palace campus. if you had hired the audio guide, it will help you understand the history behind these places.You can click photos (you need to zoom) from outside of the sanctum santorum.

A must to visit. This place is a must to visit, though the mass of tourists at almost any time of the day is somewhat bothersome in a place were contemplation was the reason d'être of the monument.
But the impressive art in he whole place is just unique. Impressive also the effort by the authorities to maintain the site.

awesome. We saw the Emerald Buddha as part of the tour of the Grand Palace, Yo are not allowed to take photos once inside the temple, but you can from outside. He is surprisingly small, but still beautiful to look at.
Nice visit. It is worth a couple of hours to see the place. The Buddha is quite impressive. It may be quite crowded at times, and hot. It is recommended to go in the morning.
A far Buddha. Like more wats in Thailand, this one is ornate. The emerald Buddha is so far away, you can hardly see it. It is green. That it's made of emerald, you have to take their word for it.
Not worth it. Lots of temples in Bangkok. Wish I had gone with my instinct and skipped this one. Plus, I'm sure my pockets were picked.
Great. Very nice. Beutifully decorated. Inspite of the crowds, it was nice to experience the temple. It is part of the Grand Palace complex.

Stunning. I was glad to see that they really maintained this temple well. It looks not much different from my visit a few years ago, couldn't get bored of visiting the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew. One reminder is that you must follow their dressing code, else you have to borrow some clothes to cover your legs and other parts of the body.

Well worth the admission. Go early and plan to spend a good part of your day. Do dress appropriately (covered arms and legs) as you will be pulled from the line and asked to return to the entrance to obtain loaned clothing if you are not respectfully dressed. The art and architecture of this wat are quite awe inspiring. Don't miss the Queen Sirikit textile museum which is also on the grounds. The explanation of how Thai silk and design became well-known to the rest of the world is very good. While the prices for textiles are fairly high for some items, the shop will help you set standards for later purchases.

Emerald Buddha. This is a glorious building, beautifully decorated. It's in the complex of The Grand Palace. You'll be asked to remove your shoes and have your knees covered both men and women, The crowds can be quite large and there is no help for handicapped. Do go inside to see many colors.

Temple - GoPro - YouTube. Very nice temple. Dress Code is pants and T-shirt. Free clothes are available if your underdressed but they won't make for a good picture. A lot of walking is required, if your backpacking it can get very hot. Cost 400BHT.Check out my short Youtube video below.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yt13k74ttsE&list=PL5rIS5J94qjdtoVI4adzoERL86bO4Y4oa&index=2
Thailand 2015. Part of the Grand Palace tour as located with the compound. Interesting especially the details of the architecture and sculptures .

Crowded 24/7. This temple is within the walls of the Grand Palace of Thailand. The entrance fee its by far the biggest of all the attractions but you have a lot to see inside. The complex is massive with at least 5 or 6 areas to see and explore.
