The Emerald Buddha itself its quite out of reach and difficult to appreciate mainly because of the distance of you with the statue.The most annoying thing about this place its the amount of people that attracts. Its by far the most crowded place in Bangkok with hordes of tourist and locals wandering the halls and areas of this place. The heat doesn't help (typical from Bangkok) and the fact that you don't have a train or metro station close by makes it even worst sometimes. The best thing to access this place its by the river, coming from the Sathon Boat station that is connected with the BTS.Its different and full of history but try not to be wear down by the crowds..

Beautiful. This is a beautiful temple and Buddha. We sat in the temple for awhile admiring everything and it gave us a chance to rest. Photos aren't allowed and there are the typical temple clothing requirements; Men wearing longer pants and women wearing longer pants/skirts.

Go for the Buddha, but the architecture is more amazing to me. First off, when dropped off by a taxi driver, don't expect to get dropped off right at the entrance- they get in trouble for that (as my taxi driver apparently discovered). Also, when you get to the entrance, there will be many toots wearing official looking badges and saying something about tickets, and the palace being closed, and trying to escort you somewhere else. Ignore them, they aren't official and they probably are trying to cheat you, but the police will do nothing about them other than posting signs giving you the same advice. 500 Baht gets you a ticket to see the Emerald Buddha and Grand Palace complex, plus free entry into the coin and jewelry antiquities museum (which I felt was small but well done). The Emerald Buddha is impressive to your eye in spite of its small stature and distance, but the guards are very brusque about trying to move people through and if you take a picture (which you aren't supposed to), they will strong arm you into deleting it while they watch. As a result, what has the potential to be an impressive memory becomes damaged by the rush of it all.The buildings, though, set in multiple styles, are a treat to the architecturally inclined. But because the buildings are intended for the use by the Thai king and his family, entry into most of the buildings is either impossible or limited to a few special occasions a year. Surrounding the entire complex is a covered walkway with, I think 700+ murals describing the life of Buddha, but I didn't find them particularly enlightening. If you can be there just before 10 or 10:30 am, or 1 or 1:30, there are guided tours done in heavily Thai accented English (which I had no problems with, but some in our group were more aurally challenged). The tour is very informative and covers both parts of the entire complex, but with a catch: once you move over to the Grand Palace, you will not be allowed to return to the Emerald Buddha, so make sure you saw your fill before you take the tour.When taking your picture with the demons and monkeys, please remember to stand with the monkeys if you want to get more intelligence and with the demons if you want more power!My biggest disappointment is that they don't make it possible to stand above the scale model of Angkor Wat that is on the grounds. Only being able to view it from the side is not very worthwhile.

A Wonderful Temple.. A Beautiful temple full of history, although the Buddha statue is called "Emerald Buddha Statue", its actually an "Emerald Coloured Jade Buddha Statue".Its good to take a Guide or Guide Book if you want the real history which is very interesting, as language is a big problem in Thailand.Also check on the days the temple is open as some days the place is closed.Be Appropriately dressed as a mark of respect to Buddhism.Also be conscious of Pickpockets although its a religious place.
Amazing temple. The emerald buddha is actually pretty small and far away so hard to see but the entire complex is amazing and worth the visit.

Better than the rest. Sometimes in places like Thailand you can get all templed out quite quickly and everything becomes a blur ,so if you are in danger of that, reserve this temple and buddha as one you must see , because it is worth it. The building in which it is housed is a marvel of intricate decoration and the buddha itself is beautiful.

a gem-the emerald Buddha. no amount of words will ever describe the feeling and the divinity I got when I was in the huge sanctum sanctorum of the Emerald Buddha.It was one of the huge buildings within the huge Gardens of the Palace.very strict about dress code,fully covered,no sleeveless,no shorts scene.there are various rooms to be seen also,like the arms room,the weapons room,the garden itself.the gold plated structure was a great structure itself.i was in awe of the beautiful Emerald Buddha.must go and take time off to stand in the queue,get the tickets,etc and see the huge palace grounds Wat Phra Kaew.

Bangkok Visit. Green Buddha is a fantastic must see attraction. Marvellous temple and surrounding buildings. Simply devine if you like intricate architecture. History of Green Buddha and three seasons dress very interesting.

Fascinating. This temple has the emerald Buddha. One should visit early in the day ( temple opens at 8.30am ). The whole compound is fascinating but these chinese tour groups make it a little annoying with lots of pushing & shouting. Altogether a great experience & a must visit for everyone visiting bangkok.
Impressive. Frankly, if you've seen one temple in Thailand, you've seen them all. However, the Emerald Buddha is a unique and almost unimaginable spectacle. It is really something to see.
Simply, the best!!!. Outstanding Thai architecture, bright colors, culture immersion, history rich, beautiful!!! Cover your shoulders and legs.

famous tample in bangkok. According to legend the Emerald Buddha statue originated in India, however other legends claimm it was originally from first vassal Kingdom of Cambodia. The image disappeared when Burmese raiders sacked Ayuttaya also spelt "Ayudaya" and the image was feared lost.[1]Statue of a kinnara in Wat Phra Kaew, Bangkok (Thailand).Continuing with the legend of the saint Nagasena of India, after remaining in Pataliputra (present day Patna) for three hundred years, the Emerald Buddha image was taken to Sri Lanka to save it from a civil war. In 457, King Anuruth of Burma sent a mission to Ceylon with a request for Buddhist scriptures and the Emerald Buddha, in order to promote Buddhism in his country. These requests were granted, but the ship lost its way in a storm during the return voyage and landed in Cambodia. When the Thais captured Angkor Wat in 1432 (following the ravage of the bubonic plague), the Emerald Buddha was taken to Ayutthaya, Kamphaeng Phet, Laos and finally Chiang Rai, where the ruler of the city hid it. Cambodian historians recorded capture of the Buddha statue in their famous Preah Ko Preah Keo legend
Very nice place. Good to see one time, wen enjoy the visit and this templeEverything was nice with family.. I recommand this place !
Stunning. If you don't go you are foolish. Its stunning and there is a a peaceful vibe despite the hoards of people.

Wonderful Temple. This is a beautiful place to visit. There is lots of unique Thai architecture and history. Go early in the morning to avoid the crowds especially for the tour groups. Wear long dress or pants and cover your shoulder & arms. The Buddha that is in a lying down position in the Temple is just incredible. Please be very respectful as this is truly a sacred place. The grounds ate full of beautiful trees, gardens and nice buildings. Outside there are food vendors and other vendors as well. There are lot of Tuk-Tuk as well in case you have to take one back to where you came from. There is a so so bathroom and I believe you have to pay and there are benches outside the bathroom area for picnics. This is a must to do attraction.
BEAUTIFULL TEMPLE. We have too short time. I love this temple so much. It shows art, culture and love. I will come back again soon and will spend longer time here.

Places of Worship National Treasure. Official name is Wat Phra Si Rattana Satsadaram. Open daily except day has ceremony. It has over 100 buildings in Rattanakosin style (old Bangkok style) in the Grand Palace. So If you have more time and very appreciate in thai cultural like painting, architecture literature and history, you may must come here early when it open with less crowd and impress for long time.Ticket entry is 500 Baht that may make you feel expensive but infact, it very so cheap because ticket include many famous and important places that you can visit in Bangkok and Nakhon Pathom as Wat Phra Kaew, Museum of National Treasures, The Royal Palace, Vimanmek Throne and 7 Dependent buildings in Bangkok and Nakhon Pathom PalaceAppropriate dress, Man use long sleeve shirts, t-shirts, shirts, long pants, Woman use t-shirts, shirts, dresses, skirts, long pants. If improperly dressed, they provide proper attire for sale in cheap and nice which be Thailand Souvenir :)

Tour Groups. The temple itself was awesome. No doubt about it. We took loads of pictures...but...mostly...of the rooftops... because we didn't want to spoil them with pictures of bus-loads of noisy Asian tour groups with their large hats, bagpacks and umbrellas. The tour groups are a-plenty and we were very disappointed that they had very little respect for the sanctity of the Temple as they spoke loudly and shouted at one another. Almost all of them! This included the tour operators. They also had even less respect for other tourists as they pushed and shoved their way around to get to the front of the line at all the entrances and the better view for a good camera shot. Very annoying! Being half Asian, I was embarassed by them. I almost wished that the authorities would limit the number of large tour groups at any given time and give priority to other smaller numbers or single tourists. In any case, this is a must visit when one is in Bangkok. Be sure to wear long pants and sleeved t-shirts (no sleeveless). Lest you want to queue to get a loaned sarong / shirt!

Breathtaking!. Fantastic day out here, think "The king and I" absolutely fantastic to see and worth the wait to get in. Always busy with lots of queues so patience is the name of the game, but you won't be disappointed once you're in there. Take your camera.

Excellent - a must see. If you are in Thailand you should definitely visit the temples & emerald Buddha. It's a fascinating place, beautiful & amazing. It does get very busy in parts, so you should go prepared, however there are also parts which aren't as busy & you can walk around freely! If you want to go into the temple to see the emerald Buddha you need to ensure you are wearing the correct clothing, arms & legs need to be covered! You can borrow clothes free of charge however the que was horrendous!

Lovely Temple. From the highly decorated, photogenic outside to the serene, photography-free atmosphere on the inside, this place is worth the visit. It's located in a mini city of temples and also next to the Grand Palace, take a moment to admire this landmark.

The construction is marvelous!. If you are in Bangkok, take out time to visit this wonderful Wat Phra Kaew. It's the tour that you will cover as part of Grand Palace tour. beautifully created, you need to walk around the whole temple and palace. Make sure the temperature is not soaring when you visit this place as you have to walk in open.
Just ok. This Buddha is very small and sits high up in a large temple so difficult to see any detail. Overall a bit of a disappointment after the crowds and heat endured in order to get to see it.

Beware the Crowds. It use to be that you could get to the palace at 8:30 when they opened and you would bypass the tour groups, but they seem to have figured out this trick and are now there when they open. So still get there early but hurry up to the ticket booth and get inside, the groups get there tickets and dawdle taking photos. You cannot take photos of the Emerald Buddha as a warning and must take your shoes off to go inside the temple. Please be respectful inside and keep quiet as locals come to pray here every day. The guardian statues and the chedis and stuppas are all great to take photos of, but in the end remember you are in a holy place....

Palace is a must, but we could take or leave it.. Our visit to the Emerald budha was ok. it was pretty hot and we did hire a guide for $20 US. She was funny and informative but really tried to rush us past many or the murals and other out buildings. it was really apparent that she was gearing to the next tour. As for the budha it is really small and way up tippy top of a building. you better have great eyesight. it was impressive and beuatuful but again we could have by passed it with out a problem. plus the cost for our family seemed high campared to what you got for it. enjoy
Impressive. The buddha is really far away and you can't really see it, but this is really the most impressive temple so it's a must see.

Superb with the palace. This is the most commercial of the Wats and I must say that to pay the equivalent of £10 each to enter the temple is a tourist rip-off. The whole place is undoubtedly beautiful and historic but reeks of the tourism trap. Oh and chaps, you have to buy long trousers outside to enter.
Different. Worth a trip, but there are other temples even more interesting. Leave it to be the last one in your list. Also, you can't take a pic inside!

Tour of the Sacred Temple of the Emerald Buddha. The most revered Temple in Bangkok. People were so respectful of this Temple. Be prepared for large crowds of people trying to photograph the Emerald Buddha from the outside (no photos from inside). These temples are so different from other temples we visited in Asia. Well worth seeing.

Wat Phra Kaew. The emerald budda and its wat are impressive to see but due to it being part of the grand palace it is very busy!! I would like to have seen it in the low season to see if it makes a difference.
Impressive. The colours! The majesty! We don't have anything like this is in the UK. One thing if you don't like taking your shoes off, don't go
Interesting Temple - another must see. Don't forget to go a view this temple as this is very interesting and depending on the season depicts the dress that this Buddha is wearing.

Colorful Place. Royal Palace and Temple of the Emerald Buddha dates back to 1782 when Bangkok was founded and an interesting place to visit. the colourful status attracts tourists like anything and I am sure that you'll also like the place like me. Lot of history is associated with this place. This place should be included in your day's tour.
Serene. Inside Grand Palace. Entry fee of 500 Baht along with Grand Place which is must see. Have to follow dress codes for entry. No Photos allowed.
very small. I thought it would be a bigger buddha after seeing the reclining buddha. plus it was not emerald...only Jade. very small and hard to see since it was so high up.
Unique. Very hard to see the emerald buddha r/t all the people. The whole palace was beautiful and worth a visit.

H is so Tiny. I was expecting a much larger Buddha figure but it was fun to learn about his dress and how it is changed for the seasons. Again we had and excellent tour guide Air of BKK tours who made everything easy to understand.

Go early. One of the official tour guides inside the tmple will give you a short hour long tour for about 500 baht which is totally worth it! It gives you an idea of what you are actually looking at - which in such a busy and marvellous temple is soooooo necessary.

Wow. Did the tour with Tour East booked through Viator as part of the Grand Palace Tour, if you get the opportunity to visit the Grand Palace you will not be disappointed. Amazing place, tends to be very busy, make sure you wear clothing to cover your knees and shoulders and also closed in shoes they dont like sandals. If you go into the Temple of the Emerald Buddha please make sure you do not point your feet at the buddha as this is supposed to be very rude.

Emerald Buddha. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew) is a definite must see during a trip to Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha itself is small and set on a raised platform. However the temple and the surrounding grouds are really lovely and photo opportunities abound. Well worth a visit.

gorgeous. The grounds beautiful. It's crowded. I liked using the audio for 200B (left my credit card as a deposit) which was very informative since I didn't have a tour guide. There's so much to take in. Dress properly to avoid the costume line and the someone yelling you're inappropriate. Not me but a poor gal in front of me. She was fine. She had a proper dark wrap around her. Others passed who were improper. Some came in proper & disrobed inside for photos. The temple is beautiful. The treasures are worth seeing.
Do not miss this place. We said this temple was the Sistine Chapel of Buddhism. It is stunning. It is very large and full of different architecture and symbols....truly remarkable.

A small but significant Emerald Buddha.. Buddhists in Laos believe this Buddha belongs to their country while Thai Buddhists are vehement it is theirs and always has been. The history of the Buddha is very interesting. It is forbidden to take photos inside the Wat but the central temple windows are left open and so with a zoom lens it is possible to take a great photo of the Buddha.

Stunning Temple Grounds. Wat Phra Kaew was the most elaborate and ornate temple sites I saw during my visit to Bangkok. There are so many statues and temple buildings, each with slight variations in detail and style, that it can almost be too much to take in. This wat is within the Grand Palace compound, and you pay one entry fee to get in. but you'll probably spend most of your time marveling at the structures around Wat Phra Kaew. Although the emerald buddha statue itself is not very large, it is very beautiful and is housed in a gorgeous room with many offerings. You will definitely want to set aside a few hours to explore this wat while in Bangkok.
Fab!. Get there early to avoid queues and make sure you wear shoes that you can take off and put on easily.

A magnificent statue in the grand palace. This is a great statue of lord buddha which radiates great spiritual energy. It is located in the heart of the grand palace which makes it all the more special.

Tourist Attraction. We visited the Emerald Buddha within the Grand Palace complex. The temple area is beautiful and I love the fact that they dress the Buddha in different clothes depending of the season of the year.

Wow! Worth a visit. The stunning architecture in here will blow you away. Steep price to get in I agree however you get to see quite a lot! Make sure you are dressed conservatively and get your camera charged!

A must see. A must see. The Buddha itself is only 66 cm and up in the air. It's very beautiful especially the costume (changes 3 times a year for cold, rainy and summer). The overall decor is really something to see. Only thing I didn't like was some of the non respectful tourists. It clearly said no picture allowed and some people had no shame flashing their cameras left and right.

Loved it.. The work that was put into the altar where the Buddha sits is incredible as well as the peace you feel when you enter it. THe story of the Buddha is very interesting and comes to show why the Thai people pay so much respect to him.

beautiful but double pricing applied. It's one of the must-see places in Bangkok. Unfortunately, like many other places in Thailand (national parks, amusement parks, even some restaurants) they have double pricing scheme. Foreigners pay a LOT more than Thais.

beautiful temple. Just beautiful and the emerald Buddha looked so pure and full of light. Unfortunately the hoards of tourists ruined any feelings of spirituality, a woman next to me was actually on her mobile phone.

Historical treasure. The temple itself is a decorative marvel. Ceramics and tiles are amazing. Wall paintings tell many stories. This temple has large grounds and very busy with tourists so allow plenty of time.

Beautiful Emerald Buddha. One of the star attractions in Bangkok is the the beautiful Emerald Buddha located in the Grand Palace complex.The Buddha image is not very large and is covered in a gold coat the changes depending on whether it's summer or winter.To pay your respect to the Buddha you will need, like all other temples to remove your shoes before entering the buildings. No photography is allowed inside. As the most revered Buddha image, Thai's visit to pray so you will need to respect them. It gets extremely busy with crowds throughout the day so it's best to get there early.
Jade Wonder. The temple is splendid and the little Buddha is inspiring. It changes costumes with the summer, winter, and rainy seasons. Another must in Bangkok.
Fabulous. Has to be seen to be believed. A great experience, ring the bells and drop your coins in little containers asking blessings for everybody you know. Fab photo spot

interesting place. It is quite an impressive place,but i won't be going to any more temples. They are all far too geared towards donations donations donations. We got a 'blessing'' from a monk for about 20 secs ,with the last words in english being 'make a donation in the box' !

very interesting... shame about the crowds.. We spent a few hours here. All the temples were really impressive and the museums in the grand palace were fascinating. It's a shame that the crowds were so huge so I'd maybe suggest getting up really early and having a look around before the mobs of large group tours show up.

Buddhist or not you should pay a visit. Here is the must visit place in Bangkok. Even if you are Buddhist or not, you shouldn't miss this holy place. You can see the beauty and rich culture in this temple, together with the traditional art everywhere. However, it's really crowded so I recommended to come early.For those who don't want to have a tour guide you can rent audio guide too.Tips: wear appropriate outfit or you have to rent the clothes there.
Visit to the temple & Grand Palace. It was okay, no wow factor but worth a visit when in the Grand Palace, which is a lot more interesting. Definitely worth a visit if you like temples/pagodas etc.
Extremly beautiful!. It is one of the most beautiful religious temples i ve ever seen!Every inch of it ,is exquisitevly decorated.
An absolute must see. This was the best thing we went to in Bangkok - absolutely amazing complex, so many beautiful style and so much gold - really beautiful. Go early, it gets busy!

Beautiful. Definitely worth the visit. This little Buddha is basking in the perfect light and they even change the robe depending on the season. I understand this Buddha is of jade, not emerald but because of the coloring they call it Emerald.

sight to see. tourist place . very nice to see when in Bangkok.
Its crowded so you better keep your things close to yourself.

Emerald Buddha. Absolutely packed but glad to see that respect still important- shoes off, no photos etc
Wonderful air of calm and contemplation inside
Crowded but a must.. Fighting to get in the temple is almost required, but it is a national treasure and key on the palace grounds. Don't forget to see the Angkor Wat model as well.

Hard to see. It's very difficult to get a good view as guests are only allowed upto a certain point and there are a ton of people.
That said, I didn't want to leave Bangkok without seeing it - so if you're like me and hate missing out, then give it a shot :)

grand palace. We expected a lot more from the visit to the grand palace. Some of the areas were closed off. The Emerald Buddha was not what we expected, much smaller. Overall good, but not worth the ticket price.

Beautiful. It was worth scrambling through the busy crowds to lay eyes on the Emerald Buddha. It was smaller than I thought and you are not allowed to take pictures inside the Wat but we managed to get a good picture from outside.I suggest you carry a bag for your shoes when visiting all the Wats so you do not have to scramble to get them when you come out (if they are still there!!).

Nice to see as well. If there is short time, this is not the most awsome to see. It is a very small Buddha if we are searching only for the beauty of it. The temple it self is really nice in terms of feeling.

Amazing place to visit. Make sure you plan accordinly with visiting the grand palace. It closes early (3:30pm), get there early to avoid crowds. However the crowds and tour buses of people make the experience a little less fun. It was uncomfortably crowded and it made it hard to get that Kodak moment.Make sure you dress appropriately when coming. You will be turned away if you are wearing a tank top with just a shawl on. Bare shoulders and bare legs are not allowed. I thought this would be acceptable and it wasn't. After already purchasing tickets for 500baht I had to purchase a T-shirt to wear. It was ridiculously hot to wear a T-shirt and pants but the palace and temples were amazing to see.The Grand Palace and the Temple of The Emerald Buddha is very impressive to see.
It was good. It was pretty, but we thought the reclining buddha literally right across the street was even better. I recommend to see both, but would choose reclining over emerald.
Of course you have to see it. But learn the history too. Fascinating story... right down to the fact that he is quite newly discovered and has his own outfits for the seasons.

Fabulous but has dim lighting. Very good temple. The interior ( near the idol) should have more lighting for a better glimpse. Photography prohibited but people still take photos. No pushing as in all famous indian temples. Surroundings excellent

Cool but huge crowds. It was super cool...and our tour guide could tell us things about the teak doors, history and put things in context. Only negative was the crowds were huge. Felt like a cow being herded!
Always a moving experience. Seeing the Emerald Budda and hearing it's history is a wonderful experience. Watching people from all cultures praying and mediating is a movingexperience
Another must see. This temple is within the Grand Palace complex. It is a mandatory visit while in Bangkok. Try to get there early to buy the ticket and have time for the whole visit.
Also a Must - when going to the Grand palace. See my remarks at the Grand Palace! The Wat is within the Grand Palace! Again, do not trust information given to you by people outside the place.
Beautiful place to stroll and photograph. This is a beautifully placed temple with some nice examples of temples and very picturesque. I would recommend a morning to visit.
Good afternoon. Locals will tell you all sorts of stories which can confuse and scare you but be sure to check websites. Temple was nice but very busy.

grand palace. Too many rude chinese. But fantastic attraction to see. The opulance is outstanding. If you like food markets turn right outside to corner and cross road to busy food stalls then get river boat to any where get ticket on boat very crowded but the way the locals travel. We went about 5 stops for 15 Bart each.

Beautiful Temple. Right in the heart of Bangkok, this temple was easy to get to. Worth visiting. Remember to wear sleeved tops and skirt/dress or long pants. If you forget, then clothing will be provided.

Marvelous Place. Despite that this place is absolutely crowded, its amazing to have the opportunity to see the Emerald Buddha, perhaps the most sacred of all Thailand. All the buildings, the paintings, the floors, the roofs, The Buddha himself are astonishing... I wish to have the opportunity to come back again in my life. Truly everything is just perfect like in a golden age of a huge and powerful Empire.About the entrance fee... don't get wrong! every single bath (of the 500) is well invest money.
Visit early morning to avoid the crowd. As a Buddhist this was a spiritual nirvana, loads of people though, hire a guide to make the most of your visit
Day Visit. Beautiful. Lots of history. Get a Guide since the signs displayed are inadequate to tell you about it.

well worth a visit. This Buddha is located inside the royal palace. This is a big compound with quite a lot of things to see. The Buddha itself is rather small and in my opinion not the most impressive thing in the compound but it is well worth a visit.

Emerald Marvel. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is collosal and the premises includes the temple, the grand palace and several other structures. So if you want to do justice to your visit and see every part of it, you may want to set aside about 4 hours. The ostentatious exterior of the temple makes you wonder at the amount of wealth that has gone in to its creation. And then you enter the 'sanctum' where you find the emerald buddha right at the pinnacle. There was a replica of the Angkor Wat Temple in Cambodia that we saw here and the detailing was superb! There is a dress code in place here. Shorts, short dresses or skirts, sleeveless shirts/tops, tights, jeggings and the like are prohibited. If you do make the mistake of wearing something like that, appropriate clothing is available within the premises for a refundable amount. But we witnessed several people who were in violation of the dress code walking around freely which was unnerving. The entrance fee we thought was exorbitant and no amount of walking around or exploring gave us the feeling that we got our money's worth! Once you get outside, Tuks tuks and cabs await to fleece you, so beware!

Make sure you are properly dressed!. Once you purchase your tickets (500 Baht each) for entry to the temple complex and are in line to enter, then there are guards checking your clothing. All must have long pants and shoulders covered. Women can wear a sarong, men may not. If you are pulled out of line you can either buy clothes at the little shop right there, or return to the main entry of the Palace grounds to borrow free clothing. You will have to pay a deposit which is returned when you return the clothes. If you know this before you purchase tickets and check out clothes (if needed) it will save you a lot of time! Once you are in the temple area the sights are beautiful, although the Emerald Buddha is pretty far away and fairly small. Make sure you go into each structure as there are fantastic statues all over! Just be prepared and this will make your experience more enjoyable!

If you only get to see one temple in Thailand this is a good one.. this temple is in the grand palace complex. So you get to see the royal temple, and the state ceremonial buildings all in one shot. (You don't get to see the living quarters.) You also get a ticket for the coin museum which is on the grounds. I highly recommend this if you want to know about the monarchy. They explain the ordination and the history quite well. You get a ticket for the material and clothing museum which is also on the grounds. This is a quick viewing of about 40 different thai outfits. influenced by the queen. They explain the evolution and history concerning thai clothing.
emerald marvollous. this buddha is emerald and marvellous in size and emerald shine like a jewwellary in the crown of a thai king
Emerald Buddha Temple. This temple is very well maintained and it is near to the King V home. it is on main road and accessible easily.
very peaceful. If you are going to travel to Thailand you must visit the temples and soak up all the energy. It is not something I'm usually into, It was both cool and interesting.

Interesting. Buddha. Temples. Emerald.
Who doesn't like a Buddha? Temples are great. Thailand has an abundance of both. Go. Go now!

Beautiful but Crowded. Have visited this many times and always very impressive. Unfortunately we went on New Year's weekend and it was terribly crowded. Getting in and out of the temple was not for the faint of heart - quite a lot of pushing and shoving.

A bit disappointed. Disappointed because you're not allowed to take pictures so I queued and fought my way through crowds of people and for what yes it's beautiful and very detailed and ornate but I haven't got the pictures to prove it.

A Temple to Far!. Bangkok is a city of magnificent temples and historical buildings.. The question you need to consider is - just how many temples do you need to see and visit? It is beautiful but this was the 4th temple on our tour and I think we had seen enough by the time we got here. Undoubtedly it is beautiful and well looked after. But choose carefully when making a tour choice
More like a tourist theme park. Hundreds of more interesting temples with a temple atmosphere near by with no entry charge plus no large tourist groups. Has become too commercialised.

A must to see in Bangkok. A visit to this beautiful site is a must if you visit Bangkok. The secret is to go early wearing long pants and to have your arms covered. If you don't wear the appropriate clothes you will need to hire them to visit this sacred site. We travelled as a family of five adults. As you enter the site you will purchase your entry tickets - and can hire a guide or purchase a listening post to travel on your own - however, once you enter you can join a FREE tour in various languages - our guide was very friendly and knowledgeable we were lucky to join this tour. Same old advice, you will be approached by shonky guides - so use your discretion - official uniformed guides are the only ones to trust.

Buddha small and not emerald.... I went in with expectations that the Buddha would be made of emerald and large (however unrealistic that may be) and it is very small and made of jade so I was a little unimpressed. The temple itself is beautiful and the grand palace compound itself (where this temple is located) is amazing.
Beautiful temple and grounds. One of the better temples and nice to wander around, especially if the weathers nice, it's that big that it never seemed too busy. We took so many photos here!
marj. A world famous site , it is a must visit in bangkok , best to go early , the emerald buddha is stunning , very well preserved and cared for .

Wonderful experience.. This was a wonderful experience, take your time, find some quiet spots as well as some of the busy spots. Let the tours go ahead, or if they are speaking your language tag on if you wish.Make merit to the hermit doctor and also to the temple, rub gold leaf on the Buddha and wish for enlightenment.Beware of people hanging around trying to get tourists to go with them. There's one main entrance only, if some people come out and tell you it's not open, try another gate.
old temple. very beautiful temple with the historical atmosphere that is far from the tourist centersIt is a complex where even the monks studying abydlílove you all show and talk with you

Very nice but a few tips. I recommend a couple things for this attraction. 1) Get there early before it gets stupid hot and all the tour buses start rolling in. Especially important if you plan on taking pictures and don't want people walking through your shot every three seconds. 2) unless you've done your research I would suggest renting the audio guide for 200baht. I didn't and had no I dea what I was looking at. You'll need a credit card or original passport to hand in, copies and drivers licence don't cut it. Also, if you're staying down on Khao San Road, don't take a tuk tuk there is absoutely no need. Just walk over to the busy highway a block over from KSR, cross at the cross walk with the giant elephant statue, hang a right and take the first street. You will probably see buses already and loads of tourists walking in the right direction. The walk shouldn't take longer than 15 minutes tops. Saves you the hassle of tuk tuk drivers. And regardless of what they say, it IS open, 8:30 am.

Beautiful but bad location. It's too bad that you have to walk through thousands of people in the grand palace to get here. It's really beauitful and worth getting an audio guide for 200 THB to hear more about the history of the emerald Buddha and where it's travelled.

Worth going....once. Very busy, fantastic architecture. However lots of scam artists & all the taxi drivers, tuk tuk etc want to charge double because of it being a tourist centre. Ensure they will work from the meter or you will be scammed. Multiple warnings about pickpockets on loudspeakers around palace.If in Bangkok you should go, make sure you wear long trousers & appropriate tops or you will have to hire clothing to get in.Combine with a trip to Khao San Road & the temple of dawn across the river (3baht water ferry).

Nice but can skip. The temple is just like any other Thai Buddhist temple, unless you are really keen on seeing a Jade statue you can skip this reason being the Buddha is kept in a hall surrounded by lot of other things like offerings and nearly 20+ ft above ground level, so you can only appriciate the existence of Jade Statue but can not enjoy the details.

Major attraction within the Grand Palace Bangkok. This temple is situated within the Grand Palace Bangkok and considered as the most sacred Buddhist temple in Thailand. Only the King of Thailand himself that can touch the statute and change the cloak around the statute 3 times a year. Magnificent architecture and statues can be found throughout the building. Dress code is very strict in this place and must be adhered to.Overall, it is worth well a visit.

Well worth it. My wife and I visited in December 2014. The structures are really stunning. We were also able to learn quite a bit about Thai history and spirituality. It was crowded, but I think we were early enough that we missed the real crush of people.

The most famous temple complex in Bangkok. If you are an architecture buff, there is no better place than to visit this temple and its surrounding i.e. The Grand Palace. A good place to take plenty of photographs for its unique architecture and ambience. a favourite place for first time tourist to Bangkok. Can be reached easily by ferry on the Chao Phraya River. Entrance fee is THB500 (2014).
Magnificent !. Cannot ever tire of the awesomely beautiful King's Palace area.....Always kept clean, and visitors are treated with great respect !

Wat = Temples. First time to visit here with my Gf. You're not allowed inside if you're wearing above the knee shorts even if you're a guy. You have to rent/buy pants outside to get in that cause 100baht for rent 70baht will be given back to you after you're done with the clothing or you can buy for 150baht. I must say the structures are stunning, a lot of tourist taking pictures everywhere, it was pretty crowded and hot. Lots of RUDE Chinese tourists, I must say. The experience was great though, and the food outside is great too!

Absolutely beautiful. All of the buildings in this complex are beautiful. The preservation work that it takes boggled the mind...my hat is off to the management of the facility. The price is minuscule for the value and experience to walk around this facility.
Grand and worth visit. It's within grand palace.bit too crowded.I think we queued for at least half an hr before we able to squeeze in.worth visit.

Beauty combined with religious meaning. Two distinct aspects will contribute to your experience in that Temp,É: the beauty of the building, and it's religious meaning to the Buddhist. In the first feature, you will see a very impressive assemble of mosaics, mother of pearls, statuary, all these in the external area. Inside, you'll have the Emerald Budha.A little word of advice - it is a very small statue, that os in a very high place - so you will hardly see it. But the chamber in which it is located is richly painted. There are also statues and other ornaments near by the Budha. The people inside, bringing offerings and saying prayers is some sort of attraction itself. It is kind of difficult to get inside - the Temple is crowded, and the stairs are full with people. it is a.so very hot inside. The visit inside is necessarily short - crowd + heat usually have that effect in people, but it is still worthy. And the outside, which is beautiful, do not suffer from the same limitations, so you can take your time.Always remember, the dress code totally applies, and people are very restrict about it.

Another of those places you must go to. If you can imagine less people around you then you can can get some sense of the meaning. Even without that you get can admire the beauty and the effort that is behind it all.

Pretty, but also pretty small. We were there during the holiday season and it was mobbed, mobbed with tourists. I didn't know what to expect but I was kind of surprise that the buddha was so, so small! Very similar to the interior of other temples with shrine elements, flowers and offerings.

Stunningly beautiful!. Deep within the Palace grounds you'll find Thailand's most sacred sight - Phra Kaew Morakot (the Emerald Buddha) contained within a beautiful temple (Wat Phra Kaeo). This highly revered Buddha sculpture is carved from a single block of jade and dates from the 15th century AD.To make the most of your visit it is worthwhile hiring a guide who will help broaden your understanding of the Wat Phra Kaeo and its colorful history.Unfortunately,we were not allowed to take any pictures,but were told that we were indeed privileged to see it!!!It's beauty resides now in my memory!

Amazing Buildings and Statures But the Emerald Buddha is Unimpressive. My wife and I took a private tour which included the Temple and the King's Palace (connected). The various Temples, grounds and statures are amazing and worth a visit and as some have said you will need a few hours to cover the entire visit. We found the exteriors of the various temples and statures the real highlights. In visiting the interior of the Emerald Buddha Temple you can not take pictures and the Buddha is very small so we were somewhat unimpressed, but the overall visit was still a highlight of our trip in Thailand.
Always a great experience.. Always a great experience. A must-see attraction. Feels like out-of this world. A little busy at times, but no trip to Bangkok should be without a visit to Wat Phra Kaew.
A peaceful place to visit and see the Emerald Buddha Statue. A ornately designed Temple with a magnificent Emerald Buddha Statue with ornately designed walls and paintings all over inside the temple.
Beautiful part of the Grand Palace. Really worth visiting. It is included in the price for the Grand Palace. Beautiful architecture, but crowded.

Temple area more impressive than the Emerald Buddha. The area surrounding the temple, and the temple itself is stunning! However, the Emerald buddha to my surprise was very small. People are trying to crowd around in front of the small window to take a photo of it (you can't take photos inside), so it's kind of chaotic. When inside the temple, you can see the Buddha better along with amazing decor and jewels.

It is in the Kings Palace compound. Every New year the Thai people visit thsi temple to take blessings of the Emerald Buddha. It is a small figure which is placed in one of the temples of the King's Palace compound.
Felt rushed. First of all we played spot the emerald Buddha as it was so small. The staff were quite rude and didn't have much time in there. Not sure I'd make it 1st to see on my list to do
Stunning!!. You will need at least 3 hours to visit the place. There are a lot of things to see carefully, so take your time to appreciate this stunning site!

Poorly managed and too expensive. The staff handle entrance are getting aggressive and just over crowded with people, hardly able to find a easy spot to do photograph shooting, screaming and kids running all over, entrance fees of 500B is overcharge and if you been there once then seriously do not make any sense to go second time, the Wat Arun is much fun then this Temple.
Good view. well placed near the Grand palace. The temple is huge. The buddha statute is small, but the place where placed is very big. All Golden and artistic.
Sacred Buddha with Emeralds.. It was very gracious to enter the temple of Emerald Buddha and see him showered with emeralds and the divinity in that place.

Grand, Opulent, Gold, and more Gold. The major attraction of Bangkok lives up to its rating of importance among Thai sights.
Fairly expensive at backpacking level travel... But since everything together at this one site...it does provide for one intensive day of sights/ cultural experience.
Tip : Pls do respect their request to cover legs while visiting this revered location.

amazing details on the temple. i like to see the details of the temple architecture and its colorful ornaments.
its amazing how they build it and watch the buddha statue

Huge Area to cover with the Palace. The Emerald Buddha looks awesome. Even though kept at a height and distance from the visitors, still you can see it clearly. Its really nice view. You can feel the atmosphere. Be ready to walk around a lot. So many statues around and don't forget to capture them with your camera.

Breath taking experience. A must for all visitors to Bangkok. The temple complex in which the Emerald Buddha is housed is magnificent. The sound of the wind chime bells is relaxing and the quiet inside the temple is very calming

Nice to see. It is nice to gave seen both the buddha and rest of the tempels and Grand Palace. Lots of tourist and the clothing for both men and women was really strict. You can borrow clothes which was really good.Be aware: There were several people outside the palace that tried to fool us that the Palace was closed and they should take us somewhere else. Odd since the palace guards actually saw it and did nothing to prevent.

Very ornate setup for the emerald buddha. The temple is in the Grand Palace complex and so if you are visiting the Palace you will eventually end up here. You have to take off your shoes to go inside a hall which has very ornate jewelry. Definitely worth visiting if you are in the Grand Palace.

Extraordinary. A treasure of human civilization. Not so much the Buddha figure itself which is small and jade (not emerald) but the wat it's housed in and the surrounding complex is breath taking. A must see place.

It's just the face! :-). Well worth the busy tourist environment! Spend at least an hour.....more if it's your first temple. No shorts or bared shoulders, so dress accordingly or line up for some borrowed clothes for free!
Must see. The pictures on the wall and the colors of the tiles are impressive. Try to avoid the visit during long holidays and festivals unless you like being in a very crowded place

Nice but too crowded. Endless crowds and people pushing in line get you in fron of the 'emerald Buddha' (in reality it I made from Jade). Worshipper quite rightly take the fron rows to pray and make their offers and tourists are asked to stand behind. The place is so crowded with people pushing to get in that you hardly enjoy the visit. It is a must see in BKK because it is so famous but you will not get an opportunity to enjoy the frescos on the walls, the atmosphere and you will be able to glance at the Buddha before you are pushed out by the entering hords!!!!

nice. In chinatown
nice temple
be aware of photo and then magnets out of them, bargain there
if you are in that area, then visit.

Special. The visit at this attraction can be combined with bot Wat Arun and Wat Pho, that area Allen the same area. The Buddha is small but still impressive. The complex of the temple is net to the Royal Palace, bring appropriate dress, long pants or long skirt and no sleaveless t-shirt or you won't be admitted (or better, you would requested to borrow some clothes before enter).
A royal temple. set in the grounds of the Grand Palace, this is a very special if not very big temple with it`s art work headed by the Emerald Buddha itself.

It was closed for a function. We went there when there was a function, so we were not allowed to go in, that was a trip that went to waste (I would have preferred to st by the pool rather than just push my way through 100s of other tourists then see nothing)
Spectacular. The Grand Palace is simply stunning. The opulence and scale is unreal. Arrive as early as possible, since tour buses unload one after the other, creating a sardine feel.
different buddhas. this had such a huge buddha idol and different poses of buddha that you would have seen at different places. it has beautiful outside open place which you dont see here

extremely crowded. the emerald buddha is special but you can't watch it closely and you can't take any pictures inside the temple. we waited in such a long queue during our visit and the temple has 2 differet lines for entrance which makes it a bit chaos when we entered the temple

A must but very busy with lot of tourists. The Wat Phra Kaeo temple is a must if you come to Bangkok. But of course like all other famous sightseening places on this globe, you will be not alone. Go there early as possible before all others come.

New Year visit!. The Emerald Buddha is located inside the palace. My friend and I went there on the new year so it was very busy especially when it was opened to tourists for free :) The sets of Buddha inside the temple were huge and as I remembered (no photos inside so just based on the counting I did in the crowd) the statues were arranged in pyramid shape, 4 Buddhas on each edge. Paintings on the wall were also fabulous. I wish we could have to tour guide to explain stories in the paintings and the statues :3

A must see when visiting the Grand Palace. The ornate detail and adornments will have you in sensory override. Be respectful and lose your shoes to enter this stunning temple. Remember the prize is the Emerald Buddha.

Overrated. It is always full and busy with tourists being bussed in. I find that Wat Pho is the better alternative - quieter, more to see. Of course Phra Kaew is great - but too many people for my liking.
the standng buddha was breathtaking. very touristy.. but enjoyed. My only wish would be to have some type of translation , i would love to know the stories behind all the pictures and stepas

Get Lost In It. It's beautiful and I got lost in the surrounding area taking dozens of pictures. The place is so well preserved it's amazing. At times I felt like I was walking back in time and others I felt like I was walking in Disney World's It's a Small World attraction. But this is the real thing.
Crowded. This was a mob scene with pushing and shoving. The building is quite impressive. The Emerald Buddha is a small image in a big, crowded space. No disrespect intended.

Grand & Rich in Details. Located inside the Grand Palace complex. You must take off your shoes and it's forbidden to take picture inside the temple. Many Thai & Buddhist tourist pray in this temple.
Just like another building in Grand Palace, this temple is very rich in details.
A must visit.
great!!. very nice & popular tourist place. too may people. The emerald Buddha is a very well respected among Thai people

awsome. beautful temple with amazing wall paintings telling the stories, the Budda is beautiful.
No photos are allowed inside the temple but you can take from the doorway outside. Very moving although the Buddha is small .

Breath-taking!. Since this temple is on the same property as the Grand Palace, it has all the royal and religious treasures. It is breath-takingly beautiful.
Since there are so many tourists there, allow yourself a few hours to see, absorb, and enjoy everything the temple and palace have to offer. Have fun, and count how many times you say, "Wooooooooooooow!" :-)

A holy place in the middle of a noisy city!. We are on our Private Tour on Bangkok Highlights which focus on Temple visits. The main attractions of this tour is the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew or the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Both attractions are just parallel to one another. It is really good thing that we came in Wat Phra Kaew after visiting the Grand Palace. The Royal Grand Palace is so crowded and coming in this place later on serves as the peaceful time to contemplate after a rush time. The line up of buddhas near the entrance looks similar, but actually not. If you look closely, the facial expressions are different. Our tour guide says, each expression reflects specific attitude of Thai culture. It is really promising to visit the place.
Well preserved Thai treasure. This is a very popular tourist spot. The emerald Buddha is a very well respected among Thai people so anyone visiting should do the same.
Nice. Temple was really nice but lot of scams outside. Group of people outside the temple tried to rip off foreigners.
One of the most perfect place. Grand palace is one of the best places that ive been through. Overall is worrh the 500baht. Its a must viait place when youre in bangkok to make it complete

If you like tourists and crowds go, otherwise stay away. On New Years Day there were simply too many people to see this temple. We tried getting there but it was not worth it! Hundred of thousands of people is not an exaggeration. Look for photos online and then visit another attraction if you have any aversion to throngs of people.

Best Thai Temple to Visit. Being in Bangkok without ever visited Wat Phra Kaew is like never been to the City of the Angels. Wat Phra Kaew or the Temple of the Emerald Buddha has all the treasures accumulated in one temple next to the Royal Palace. Normally whether it is an independent visit or a guided tour, the two important attractions are combined as one sightseeing tour. Many visitors were confused with the different areas visited whether it was in the temple or the palace. Therefore as a simple rule, anythings that were allow to be photographed are likely to be in the temple ground. Simply take a look at the photos taken in the Emerald Buddha Temple in the TripAdvisor and that can give you the sights not to be missed.

Most incredible sight. This was one of the most beautiful sights that I have ever seen. The sun was hot and of course it was very crowded. It costs 500 baht but is worth it. Beware of folks outside the compound trying to talk you out of going. It actually happened to me and they sound very convincing. I just walked away and went in but it was quite disturbing.

Uncontrolled crowd, nice view. Wish the crowd was managed better. Hardly any queues. Emerald Buddha reigns supreme, some Buddhist murals on the walls. Nothing great but some history and lot of faith attached.

Worth a Visit. Very impressive and worth a visit. Make sure you are wearing clothes that cover your knees and shoulders and nothing see through! It was very crowded when we visited. Definitely something you can do on your own- no need to pay for a guide.
Worth the effort. The buddha is quite small but it is so revered in Bangkok that you have to take a look. The temple complex is also pretty spectacular. I enjoyed it a lot

See first thing in the morning and with a local guide. As mentioned in my reviews for Grand Palace and Thai Private Tour Guides, this temple is best as early as possible. Also, if you have a private guide, who is good as Am was for us, she avoided the lines and crowds, and deftly guided us through this attraction like a local. This added so much to the experience to not have to stand in lines or be bulked up with huge crowds.TIPS: Be ready for a hot day and be hydrated. Also, as with any temple, dress with LONG pants and no breasts showing for women. If you have on shorts, the temple will provide clothing for the visit, but wearing long, light clothes also works. As for hydration, if you have an amazing local guide like Am, she will provide you will cold drinks for your visit. Stay hydrated during the visit.
Spectacular. Another amazing temple in Bangkok. We spent a good half hour outside just admiring the detailed work on the buildings! Gorgeous buddha!

Great half day visit. We book the trip on line,half day visit with a tour guide. I guess is double the price,if you buy tickets at the gate,but its worth the money.Mini bus took us from the hotel.The guide explain us everything.There is a dress code.No shorts and shoulders have to be cover. Its a very crowded place,so be sure to keep small kids next to you.As many places in Thailand,you have to leave your shoes outside,so no expensive one please and better if you have socks in your bag in advance. I really don't feel comfortable to walk without socks in such a places. We went there morning time. And is better,before sun hit you. Have water with you,as the place is huge and shops are far. Great day for family attraction visit with 3 young kids.

Go see it. Look, quite possibly for many of you, this will be one of the few trips you ever take to Thailand. This is one of those landmarks that you must see. Be advised, however, that any tour of Bangkok is much better when you know the history behind what you are seeing. My recommendation...see this landmark with a tour guide or study up ahead of time. Trust me, it will be worth it

Munchkin Land for Adults. The Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew are amazing. First, be prepared for the crowds because it is very crowded even if you get there early in the morning. Second, make sure you dress appropriately. The fashion police are there to make sure you do. If not, then you will have to borrow clothing (blouse for women) and (pants for men) and return it upon your departure. It is like a fantasy land when you get to the area of the Wat Phra Kaew. The crowds were very pushy in trying to get into the temple. I understand that it is a very special place, but I think that some crowd organization and direction is in serious need. The Emerald Buddha sits way up on top of the altar and it is very small so don't miss it!
Nice... Big temple...impressive Buddha idol..nice and serene in the inside....shoulder covering is compulsory...

Interesting visit. This is a very interesting site to visit. The temple with the actual Emerald Buddha (that isn't actually emerald) is quite crowded with guards everywhere to ensure that you don't take photos. I even saw them confront a monk about photos! It's a shame that they don't allow photos in so many places.
Great temple. Temple was great, but the grand palace was just Ok. Highly priced entry fee of 500 Baht. Indians would not like because they have palaces which more grand back home.

Spectacular. Fascinating. The Emerald Buddha temple was the primary reason for me to get to the Grand Palace. It is mesmerizing. The decoration so rich and diverse that you could spend here hours looking at the detail. The temple is surrounded with the most intricate and sophisticated architectural pieces. The massive golden stupas near it are impressive. The decoration is so rich in color and elements that you are absolutely fascinated. Interior of the temple is very beautiful too. The Emerald Buddha statue is relatively small and close to the ceiling. Photos are not allowed. The temple is usually crowded, but it is worth visiting as it is one of the richest and most beautiful temples in Bangkok.

Beautiful and worth to see. Although the size of the Emerald Buddha is not as large as I expected, it is really beautiful, crystal-clear, glittering. Words can not describe its beauty. You will feel your mind is being cleared when you just look at it.
Must visit. The temple is nice with traditional architecture design. There are many scenes to see. But it is always crowded and needed to queue a very long line. Anyway, it was an amazing tour.

Emerald Buddha statue carved from a single block of jade. It is considered as one of the most important Buddha temples of Bangkok . It is located near Grand Palace and the temple of the reclining Buddha . The most famous attraction in this temple is The Emerald Buddha statue , a Buddha image in the meditating position carved from a single block of jade.

too expensive to my liking. so we did not enter. Although a must see according to some.
Still the crowd and the price turned us of and although at first a bit disappointed I was happy we went to see Wat Pho in stead.

Absolutely Amazing. Wow! Wow! Wow! Definite must see when in Bangkok! Make this your first stop! Such incredible beauty. Make sure you wear long pants and a t-shirt otherwise you will not be allowed in.

A Shining Temple. This temple is located right next to the grand palace. Actually, it is inside of the palace and you will buy one ticket for both this temple and the palace. This temple was just stunningly beautiful. My wife and I were so amazed how Thai temple can be extremely luxurious and shining and beautiful. This place, as other travelers already mentioned, is a must-visit place.
Worth a visit. Go early to avoid major amounts of tourists. Certainly worth seeing. Looks like a fairy tale castle. Well worth getting a guided tour.

A must see. This temple located next to the Grand Palace. It was very nice temple. The details of those stupas and the temple it self were magnificent. Lots of details you can see and enjoy even with my children.
Very beautiful. Crowded but wonderful. No shoes and shoulders covered, long pants or long skirt for ladies, long pants for men out of respect. Lots of stairs.

Do Not Miss the Palace or the Emerald Buddha. No visit to Bangkok is complete without visiting this temple and the palace itself. If you have 3-4 hours you could easily see the palace and this temple, Wat Pho and Wat Arun. They are all close together (Wat Arun is across the river). I would start with the Emerald Buddha and palace grounds. While it is small, and raised on a pedestal, its religious significance can not be denied. I was here in the late morning and this seems to be the peak time for tour groups. I noticed that the crowds were much lower at the entrance when I was leaving, suggesting that early afternoons will be much less crowded. There is easy access to the palace via the water bus system. Just beware of the Tourist Police (in uniform) who will tell you the palace is closed and redirect you to a Tuk Tuk driver who will then take you on "tour" and shopping trip (for 40 Baht I actually had an enjoyable tour but do not fall victim to the shops they take you to).
Really awesome. Lots of tourists in this place, if you can avoid visiting it during the weekend, it will be better. Otherwise, this temple and the whole palace are beautiful.

Dress code!. Do note you need to wear long pants and sleeved tops to enter. Ladies who use shawl to cover their shoulder will not be allowed to enter; u will need to buy a tshirt at the souvenir shop. You can queue at the entrance to borrow pants but be prepared to queue though. Entrance fee is THB500 for tourists, the locals can enter for free.

Beautiful but overwhelming. There is so much to see it can be overwhelming. Highly recommend visiting with a tour guide who speaks your native language if you do not speak Thai. Tip for getting your picture with the Emerald Buddha (no pictures allowed inside) - leave someone outside and you will be able to take their picture with the Buddha in the background.
amazing. that was very beautiful and amazing .I like there so much.it is mix of history and glory .every thing there have discipline.

a very special temple. the Emerald Buddha is very small and up high, so after the greatness of the reclining buddha you almost need binoculars. but it's worth it. the emerald buddha is either more or less exposed depending on the season, it has three sets of gold clothing, so make sure you have a look at the guide books to see various "looks".

Average but clubbed with Grand Palace. This is over rated. Its well within the premise of Grand Palace and gets covered automatically hence. Have seen umpteen times better places in my life and hence found it very average.

Thai proud Buddists. Its nice to see the respect the Thai have for there religion. The temples I visit clean and well maintained.The might not have the knowledge about there own religion but the the proudness that they all belong to something, nice to to see.

Great place to see. First Buddha visit for me during staying in BKK it was quite interesting. The whole area consists of quite a lot interesting buildings which are nice to look upon. The "main attraction" is the emerald buddha (in size it remains a little to the Mona Lisa in the Louvre, everybody heard about it and thinks it to be gigantic - in reality it's rather small) if worth fighting through the heat and humidity and I would recommend my friends visiting BKK to go here.Temple can/should/has to be (?) done together with the Grand Palace since you buy one ticket for both and after leaving the temple area you will enter the palace area.Furthermore go get some water before you enter this one because inside you can only buy water within the Grad Palace area and from there it is not possible to go back to the temple area. p.s.: remember to wear slippers since you will have to take off your shoes before going right into the temple
Awesome. Its a must see attraction if you are in Bangkok. Though its a very small statue of Buddha (compared to the other Buddha attractions in Thailand), it is an enthralling experience.

Beauty, peace and tranquility ........ Wow, what a place. Steeped in history, and beauty. This place is a must do in Bangkok. Take your walking shoes, fluids, and an perhaps read the guide book before you go there, to maximise your visit. This is a place to meander through, don't rush, and try and go in the cool of the day before the masses get there.

Jaw-dropping. Being a huge fan of far-eastern culture and architecture, this Thai temple has struck me vigorously. IMHO the most beautiful part is the outside of the building: the richness of the decorations and the care they've put to it is unbelievable! The Emerald statue isn't as big as I thought it would be-
Very impressive. Part of the Grand Palace complex, this was well worth a visit. It's very busy and hot so make sure you take some water with you.

Too crowded but glad we saw it. The emerald Buddha is impressive, and I’m glad I saw it, but I’m not sure it was worth the hassle among the throngs of other visitors. If you get anxious easily in a crowd and are height-challenged, then this is okay to miss. It’s on the grounds of the Grand Palace, so there will be plenty of other things to walk around and see.The interior of this temple offers an exotic, mysterious air surrounding the ancient 30” figure, but it can be difficult to get a decent view since ropes hold everyone back quite a ways. On the busy day we went, basically we removed our shoes and stowed them outside, went in the entrance on the left, took baby steps with the crowd past the well-lit Buddha, then slowly waddled our way out the door on the right. No photography inside, and respectful dress is required (no bare shoulders or legs).
Worth a visit. The Emerald Buddha is beautiful and the views are stunning. Wonderful colours and incredible architecture.

Small and highly spiritual. There was something exceptionally moving about this small jade Buddha - wrapped in his "winter gold clothes." This temple really evoked a deep sense of beauty and spirituality. The view was also lovely.
Too many tourists but amazing temples. Go early or during the week. It was overrun with tourist when we went on a Saturday but it was worth it. The temples are amazing and so beautiful.

Spiritual experience. They change the golden vestments of the emerald Buddha for each season. Keep in mind that you may not take photographs inside the temple and you must remove your shoes before you enter. You must kneel before the Buddha but it really makes you appreciate this stunning statue and understand the Thai people's reverence for him.
Awesome. Great temple, great views, i liked is must to show respect to thai religion and what i disliked isnsome people do not wear proper attirenwhen visiting temples...

A great complex. The complex is huge and very colorful and scenic. The Idol is considered the most sacred in Thailand and unfortunately not allowed to take photos inside the temple. It's highly recommended to get a guide for the visit and there's a lot to ask about. The visit includes the Grand Palace and the adjacent museums.

Fantastic but busy. The architecture and detail in the temple is incredible. Every part tells a story and I recommend going with a guide so that the history can be explained otherwise it can be a bit overwhelming. The emerald buddha is actually made from green jade so the name is misleading but that is because when they discovered it centuries ago, they thought it was emerald and the name stuck. Anyway, its small and you can't really see it that well. Also, it was so full that I just wanted to get out. I highly recommend going first thing in the morning to avoid the rush.

Another have to see sightseeing. Yet again, Bangkok and sightseeing does not finish that fast... A part of the Grand Palace, Temple of the Emerald Buddha is on of the main attractions inside the palace. Yet another Buddha inside the temple, but this time Emerald, quite fascinating statue to be honest and totally worth spending a few minutes inside the table, admiring it. Unfortunately pictures are not allowed to be taken!

A place to relax and make your mind calm in peace.... This is a place that can bring peace of mind & relaxation as you enter inside the temple. Lord Buddha's wardrobes are changed accordingly with the 3 seasons and you can find in shops the 3 different beautiful statues of Emerald Buddha...It's something that can highlight in your Thailand visit...

Green with Envy. This is part of the palace complex and has many rules and protocols you need to be respectful of. Unlike it's large and golden friends, this Buddha is small, ornate, and special in its own right. Pay for the audio tour so you get the history of the sight. Legs and shoulders should be covered in this area.

Nice Place, very busy. . A visit to the Emerald Buddha and the grounds around are something that you should do when in Bangkok. That being said, it will undoubtedly be busy and with a 500bhat enterence fee you may find yourself thinking was it really worth it. I respect the history and culture so will say yes. The buildings and structures are stunning, the Emerald Buddha is itself small but it sits in the most ornate temple.
Temple of the Emerald Buddha complex. It was very crowed and hot with the extra clothing on, (no shorts or t shirts) lots to see we were very impressed.

Spectacular but crowded. The temple is amazing, but if you hate crowds stay away as it's super crowded. You can't photograph in actual temple, but there is so much outside to photograph it's no big deal.

Wat Phra Kaeo is a fantastic and so special place. You will not forget your visit of Wat Pra Kaeo. Wen you arrive in Bangkok go and visit this place and you will be in the mood of this country which is Thailand. It is a special and beautiful place !The only problem is that there are sometimes so many people. Taking pictures is very difficult.

Enchanting!. I'd read that the Emerald Buddha was smaller than one might expect, but his position, high up on a throne and his seasonal garb made the view magical & impressive. The one unpleasant aspect was that the floor was somewhat sticky/smelly. No pix but crowd flowed in and out nicelyThere is a museum nearby with the Buddha's other seasonal garb (all gold)....The summer outfit seemed the most dramatic. (you apparently need a pink slip to get in...it's right near the Nepalese gift stand on the way in....I didn't have the pink ticket, but showed the guard all the others I had, and they laughed and let me in~ It was well worth the visit).

Sadhu Sadhu. Being Buddhist myself I found this place wonderful, in the temple of Emerald Buddha there are hundreds of visitors coming and going, but nothing disturbs your meditation.  Wonderful place.

Boring and LEGGINGS are insufficient coverage ladies!. I should preface my review with this disclaimer: I visited Wat Pho and Wat Traimit the day before and I am completely "templed" out. That, and then they asked me to wear a sarong over my leggings (even though I was wearing a long shirt, with sleeves, that covered my bottom, which was perfectly acceptable at BOTH temples yesterday) I was completely over it. I would not have even gone into the palace/temple if we hadn't already paid for admission in advance through our tour group. I should also note I am completely over Bangkok to the point where the only thing that recommends a visit is the exchange rate, unless you need clothing tailor-made or you happen to enjoy visiting large urban cities with mass poverty. Seriously, if this place is a "bucket-list" place for you, spend two days max, do a bike tour to hit highlights and then get out. That off my chest, the temple was pretty but not nearly as impressive as anything in Europe. It is only around 200 years old at the maximum. So you spend hours looking at temple that looks like all the others (as if someone built spires/buildings out of tile and then went crazy with glitter and mirror pieces). And then they show you some two-dimensional murals and we are supposed to be impressed? No thanks. I recommend you pick one or if you have to do them all, run through it to say you did it and then go get lunch.

Nice to place to visit and see Thai culture. you need to wear long pants and a shirt with sleeves. so many foreign visitors and I thought they annoy the prayers. Unless you can respect Buddhism, you should not visit there.

Go and visit!!!. This temple is few minutes walk from the reclining budha temple and beside the palace grounds.Theres a lot of spot to take pictures with. Usually pack so be sure you are mindful of youre stuff..Dont forget to wear shirts with sleeves and long pants as the guards are very strict. There are some vendors selling clothes just outside the entrance for tourist who forgot to wear the approrpiate clothes; )
Must see. I would suggest that you take a guided tour of the Old capital of Thailand, this will include the emerald Buddha and other attractions

The only good thing inside the Grand Palace. Despite the overcrowdedness, the environ was serene but also stinky with sweat of visitors! When we visited, a politician or royalty had come to visit the temple leading to a 40 minute delay in entrance

Magical Experience. Situated within the grounds of the Grand Palace. This is a very spiritual place to visit. So beautiful. Great place to sit in contemplative silence. Admire the Emerald Buddha, the ambience, the artwork.As a sign of respect, No shoes, no hats and modest clothing...which means covering arms and legs.... is required in all of the temples. Standing at the altar, back to Buddha, or directing soles of feet towards Buddha is not acceptable, and extremely disrespectful. Sadly, not all tourists show respect in these temples. Not even heeding the guard who repeatedly asks them to sit. If you choose to visit, show respect. Do not show disrespect in such a revered location.

Serene and Powerful. This ornate temple is absolutely beautiful! The chaos outside is completely halted upon entering the temple and seeing the shrine. I did not expect to be so affected by its beauty and calming presence. There are signs advising NO PHOTOS but of course there are still tourists who do which I found very disrespectful.

So beautiful and all dressed up for Winter. A small buddha made of Jade not Emerald and set way up high. As it was "winter" he had been dressed in his gold winter finery. A peaceful temple despite all the bustle
beautiful. take your time to sit to one side in the temple and enjoy the silence and beauty !!! Beautiful and omnipresent

Main Attraction in Grand Palace. You are taken to this temple, when you visit Grand Palace, its one of the major attraction inside grand palace. Crowded place, don't get to sit and spend time, just walk past to see the shining bright emerald buddha.

Magical A Must see. Take the speed boat, not the touristy one, and pay only 15 Bachts on board. Catch the subway to Saphan Taksim station ( central pier) and take the boat from, you don't have to pay anything until on board. Don't go to ticket counter they will charge you 42 Bachts. It's very easy and simple you just need a detailed map from the hotel and patience. Most of Thai ppl don't speak English. Having said that, once you arrive at the GrandPalace stop which is pier N9. For men no shorts and women shoulders and legs must be covered. Don't worry they provide pants and shawls at the door in case. The Palace visit should take half of day if not the whole day, so plan accordingly, do buy some food or fruits from the stalls outside the pier, I. Recommend a icy fresh coconut water to keep you hydrated. Cheers!

Really beautiful . Really beautiful temple and definitively a must go! just a shame there are so many tourist, but nothing you can do about it. But together with the declining Buddha it's definitively the best temples in Bangkok.
Amazing place. It s a really stunning place to visit, I think the best temple where I have ever been so far.The only thing I can say it s just go there you can t miss it if you re in Bangkok.
A must in bkk. Stunning a must not cheap but you get to see the president palace and many other things and that's worshipping buddha

Glittering. This is the most reverential temple, situated within the Grand Palace. It is one of the most elegantly decorated place you are likely to see with a dazzling display of emeralds, gold and fine jewellery on a large display at what would be an altar, the top of which is a golden Buddha. This is highly policed, no photos, no phones and no pointing feet towards Buddha. Many people come to pray and silence is encouraged.

The best tourist sight in Bangkok. The sheer shine of the temple of the emerald buddha will take your breath away. The work , the carvings and the details on the temple itself is bespoke. And then there is the emerald buddha himself. Absolutely stunning. A must visit.

Beautiful Culture. We went to visit this temple and was taken back with the history, beauty and colours surrounding it. We organized the trip through our rep it was not expensive and our guide was brilliant and very knowledgeable.

visit to the emerarld buddha temple. we had visted emerald buddha temple and was was very well lighte and we realy loved to spend time and enjoyed the visit the river is flowwing with the boats a boat has a restaurant and foog is served.

Fantastic sights but praises end there unfortunately. The sights were amazing and enjoyed the atmosphere but as a foreigner I found the toilets difficult to navigate and ultimately it was a bit pricey for just looking around and then you are expected to pay more to 'give thanks' would be nice if that was included with entry fee along with toilet paper! Or just carry your own in your bag.

Too Crowded. The last time I visited was 20 years ago. I would say is too crowded with tourist. And the entrance fees is B$500, I think is too expansive for a tourist attraction. Emerald Buddha is the only thing I am here for. It is the most important Buddha in Thaland and 2nd most beautiful in Thailand (Most beautiful is in Phitsanolok Phra Chinnarat)

Nice temple apart from the no photo policy. Wat Phra Kaew better known as the temple of the emerald Buddha which has 3 different costumes for the 3 different seasons.
