I visited this temple as apart of the grand palace and didn't know that you can't take pictures of the Emerald Buddha in it's room only from outside, so if you want a good picture you will need a decent zoom lense camera or just buy a post card like I did.
Smaller than expected. But still well worth the visit. The whole complex is worth a good look around. Beautiful temples and lots of well renovated tilted buildings

A must see in Bangkok. Would you go to New York and not see Times Square or go to Rome and not see The Coloseum ? Same can be said here. The Emerald Buddha has to be high on your to do list when visiting Bangkok. The Buddha is inside the Wat Phra Kaew Temple which itself is inside and on the grounds of The Grand Palace. Once inside the grounds, just look for signs to guide you to the Emerald Buddha. There are racks to store your footware, which is not allowed inside the temple. Wear old or dark socks. Once inside you may do like many and glance around looking for some large life size figure. Just look straight ahead and up as high as you can look, because the Emerald Buddha is a small figure nestled high up off the ground and behind roped off guarded space. For its small size it is a magnificent sight. Carved from a single piece of jade, it represents the most important symbol of Thailand. Buddha has 3 change of clothing for the 3 primary seasons of Thailand and the royalty takes part in the tri year ceremony to change buddha's clothing. The Buddha and the temple are spectacularly decorated with vivid colors and designs representative of Buddhism and its culture. Will not go on with the history, you can certainly read up on it yourself, but just say, do not miss this site. Also proper dress required inside the palace grounds, long pants for men, and some sort of sleeve shirt. No tank tops, shoulders showing, flip flops. Etc. Thai double standard applies here, 500 baht entrance fee for foreigners, 100 for locals.
Majestic. It was amazing , the red ruby,emerald to be precise was visible from the door even, and it was truly fascinating,

Big, sprawling temple complex. There is a lot to see here. It can be crowded, but not too much so. Check dress code before heading out there! Beautiful complex, tons of history. I would recommend checking it out for sure. So many temples in Bangkok, but this was one of the better ones.
Amazing place. It was exactly what I was expecting. A lot of people amazed by the magnificent view of the temple. I teccomend to go during lunch time to avoid crowd.

Beautiful temple, very crowded. Great temple and elegantly decorated. The Buddha is small and at the very top of the hall.
It gets very crowded and smelly because you need to take your shoes off. Just a 2 minute visit.

Perfect location for taking memorable photos. The temple seemed to just glitter and shine on the day we were there.Tour guides wait outside to offer to help you. I prefer not to have someone talking the whole time, instead just leisurely explore the temple. The Emerald Buddha was much smaller than we expected.

Jade Legend, if only photos were permitted inside!. This is another inspiring story of a hidden treasure accidentally found when concrete broke during a move to expose the beautiful Jade Buddha enveloped! Interesting that the dressing changes with the three seasons and worth the serenity, meditative environment and beautiful surrounding buildings! Employ a guide for the temples to learn some of the history which richens the experience and see the Reclining and Golden Buddha all in a few hours, would be my recommendation. But be sure to avoid the scams of sapphire purchases, and hand-made clothes within your tour if you select one.

Interesting Temple. The architecture, design and the way the temple is built is truly amazing. Emerald Buddha is a must see attraction in Bangkok. Another interesting aspect is the way the entire walls in walkways are painted to depict epic stories. There are sections where Ramayana is depicted in Thai version..very interesting to see these paintings. If you are going to visit this temple on a hot day, plz be prepared to carry an umbrella, lots of sunscreen and water. Enjoy!!!!

Part of the Grand Palace, very intricate!. Beautiful temple, one the most intricate I saw during our trip. Absolutely no pictures inside unless you want to get your camera confiscated. Packed no matter what time of day so just pack your patience.

best place to visit. i like the temple. so may gods are there, on the top of the roof there is the complete view of pattaya city. and we purshase a devotional books from there. we peoples are enjoyed a lot.

Awesome Temple. You may be like me when first visiting...the actual emerald Buddha is rather quite small. It was hard to see it from the distance the crowds were kept, but the temple is wonderful and worth the visit.
Beautiful. Magical moment, beautiful temple. amazing day we spent visiting many temples but this one was just perfect.

Otherworldly. This place says Thailand like no other. I've never seen so much interesting architecture in one place before. It is amazing. Everything is gilded or tiled or bejeweled. The emerald Buddha itself is fairly small, but the temple complex is quite large. You need an hour or 2 here, particularly if you are going to do the Grand Palace as well, which is right next door.

You can skip this. After visiting several temples and buddhas, this definitely was the one I would skip, is just a tiny esmerald buddha, that you barely see and can't take picture of it. It has a history on it but Im not the type of traveler that enjoy that.
Busy but beautiful. Went during King's birthday celebrations so free entry but very busy. Definitely a must see, remember to wear modest clothing, men and women
Incredible. This was an absolutely amazing experience and a must see for any visitor...we visited in August 2013...I would go back again!

A lovely attraction. Like other temples in Bangkok, this one managed to amaze me. The main attraction inside the premises is a small Buddha statue made out of emeralds. Photography is prohibited inside, but the visit is well worth it.
So much gold. A beautiful temple that is awe inspiring. Make sure t keep quiet while the faithful pray and no pictures are allowed.

Organised Chaos but Worth It. We visited the Emerald Buddha as part of our tour and we had this as our first visit in the morning to try and miss the crowds. We arrived just after 9am and it was already packed with tourists. Lots to see and some excellent 'picture postcard' opportunities to be had. The detail and decorations in every corner of this place is beautiful. The colours, the gems the layout - Perfect. Did expect the actual emerald Budha to be larger than it was and we couldnt get that close to it but still a beatuiful site. Did feel very crowded so wasnt the longest visit but definetly worth the visit.
Worth a visit. This is one of the most famous Buddhas in Bangkok. So, it's worth a visit. It was difficult to get close to it though due to the large number of people.

Disappointing. With limited time in BKK, it didn't too sit well that the Military decided to pay their respects and had the Temple closed off to the public for the afternoon.Check to see whether you can visit the Temple before you buy your tickets.
A must see. Gorgeous and very impressive. Really impressed by the gold stupas and surroundings. Very ornate and breath taking. Not to be missed. Went by water...a real treat,
stunning!!. This is absolutely beautiful but prepare to be barged.. The buddah itself is rather small but it is spectacular! Well worth seeing!

Super touristy, but just fantastic to look at.. When first arriving, beware of scams - some man will tell you that it's not open at the moment except for tour groups and will offer you a tuk-tuk tour which takes about 2 hours. Don't listen to him and just proceed. Once you've waited long enough and got your ticket, you're practically in - you just need to get through the mass of people in front first...The temple complex itself is pretty big. It glitters, it's golden and it's fancy. All the colors can be blinding in bright sunlight - it's simply mesmerizing.However, be sure to bring some water, especially on a hot day. They do have some vendors inside, but their prices are generally pretty touristy.

Here traveller guides are right - a must see. This is the Highlight of Thai sacred art. Take you time and admire the paintings depicting Scenes from the Ramayana. I just dislike that the entrance fee for non Thai visitors has been doubled within the last two years. It´s now the same amout that you also pay in Europe.

Excellent but crowded. For first timers in Bangkok, the Grand Palace + Emerald Buddha tour is almost mandatory, though not without good reason. The Emerald Buddha itself is spectacular, albeit much smaller than it’s equally famous counterparts, and it is surrounded by stunning buildings which are expertly maintained. The Grand Palace is also quite stunning, but like the museum, it is less interesting than the temple. Unfortunately the complex is swarming with hordes of Chinese tour groups and other tourists, so try to come early to avoid the crowds and the heat as much as possible.

One of the must sees!. What is there to say? If you see the Wat Pho (and you must)....then you must see the Wat Phra. Both require a camera for certain (goes without saying) and try to get elevated and shoot from the high elevations. BRING WATER! The places get very hot, and water is not that easy to get.

Favorite of the temples. It is a good attraction to go see. My only pro tip for you is always have cotton breathable pants and long sleeve shirt. All of the temples require you to be fully covered up and if you have jeans it can get uncomfortable.Also buy the coins and think about what you want as you drop the coins into the pails. The monks then take this to buy food as I understand it.

You gotta go see it!. Absolutely beautiful. I was in complete awe by the amount of detail and beauty of that place. Make sure to be respectful and follow the appropriate dress code, and take off your shoes before you walk I to the temple!

Very crowded, but impressive. This temple was impressive. It sits inside a complex of temples and stupas. It was very crowded the day we were there and it was hard to really concentrate - but that is really beside the point. Lots of history at this site and I would recommend you have a guide with you so that you get a feel for the stories behind who built these temples and what was going on in the world during those times. Without a sense of the history, it is just one temple after another.

Nice but distant. The Emerald Buddha was 'dressed' in his 'winter' attire. It's not that I didn't like this Buddha, it's just that compared the the others... It was at a bit of a distance, making it difficult for me to see the workmanship and details. Perhaps if you have a camera with a great zoom lens you will feel differently.

The most important Temple. Inside Grand Palace area you will find the small emerald Buddha which is one of the most important temples in Bangkok. Be nice dressed or you will not be entering as guards may reject your visit
Great Attraction. Must see if ur in bangkok, make sure you wear pants or long skirts and covered shoulders or they won't let you in.

Wow wow Wonderful. Spectacular, Emerald Buddha is worth a stop. You have to take off you shoes but you are not aloud to take pictures inside the temple. They will open the door in the middle with a tour guide, then you will have the chance to take pictures, takes loads of pictures. This is a master piece. Pay attention to the dress that the bouddha is wearing, they chance him three times a year. Two are made of gold and one of silver depending of the season. When you come in the temple it is expected that you will sit down and be quiet.
Historical. At first it seemed very simple and not as elaborate as I had expected, but when I realized the history behind the temple and the Buddha, made the visit much more significant.

Much smaller then expected, but still awesome!. This is one of the smaller Buddhas I saw on my trip in Bangkok. Especially after seeing the solid gold Buddha in Chinatown, and the Reclining Buddha after it, this Buddha is not as impressive in size. But what it doesn't have in size, it makes up in beauty. You can't take pictures in the room where it is kept, but you will definitely remember the Emerald Buddha for being beautiful (even though its not actually made of Emerald... its made of Jade). You can't miss this, as it is a key part of the Grand Palace tour!Enjoy!

Do not visit during busy times. The entry and exit are way too small to accommodate the masses of tourist that want to see it and unless you love to push against a human wall of sweaty bodies for 20 minutes or so, stay away during all busy times. Impossible to absorb any of the spirituality of the surroundings.

Must see in Bangkok. The temple was nice to see but there were just too many tourists and the guards kept telling the visitors to sit down and no pictures etc, so it was hard for us to really enjoy the experience.

Worth a look. Like many attractions of this sort, if it were the only thing to look at I think it may be a little disappointing. However, as part of a day out then it's well worth the look. I liked it that a lot of people were treating it as a pilgrimage; I guess having gawking tourists chatting away might be a bit off putting for them, but most people were treating the whole site with respect, hats and shoes off etc etc. I learned afterwards that the Buddha is made of Jade not Emerald, there is a story behind it.

It was tiny. We were told it was "across the street" from Wat Pho, which technically it is, but you must walk a very long city block to get to the front and entrance of the compound. The emerald Buddha is very tiny and you cannot take pictures there.

Beautiful structure and grounds. We took the Chrao Phraya river express from Sathorn pier to the grand palace (get off at pier no.9). There is an entrance fee to the grand palace complex but it is worth it. Go in the morning as soon as it opens as later in the day you will find CROWDS of chinese tour bus groups clicking away on their cameras. We got there around noon and the crowds were unbearable. The buildings are beautiful and intricate and the emerald buddha itself is just stunning. We sat on the cool floor and gazed at it for a while, it's a lovely room. Don't wear short shorts or short skirts. If you do, take a sarong or wrap to cover up. Take water as it will get very very hot. Be prepared for huge crowds when you get off the boat, it's just crazy. Really wish I had gone early in the morning. If you take a tuk tuk, specifically as for sathorn pier. If you just say 'river', they will take you to one of their friend's river tours, which could cost upwards of 1500 baht/person. Keep saying sathorn pier, where it should only cost you 15 baht for a ticket on the boat to the grand palace complex.
Serene pilgrimage for many. Make sure to at least see the Jade Buddha. It was beautiful to witness the monks and other Buddhists at this site. I felt like I was witnessing a pilgrimage.
Must visit. Very beautiful temple and really big, I really recommend to rent the audio guided tour, as you can understand all the background of all the structures, and the history surrounding it.

Thailands equivalent to the Sistine Chapel. This temple was just breath taking, the murals were stunning. Also the vibrant colours everywhere that you looked and the glitter. Just beautiful. The only downfall was the crowds but that is to be expected. Make sure that you are wearing appropriate clothing that cover your shoulders and if you are a woman your knees and if a man wear trousers otherwise they will not let you in. It is certainly worth visiting.

A Rich Little Buddha Way Up High. A must see for Buddha fans...expect thousands of fellow observers. I preferred the less hectic reclining big Buddha up close and personal with my shoes on a hand bag provided rather than left outside on a communal rack.

Stunning Temple Building. Remarkable temple building and stately, serene location for the famous Emerald Buddha. Be ready for crowds! The temple is in the Grand Palace complex and there were thousands of people visiting! Very hot, make sure you take water in with you as you will be there a few hours and not easy to get a drink once in the complex. As well as the Buddha, note the floor to ceiling tapestries inside as well. Well worth a visit.
Jade Buddha. A huge and very nice Jade Buddha in this temple. Try to go early morning for prayer. A must go temple in Bangkok

A signature temple in Bangkok. it's one of the royal temple which you shouldn't miss. If you come to BKK and fail to visit this temple. it means you haven't reach BKK yet.This temple is the royal temple next to Grand Palace. The signature of this temple is you can pray a best wish to the emerald buddha for good luck.The important recommendation for this trip is you are required to dress politely. No sandles, not vest, no shorts. But if you don't prepare for it, you can rent outside before you enter into the temple.

Magnificent, MUST SEE, but crowded.. If you only visit one temple in Bangkok, this is the one. Unfortunately thousands do visit here every day, and it is very very crowded but well worth it. The least worse time to visit may be at 8:30 am when they open.This compound houses the wat Phra Keo (jade Budha) in the Kings personal temple. Numerous other shrines surround it with stunning art and statuary. It is adjacent to the Grand Palace which is a former royal residence. Opulent and beautiful.Admission is a very steep 500 baht, but worth it if you've never been here before. It was my 5 th visit and I do not begrudge the fee which helps to maintain these magnificent edifices. Admission includes the grand palace and the Villamook palace which is in another location but well worth visiting.Be WARNED, they strictly enforce their dress code, no sleeveless attire for women, modest tops and no short skirts. Men and women can not wear shorts or 3/4 length pants. You can "borrow" suitable attire from the building immediately to your right when you enter the main exterior gate. Free, just leave a 200 baht deposit. If you are a very large person they will not have your size.
Very historic and sacred. Lots of travelers were with us that came to see the emerald buddha - very hostoric and sacred. It was not very crowded and we were able to stay as long as we desired.
Amaizing. The image its amaizing, but can't apreciatted well 'cause there were soooo many people, and there was much noise and squizeed. The guards can't take care so many people

Best thing at Grand Palace. We had not trouble getting inside to see the Emerald Buddah. Of course we first removed our shoes and found an obvious place to put mine. Donna carried hers inside in a bag. Clever lady. We sat on the floor and enjoyed the entire experience. Even though it was an oppressively hot day and very crowded outside, this was a welcome respite. Loved the large fans that cooled the inside of the temple. Make sure you don't pass this one up. If you are in Bangkok, go see the Emerald Buddah.
What a gem. The beauty and detail to this statue is breathtaking. Definitely worth fighting the crowds--make sure you spend time in there seeing the other arifacts

Go there but go there early. Beautiful but crowded. Lots of large travel groups and quite a few of the particularly annoying kind who are even getting on the Thais' nerves. Pushing, shoving, blocking, photo-crushing and all. Beat them to it if you can.
Worth for visit. I highly recommended to visit this place, it's incredible and beautiful. Surely, I would say that it's worth for visit.

overcrowding. After seeing the Wat pho and a series of temples, we proceeded to the Emerald Buddha to check whats in store for us. it was overcrowded, pilgrims lined up outside on a weekday, mostly chinese. We never got to see the Emerald Buddha but got a glimpse of it from afar. There is fee inside and forgot but minimal and we just strolled outside, very spacious. The Grand Palace could also be viewed very adjacent to it.
Bring a Binocle. Pros-Architecture is splendid and just breath taking. Look more grand than in the picturesCons-cannot really go near the emerald budda. so, bring a binocle

Should not miss. This is one of the top places to visit when going to bangkok, the complex is very big, with many buildings with beautiful arquitecture and decorations and paintings with history. This is one of the more religuious places in bangkok. The emerauld buddha is inside the main building and you have to take out your shoes to enter and show respect. Don´t miss this place.

Too crowded. You pay 500 baht for nothing special, definitely overpriced and overrated! Not relly worth a visit. And you have to wear long pants (guys), girls also have to cover otherwise you don't get in or they make you buy something to cover.
A must see visit. This is a good tourist attraction and is a must see if in Bangkok and you have time to go. Steeped in Buddha history.

Just beautiful. You can't help but be amazed by the temple of the Emerald Buddha,,it is just beautiful! The outside is so ornate and the building is so imposing!Inside of course is the emerald Buddha, it is not big, but is still good to see. You must take your shoes off to enter the building.The crowds are a little bit difficult to bear, but it is worth visiting as the architecture and decoration is so beautiful.Try to visit early in the day as it does get very hot!

okei. The sight was good, but it got ruined because we were told by random "helpers" that this sight was closed until late afternoon because of a buddist holiday which was untrue. They tried to sell us rides to other temples that were "open."
Magnificent!. It's a must visit for first time tourist to Thailand. This temple has a magnificent architecture and one of the most famous Buddha in Thailand. Be prepare for a hot sunny day!

Don't take a photo of the emerald buddha!. The Emerald Buddha was a real beauty. It's very elegant and your jaw will really drop when you get inside. Just one thing i'm quite annoyed is to the staff of the grand palace who just takes away the phones/cameras of tourist who tries to take a picture of the emerald buddha. i know it's not allowed to take pictures inside and can they be more polite and tell the tourists that it's not allowed and not just snatch away your phone or cam.
Magnificent. Definitely worth the visit. although the crowds are difficult to deal with. Small gold Buddha wrapped in gold cloth.
Spectacular buildings. Very interesting buildings that had unique architecture and were very colourful. Very overcrowded - get there early
Amazing. Historical, religious, and cultural landmark. Entry ticket is one package with Royal Palace and couple of museum. To enter the temple need take off your shoes.
simply awesome. Outstanding experience , you get excellent architecture and peace. Perectangular place to get lost in Buddha !!!

Has the royal feel just like at Buckingham Palace. The culture is here and the history, gets a bit crowded on most days, make sure to cover up, no short dresses or excess skin allowed to be shown, out of respect for royalty and the buddha.
Grate. wonderful place and good place for relex and take your time slowly. Have many thing to look. we looking forword to going back again.
Can't leave BKK without visiting it. 500 baht is expensive for a visit but the palace and all the temples around it make for such a rich visit.

Worth visiting. I visited this place last week. you'll be amazed by this area, not only the temple. She couldn't be just described by words. 500 baht is very worthy for this place. We also hired a licensed tour guide to take us for a tour around this area. Have a better understanding on the history and also the stories behind the architecture.

Once in a lifetime, take your time.. This is the most holy Buddha and was the second most desired place I wanted to visit of the temples in Bangkok and I was not disappointed. After seeing Wat Pho first, we tuk tuked (40 baht - he asked 50) to the front gate of the palace and temple grounds. Here you will be inspected for appropriate dress and sent back if you don't comply. The ticket lines go quickly - don't be daunted. My breath was taken away as soon as I stepped into this compound. Whereas Wat Pho looked like a garden of temples, this compound was chock a block with colorful, golden and mirrored buildings one against another, all the hallways decorated with murals and tiles and small statuettes, the pathways filled with people, all moving smoothly and easily together. Again, getting in to see the Emerald Buddha was easy and smooth despite the crowds. I was thrilled (who knows why...) at seeing that his clothes had been ceremoniously changed for the new season. My husband waited outside (one temple was enough for him) and we arranged to meet a half an hour later at the 'first' exit, which is right by the ticket line. I found it by following the general route of the tours and guides, otherwise, the place could be a maze of gates and passageways. A half an hour doesn't even scratch the surface, so go for longer if you can. There's no modern place on earth that can match the splendor of this place.

Impressive!. The place was very crowded however one may understand why so many wish to see it! It is indeed very impressive how the details are placed and the luxury in this building. Very different from everything I've seen!

Underwhelming. I appreciate that the temple is essentially a place of worship and the greater priority is to be given to those who revere the Buddha but as a tourist attraction it's a little disappointing. The significance and history of the Buddha's not wasted on my but i think i'd have prefered to have just read about the legend and enjoyed it's mystique rather than viewing it from afar through a crowded doorway.
Emeral Buddha. Any trip to Thailand must have a visit to a temple. If you only go to one make this one. You will never have seen a Buddha like this.

Solemnity at it's peak!. even though the area is frequently mobbed by tourists (as it is one of their prime attraction) the destination still has that solemn vibe in it. Everyone coming from various religions visit this and show respect while inside. I don't have any problems with taking off my shoes before I enter the temple or not being allowed to wear clothes that are revealing---it's ok with everyone.. and I tell you, you will be amazed when you go inside this area, not just the temple, but when you enter those gates...it's like you have been transported back in time...

Not worth the price. Over run with people and combined price with the Grand Palace is 1000bht or US$35, not worth it! Yes the space and structures are breathtaking, but the crowds spoil it all. Cannot recommend this attraction.

Very spiritual. Wat Phra Kaew is the part of rand Palace. The temple is sparkling with gold and gems, Buddha itself is quite small but due to many people praying it was very spiritual. Also they are changing Buddha's clothes depending on the season.I would advise to get an audio guide to learn more about the temple and Grand Palace as a whole

nice place with a lot of people BUT. it is 1 of the most popular place in Banhgkok.....Big Touristic attractionBUT to give 500 Baht for enter to the Temple(because i am no Thai...Thai people can enter Free)....i think that is too much!!!!i prefer go and spend these money for food or give to the poor than give in the Temple.....Execept of this thing,the place is very nice and a lot of people visiting it everyday!!!

Interesting Cultural Experience. Bring long pants and cover your shoulders. They lend clothes there, but it'll save quite a bit of time if you come appropriately dressed. Try to go on a cooler day or bring an umbrella, a lot of time in the sun.

Use audio guide or take a tour. You have to dress properly or deposit some money and get some outfit in the entrance. When you return the clothes they refund your money. T-shirts are OK but shorts, torn jeans, sleeveless everything is not OK. This is a huge place, lots of things to see. I advice you to get a audioguide that you can use for both the temple and the palace. A must see.

This will blow you away!. So the first thing I will say is TAKE THE TOUR! There is a free tour that goes every half hour, only lasts an hour, but will help you get so much more out of the sights than if you were just to walk around yourself. And IT IS AMAZING! So ornate and there is so much history. Every angle is a different view of unsurpassed beauty. The gold is so bright!The emerald Buddha is really only a miniscule part of what Wat Phra Kaew has to offer with most of the other buildings having more history associated to them and a ton more impressive. You do need to be sure to have your legs and arms covered and there are free pants (men), serongs (women), and scarves (women) for those who did not dress properly. Since it is soooo hot, I was not about to wear long sleeves/pants the whole day so I opted for this service as did many others and the clothes were clean and quality. Flip flops and sandles appeared to be permissable.
Another Fantastic Bangkok Temple. A most beautiful temple in this fantastic city.. Not to be missed The Emerald Buddha is just beautiful.

Beautiful. Avoid Peak times & holidays.. In order to give this wat a fair review I need to mention that we ended up heading here on Chulalongkorn Day at about 1:30. The Palace was closed at this time for a ceremony. Therefore, there were A LOT of people there. My boyfriend had been here before and he said it was busy.. but nothing like we experienced. At first you could barely move.. there were so many people. This was our last day in Bangkok and the temple was free (I've heard people mention it cost them money, so I'm not sure if it was just free this day?) Anyway, we decided to go in to see if it was any less packed once we got past the entrance. It was not. Never-the-less, to our benefit a massive storm came in. We hid out in one of the temples until it passed. It took awhile to wait it out, but when we emerged the place had emptied out quite a bit. This was my first wat visit, but I thought it was extraordinary. The emerald Buddha is very small, but very interesting. I loved walking around the outer perimeter looking at the murals and the stories they depicted. Since we hung out here for so long to avoid the storm, we were around as the sun started to go down. I love being at wats at this time, as it is very interesting to sit and observe the monks chanting. Also I think this is one of the best times at the wat in terms of number of tourists. By the time we were leaving there was next to no one here. Consequently, it was a lot easier to take photos and not have a crowd of people ruining them and your experience.

Amazing sight well worth a visit. Went late afternoon not crowded and very peaceful. Reclining Buddah very impressive and rest of Wat has nice atmosphere. Queue at nearby waterbus stop small but waited 20 mins and boat very crowded and uncomfortable so got off before link to skytrain

Quite a complex; actual Emerald Buddha not the only highlight. The entrance is on the North wall. If you're coming from the Reclining Buddha (across from the South wall), as I was, it is quite a trek around. It was very crowded during my visit. There are lots of "helpful" people out front who want to help you find your wallet, but they are not too aggressive and easily avoided.

A Must!. Wat Phra Kaew is a beautiful temple but what is really important is inside it. The Emerald Buddha! The most important statue of Buddha in Thailand! It has 3 different pieces of clothing for each of 3 seasons in Thailand and depending of the season you visit this temple in you'll see a different piece of wonderfull golden cloth. It is a highlight of any trip to Bangkok.
Amazing peaceful place. just superb.... good peaceful atmosphere... should at least visit once ..... nice place.... you will surely come to know what bangkok stands for.......

A must see. Easy access, enjoyed the tour. Lots to see. We brought a huge stroller for two babies and managed to maneuver through the crowds just fine. Do come properly dressed, no shorts or sleeveless shirts.

The Thai people have a lot of pride in this statue. If you are in the Grand Palace stop in to see this one. Not one of the biggest Buddha but it is made of solid jade. Depending on the season they change his covering.
Worth the time is in the area. I wouldn't travel across the city to see this one, but if you are in the area sighteeing anyway, be sure to take a few minutes to enjoy it!

Grand palace and emerald Buddha. Good day out to visit the grand palace which houses the temple with the emerald Buddha. Go early if possible because there will be crowds there. Take your own long trousers or long skirt/sarong unless you don't mind borrowing ones that they will issue you with. Also take plenty of bottled water as it probably will be hot! watch out for any guys outside that might tell you that the palace is closed and offer to show you somewhere else. It probably wont be closed but there is only one entrance so ask around to find it and check for yourself.
Worth Visit. The emerald budda is much smaller than i expected but still very impressive and housed in what is thailands most important temple. Very crowded but well worth a visit

Just amazing. While the Emerald Buddah is much smaller than you may think, this Wat is worth visiting. There is entrance fee of 300 Baht and be sure to bring something to cover your exposed legs and shoulders. If not, there are plenty of merchants who will be happy to sell whatever you may need.To get more information you can hire a personal guide but be sure to negotiate the price. Once inside you can also join for free a guided tour which is what we did. As other temples this one does not disappoint. There are more details that you can absorb in one visit and plenty of opportunities for fantastic photos.

Beautiful Wat. Emerald Buddah Temple is beautiful and glitters and shines. There are several buildings throughout the property and they are all spectacular. They are very strict on dress code (shoulders covered, don't show knees) but do have clothes rental. The crowds are pretty bad and it's very crowded but after you see it, you understand why and for good reason. I especially enjoyed the murals which seems to be one of the more overlooked aspects.

Nice to say you've seen it. I was expecting a little more from the Emerald Buddha. It's impressive if you have good eye sight, as the Buddha is perched high above the floor. However, it's lovely to see as it is very quiet and gives you a nice moment to reflect.
awesome. The temple was everything we expected , a lot of people there , it is a famous temple , the emerald buddha has great significence for the thais .
Small but lovely. I expected a huge buddha like the others, this guy is little but the set up of the temple is gorgeous and a must see attraction.

Never dissapoints. I had been here before several years ago and expected the decor to be a bit worn now. But everything was just as before and they obviously spend a lot of time giving the Grand Palace some care and attention. The things to watch out for are the touts and conmen outside the main gates as well a pick pockets. Men remember to wear long trousers and ladies avoid sleeveless tops. If you forget then you are able to borrow sweat pants and shawls for free but you must leave a 200 bart deposit.

Emerald Buddha. This is probably the most important Buddist temple in Thailand. The Emeral Buddha is very beautiful although it is not large like the Wat Pho reclining Buddha. Definitely worth the visit, adjacent to the "must see" Grand Palace.

A beautiful Wat. The outside decoration of the temple is worth a visit in itself. Once inside you will see the Emerald Buddha and it's a lot smaller than you think but the Buddha 'wears' different gold garment depending on the season so that's pretty cool to see. You can't take photos inside but it's a good thing because it make you look with your eyes rather than busy fiddling with your camera. Take the opportunity to reflect a bit, that's what Buddhism is about.

The crowds make it hard to appreciate. The site is undoubtedly sensational, but predictably, this brings in the large crowds (sure, I was one of them) that choke the walkways and views. I could glance the Buddha for a few seconds before being pushed along. It was a very hot day too, and adding the steep access fee, the whole experience was less than satisfying. It felt like ticking the box and moving on.

amazing. A place like no many others - pure spiritual! You feel great inside and peace and calm are almost touchable! It's a great Palace and you may see more, if you like. Maybe just sit and look at this amazing temple! You know that the King himself changes the clothes of Buddha each season?

Huge fascinating complex. It's well worth a visit, even though the Emerald Buddha is small and you cannot take photos inside the shrine area, it is a lovely image to take away from your trip to Thailand.It gets very crowded at times, please cover up (Men- Shirt or T-shirt which covers your shoulders, long trousers and I think proper shoes, not flip flop sandals. Women- Long skirt or trousers, and cover up your shoulders).If you forget, you can rent suitable attire in the complex itself. Take your shoes off before entering the shrine area.Be aware of the touts outside the temple, most are just trying to make a living, but it can be annoying and frustrating. Walk along a bit to try to get a taxi, with luck you will eventually find one that uses the meter.The cost is 500 baht (about 10 pounds), which doesn't seem a lot for a tourist, but Thais get in for free, whether they are there to worship or not. No discount is given for tax paying expats either. That being said, the ticket also allows entry to the Vimanmek Palace within 7 days of the ticket purchase.

Magnificent. If you travel to Bangkok, you absolutely must visit this incredible site. Everywhere you turn is more fantastic than the spot you just left. Awe inspiring does not even describe the beauty and majesty of this temple compound. Be sure to go early, as it gets quite hot in the afternoon here. If you visit only one place in Bangkok, make sure it is here. You won't be sorry

Crowded. The obvious draw is the Temple. Next time, I will arrive as early as possible to avoid the crowds. I suggest you get a guide since navigating based on the map can be confusing since the various sites are within a relatively small area.

Nice complex of temples, but overpriced. It's one of the main tourist attraction in Thailand (not only in Bangkok) so avoid coming here at weekends. Come early morning when it's not too hot and there are less visitors. Entry ticket is 500 baht for foreigners (includes Grand Palace, Coin Museum and Vimanmek mansion, valids within 7 days) and free for locals. Yes, in my opinion it's a rip off. Dress code is the same as in other royal properties, cover your knees and shoulders. Sarong is available for rent but you may want to skip the queue. Local style long pants are available for sale (200B) opposite the main entrance.If you are a bit adventurous go to Sanam Luang and hop on bus number 15. The bus will pass some old buildings, including a fort and many temples. Just press the button when you want to get off and continue your ride with the next bus. It will eventually take you to MBK and Siam. Depending on the bus, you might get free bus or have to pay 6.5 baht each person, flat fare. Cheap but most of them are old buses with no aircon.
So many people. Guide was very knowledgeable but there were so many other visitors there all pushing to see the Jade Buddha. Photo's can only be taken through the doorway.

The Emerald Buddha. What I like the place is that it not only offers the emerald Buddha, The place also offers numerous Thai symbols and articrafts. We don't have a comparable site in the Philippines.

Stunning; like nothing you've seen before. Totally worth the £10 entrance fee to see this wonderful Grand Palace. Your ticket actually gives you entry to the Grand Palace, museum of coins and museum of textiles which exhibits the Queen's beautiful wardrobe. The temple itself is beautiful and we took so many pictures because every building was a work of art. The emerald Buddha, complete with different outfits for the seasons, was beautiful.One tip; wear clothes to cover your legs and arms; otherwise it's a long queue to get some rather sweaty, hired clothes.

Not just another temple.... Seen one temple, seen them all? Or, so you thought...its quite expensive, in the grand scheme of things to get in here, and perhaps a bit more touristy than I would normally go for but it is a marvellous place to visit. The grand palace and emerald buddha should be on any Bangkok, places to see list. The craftsmanship of the buildings/temples/statues are amazing and you have to see it to believe the intricacies of the work. Waring to anyone thinking they can sneak a photo - don't bother! I saw many tourists ignoring the warnings and having the security make them wipe their camera memory cards. Respect the wishes of the Thai people and don't disobey the rules....
Part of the Palace complex. This temple is part of the Grand Palace complex. The temple and the Buddha are beautiful and a must see.

Top spot in Bangkok. That is the absolute top spot in Bangkok. A must see. Unfortunately, you are not the only one who knows that. So it is heavily crowded. And be prapared to take off the shoes whenever you enter a temple. There are strict dress codes for the Royal Palace area, where the Emerald Buddha temple. No short trousers for men, no short skirts or dresses for women. Long dresses/trousers can be rented for free, but you might have to queue and might prefer your own clothes. Anyway, the Emerald buddha is definitely worth a visit. Don't miss it.
Nice. It was shorter than I though, I like the way that Thai people make an effort for keep it clean. Woman should cover their shoulders.
Worth the stop. Keep in mind this Buddha is very small. But its unique. Definitely worth the stop for a look. Much to see and do in the area.

A must see!!!. This wonderful temple situated in the heart of bangkok is a must see for anyone who appreciates culture and tradition. The sight of the emerald Buddha is marvellous and left us in awe. Absolutely breathtaking. The calm nature of the temples, with people sitting in silence praying in front of the Buddha was a different and worthwhile experience. Must see if you visit bangkok! You won't regret it.
okay. It's okay... I don't know, maybe I'm not really into history I guess.I'm more of an adventure person. And the weather was getting to me so I visited this one quickly.

Nice temple. This temple is dedicated to the holy Emerald Buddha that in Thailand is considered the most important Buddha figure. The king,or a liasion, change it's gold clothing three times a year, after each season (the cold, the warm and the rainy season). The temple is very nice, but the lines to get inside the temple can sometimes be very long - choose a off-season visit if possible.While inside, take the time to sit and imbibe the "holy" feeling. Take in consideration that this Buddha figure is considered holy, so please show respect to the local worshippers:1. Sit properly, with your feet always pointing away from the Buddha!2. Don't make unnecessary noises, whisper if you need to speak.3. Don't use your camera inside, it's forbidden!

Bling. Very hot day in Bangkok when I visited. But what a surprise! Beautiful temples & murals! Wat Pho Kaow was amazing, leaning Buddha much anticipated, & I want dissapointed. Huge & so much gold!! Not to be missed in Bangkok.

Inside the great palace (king's) beautiful place. Impressive from the outside as from within the Emerald Buddha temple is a "must go to" place in Bangkok, if only for a glimpse of the entire compound. do not be fooled from impostors that claim that the palace is closed or full, and when you get off of the taxi walk straight inside and buy a ticket from the cashier to the entire place. only believe official uniform personal.
Emerald Buddha. Wanted to see this sooo much and it lived up to my. Expectations. Worth a visit to see everything. Make sure you are suitably attired I.e. Shoulders/ legs covered

impressive. For me it's a great pity it is forbidden to make photos - i want to take this beauty back not only in my memory but also in pics. When u are finally in - u are holding your breath, so beautiful is the whole scene u see. it is like a gold temple of Emerald Buddha inside another temple.

Not to be missed. The building that houses the emerald Buddha is located in the Grand Palace and is beautiful. There were many people when we went but it still is worth the visit. It is an impressive building and statue

Beautiful Temple. The details and architecture in this temple is stunning. Wear respectful clothes and shoes that are easy to remove. The Emerald Buddha is actually quite small and high above. The room also gets extremely crowded. No pictures are allowed once inside.

Rich and beautiful. You could literally go blind with so much bling all around. The entire complex is a collection of beauties glided in perfection and ethereal beauty. Crowded yet giving you enough to maneuver around. Better to catch an official guide to take you through the place along with the rundown of the trivia and history of the whole complex. Keep a large portion of your day for this place to admire everything around here

Interesting sight. It's a relatively small buddha that's part of a larger temple. Located in the Grand Palace grounds.This buddha has a pretty cool story that it was covered in plaster during an invasion so that the invaders wouldn't steal it. Only much later was the plaster accidentally cracked and the emerald was seen.Make sure not to point your feet at the buddha as a sign of respect.

Beautiful Temple!. This was my second time at Wat Phra Kaew and can clearly say now that even though this place is absolutely beautiful, there are other temples that take the cake over that one. The architecture and grandiose of this area is not questionable but there are way too many people there every day and very hard to get the picture you want. Of course it is impossible to visit Bangkok without visiting this iconic area, but it is almost $20 USD per person and you have to be covered from head to toe if you want to go in. No ripped jeans, no short blouses for women either. You must have long pants and cover as much as you can on top as well especially if you are a woman. They are very strict on dress code there and will turn you around if they do not see fit.Overall, a must see in Bangkok but with a bigger admission price and definitely a lot of sweating along the way.
Great work of Art.. It marks the tradition and marksmenship of thailand. you need lot of stamina to visit this place. but definatly a must visit place in bangkok.
Many things to visit. There are many buildings to visit treat for eyes as well as camera. Please try to get DSLR camera. Lot of Picturesque buildings to capture

Just amazing. The building is utterly stunning. You just can't helped but be amazed being here. All the buildings are simply stunning. All so elaborate with the rich golds shinning in the sun. You have to remove your shoes to go in the temple and even then you can't get very close. I think I was more impressed with the building than the Emerald Buddha. I thought it was going to be bigger than it was. But I don't want to take away it's sheer beauty. It is stunning but I only wish you could get closer. You have to wait your turn to take photos but with a good lens you can get reasonably decent photos. It's quite amazing to think how old it is.Well worth a visit.

Amazing workmanship. Although the temple was full to overflowing as were the entire grounds of the Grand Palace with thousands of noisy, rude, pushy and disrespectful Chinese tour groups the workmanship that has gone into this building is amazing. Very difficult to get a good look at the Buddha and the surroundings due to the absolute crush of people, however the building itself is breathtaking. No photos allowed which I totally respect, this is after all a religious site. The floor is made of inlaid marble of several different colours in a very intricate pattern. I only wished my son-in-law who is a stone mason could have seen it. He would have been awestruck. As with the entire grand Palace precinct, I believe it needs to have some restrictions put on visitor numbers. A higher entry that includes a guide and maybe even a pre-booking system for non Thais would lead to a much more enjoyable experience.

impressive sculpture. Our guide had really built up our expectation of the Emerald Buddha and I was very surprised to find it was so small as had been expecting something much larger. However still an impressive piece of sculpture in a beautiful temple.

Jaw-dropping and beautiful. Line up, shoes off, camera switched off, sun hat off, kneel down and admire (one cannot stand or point one's feet at this particular statue). Took me a moment or two to find the centre of attention - this Buddha statue isn't particularly large and sits atop an ornate gilt pedestal rather than dominate the temple - but it is stunningly beautiful. Jade, rather than emerald, but quite awe-inspiring nonetheless. No trip to the Grand Palace complex would be complete unless one visited this shrine. And my shoes were still there when I'd finished my visit.

small buddha big place.. This is such an ornate palace or temple. The building itself is really interesting but do not come expecting a big Emerald Buddha. It is small and quite hard to see as it is way up in the rafters of the building. You will be there for the temple itself and be aware of shoes off at the entrances.

Most revered Buddha.... The Emerald Buddha is the most revered Buddha in Thailand and because of this, no photography is allowed inside the temple. There is however a window opening through which you can photograph the Buddha from outside but considering the Buddha is not too large, it is difficult. A zoom lens would help in this instance....

Wonderful. A vast expanse of buildings and temples which are architecturally brilliant and in vivid colors which you would usually associate with Thailand. Also this is the place of the emerald Buddha. Needs time and efforts to go around this place as the heat gets to you but is a great photo opportunity.

same same!. so crowed place with many many visitors!but as usually you will see another budha!but this time it's in Jade and usually they call it emralde budha!u can not take it in picture!just vidit it!

Once in a lifetime. Watching the changing of the Buddha's clothing was amazing. Beautifully dressed people surrounded the royals as the said prayers - we were so far in the back I couldn't hear anything though. The Prince of Thailand removed his winter coat and put on a different one for summer. The winter and rainy season coats are on display - simply awesome. We don't speak Thai, so we relied on our hosts to explain how they cared for the artifact, and he was quite knowledgeable (recommended by the Hilton concierge). In my opinion, it is worth visiting Bangkok to see the ceremony and the Palace.

The Teeny Emerald Buddha. I honestly was not impressed. This is for someone who holds some kind of a spiritual connection with these temples in the middle of the city. The Emerald Buddha was not mind blowing at all. it was crowded. We actually missed the actual statue due to the hustle and bustle to get in. Typical tourist trap.
crowded. cant take photo once in the shrine of the Bud ha and it is so high up to the ceiling iit looks tiny compared to the reclining and golden Bud ha

Fantastic temple. Combined with a Grand Palace visit this temple is mind-blowing. You can't take a photo of the emerald Buddha from inside the temple, but a zoom lens from outside will get you a great picture. The temple, and the Grand Palace, and Wat Pho is easily doable in a day, but it's quite a bit of traipsing around, so suggest you start early, take water, and take your time.

A master piece. A real master piece with how they could build the place with so many gold pieces. Especially the library building where so many pieces of gold were used. The jade buddha will also change their "clothes" according to the seasons (winter, summer, spring, autumn) which was an interesting fact to learn.
Very impressive. The Grand Palace complex is impressive enough already, but the Emerald Buddha is the highlight of the complex
Emerald Buddha. Sooo Peaceful ...and Soo soothing to see Emerald Buddha statue.... I sat there for 2 hours and It was soo pure place to feel the lightness in heart mind and soul ....
Nice and a must visit. similar to other Buddha temple with great grandeur and nice decoration for Lord Buddha. Visiting this is must for completing your Bangkok trip.

Its good place to see, But enterence is very costly. We have pay 500Bhat to the enterece, Since after taking 500 rupees ticket only then only we can see this Grand palace and this Emrald Buddha,
So overall i dint like this place when compared with What Pho
Nearly life size Buddha. Well maintained and clean. The crowd control was excellent, the staff are very polite and courteous.
Nice of course. Difficult to get the spirit of the place, but nice of course. Too much people on the same time. The buddha is small but brillant
Very Nice. With the way it's built up you'd think it would be huge, but it's actually quite small. Still, it was very impressive and I'm glad we made the effort to see it.

Temple visit. Everything was good. Culture from the country is very visible during the visit. A lot of history in one place and a lot of visitors from all over the world. You can rent also something for wearing during the vist.

Emerald Buddha okay; Temple Complex better – 3.5+ out 5 rating. Wat Phra Kaew is regarded as the most important Buddhist Temple in Thailand and is located within the grounds of the Grand Palace complex. We were there in mid-December and it was really crowded.Once we walked past the main gate of the Grand Palace complex occupied by an army “checkpoint”, we could see the Temple Complex to the left across the open field.Past the Temple entrance, the first attraction on the site is a statue of the “hermit doctor” who is supposed to have healing powers. Directly behind the hermit doctor statue is Wat Phra Kaew.In the same area around, the hermit doctor, we encountered the imposing 5 metre tall (16 feet) guards for the temple complex towering over the tourists. These guardians of the gate called Yakshis are common throughout the temples in the country.Once you’re at the Temple, you’ll notice the decorations on the outside of the temple wall. The walls of the bot (ordination hall) have 112 golden garudas - mythical bird like creatures with a humanoid form.The Emerald Buddha is carved from a single block of jade and is around 66 centimetres (26 inches) in height. The Emerald Buddha is relatively small, is also elevated on a pedestal and is cordoned off. As a result you cannot get close enough to get a really good look. It might be a good idea to bring a pair of binoculars.The Emerald Buddha has three changes of robes each year corresponding to the three seasons - the summer – diamond encrusted gold robe, winter - solid gold robe and the rainy season – a gilded monk’s robe. No one is allowed near or to touch the Emerald Buddha except the King of Thailand. That being the case, the King performs the changing of the robe ceremony during each season to bring good fortune.Before you enter the temple you will have to remove your shoes and NO photography is allowed inside. A tourist took some photos inside and security quickly came and confiscated the camera. I don’t know what happened to the tourist and the camera.Our group spent at most 30 minutes at the actual temple.Before and after the visit of the Emerald Buddha, we walked through the Temple grounds. On the grounds you will be able to see many monuments, structures and statues including the following:• Gold coloured statues of kinnara (male) and kinnaris (female) - a half human, half bird creature.• Phra Mondhop – library next to Phra Si Rattana Chedi• Phra Si Rattana Chedi - a gold coloured, bell shaped structure with a spire – a place for prayer• Phra Chedi Thong (The Twin Golden Stupas) – demons and monkeys “holding up” the stupa (prayer mound).• Close to the Temple, you’ll also see a model of Angkor Wat – a famous 12th century temple in Cambodia. From what I have read, the King Rama IV started the model project and the King Rama V completed this model to celebrate the centennial of Bangkok as the Royal City and show Thailand’s early history of owning what is now called Cambodia.We spent somewhere around 90 minutes visiting the complex; anything less and you would be doing a disservice to yourself. I probably could have spent at least another 30-60 minutes at the site.The architecture of the various buildings and the many mythical statues within the Temple complex are spectacular in my opinion because of its beauty, symbolism and the uniqueness. One could argue the architecture and the mythical creature statues were much more interesting than the actual Emerald Buddha. If there was a separate rating / review for the Wat Phra Kaew complex (not including the Temple) I would give it a higher rating of 4+ out of 5.In my opinion, the Emerald Buddha is interesting but the Reclining Buddha at Wat Pho is more impressive. Although, I will say the Temple housing the Emerald Buddha is quite nice. I would rate the Emerald Buddha site as just average; at most 3+ out 5.Notes and Tips• When you pay your entrance fee, be sure to pick up a map of the Grand Palace complex.• There are no monks resident in this temple complex unlike the many other temples.• We were quite prepared in terms of what clothes to wear and not to wear so we did have any issues entering the Grand Palace grounds. If your clothing is deemed inappropriate, you can rent clothes for a nominal fee (refundable deposit) at the front gate or another option is to buy some clothes from street vendors.• There are 12 Yakshis with a pair standing at each of the 6 gates to the Temple complex. Each of them has a different name. In addition to the 12 guarding the gates, there are more inside the complex. There are 4 more pairs guarding each of the four entrances at Phra Mondop (library).• If you’re into photography, in my opinion, a 200 mm telephoto lens (slr camera) would be the minimum to get an average close up of the Emerald Buddha. If you have a regular digital camera like many people; one with 20x or 30x optical zoom (not digital zoom) would be ideal.• Like Wat Pho – Temple of the Reclining Buddha, there is more to Wat Phra Kaew than the temple. There are lots of interesting structures.• The Grand Palace complex sits adjacent to the Wat Pho complex. It is approximately 1 kilometre (6/10th of mile) to the entrance.• This was day 2 of 3 of our Bangkok tour through Wandee Tours. Our tour guide Wandee spoke fairly good English; good enough for us to understand.• Days 1 and 3 included tours of the Jim Thompson House, the Golden Buddha, Chinatown, the Flower Market, the train market, a canal boat tour and the floating market.• Our ship the Azamara Journey has a capacity of 694 passengers and because it is a smaller ship, it can dock “downtown”. The larger ships dock farther away resulting in longer transportation times to the downtown core.• The first thing I noticed while I was on the bus was the amount of traffic on the roads. Regardless of the time of day it appeared that “rush hour” was all day and evening. Furthermore, the shoulder of the road becomes an “extra” lane.
jo. A n iconic tempole , a must visit when in Thailand , it is a spectacular big Buddha , a lot of traffic on the way , go eraly morning .

Sacred and great sense of peace. Before you come, please wear a shirt with sleeves and long pants or long skirt. NO SHORTS OR SLEEVELESS SHIRT..not even if you wear a shawl over your sleeveless top. It's prohibited. They are very strict. You may wear sandals but yo need to remove them once inside. Regarded the most holiest and significant Buddhist temple in Thailand. The Buddha image meticulously carved from a single block of jade. No one is allowed near the Buddha except the KING. You may kneel and say a prayer in front of the Emerald Buddha. I felt thankful after seeing the Buddha in person.
mandy. We had to see this famous temple , went early , it was spectacular , the emerald buddha is breathtaking , no trouble getting there ,

Must see !!!. This is beautiful place. I and my friends spent almost half days walking around seeing the ancient Thai artists works for painting aged 200 years ago and also for I have no idea how to call, but we like that they put tiny little things all around the main temple and nearby. Very beautiful, I couldn't imagine how many hours ancient people spent for those beautiful art works.This is the place you shouldn't miss.

Princess Arriving - everything is orange today. What a spectacular sight this place was on Saturday. The princess was arriving and the entire place had been dressed up in orange and yellow. The bands were playing and the police were in full force. While our tour guide tried, he could not get us past any of the many doors leading into the temple. But, nonetheless, I got a recording of the band, peeked in some windows, and for the most part, really enjoyed just being there to watch the crowd shuffle into the area.

Mesmerizing! Except for the scene stealer.... It was definitely mesmerizing to see the Emerald Buddha but we weren't allowed to take pictures inside the temple, unlike the other temples we've been to (Wat Traimit, Wat Pho, etc.). Also, there was this guy (Imagine that, their fellow countryman) who took a picture of the Emerald Buddha.(he was sitting right in front of us in the temple) He got apprehended by one of the temple guards and was ordered to delete the photo. He did so, but as the temple guard turned his back on this guy, he secretly took another photo of the Buddha using his phone, not knowing that there were 2 other guards standing near him. So one of them approached and asked him to unlock his phone but since he didn't do so, the guard left taking his phone away. We didn't know what happened next but kudos to the temple guards for doing their job.
Lovely Thailand Experience. The place was well kept and quite a tourist haven, was amazed with the history and the huge number of people coming there daily
Amazing yet overpriced. This temple is undoubtably beatiful, however the enterance fee for this and the grand palace is overpriced in my opinion.
Stunning!. Second visit this year and equally stunning second time around. Not to be missed. Really stunning and spiritual temple.
Go!. Amazing! Respect the culture & dress appropriately please! Try & avoid busy times of day, it gets really busy!
Interesting. We had been to Laos were they are insistent that this Buddha was stolen from them! So it was more than interesting to hear The Thai version of this story.

Just stunning!. This was one of my favourite parts of our trip to Bangkok, the temple itself is absolutely beautiful and the detail which went into building each of it's parts is incredible. The Emerald Buddha itself is surprisingly small and also made of jade but it was beautiful and wearing a beautiful gold outfit matching the elegance of the exterior.

Most sacred place in thailand. This is the most important and most visited temple in Bangkok and is located in the Grand palace and it is where the emerald buddha is kept. This is small miniature and unless you know where it is you will not notice it. I missed it! Locals go inside the temple to offer prayers. You need to take your shoes off to go inside where photography is no allowed. There is not much inside the temple. This is said to the holiest place in Thailand and is very much revered. Locals says it is due to this buddha that the monarch was protected!

Beautiful Experience. We visited the Emerald Buddha today and I found it to be a beautiful experience. The whole of the temple complex at the grand palace is awe inspiring. It is worth a visit. Please go conservatively dressed.

Top 10 to visit in Bangkok Thailand. Been there many time , I love the way how people can made such a great and beautiful temple like this , lots of people over the world come to see this temple , 1 in top ten that you should not miss if have a chance to visit Thailand

The Best Wat in Thailand. I say it is the best because it is the most sacred Wat in Thailand. It is always crowded but don't let that put you off. The Thai people come here in droves to pray. The Emerald Buddha is actually green jade, it is not very large, and it is way up high in the Wat, so it is not very possible to see any details of the carving. However, the spiritual feeling you get just being here is quite amazing, even if you are Christian. Don't pass this up!
Nice place to visit for 1st timer. Try to get a local tour guide to know more about the history and architecture. Wear properly as there is a dress code to enter all the temples.

Be prepared to be underwhelmed. The Buddha is lovely - but not very large and situated quite far from where you can see it. And crowds the day we visited were nearly overwhelming. Wat Pho was a much better experience - not to mention 1/5 the cost for entry!

Another must-see in Bangkok. Again, what more can I say here, this is another must-see location. The story behind the emerald buddha is great too, so make sure to read about it - or better - go with a guide.

Good but pricey. The temple of emerald buddha is inside the Grand palace complex.The temple is without any doubt a great place to visit ,but its a bit pricey.Entry ticket costs 500TBT for foreigners.They give a map at the time of entry.Please study it carefully because the campus is huge and chances are you will come out missing something.BEWARE of cheats who stand outside the temple in official looking attire and tell you that the temple is closed.They will try to take you to some other godforsaken place for a lot of money.Do not pay any heed to them.Just keep walking upto the entrance gate.The temple is open everyday morning 9:30 to evening 5:30(Please recheck from their website) except national holidays.

Calming Place If You Can Avoid The Crowd. This place was majestic, and befitted the temple built by Monarchs.
As soon as you enter, you will be in awe of the interiors, and the Buddha carved in Jade.
Certainly a must visit on a trip to Bangkok.

Impressive. When we visited it was very busy, very hot - but worth battling the crowds. There is more to the site than we saw - lots of artwork on the walls etc. Truly unlike anything else I've seen - would advise going early in the morning to avoid as many of the other tourists as possible!

Cool and calm place. Easily the most quiet of the 'wats' , one can sense a deep religious atmosphere inside. Most if not everyone is seated low on the floor. Try to spend some time in there away from the hustle and bustle of the crowds outside.

Too Many Tourist!. When I first came here (more than 5 years ago), I liked the temple very much! It's glamorous and beautiful architecture, the elusive and solemn emerald buddha, the silence and peace of the entire place...now it is all filled with thousands of...ehm...noisy tourist everyday, not to mention the doubled entrance fee due to its overated popularity (I once enjoyed THB250 for each entrance, now it is THB500), and countless staff at the gate yelling ceaseless in Mandarin about your attire. I just can not enjoy the environment. Still, it is the most important temple in the Kingdom of Thailand. Now I am just glad that i have been there, done that.
temple. There are so many temples in Bangkok. Definitely worth the visit. Would love to bring our grown children on a visit to Thailand so they can appreciate the wonderful culture

Go deep into buddhism. It's a paradox. When you seat on you knees in this small closed wat, there too many people are near you. But the fresh air is all around. And you really feel how small you are in this World, and how deep and grate is this religion. And you are not alone in this World. And in does't meter what is your religion or no religion. This sense is grate.

It's not actually emerald!!. This temple is located located within the larger Grand Palace complex. The entrance fee is around 500 baht (quite a lot for Asia) but this covers the whole complex and a couple of other royal sites in Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha Temple is beautiful and houses, of course, the Emerald Buddha. Ensure that you learn the interesting story behind the statue. Try to avoid going in at the same time as a tour group otherwise you will feel quite cramped and may loose your shoes outside!!

stunning. This is an amazing place, we took a water taxi from the landmark hotel to the area, again be mindful of your possessions and fake police trying to convince you to visit other sites. Be mindful of the dress code in the area, no shoes allowed or hats.

most beautiful complex in bangkok. The entry fee for foreigners is high (500 Bhats per person) - Thai people do not pay any fee. The temple is included in a large complex that also includes the royal palace. Very impressive. Note- only a single entrence per the temple of emerald Buddha is allowed.

Beautiful building. This temple is included with the admission of the Royal Palace. It's one of the dominant buildings and is very lavishly decorated particularly on the outside. You can't miss this once you are there. There were large crowds when we were there, so we waited a while and they soon thinned out. The Buddah inside is quite small and is carved from a single piece of jade.

One of the most respectful Thai wat. Visited this Emerald Buddha Temple (Wat Phra Kaew) when visiting Grand Palace. This Wat is located in the Grand Palace. The history of the Buddha Statue can be traced back to Lanna Kingdom in Northern Thai where the statue is found.The Buddha statue sat in the Wat Phra Kaew since Rama I relocated the capital from Thonburi to Bangkok. Every year, HRH King of Thailand will change the Kartina of the Buddha by himself for three time. The change of the Kartina is according to three different seasons of the Thailand.If you want to have a look on another two Kartinas, you can visit the Pavilion of Regalia, Royal Decorations and Coins (located next to the ticket-checking entrance into Grand Palace). If you are a Buddhist, pray sincerely to the Buddha. If you are from other religions, respect the devotees and follow the instructions.No photo taking is allowed in the temple. So bring a long zoom lens and take the photos from outside the temple.

Not to be missed. Always a stop for me in BKK, this shrine is culturally one of the most important for thr Thai. Architecture buffs will not be disappointed; this is Thai architecture all-out. Come early before the tourist buses come in order to appreciate the gardens and temple in relative serenity
Lovely. Very nice experience and the guide that we had was very knowledgeable which made our visit all the better.

must see. You just need to go there and see this Buddha. Also when not religious or not a Buddhist, this is one of the most important things you can see in the eyes of many Thai people, so just go!It can be very busy, but be patient. It is a very small statue, but nonetheless: just go and see it :-)
Amazing Temple. Very nice architecture and good reflection of culture if you like such places you should look for each point of this place
Love. You have to see this amazing sight. I did not know what to expect then all the sudden you see this amazing sight. Take your camera you will want lots of photos.

Not my first time. Not my first time visiting this temple but it was my partner'so first time.. I didn't know that he need loans tousers and a shirt ( he wore t-shirt and a short) So we had to borrow them.. It was jot and humid and crowed as usual but it worths the effort. Amazing artworks and decor.

Great historical site. You can only take photos of the Buddha from outside the building. Consequently, it puts a challenge on your camera and photography skills. Fortunately, I have a great camera. We loved experiencing this important site for Buddhist followers in this part of the world.

Temple day 3. This is the most fantastic temple to visit there are cloths to rent if you forget to wear long trousers or long sleeve tops. Make sure you have plenty of space on your camera memory card you will need it.This temple you cant afford to miss

Nice temple but don't expect much. The Buddha is very small, it can only be seen from afar as there is a barricade in front of it and taking pictures is not allowed.I still recommend to go and see it if you are already walking around the grand palace.

Temple with 'tradition' written all over !. A real eye opener when it came to viewing a Buddhist temple and in true Thai traditional architecture. As most of the viewing is from outside the heat and the humidity can cause some amount of discomfort.
Within Grand Palace compound. get there early if wanting to get inside, as part of a larger tourist attraction. well worth a visit, as are the whole Palace.
Awe Inspiring. This place must be visited if you are in Bangkok. It is in a huge complex, along with the Grand Palace.
Breathtaking. This place will make you speachless. It is accessible by taking a tuk tuk. There are 3 areas to spend your time at. It is very croweded in the late afternoon so get there early.
Nice temple. If you have enough time in Bangkok after seeing the other main attractions then this is still worth a visit. If time is tight then perhaps give it a miss.

Majestic. Its a must go place for Buddhists. Even if you are not religious, this is worth seeing. The temple lies in the middle of the vast Grand Palace complex. You can reach here by taking a tuk tuk from the National Stadium BTS station. There are a few gates into the palace, just ask a traffic cop and he will point the main entry gate out for you. Go straight in and walk to the ticket office. The ticket is 500 baht (includes the ticket for the Temple, the Grand Palace, the Ananda Samakhom Throne Hall Museum, The Royal Textile gallery)After buying the ticket, turn left and walk till you come to the security checkpost for the temple. Once you enter, don't forget to check out the fantastic murals on the walls of the inner courtyard. Despite its name, the actual statue is made of green jasper, not emerald. The statue lies in the middle of dozens of other statues, some made of gold. Shoes and cameras are not allowed inside. You also have to dress modestly in order to enter.
Within the Grand Palace. nice atmosphere. It was very crowded (when we went), but still could spend a few moments inside. Awesome art to view, filled with history.
too busy place. Many people... many chinese during their week of holiday first week in october.. But the temple is amazing, and it deserves the queue...

Just average. As I come from the land of Pagodas ,Myanmar the visit was just average . The ticket fee is 500baht per pax and not allow shorts to wear so ve aware of dress code.2-3 hrs of visit is recimmended and if you rent a taxi on the way back , get ine with metered and most of them will try to ask for a fixed price which is much hifer than the regular one. Happy Visiting.

number one temple in bangkok. this is the best temple in bangkok. you can walk around and see mural paintings of finest thai art, statues of laotian origin and. chinese statues even if you would be there for weeks you couldn't see all of it.

Breath-taking. The temple is simply amazing, beautiful! One of the biggest and most beautiful temple in Thailand! Well worth the 500 baht for the entrance ticket.
I just don't understand why they put a small model of Cambodia's Angkor Wat inside the temple?

Nice sight. Apart from being inside the Grand Palace which I wasn't a fan of the Emerald Buddha made up for it as it was beautiful to see, depending on the time of year it will be a different Buddha and you can see the others in the musuem on site

Interesting visit. Interesting visit. The Buddha is pretty small and hiding way at the back so its a bit tricky to get a good look, if you want a picture you need to take it from the outside. Otherwise the general temple area is interesting & extravagant and always a big contrast to life outside the temple. Don't forget to follow the dress code.Plenty of touts selling stuff on the street to watch out for, usually everything they are selling is available elsewhere for much less so don't buy unless you really need to.
Busy. Hot. But incredible.. It was really busy when we went, but despite this it is just amazing. Such a sight and nothing like anything I have seen before. Definitely worth the visit.
Busy. Hot. But incredible.. It was really busy when we went, but despite this it is just amazing. Such a sight and nothing like anything I have seen before. Definitely worth the visit.

Beautiful Temple on the Outside. I loved the outside of this building and the surrounding temples on the palace grounds. However, to be perfectly honest I was a bit disappointed with the inside of the building. The Buddha is a teeny tiny little thing. There were so many people inside the temple trying to look at him, and that combined with the extreme heat made the experience was draining for me. Never the less, even if you only see the outside of the temple it is still worth visiting. Plus, the combination of the other beautiful temples in the complex makes it worth while. As a side note, my husband and I are Christians so perhaps that is why we did not enjoy the temple quite as much as others have. Other helpful information: -There is a fee to get inside the palace grounds, but no extra fees to see the temple. -Bring a bottle of water, or two! We were there in the middle of summer and became very dehydrated. The water outside the palace is over priced because everyone needs it so badly. -There are lots of steps everywhere you go with no wheel chair access. Be prepared for that if have problems with mobility.-This is not really a place for children. Although this a great place for looking at beautiful architecture, it is something small children would find boring.

Breathtaking. I got to the venue by BST and public water bus which proved cheap and extremely efficient (BST 35baht and Water Bus 40Baht single fare). A very short walk saw me to the entrance of the attraction. Crowds were ok and the recent downpour possibly helped in that respect. There are guides available who speak English but I preferred to simply find my own way, at my pace, and not join a tour. Whilst avoiding using a guide I might have missed out on interesting facts, what I came for could not be missed. The breathtaking spend our of Wat Phra Kaerw cannot be overstated (though that may be a personal opinion not shared by all).
