The attraction is only opened for entry until 3.30pm so don't leave it late in the day to visit or you may be disappointed in not seeing as much as you would have liked. Entrance for foreigners is 500baht but that get you full access. Expect to pay to "spend a penny" and also make sure that you dress respectfully or you simply will not be allowed entry. If you go early enough in the day on the water bus like I did it is also possible to take in Wat Arun which lies one stop down river on the opposite bank (free entry if I remember from my last visit).

Spectacular. One of those must-see things in Bangkok. The emerald Buddha is really a great sight, and something which should not be missed. No pictures of the Buddha itself are allowed, but if you have a good camera with a zoom, you can get a snap of it from quite far outside the temple. You must take a tour guide with you - and unfortunately be wary of pickpockets!

The heart and soul of Thailand. Wat Phra Kaew is located within the grounds of the Grand Palace. If you are a non-Asian foreigner, you will most likely have to pay the entrance fee for the Grand in order to see Wat Phra Kaew (if you are Asian, you may be able to slip into the Palace and Wat Phra Kaew without paying the entrance fee, even if you are not Buudhist, although this is becoming more and more difficult). A complete visit of the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew is certainly highly recommended for all visitors to Thailand.Wat Phra Kaew can be a very serene and peaceful place. But it's definitely best to visit at non-peak hours (avoid from mid-morning till early afternoon) to avoid the tourist mobs and noise. The emerald Buddha itself (the source of all the hype around Wat Phra Kaew) is somewhat under-whelming in my opinion. But it still should be a part of every visitor's itinerary.Please be courteous, quiet and respectful when visiting the temple. It is meant to be a place of serious prayer, worship and solitude.

An Amazing Temple Complex. The temple complex at Way Phra Kaew is extensive and amazing. You are not allowed to take pictures of the Emerald Buddha while inside the building, so many people line up outside to shoot photos through the doors. But the Buddha itself is small, and you're better off going inside and absorbing the essence of the temple than languishing outside in the crowds. Hint: we met one American who was denied admission for immodest dress. She had a sleeveless shirt, and thought that covering her shoulders with a shawl would be acceptable. It was not. She had to rent a blouse. Bring your own instead. And definitely long trousers for me.
Very very special. One of the best temple I have visited. Very very special and to know the significant of it is even more special. Must Visit!

the king of siam , says it all really. this place is home to the most famous and most loved king in the world , if your in bangkok you have got to visit this palace . go and see the emerald buddha with his soild gold coat

Intriguing Jade Buddha.. Having visited both of pagoda, personally I felt that this pagoda had better design than Reclining Buddha. The atmosphere felt more solemn, and the exterior was decorated with beautiful jade. Moreover, it was not only the Jade Buddha was beautiful but the buildings around here were also worth seeing.
Must see. There are lots of beautifully decorated buildings and statues. You will need a half day to see it all.

Green Jade buddha. The temple/pagoda is gorgeous with intricate designs. The exterior is really very well decorated with lot of detail. Initially it was thought emerald, but later confirmed as jade is located within royal palace complex. Kindly respect the temple by maintaining silence, as it is a place of worship. It is very unpleasant to see some tourists making loud noise, screaming, yelling and laughing making jokes inside the temple. Note that there are scams all around the temple and royal palace complex saying the temple, palace is closed. Do not listen to anyone including your taxi/ tuk tuk driver. Thus there are announcements made through speakers about the palace and pagoda hours all the time. You can also fill drinking water through tap as it is safe to drink.

Best of the temples!. I found the experience here the best (comparison to the other temples tourists visit)The atmosphere in the building hosing the emerald buddha is very serene and holy despite there being so many people and tourists taking pictures (making it a bit commercial)
Very nice!!. Great to see the emerald buddha!! He's very beautiful and they change his outfits based on season! Recommend going with a guide as I think we got more out of it if we hadn't!
Interesting. Quite impressive! Definitely worth a visit and a guide to talk about the culture, history and religion.
Advice for unwary tourists. Yes the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is great to see BUT Be careful! If someone is coming to you on the street – 99% he is scum
Bloody hot!. Watch out for the dodgy taxi drivers and make sure you don't listen to any dodgy tour guides saying it's not open!.....it's open from 8:30am to 3:30pm!

Be smart and avoid the scam artists outside. The temple is impressive. It is financed by the government which explains a lot once you have gone in. There are con/scam artists that sit out in front of the gates. Some claim to be police or security. They will be happy to tell you that no shorts are allowed and you can pay them for a tour, and a boat tour, etc. Ignore them but be polite. Once you enter the temple, yes, you cannot wear shorts. If you made this transgression, you rent long baggy pants. In May, in the unforgiving heat, I was impressed at how much sweat my legs could produce.Recommendation: We stayed at the Doubletree Sukhomvit - you can leave the temple, walk 5 mins and catch the river taxi. i even had tine for a super cold beer. Take a 15 min awesome ride up a depressingly polluted river and catch the skytrain back to Sukhomvit.
amazingly beautiful. Withing the Grand Palace area you can find this breathtaking temple. Take some time to see all little details and enjoy the view.
Worth seeing. Hard to believe that this Buddha had been covered in render and then due to a crack and rain they discovered it had been made from one piece of jade.

Must visit while in bangkok. Things to consider :  Entry fee: 500 THB (only for tourists ) Clothing : No sleeveless tops & vests , No shorts / skirts above knee length No Exposed tattoo'sClothing available at a refundable deposit of 200 THB per piece of cloth.prefer to wear sandals or slip on shoes / chappals & dress properly will save time place is beyond words to express ... must see by self .

flaking plaster turning Emerald. this year my daughter ,me and her two friends went to Bangkok.very excited as the first place she said"Let's visit the Emerald Buddha".One of the most venerated sites in Thailand where people convene to pay respect to the Lord Buddha and His teachings is the Royal Monastery of the Emerald Buddha.the Emerald Buddha is in fact carved from a block of green jade.it was first discovered in 1434 in a stupa in Chiang Mai.At that time the image was covered with plaster and was thought to be an ordinary Buddha image.Later the Abbot who ahd found the image noticed that the plaster on the nose had flaked off,revealing the green stone underneath.thus the legend of the Emerald began.the Emerald Buddha is enshrined on a golden traditional Thai-style throne made of gilded-carved wood,known as a Busabok.The temple itself is housed in the Grand Palace for which read another review of mine titled THE Grand Palace.

Amazing. If only it wasn't as hot as it was when we visited but it was just amazing! This is the second time that I have been to the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and this time around, I got to see him in the clothing for the Rainy Season. I have previously been in the middle of summer and saw him in the Summer clothing. The whole experience is majestic and even though there were so many people there, just sitting in front of Buddha is very peaceful. A great place to visit for anyone coming to Bangkok!!

gorgeous monastary. Really stunning and intricate mosaic tiles cover the entire building. The emerald Buddha is called such because of its color and because those who first found it thought it was emerald though it is actually jade. The grounds and dependent buildings are also very beautiful and peaceful.

A very beautiful temple but organise yourself first. This is part of the Grand Palace complex but is sufficiently important to be reviewed separately. Both temple and Buddha image are exquisitely beautiful. Go to the museum first and you can see the seasonal changes of clothing for the emerald green jade Buddha image, all in fine gold work. You can also watch a very short film of the King in his younger days performing the change of clothing ceremony. You need to prepare yourself properly: as always in Thai temples, show respect - long trousers for men and no bare arms for ladies.. Read a good guide book and be prepared to be patient. Reading other reviews makes it clear there are issues some difficult days and on the day we went a 10 minute wait was needed as a group of dignitaries passed through. But they do seem to mange the numbers inside quite well. You can't take photos inside but there are numerous photo opportunities if you study the beautifully decorated exterior, for example, if you stand at the front door end and look down the side colonnade to the right. I was not aware that our guide paid any charge here other than the original Grand Palace entry charge. As I said, you need a bit of patience and it is also worth noting the obvious reverence of the locals. It is not only a question of what it looks like, you need to try to grasp what it means to people from that culture.

Wat Phra Kaew and the Grand Palace. First tip: dress appropriately. This means no sleeveless tops or revealing outfits, no trousers or skirts above the knee. My travel companion arrived there wearing long trousers, sleeveless top and a shawl as cover up, but she was still requested to 'cover' her shoulders. Clothes rental is available at the entrance for 200 baht. Save yourself from the hassle though. Also, I think it is best to wear sandals or slip ons, as there are places in the palace wherein you won't be allowed to enter unless you take off your shoes. Outside the temple, there will be cons who will approach tourists and travellers, saying that the temple will close earlier, and that he knows which entrance to go and will offer to guide you instead. Don't fall for this - they dress up like professionals and can pass for an accredited tourist guide. They will charge you more and will cheat you to go somewhere else.Entrance fee at the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew is 500 baht per person. It's usually very crowded. Once inside, prepare to be amazed with the structures and the intricate beauty of the temples. Don't miss to enter the temple of the Emerald Buddha. It's amazing.You also have the option to visit Queen Sirikit Museum. They have a separate entrance fee for this, but this is something that you should not miss while you're there at the Grand Palace. - Bring an umbrella or a hat, it can get very hot especially when you're visiting around 1:00pm to 2:00pm.- Take a bottle of water with you. The area is quite massive and the walk trip might exhaust you. It's good to be prepared, as some vendors outside the palace will try to charge you more than half the price of their bottled water.

Wow. Buddha is made of jade, not emerald. Still no clarification as to why it's the Emerald Buddha, and not the Jade Buddha. Could be the color. Anyhow, this is by far the most beautiful temple I visited. I literally almost fell to my knees in awe, when I entered. It is equally if not exponentially beautiful on the outside.
Grand Palace and Emerald Buddha. It took my breath away. Absolutely stunning. I also enjoy getting the tourist boat out to the nearest pier. But it really is an engaging, beautiful place.

They try to cheat you. I have been here 3 times now, and the local still try to cheat you to go to their comission based places. Dont believe anyone who want to try and help without you have asked them first. They are commission riders!
A memorable visit. The visit was adorable, I learned so much, not only the beauty of the temple but the culture of the people. I like everything a bout it
Nice history. I loved the architecture, the layout of the grounds. Since we visited many temples then I recommend to wear comfortable shoes. It is well worth the visit but wear conservative clothing.
breathtaking. a breath taking monument , makes you feel quite humble in the presence of such an iconic and beautiful religious idol

Temple tours. All the temples we visited were interesting but the emerald Buddha was slightly underwhelming. You will need a good eye to actually see it! Try to avoid early afternoon visits as it can be particularly busy and very hot and sticky. Make sure you cover up and respect the Thai culture.Be aware of the various scams that go on outside the temples with dodgy tour guides,tuk tuk tours after telling you the temple is closed etc. Just be on your guard and don't believe the first person who befriends you?

Great half day. You need to spend a good half day in this area as it part of the grand palace exhibition. You get three tickets for three different exhibits, the grand palace, the museum and the emerald Buddha, so take your time here and take lots of photos.

Smaller than expected. My partner has been here before & even she was confused at what we had just seen. The Buddha is only about 2ft tall & is changed dependant upon season in Thailand (Thailand only has 3 seasons). When we went in we didn't initially notice the little green Buddha sitting on top. It was not until we went into one of the museums the we saw the other 2 behind the cabinet so we knew what to look for. This is within the Grand Palace so you do have to pay for the palace but free once inside.

A special experience!. This was the first temple that we visited in Bangkok and it was a special experience. The Emerald Buddha is impressive but do take the time to walk around the whole complex. It is very peaceful.

Surprised at its size. Saw the emerald (jade) Buddha yesterday and was naturally expecting it to be huge give the grand building in which it resides, in fact the Buddha is very small, surprising given is within the royal's grand palace. Was hard to spot at first as amongst all this ornamentation and he is atop, but a little green Buddha sits atop it all wearing one of three outfits depending on which season it is. Worth a visit.
Really interesting. A must-see location in Bangkok and well worth spending time here. Recommend going with a knowledgable tour operator.
quite disappointing as the statue is in jade and not emerald. The statue is in jade very small and disappointing. We expect one in emerald but it is in Jade and they continue to call Emerald

Nice spot to visit Thai cultural heritage. I would compare the emerald buddhe to the "maneken pis" in brussels. very weel known, but small and easily missed.
However, a nice place to visit, since it is located in something like a complex of temples.
It can be a very crowded place

Amazing and well ornamented interior. I was able to take a picture inside because no other devotees were there
You have to leave your footwear outside.
I was amazed of the ornamentation inside. Some gold clad decors and columns.
A typical oriental architecture, particularly Thai. So beautiful!!!

Majestic. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha looks beautiful from inside. No photographs allowed. Visitors are expected to maintain silence as many people are actually praying. The Buddha sits on a nigh pedestal and is made of Jade. Within the premises of the Grand Palace.
beautiful. Must to see when you are in Bangkok, this temple is really beautiful, enjoy and discover Buddhist Thai culture

Small Buddha. The ticket comprises the entry to 3 different building, the Grand Palace and this temple, and 2 museums. Have to visit the other museums to understand the importance of the Emerald Buddha and to appreciate its beauty

Great Story, Small Buddha. Worth seeing, but if you are expecting something grandiose you will be disappointed. First, the Buddha is not actually Emerald as the name implies, it is out of Jade. This does not make it less beautiful. But it is very small, and far away. You can't take pictures inside. The story of this Temple and how the Buddha moved to Bangkok is very interesting, and it's also very nice they cover the Buddha during their "winter" time.

Wat Phra Kaew. I was expecting some thing more spacious and huge, but it wasn't as good as I expected. It seemed very nice and thought that must have taken much effort to build it but it didn't amaze me as much as I expected.
Worth Seeing. Not the largest or most impressive Buddha in Bangkok by any means but an interesting story and a very peace Wat to visit.

It's actually jade.... The significance of this temple might be lost to non-Buddhists but the architectural design is grand and elegant,with intricate inlaid mosaic pillars and a gilded altar. The iconic Buddha is merely 2 feet tall carved out of jade ( emerald refers to the color). This is the most sacred of Buddhist temples (similar to Mecca) and for that reason alone, is a must-see in Bangkok. It is best to see this in the early morning to avoid the punishing heat and the throng of tourists who come later in the day.
Amazing. Really liked this bit of my visit to Bangkok. The little fella really makes you think. Would go back again and again.

Too crowded. As part of the Grand Palace visit this is acceptable. Otherwise this temple is too crowded to be enjoyed. With all due respect to the Buddha the statue is difficult to view because of the size (small).

Worth seeing. As a group of four we picked up a guide inside the gates (no scam involved) and found this a great way to go. The temple and palace grounds are extensive and she took us to key points, shared her knowledge and was our personal photographer! She kept us moving along on a hot day and found us shady, breezy spots just when we needed it. After the temple and the palace, she left us and suggested we wander through the Queens textile museum, the air conditioned comfort was a welcome relief but the museum was also well worth a look! Loved it all

Don't listen to people outside !. More than likely you will get approached by local men, tut tut & taxi drivers telling you that temple is closed or that people are praying , talking you into going somewhere else , getting a boat . DO NOT LISTEN TO THEM - even if they say they work there . One man told us he was security but when i asked to see his badge he backed away . People will also approach you telling you to buy clothing to cover up , don't buy . There are 3 different entrances but only one main entrance you need to get too - clothing is provided once your inside the gates . its such a shame how many people we saw get conned . A beautiful place once in , must see !! A tour guide would be advisable there are plenty inside the gates - 250baht per person, A general rule of thumb if someone approaches you to say either they're closed or you need to cover up you/ buy clothes you are at the wrong entrance, keep walking around until you see the main gates and where lots of people are walking in.

Very nice within the complex. hard to miss if you are in the complexes but its worth it. The history is interesting and observing it is unique. Always enjoy the temples of thailand even among the crowds it will relax your mind.

Beautiful!. Although it was smaller than I expected, it compensates in beauty. The Emerald Buddha (which is actually made of Jade) is just beautiful. The temple is just full of art and history, totally worth the visit. Cons: As in every temple in Thailand you need to dress discreetly and wear long pants/skirt and no sleeveless shirts or cleavage. It is REALLY hot, so be prepared with an umbrella, water, fan, etc. It is also crowded so make sure to get there early!

It's smaller than expected!. The Wat Phra Kaew is within the Grand Palace grounds and houses the Emerald Buddha. The Emeral Buddha looks to be abou 8-10 inches tall, which I suppose, is big for an Emerald, but smaller than I had imagined. Fortunately there is much of beauty within the palace walls and you will find the price of admission worthwhile. Try to visit early in the day before the relentless sun and crowds reach their peak. Nearby, there were a group of people chanting opposite the entrance to the Hor Monthien Dharam... We took a moment to sit in the shade and reflect upon their prayers. This was perhaps more poignant than the Emerald Buddha. In contrast, the Reclining Buddha was bigger than expected and also worth a visit. It's not far at all from the Grand Palace.

interesting. This houses the most sacred Buddha image in Thailand. A small image of green stone, 75cm high. It is known for it's multi-chrome, gilded pavilions, stupas with glittering spires and fanciful mythical figures. Proper dress should be observed. No short pants, singlets, spaghetti straps or sandals with no backs.

A royal treasure to see. This is just one of those places you have to see when your in Bangkok.It is super super busy though remember that. Watch out for all the people outside trying to scam you by telling you the palace is closed or they are having lunch...blah blah....ignore them and walk into the gates.Make sure you are dressed right though. No shorts or tank tops. If you do forget though you can line up and rent clothing for a deposit.The temple itself is so amazing. The colours and design are so beautiful. It was well worth standing in line in the hot sun. Once you've seen the temple you can spend the rest of your time visiting the grounds which are super huge. Make sure you wear some comfy shoes and drink lots of water since there is no shade to get a break from the sun.

Signature of visiting. This temple has a lot of strict rules to follow such as you can't wear tank-top, sandals, shorts when visiting this temple. Then please prepare yourself to wear something polite before visiting.It is the signature of visiting Bangkok so there's no doubt that you would find so so so many tourists from everywhere in this world here.The wall painting around the temple is unique and beautiful. The maintenance team works very well because the old of the paints on the wall. There's some fee for expat but free for Thai. There is a separated line for Thai people. Please do not try to sneak in since all the officers notice.The Grand Palace is connected to this temple so you don't have to pay it twice to visit. There is an arrow sign to show how to walk to the Grand Palace.

Royal treasure. The emarald buddha is housed in a beautiful temple within the Grand Palace. It's a Thai royal treasure. Worth a visit to learn more about the royal Thai history. No photography is allowed in this temple.
Nice Experience. Nice temple to visit for a day of relaxion and to do something spiritual in Bangkok. I saw more exting temples in Thailand, in Ching mai and Petchabun.Worth a visit

Very busy but it. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is in the royal place complex which is 2 minutes walk from the river. Please be respectful and wear appropriate clothing as you are visiting a Buddhist temple. When you enter you get to chose which of several museums to visit. If you go to the see the crown jewels you can also see the emerald Buddha's pure gold clothing. He has three sets so two will be on display and he will be wearing one. The Royal complex is an absolutely amazing place! The temple is very colorful and there so much detail that one could easily spend a day marveling at all the statues, ornaments and artworks. When visiting the Buddha you need to remove your shoes and wait respectfully in the line. You can purchase offering there if you want to make a Buddhist offering. This place is a must, if you're in Bangkok. Don't forget your camera and take your time. It's really a place worth exploring and take in the atmosphere. Even after seeing many beautiful temples it's still one of my favorites in the country. There is a coffee souvenir shop if you can find it, it has some very cheap good quality book on the place and temple.
Small Buddha actually of Jade. Worth a look for sure! What a beautiful Temple. Fascinating the custom of the King dressing this Buddha for the season. We really enjoyed visiting this Temple.
really good to see. keep your eyes peeled for the emerald buddha and check out the coin museum to see the different buddha's for the different seasons.
Been a good moment!. I like this temple it is because the designed it can be consider one of the spectacular temple i ever seen!Over Good!
The Kings personal Temple. The Emerald Buddha is small in comparison to other surrounding buddha's but the temple is breath taking and it feels to quiet and peaceful. A wonderful place to visit.

Breathtaking. Absolutely amazing place! The temple is very colorful and there so many details that one could easily spend a day marvelling at all the statues, ornaments and artworks. This is a must, if you're in Bangkok. Don't forget your camera and take your time. It's really a place worth to explore and take in the atmosphere. Even after seeing many beautiful temples it's still one of my favourites in the country.

amazing. just to stroll around this temple gives a feeling of peace & reverence,the upkeep & care taken with the gardens is beautifull to see,the sheer size & extent of the grounds takes a whole day to wander & take so many photos,if the history & artistry of the temple left me in awe of the beauty,& the work being done to recreate the very old paintings is really something to see,restoring the past bringing it back to its former beauty.

A must in Bangkok. Is a beautiful place.... Take your time to walk And enjoy...
Don't forget to dress modesto y, coger your Inés And shoulders , in That way you don't have to buy a tshirt o a long skirt in order to acces to the temple...
A must see when in Bangkok.. Amazing! Don't miss this when you are in Bangkok. Make sure you have a camera. Can be hot so bring some water and a hat.

Absolutely Amazing. The top attraction in Bangkok. It is peaceful despite the number of people. The building and the surrounding ones have amazing architectures, and murals. On the inside, the idol of Buddha as well as the throne it is placed on is very beautiful. Definitely recommend a visit.

Definitely See this. Its magnificents.
Great murals along the walls depicting stories from the ancient scriptures.
It's the "temple in the palace" where royal ceremonies are held.
That's why it's also called the Grand Palace Temple.

Simply Stunning. Visited here as part of the grand palace Tour.
loved all of this,Simply stunning,go and see for yourself how stunning this place is.

Beautiful, but the Buddha a little underwhelming.... Really lovely and obviously a very holy place for Buddhists, but after all the hype, I don't know why but I was expecting the Buddha to be bigger (MUCH smaller than expected)...worth a trip, just don't spend ages here....

A little Overrated. I guess it's partially my fault because I didn't do enough research but I was expecting a GRAND Buddha, since the Emerald Buddha is in the Grand Palace. It is beautiful, but very very small. And it's on top of a 60+ foot shrine, so it's very hard to see.
magic. i was very pleased i went to see it , it is a world famous temple witha massive buddha , a very important temple for buddhists .

Beautiful. This temple is right next to the Grand Palace. I wasn't able to take photographs inside of the Emerald Buddha, which is actually made out of jade. The intricacy of the temple is first class. This is another must see when in Bangkok.

BEAUTIFUL. Loved it. Magical experience.
The day was beautiful, sunny but not too hot to be outside. We visited every corner of this temple and definitely it is a experience to go for.

Wonderful temple and don't miss the side hall. Wat Phra Kaew was very beautiful not only because of the Emerald Buddha but the frescos in the temple on the wall were also gorgeous and interesting. It also has a sanctuary of turtles and a side hall with some interesting relics, antiques and surprising preserved animals..don't miss it.

'a Buddhist master piece and a symbol of Siam nationhood. Situate inside the ground of the Grand Palace, Wat Phra Kaew is one of the sights in Bangkok that you should visit. Wat Phra Kaew or the temple of the Holy Jewel Image houses the venerate Emerald Buddha. The image, carved from a large solid piece of green jade and brought from Vientiane by King Rama I in 1778, became the symbol of Siam (Thailand) nationhood.I live in Bangkok and I visited the Grand Palace and the Buddha's chapel at least four times and each time I discover something new. For your first visit you should take a good book guide or a tour and take the boat at the pier of Saphan Taksin.

Emerald Buddha. fantastic place to visit, cannot take photo's inside temple, so please don't try outside there are a few books you can buy cost about 20bht + so not expensive, please dress correctly skin must be covered, TShirts are ok

Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Most people mention this temple when discussing Bangkok. It is fascinating, as it is a very small statue when you see it. I expected it to be much bigger. It is carved from a single piece of JADE, so it is emerald in colour. It is in the Grand Palace 'complex'. It is nice to note that locals do not have to pay entry to see their own sights.

Simply Beautiful!. The experience here is just like the one I had in the Sistine Chapel in Rome. It was very nice. Quiet. Just being there and appreciating the beauty of the works of the buddha images and murals itself was amazing.

Beautiful. Inside the Grand Palace this is Thailand's most valued temple. The Buddha statue dates from the 14th century. Once again you will have to cover bare arms and legs and take off shoes in order to enter the temple. But it's worth it! So ornate and truly magnificent.

for the first timers in bangkok. definitely a must-see when in bangkok for the first time. this is a national treasure of thailand. the wat complex has more to offer aside from the tepmple of the emerald buddha, good place to explore. be wary of strangers approaching you, though.

You' ll love it!. The visit is really impressive. Beautiful buildings, beautiful buddha's.And on top of that you are dressed up ( pants for men, shirts for woman) which adds a nice flavour to your pictures.

Another Must See. So many wonderful sights in BKK but Emerald Buddha should not be missed. Shoes off and arms covered as required by many temples. We used private guide which helped us learn more than we would have had we gone on our own.
hard to get the perspective. along with loads of other tourists i filed through - and whilst it's hard to get the perspetive of something so large from close quarters, it's pretty impressive still
Tiny Buddha. Check out the Crown Jewels building first to see the intricate clothing up close... the King must dress the jade Buddha himself 3 times each year.

Good but a little on the smaller size to appreciate. As most other reviews indicate, this is a must visit temple and the most important for Thais as they must journey here at least once in a lifetime.
Because it is relatively small and surrounded by such big structure, it's a bit hard to see/appreciate. Wish there was a way to see it a little more up close.

Beautiful and amazing. Peaceful, amazing, beautiful, this place will amaze your senses, physical and also spiritual.
A must do visit which you will remember all your life.
bai. A famous ancient temple , just stunning , the emerald buddha is amazing , we felt very moved by the visit , reccommended

A must visit. Really enjoyed the scale and beauty of this palace. The jade buddha itself I actually overlooked the first time I was in the room, as everything around it is so opulent. The most bling place I've been in Asia.
amazing. this place is amazing, and worth to visit, Maybe this temple should in the list a must when in bangkok.

Royal Treatment. This Buddha is at first a little disappointing because it is small. But once you start to examine, you realise its spiritual power that holds your attention. This Buddha wears clothes that are changed each season. This can only be done by the King of Thailand. Just wish I could have been there when it happens. It is part of the Grand Palace, so don't miss it.
A must when in Bangkok. If you are in Bangkok for the first time this is the place you should start with. If you were in Bangkok and have not visited the Temple, you missed something very important.
Amazing sight!. You won't take any photos in here but the spectacle of the Emerald Buddha is definitely something to behold

Good. I liked it, as I liked all the other temples. The Emerald Buddha is the most important Buddha for Thais, it is beautiful but I think the Reclining is much more! The Wat Phra Kaew museum is very nice, also.

This temple must be at the top of the attractions. Beautiful, astonishing, amazing..... I loved this temple and all the architecture around it, including the Balcony.The Emerald Buddha is in a breathtaking environment. At the entrance you actually get 3 tickets,one to the Emerald Buddha and all the structure, including the Grand Palace, and two other tickets to two other museums.Be aware that men must wear long trousers and women must have legs and shoulders covered. Otherwise they lend the clothes to you and you need to return them on the way out, no fee.. Just a deposit.But there is a queue to get them.Leaving the place there is a small shop where you can buy water, or coconut or ice cream.

Beautiful to see. We were surprised by the small to medium size of this Emerald Buddha, but understood the importance of this ancient and long-lasting history of this very precious kind of stone. The temple is decorated with beautiful hand-crafted and colourful tiles. An awesome temple to visit and not to be missed because this is so much part of the Thai Buddism.
Absolutely amazing. What a fantastic experience, everything is covered in Gold leaf, the Budda is actually Jade, 2000 years old, the whole trip to the Grand Palace was awesome, highly recommended.

The Green Buddha. This temple keeps a wonderful and holy green Buddha. You mustn´t wait for an enormous statue like the Reclining Buddha in the Wat Pho Temple. This piece is a small Buddha made with jade (no emerald), but I´m sure you´ll like seeing it. Remember, you have to leave the shoes before going into any sacred place in Thailand and you can´t sit down with your legs towards the Buddha. It´s a lack of respect. I hope enjoy your visit!

Beautiful and intricate architecture. The temple is located within the premises of the Grand Palace. You need to take off your shoes before entering the temple. They have nice practice of cleansing hands with lotus flowers dipped in water. The temple itself is very beautiful with very intricate architecture. The Emerald Buddha statue is small statue situated on the top. Just sit there and enjoy the peaceful environment in temple premises. Note: Though photography in Grand Palace is allowed, you are not allowed to take pictures inside the temple.

Breathtaking! Come early. This place is a must, even though it is jam-packed with tourists and the entry fee is relatively high for Bangkok. The architecture, murals are very nice, the very detailed work on all the surfaces and the details are simply breathtaking. Do come early to take advantage of lower temperatures (there is little shade) and avoid the worst of the crowding.
A must see, but after a while temples look alike. Very ornate and beautiful, but similar to temple of reclining Buddha and Imperial Palace. Very crowded, esp on weekends. Becareful of pickpockets

Go for stunning architecture!. Located in the compound of Grand Palace, Wat Phra Kaew is one of the most revered temple in Bangkok. The Grand Palace has got some really stunning structures that will leave you spellbound. However, the tickets is slightly expensive (THB 500/person) but this is must go place for every tourist to see top landmark of Bangkok.Tips- Shorts/sleeveless tees strictly not allowed - Entrance Fee of THB 500- Beverages available on payment- Do carry passport/credit card to rent audio device- Reach early as the place get crowded by afternoon

Impressive, difficult at hot day . We are a family of 5 (16,13,8) and spent ~ 1-2 hours at the palace.Pros:- Very impressive- Beautiful- Well organized- You can loan long trousers on siteCons:- Very crowded- Very difficult to enjoy at hot dayRecommendations:- Bring a lot of water- Come early- Bring hats and umbrella's- Dress with long and decent trousers as well as decent T-shirtsMake sure to visit the textile museum, recommended

Don't blink. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is one of the most beautiful things I've ever seen. I would highly recommend going with a guide though as my first trip through I actually missed the Emerald Buddha as I thought I was looking for something much larger.
Very good, very big. The place is massive and crowded. its beautiful. lots of blings. lots to take photos of. You have to walk a lot to get to The Emerald Buddha.
Fantastic trip. Amazing experience! Wear good shoes lots of walking. Better to have a tour guide who is update on the history of the grand palace.

Stunning, a must see when in Bangkok. Even at a staggering 500THB per person, the money is well spent for a few hours of gazing at the plethora of ornaments, paintings and statues. I had to get a pair of rental pants from the counter, which went fairly smoothly all in all. 200thb per piece - you get it back when you return it.Bring plenty of water (and maybe food), there is only one place just outside the palace and they don't have a lot on offer.

Real emrald. Real emrald big buddha statue,Some history says it has been taken from India,Worship by king in certain ocassion,Temple is well maintained and must see place.Taking pic from inside temple not allowed but kust pick up a high lemse camera and take it from outside.

Very Rich History and Beautiful Buildings. I booked a tour online where they include hotel pick up and drop off with a guide. She took us through the hotel Grand Palace and to see the Emerald Buddha. The colours on all of the statues and buildings are incredible. The people that built it really took time on the little things and it shows.
Historical must. This is a must to see in Bangkok! You can't take a picture of it in the Wat but you can outside the Wat.

You can find calmness here. It's the most sacred place in Thailand. So please go there with proper respect. Taking picture is not permitted within the temple. But you can carry cameras as long as they are switched off.To enter into this temple first you have to enter The Grand Palace with a ticket costing 500 Baht. No additional ticket is needed for the temple. The temple is very gorgeous inside and outside. The Emerald Buddha is a dark green statue carved from a single Jade stone. It's dark green. Very beautiful. And the base of the Buddha is also gorgeous. You need to dressed properly to enter into the temple. No shoulder open dress, no see through dress will be allowed. Full pants are required. If you are dressed improperly you need to rent dressed from the gate on very high cost.Be careful of frauds, waiting outside the gate of The Grand Palace, to confuse you. They may say to you that the palace is closed now let's see another attraction first. But don't believe them. Just enter the Palace and ask the proper authority for the information.For more information you may visit: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wat_Phra_Kaew

Golden Temple. Fantastic temple, for local thai like me its free and for foreigners there is entrance fee. The emerald Buddha is beautiful and i got to see the summer Buddha which is the most expensive and bejeweled. There is a strict dress code for the temple and adjoining palace both men and women must wear long pants and covered shoulders. Clothes can be hired but save yourself the hassle and the line up by being prepared. Make sure to visit the textile museum with all the queens’ outfits and a nice museum to wonder around with the added benefit of air con after all that walking in the heat.
Lovely temple. This temple is lovely and has great history to it. There are lots of people selling you things around the temple but if you say no they respect that and leave you alone. Worth a trip

Emerald Buddha. Set in a Temple within the Grand Palace. You leave your shoes outside and sit on the floor inside. It is dimly lit and the Emerald Buddha is set up high and draped in a robe. It is a small statue but sacred here. You are there 5 minutes at most. If you are already in the Grand Palace it is worth seeing.

Worth the trip. This place is wild! Make sure to wear proper clothing as you will have to rent clothing when you get into the palace which is amazing and beautiful! There are a ton of crowds but be patient and enjoy the architecture as it's breath taking.

emerald in name only. It is actually jade, but this temple is the most sacred in Thailland. Compared to the scale and the obvious opulence of the Grand Palace, the Emerald Buddha seems understated and serene. It comes as a pleasant surprise, and it really does encourage contemplation and reflection.

Wonderful palace ... rich in culture. This palace is very rich in culture. Its best when you have a guide to walk you through the various parts of the palace. The emerald Buddha is stunning. Walk to the main entrance. Dont listen to the people outside.The Buddha shrine just glitters and the outfits of the Buddha are beautiful. It changes with the season. If you are in summer, get the postcards. The place is slightly crowded though.

Fab. A must do when in Bangkok. Be wary of local people outside telling you the temple is "closed until 1pm" or similar- this is a scam to get money out of you. Don't listen and walk to the main entrance!

quite unique ..well worth a visit. i revisited the Grand Palace and the Temple of the Emerald Buddha .. after first visiting 40 years ago and i am so happy that i did ..it really is absolutely unique .. such a beautiful place and one of the great sights of the world ...
Lovely place well worth seeing. I would say it is well worth seeing much better than seeing the reclining Buddha. But that is only my option. But this also was quite busy

It is not emerald !! It´s jade !!. If you expect a large emerald Buddha, forget it ! Besides being made of jade, the statue is small in a sensational shrine and they change his clothes ( always in pure gold...) depending on the season !!
Always a different costume, beautiful temple. You should definitely go see him, the most beautiful outfit is his winter costume, but if you're there in summer, just buy a post card of it :)
Amazing. Ask for the tour guide at the main entrance, this costs a bit more but was really worth it to get the history and have things pointed out.
A must see. You aren't allowed to take photos inside but it is an amazing sight to see. Just the pictures all across the hall and the buddha itself on top of its party is worth seeing

Beautiful architecture. This was so much more than just the emeral Buddha- to me it was more about the whole complex-- the statues, the structures, the foliage... It's all so picturesque.The Buddha itself is also really amazing, and if you can get up close, there's a lot to appreciate... But be warned, there are no pictures inside that particular structure. You can get a photo of this Buddha standing outside, but you'll need a decent zoom lens.The whole place is popular and can get crowded; the emerald Buddha draws the biggest crowd. Worth it.

Must see while in Bangkok.... The Buddha and this temple complex is THE place to see in Bangkok.I can understand that the actual statue is quite small but it represents alot for the Thais.Obviously the whole complex must be visited.Strict dress code!
Must-go for Art Lovers. Eminence of the main Buddhist temple, Wall paintings, architectural layout etc. are quite interesting to watch
Interesting!. The tample is amazing. Very impressive. Take in concideration that sholders have to be covered. Men with no short pants.

Its ok. Nothing to shout about taught we should see it as we had some free time in the day and it was a highlight on my map, just another Buddha in different composition, perhaps that's just my ignorant opinion
Beautiful. The whole place is stunning and full of colour and beautiful decor. We joined a tour which was helpful. We walked here from the Khao san road.. You need to spend at least 4 hours here.
No inside pictures. Emerald Buddha was very impressive (like most other Buddha statues), however you can only get pictures of this Buddha from outside the building.

Another commercialise temple. Another temple that way too commercialise like Wat Pho but the beauty of this place is the history, please rent the audio guide to learn more about the beautiful thai history. I wish it was is printed on plagues for us to read.
Awesome. If your at the Grand Palace why not swing in! Cool place to check out, doesn't take to long to walk around but certainly worth a look!

Spectacular. The beauty and craftsmenship of this Temple are a challenge to your senses. I was moved, excited and charmed by it all at the same time . I am so glad we had a guide with us so that we learnt a lot about the history of the Temple but he also then left us to explore at our leisure. Defineately a highlight of our trip

A crowded shrine. The highlight, I think, in my visit to the Grand Palace compound in Bangkok. A cute Budda statue high up surrounded by a massive conglomerate of guards (statues) and an impressive mixture of so many small details that it takes quite a while to take it all in. I suggest to sit down on the floor, even if you are not a Buddhist or believer of anything, to enable you to explore all the small details, and there is all the time more and more. An uplifting experience and a visit is 'obligatory' so if you do nothing else in Bangkok, I recommend a visit to Wat Phra Kaew, and look for the green on Buddha statue in the sea of all gold.
Must see. The complex that houses the temple of emerald buddha is beautiful and the story of the image amazing. Do visit to see one of the Bangkok's best maintained and most beautiful temples.

Beautiful golden temple. Fantastic temple, worth the entrance fee (500 baht) in my opinion. Thais go free I think which is understandable. We managed to get on a free tour with Ken at the entrance who was brilliant very informative and funny. The emerald Buddha is beautiful and we got to see the summer Buddha which is the most expensive and bejewelled. There is a strict dress code for the temple and adjoining palace both men and women must wear long pants and covered shoulders (a shawl is not good enough must be a shirt or t shirt ect). These can be hired but save yourself the hassle and the line up by being prepared. Make sure to visit the textile museum with all the queens outfits it's included in your ticket and a nice museum to wonder around with the added benefit of air con after all that walking in the heat.

Magnificent Architectural and Gorgeous Buildings.. I am combine my review of Emerald and Grand Palace together simply because there are in the same compound. This is the most famous place that is a must visit for Thailand trip for sure. It is a large compound located near Sanam Luang in the very heart of Bangkok. The Grand Palace and the Temple of the Emerald Buddha are Magnificent with several buildings in different styles of architecture with gold accented and attention to every details with used of jewels that sparkles everywhere you looked. There are so elegant and gorgeous buildings.The grounds also are covered with interesting sculpture of animals in mythology that are very beautiful and well maintained. Inside the Emerald Temple is unbelievable beautiful, there are extensive mural paintings depicting scenes from the famous epic "Ramayana". It is the longest wall painting in the Thailand. In the center and up high is the most highly revered Buddha carved from a single block of find Jade which is pretty tiny that you won't be able to see any detail at all( NO picture taking and should respect that). Beside being such a tiny Buddha and sitting up high, he also cover in outfit and I believed they have a ceremony changing the outfit for the Emerald Buddha 4 times a year(Spring, Summer, Fall and Winter). Even that NO ONE can take pictures and this including Thais. A distinctive characteristic of this temple is that there are NO monks living in this temple like any other temples in Thailand.Emerald Temple is GORGEOUS Temple and the most important temple in Thailand. Visitors are requested to be dressed properly and appropriately upon entering the ground of the Grand Palace. And we tourist should totally respected that( I had read a lot of complaint about how hot it is to have to wear a certain cloths or shoe that expecting us to do. I think we need to learn to adopt to Thai culture when we come to Thailand period. If we are going to a Muslims Country which would definitely have more severe punishment, would you respect their cultures? So please stop complaining about the dress codes for Temples in Thailand, and show some respect for the place and people here.It opens at 8:30 am to 3:30 pm every single day. The early you come, the mostly likely you can get in without waiting in line and less crowded it is. There is wet frozen towel for you to buy and it helps for 30 BTH and it last for a couple hours. The fee to get in is 500 BTH but it worth it. NO other Temple is this beautiful. I love it and revisiting quite often with friends from all over the world.
Attention to detail great.. This is also a must see attraction when in Bangkok. It is amazing the number of jewels used. The attention to detail is amazing.

Fabulous, but crowded.. No photos allowed inside. No chairs available and you have to sit on the floor. If you are old and inflexible like me, it might be difficult to sit on the floor. DO NOT point your feet toward the Emerald Buddha like I did by mistake, the gendarmes will be on you like a fly on fly paper. Be prepared to stand in line unless you are at the main gate at 8:30 am to rush the ticket booth, then the Emerald Buddha Temple. Do this then look leisurely at all the other sites in the Grand Palace area. Gets really, really hot in the sun so be prepared with hat and sun block. Must cover arms/shoulders and legs.

Gilded. Everything is gilded and sparkles. The interiors of the main temple and the premises are bathed in elegance and semi precious stones and gold works. It is a beauty and truly worth visiting but just as with any other places you are expected to be modestly dressed and most importantly covered. Take time because you will need it at the place.
Emerald Buddah. Again, all bvery nice and I appreciate its a house of worship but this is a tourist attraction and there are too many restrictions i.e. photography etc.

Photos are not allowed!. Nothing extraordinary inside. Just a place full of gold! Or perhaps the exterior is too grand that it does not match the temples interior. Photos are not allowed also though you could try standing in one of the doors and have your photo taken from the outside with the buddha as your background. I was not able to do this though because of an old Chinese woman who kept shouting inside the temple. We were then asked by the guard to go outside the temple.
Beautiful Jade Buddha. This temple of Emerald Buddha is in the grounds of the Grand Palace. The Buddha statue is actually Jade and mistaken for Emerald originally and since the name.

Beautiful Temple. So beautiful in terms of decoration and well worth a visit. This is the one Buddha we were forbidden from taking photographs of. I understand it is Thailand's most sacred? As a woman I had to cover myself up- long trousers and cardigan and my partner had to wear long trousers.
Longest Buddha Statue. Don't forget to put 109 coins in the 109 pots while your visit and do visit the palm reader, its worth to know your past,present,future to make life easy

a symbol of Peace in the crowded city of Bangkok. This temple is really awsome. it has so much peace in it. while waking along the walls of temple you can see depection of Ramayana and Thai culture, the most important is the buddha sitting in the center of the temple. you can sit and meditate for hours in this temple. it restores the peace in you and makes one very calm. the enterence of temple one finds Hermit- the God of good health, one feels healthy at very site of this God. While there are other structures- Combodian style temple architecture and Srilanka type temple architecture, but i would recommend to spend more time in front of Emerald Buddha rather than taking photos of these architectures.go to this temple for praying to Hermit for good health and Buddha for good life- in my experience They listen.

If you're touring the cool wats, put this on your list. I'm a well-traveled American, but I don't have a deep knowledge of Buddhist culture or history so I'll admit that after having seen a few dozen wats they begin to blend together in my mind. Even so, I enjoyed seeing this wat and can remember this one clearly.
Mesmerising. So amazing worth the trip. Such a hot day plenty of big fans around ! Water was cheap to buy. Felt sorry for the guards standing still. In the heat.
Actually Jade. The temple complex is everything you can imagine about Thailand. Bring your camera though photos are not allowed inside the temple.

Beautiful, Fascinating, Interesting. Absolutely wonderful. I went with my family. we hired a guide from the entrance - who was fantastic! I would recommend having a guide - without one it would seem a bit like a boring, glistening museum. Whilst we were there, the monks started prayer which was a lovely thing to watch and hear. The temple was just so unbelievably beautiful, and very touching for us as a family to have done together. My younger brother and sister got more bored as it went on, so I would say it probably isn't for kids under the age of 14, (although they loved the massage school, which is a MUST DO).
Good Experience. I decide to visit this temple for a day of spirituality. It was a good choice and i loved the experience. The history behind is amazing, get a tour guide with you.

A must visit place. The different designs of the buildings inside the palace walls were by far the best seen in four months of travel. The paintings and murals which line the walls in the walkways are fascinating and could be studied for months and you would still find something different when you looked again. Listen to the announcements about dress and touts before you visit, best to cover arms and legs then you will be all sorted. The Emerald Buddha was ok but the buildings and paintings did it for me.
Beautiful Buddha. So much gold in its architecture! You could see it glisten and glitter when the sun beamed. The temple was beautiful.

Must see. Definitely a must see. I have seen better temples around Thailand but this Temple is iconic and is a must for your trip. I also find the entrance fee to be overpriced at about 500 baht per person. But the architecture of the temple is worth you seeing.

Worth the Stop. Not to be gauche, but the emerald Buddha was not enormous. I guess we expected something more startling given some of the other temples visited the same day. But the temple was lovely and it was definitely worth the stop.

Out of the world Buddha Temple. Its just amazing temple of Buddha. The history behind it also amazing. Temple and statue is very spiritual and peaceful. This is one of the must visit temple in Bangkok.
Very interesting. It's one of BKK's most expensive temples but it's undoubtedly worth it and will hardly break the bank. It's mind blowing how ornate everything is - definitely worth a visit.
A Possible Life Changer. Take the time to sit and meditate with The Buddha. Enjoy and absorb the fabulous atmosphere. You'll be glad you did!

It is really amazed!. If you really want to see Thai tradition and architecture you can not fail to visit this temple. This is a flawless work of art and have cultural values ​​critical . I was really suprise with beauty mystery of the sacred temples. If i have another chance i will be back here again to learn more about the culture and Thai people.
must go. i loved the place....very interesting and the beautiful display of budhas...lots of tourists....if you are interested in seeing landmarks...this is the place...

Beautiful temple. In fact, the Budda in side this temple is a Jade Budda, it was in Cambodia many centuries ago and was brought back to Thailand, kept first in the former capital Sokhothai, then brought to Bangkok and kept in this temple.
Great and must visit. If you want to see Thai tradition and architecture don't miss this. Intricate floral work, inspiration from indo-Sino architecture is really whaw !

Best wat ever. This wat stunned us as soon as we entered it. Colorful giant (16 ft. tall) yakshas (demons) immediately come into view as does the beautiful gold chedi (Phra Si Rattana). Because we got there when the wat had just opened, the guide there told us to go see the Emerald Buddha first because the temple housing it would get crowded quickly...we did so and it was very good advice. The Emerald Buddha is impressive but very small! Another beautiful building is the Mondop (library) - can't go inside but worth walking around the exterior. Next to it is a small reproduction of Angkor Wat, worth a look if you've seen the real thing or are going to see the real thing. And do not miss the beautiful wall paintings in the Ramakien Gallery. If you are short of time and can't visit both the Wat and the Grand Palace, I'd visit the wat or spend more time there. The Palace is pretty but not as interesting as the wat.

Scam day at the Temple. What a shame such a wonderful tourist attraction is tainted by a total lack of regulation of street scamsters! This is one of the world's great attractions, but yet we had a very ordinary experience which ruined what should have been a great day. From Sapphin Taksin station we walked to the river where we were conned into a river boat ride to the temple at 150 bht when we thought we were getting on the public ferry which is just 15 bht. Then had to pay a 50 bht "landing fee" to a beefed up tough guy on the dock at the temple end. From the dock we walked up the road and were ushered across to an entrance to the palace about 11am where we halted at a gate by an official looking guy and an apparent palace soldier in uniform and hold we could not enter. They said the Palace closed on Monday until 2pm and suggested we could fill the time by visiting a couple of local temples in a tuk tuk for 40 bht round trip. Also today we were sooo lucky because "this is the one week of the year when the wholesale export outlets are open to the public" so they would take us there for a look. Sadly we agreed not realising at first that this was a scam. The first temple actually wasn't too bad but at the second temple which was very ordinary we found ourselves in conversation with a tall thin young Asian man with good English and excellent knowledge of Australian culture who informed us that he was on his 7th trip from his home country of Singapore. He took the opportunity to also restate how lucky we were that this was a really good week to be checking out the export outlets. Our suspicions were immediately raised. We were then escorted around 3 or 4 export outlets with the highest pressure salespeople I've ever seen at Chinese and Indian trading houses where they pushed hard to get us to buy jewellery and suits. By 1pm we had had enough and asked to be taken back to the Palace, but our tuk tuk driver insisted on one last stop which was a travel agency. When the girl at the travel agency asked us where we would like to go she was quite shocked when I said we were not interested in booking anything and promptly escorted us to the door. When we finally returned to the Palace about 1.30 we were annoyed to find it had been open since 8:30. Needless to say - not impressed.We were picked up by a guide for a guided tour at the correct main gate. He claimed to be a retired Royal Guard. He seemed authentic and did give us an informative tour of the site, although our concerns were raised when near the end of the tour when he seemed quite happy to pass us back to a couple of high pressure people selling canal cruises at 1600 bht. Needless to say we passed on that idea and chose to find another way home. We would regard ourselves as quite experienced travellers and have never been so blatantly scammed anywhere else in the world. I hope this serves as a warning to other travellers to cultural sites in BKK.
Top temple. Should be on everybody's itenerary. Iconic Thai Temple, with a very special Buddha. And who wants to admit havn visited Bangkok without seeing this one?

I know... I'm not mainstream, but:. Do not go there. Entrance fee is absolutely ridiculous, 500B, even for kids. If they are less than 120 cm, which cannot happen with regular western kids of 6 and older. They force you to dress like a monk if you wear shorts or short sleeves, with pants and sarongs they lend you (another 500B deposit, but you get it back when out). I mean, this is crazy, my daughters had shorts to the knee, and shoulders covered. We're in BKK, come on, it's 38°C out there! All this for so-called buddhist thing. Well, monks are supposed, according to buddhism, to carry only vital items, nothing fancy, right? So why do they wander around with tablets, cell phones, and leather briefcases? I can't accept that an iPhone owner wearing an orange dress and no hair on skull forces my daughters to wear a thick dress from neck to toes by such temperatures.Anyways, back to the temple itself. Yep, that's interesting. Emerald Buddha can be seen only if you have a 400 mm lens at f/2 (in this case, you won't bother with the entrance fee!) or a good telescope. Tiny little thing on a very high pedestal. Temples you can't photograph, all red and gold. Packed with people. Unfriendly staff. Take your 2000 B you would have spent for family visit and get a nice book about emerald buddha and grand palace.And if you still want to go there: beware of all scammers out there, telling you the temple is closed, or any othe BS. All they say is untrue. And when back, walk for at least half a km before you can find honest taxi or tuktuk.

Great architecture. This is a great place to visit. The architecture is beautiful and the have beautiful wall paintings on the side when you go in. You can also take a lot of photographs here. However, be sure to get there early to avoid the crowd and bring along lots of water to rehydrate.

Fantastic. This is the best of all, if you have to see one temple see this, it's Grand and spectacular. Spend about 1to2 hours in such splendour fit for a King. Expensive entrance fee but well worth a visit. Excellent for photo too
Beautiful Place. A great temple, there's much to see but it's so crowded. Maybe next time I go there, I will go earlier. Cause in the afternoon it's so crowded and hot. Remember to bring water

Massive Tour. WOW.Second time I have been here.Make sure you get a good guide, makes the experience so much more worthwhile.The tour takes a good 2 house with so much to see and do.It can be very warm out in the open so wear a hat and bring something to fan yourself with. And plenty of water.
crowded. It is so crowded, go in early morning. Bring water or something. The Emerald Buddha is really small hehe and nooo photo
A must visit. A great temple to visit and learn about the history. Be sure to use a guide so you will get a full tour and all of the history.

Beautiful. The diamond statue is so beautiful. But it is so small that I cannot see. Otherwise, I was not allowed to go inside. So if you want to go insde but not want to pay money, you could find way to hide into the crowd so the guards cannot realize you haha
Check Events Schedule. When we went, there was an event happening so the area was roped off and we could only look from afar. seems amazing though

Not allowed in!. We went several times to visit this temple but were shooed away and told that only the local people may enter. We were directed around the corner to another entrance where a polite man explained it was because the king was there and we were not allowed (as non-Thai people) to enter. He proposed a boat cruise and found Tuk-tuks to transport us. We were told to come back later in the day which we did and had the same experience, except the taxi we hailed there wanted to force us to go to a gem shop so he could get stamps. He was most unpleasant and we exited his cab and found alternate transport. The day was very hot and somewhat frustrating. We didn't another opportunity to go to the temple.

Beautiful temple complex. Once you pass by those men in front of the entrance who try to pursue you that the complex is closed for lunch in order to sell you a pretty expensive tuk-tuk drive, you will pay 500 baht per person, and you are inside. For this price you get one bottle of water, and take it because there is no water to buy inside. You should wear long clothes because they won't let you in, and have a strong sun block. The whole complex is beautiful and it takes more than 3 hours to see everything and admire beautiful architecture. The price is low compared to some equally popular destinations and you get quite a lot for that amount. This is the only temple complex this expensive and it is a must when in Bangkok.
Wow. Wow I have seen this 8 times and I am always amazed. Bangkok has such beautiful things to see and explore, that's why I keep coming back and taking my family - its is beyond beauty.

Small but worthwhile. We were surprised how small the little buddha was especially in the scheme of the grand place. Sadly you can't really take photos inside so you will have to remember what it looked like. Interesting that the buddha is not made of emerald but of jade - emerald means green in color that is how it received its name. Go early before it gets to crowded and hot!

Overcrowed. It is so hot and crowed. It does not match the slow atmosphere of bangkok at all.It definitely does not deserve the 500 Baht. I would strongly recommend Wat Pho instead which is more quiet and beautiful.
stunning!. All the temples and buddhas in Thailand were wonderful, the workmanship and beauty are breathtaking and this was no different.

Everyone in Bangkok stops here at least once!. One of the must-see places when in Downtown Bangkok. It is often very crowded as it is popular with tour companies bringing through busloads of tourists. If you go on your own, you can take your time and just enjoy the grounds without being shuttled quickly from place to place.There are plenty of touts and scammers outside the grounds that will tell you things like that the place is closed (and have a better place for you to go). Don't bother with these people, just smile and go on to the main gates.
So much to say. Ornate and beautiful, the temple and its surroundings offer so much to see. Definitely worth the stop.

True Thai culture. If you go to Bangkok, the Grand Palace and Temple are a must-see. You'll get a real sense of Thai Buddhism here.It's not the easiest place to get to. If you're downtown, you have to take the MRT to the public ferry. There will be people at the ferry landing who will want to sell you a long-boat ride. The rides are fun, but if you just want to get to the Grand Palace, then ask at the public Information booth to make sure you're in the right place. The ferry costs 20 baht. When you get off the ferry, you'll walk through a market. Best to wait until you return to buy anything. Things are a little less expensive the further you get from the ferry. People will tell you that the palace and temple are closed or are opening late. Don't believe them--they want to sell you a tuk-tuk ride.Once you're at the temple, the buildings, murals, and statues are simply amazing.

Its huge and interesting. Lovely serene place, you have to take off your shoes and you can't point your feet up facing the emerald buddha.
A very nice place and a real great place to observe how this temple differs from others.

Worth see attraction. The temple is amazingly designed and decorated. It is also well managed.
I found bit difficult to get vegetarian food around the place. Rest all was awesome.
see night markets. great experience to travel like the locals and only had to go 2 stops to the night markets and restaurants
Popular, bit crowdy, worth see. Beautiful place, one of the most popular sights, good to be there, maybe as a part of a big tour for like 5-6 hours of main temples(that's what we made)

Unmatched grandeur. My favorite route to the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the Great Palace is to take BTS to Saphon Taksin. Then the Orange Flag taxi boat (only 15 baht) to Pier #9. For 500 baht you will receive entrance to both the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the Great Palace. The grounds are extraordinary. I took many pictures, but no photo could possible portray the grandeur of this temple. The Emerald Buddha itself it actually quite small and made of jade. I was more taken with the grounds and buildings. I highly recommend you see this temple with your own eyes!
Not so special at all. The best known Buddha in Thailand, but so small. Nice to see, but I wasn't that impressed. Maybe because of the disturbing heat and the fact that you need to cover up.

Amazing. Upon arriving this place gives you the wow factor! We could have walked around for much longer than we did but the heat got too much so make sure you take water! You also need to be covered up but if you forget there is a place inside the opening to hire clothes to wear. We were only there for 1hr 30 and feel we saw what the area had to offer which was good as it enabled us to do more with our day. A must see in Bangkok!!

If you are 1st time in BKK: this is where you go. Well, there is nothing to add here. It's the most magnificent temple in BKK. You should go there at least once, regardless of your purpose of visit to BKK. Try to attach yourself to a tour, so a guide can explain to you what is what!

The Entire Temple Compound is Gorgeous. The entire temple compound is truly gorgeous to see. Each building is unique and the history is fascinating. While the actual Emerald Buddha is much smaller than you might expect, it is still impressive. The entire room that houses the Buddha is magnificent. Do note that the Buddha is not made of emerald but of Jade.

Please respect the Emerald Buddah- don't take a photo. This is an important temple that is worth visitingwith all due respects (no spaghetti strap tops, shorts and excessively open cleavage clothing. The emerald buddah is amazing but you need to admire it and keep the memory in your hearts. Do not try and take pictures of it especially with flashes and all that - let it last for prosterity. It is beautiful.

A great visit. You pay 500 bhat for tickets to both the Emerald Buddha and the Grand Palace. It's the most expensive attraction in Bangkok, but there is really some stunning beauty around the entire complex. Spend an hour at least just walking through. Actually kind of funny how small the Emerald (apparently Jade?) Buddha is, but there is a unique story behind it. Be prepared for lots of tourists as this is probably the #1 attraction in Bangkok.
Great. Nice places. beutifull buildings.... It is nice to explore places like this. You can spend few hours for this complex. Again take some water. Places are hot and sunny.

Wow!. As I had read reviews earlier I was prepared for the actual size to be smaller than expected. A bit like seeing the Mona Lisa for the first time. That being said, the temple was breathtaking. Reading the history of the Emerald Buddha made it even more special and you can appreciate the detail in the beautiful temple even more. If you see nothing else in Bangkok you must go to the Grand Palace compound and see the Temple of the Emerald Buddha.
Great sight to see in Bangkok. Beware of the Scamers around the venue. The Grand Palace is not closed and you do not want to go to theirs friends Gem store...
Emerald Buddha. Quiet, smaller grounds. Beautiful. Its always nice to make a donation, they appreciate it, so come with a little extra baht in your pocket.

Amazing structure. Amazing complex of buildings, each one more beautiful and spectacular than the other. You definately need time to see and enjoy it. There's lots of gold going around in statues and even buildings. It is a must see when in Bangkok.

Could walk around for hours. Loved all the color and different parts of the palace etc., The opening and closing times are kind of difficult to plan around, so you should probably make this your first stop of the day.

Peaceful Ambience. Once I get inside the main praying room (indoor), I feel so peaceful somehow. It was forbidden to take photographs inside the main praying room, but allowed to take some photo-shot from outside. I zoom the lens and got the picture of Emerald Budha.It called emerald because the statue made from green jade. Local citizens and foreigners were allowed to stay inside the main praying room as long as they want. Some of them took a meditation time. Anothers are admiring the beautiful of its interior decoration.

Special day out. Maybe the most impressive part about this complex is the wall painting of the Ramakien (the Thai version of the Ramayana), most tourists wander aimlessly by but some of the parts of the mural are simply breathtaking and the area provides much appreciated shade. The tickets also gives you access to the Royal Palace, worth the visit and for those with a sense of fashion entrance to the brand new princess Sirikit museum of Textile. The shop of this museum is the place to be for the more upscale gifts but even on a low budget there are nice things to find. The ticket also gives you a pass to the Vivanmek Mansion, a wonderful teak palace a little more North in a lovely green area (you don't even have to do it on the same day, the ticket is valid for two days). Do remember to dress appropriately (no sleeveless shirts, no bermuda's, shorts or short skirts). All in all, worth every penny and an unforgettable experience

Wonderful Temple with history.... The Emerald buddha is the highlight of this temple, but I can't deny the temple itself is the most beautiful in every details.You will love this place.** Ladies, please wear proper costume when visit, pay respect by not wearing shorts or vast.

Wat Phra Kaew biggest temple in Bangkok. This can be visited at the same time as the Grand Palace and Wat Po as all three are very near to each other. This temple is the most famous and biggest attraction in Bangkok and no one, absolutley no one should miss this when visiting the city. It's completely covered in gold and coloured glass mosaic tiles and the bells that are just below the temple's roof chime in the wind to make this a magical place. Only Thai people get in free as this is a working temple where they can go to pray. This has many wonderful things including many Garudas that protect the temple from evil spirits. You may need a guide to understand all the many buildings and art treasures in this temple.

Beautiful. Located in the Grand Palace and beautiful to see. I have seen many Buddha's but never an Emerald Buddha and was not disappointed when i visited. Don't forget to cover up out of respect and allow for a few hours to take in all the sites.

Beautiful. Its mind blowing. This is a temple that is being used constantly, with services go on all around, and tourists and locals sitting down for a few minutes to soak up the atmosphere, its noisy, but peaceful at the same time. Well worth the visit just for the Buddha, and the story about its rediscovery.

Just good one time. After being in Thailand and Bkk so many times it's gets boring.Showing friends the temple.This is very good trip for the first time visitor. And don't forget to bring long pants and cover shoulder.If you forget the temple has for you to borrow. You need to leave a deposit and do not loose the receipt.
applaudable and historic.and.... When you walk in this place to enjoy the company ... so ... beautiful architecture, a historic place... I like it ....
Emerald Buddha. I loved this place. So serene with the hundreds of bells surrounding the temple tinkling in the breeze. Buddha itself is smaller that expected, but still amazing.

Beautiful! Photos do not do this place justice!. You could easily spend an entire day looking at the temple of the emerald buddha and the grand palace - Photos of the temple do not do it justice - it is beyond beautiful and amazing in person. It is a MUST SEE in Bangkok. We caught a boat up the river and got off at the pier closest to the temple, we had no trouble. Just be careful with your belongings around the piers and the markets that are often set up out the front.

A wonderful experience... The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is within the National Palace and is the only alive part of the Palace. This is not a museum or display. It's real and very important temple (church), The Emerald Budda is the holiest and most revered of religious objects in Thailand today. Go, take time to sit and pray, be respectful. It;s not likely your church, but it's a wonderful experience..
Must. The temple is beautiful. Although you can not see the Emerald Buddha closely (which is actually Jade), the place impresses with beauty. The mosaics are very rich and superb architecture.
A must-see. The highlight of the palace complex. It's extremely busy but keep pushing and get yourself a view of the beautiful Buddha.

So Unique and Beautiful!!. I really enjoyed visiting this place and noticed how the temples decorated with small glasses and gold. So unique, colorful and complicated design. I think it's worth it even though you have to pay 500 baht for the entrance ticket. Don't miss it!

Do not miss but, Beware of the guides.. This Temple was filled with beauty you could wander around and soak in. Be informed before you go and check that there aren't any ceremonies happening at the temple that day, that limit your time, as it will take you at least 3 to 4 hrs to get around at a leisurely pace.Entrance is 500 baht each.There is a strict dress code, but they cater to the unknowing tourist. You can buy some loose fitting pants at the main gate for 150Baht.There are no Free tours as there once was, so be ready to be inundated with requests for a personal guide, we did our own thing, with the help of Google, it took us a little longer but satisfying.

Nice contrast from city buildings. We used the public boat there which was a lot cheaper than the tourist boats and gave us great views of other temples located by the river. A scammer tried to tell us the palace was closed but yes smile and just carry on walking.they offer a complimentary group tour guide at certain times of day but after waiting half a hour after the allocated time we decided to discover it for ourselves.
