They do offer audio guides which I would recommend as I would have loved to have learnt more about the history. The palace is worth seeing, it's incredibly beautiful and well maintained. Cover up, you can rent clothes there but not most hygienic option. Or you could pay extortionate prices for a wrap at the markets nearby who naturally utilise on tourists who weren't in the know.

Free for Thai /500 THB for Foreigner. Admission Fee 500 THB for Foreigner; Thais is free for enter; A big temple coumpond with King's Rama9 Summer Palace; The inner green lawn yard section not allowed to see; The main ordination hall situated with Green Jaded Emerald Bhuddha while the corridor painting Ramayana stories line; The walkway only one way direction in; So try not too miss anything ;because you could not go back after 500 THB had paid!! Daytime must be very superb busy tourist crowded; Bring hat and put anti-sunburnt lotion on; as it might be 40 degree+ celcius in mid April month. Also warning: Beware fake stranger guide/Tuk tuk driver for jewelry scam.Suggestion:If need more peacefully visit with same Thai temple beauty and also free or low admission entrance; try other less famous temple such as "Temple of the dawn" "Wat Pho" "Wat Trimit" "Wat Benchamaborphit" "Wat Suthat" "wat Kanlayanimit" instead.

Just words cannot describe the feeling u get once u r inside the Temple, tears just kept flowing, love it very much.. pl be well dressed when u go to Temples, Everything is just so nice, the pagodas, the art and the chimes in that one particular temple, u just dont know from where the music is comming from. like I said earlier, the entry fee is just a little too much, but worth, do not miss it for anything, the whole area is worth paying for.
Smaller than i expected. The Emerald buddha is somewhat smaller than I had expected and is almost lost in amongst the alter decorations. I would like to have been able to get closer to it.

Worth visiting but watch the scammers loitering around outside. First the bad part - The moment you drop off from a taxi onto the walls of the temple and grand palace, you will lose your orientation and will not be able to recognise which is the main entrance. Locals get in free from all exits, but foreigners have to get a ticket from only one entrance. Anyone else that comes up to you, however friendly or with a "tourist guide" badge, or tells you that it is closed today for prayers and recommends elsewhere, is a scammer and you should just smile and walk away. That said, the entrance is basically near to a traffic light crossing where the opposite is a row of shops consisting of cafes, etc. There is a ticket booth there as well as a dress code where you have to borrow scarfs to cover up if you are not properly dressed. The interiors are amazingly well maintained, and the gilded gold images on the walls tell of the epic battles and legends from Ramayana. The Emerald Buddha is also a wonderful sight to visit, and the building that houses it is also intricately designed and constructed. This place is well worth the price to visit.

Excellent. Worth the trip. The architecture is amazing! Check out the details, you won't believe how spectacular they are! Don't forget to look up, or you will miss a lot. Go early before its too hot. Don't let the scam artists tell you that the temple is closed because the monks are praying and I will open later, unless you want to be taken for a ride. See the temple first, then, if you want, let them take you to the shops. They get free petrol, and maybe more, but who cares, you're on vacation. Go into the shops, look around, buy or not, it doesn't matter, you're not obligated. The Tuk-Tuk driver will take you back to the temple, you had some shopping fun (unless you are a guy, but you made your wife happy) and the driver makes out. Just don't let him charge you more than 50 baht, unless you feel bad, then give him whatever you want.
Must visit. A must to visit if it's your first trip to Bangkok! Spend some time with the Buddha for some quiet time.
Well worth a visit. A must see for first timers to Bangkok. The temple grounds are lovely to walk round also. Make sure to dress appropriately.

Worth every penny. Beautiful, clean, well-maintained site. Entry, including the clothes rental (both men and women must have knees and shoulders covered or they much rent shirts, pants, or sarongs, but the 200 BHT deposit is refunded if you return the clothes at the end of the visit) were very efficient, even though the staff wasn't friendly. Signage could have been better.

Beautiful. Wat Phra Kaew is part of the Grand Palace complex. This little temple is mesmirisingly beautiful in its architechture. The Emerald Buddha himself is quite small sitting atop all the finery in this temple. As with other temples, be prepared to dress modestly and take your shoes off. Another thing to note is that pictures are not allowed inside this temple. It is one of the few temples we visited that actually had people praying in it - most other temples only had tourists in them. A must-see while visiting the Grand Palace in Bangkok.
Part of the Grand Palace complex. The Emerald (Jade) Buddha is quite small and set up high in it's own temple, so it's hard to see any detail. No photos allowed inside.

Worth the visit. Worth visiting for tourists. Quite grand and one of the main temples in Bangkok to visit. You should remember to have clothing appropriate for temples including covering shoulders and no short shorts or skirts

Simply Amazing. By far the most grand temple we visited, the architecture is beautiful. As expected it is extremely busy but we still managed to spend a few hours walking around and saw everything we wanted to. If you visit Bangkok this temple is a must, especially if you are a Buddhist!

A must for anyone in Bangkok. As the title says a must if your in Bangkok. The whole experience is humbling and very moving, from siting in the temple next to the praying monks to the locals paying their respects to the tourists being amazed by the beauty all around. Everything here is absolutely fantastic and I'd go again and again. If your in Bangkok please go and see it, we went just before 3.30 and there wasn't too many people around.
Must see!. You can't come to Bangkok without making a visit to the green Buddha temple. Be sure to wear proper clothing or be dressed by the temple officer.

Inspiring. The workmanship is amazing. The buddha statue itself is magnificent although smaller than I had imagined. The atmosphere was very peaceful despite a fair few fellow tourists. What I did not like was the tourists taking pictures despite signs asking them not to.

Wat Phra Kaew. The Grand Palace grounds contain this Wat. Be prepared to rent long pants and/or shirt if in shorts and skeeveless. Also, it's wise to wear socks with shoes, because when you take off your shoes to enter the area, the pavement can be very hot! Although no photos are allowed inside the temple, the architecture on the grounds is a photographer's delight.

Visit with avoidable experience. The temple is must visit in Bangkok. But the regulations are quite inimical to first time visitors. One is made to use clothes specially pyjamas (kind of trousers) which are used by many in each day. The hygiene is casualty and visitor (specially foreign one) is left with very few options as the code of dress is enforced in a bizarre manner. But the place is architectural marvel and is historical. The temple is serene and spiritually reverent. The energy inside the premise is very positive and one can feel the same. The history and mythology though merges when the discourse comes from guide but still one can chaff the mythical part from the factual history. Landmark place not to be missed.

Part of Grand Palace. This is house in Grand Palace, your entrance fee is included in this attraction. The temple itself is quite grand, very glittering the Emerald Buddha is very small i didnt even see it myself, after coming out and looking at the map i relized i just bypast the Emerald Buddha as its house quite far away if you dont looking closely you will missed it. Inside the temple had people praying.
Out of this world structure. Was amazed at the emerald Buddha statue. was worth standing in the queue to see the Statue.Photography was not allowed in the temple.
Very crowded. Very hot and jammed packed, try not going during peak season. People were rude and pushy and taking photos when asked not to.

Another beautiful Bangkok Wat. Everything that can be said about this particular Wat has been said in previous reviews. Here's what I'll add: go with a guide. We used guides for all our temple visits, and we simply learned things and saw things that we wouldn't have otherwise. Bangkok is rich in temples (heck, southeast Asia is rich in temples for that matter), and you will get a better sense of their history, the religious philosophy behind their creation, and the people who pray there.

Gorgeous!. likes - architecture, magnificent murals, size of the temple, Emerald Buddhadislikes - charged 500 baht for "foreigners"....in relation to the Thai folks, it's considered a lot! Obviously for people who's money is stronger than the Thai baht, it doesn't make much of a difference...but as a Thai person, I think it's the principle that urks me more than anything. We are all humans the same, so if they're going to make money, why not charge everyone a fair fee instead.
Must see. When you go to the Grand Palace, this is definitely a "must see". Very detailed buildings, get place to take photos.

Emerald Buddha. A very small Buddha for all the hype. I had read about it and knew it was a very sacred Buddha. It is enshrined in a beautiful temple and that was what was so amazing. The details on the walls and all the decorations were breathtaking.

Besutiful. Best Buddha temple that we saw in Thailand. We took the free guide that is available once you are inside the premises of the temple (free tour is available at fixed timing of 10:00, 12:00, 13:30 etc. We tagged along with the 13:30 group and saved at least 500 Baht). The inside of the temple was pristine and serene. We were wowed by it's beauty. Visited quite a few other temples in Thailand, but none was as good as the Emerald Buddha.
Amazing place to visit. This temple is fabulous, the buddha is small but well worth a visit. Cant take cameras inside but the building is just WOW. A must see

Temple within the Grand Palace Attraction!. This is a stunning and significant temple within the grounds of the grand palace attraction. I never quite understand why people on TA break up attractions (with paid entry) into all their individual sub components.

Thai Thai. It's Thailand. The most beautiful temple buildings. Rich golden colors everywhere. Too many tourists make overcrowded inside. Anyhow it's the place worth to visit.
Grand palace is in the same region.
Busy but worthwhile. The template is very busy as it's situated in the Grand Palace grounds. The Buddha itself is actually quite small but the building & surroundings are beautiful.

Inside the Grand Palace. If you go to Grand Palace then you can visit this as well. However it is worth it to go straight to this temple. this temple is beautifully built. They give you free map and you can follow along the map. Take plenty of pictures of the architecture as it seems to be unique. You are not allowed to take photographs of the Emerald Buddha from the inside of the temple. Also don't even try to do that too many guards inside. I you really want a picture take it from the outside.
Impressive and peaceful.. Better to visit at the early hours because the crowd could be disturbing if you want to see not just with your eyes.

Simply amazing. This place is a must see. It comes with the combo ticket to the Grand Palace and there was a whole other bunch of tickets that came free with it. The architecture of the was just amazing and breathtaking. We were here on a weekday and the place was filled with lots of tourists! There were a lot of people trying to cheat tourist outside the entrance. Make sure you wear clothes that cover your legs and shirts must have sleeves. If somehow you do not have a change of clothes, dont worry, there are clothes to borrow. You just need to pay a refundable deposit. Outside the entrance, shop keepers are trying to rent their clothes for 30baht.

Amazing!. A visit to Emerald Buddha should be part of the visit to the Grand Palace. The Royal Chapel of the Emerald Buddha, which is simply breathtaking over shadows the visit to the Palace as such. I would recommend to do the audio tour, which only will set you back 200baht, in order to get as much as possible out of your visit here.

Montharak paya pvatanawong. This temple is very beautiful and ancient,it 's near grand palace and there is promotion prices when you buy the ticket you can go two places within 7 days free "Ananda Samakhom Throne Hall" and "Vimanmek Mansion" don't miss it!!!

Absolute "must see". Temple is absolutely fantastic. This is one of the most important things to see in Bangkok in my opinion. You can buy combo ticket for temple and palace. Tour starts from the temple. Don't forget to cover your legs and arms. No vests, light dress, shorts, 3/4 shorts, tattoos in visible places are allowed. They are strictly about it. You can rent clothing for 200 bath deposit, which can be fully refund at the exit.Temple is awesome and it took me about 2h to explore every single corner of it. And there is much to see and admire.

Another stunning sight.. It was facinating to learn the history of the Emerald Budda and see it . I just wish I could have photographed it from inside. You can position ones self out front and with a good camera , zoom in through the open doorway for a photo.

Beautiful temple. Nice place to visit in Bangkok; Next day we were in palace in saw all the gold clothes for the emerald Buddha in museum; There were few monks but place really crowdy with the tourists;

Take the free tour. This place was amazing. I am really impressed by the patterns and designs. Better arrived earlier as it was blazing hot in the afternoon. Take the Chao Phraya express boat for only 15 baht to arrive at this place. Dress appropriately or you will be denied entry.Please note that the entrance fee (500 baht) is included with Vimanmek Palace ticket, so please do NOT throw your ticket away.
must see. You have to visit it. It is like magic. I was amazed by the beauty, details and shine. Never ending display of beauty

Amazing craftsmanship, take a tour. Do - go early before the hordes of tourists show up, get a guide to show you around, the history is very interesting, bring water..... it gets soooo hot!!!Don't - show up in the middle of the day in the heat with busloads of touristsAmazing. Very much part of what makes Bangkok magical. Take the time to soak up all the details and hear the mythology and history of the architecture and design.

Just WOW!!. We made our way to the Grand Palace via the BTS and stopped at Saphan Taksin station. At Saphan Taksin, go down to Sathorn pier under the station, which is also known as Central pier. Get on the Chao Phraya Express Boat coming from your left. Take a boat with no flag, an orange flag, or a green flag. You pay the fare of around 15 baht on board to the ticket seller, tell her "Tha Chang" (pier N9).We paid 500 baht entrance fee pp (temple on the Grand Palace grounds) and made sure we wearing the right attire (long pants and something that covers the shoulders) but you are able to hire clothing at the grounds.We stayed at the temple and surrounding area for over 2 hours as there is lots to see and plenty of photo opportunities. Incredibly hot when we went so make sure you have a bottle of water with you - they have a free water fountain in the temple complex.Be wary of the scammers outside of the complex saying that it is closed or your footwear is inappropriate!A must see if you are in Thailand
A calming place to visit. Your Bangkok trip would not be complete unless you coma and see the Emerald Buddha, it's a place whee you can appreciate and understand this beautiful religion.

My favorite Buddha. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is on the grounds of the Grand Palace. The Buddha itself is in its own temple. It is pretty cool but you can't take its picture from inside the temple, where you can go to see it much closer up. Pictures must be taken from outside, which is where I took mine (long zoom capabilities on my camera). Worth seeing but it only takes a few minutes. The Grand Palace grounds, themselves, are what will take up most of your trip here.

More to see than the Emerald Buddha. Famous for the Temple with the Emerald Buddha. Beautiful. But there is more to see. Lots more... Overwhelming display of gold decorated temples, statues, murals in the border buildings... and many tourists. Make sure to come a little early before all buses arrive... But certainly a must-see.

Wow! Fantastic!. Went here last May 20, 2014 with my family as part of our Thailand holiday. we did not expect the place to be so colorful, vibrant and absolutely fantastic! I just wish that I had a whole day to spend in this place to take some really serious photos. The place is just so picturesque! So far the best place I've seen so far as far as historical temples are concerned. Definitely a must see when in Bangkok!
Must see!. This is located at the grand palace. I would recommend going early as it gets very busy, but well worth the visit.

Wow!. The Wat Pho houses the largest Buddha which is pretty cool, but the intricacies that abound throughout Wat Phra Kaew is amazing. The Emerald Buddha itself is a bit underwhelming, but the rest of the temple ground more than make up for it.Make sure to check out the murals that are in the border buildings that run all the way around the temple grounds.

The whole complex is breathtaking. Plan on spending several hours touring the whole complex - it is absolutely extraordinary - wonderful cafe on the far side serving incredible fruit platters and fruit juices.
A must!. You can not miss this during your days in Bangkok! Check opening hours with them directly before you go, everyone tells you it closes at 4 but its actually open until 6 or so ...
A must!. This is an amazing temple with handicrafts of over 200 years old. All the details are amazing. It's here that housed the most secret Emerald Buddha worshiped by all Thais.

Quiet on a chaotic day. This temple is inside the Grand Palace complex. I always appreciate a quiet moment in a Buddhist temple. Every temple has it's special image. This one is small, placed very high and made of jade not emerald. Still it drew me to quiet thought on a very hot day in a very crowded palace.

Emerald Buddha - Wat Phra Kaew. This is in the Royal Palace tour - so it is a must see if you are only in Bangkok for a short time - it is one of the nicer temples. Make sure that you were clothing that is appropriate - long skirts, pants capris , no sleeveless shirts - you can rent clothing. It can be hot - so bring water.

A must see when in bangkok. There are 8 temples that anyone should visit while in bankok but wat pra kaew may be one of the most important ones - go early in the morning and maybe best way is go by the very low cost river express

Worth the long walk in the heat. When you finally trudge into the temple of the emerald buddha, you've probably been footing it for an hour in the heat.But once inside, it's cool and peaceful - and with a solemn, holy air.There's always a crowd - so expect a fair amount of jostling. Hold on to purses and watch out for pick-pockets.No pictures allowed.The statue itself is surprisingly small - but truly breathtaking!

My favourite Temple. These grounds are just so peaceful once you go in. The Reclining Buddha is amazing but the temple in here I love. I can't remember the times exactly but I think it is around 11am & 5pm the monks come to chant in the other temple. Just removes you from the madness going on all around you out in the city.

most magnificent temple of thailand. Beautiful, shimmering. Truly a representation of the great wealth of the Thai kingdom in the older days. Even the locals come to pay respects for special occassions. Try to avoid talking to over-friendly locals, we almost got scammed twice. They said the temple is closed early and offered to take us elsewhere. Its easy to get there by the chao phraya river ferry for 15baht one way to tha tien jetty from sathorn jetty. You will reach the reclining buddha temple. The emerald buddha temple is within the grand palace which is about 10min walk away.

Emerald Buddha. This temple is located on the territory of the Palace, so there is a huge crowd of tourists. We were not even able to get inside of the temple and had to stand on the steps to it. Buddha statue is very small and located very far away from the visitors.

A big area for such a small Buddha. The cost of this experience was excessive at 500 baht given that Wat Po was only 100 baht for a much larger and more interesting (in my opinion) temple. This is a nice enough temple and the emerald Buddha is in a pretty impressive shrine.
big. A lot of security now but well worth seeing this Wat , it is world famous , really stunning , highly reccomendedn .

Sleeping Buddha. Typical Asian type of building. Bright colors and amazing structures.
The sleeping Buddha is worth seeing.
Smaller than I thought. The actual Buddha is a lot smaller than I imagined. Busy crowds in and around the temple. Cameras not allowed in the temple.

powerful experience. I must say Emerald Buddha had a strong impact on me. Such peace and calmness coming from his statue... it really is something special. Definitely worth mixing with the crowds to see him! I must say the best to see in Thailand!

Beautiful architecture inside the building.. Must see when you visit the grand palace. Jaws dropping mural on the wall, very serene place inside through no photography is allowed and must remain silent while inside the hall.
Overall, it's a nice place.

Spectacular temple. We visited this as part of the half-day temple tour. this temple was by far one of the best we saw. The intricate detail on the building inside and out was amazing. The emerald Buddha itself is tiny (ands actually made of jade-not emerald), and it was interesting to learn that the King comes in at the start of every season to personally change the Buddha's gold cloak. Cameras are not allowed inside the temple, however, if you really must walk away with a snap of the statue, stand outside the front of the temple and zoom in through the middle window - you will get a great shot from here

Breathtaking. I have visited this site several times, and every time its just like I have never been there before. I am not a religious person, but this place has an effect on you. A must do when in Bangkok.

See this Temple Before the Rest. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha was the last temple I saw on my trip to Thailand. So many beautiful temples to keep track of! However, this one was my least favorite. I recommend that you see this one first, as you'll have no basis of comparison. No photos are allowed in this temple, and the Buddha is very small, and can be hard to see. This temple was also the most crowded - it's good for a quick peep in. This temple is a part of the Grand Palace compound, so it definitely shouldn't be missed, but don't expect it to be the highlight of your Grand Palace compound tour.

Magnificent Wat Phra Kaew. Visited during our city & temple tour, located inside the Grand Palace grounds, Thailand's most valued temple, features the magnificent Emerald Budhha idol, dating back to 14 century. The treasured idol, housed in a throne case was seen in summer seasonal costume. The other seasonal costumes being that of monsoon & winter. The temple complex also houses a sandstone miniature model of the famous Angkor Wat temple, many decorative sculptures & statues of the Buddha & from the holy scriptures. Without doubt, a must visit if you are in Bangkok.
Of general interest.. Wat Phra Kaew is within the Grand Palace compound so easy to include in your tour. The temple consists of four buildings each having a different function for the royal family.

The Highlight of the Grand Palace in Bangkok. The Highlight of your visit to the Grand Palace is Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha), which is considered to be the sacred Buddhist temple in Thailand and the location where you can see the famous Emerald Buddha. The temple is found at the Upper Terrace of the Grand Palace and is a highly decorative building, featuring Rattanakosin (old Bangkok) style architecture, immaculate exterior carvings, pillars and design, lovely interior wall murals as well as the sacred Emerald Buddha, which was discovered in 1434 in a stupa in Chiang Rai. Beyond its discovery, Its origins are unknown. The Buddha image is enshrined in a throne case, it is covered in one of three seasonal costumes and situated in the main ordination hall for all to see. Of interesting note, when viewing the Emerald Buddha, you'll probably notice that it doesn't appear to be made of emerald. This is because it is actually carved out of green jade instead. The name was given by the monk who originally found the object and mistakenly thought the Buddha was of emerald stone. After visiting the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, it is well worth seeing the other interesting attractions at the Upper Terrace including the Phra Siratani Chedi, a 19th-century, Sri Lankan style stupa building with is believed to hold ashes of the Lord Buddha. You can also see the important Phra Mondop building, which holds historic Buddhist scriptures that are inscribed on palm leaves which are contained within a decorative, mother-of-pearl inlaid cabinet. There is also a sandstone model of Angkor Wat (circa 1860), which was commissioned when Thailand ruled over this modern day Cambodian World Heritage Sight. You can also find, many decorative statues, elephants and other nice images spread around the Upper Terrace. These are all lovely to see before or after you experience the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. In the end, if there is only one thing you are going to see during your visit to the Grand Palace, it should be the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. You can stay there for as little as 5 minutes or you can spend as much time as you like inside the ordination hall, viewing this sacred Buddha. Then you can visit other areas of the Grand Palace. Tip: Photography isn't allowed within the Ordination Hall that houses the Emerald Buddha. Tip: You must remove your shoes prior to entering the temple. There are plenty of racks available for you store you shoes located just before the entrance.
An Amazing Temple. We loved visiting this temple. You get a real feel for how much work went into the statues and hand carving in the temples.

Amazing visit - Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Amazing sight. Go with a guide who can provide additional information on the temple. Beautiful buildings and Emerald Buddha. Certainly a location not to be missed on any visit to Bangkok.

Emerald Buddha. As long as you go there with a tempered down expectation you would love it. I guess after the sheer size of the Reclining Buddha I was a little disappointed in the size. But then logically how can you have a Buddha made out of a single stone that is bigger! The paintings on the walls are superb and so are the other decorations. The Buddha is dressed in different sets of clothes dependent on the season and since there are three seasons in Thailand there are three sets of clothes made out of gold. The clothes are changed by the King or his family members in a ceremony , this part of the information was courtesy the guide.

Interesting!. I visited this place together with a tour guide. The emerald buddha inside the temple cannot be seen and it's too distant from the ground. If you would like to enter this attraction, better to wear proper attire. No shorts are allowed here and better wear modest apparel. Otherwise, you need to pay a rental fee for the malong or a skirt for your to wear inside the temple. The place is crowded during weekends.

Every turn--beauty and opulence. My family and I enjoyed the Grand Palace and the view of the Emerald Buddha--despite the heat! So many gorgeous tiles, sculptures, mosaics and colors. The whole complex was like a jewel box. I was glad we had a tour guide, otherwise I would not have understood all the buildings and their functions.
beautiful park and views from the top. go with a good guide who is able to share the history of the temple. The buildings here are totally amazing. A must see.
Was not what I had Expected. Its probably just me, but in my mind I had envisaged the statue to be bigger than it actually is. No photos are allowed inside.

After a few temples, it really does seem like you have seen them all.... This one is beautiful and has some history behind it, however it is just a temple. The hand painted walls and the beautiful Buddha are great to see, but it as about comparable to the reclining Buddha or maybe the gold Buddha or temple of dawn.
Stunning. Ok, yes it is not the most original place to visit but you really should go. It's an island of tranquillity in the madness that is Bangkok.
bling bling. all the buildings in temple are bling, but i am not a buddhist, just walked around
Awesome and inspiring. Beautiful and spiritual place to visit. Loved it. Temples in Thailand are just amazing. You can feel the serenity

Grand Palace & Emerald Buddha. This is a must see always very crowded so get there early as it can also be very very hot there. The Emerald Buddha is one of the most revered Buddha in Thailand and is very small but you must go to see it . The Grand Palace is a fascinating look into the life of the Thai royals although they don't use it nowadays except for very special occasions .
What a place. This a must see in Bangkok The palace is serene and give a place for reflection. You can learn about the buddism and this place is condusive to reflect on life and compassion.

Amazing must see. Awe inspiring - so much detail everywhere you can see. It's a spectacular temple within the grand place. It's a must visit and worth the trip to Bangkok if you're not sure. The Emerald Buddha itself is too far away from a good viewing vantage point and no pictures are allowed inside. But the temple itself both inside and out is richly ordained with details and symbolism.Good early to avoid the crowds. Price for entry is 500 baht (not the 350 published) but worth paying at least once.

a must see. go early in the day and direct to the ticket counter by passing the outside punters who often try to lie to you that the temple opens later.remember to dress modestly and for all to cover their legs
Must see. #1 place to see in Bankgkok, temples are fantastic. This is an active temple, not only a tourist attraction. Make sure you have long skirts/pants - man and women.

Breathtaking. Huge temple in the Grand Palace complex of Bangkok. It takes our breath away to see the detail and the beautiful artwork, the detailed statues, and especially the mother of pearl inlaid doors. It is a fantastic example of temple artwork.On our visit it was very crowded, so be prepared to mix it up with thick crowds.

Great place, entrance fee keeps rising. Entrance is now up to 500 THB for foreigners... its getting high for no noticeable improvements in scale or view beyond normal maintenance. To put in perspective it was 150 THB 10 years ago so thats a fairly large increase.That said, this is one of the very few 'must visit places' in Thailand for tourists. Times to avoid coming here:1. During any Mainland China holiday period (1st week of May, Chinese new year week or the 1st week of October)2. Xmas week3. Easter week4. Anytime during March-May when its super hot.

Worth the Visit. The Emerald Buddha is in the King Palace by the river. If you visit men must wear long pnats or hire a pair at the gate. Westerners must pay THB500 enterence fee to the palace. It is all worth a half day visit but take plenty of water and go early as it can get hot.

Nice Temple - Small Buddha - No Photos. Not really sure why you can take photos in some temples and not others? You can take a picture of a Golden Reclining Buddha but not a small green one? I wonder what the Lord Buddha would think of the way that men have interpreted his works and made god like temples to worship him? He was a Guru NOT a God and it would be nice to think you could take pictures, show people and spread his word.

Leave mundane thoughts,sit here, and pray!. i visited this temple on 10th April, 2014. As a traveller from the land of Lord Buddha,being one who has studied something about him, being an author, i felt much happy on the serenity maintained at the temple, its holy environment, cleanliness, and promptness of the staff in maintaining the sacredness of the place. the paintings on the wall,the different idols kept there at different levels, floor mat, everything makes us to sit there for sometime and look at the Emarold Buddha statue,placed at the top of the the platform. Visit this, and spend some time under the feet of the Lord

Excellent. The temple and architecture was amazing. We were there during Thai New Year so there were a lot of worshippers around which added to the feeling of being somewhere special. The Buddha itself is a little disappointing.... it is actually quite small.

Most Amazing of all of Thailand's beautiful treasures. This is truly the most beautiful place of worship I have ever visited. We hired a guide at the start for about 500 baht and it was well worth it. I believe they are all trained guides - I know ours was and his appreciation for Thai culture, history and religion were obvious. He guided us around the complete structure telling us the significance of each element of design making up the temple, and the history of the Thai Buddhism, the Emerald Buddha, the gorgeous murals, the palace design, and the various kings of Thailand. Absolutely amazing! What a wonderful service offered to the tourists who visit the palace. We also appreciated the generous service of loaning garments for those who not appropriately attired. After the long trek to the temple, we would have hated to leave since my husband was in shorts, but they loaned us pants and have a well operated lending station. The temple and Royal Palace are worth the admission price of 500 baht and so is the guide.
Beautiful piece of Emerald. A very beautiful temple which has an excellent emerald buddha statue that is truly amazing and made of a single piece of Jade.

You can't see up close. Impressive jade statue of the Buddha. This emerald sculpture, carved out of a single piece, is set atop a tall pedestal inside the Grand Palace Temple and the closest you can see it is at a distance of some 20-25 feet. You can take pictures of it from outside the temple through the arched window. Inside, it is resplendent.

just 5 minutes. this is a small temple inside the huge Royal Palace. the Buddha is very small and the King change it's dress every season. Because i don't like to meditate i had just a fast look, but the atmosphere is very buddhist. good for meditation. No noise at all.

See also Grand palace in my reviews. A must see eben if the Buddha shall not impress you by it's size. It's very popular and the temple beautiful A must see. To read more about this location see my review on Grand palace
Amazing. The Buddha is truly amazing, made of a single piece of jade. Lots of tourists, so make sure you're in the right frame of mind when you get there, and you'll have fun!

Must!. You hear many stories and have seen images, but seeing the Grand palace in person was even a better experience than I expected. What an impressive sight. The beauty and detail of the buildings, and of course the Emerald Buddha who's clothes are changed three times a year! They were offering free water and have reasonable toilet facilities on site.We started our sightseeing here, following a route suggested by Lonely Planet. Can recommend the route, which will take you altogether about 4-5 hours.

Average. I enjoyed my time here but have seen better. There was thousands of tourists and 500b doesn't justify what you see. I was very disappointed after with this after visiting wat pho which was such good value for money! If you can afford it go, if not I wouldn't bother!
Nice but not an attraction on its own. This was an add on to the palace. It is very special and nice, but after seeing the big Buddhas it was somewhat disappointing.

A special temple in the Grand Palace complex. Lovely temple with devotees and monks worshiping. Although the Grand Palace complex Buddha is relatively small and perched high atop a shrine but draws the eye. Lovely, peaceful, beautiful.
Great experience. This is a very busy Temple you really have to walk in and pass the Buddha as there is so many people that you do not have time to stand and really enjoy

Don't let the crowds put you off. Yes it is busy but once you're inside this grand temple I don't think you'll notice, I certainly didn't. It really is a a joy to find a space on the floor, take a few tranquil minutes sitting still, and admire your very beautiful surroundings.

Crowded but lovely. This place was packed with loads of visitors by the time we got there, which was mid-morning. Whether one comes here for worship, to seek solace, to be a tourist gazing upon the magnificence of the Emerald Buddha or simply to take photos, everyone here is purposeful and intense, it seems.The architectural of the shrine and its surrounding pagodas are simply, simply magnificent and stunning - it feels like a very sacrad place , just stepping into this area. The Emerald Buddha is beautiful and enchanting to gaze upon - one almost gets a sense of tranquil nearly immediately.Do drop by this place for this intricately-designed temple.For more detailed information and photos, do visit:http://thearcticstar.blogspot.sg/2014/01/tackling-thailand-bangkok.html
iconic bangkok site. if there is only one place you visit in bangkok this should be it. amazing thai architecture, history, art and national significance to the Thais

Go there early and with time. It's extremely touristic, but it's a great experience. Amazing Architecture and art. Go there early and with time, avoid noon (too full and too hot). Take your time inside the temple where the emerald buddha is (there are a lot of air fans inside) and enjoy the silence, the art and the experience.
Stunning. I've seen a lot of temple and buddha's through out India and Nepal but this was stunning. I have never seen such well preserved or beautiful as this one.
Stunningly beautiful. One of the best temples in Bangkok absolutely beautiful a definite must see, so peaceful and tranquil an amazing temple.

Amazing and colorful temple. O love Thai temples and this was one of my favourites. Big, colourful and full of culture and traditions. Although it is usually crowded, you have plenty of room to take good pictures and relax. A must see.
Very nice. Its in the palace grounds , very cute, only the royal family change its clothes.Its also close to the river and dont forget to wear long pants....

How can you be charged so much to see a temple?. I was absolutely disgusted that they charge people to see this temple! Temple visits should be free. I didnt bother going in because every other temple my wife and I had visited were free. I think its disgusting.

Beautiful!. Visiting this temple you feel extremely calm and peaceful.
Gorgeous work displayed on walls and doors.

Another beautiful temple. We can't whole week for only visit the temple in Thailand. Well , it was a very lovely temple with so many people around. The architecture of this temple was very unique , beauty from inside till outside.
Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Really a traditional marvel! So beautifully and ornately built and maintained, a must see for visitors to the city.
Well worth a visit. It's a lovely temple and the detailing around the grounds is great if you're a photographer. Definitely in the top 10 sights in Bangkok.

Beautiful place, a must see!. Breathtakingly beautiful place with a genuine sense of history and passion, a must see if you are in Bangkok!
Worth noting that you need to have your full legs and shoulders covered, but they loan you clothes for free if you need them.

Wow!. I almost missed this amazing experience! What I didn't know is that Behring the temple is a Chinese Herbologist shop. Shake out 3 sticks, take them to the counter and get the herbs you need for your health! I won't miss that next time!

One of the most venerated sites in Thailand.... A site where people convene to pay respect to the Lord Buddha and His Teachings.Great Thai architecture and tradition...A must see when you visit Bangkok!!
Lot of Gold. very intricate inside of the temple and the surroundings were very ornate - very quiet place to reflect and to escape the April heat

Worth a visit. A beautiful temple with intricate carvings, statues and buildings. This is adjacent to the Grand Palace. Worth a visit especially if you want to photograph the Thai culture and religion. We went in the morning and it was good timing as the sun was not up yet and not so warm.

only one word can discribe this temple' peaceful'. This is 2nd time I've come to the a the temple of the emerald Buddha, the experience you'll have here is nothing short of spiritual and if you just 10 minutes of your holiday and just sit and breath and let the experience take you over like me you'll feel at peace for days this is a very important temple to the Thai people so please respect the customs whilst here this Buddha statue is revered highly so ensure that you keep your feet always behind you whilst sitting in the grand hall. On leaving you may also like to dip a lotus blossom in the blessed water and wet your head

Amazing. Such an amazing temple complex.There is so much detail here and lots of different building styles and shapes. To the left of the Temple is a large scaled model of Angkor Wat which is just stunning as well as nice bas-reliefs all around depicting scenes from the Rama.Well Worth the visit but busy and expensive so take a deep breath before you enter.
Crowded & Very Hot during Summer. Not recommend to visit during summer (Jun to Sep). Very crowded and hot. You can't enjoy the view. Suggest to visit during winter (Dec to Feb).

One of the Most Beautiful Temples I have Seen. The structures in this temple are unbelievably beautiful. The Emerald Buddha (okay, it's made of jade) is incredible. You feel its spiritual importance when you are in front of it. I highly recommend it as long as you are aware of the many scams run outside of the Grand Palace.
Wow.... I think the title says it all, cos i was really amazed with my trip to Wat Phra Kaew. Its really impressive with all those buildings, temples and statues that are beautifully decorated.

Should Not Miss.. This Temple is absolutely amazing, which is actually carved from Jade & set in the grounds of The Grand Palace, unfortunately no photos are allowed to be taken inside.Dress code must be respectable, no flimsey type tops or see throughs allowed & no thongs.From memory the cost was approx 200 Baht & its open daily from about 9am to 3 or 4pm.Well worth the visit & is in the heart of Bangkok.

Small Buddha Big Temple. Part of Grand Palace complex and home to the most significant Buddha in all Thailand. Entrance to the large walled palace is through a gate on the northern side next to the huge field called Sanam Luang. There's a strict dress code, no shorts and your shoulders must be covered, a booth just inside the entrance lets you cover up if need to.Inside you will see a lot of 2 main types of statue, Demons and Monkeys. Demons have green faces and wear shoes, Monkeys are open mouthed and barefoot. There's a huge mural depicting the Ramayana in one of the halls. No photos allowed in the main hall housing the Buddha, so you will have to buy a postcard if you want to remember what he was like. The statue is really small, remember to show respect and not walk infront of people praying or point your feet in the direction of Buddha - this is a no no.

Emerald Buddha. Inside the Grand Palace are a series of impressive buildings, including Wat Phra Kaew (otherwise known as the Temple of the Emerald Buddha), which is one of the actual highlights of the entire city. This emerald Buddha is very small in size, yet hugely revered, and is, as the centrepiece of Wat Phra Kaew, actually regarded as the most important Buddhist site in Thailand.

Tiny. Be prepared to walk in this area--the entire area was much larger than we had imagined. We felt, at times, like we were going around in circles. The Emerald Buddha was smaller than what we had imagined and at first, we were not sure if we were looking at it or not.
good. this is one of the most favourite temple in town. there are golden buddha.Quite an experience - really helped put the Temple and Buddhism in Thailand in a better perspective!.

Amazing. This place is amazing, the gold and jewels in and around the building are unbelievable. This is one of the Buddah's that you cannot photograph whilst inside, this temple is part of the kings palace complex which you should not miss.

Every Visitor Must See. Wat Pra Kaew is the words Thai people commonly call this temple. It locates next to the Grand Palace. The whole sculptured Buddha is made from real precious emerald!! All buildings in this temple are golden and colorful. There are a numbers of statues representing giants and old wall paintings from Ramayana story. Classical tiny bells always make beautiful ringing sound when we walk around. Visitors can take a lot of beautiful photos from every corner inside this temple. Please bring umbrellas because it will be much cooler under their shade.

Always Good!. This time we arrived at the same time as a group of about 30 or so young Thai men, experiencing the Buddhist novitiate. They conducted a brief liturgy, supervised and led by the older monks.Quite an experience - really helped put the Temple and Buddhism in Thailand in a better perspective!

Heavenly feeling. If you are not afraid of the crowded place, this place is one of the most interesting temples you will meet.Instead of Buddha, found in most of the temples, you will see the divine character not touching, like a fairy emerging from the darkness of the temple, and all of her is glamorous.Sit on the carpet in front of her and let yourself get into a feeling of peace of mind.

Huge temple, amazing wall paintings. Visiting Bangkok and not visiting Wat Phra Kaew is a no go. Be prepared to spend some time exploring all the sights. I especially loved the wall paintings, located in the outer wall of the temple. But also the different and very colourful buildings are must see. Be sure to bring your camera and an extra battery (they unwind quite fast in the heat and when taking lots of pictures). In the hall of the Emerald Buddha one is not allowed the take photos. It's a huge building with lots of gold and a rather small Emerald Buddha! Too me a big fuss for not so much. Still worth seeing.

Must - Visit Cultural attraction in Bangkok. As Thai, I have been there few times....This temple is an important place for Thai people; it used to be where the Kings lived at the establishment period of Bangkok but the monarchy has not been living there for ages; the temple is still used in some formal royal ceremonies. You will get to see different architecture styles. However, it is prohibited to take photos of Emerald Buddha himself. If you would like to see cultures and learn a bit more of Thai history then, you have to visit this place.If you are not that interested in history, it's still worth visiting this place to see beautiful Thai architectures.If you miss visiting this place when coming to Bangkok, it'd be like you go to Rome without visiting the Colosseum! Anyway, the tips are to wear long pants and t-shirt or shirts with sleeves. There is a sarong (Thai long skirt) and long pants rental available in case you got your shorts and tank tops on.Furthermore, it's really hot and humid so bring a small towel and a bottle of water with you. The only backlash would be tourists crowds.

Wonderful place of Bangkok history.. Wonderful place of Bangkok history. i'm sure you will never see the building very beautiful place like this before. delicately. And this temple is very important for Thai people. Because that is temple of the King. yes you know Thai people really love The King. absolutely!!! Once you go there you will feeling of the real peace. so that mean once in a lifetime your need to go there. for great experience..

Amazing place and photographers' paradise. I have been here several times as it is such a lovely place to visit. Especially during the time of summer and winter. The place has some clothing requirements for foreigners, but nothing serious about it. I loved my time every time I went there and it's fantastic place to take a photos.

Always packed, but serene. The same comments apply as for the Kings Palace - it is in the grounds. The most holy site in Thailand and quite remarkable. I prefer some of the other temples in Bangkok, and the ones in Chiang Mai, all of which are completely free.

Gorgeous Buildings, Busy and Crowded. The buildings themselves are exquisite and the whole palace complex is breathtaking. The admission is expensive and lines to buy tickets were long. Inside the Emerald Buddha's temple, it was unbelievably crowded, and outside it was uncomfortably hot. A hat and water are highly recommended, although there is a small café with ice cold drinks, coffee, tea and ice cream. We were told that there are three seasons in Bangkok, "hot, hotter, and hottest," so this site, with its large, open patios and hardly any shade, would probably be hot any time of year.

Beautiful temples, awful experience. The temples are stunning yes, the experience as a whole is terrible.It's a huge tourist attraction meaning Thais yelling at tourist in megaphones about wearing the wrong length of pants (!) note leggings are even black ones are not allowed, but see through dresses are (Thai logic?) so you have to walk around wearing a lot of clothes when it's terribly hot, With large groups of tourist bustling around pushing, and the worst all the scam artists approaching you trying to sell stuff tuk tuk rides or guided tours.The queues are slow and long, the temples are terribly crowded both inside and outside, not to mention temperatures around the temple with no wind and stone paving reaches +40 c.My advice would be to stay away and visit nicer more authentic and calm temples like Wat Pho, Wat Laksi or Wat Arun in Bangkok.
Stunning!. Words would do no justice to the Emerald Buddha. I simply urge anyone visiting Bangkok to marvel at this exquisite work with their own eyes.
LIve like a king. So this is how royalty lives! Amazing palace complex. Expensive but turned out to be worth it. I'm very glad I went. Very hot and crowded- bring water!
Breathtaking!. It was busy inside the temple but the statue, which actually is jade (and gold!) is quite magnificent. You must remove your shoes.
The jewel of Thailand. The shining jewel in Thailand. Small in size but unlimited in glory. The respect this commands is well deserved

Great Pictures!. Glad to have gone, but it was DANG HOT in the afternoon, VERY CROWDED, and we didn't have any guide, so we didn't even see the Emerald Buddha! Ha! I think by this point, we were Watted out. But what else is there to do in Bangkok besides shop or go to a Wat?
Another historic site. If you hop on to the boat at chao praya, you also can visit this one. But, if you already seeing lot of temple, skip this. :))

This is really the Temple of the Jade Buddha!. This is a Buddha which strikes you as being quite different when you come here after having seen the massive reclining gold plated Buddha. This idol is made from green jade, although it is called called the Emerald Buddha! A misnomer!You move in a queue and go up a few steps to enter a large hall and then you see the pale green idol, raised up high on a pedestal. It was interesting to learn that the garb of the Buddha is changed thrice a year depending on the season. The dressing of the Buddha used to be done by the King. Now that the king has aged, it falls on the Crown Prince to reach up to the pedestal to change its clothes! I expect the Prince must be hoisted up on a cherry picker or similar device. And on the three days in the year when the idol is having its seasonal change of clothes, I was told the temple is closed to visitors. But given the number of similar scams in Bangkok, I would check this out!

There were many people praying to Buddha in this temple. What beautiful paintings on all the walls and ceilings of this temple. Emerald Buddha was in the far back part of the temple but two other Buddhas were up front and easier to view.

Introduction to Thai Royalty. It was our adventure in Thailand. The audio tour is great, about 200 bhat ($6)/person. Good introduction to Thai History and Buddhist Culture. We toured Wat Phra Kaew along with the Grand Palace.
Worth the trip. Not hard to get to as an addition to the Royal Palace site. Large room that allows you to view both front and back of the gold leaf covered Buddha. Quite impressive.

One of the great sights in the world...... This complex of buildings, statues and monuments, including the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the royal palace is one of the great places to visit in the world. Everywhere you look is a beautiful sight....inspired Thai architecture, golden statures and spires, high roofed buildings, and beautiful planted details. The complex is a major holy sight to he Buddhist people, so proper dress is required. 3 men in our tour group were wearing shorts, and they had to rent long pants in order to visit the Temple. Same for women....those is shorts or short skirts had to rent a cloth to make into a wraparound skirt, and those with bare shoulders had to wear a cloth shawl.The grounds are fairly large, and are totally immaculate....no trash anywhere, and the maintenance on the buildings, grounds and lawns is perfect. The Emerald Buddha is in a typically opulent building. You must remove your shoes to enter, and no pictures are allowed inside where the Buddha is located. It is about 2-3 feet tall, and is made of jade. Every couple of months the king has to come and change the Buddha's clothing...apparently there are several different outfits.This visit is certainly on a par with Notre Dame in Paris, the Blue Mosque in Istanbul and the palaces in St. Petersburg as 'bucket list' sights that you don't want to miss.

A must see, but try to avoid the mid-day heat. If going to Bangkok on vacation, I would definitely say this was on the "must see" list. I would definitely recommend not going at the peak heat times though since there is very little shade and whew, it was hot! This is another one of the sites where appropriately conservative dress is mandatory. They do provide options rent clothing that will cover (lose pants for men, large wrap cloth for women), but to avoid that long line when you first enter, I would just be sure that you have clothing that covers shoulders, and your entire legs.

The Emerald Buddha is actually jade. First off, this is not a place for Americans to wear their shorts. I found it interesting that the Emerald Buddha changes his outfits with the seasons. The Buddha is actually just over 2ft high. It's a must see to say you saw it.

Amazing, must do!. I'd been to Bangkok a few times before this visit and never made it to the Grand Palace and Emerald Buddha temple. WOW - amazing complex of temples and shrines, palace buildings and museums. Totally worth going, I was there a couple of hours at least, totally blown away by the intricate and ornate designs and decorations of the buildings. I found the section around the Emerald Buddha temple to be more interesting than that around the palace but it could just be that the heat was getting to me by then

Amazing place. You get a great feel of Thailand's strong connection and worship towards Buddhism when you step inside this Palace and temple complex. The buildings shine with gold, opal, emeralds and the entire structure is impressive. At 500 baht entry, it's worth to spend at least 2 hours seeing everything.If someone says the temple is not open and offers to take you on tour, just walk past and go straight to the entry. The Palace and temple officially close at 6.30pm.A NOTE: Do NOT under any circumstance try to take photos inside the temple of the Emerald Buddha. The guards wil take your phone or camera and never give it back.This happened to my friend.Wear long sleeve pants and a T-shirt is fine. Take off shoes where indicated.

Amazing history and architecture. The Grand Palace and Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew) was my favourite thing about Bangkok. The history captured in the walls of the palace and temples is amazing. There is soo much detail to every column pillar and feature that it is mind boggling.Not to mention the amount of jewels and gold plated areas that just capture the sunlight and make everything sparkle. And to think that these building are thousands of years old , with so much history to be told is truly awe-inspiring.but i think one of my favourite parts of this place i could not photograph, and that was inside the grand hall of the emerald buddha itself. The decoration, attention to detail of the whole room is beautiful. Especially the paintings which line every wall telling the stories of ancient Siam.If you ever stop by Bangkok , make sure this place is on your to do list.

Buda. We got a taxi to river caught a river taxi to the temple the cruise down the river is well worth the trip then to the temple take my advice go to the main entrance not the corner ones there are tuktuk drivers telling you you will not be allowed in because you have shorts on don't worrying just go into the entrance of the main gate and see one of the guides the official ones I mean they have proper id badges around there neck they will supply you with some light wait trousers take a guide to go round the pallace it's worth every penny I say again do not take any notice of the free lance guides out side they just won't you to go to a shopping Mal or market with them so they can get there commission and will take you some were you don't want to go don't let these ruing your daily shight seeing tour wich they nearly did ours enjoy

A must see.. The gold that surrounds this Emerald buddha is amazing. Sadly you are unable to take photos inside of this buddha but if your lucky you can get a good shot through the window when there is no one standing in your way. A really amazing place.
Get a zoom lens. I'm glad that we went to visit the Emerald Buddha but I wish I had know to take a zoom lens since visitors cannot take photos inside. We had a guided tour which I recommended.

Small green Buddha statue is a solid piece of emerald. The statue is about 18" high and sits atop a very huge monument. Three times a year the son of the King will climb to the top and change the clothes on the statue. This place is a very big deal to Thais and to Buddhist so be reverant. This is like going into St Pauls in Rome. Be quiet - no flash pics. Keep your feet close to you if you sit, or sit on top of them. Do not point your feet at the statue or anyone in the room. Many people have traveled a long distance to worship here so be aware of who is next to you. Not all Buddhist are Asians. All in all this is up near the top of places to go in Bangkok.

Unforgettably Beautful!. My family and I went to Wat Phra Kaew with our tour group, and we could not have been more enthralled! Out of the six temples we ended up visiting during our stay in Thailand, this one was by far our favorite! The splendor of the campus far surpassed that of any others. We found the architecture absolutely extraordinary, and all the buildings magnificent. It was interesting how there was this humongous area for such a small Buddha, because the actual "Emerald Buddha" (made of Jade) is quite small. The cultural and religious experiences at this temple are endless, and those of all ethnic backgrounds will enjoy it thoroughly. Even my two children (ages 14 and 8) were beyond thrilled! An important thing to remember is to wear long pants and sleeved shirts because you will not be allowed into the temple without them. A visit to Bangkok is certainly not complete without a visit to Wat Phra Kaew.

Truly Thai Experience. The Emerald Buddha and the temple complex are really key experiences in Bangkok. Getting here can be arduous, but you will be richly rewarded for braving the traffic. The Emerald Buddha makes up in splendor for what it lacks in size. Wear proper attire to avoid having to rent the Buddhist "burka" and looking like a clueless tourist, even if you are a clueless tourist. The entire temple complex is stunning. Pay attention to the outlying sights, like the Chinese statues used as ballast from the trading ships and the broken ceramics used to decorate. The other viewers are correct, without the temple, you've not seen Thailand.
Amazing Spleldor. What a treasure in Bangkok. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the Reclining Buddha are not to be missed.

A little history helpful. It helps to enhance the Buddha viewing if you look up some historybeforehand. But the entire grounds is splendiferous. I considerthis a must do. Experience all of it! That says it all.

Astonishingly Beautiful. The Temple is on the Grand Palace grounds, and you must pay admission for entry to the temple, even though there is no fee to get into the gated grounds of the palace complex.Proper attire is required of everyone visiting the palace grounds. Visitors can't wear shorts or sleeveless tops, and women can't wear short dresses. You can rent appropriate clothing just inside the main gate for 200 baht, which is refundable when you return the clothing. Vendors also sell proper clothing just outside the gate. There is no refund for those items though.Admission to the Temple grounds is about $15 US, which gains you access to all areas except the administrative and residential buildings. A complimentary brochure is provided at the entrance, which gives you background information and history, so you know what you're looking at. Once inside, you can also buy a guided tour for an additional $15 US, but I find that I can't understand the English of most tour guides in Bangkok. It's difficult to describe the splendor here. Plan to spend a few hours gawking at every ornate inch of the magnificent architecture throughout the palace grounds. The inside of the Temple is adorned with so much gold, it almost hurts your eyes to look. Photography is prohibited inside. The Emerald Buddha is, in fact, carved from a block of jade and has a fascinating history.End your visit at the coffee bar just outside the clothing rental area, where cold fruit smoothies are available for about $2.50 US. Don't miss the Temple of the Emerald Buddha.

Don't miss it. Located on the palace grounds this is a must see on any itinerary. As a stand alone sight it is very average and the crowds and the way you are herded through the site are very off putting. However, it is a part of the palace grounds and they are a wonder onto themselves. Allow at least 3-4 hours to tour the place grounds and your visit will be well rewarded with and explosion of color and oriental architecture.
The holiest buddha shrine and magnificient statuette of jade stone. Humbling, magnificient, sublime...with all earthly pleasures of Bang-Kok this is a place to start all visit with

Beautiful. A beautiful temple with lots to see. Amazing to look around and admire. You have to be appropriately dress if you aren't you have to put a deposit down to borrow some clothes (200 baht).
It is a must for tourists in Bangkok.

Not to be Missed. The entire Temple Complex including the Emerald Buddha within the King's Palace Complex is not to be missed for its ornate splendor, its spiritual beauty, and to demonstrate the innate religiosity of the Thai people. Do not miss under any circumstances1
This is very nice. This tiny Buddha makes me think of the little Mermaid in Copenhagen, except it is far more majestically dressed in gold. No shoes or photos are allowed.

if you don't see this you have not seen Thailand. next door to the palace. breathtakingly beautiful, makes you forget
the modern busyness of Bangkok and allows for contemplation if you come early mornings

Must Visit in Bangkok. It's part of the Palace complex. Easiest way to get here is by express boat from Sathorn Pier. Get off at Pier 9. Beware of touts who will tell you that the palace is closed and will take you to visit Lucky Buddha Temple. It's just a money making racket. Proper clothing required (no shorts, sleeveless). Clothes are available on rent from within the complex but usually has a long line. Better to carry your own change of clothes. You will need to take off your shoes to enter the temple area. The temple itself is very beautiful and has a history behind it. It's very spiritual and serene inside the temple. Lots of intricate art work surround the emerald statue. Recommended to stay inside the temple for at least 10-15 mins and soak in the beauty.

The temple is fantastic. The temple of the Emerald Buddha and Grand Palace complex is rightly one of Bangkok's big draws, but it is a relatively expensive site, and you need to be careful to dress appropriately.

Not too impressive. The Emerald Buddha is much smaller than the other Buddha images we saw in Bangkok. It is actually made of jade, we were told. Do go see it, especially if you will be going to Laos because there you will see a temple in Luang Prabang and one in Vientiane that each housed the Emerald Buddha at one time.

Wat Phra Kaew. No wonder it is one of the most see place in Bangkok! It's breath-taking. There is also free tour guide, once every hour. And do not rent the audio guide, because it's very poor and you can have all information in the flyer.

Beautiful temple but.... This temple is beautiful but...- expensive (500bahts), compared to Wat Pho or Wat Arun, that are, to me, also gorgeous places. - they are more severe with dressing. Do not forget to completely cover your body with clothes.However if you like temple and if you are in Bangkok, it is a must, Wat Phra Kaeo worth the visit.

Fantastic!!! must to see in town!. It's a beautiful temple inside the magic atmosphere of Royal Palace!!! The Buddha itself is quite small compared to others, but its so precious and brillant!! Unforgivable and unique experience!!! it's a mandatory to see it together with all the huge area around of Royal Palace!

tour to the temple and palace. When we arrived at our hotel, a wonderfully friendly and helpful guide (Sincere Nan) from Destination Asia met us and arranged activities for the few days that we were there, and this was one of the tours. Our guide for the day was Rio, a very enrtertaining and informative guide. We found both the temple and palace visits to be very interesting. The one thing that spoils almost every trip or tour in Bangkok, seems to be the "connection" between the taxis and tour busses and the local gemstone shops. Every single taxi and tour wants to take you past the gemstone factory where you are told that you will be told how gem stones are mined and cut. Quite interesting we thought, not so! You are whisked past the "factory side" very quickly and shown around their giant show room where pushy and demanding sales people become rather sulky when you fail to purchase. We were conned into this visit once and then a second time when we took a random taxi. So a major tip, INSIST on going directly to the destination of your choice and do not be conned into a visit to a tailor or a gemstone shop - its a waste of good holiday time and not a pleasant experience if you don't shop at the stores!

Guide totally made it. We paid for an audio guide but actually, in the end didn't use it at all as we joined an English speaking tour (free) that was just starting. The tour guide was excellent, would highly recommend.

The most Catholic looking Buddhist temple I've seen. This is a temple with a very flashy pedestal around a very small green Buddha statue. From what I understand it's main claim to fame is being stolen on a raid.As it's on the grounds of the royal palace, so I'd recommend catching it if you're there anyway, just don't expect to be blown away.

Amazing place, but too crowded. Grand palace and temple of emerald Buddha are definitely places one must not miss while in Bangkok. Though management team of this venue have put adequate security forces, they need to improve their efforts in order to avoid frequent crowding. Carvings, paintings and the entire ambiance of this temple is very nice. One should take a guided tour - either provided by appointed private guides at a cost or through govt appointed guides (free) - to understand the history of this place.Note for fellow travellers - there are stairs and uneven areas in this temple where wheelchair access is difficult. Other tourists would normally help you upon your request though.

Great temple with artistic design. What an art work! Blending of History, culture, religion. Also the Emerald Buddha was beautiful. Though too crowded but no tourist should miss this (actually the Grand palace) if they are in Bangkok. Go early as it closes at 3:30 everyday.

Hmmm. Yes it is impressive but too crowded and people have no regard for personal space or politeness it would appear. Its in the same complex as the palace and i wasnt taken with the entire place tbh. If you go and enjoy it fair play to you.

Emerald Buddha. This is a very beautiful temple complex in Bangkok. The carvings and the beautiful creations on the walls of temple are indeed very beautiful. This is a place that no tourist should miss when travelling to Bangkok. I visited this place in 2006

Need one full day to visit the Grand Palace. Its a nice place to see the Royal Culture of Thailand, but please remember to keep one full day for this as Emerald Buddha is not the only thing for which you visit Grand Palace, and be very careful about your dress... no shorts, no see thru T-Shirts, no torn denims no slacks for both men & women.
a must see. Just one of those things you need to tick off your list of things to see in BKK...easily accessed from the river as well...

Holiday to Singapore andThailand. This is a must see when visiting Bangkok, it's amazing! Looking back on The photo's we took is great, but they don't do the colours or the architecture justice. It is one of those places you feel privileged to have seen.n

My favorite Buddha. Very pretty but make sure you cover up when you go or you have to rent clothes. You also can't take photos inside the temple but on the plus side you can walk their from Ko San road. Costs 500 baht to get in. Be careful men outside tell you it's shut try and get you on expensive boat trips.
iconic. Not to be missed , we went in the morning , it is a famous temple , beautifully maintained , the buddha satues is impressive , reccommended .

A nice part of the compound, but hard to see and nothing incredible.. The palace is astonishing, as is the building that the Emerald Buddha is in, however, you have to peer in from the outside, and the statue is quite small, so difficult to see, and really nothing that special, unless you might value historical or religious aspects of the site.
Wat Phra Kaew. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is well worth a visit. The Temple is very beautiful although the statue itself is quite small, high up and I think is made of Jade?

Fascinating!. We loved our visit to the Emerald Buddha - the Thai beliefs are magical and incredibly interesting. This really added culture to our honeymoon stay in Thailand. We would recommend getting a guide - our guy 'Captain' was really funny and full of great stories!

Place u can't miss. . Must visit if you visit Bangkok.
The emerald buddha is a sight to watch. The entire complex contains amazing buildings.
Don't forget to enjoy fresh coconut water at the restaurant in the premise.
Emerald (Jade) Buddha. It is really a Jade Buddha. It was amazing to view this creation. The reverence that is shown is spiritual

Not an Emerald Buddha. The Emerald Buddha is actually Jade, which I didn't realize and decreased the "Wow" factor a bit. Still, seeing the Emerald Buddha in his seasonal garb (he changes clothes for each of the three Thai seasons) surrounded by more riches and artifacts than anywhere in Bangkok was pretty neat.

Beautiful. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is in the Grand Palace complex. Everything in this complex is so beautiful, but this temple in particular took my breath away. The intricate mosaic work on every surface of the temple is amazing and truly awe-inspiring. I would definitely recommend seeing it in person.

zen. peaceful place with beautiful gardens ... to be visited
if you love calm and zen attitudes be sure this place is gonna be your place

Worth a visit. Really nice place to visit if you got a few hours to spare in Bangkok. It's like a mini village in the middle do the big city with various temples and shrines located all around the area, and of course the emerald Buddha.

Meh. Don't get me wrong, it was ornate and lovely, but the Jade Buddha is only about a meter tall, and was mostly covered in elaborate clothing, and was set so high up that it was almost impossible to see. Plus, no photos allowed.

Lots To See!. This place was amazing as there was a lot to see. It does cost a lot to walk around but I would say it was worth it. It's busy no matter what time of day you go. I would highly recommend taking suitable clothing otherwise you will find yourself waiting in a queue to put a deposit down on rental clothes or buying from a seller just outside.
Not to be missed!. Part of the Grand Palace ticket and tour. Impressive display of Buddhist culture and tradition.Not to be missed!

Definitely worth a visit..... as long as you can bear the number of tourists. Lots and lots of people -so do not visit if you do not like crowds. The temple is magnificent. We took a free tour offered in the temple and our guide explained everything. A "do not miss" experience

Lots of gold. Really bueutiful, even thugh the emerald (or actually jade) statue ie not impressive in size and udditionally covered with dress. But absolutely worth the visit as that is most important piece of art possessed by Thais and envied by other neighbour nations that used to hołd it for some time in the past.The temple itself is a part of Grand Pałace and , as everything within it, mądre with real eastern splendour - lots of gold, gems and colours. Stunning.
Special temple. It was rather special-etheral-being inside this temple. Beautifully decorated from the outside with the colourful and sparkling tiny tiles,and the inside was just as nice.

Beautiful. Worth seeking out and visiting The Emerald Buddha whilst within The Grand Palace vast grounds.You have to remove your shoes outside the temple and also wear suitable clothes to enter.Although you can view The Emerald Buddha and take beautiful photographs from outside, go inside to soak up the atmosphere and gaze at the beauty of both The Emerald Buddha and temple itself.Read the history behind the statue for added amazement.
Another Wat with small Buddha. Another Wat. Wat is the point? I like Wat's but this was just ok, The Buddha is really small and you cant take pictures. Seems well used though

don't miss!. Don't miss this fabulous temple! Lot's to see, need a good guide book or a real guide. Remember, no shorts! Gotta cover up. Good to take Croks or a shoe that slips off and on easily since you will be removing your shoes frequently. Stay hydrated!!! it can be overwhelmingly hot.

Very Croweded, But A Must Do In Bangkok. The Grand Palace is very busy so best get here very early.:It opens at 8:30, don't let anyone come up to you and tell you anything different, it is a ploy to get you to go somewhere in a tuk tuk and charge you more money than you need to pay.We didn't get a guide as you get a free mp when you get further in.If you are a female then it is best to go ready dressed, or face a long queue and leaving your passport with someone so that you can hire a dress and t-shirt, presuming that you would be wearing a pair of shorts and a vest top. No shoulders are allowed to be on show.

Stunning. Favourite Temple in Thailand! Beautiful, Sparkley and lots to see. Highly recommend! Book a guide so you get the full history and make sure to wear clothes that cover your knees and shoulders for men and women. Buy water as there is lots of walking.

Part of Grand Palace, not to be missed. Out of this world attraction, beautiful. If only a few hours to spend sightseeing, then the Reclining Buddha / Wat Pho and nearby Grand Palace are not to be missed.

Beautiful. The actual temple is located in the Grand Palace complex. There is a lot to see, many beautiful buildings, and murals. You need to make sure you wear long pants and shirts with sleeves to gain entrance. There is no photography allowed in the actual temple where the Emerald Buddha is located unfortunately. Although you can take pictures from the outside.
Spectacular. Beautiful Plenty to see...make sure you wear walking shoes that are easy to remove. Many places the shoes must be removed to view the interiors.

Soak in the zen.. For some reason this one over all the others here felt peaceful, calming, quiet in the crowd. Sit down in a cross-legged yoga pose and breathe. Relax. Be one with the Buddha. In Grand Palace Fortress. Part of GP 500 baht ticket. T-shirt/long pants good. No shoes with Buddha. Absolutely no photos allowed. They are watching you.

The Place do not miss!!!. I did there several times during in bkk and still love for Thailand culture, I can not say just only beautiful but it has more feeling than any words to explain, I do suggest you to see one time then you will come back agian.

It was worth to see. There was in complex The Grand Place. That was one typical architect of temples. Amazing with All golden color I saw - all gold. Emerald Buddha was kept sacred on the top of the altar .Unfortunate when I got friendly tourist guide showed me nice special cultural in here.Expensive entrance fee tickets, but it was worth for all complex.

Amazing Temple. If you have time for nothing else this is a must. It is amazing. Get a tour guide and you will learn so much of the history and culture. If you go early in the morning there will be less of a crowd and the heat will not be so brutal. We went there in March and it can get to be 95 degrees in the afternoon. Women must be covered up to show respect. I wore shorts and brought a long skirt with me which I did put on. They do offer woman sarong's to wear but I prefer to wear my own clothes. The beautiful pictures painted on the wall tell the story of the good king and the bad king. It is incredibly beautiful. I have traveled all over and this is one of the most awesome places I have visited.
