Must see.. The buildings around the property are very ornate and beautiful. The little buddha is smaller than expected. I bought a wrap before walking in from a street vendor to cover my shoulders. However, I was still pulled aside when I walked in and told that I had to borrow one of their shirts. None of my arms or upper shoulder was exposed so I was not sure why this was but didn't want to argue. This policy is not universally enforced as we walked past many women with spaghetti straps. Whatever you do, don't get stuck wearing one of their borrowed shirts. They don't make for very flattering pictures. We went on a Monday morning. It was very crowded However, it was not so crowded that you couldn't take a picture if you were willing to wait for a few minutes. We arrived around 10am and left around 12pm. It was sweltering hot. I couldn't imagine going any later. There are some fans in some of the buildings though so you can always squat in front of a fan if you need a break.

Small ... but exquisite!. Wat Phra Kaew houses the Emerald Buddha, which is a relatively small but exquisite statue in the main part of the temple. the temple itself is very decorative and a photographer's dream!Everywhere you look there is something to see and, with a guide who can share much of its history, the whole experience is enhanced!This was one of the most beautiful places we visited during the whole of our SE Asian adventure!
Worth seeing. We visited this temple as part of a day tour and it was definitely worth a visit. Be prepared though during peak periods it is very busy.

The painting in the gallery are gorgeous. If you only have time to do one cultural thing in Bangkok visit the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and hire a guide. The guide will cost you less than $20 and it makes all the difference in the visit. The temple buildings are spectacular and they represent Thai, Cambodian and Sri Lankan styles.

Not just another Wat. If you have enough time in Bangkok - after seeing the other main attractions - then this is still worth a visit. If time is tight then perhaps give it a miss. I went and am glad I did!

This little guy is worth the view. Emerald = Jade. Definitely don't want to take any photos - the girl next to us caused a stir with security after flashing a photo and they made her erase the photo from her camera in front of them. We had a tour guide, which made the experience more valuable than just looking at varied buddhas, statues, and bldgs on our own. A peaceful place in an otherwise busy city.
Top Sight in Bangkok. Top sight and therefore crowded, be prepard for the crowds. For photographers: Best Pictures with a fish-eye lens because one is relatively Close to the buildings
The essential visit. If you are just a short time in Bangkok you should do this. Although it is awfully crouded, this is a place you should not miss.

Disappointing. After seeing so many huge Buddha, this one was disappointing. It is very small and you can hardly see it from distance. It is very authentic and traditional. The temple is quite big and crowded. You can sit there and admire the atmosphere quietly. Just do not sit pointing your feet to the Buddha- is it a sign of lack of respect and you will probably get told off by one of its devotees and guards.
Very crowded but worth while!. This is in the Grand Palace so it was very busy when we arrived, definetly worth visiting if you are in town! :)

My Favorite Temple in Bangkok. When I entered Wat Phra Kaeo, I felt I was truly in a holy place. The Emerald Buddha is small but beautiful. It was winter so he was dressed in his winter outfit. The altar around him was filled with flowers and just pulled me in. You are not allowed to take any pictures inside. As I sat with my legs behind me a felt a peaceful feeling come over me in was a temple I longed to spend more time inside. As with all temples you must remove your shoes and leave the outside. You should also be respect with you dress: knees covered along with upper arms.
Excellent place. Very nice place to visit, the scene is so good, and plenty of tourist roaming around. It's a must place to visit in Bangkok.

Just plain beautiful. A must for EVERY tourist who visits BKK. The temples are beaitully constructed and very colorful. Watch our for scammers outside who tell you the temple is closed, as it is almost never closed.

The Emerald (aka Jade) Buddah. The palace grounds are amazing and the Emerald Buddha is a must stop--particularly if you also go to Laos. (It has a checkered past). Not very large, bring a good telephoto lens because guards prevent photos in the Wat. (We saw one man abruptly removed--not sure if he was able to keep his camera)
Worth the high entry fee alone. This temple and it's surroundings are easily the highlight of the Grand Palace complex, the Emerald Buddha temple was a real joy and very pretty.
must visit !!!. REALLY IMPRESSIVE PLACE TO VISIT. It has a lot of buildings with beautiful architectures hosting Buddha. take as many as photographs as it has different themes temples, buildings.

Very impressive and a must see whilst in Bangkok. We visited the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the Royal Palace on a combined admission ticket price of 500 bahts which as first seemed quite high compared to the cost of admission to the Reclining Buddha.However after the visit we quickly concluded that there is much to see and the admission charge represents excellent value for money.Well worth a visit.
Another Buddha highlight. Wat Phra Kaeo is a beautiful temple containing the exquisite jade "emerald" Buddha which is thought to be nearly 2000 years old.
stunning. Great beauty and calm temple must go with a knowledgeable guide to get best out of visit used Wandee tours guide was fon english speaking very good

It's worth it, if only for the photos.. Everyone that has been to Bangkok will say that you must visit Wat Phra Kaeo. It is so outrageously opulent that it has to be seen to be believed. Really. Like a city in a Star Wars sequel. Ancient Asia cum Las Vegas.It's my wallpaper!!

Excellent. Beautiful, intricate building holding a small Jade Budda which has a very expensive dress sense!
Well worth the trip

Good experience. If you are going to the Grand Palce you will want to stop by the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. The only thing I regret is not getting a hand held audio guide when we arrived. We walked blindly through everything and I think I would have learned more with an audio guide. Another thing is, they don't allow pictures in a lot of the places....

Small but Impressive. The Emerald Buddha sits high and away from the crowds and is smaller than one would initially think. It is located in the Grand Palace and is actually made of green jade and not emerald. At different seasons the Buddha is draped. Very interesting

Beautiful and glittery. The cost of entry to the place is approx 350 baht for individual and surprisingly with that I also got a free guide service that was more than helpful in taking me around the place and explaining the places to me. It’s like the place will make you blind with all the amount of gold works and the sparkling all around the place. The intricate detailing of the place is amazing and no matter where you look there is something for everybody making their jaw drop. I think this place offered one of the best photographs I had taken in whole of Bangkok. The illustrations around the place narrate the traditions and stories of the place and are good to have a guide with you to get a proper explanation to all of these.

Beautiful but very small. We visited as part of a tour of the palace grounds. Its a beautiful temple but just a pity that you can't take photographs inside. Also, I imagined that the emerald Buddha would be large, but it isn't.

Stunnign sorroundings. Note all the details at the buildings and the Emerald Temple itself. Thais love details... and porcelain. If you have been to Angkor Wat, don't miss the representation on the right side of the temple... you will be shocked how awful it looks (Even though you know it's a wonderful place as well), so you realized the antagonism between Thais and Cambodians!

Large Emerald Buddah that looks small in the temple. Our tour guide showed us a photo of the emerald buddah and it looked very impressive. He then warned us that when we enter the building, we will see a green dot and he was right. The buddah is on a high stage with gold religious items surrounding the stage and the building and stage are so large that it makes the emerald buddah seem so small. Nevertheless, an impressive sight. The temple area also has other beautiful buildings and there is also a model of Cambodia's Angor Wat. In my opinion, it's one of those attractions that you can miss but if you're in the area, then stop in.

Spectacular Temple! A must visit.. We visited the Temple of the Emerald Buddha just after the Chinese New Year and although quite a few people at the site it wasn't too bad.We went with the River Tourist Bus which cost 40 Baht each way and it was great fun and the river pier is only 5 minutes walk from the entrance to the Temple and the adjoining Grand Palace which you can visit at the same time.The temple grounds are full of smaller temples, stupas and buildings in fantastic Thai architecture covered in amazing gold mosaics and wall decorations and together with Beautiful statues in the perfectly manicured gardens make this quite a special place.The Emerald Buddha is sited in the main temple surrounded by lavish ornaments and decorations.This is the most important Buddha statue for the Thai people and it's imperative that visitors realise that this is a place of worship so long trousers and shirts with sleeves is a must.To us this is the must visit place in Bangkok and it encapsulates everything that is Thailand.Don't miss it.

Underwhelming. This was a must for me being in Bangkok however i was bored! There are lots of statues to look at however most buildings were shut... dont go on a Sunday!!!! the price was no cheaper on a Sunday but they do not warn you that most things are closed. Was there an hour and that was enough!

Historic Buddha, beautiful temple. I advise you to learn about the history of the Emerald Buddha, which has been the center of pull and push between Thailand and Laos. Wars have been waged to retrieve it, making it the symbol of Thai national identity. The history is in sharp contrast with the peaceful energy that the place has. Do not miss this beautiful attraction, especially since it's in the center of numerous other not to be missed attractions.

temple at Bangkon. this temple is very beautiful and peaceful,the temple have long history in Thailang.the evironment of temple is very clean.Monk at the temple is very friendly. I like this temple very much.

One of Bangkok's boxes you must tick. As our visit was in the middle of winter we expected wearing the mandatory covered shoulders and ankles wouldn't be a problem, we were wrong, there is a lot of ground to cover at the grand palace before you arrive at the emerald Buddha, and it's hot! Luckily we bought some banana leaf traditional Thai umbrella's (3 for 500baht) before we went in because we wouldn't have made the whole tour.We had 6 people (each with different levels of enthusiasm and interest) So we decided to get a guide I think we paid 500 baht, our guide spoke good English as gave us enough information that we felt like we learned about the Thia history, traditions and monarchy-which is of great importance to the Thia's and valuable to know about if you plan on spending any amount of time here. Our guide was incredibly patient, as half of our group are filmmakers and consequently like to "capture" their experiences-which can be timely, while waiting for our group to catch up, she shared her knowledge and experiences with us generously.Make sure you wear a hat/buy an umbrella pack your camera and take a water bottle.

dissapointed. had a high expectation about the visit. But mostly, too many tourist around to have a good view of the statue. Viewed from quite far away. Most of the tourist was just getting the opportunity to sit in the temple and not respecting it as a place of prayer for those practicing Buddhism.

Absolutely lovely!. Probably my personal favorite of all of the Buddhas. You aren't allowed to take pictures inside, and you might be just surprised at the size of this Buddha! Lots of tourists, signs to beware of pick-pockets abound. There is a central door (reserved for the King in official ceremonies) that was open while we were there allowing outside-in pictures of Buddha.

A fascinating place to see.. Unfortunately, we visited on New Years Day and it seemed most of Bangkok was there also. It was so crowded and very slow to get inside and then we were pushed on so quickly out the door, we didn't see very much! Go on a quieter day if you can!

Amezing. i dont know how i can say what amezing temple in bangkok, i think its a number one temple in bangkok, so beautiful and big temple in grand palace. i been there many times with friends and family

Dispointed. Even if it's a small wonder, the guards don't allow pictures to be taken and push visitors to shorten their stay to a couple of seconds, one minute at most. There is no information plaque, so without a guide, it's useless

Beautiful and must be seen. You may have visited many fine Buddhist temples in Asia but this is a "must". It is full of magnificent architecture and gilded roofs and elegant mythical statues large and small.The Emerald Buddha just took my breath away with it's simplicity and beauty.I am so grateful that non-Buddhists are permitted to see all of this. Thank you.

Must see in Bangkok. Tour starts early due to midday heat - approx. 8 am. Due to the political ongoing demonstrations Bangkok is 50% less busy and therefore no crowds in the palace meant we could move around and take our time. Interesting place even if you are not interested in Buddism - architecture is amazing.

a must!!!. an excellent day out! we loved it and didn't even get to see all of the displays. so much to see and many tourists seemed to miss the painted colonnade... beautiful. watch out for some of the local guides...some traipse you around really quickly... others take great pride in taking you around

Like an Eastern Disneyland. It's an amazing place, absolutely worth visiting.....bloody hard work though! It's so hot and there's little shelter and it's basically crowd surfing in sweaty clothes while being blinded by the blinged out temples and monuments. Do it, spend a couple of hours, be glad you saw it, then bail and get a cold drink and enjoy yourself.

Buddhisme at a high level. Very unique and beautiful buddha in an unique setting. The royal Palace in Bangkok. The walls explain many histrories of the royal Family and Buddha life. Don't forget to visit the museul that is dedicated to the Emeral Buddha; it shows a lot of inside of the Buddha, which comes from the nrth of Thailand but spend many years in Laos.
Don't miss it!. If temples aren't your thing, but you want to see at least one while in Bangkok than this is the one! Don't miss out on seeing the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. It is amazing!

Lots of restoration taking place. I visited this temple about 6 years ago but this time there seemed to be much more work taking place. The entrance fee is about £10 but does include the new Queen Sirikit museum entrance fee. An impressive display of the Queen's textile work with local producers.
great experience. The complex is beautiful ,would advise visiting before it gets hot.the audio guide was a v.good option

Distinctively ornate!. This temple is part of the Grand Palace complex and so incredibly ornate, you won't know where to start or stop taking pictures. The thing you CAN'T photograph is the Emerald Buddha which will be wearing one of three outfits, depending on the season. They do have postcards, however...
Very stunning. Amazing architecture but always very crowded and impossible to escape the heat. Protests made it hard to get around

another nice well ornamented temple. I must admit I get tired of seeing these things... however this is very ornate... and a little different. I have been here 3 times now and still like the afternoon into later evening or best of all early in the morning... these are the best photo opportunities.

It's ok..... Luckily it's included as part of the grand palace complex and ticket. 500baht is steep to see a temple and a Buddha, but, when in Rome....This is ok, you can't take photos though. (No guards when we went, so people were taking photos)We went on a very hot day. So it was not a great day for us. If it was cooler, maybe I'd appreciate it more.Hot tip - you need long pants! Men as well. You can borrow/rent them at the entry or nip over the road to the conveniently placed shops selling pants to tourists. They are only 100baht for a cool pair of light pants. If it's hot - don't wear jeans. Women will need sleeves! No singlets, and keep the buttons done up.Can be done straight after the reclining Buddha. Then go to the zoo!
Adorable Buddha. Small in comparison to others in the area, but still amazing. Beautiful craftsmen ship with plenty of bling. Yet, at the same time you can feel the spiritual importance of the piece.

Best Detail of Art. Amazing.... It is a beautiful temple.. so much detail in everything.. the wall painting is superb... Everything is so perfect... this place is a must to visit.. but you have to use proper cloths.. It seems so many rude guard in front of the gate that will tell you what to wear... Really worth to go. Bring a lot of drink and umbrella since the place is so hot at noon.
Wow! Another wonderful temple experience!. This was a delightful place to go! Bangkok's temples are so highly decorated they are a joy to behold! A little crowded but a real phot opportunity!
Emeral Buddha. It is amazing and people respect the temple and all foot wear have to removed and walk bare feet. There are so many tourists and you have to wait for your turn

Top Memorable Experience. A must see! Remember to wear a shirt that covers shoulders and long pants. A shawl at this temple is not enough to be admitted on the grounds. If you only have a shawl or are wearing tight pants or shorts they will provide clothes for you with a deposit. Easier to just bring the correct clothes. I saw way to many westerners arguing with the guards at the temple. It was very embarrassing. Just wear the correct clothing and avoid the confrontation. As a tourist we are on someone else's land and at a sacred site. Respect.

Marvel in the wonders. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is marvelous... so much time, effort and love has been put into this Temple. It is such a peaceful and wonderful place to be. The Emerald Buddha is beautiful, take the time to stop and ponder on the details and beautiful things within the Temple.

Good Lord the Ramakien Mural Cloisters!. The temple is one of my favorite in Thailand. The walls of its main temple are covered with colorful mosaics and shinny golds. Not to mention the golden statues and pagoda. And did I mention the long long Ramakien Mural Cloisters around the temple? They are beyond words, depicting an ancient Buddhism story. I'd love to hire a guide to tell me every detail of the whole story. But sadly, I didn't have enough time for that. So if you plan to visit this temple, you might want to do a little research on its history. One more thing: the temple is within the Grand Palace, whose ticket includes the temple as well. Do enjoy a wonderful time here!

This temple and its surroundings are just insane. Doing temples in Bangkok is really an experience. I got started of with Wat Pho, did Wat Arun after that and then came to this area with the temple of the emerald Buddha and the grand palace. And I think I would do them in that order were I to revisit them.Moving along though this temple is just insanely glittery and there is so much fitted in to this pretty limited area except the hall housing the emerald buddha, there is for example a miniature of Angkor Wat in Cambodia and much more. So plan your time accordingly!As said the area might not be super big, but they kind of through everything in there so seeing it all can be a little bit challenging, I mean you will be like a kid on christmas eve, there is just so much shiny things! Then of course, being a really common tourist attraction the place is really crowded!

The grounds at the Emerald Buddha are beautiful. The grounds at the temple of the Emerald Buddha are absolutely one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. Spend some time here because you will want to take many pictures. No pictures are allowed inside the temple though.

Worth a visit if 1st time in Bangkok. The buildings are beautiful. I was not as impressed with the Budduha. I enjoyed the architecture and grounds more. Dress appropriately, they are strict! Great photo ops too.

under whelming and over-zealous staff. The Wat itself is pretty enough and the shrine covered in gold and glitter HOWEVER the main attraction, the emerald buddha, is very small and is actually jade! The guards there are very intrusive telling you to "sit down, sit down" but had I sat on the floor I would never have got back up again so I didn't feel able to linger for long and enjoy the visit. My husband also had his camera checked before we left and photos deleted. All in all not a great experience
beautiful temple. it is so crowded every time, but worth to visit to worsip the emerald budda.

Don't expect a large Budha.. I had it in my head this was going to be a floor to ceiling size Budha - so I was a little disappointed - but now I know !Ignore anyone approaching you saying that the Temple is closed and that you should return later. This is all to do with you spending money elsewhere - we were nearly taken in !

Awesome sight. This is one of the more popular places so it was crowded, but there is a lot to see. It is connected with the Grand Palace tour but this is the highlight of the two. You can not take pictures of the inside, but the view is great and there are other buildings and sights to capture with a camera.

Most important Temple for your visit. The royal Wat Phra Kaeo should be your foremost place to visit in Bangkok. I have visited this city seven times and on this recent visit enjoyed the Temple (Wat) as much as ever.

Nice but nothing special. The Temple of emerald Buddha is nice to see but nothing special with respect to the temples you can find in Bangkok and in Thailand in general. The Grand Palace complex, inside which the temple is located, is really wonderful and impressive. The emerald Buddha statue (that, to be precise, is a jade Buddha) is small and in high position inside the temple, far from you. It is very famous since it is one of the most sacred in Thailand, but you feel a bit disappointed by the emerald Buddha.

Peaceful & calm. The thai architecture is amazing. The details and delicate work found at different corners of the building is unique. The place is huge and peaceful. There were lots of people coming to worship or ask for daily blessings.The statute is crafted with skilled hands.
Precious little gem. The Thais are proud of there history and this is a beauitful example where they are trying to preserve it. it is all lovely there.

Worth seeing.... As a part of Grand palace tour... the 1st step is Wat Phra Kaeo... intecrately decorative and well preserved temple complex... heaven to take photos... though the main Emrald Buddha is far away on a throne, the paintings on temple wall will astonise you.

cant take photos inside but can get a good shot thru door.. if your going to be in thailand, at least look at some of these amazing sights. not only the Emerald Buddha but the surrounding grounds make this an experience you will always remember.

Beautiful! A must in Bangkok. Simply said, this is a must if you're in Bangkok for a few days. This self guided tour can be combined with a visit to the Grand Palace. All in, it's about $15 (USD) for to foreigners to visit these temples and the Grand Palace. Worth your while!
How do they get the frocks on?. The tiny figure of the Jade buddha dressed by the Crown Prince according to the season sits above a plethora of gold leafed statues and models.

Fantastic!. I loved the whole complex, a must see for everybody. Loved the wallpainting, with the thai version of Mahabharata, with the Hanuman figures. The buildings were spectaculare, so rich in visual, that I cant compare any other experiences of me to it.

Great temple, very crowded. Out of all the Wats I visited in Bangkok this is definitely the most popular and very crowded. No cameras, hats or shoes allowed inside the temple. If I'm not mistaken the Emerald Buddha wears different clothing depending on the season. I learned this from the Pavilion of Regalia just before the entrance to Wat Phra Kaew. Be sure not to miss it during your visit.

A small Buddha for a great kingdom. The temple is a must as it's a beautiful sight. Both men n women must wear full length trousers. Photography is not permitted inside but carry a zoom lens to take pictures of the statue from outside. The weather is ok in january !Finally, sit in the temple for few minutes and let yourself to drown in the peace!Wat Phra Kraew is part of the Grand Palace and visit in the entrance ticket which costs 500 baht per person! It is open from 8.30 to 15.30, except New Year and Songkran Holidays!Small statue 45 inches tall emerald had many "homes", and it's here in 1784!The Emerald Buddha itself is simply the Jadeite statue,[4] but it is adorned with garments made of gold. There are three different sets of gold clothing, which are changed by the King of Thailand or a liaison in a ceremony at the changing of the seasons – in the 1st Waning of lunar months 4, 8 and 12 (around March, July and November). The three sets of gold garments correspond to Thailand's summer season, rainy season, and cool season!

Culture in Bangkok City Centre 2. Another amazing place to visit, inside the Grand Palace complex. You will probably only spend 10-15 minutes, but due to the large crowds you cannot spend a lot of time here. Also, be aware that you won't be able to take any photos inside, although if you have a good camera you can take a photo through the doorway. The best bet is to buy the postcard!

Must see in Bangkok. The Grand Palace and the Temple of the Emerald Buddha are a must see in Bangkok! Don't be surprised if someone outside the entrance tells you that this attraction is closed, it's open every day. It'll take a few hours to walk around the palace as there is lot's to see. The Buddha itself is quite small and adorned in gold clothing, but worth a visit and the tapestry inside the temple is spectacular.

Now that is Interesting!. Beautiful ! What I did not learn in Myanmar about Buddhism, I l was even more informed here, our guide, being a aThai Buddhist herself and a guide for 36 years, was truly informative and thorough. This would be a must see site when visiting Bangkok to get a sense of it's " spiritual " and political heritage.

Top attraction in Bangkok. Wat Phra Kaeo in Grand Palace is absolutely the top attraction of Bangkok. Take care for your clothes, no short and open shoulders are allowed. Also take care for the "advisors" in the street just at the entrance to Grand Palace who try to convince you to visit different other Buddha monuments instead. We were told that the Palace is closed but "naturally" it was open. Someone else told us that What Arun is closed but again it was open. Do onot listen to these people!Wat Phra Kaeo includes several beautifully decorated buildings including the home of emerald Buddha. You may spend 2 hours among thees building there are so many beauties around.Unfortunately there are no English information tables this is why some time it is difficult to understand what you see.

Emerald Buddah. Yet another temple!!!!! Quite different from a lot of the others you will see in Thailand given that it is emerald (or Jade in this case). I was surprised by the actual size of the Buddha as it was quite small compared to a great deal of the others although that made it stand out!The Bhudda is housed in a great temple although be aware, no women are allowed within the temple housing the statue. you can get decent shots from outside if you have a decent lens on the camera. Depending on the time of year he is dressed in different outfits (made of Gold!). I would recommend visiting this attraction along with the rest of the Grand Palace!

Don't point your feet at him!. Impressive and very sacred - interesting to find out the buddha is dressed in different attire for each season so worth visiting more than once if you can. Just be respectful and don't point your feet towards him - you'll get told off!

Bit underwhelming, I thought. With all the wonderful wats/temples in Bangkok, not to mention the multitude of buddhas, this one was disappointing. It is always very crowded; you can't get close to see the statue(which is pretty small to start with!), and it's wrapped in 'clothes'; no photos inside; and the layout, design and general appearance of the temple is not a lot different from others, so I was not overly impressed. I thought the nearby buildings (eg the gold jedi and the library) were both much more impressive and individual, with better ornamentation.

Royal Shrine. This is inside the grounds of the Grand Palace and is therefore included in the Grand Palace ticket and is worth doing. Made from a single piece of jade (the green colour giving it it's name) the statue wears gold adornments that are changed by the King three times a year, one for each season of winter, summer and monsoon. Remember to cover up legs and shoulders. The palace has a FREE guided tour of the complex in ENGLISH 3 times a day - morn 11 and afternoon 1.30 and 2.30 - our guide was excellent. Ticket to enter Grand Palace complex is bundled with three exhibitions, the Grand Palace complex, the Pavilion of Regalia, and the Queen Sirikit textile museum. So make sure you don't skip any of them.
a wonderful thing to behold. one of the many beautiful things to see in Bangkok. the colours all gleam with life. the gold shines in a vision of beauty. the emerald is huge.
Very impressive Buddha. The emerald Buddha was a very impressive one. But after looking at so many, you kind of get jaded to look and assess the quality of the Buddhas.

Grandiose. What a wonderful and beautiful place - certainly a must to visit. But you must be appropriately dressed - if not you will be directed to where you can get a skirt (sarong style) and pay a refundable amount of 200baht. Such richness with statues decorated in gold. Despite the fact that it is a tourist attraction there is still a feeling of peace and serenity with so many praying to pay respect for or towards one's needs.Definitely a place of must go, see and experience, and if lucky you might also witness a process of the Guards.
Beautiful. Was impressive, but the complex was not as impressive as the reclining Budda, but definitely worth a visit
Must see Temple. Interesting temple with a more spiritual than tourist experience. We enjoyed meeting some monks. A little off the beaten path.
one of my favorites. While I enjoy visiting all of the temples, this one is always my favorite. Peaceful, serene and easily accessible.

Temple is serine and peaceful... The visit to this temple can be made along with grand palace since the temple is right inside the grand palace vicinity and therefore there is no separate entry ticket for this place..The temple is beautiful and very peaceful.. Most of the people pay visit to the place during their visit to bangkok.. Has a lot of religious importance..So worth one time visit..

Absolutely beautiful. Visiting this Buddha is probably the best part of the Royal Palace complex and being in this temple is a true privilege. If you are in the Palace complex and it is busy, full of people, hot and sticky and you are tempted to give this a miss; don't. Go in and enjoy the statue and the (relative) solitude.
Beautiful building. This place is always crowded and it can be a challenge to take photos. The Emerald Buddha is small but impressive.

Beautiful Temples. This Temple was huge. It is definitely worth seeing. Make sure the women bring something to cover themselves as you can't go in with your shorts and a tank shirt. Long pants and a shawl would be needed.
Part of the tour. Full of people but easy to move around. Stay there a while make your wishes and listen to the stories they tell about it, how it get "dressed"by the king, etc..
Such a beautiful Jade Buddha. The Emerald Buddha is an immense single piece of jade. They have built a new temple for it so it can be seen from all sides. Unfortunately they don't allow photos.

Amazing temple complex. The whole complex is really beautiful. This was a real highlight of our trip to Bangkok - have a good walk around the grounds and other buildings as well as looking at the Emerald Buddha himself - there are all sorts of beautiful details to see.We bought our ticket as part of the Grand Palace entrance fee - not sure if you can buy it separately - but definitely worth seeing both even if a bit expensive (500 baht) compared to other temples. As other reviewers have said make sure you are well covered (at least no shoulders and knees). if you are inappropriately dressed you will be lent garments to cover up with.

A real eye opener.. This Grand Palace and Temple complex is a real eye-opener and a must see in Bangkok. It is a demonstration of Thai culture, heritage, religion and oppulence. The Buddha itself is small and is actually made from Jade but the sheer size and nature of the complex itself is truly amazing and it takes nearly a half a day to thoroughly get around all the buildings to see everything on offer. This is the second time i have been through this complex and i think only now the second time have i managed to experience the entire place! Be aware though that both male and females need to be appropriately dressed, so to get in quicker make sure you carry a sarong or long pants in your pack and wear a shirt that covers your shoulders. Also, there are always those people outside the palace who will try to tell you the place is closed or redirect you to the wrong entrance. Just ignore them and make your way around to the right opening and enter.

One of many Bangkok's great temples. Hot weather and full of people, still definitely worth of visit. One of the best temples in Bangkok and lot to see, so don't forget your camera and despite the weather, ladies don't come in mini skirts and tank tops
The best. There was something about this Buddha which made me feel it was looking at me. Total feeling extra special. A no miss attraction

If you want to see a masterpiece. The whole complex is a masterpiece of art and architecture. It is crowded but definitely worth visiting. Don't forget to wear proper clothes. Bring bottled water and hat.

big jade buddha. big jade buddha in the grand palace, on the tourist route must see in bangkok, it is what it is. grand palace is a bit pricey to enter compared to everything else. watch out for the bangkok jewellry scam men everywhere in this part of bangkok

Slightly disappointing. I was somewhat disappointed by this experience in the Grand Palace. I mean you're probably still going to do it anyway.The emerald buddha is a lot smaller than the other buddhas you might encounter. You'll also see it from pretty far away. Unlike many of the temples where you can actually have a meditative experience, instead you'll be thronged with a surging mass of tourists coming and going. Don't plan on any *experience* here.

Crowded but beautiful. Brace yourself. When you enter the Grand Palace you see the beauty of this place. It is magnificent. gold and mosaic sculptures await you inside. It is unfortunate that you can not take photos of the emerald Buddha but I guess this helps enjoy the place more rather than running around for the best photo.We were there in high season and therefore the temple was packed but we did not feel claustrophobic. A guided tour would be recommended. We did not take one but we followed a group around and it was very informative.Definitely a must see.
Cool. In Thailand if you want to visit important sights include this on you list. It's location on the river makes it easy to get to. BTW take the local boats, and pay on the boat.
Amazing. Loved this place, although there is always lots of people visiting it is one of the most beautiful places I've visited. The colors, the materials, the Buda, the palace, it is worth a visit!

Wat Phra Kaeo - emerald Buddha. Give yourself at least three hours to leisurely walk through the grounds. There is a lot to see besides the Emerald Buddha. There are murals on the wall depicting the Hindu Ramayan which the Thais call Ramakien. Sit and relax in the shade and listen to the buddhist nuns recite prayers. A miniature version of the Cambodian Angor Wat is displayed on the grounds as well. Well worth the price.

A Must See. Despite being overcrowded and costly vs other temples, this is definitely a must do at least once. Every square inch of space has been decorated and you will find yourself taking photos at every turn of the complex (with the exception of the inside of the temple)

Bigger than you think. Wow really a sight to see, from the pictures and after seeing the reclining Buddha I was expecting to see a larger than human statue but in reality it was only about two feet in height on top of a huge throne of jewels. A must see!

Must see. The Buddha statue is way up and quite small in size. Made from very good quality jade.But if you go inside and sit down you will get to see the detail in the stairs and ceiling. We hired a guide. Helpful to have them. Because it is winter he was draped in gold shawl. There is so much detail in and around the temple. The tile work and colors is amazing.

Breathtaking structures. Tickets are included with the grand palace entry. One of the better part from the whole grand palace complex, simply amazing view, downside is we can't take a picture of the buddha inside the structure.Went there ard 2.30, blazing hot, bring ur sunglass, bottled water, hat and sun cream just in case.

beautiful. temple is beautiful, one of my favourite that i visited in bangkok. loved all the mosaic and surrounding structures. found this one to be peaceful. It is part of your entrance fee to the grand palace. in my opinion this is the only part of the grand palace worth visiting and could have skipped the rest. entrance fee however is quite steep at about 16cdn.
Beautiful temple. Very impressive temple and beautiful Buddha than changes jewelry with the seasons. The emerald Buddha is much smaller than you'd expect, but still worth a visit.

One must visit. It is one of the most beautiful temples I ever visited. Utilize most of your time in this complex here. Go to this place by boat from pier near to your hotel. This cheapest and faster way to travel. When you buy the ticket it comes with grand palace ticket. I donot recommend to rent their recorded guide as you will get free hard copy of the complex when you enter. There is dress code to wear dress below knee and no sleeveless. Do not rent pajamas by outside vendors as clean wrap arounds will be given inside the premises.
Amazing. Amazing architecture and the inside of the temple is spectacular! The tiles around the outside of the building are beautiful. You really have to see this temple if you go to Bangkok.
no pictures. Only downfall was we could not take pictures and he is a smaller Buddha. It is a very pleasant area.

Not to be missed. There is a lot of history about the Emerald Buddha that is very important to Thai culture. Be sure to read up before you go so that you understand the import of this temple. Also, take time to meditate or sit quietly with locals on the carpet. You can get a really good view from there.

Busy place but worth it. This temple is on the grounds of the Grand Palace and you pay to see both when you purchase tickets. The outside of the temple is wonderful to look at with so much detail and color. The inside of the temple is open to tourist but no photographs or video are allowed inside. It is easy enough to stand outside the windows which are usually open and snap photos. Use your zoom lens for a great pic. The rest of the grounds can be explored as well. Remember your long pants or skirt or they have ones to borrow for a deposit. Short sleeves or longer for adults too.
A must!. Pros:BeautifulJust see this temple in Bangkok is enoughThey provide clothes if yours are inadequate (you make a deposit and get it back)Cons:Can get hot so bring water!500 baht per person

Worth a visit. Very ornate and beautiful, for me I love it here, not my first visit..for my boyfriend an hours visit was enough but worth a visit. Do watch out for the scams...but I think every review will tell you that. Do go dressed correctly, longish trousers, shoulders covered....however flip flops are allowed!
Gorgeous. Just gorgeous.. This is part of a larger complex that houses the Emerald Palace. It's pretty amazing. Visually striking.

spectacular. another amazing location in Bangkok... with places to go and sit and relax the whole area here is great... the temple was lovely... with pics taken outside to the Buddha... and sitting inside was moving and insipring to look around...

Good design work. Temple of emerald Buddha is one of the best places here. It was nice to see such a good sculpture and was really amazed by the detailed work done by workers in building this temple. My complete family liked this temple a lot and we spent almost more than 2 hours there.

Beautiful. This temple is very beautiful! Don't be let down by the size of the Buda and pay attention to all the amazing details.
Recommend to get an audio guide or tour guide to get the details right.

Impressive building, little Buddha. Well worth visiting the whole Grand palace site if you are in Bangkok. Amazing asian architecture. Husband didn't like it though as he found it too gaudy and glittery. Not my style but I still couldn't help being impressed. Quite expensive to get in at 500 baht each, kids were free if under 1.2 m tall.

Within Grand Palace. Really this doesn't deserve its own page, because if you go into the grand palace, you will see the Emerald Buddah. Very interesting looking. There's some history and ritual going on here that is not well explained, so do some research before you come or come with a tour guide. You must remove your shoes and no photography inside. Smaller than expected, but still interesting to see.

Nice but could not see much. There was a long queue around the room where the Buddha is kept, but the main problem is that the (small) statue is really far and I could not see much. It is indeed a nice piece of art, worh going if you are visiting the Royal Palace.

very beautiful. Agree totally with other contributors - you should get there early and take a parasol if you don't like the sun. I took a guided tour (in English) that was included in the cost of the entrance fee and it was good to do. Also make sure that you dress conservatively - no short and singlets - long trousers or dress and cover your shoulders. It is all about respecting this important religious site.
Worth visiting. The Emerald Buddha itself was good, but it was that in conjunction with the surrounding area that made the visit really worthwhile.

Vast and impressive. Arrive very early in the morning in order to beat the huge crowds. There is so much to see on different levels. We loved the model of Anghor Wat. It might be worth reading up beforehand about the various areas of the complex and it would be interesting to know the details of the Ramakian, if you are so inclined. The many scenes painted on the walls are beautiful but require some explanation.
Double standards keeps on. Entrance Fee :Foreigner 500 Baht.Thai FREE.It is Thai way.

Glittering Temple. Perfect location for taking memorable photos. The temple seemed to just glitter and shine on the day we were there.Make sure you dress appropriately, otherwise you will have to rent uncomfortable hot clothing.Tour guides wait outside to offer to help you. I prefer not to have someone talking the whole time. Instead just leaisurly explore the temple. Bring one of the DK books to give you insight instead.The Emerald Buddha was much smaller than we expected.

Well worth a visit. Liked: fascinating to see all the amazing temples
Disliked: Beware of the folks outside the gates that try to tell you that it is closed and that they can take you to another temple in the meantime. They lie.
Uniquely beautiful sight. Very detailed architecture on this stunning landmark, worth a visit. Make sure you wear trousers or you will be sold some funky ones to wear on your visit.

symbol of Bangkok. Wonderful place. The temple is preety big so plan about 2 hours to visit it. Always there are a lot of tourists, so you will wait a moment to ticket office. It is not allowed to take a picture of Buddha and Thai people are wery keen of it. You are not allowed to visit a temple when Thai people have its holidays and prayers.
This is astounding. I spent the entire time walking around here in awe. The building itself is incredible. Just don't miss the Buddha himself.

Absolutely AMAZING. This is a highly education and awe-inspiring visit for people of any age. The entire temple and the Grand Palace are all breathtaking and really provide an insight into Thai culture and Buddhism itself. I would recommend renting an audio guide for 200Baht, as it provides an in-depth guide to all the attractions, and will leave you with a wealth of knowledge. Remember to wear long pants, as you will required to rent these if you do not. This venue requires 1-3 hours to explore and try to be patient with the horde of tourists that will be there. Water is required or face the overpriced stall owners. Many great photo opportunities here and a MUST visit!

A must visit... but don't fall prey to scams.... The Temple and Grand Palace are a definite must see when in Bangkok. But there are a lot of traps for tourists approaching the Grand Palace. Just ignore anyone giving you advices and tips. Especially those who recommend another temple to see for 1-2 hours because they say the Grand Place is closed for some functions. There are organised networks of scam professionals, from the fake-badged guides or passer-bys to tuk tuk drivers, who take you to overprices shops.

Gold, gold, gold. an amazing experience; a must do for visitors to Bangkok. The whole Grand palace experience is a worthwhile visit. Allow at least half a day and take plenty of cold drinks for the hot weather.

2nd time lucky. Awestruck! Simply Beautiful! Photographers...please carrry a wide angle lens! Please give yourself atleast 4 hours for this trip! and do wear full clothes otherwise you might have to pose in really colourful pants which you have to rent :D!

Leave Your Shoes. Since you have to leave your shoes at the gate, I was worried a bit that someone might mistakenly pick it up. Perhaps they could implement a system for this, given we had to pay a huge amount. The temple itself was serene and beautifully decorated.

Grand, "must see list". The Temple is very crowded.Men must wear long trousers, women skirts that go below the knees. All must cover their shoulders.This is strictly enforced, a way around is to borrow stuff at the entrance. The deposit is refunded.The temple closes at 15:30 but if you get in then, you have an hour with only few people and can savor the place rather undisturbed.Go from there a short walk to Wat Po and also havw a much smaller crowd than usual.

Wat Phra Kaeo. This is located inside The Grand Palace. Make sure you won't miss this as the Entrance of Grand Palace costs 500 Baht per person, this includes the Emerald Buddha.
Very beautiful Buddha.

JUST WOW!. It's a great temple in a great complex. The temple is beautiful. It has amazing painting and a very tinny but beautiful emerald buddha. This buddha is inside the grand palace so if you go inside the grand palace you have to see this.

Must See. We didn't know what exactly to expect when we arrived at the Grand Palace but it was huge, gorgeous and we ended up spending a few hours there! We traveled Thailand for 2.5 weeks and it was easily the largest and most intricate temple we visited. In our opinion, a must see in Bangkok
One of the must see in Bangkok. This is the highlight or must see or do when in Bagnkok. May also join the guided tour which is free.
Interesting but tiny. The temples in general are very impressive. Knowing that the Buddha is made of emerald is impressive but you can barely see it.
In Grand palace complex. Very crowded, Buddha statue is very tiny and situated on a high platform. This was a religious site more than tourist.
Worth a look. Very crowded, but the inside has a calmness, the buddha is striking, you are not allowed to take pictures inside.

Most sacred temple in Thailand. A magical place full of great energy.
We saw the Emerald Buddha (which really is Jade) in his winter clothes.
Lovely. The temple is quite crowded (not surprising) and the Buddha is very high and far away, but it is still an impressive sight and the Buddha is beautiful.

Beautiful. Absolutely gorgeous. I really enjoyed the size of the Buddha (tiny) versus that building (huge). Make sure you dress appropriately or they won't let you in without wearing long pants and sleeves. You can rent stuff but it looked fairly uncomfortable.

Must See-As part of your other tours. We took this in as part of our overall tour of the city. As said before it can be crowded, no you do not need a guide, but we had a private city tour guide which made the experience better. Spent at the most 30 mins to look and discuss. It can be crowded- there were people there praying so can be quiet. Meditative? I guess depends upon the time of day. However, you really need to visit at least once and learn some of its back story; because as I found out on the guided trip this time, much more to the back stories than just in the guide books.

Crowded but serene. The temple (including the surrounding area) was very crowded, but incredibly serene inside. People were respectful and it felt very peaceful just sitting there on the ground and admiring the Buddha and ornaments. One of the number of places in Bangkok where a visit is warranted at least once.
Grand. Although this was awe inspiring, it was very crowded. We were able to pay our respect to the Emerald Buddha. Best to come early to avoid the crowds.

Overrated and Overdone, but worth seeing once.. Overrated and Overdone, but worth seeing once. Like over the top temples and shrines, a bit too congested, overkill and very crowded if not early. Worth seeing once, as its rather pricey for Thailand. Otherwise, if overly decadent palaces are not your vibe, avoid!

Part of your Grand Palace Tour - that is where it is.. The forst time I went to bangkok, I booked my tours as soon as I arrived. One fopr the Grand Palace, One for the Emerald Buddha and another for Wat Po. They are all next to eachother and you don't need a tour nor a guide.The emerald Buddha, is tiny atop his huge table, but the whole of the Grand Palace is one of the best contained tourist attractions in the world. It easily compares with the pyramids.You will need to wear long trousers and women need to be covered. If you don't take something with you, they have them to load as you go in. Don't go by Tuk Tuk, they will tell you it is closed and take you somewhere else. Get on an orange flag River Boat and get off at the Grand Palace Dock - it is so simple
A gem in Bangkok. Loved the Grand Palace and the emerald buddha. A beautiful historical camp, would recommend to get there early and to get the audio map.
Fabulous Temple. Another amazing temple - You must add this to your itinerary if visiting Bangkok, we loved every minute

Tiny on the pedestal, not easy to see. This is worth a peek when you're inside the Grand Palace. Our guide showed us an image outside of the clothing that the emerald Buddha wears to match the three seasons of Thailand (and no, their seasons are not hot, hotter and hottest: they have summer, winter and rainy and the King drapes this Buddha in gold clothing to match each season).Take your shoes off outside. It's tough to see the Buddha because it is not huge, and it sits on a high pedestal in the middle of the temple. Many people kneel to pray in front so you can't get too close, and no photos are allowed. Interesting history, though, on how and where it was discovered. Read about it before you go if you don't have a guide.
Peaceful. Love that picture taking and videoing is banned inside the temple. One feels a sense of peace and quietness entering the temple.
amazing!!!. i don't have any particular dislike w/ this place.........it's amazing merely looking at the said temple.........
A must see. The emerald Buddha is a must see. The temple guards are amazing. Also visit Wat Po for a massage at the school located on the grounds. You will not regret it.

small but attractive Buddha. The Buddha is seated on a tall pedestal and it is quite small compared to several other Buddha statues you see around. But it looks attractive and fascinating. It has an emerald color.
Amazing temple complex. One of the most beautifull temples in Thailand. Dont forget to visit also the museum, it is very interesting
Need to check it out. This temple is really cool. It's on the grounds of the Grand Palace. The Buddha is really small because it's made of pure Emerald. It's really neat.
Worth the visit. The Emerald Buddha itself is a great sight! And also the compound just outside the temple. A very pleasing walk, recommended to get a guide for a more wholesome experience.

A must visit place!!!. its an astonishing temple...truly conforming to its name... its the best part of palace... the interior and architecture/ beauty just catches the eye of beholder.. its worth although they charge tourists some 500 Baht.

Fine Designs. Located within the Grand Palace compound so the the admission fee to this temple is included from the TH฿500 pass to the Grand PalaceNo video recording and picture taking allowed inside and there are marshals who will ensure that the policy is complied.You also need to leave your shoes, sandals, and sleepers in the racks just outside the temple.The grand Palace opens at 08:30AM so be there while there are still few tourists.
Excellent. Loved all the temples and the amazing Buddha statues. Please take the time to visit as many temples as you can as they are all incredible.

A Temple you must see. This temple is in the Grand Palace. If you see anything in Bangkok, spend the time to see the Grand Palace and this temple. The amazing gold and inlaid stones are simply beautiful and must be seen. Yes, you will be there with many other tourists, its worth it. Take you time to enjoy all of the Palace.
Got to love it!. This is one of the major go-to attractions when visiting Bangkok. Got to love it. The entire complex including the palace is absolutely astonishing.
Small but beautiful. The temple itself is beautiful and the atmosphere is so calm and serene, despite many people. What strikes you is that the Emerald Buddha is so small, but it is very exquisite.

Getting there is worth it. The Emerald Buddha itself isn't much to look at, but the temple complex around it is spectacular. Definitely worth the trip! If you REALLY want a pic of the Emerald Buddha, be sure to bring a telephoto lens--no pics allowed inside!

Beautiful temple. The temple is located within the grand palace and is a beautiful example of Buddhist temple.
This is a beautiful temple with very beautiful murals, paintings and beautiful work on walls, pillars etc. it is a beautiful temple and worth a visit,

Big Temples in same style. Close (within three blocks) to other big temples. If you want to see four of the biggest Temples in one day, that no problem as they are all next to each other or just across the river and you can take a (cross river) fairy at 5Bath to get to the other side.

The place is Handful. The size of the whole emerald Buddha isn’t much in comparison to real life but even though it is unmatched in its aura and beauty with all the adornments on the Buddha against the strikingly beautiful and intricate background of the temple and moreover the whole complex is different in its charm. Sadly they do not allow you to take photographs inside the temple which is understandable considering the fact that it is still an active temple. The only problem is that the crowd gets to you in your experience and if you seek for a little time to admire the place, then it could be difficult. While there I also saw some of the monks in practice and it was a divine view to have experienced with the whole interiors of the temple. The temple forms the part of the Grand Palace complex and like many other structures around it, the place is breathtaking. The place opens around 8 in the morning and expects you to be modestly dressed. It will be a good thing to catch this place early in the morning to avoid the push and pulls of the crowds.

Best part of Grand Palace. This building is beautiful. Located inside the The Grand Palace it is the the highlight. It is smaller than you'd think but the room is decorated with lots of statues and the walls are painted wonderfully. It is a great spot to go inside, sit, pray, relax, and stare in awe.Be aware that to enter the Grand Palace complex you have to be wearing long pants and have your shoulders covered. They offer free clothes to wear if you are not dressed correctly, though there is a long line. You can "rent" a pair of pants just outside the gate for 30 Baht.

Smaller than expected, but impressive. As a first-time visitor, you are not sure what to expect. As a fan of emerald I appreciated the beauty, and loved the beauty of the temple where it is housed. I am glad we got a chance to see this beauty.

Worth a visit. Worth going to see as the entrance fee for the grand palace includes this. Shame you can't take photos inside the temple but plenty of other photo opportunities within the palace grounds

Visiting the Emerald Buddha. The emerald Buddha is something worth seeing. He is MUCH smaller than I expected but is pretty magnificent none-the-less. The story of the King ( or price these days as the king is rather elderly) changing his golden clothes three times a year is well worth hearing about as is visiting the robes themselves ( displayed elsewhere on the grounds of theGrand Palace).
Nice. Liked the palace complex in general. The Emerald Buddha was smaller than what I had imagined but none the less we got a good view. Must do on your Bangkok list

Absolutely beautiful!. The buddha is quite small but hey, it is all done with Emeralds! I believe it is one piece of emerald only.... you cannot take pictures inside of the temple but on the outside bit you can still see the buddha and take pictures of the buddha. I recommend people to be quiet please, I saw so many tourists being extremely rude while the monks were praying. Remember that even though it is a tourist attraction, it is still a temple!

Over crowded an difficult to appreciate. We visited this attraction on 20 Dec and even with a private guide we were relieved to get out. The crowds were immense, however the intricate work on each of the palaces was spectacular. As to be expected no photos or videos of the Buddha are allowed but due tone crowds we really did not get a chance to stand and appreciate what we were seeing. We were moved along quickly and everyone was pushing and shoving so unfortunately not a great experience. I am sure on another day there would be a lot more to appreciate, I am sure we were just unlucky.

Stunning temple. The temple is stunning and the complex is very nice. We were lucky that it wasn't too busy when we were there so we got great pictures and the sun was shining beautifully on the jewels and gold. Be aware that no sleeveless shirts or shorts/skirts above the knee are allowed (man or woman). Thankfully, they do have clothes you can rent to put on over your clothes or you can come prepared.
Beautiful but crowded. It is a large temple located inside of Grand Palace. There are always many people visiting this temple. I suggest to come early in order to beat the crowd.
Emerald Buddha. It was very hot. We went in the afternoon. It was a very peaceful experience. We took the Chao Praya express and it is a great way to see the city

Nice Temple but crowded. The temple complex is within the Grand Palace which opens at 8:30 am. Be sure to be close to the main entrance of the palace complex so that you can be at the temple complex with minimal people around. It gets very crowded very fast and it'll be hard to take photos.Its good to take a guide who will explain about the history of this temple and other palaces inside grand palace. Believe me i didnt took a guide and i wasnt able to understand anything.Believe me after seeing so many temples you will get bored and tired of walking inside grand palace, hence you need a guide who will keep your interest.

Wonderful construction. The temple complex is within the Grand Palace which opens at 8:30 am. Be sure to be close to the main entrance of the palace complex so that you can be at the temple complex with minimal people around. It gets very crowded very fast and it'll be hard to take photos. Nowadays its a trend to visit the temple complex first and then other places within the palace complex. So, try to visit the temple complex in the end, within the grand palace complex so that the crowd could be relatively lesser. Temple and its surroundings are just amazing with vivid colors. The actual Emarald Buddha statue is small and you're not allowed to take photos of it within the main temple. A fee of 150 BHT for the entrance of Grand palace is worth the views in the temple complex.

Must See In Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha Temple located within the Grand Palace is a must see. The Buddha itself is rather small in comparison to the room, surrounding buildings, and the other ornamentation in the space. You most likely will not spend that much time here, but it is definitely worth a visit.

History & Culture - A One Off Experience. We made this visit with the services of a private guide who was able to give us the history of this temple. It was a very busy Tuesday when we took this tour but Ms Pu, our Thai Tour Guide, knew all the easy entrances into the various attractions and was a mine of information. We were not just looking but gaining a knowledge and insight into its history and building of this exquisite Wat Phra Kaeo.This building was only a portion of the tour which included The Royal Grand Palace, The Reclining Buddha etc. Ms Pu kindly took photos of the numerous points of interest for me, being an older person, and of myself and daughter.Thoroughly enjoyed our tour although a bit tiring - not to be missed though.

worth a visit, but might be overcrowded. I think we went in a wrong time, when people were everywhere. Early morning hours would be better if you want to enjoy this in peace and harmony (as I think it should be). We got a bit tired of lines and so many people, so left after 1 hour spending there
Amazing inside and out. This is a beautiful temple with sensational art outside and and amazing artistic temple with buddha`s inside, well worth the trip.
Lovely Place. very interesting done with a tour guide who explained things very well very photographic well worth doing
So many tourists.. Amazing place steeped in rich history, only downfall is everyone on earth is there with you, including the jersey shore generation.

Don't miss this place!. Everyone who visits Bangkok should NEVER miss this wonderful place!If you see great photos of this place, it's all that and a lot more!You won;t be allowed to take pictures in some areas of the place, yeah, some places are for your eyes only so if you're in Bangkok, put this place to your list of places to visit!

Too many people, small Buddha. The Grand Palace complex is beautiful but the amount of tour groups there in the morning really distract from your ability to enjoy it. Go in the evening and enjoy a much better view.

As temply as they come. It was a temple, it had a Buddha statue made of emerald. They play dress-up with it according to the seasons. Very nice and spiritual. If you're seeing the kings castle you'll probably end up in here as well.
Amazing place.. Absolutely amazing place. You must go here if in Bangkok. Superb temple that has to be seen to be believed.
temple. again very interesting done with a tour guide who explained things very well very photographic well worth doing

Royal palace & Temple of Emerald Buddja. Absolutely fabulous! Amazing palaces & throne rooms saw the guys hand painting the wall covering unbelievable. Definitely a worth while tour the complex is vast.
Must see. If you are in Bangkok then you must go and see the Emerald Buddha. Although this was smaller than I had imagined it wasd well worth the visit.
this is total beautiful... i would tell anyone to go see this.. you take your shoes off going in. and you would be in awe.this is a total beautiful place..
It has to be done!. This temple was in the Royal Palace. It is worth a visit. It's best to go with a tour guide who can inform you of the history of the place.

Lovely temple. I was at the temple with an organized tour and unfortunately we didn’t stay as much as I would have loved to, because we had to hurry to the next site. However it was impressive it is a lovely temple. Too bad we weren’t allowed to take pictures. The feeling of peace and serenity fills the air and for me it was an outstanding experience and may I say unique compared to other temples I have seen. Don’t miss the chance to visit if you’re nearby.
A very serene feeling. A beautiful statue of Buddha made of emerald stone in the midst of a huge quadrangle within the precincts of the grand palace.

Small Buddha big temple. The temple of the Emerald Buddha and Grand Palace complex is rightly one of Bangkok's big draws, but it is a relatively expensive site, and you need to be careful to dress appropriately. The temple is fantastic, and you can easily spend an hour wandering round just looking at the different very impressive bits. Don't miss the model of Angkor Watt behind the famous gold dome - it's very cool.

Bonus Point for visiting the Grand Palace. This temple was adjacent to the Grand Palace. After a great tour of the Palace, you will soon forget most of the things you see here, except of course the Jade Budda. It was memorable because you couldn't get near to admire it, it was at least 30 yards or more from the roped area and then it was half way up to the ceiling, and it was actually a smaller size budda, all I could see was that it was really green. Nothing to compare with the Lying Down Budda or the thousand buddas at Wat Pho. If you have the time and you were at the Grand Palace, might as well have a visit. However, if there are lots of people and you hate the heat, then you can skip.

Pleasure for eyes but very very crowded. Extremely beautiful architecture and it was a pleasure for the eyes. Beautiful Emerald Buddha was wearing his winter costume. We are not allowed to wear short or sleeveless tops. No photos inside the temple but photos can be taken from the windows. But the crowd keeps posing for photos right in front of Buddha and it was very irritating. Very well maintained temple.

Overcrowded. If you like old stones, and old temples (like in Cambodia), avoid this place.The biggest issue here is the crowd : you just cannot take a picture with nobody on it. The temples are nice, but not beautiful.
Beautiful!. Gorgeous artwork and motifs. Enjoyed this visit very much, but I don't understand why photos can only be taken from the outside.

Beautiful, but CROWDED. This is where the crowd crush hit us. The grounds are beautiful, with huge gold spires, big Buddha statues, and sculpted bushes. Walking around was a neat experience, except you keep getting stuck in huge tour groups, sometimes it is shoulder to shoulder. Still, it's a neat place to see, at night, too. Maybe if you get there early enough in the morning the crowds wont be as bad.
Reverential. Super event to witness the devotees of calmness by persons of a variety of religious belief visiting this iconic Thai Buddhist temple where reverential respect was given by all
STUNNING!!!!. Was WORTH braving the hot sun. Words cannot really explain how amazing it was. One of the must see temples in Bangkok. It was a little touristy but to be expected

Spectacular temple/palace complex. This is a good locale for holiday photos etc as there many interesting 'asian' style statues of demons and deities to be photographed with.In the temple, shoes must be removed before entry, no talking is allowed, modest clothing (legs and shoulders covered, you can buy shawls and trousers outside the complex).Although the Emerald Buddha is quite small, it is one of the most important in the world to Buddhists.

Anotehr must see temple. A must see in Bangkok. There are temples all over but this is one that should be seen as a priority. Nearby is also the flower market which is also worth popping into for the colour and non-tourist atmosphere. Beware the 'guides' in the streets nearby that try to tell you it is shut and offer to take you to another temple nearby

Such a Gem!. Although the Emerald Buddha is relatively small! the temple and setting is magnificent! We finished our two,month tour of SE Asia with 3 days in Bangkok. We had inadvertently followed the path of the Emerald Buddha all through our tour and were very pleased to finally view this wonderful artifact in a most entrancing setting.

Wonderful experience. You need to experience this visit yourself no one can explain the feeling of tranquility and wonder of the whole visit to the Grand Palace, The Emerald Buddha at Wat Phra Kaeo is true to the meaning small is beautiful, depending on when you visit the robes are different.

Impressive, amazing and well maintained. The architecture is stunning. The site is well-maintained and very large. There are guides available for 500 Baht. We had an excellent and very knowledgeable tour guide who gave us a tour of the template and grand palace. It took us around 1.5 hrs to finish.We took the skytrain from Siam Paragon to the pier, then took a longtail boat (500Baht for 3 adults, one-way) that stops by the grand palace. It took us around 45 minutes to get there but it is part of the experiences for us, with our 2.5 yr old. Going back, it was 600Baht (not sure why, but there was no one else on the boat but us).This place is really worth visiting. It is simply amazing.

Awsome. You can spend several hours here, really amazing and shiny. Visit the temple and all of the buildings around. If you see this attraction, you can say, you see all of the types of temple and statue.

Simply divine. I was just awestruck when I saw the inside of the temple. Taking pictures is not allowed, so be content in looking. A side note: the Emerald Buddha has different robes for each season (winter, spring, summer, and fall).

Small but meaningful Buddha. There's a neat story about this Buddha, but first, logistics: this temple is located within the walls of the Grand Palace compound, so you'll need to pay admission to the palace grounds in order to see it. If you're there anyway -- and you should be! -- it's worth visiting the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, which is considered the most sacred Buddhist Temple in Thailand. Remember that you will not be permitted inside sacred temples or royal sites such as this one without proper attire: covered shoulders (t-shirts okay) and pants or skirts at least a couple inches below the knee. You can rent pants or a long skirt at the main gate for ~$7. Flip-flops are allowed but you'll have to take any footwear off when entering certain buildings, including this one.Though legend dates this carved Buddha back about two thousand years, modern chronicles place its discovery in the early 15th century, after a lightning storm struck a temple in Chiang Rai. The statue, covered in plaster to conceal its value and placed among other lesser images, fell to the ground and revealed a glimmer of green stone. Monks discovered a perfect carved Buddha, about two feet tall, made from a single hunk of jade. (Yes, jade -- not an actual emerald.) It has traveled a great deal since then, until being housed reverentially on the Grand Palace grounds in 1782. Only the king can touch it. So yes, it is small; and no, pictures are not allowed out of respect for its religious significance. But even so and even at a distance, the emerald Buddha is quite a sight.

Surely one of the must see sites in Bangkok. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is set within the Grand Palace complex. The Buddha itself sits in a temple on a huge highly decorative golden stand. There are many stunning buildings in the whole complex which are mind blowingly decorative. I loved the really exotic architecture and decor - highly coloured and lots of gold in evidence. It is pretty crowded - an early start woold be beneficial. Also be aware that there is a dress code - this is a sacred place - so make sure legs and shoulders are covered.

Beautiful Temple. We visited with a guide which made the day more interesting. Our guide explained the three different ways the Buddha was dressed depending on the seasons. The Temple itself is impressive and worth a visit.
Serene. Great visit to the emerald Buddha, we had a personal guide, well worth the small expense, so informative.
A big area with a lot of things to see. I just wonder how it's possible to build such nice houses and temples as in this area. Take time to walk around and enjoy the beautiful architecture.

Expensive and crowded... but sort of required thing to see. We visited late morning, which may have been part of the problem. It was super crowded and very hot. Be prepared to wear full pants, at least 3 inches below your knee. I feel we had to visit it since it was our first time in bangkok. But I would not visit again as it was very expensive (500 baht pp) compared to other things to do. The history is interesting and the structures are beautiful, so worth the trip if you are into that sort of thing.

Emerald Buddha. I would recommend going into Wat Phra Kaeo to see the Emerald buddha, it is cloaked in different "clothing" for every season and it was interesting to learn about the history around the buddha.

Fantastic!. Whilst Thailand is full of interesting temples & architecture, The Emerald Buddha is steeped in history & the Thai culture, the jade statue is amazing & you will be able to take photos of artifacts & buildings the like of which we do not normally see.This is Thailand at its best & is to be appreciated as to how a dynasty was created.

Awsome sight. Amazing attraction to see However you need to go early to avoid bus loads of tourists so you can take good photos with out so many people . Free bottled water is given to tourists.. Highly recommend this attraction

Beautiful. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha was beautiful. It is one of the most holy of holy Buddha statues in Bangkok. Althought the name says it is made of Emerald it is actually made of Jade. The statue is small compared to many other Buddha statues but that doesnt take away from the experience. No cameras are allowed inside the temple so please be respectful. Also make sure you are wearing appropreatire clothing or you wont be allowed to enter the temple.

Very Interesting View of Thai Culture. This is a very interesting Buddha temple. It takes about 2 - 3 hours to walk the entire complex. You can get a personal guide or do a self guided audio tour. Be sure to dress appropriately or they won't let you in.
One of the best country to visit. My first visit with friends.Learn a lots of Thai language.For those who love architect you must be there.Heaven of shopping.

Pretty complex - Underwhelmed by Size. The emerald buddha complex is beautiful but, the Buddha itself is rather small which is somewhat of a let down. It is close to a lot of the other complexes so if it doesn't cost a lot more you might want to hop in.

Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Many visits, first was in 1992 with a tour group.
wonderful to see and experience the history of Thailand
many visits subsequently with my wife and friends

Magnificent. If you'd love to see the finest Thai architect, then you must be here. The temple is incredible in the day time and shining at the night time. Also the areas around Ratthanakosin Island are traditional and authentic.

Beautiful. Again a must visit on your itinerary.. This is smallest Buddha statue with a very interesting history. It has 3 gold costumes according to the season which are only changed by the king. Perched high in the temple. The costume is made of gold and so is the temple . The temple is situated in the grand palace. So one can visit the both sites together.

Overwhelmingly Beautiful Temple. This was my favorite Wat in Bangkok. Right from the time we stepped in and noticed the statue of the man sitting at the entrance which our guide explained was the medicine man statue I was hooked. As we moved in we noticed several huge pagodas and yakshas and kinnaras. Each building was more beautiful than the other and it is a photographers paradise. The yakshas guarding each room entrance are beautifully carved and along with the smaller versions of the same they set up the ambience of the temple very well. The golden pagoda and the spires of the other pagodas form a beautiful backdrop to this amazing temple. Take time to soak in the richness and the intricacy of the architecture. The carving on every wall has been very carefully and meticulously done and as you proceed to see the Emerald Buddha spend some time to also notice the painting of the Ramakien or the Ramayana as it is popularly known. There are very colorful and lavish paintings of this epic all along the walls of this temple, The paintings are simply exotic.The Emerald Buddha is a very small statue but a stunning one. And the room in which he is housed is gorgeously and richly decorated. You have to spend couple of minutes to admire the detail of the paintings on the ceiling and the walls. You can take pictures of Buddha from outside. In all it is a stunning temple and a must visit when in Bangkok.
simply unbelieveable. A level of art and detail not seen in many places in this the world, spotless maintained and incredible spiritual...

There can only be one place like this. It is a bit surreal, and colors, statues, glitter and the number of people attack your senses the moment you walk through the gate. Go early in the morning. We made the mistake of getting there mid-morning at which time the complex is overrun with people and does not really give you a chance to appreciate what you are looking at.

Amazing history and incredible beauty. At times can get a little crowded, but it is possible to find some places and be relatively unbothered. Very beautiful history on display and one of those places that is a must see!
