Inspiring and reverent.. One of the man must see sites in Bangkok. Part of a well spent day at the Grand Palace and Wat Pho complex.

BEAUTIFUL. The interior is stunning! As well as being impressed by the Emerald Buddha I was entranced by the beautiful interior decoration of the room. It was very busy but thats understandable, I would recommend this to anyone on a trip to Bangkok.

Amazing structure. It is located in the Grand Palace, so, you have to pay for Grand Palace entrance fee (500 Baht for foreigner and free for Thai resident) in order to visit. The temple which housed the Emerald Buddha has a great traditional type of architectural structure. It is a religious place, so, you have to remove your shoes to enter and strictly no photograph inside.Sometimes, this temple can be closed for certain ceremonies, so, it is recommended to make an inquiry at the information counter prior to visit. It was very crowded during my visit.

Marvelous. Well worth seeing whenever in Bangkok, this temple complex is intricate with subtle details, colorful angles and artful nuances that render it a particular challenge for capturing its essence using photographic images. Highly recommended as part of a 3-day tour arranged through Absolute Bangkok.
A must. This is the main temple of Bangkok situated within the Royal palace. A great place to see Thai art and building.
A great place to visit. This is my fourth visit to Thailand and I always go to it. It is a remarkable place. You will need to go early due to ling lines. Have water with you
Must see Emerald Buddha. This is the most important Buddha in Thailand to see. It is most revered by everyone and located in the Grand Palace compound.

Great Buddha. Just recently saw this Emerald Buddha and he was still dressed in his Rainy season outfit. Found out that he has 3 outfits all made of gold and the King changes then for the different seasons. Beautiful Temple even though the Buddha isn't very large this is worth seeing!
Solemn, interesting history finding the Buddha. Interesting to know the history of this Buddha. Feels very solemn inside. The walls are hand painted and very detailed. It was a different experience.

A very very small Buddha, but nice temple. The palace is inside the Grand Palace, so you might as well go inside at see the Buddha. The temple is very beautiful but was a bit disappointed of the Buddha.

Amazing temple. One of the best in the world. Greatly enjoyed. Large complex with many amazing sights and architecture. Emerald buddha was a little disappointing because of small size but looking up actual and mythical history was so much fun.

good to see.. It is one of the most important temple in BKK, so you have to go there. I was there during first day in Thailand, and it was not a good idea, noise, hot etc. so my way of seeing a temple was suppressed.Nevertheles it is important to see it. For me it wasn't so amazing as I though.Remeber to dress properly, shorts could be ok, but no too short :). T-shirt also. Shirt should have a sleeve (short are ok :) )
Very Bright and lots of colour. A very nice experience although sometimes crowded.make sure you wear long pants and don't have shoulders exposed.
Marvellous gold Budhha. I found it to be one if the best temples ever built, comparable to the Golden Temple at Amritsar, the most reverred Sikh temple in India. A must see for all.
Impressive!. This temple is part of the Grand Palace compound. Do yourself a favor and get a tour guide (they're readily available at the entrance for 500THB). Super part of Thai history!
A must see. The Emerald Buddha (jade, really) is somewhat small, but the temple is so beautiful that it's otherworldly!

major sightseeing in Bangkok. The temple is located inside the wall of the grand palace. To enter the temple you have to wear proper clothes (pants, shoulder need to be covered). Clothes can be rent at the entrance but the queue can be long. We had to visit the temple very quickly as it was closing earlier because of a religious ceremony. Still the inside of the temple is impressive. Then we walked around a had a look at the other monument of the grand palace. The place is colorful, full of history.
It's was cool. It was nice to see, you only need to visit one temple in my opinion. If you see one you've the other. I would pick this one.

A must do when in Bangkok. Ticket for this is included in your 500bhat entry fee for the Grand Palace. Wonderful to see this! Discover a bit of the history beforehand and the visit will be more meaningful.
Must-see place. I felt Thai brilliance. I was surprised that an emerald Buddha statue was very smaller than imagination, but felt the faith depth of Thai people.

Amazing cultural experience!. I went there by myself and it was amazing! It's like entering a experiencing a new world, going through history and delving into the Thai culture! I loved it and it's def worth visiting! Make sure to use all the 3 tickets you get for the coins museum, queen sirikit's silk museum and the grand palace etc...
Beautiful. Once again another lovely temple to visit, very busy, so maybe go in the afternoon when its cooler as the heat in Bangkok is insane!

Another must see. Sometimes you just have to do the tourist thing and when you do this one should be added to your list. Although much smaller than I expected and not really made of emeralds (jade actually) I'm glad I went.

em..... temple great, but looks same with other standard temple.
maybe my feeling couldn't be good, coz i came here with tuk-tuk.
maybe 1time people can come here.
Worth a visit. Located inside the palace. No separate entry fee. It looks beautiful. No pics can be taken inside. Popular place and hence crowded.

Impressive. My family (mom and two sisters) were booked on a tour here. We arrived at around 9AM, it was not so hot. We alighted across the street, both of my sisters had to rent wrap-around garments because they were wearing black tights for 30 THB (strict dress code here).The tour guide was very informative, listening to her made the experience more astonishing. Walking around wouldn't do it, it really pays to have a tour guide with you. The key to this experience is in the details of the stories behind the attraction.Coming up close to the temples & seeing the detailed handcrafted work done on it, and not to mention its size, it's simply amazing.It's a little crowded though, and it gets hot later in the day. There's not much to rest your feet too. If you're in Bangkok, don't miss this one.Tip: dress appropriately. Ask locals what to wear. We wore black & white only because it was a time if mourning for the nation at that time. Red was discouraged because of a political uprising involving that color at that time too. Bring water, umbrella (for the heat or in case it rains), and shades.

Interesting temple. This was a very interesting temple with plenty to see and discover. We particularly enjoyed seeing the replica of Angkor Wat. A lot to see and do but make sure to dress appropriately or stop at the booth at the entrance and rent the necessary cover up

Within the palace complex. This little wonder is part of the palace complex. A photographer's paradise. The architecture is well worth the 500 baht entry fee. Gold with beautiful inlays in coloured glass are just gorgeous. They also have a mini scale size replica of the Ankor Wat.The Emerald Buddha itself is housed in a quiet temple.The Queen Sirikit textile house is also worth a quick visit.

Beautiful Temple. Temple of Emerald Buddha is located inside the Grand Palace complex. There was lotus flower in holy water outside the temple for blessing or maybe for purification before you entered the temple. Camera was prohibited inside the temple and also you had to remove your shoes before entering the temple. It was really nice to see people were praying in there, and admiring the golden statue of Buddha. It was amazing. It was beautiful!

Another famous site that should not be missed.. Beautiful religious setting for this stunning Buddha. The Emerald Buddha is historically significant and quite a site to see. SHould you have the opportunity check it out.

so relaxing. after being aware not to believe anyone that tells u the palace is shut, unfortunately on our day it was for a ceremony so we spent more time in the emerald buddha temple. It was so relaxing and lovely to sit amongst people from all over the world, monks, kids not in total silence but most people respected the request for quiet. no photos are allowed to be taken and u have to take off your shoes, wear long pants and covered shoulders. i was surprised that many tourists were dressed appropriately but there were clothes to borrow so they could go in. the Buddha is small but the building is a masterpiece and as a mosaic artist i was fascinated by all the different mosaic techniques used from colored glass to old crockery. u can walk around the fort walls which are hand painted beautifully the entire length on the inside walls. buy water it gets hot. make time to wander away from large tour groups and see artist and monks going about their daily business.

Most revered image of Buddha in Thailand. After reaching the place taking a boat ferry along the chao phraya river, you find yourself surrounded by religious buildings, Chinese, Hindu and Buddhist statues. The crafting of the buildings is amazing, with the sunlight playing over the surface of the materials making everything shine! Besides the overwhelming architecture and despite how crowded it can get, you can actually feel peace and well being while walking around the place. The emerald Buddha is the most revered image in Thailand, so dress accordingly, don't photograph it and don't point your feet to it while sitting!!! It is better to walk the place in flip flops or sandals because you must be barefoot to enter any building. Being a religious place, no shouting is allowed. If you are lucky, you can take pictures of monks passing by. Once you tour the site (including an incredible maquette of Angkor wat!) you get to the royal palace, which stands out from the others since it looks very European.Take your time to walk the place! The size of the complex and the heat of Bangkok can easily dehydrate, so drink plenty of water.

Majestic. Beautiful, gorgeous, and majestic! Many visitors of course, but this is a small price to pay for visiting this huge temple. The temple is huge with many colorful buildings and all the gilt, frescoes, deities, a real feast for the eyes. We achieved a peaceful state of mind in this place filled with culture. This temple is outstanding from every point of view and it cannot be describe in words. You must go and see it with your own eyes.

Emrald Buddha temple. the murals were beautiful and even though it was so crowded when we went, the place still felt peaceful and the small emrald buddha statue was beautiful and for some reason, inspiring to beholdFor wheel chair users, it can be a bumpy ride due to the uneven walking path and walking up a few rather tall steps necessary to enter the temple. It is also required that one remove shoes to enter the temple - although there can be allowances made for the mobility challenged and the wheel chair be allowed to enter but only recommended if at least slightly mobile.

So. Shiny.. If you're one for beautiful architecture + LOTS OF SHINY. This is the one. Literally everything glimmers. We managed to sneak in with a tour guide and he showed us all of the "interesting" parts, they were amazing. All of the temples were so well crafted, and we saw how well they looked after it as well - there were men and women, repainting old wallpaper, re-jeweling dragons, and gold-leafing ceilings. It was an incredible place! The Emerald Buddha itself was very beautiful, you get the chance to go in, and meditate or pray for a while (there are also fans to give you some relief from the heat!) Lovely, lovely, lovely, don't miss the opportunity if you're in Bangkok!

Beautiful Temple. This was incredible. Truely beautiful. I would recommend getting an early start when going to view the Temple and the Palace as it seemed to get more crowded as the day went on. Make sure that you bring the proper clothing and footwear. Sandals were not premitted in the temple, and shoulder covering shirts and long skirts/pants were a part of the dress code.

The best Temple in Bangkok. I'm not a religious person, however the experience of a visit to the Emerald Buddha and seeing the Thai culture in action is a must while in Bangkok. The almost perfect ornateness is something to behold.The murals around the walls telling stories of the past are breathtaking.The only downside of the experience is the amount of money that has been used to create and maintain this contradicts the living styles of the many poor people in Bangkok and Thailand, but they love their places of worship.

Place Of Paradise. This is the 4th time I had visited Wat Phra Keo.Things I like here is because:-1. The temple is so calming & peaceful feeling when you are in it.2. Architectural is so fine with its fine materials & handicraft workmanships.3. It gives one a great feeling with its highest ambience.4. Freedom on your own, nobody will stopped you etc.Things I dislikes here are:-1. Toilets is quite difficult to locate if you are the first timer to visit here.2. Most of the signs are written in Thai languages and is difficult to interpret if you don't read Thais.3. Directional signs within the palace is not quite clearly displayed.NB: Cautions to would be visitors to the Grand Palace. There are plenty of scammer located outside the vicinity. Once they will approach you and tell that the temple is closed for the day and they can bring to another temple similar to or even better than this one, don't take in by them.All my previous visit I was approached by them using the same ruse take the unsuspected for quick profit. Just smile with them and say thank you. Walk away and avoid them.

Emerald Buddha. Interesting place to visit . The Grounds were fabulous. The Buddha was quite amazing to see. I did become a bit jaded about all the gold figurines as could see how the money here could help the people living in shanties. The place was well maintained and the buildings, statues and grounds were quite spectacular.

Do not miss this if you come to Bangkok. THis temple is something very special but very popular. The cultural aspects are simlpy fascinating and do not miss the massage. Only drawback - other tourists lack of respect so visit early or late in the day!

Lots of things to see on the temple ground - More than just the Emerald Buddha.. This is located on the grounds of the Grand Palace, and is the first area that you have access to after going through security. There are quite a lot of details to be seen on the Wat Phra Kaew grounds. This is almost like the “can’t see the trees because of the forest”. Besides all the highly decorated temples, you will see the first of several giant ogres. There are many other mythical creatures on the ground that are highly decorated. You can see from the many photos of the sites how beautiful all the building on the temple grounds are decorated. The inside of the walls that surround the whole complex is painted with murals that were originally painted in the late 1700.Prior to your visit to the temple area, it would be helpful as an aid to print out a map of Wat Phra Kaeo from Wikipedia. This map has all the structures and figures label as to what it is and their locations. I noted that some reviewers only describe their visit to the main temple that house the Emerald Buddha, and yes, it would be disappointing if this was the only thing to be seen here. The temple area is a very large complex, and it would take several hours to see everything in this one section.Visit Notes:The three attractions, Grand Palace, Wat Pho (Temple of the Emerald Buddha, and Wat Pho, will consume a good portion of your day. The main entrance is located on the middle of the north wall. The street areas are lined with sidewalk vendors. The entry fee, which includes both Wat Phra Kaeo and the Grand Palace is 500 baht. To enter the temple that housed the Emerald Buddha, you will have to take your shoes off outside. No photography is allowed inside this temple. Bring your own water, as there are no vendors once inside the paid entry area. No bare shoulder, shorts, capri pants is allowed when visiting the Grand Place ground. Once through the gate, you may have to temporary rent a shawl, sarong, or a pair of pants. You only have to put a deposit of 200 baht for the rental and the 200 baht is returned at the end of the visit. Other reviewers are miss-informed, thinking they had to rent the garment for 200 baht. You get your 200 baht back when you return the garment. Miss-information and Scams:Depending on how you get there, taxi, tut-tut, ferry, you may be approached or informed by your driver that the place is closed for a holiday or a special event is taking place and no one is allowed in for a few hours. They will then volunteer to take you to another place that is just as good or better. On the way, they will stop off at the “sponsor”, who has great prices on anything you want to buy. This is just a scam, in the high fare to take you to the “better spot”, and to the store front with the great prices.
Must-see when at the Grand Palace. This temple is situated within the grand palace compound. Amazing emerald Buddha statue in the temple.

Unbelievable but Real !!. A must see if you are in Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha and the architecture of the temple its paintings are outstanding and best part is the process of restoration of such beautiful existence of thai craftsmanship.

Worth checking out. When I went there the place was jam packed. Going inside the gates was approached by a tour guide offering to take me around. Normally I steer clear of this sort of setup smelling a scam but no it was all good, can't remember how much I paid but was very cheap. Ended up coupling up with another group and we are shared the cost.The benefit: besides the obvious being shown around and explained what everything is was that we were able to get in straight away without queuing for tickets as the line was long.This place is a must see on your visit to Bangkok. Awesome buildings if you only go to one temple in Thailand, go to this one and recommend getting a guide

Beautiful. The interior is stunning! As well as being impressed by the Emerald Buddha I was entranced by the beautiful interior decoration of the room. It was very busy but thats understandable, I would recommend this to anyone on a trip to Bangkok.

A most revered Buddha. The temple houses Thailand's most revered Buddha. Wat Phra Kaew is a wonder of gleaming gilded stupas, mosaic encrusted pillars and rich marble. You need at least one and a half hours to tour the complex.
Emerald Buddha. The temple of the emerald Buddha is in the grand palace, what a fantastic temple to visit, the emerald Buddha was dressed in his finest winter attire. Superb

Lovely Little Buddha. Go EARLY!!! This attraction is packed with tour groups and individual travelers lining up to see the Emerald Buddha (which is made of jade) Right now he is dressed for the Rainy Season, but next week he will be changed into his Winter outfit. The Buddha himself is quite small, but still very impressive and well worth going to see...IF you go early.

Intricate work. Amazing detail. Incredibly intricate work. Please be aware that there's a dress code. If you are not appropriately covered up, you can get what you need at the entrance by paying a refundable deposit.

Small. Was a bit disappointed with this Buddha as everyone talks about it been the 'emerald' Buddha! But it is tiny compared to all the others that you see. It's still beautiful, don't get me wrong but just so small.

Good experience. We enjoyed the tour of the Temple of the Emerald Buddha in every facet. We had our own guide, Ratana, who provided excellent background in relation to the temple that enhanced the experience.

Such a interesting place. Great to visit and see all the stuff there. Recommended. We´ve been there in the middle of summer, but stayed really long time, notwithstanding it was really hot, because of it´s power of beauty and energy.

Great visit. According to the tour guide, the Emerald Buddha has some long history that was from Loas? Amazing conditions. I still can't get over it on how amazing the Thais are and the great respect to the Kings and its religious heritage.

colorful and the kitschy. Personally I thought the design was busy lots of buildings crammed together. a mish mash of the colorful and the kitschy but it's still worth a visit. don't take a guide there's a free English tour of the complex with a lovely lovely lady. I had a hard time understanding her in the beginning but she was so nice and funny that I got over the accent barrier in no time. I really liked the story about the porcelain covered building- the shipment of plates from chine came broken and they didn't want to waste it so they put it on a building. And the shaping of the lotus flower to sprinkle holy water on us : ) Highly recommended

felt lot of energy there. lot to walk in the sun, too humid and crazy dress codes. finicky staff in the dressing change areas . but the palce is stunning and the buddha in emerald is worth all the troubles
Good place. is a really interesting place but the tourist guides dont stop to say stupid things and u will waste your time in this place, if u want to go, without tourist guide is the best choice

The Kings Private Temple. Housed within the Grand Palace complex the temple of the Emerald Buddha is a must visit as part of a broader visit to the palace.It is incredibly ornate and in keeping with the sweeping beauty of the Grand Palace.Please note that photos are not allowed inside the temple or any of the main Grand Palace buildings and there are strict clothing codes.

The grand palace value. The grand palace is located in downtown Bangkok, Thailand, Thailand's all previous dynasties to save the most perfect, the largest and most national characteristics of the king's palace.The grand palace is modelled on the old capital city, old palace built, through continuous expansion, the Kings of the large now finally built the grand palace complex.
Amazing!. What can I say - I walked in and found myself in tears - pure NO PHOTOS - I do not respect the foreigners who do take picturesDEFINITELY a place everyone should visit

Very beautiful templ. It was very beautiful temple and the design was so nice. It really worth to take a look plus pls bring a nice camera going there to take more pic. The fees was included together with the The Grand palace ticket which fees was 500 baht. U need to wear long pant for men and for women or gal wear skirt higher to knee and no singlet. If u don't wear this u can rent it at the building next to the entrance no need to buy from outside the entrance. It need to put deposit fees after return back the item u can take it back the deposit fees so dont worry.

Lovely Temple. Lovely to see if you have the time, however youre not allowed to take photos of this one and the guards are heavy handed if you try and sneak one, whilst we were there they took a girls phone apart to delete the photos on her memory card so be warned.
Its a must see!!. I dont know why its not part of the 'wonders of the world'. This temple will leave you speechless! This is part of the grand palace. One needs about 2 hours to see the whole place!

small statue but a big complex. this statue has history, it was 1st in THAILAND then taken away to Laos but later reclaimed by King Rama V and brought to Bangkok when he shifted his capital to Bangkok. every year thrice the king changes the dress of the statue in accordance with the seasons, summer, winter and raining. the temple is in a huge complex with 2 more structures, housing the kings' ashes as well as budhha statues. its inside the Grand Palace complex which was the old residence of the Kings of Thailand
Excellent. Very crowded.. Management is not good.. Excellent tourists spot.. Good Temple.. Monuments is great to see

Lovely and Quiet. Our tour guide Natt took us here after the Grand Palace in a tuk tuk. The entrance fees for tourist is much more reasonable. The temple was lovely and in some sections, very quiet and peaceful. Remember, there is lots more to see than just the 'reclining buddha'. Keep walking into the complex and enjoy!

Worth seeing!. We took a taxi to grand palace, and when we were approaching, the taxi driver “greeted” the Buddha statues and the building. It was clear that it is a very important and special place for Thai people.I think that the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a must see when you visit Bangkok. Ok, the place is FULL of people, but it is really is worth visiting. The architecture is amazing! Make sure you have at least an audio guide, or you will wonder around without knowing what you are looking at.Don’t forget to wear long pants and a t-shirt that covers your shoulder!

Marble floored temple. This temple is marble floored. Bronze gold plated Buddha statue.They say that American President won elections for the second time after visiting this temple. There are many other foreign dignitaries who have visited this temple.This is also a must visit in your Bangkok tour.

tourist trap. It was very interesting to see but you get trampled by all the touristsYou have to wear long pants but they will provide you with a long pants free (200 B refundable deposit)If you are looking for a religious experience, this is not the place
beautiful. very nice but u must get a tour guide (make sure its a certified one with a badge INSIDE the temple) lots to see and its hard to understand the complexity of the paintings and structures

Spectacular. Spectacular grounds and multiple temples. Like nothing else I have ever seen. The Emerald temple is one of many on the grounds and is the most famous, it can be fiercely crowded. The whole area once housed the royal family, and it shows. Get there for opening to avoid the worst of the crowds.
Beautiful. Beautiful, but full of people. The architecture and attention to detail (both inside and outside) in incredible

Bangkok - You will love it!. Interesting & Amazing ... Unique architecture .. Make you wonder how people in the past are able to create , design & create these buildings and monuments using ancient technologies and methods. Within the Grand Palace, this is must see-stop
Meh. You can't get close. Since you will probably be going to the Grand Palace anyway, you might as well take a look.

Definitely worth seeing. The architecture and design here is definitely a must-see on any trip to BK. You should also make sure to visit the small market across the street from the entrance for little buddhist prayer cards and brass charms

Temple of Emerald Buddha. Very educative of Buddhist culture and on the teaching of Buddha. The visitors flow to the temple is well regulated. Guides are available for a nominal fee. Temple is kept clean. Respect the dress code (Sarong for men and no bare head or ancles for ladies). Sarongs can be purchased or RENTED (nominal deposit) from near by shops.

Simply amazing!. A really beautiful temple located in the Grand Palace complex. The Buddha is carved from a single piece of jade and is really lovely.i was surprised that everyone respected the request not to take photos inside. It was very busy with tourists, mostly Chinese , but seemed very peaceful and calm. A must see in Bangkok. It is important to be careful and avoid the scammers outside who try to tell you ' it is closed today come and see the big Buddha or the lucky Buddha' And those inside who want to sell you trousers or a sarong that you can simply borrow from the temple or even those who want to give you a tour. If you want more information it is probably better to get an audio guide.
The best of the best. An amazing place with atmosphere, ambience and plenty to see. Plan on spending at least half a day visiting this sight take ID so you can rent audio guide.
spectacular. respect thai culture and do not use camera inside temple. a must visit in bangkok as is the whole of the palace grounds gents long trousers please and ladies cover legs

Another tourist spot/trap. From our perspective, nothing special, buses and buses of tourists and traps. If you decide to go, read other posts on how to avoid tourist traps - bottom line - IGNORE THE HELPFUL LOCALS, especially the ones approach you and volunteer to help. Additionally, save you some time if you wear clothing that covers your shoulders and knees so you can avoid buying or the need to stand in line to borrow paints/shirts to cover them.

Have to see?. My husband and I were only in Bangkok for 3 full days and I had planned one of those day to be a "temple day". On the list was Temple of Dawn, Reclining Buddha, and Emerald Buddha. In that order it was cheapest to most expensive entry fees at 50, 100, 500 baht per person. While I felt the Emerald Buddha was a must do and I still think it is, the experience was not awesome. After leaving the Reclining Buddha we thought it would be an easy walk to the Grand Palace entrance but it was quite far(wish we had taken a tuk-tuk but they are WAY over-priced in this area!). After arriving at the entrance I could barely see the ground because there were so many tourists(hoards of Chinese!). We debated going in because we thought it was going to be 400 baht each and it had gone up to 500 baht. After a quick debate we decided we were here and it was a "must see". The ticket price does include entrance to the Grand Palace, Emerald Buddha, and the Queen's Museum of Textiles. We shuffled our way to the Emerald Buddha where shoes need to be removed and it was a one way in entrance(which was good for the crowds). Unfortunately half of the room/view was under construction tarp with scaffolding, which really was an eye sore! The other half you could see the Emerald Buddha. It was beautiful to look at(no pictures allowed!)but I wish you could get closer to see it because it is so small you cannot take in all the detail of it from where you and the hoards of others are. We didn't spend much time in this room and we moved outside. There was a very impressive model of Angor Wat which was one of the highlights for us! We viewed some of the other areas but did not go into the Textile Museum as the crowds were too much. We left after about just over an hour and I am glad we did it but I am not sure it was worth 1000 baht for 2 people. I struggled with an average or very good rating and I decided to go with very good even though the crowds, construction, and fee put a damper on the visit! The Temple of Dawn was only 50 baht and the Reclining Buddha was 100! Much better priced!FYI: DO NOT TAKE A TAXI OR TUK-TUK THAT IS SITTING RIGHT OUTSIDE THE ENTRANCE TO THE GRAND PALACE! ALL OF THEM ARE RIDICULOUSLY OVER-PRICED, GIVE YOU SET FARES INSTEAD OF THE METER, AND ARE CRANKY! Instead my husband and I hung a right out of the Palace, went around the first corner and flagged down a tuk-tuk that was dropping a fare off. He tried to charge 50 baht but my husband got him to 20 baht because we needed less than a 5 min ride to the ferry at the Reclining Buddha.

Check out the available admission options for your tour!. We had pre-booked an Isango Tour for Saturday 5th October only to find that the Temple is closed on Saturday and Sunday, plus 5th of each month being the anniversary of the King's Birthday. We had a great tour guide but overall the experience was curtailed by not getting access to the Temple and Emerald Buddha.

Traveling by train. Bangkok has one of ther best train systems at a very affordable rate that you can wish for! The trains are airconditioned, runs regularly and are very clean! It is almost the best form of transport in Bangkok! No traffic in a taxi or petrol fumes on a Tuk-tuk!

Peace reigns here. The temple is magnificent! This is a must-see in Bangkok. At first I was apprehensive about leaving my shoes outside, but they were exactly where I'd left them when I returned. Your dress must be appropriate or you will have to "rent" clothes from a vendor across the street before entering the temple. The Emerald Buddha was a bit smaller than I had imagined, perhaps it was that I went to the temple right after seeing the Reclining Buddha. This temple is not to be missed.

Gorgeous grounds and elaborate temple. I was struck more by the grounds, paintings on the wall and other buddhas than the emerald buddha. It was beautiful and overwhelming. As expected, you do have to take your shoes off to go into the temple. Unexpectedly, the temple grounds floor and area outside the temple felt cleaner on my feet than my own home.
nice temple. another wonderfull place to visit in Bangkok. visitor will receive map of this temple to see around. little bit hot there but worth with the view.

Mind-boggling. Extraordinarily opulent and dazzling. Although the Emerald Buddha is the 'main attraction', I thought the rest of the temple equally amazing. The whole structure is a work of art, quite unlike anything I'd ever seen before.

Temple of the Emerald Bhudda. This area of the palace is spectacular - and this is a must to see for everyone that goes to Bangkok. Even by just being inside the Temple there is an amazing feeling of inner peace.

One Big Piece of Jade. The emerald buddha sits high above an offering pyre and is about 3-4' tall but the amazing part is that it is all jade, one carved piece. No pictures or video are allowed. Worth the time and effort to go.

a bit small. This was on my list to see because it seems to be an important item for locals.it is very disappointing, it is small, not the size of a statue more a large ornament.it is in a glass case. The temple is busy so it is beholden on visitors to observe thelocal customs ie, if you sit as many do to look at the Buddha your toes must face away from thealtar. As ever go but do not expect too much.

Don't be taken for a ride.. A word of warning. While on the way to the temple you will be approached by various men who will tell you the temple is closed. Or, that its the lunch time break. It won't be closed this is merely a tactic to get you into their tuk tuk or their accomplices tuk tuk to wisk you away to various jewelery and fabric factories. After several wasted hours they will return you and your empty wallet to the Temple. Telling you that now it is open. Make sure you see the Jade Buddhas clothes which are housed in the museum. He had a summer one, a winter and a rainy season one. They not only change his tunic but his head piece as well.

A temple with unique exterior decoration. When entering the temple, I had no idea that the Buddha statue of jade is very small in size. It turns out the statue is at the top of the golden arrangement. At the outside the temple decoration is very interesting and unique.

Emerald Buddha. We found the whole temple very interesting. The emerald buddha itself is quite small and up high. The painting on the walls was fantastic. We loved the intricate detail in the story of the life of the buddha. Very colourful. Worth a visit.

Must see but overrated. The Palace + Wat Phra Kaeo are worth a visit, but I was a bit disappointed. I think 500 Baht entrance fee are too expensive. The architecture ist great, but so it is in most Wats around Bangkok. There are way to many tourist, so you run around trying not to stand in the way of people taking photos while trying to take one or two nice pics yourself.There is no such thing as spirituality inside Wat Phra Kaeo due to many non-religious (or non-buddhistic) bystanders, but anyway the Emerald Buddha is impressive.If you like touristic sightseeing then visit, if you are looking for some spirituality go to other Wats.

nice. it is very impressive, just rember to come all covered up or you will have wait in line to get a cover, and leave deposits ( men and women all covered, no shorts no spagetti tops) and entrence is 500 bath each.
Its all been said before.. Sit down and absorb the atmosphere and peace and calm while you eyes are treated to some amazing sights
A must see. Although it is quite small, it is a must see when in Bangkok. We have visited the Temple of the Emerald Buddha a few times and his clothing changes.
wow. What can i say about this.What a treat to see things like this.I would say to everyone going to Bangkok then go and see they are a must.

Epic experience; breath taking beauty. What a trip! You would not be disappointed in any way with the breath taking beauty of this historic famous temple. We had a very funny guide, good english, and free ! When you pay to get in at the gate, on the left of the open archway entrance you will see a small desk where a lady has a list of names waiting to go with the english speaking tour guide . The times of the free tours are 10.00am & 10.30am , 1.30pm & 2.00pm. You will not be disappointed with any of the tour. He will help you to take photos and walk you round the whole temple/s in a good pace.It is hot and their water stop is 20 mins round - so take lots of water with you !
Crowded. Go early,it is so very crowded with tour groups. Wear flip flops to take off to enter the temple...but it is worth seeing.

Big place but very expensive gate receipt. We did not really enjoy going around the place since we arrived in the aternoon when the weather is really hot. There are too many tourists so taking picture is definitely an issue.
Beautiful jade Buddha. This is a huge and beautiful temple. You must have have a tour guide to understand it all. Buddha statue is gorgeous.

Beautiful temple. make sure you do not wear shorts otherwise you have to queue up to rent a long pants and no slippers.
have to pay 500 baht for entrance.
beautiful temple and the grand palace is in the same compound.
A little palace of heaven. Quite reflective tranquility, a place fit for a jewelled Buddha, a place for quite contemplatn and thanks giving. Fine big palace, high level of decoration and ornatation

You should come very early in the morning. Although taking pictures of the Emerald Buddha is not allowed, the others are okay, so spend at least 2 hours there. And you should come very early in the morning for better experience, I guess. We came there in the early afternoon and gosh, jam-packed of tourists.

Good. Best to have a guided tour. You can see the Emerald Buddha from the outside but its not as big as the Golden Buddha..Inside the temple is a magnificent painting of Thai culture/community and great architecture of ceiling. footwear and picture taking inside the temple is not allowed.

Very dissapointed as the Budha was closed and at no time where were informed about it.. It was okay but it is wiser to go on a guided tour as we just walked about aimlessly not knowing what each building or Budha represented
nice temple. was my 2nd visit and the grandeur of the temple and the Buddha himself gives you a certain peaceful state of mind. part of grand palace complex.

Beautiful temple and value to see. Wat Phra Kaeo is very large and big temple. it was sparkling in sunny and very touristy. opening everyday from 8:30am - 3:30pm. (should know about opening time because we was stupid to believing Tuktuk drive that it was opened only in the afternoon)Tip: let go there in early morning and become those first tourist you can take picture of temple without unexpected guys standing aroundEntrance ticket: 500Thb/pp
Exelent - but crowded. Like: All there is to see.Dislice: It was crowded. Even by Bangkok standards.BUT: You can not go to Bankok whitout seeing this!

Small jade statue filled with symbolism to the Thai people. It's inside the Grand Palace, so you don't have to pay extra (the fee for the Grand Palace complex is high, though, 500 baht).Of course, you will have to take off your shoes before entering and you also have to obey the dress code. No photos are allowed inside the temple.The Buddha statue itself is rather small, made of jade and not emerald, held high on top of a beautiful decorated base. It has a lot of symbolism to the Thai people and culture, hence the interest on the statue. If you're there, it sure is worth a visit.
Heart of Bangkok. This buddha is amazing and worth visiting although you cant have a photo of it as it is not allowed. It is worth visiting :)

Exquisite. Temple of the emerald Buddha is an exquisite masterpiece of Buddhist artistry! The feeling and energy you feel in the presence of the Buddha is one of peace and serenity. We loved our day trip here and having seen so many temples around Asia this one truly is a unique experience.

Still beautiful but overrun by Chinese tourists. This is THE sight to see when visiting Bangkok but my last trip was about 12 years ago and it was much more pleasant as the number of visitors was significantly less. Getting into the grounds and then again into the building to see the Emerald Buddha is like going into any transit station during rush hour. We went shortly after noon on a Monday so maybe that was a peak time. Next time I go I'll inquire about what days and times it might be less crowded. The grounds are spacious but still full of visitors everywhere.Go with a good guidebook, hire a guide, or rent an audio guide near the ticket counters to understand all that there is there to see.

A must see. We visited in February and it was pretty hot and busy with bus loads of tourists which I guess is an everyday occurence. I think you need at least 3 or 4 hours to really appreciate the splendour so if you are on an organised trip it would for me be too rushed. It was nice when there was a lull in the tourist mayhem. The Buddah is small and at quite a distance. We visited on a weekend when some of the attractions were closed. The dress code for ladies didnt seem always to be enforced and saw several women with short skirts or t shirts with shoulders showing. The dressing area where you can borrow 'cover ups' was busy with queues. Watch out for the touts outside. We never managed to get a taxi to turn on its meter so had to negotiate fee. Traffic in Bangkok horrendous so make sure air con works in the cab of your choice as you will be in there for quite a while.

Disappointing. Not to insult anyone's religion, but this Buddha is tiny compared to the Golden Buddha nearby and there is currently construction scaffolding which mars the view. Also no photo permitted and indoor temps are a bit high (hint- sit near a fan). As others have noted it is part of the palace admission but I would not go out of my way to visit if you are pressed for time.
great attraction. we really enjoyed this attraction , a very famous icon , the emerald budda was awseome , easy to get too by tuk-tuk
stunning. The emerald Buddah is surrounded by a wonderfully complex temple. Pay close attention to the details of the temple so as to not miss anything.

A must see sight in Bangkok. The temples are amazing in details and craftsmanship. Overwhelming in beauty and complexity in design. The emerald Buddha was small and easily overlooked among the golden splendor of it's surroundings.

its an amazing place.. it was worth the visit. Not too far from the city and a 100 bhath taxi ride. it gets scorching hot during mid day so wear a hat or cap. Make sure that you are clad in full on attire or you will have to buy/hire sarong/scarf from a place within the premises.

Small Buddha but ornate building. We went to the Emerald Buddha as it is within the grounds of the Grand Palace so entrance fees already paid. It Emerald Buddha itself is very small. You can take photos from outside but not inside the building. It is very ornate and beautiful inside. You must take your shoes off to enter building. It is a huge tourist site. You must dress appropriately to enter the Grand Palace. Women tee shirt with sleeves, 3/4 pants or long skirts, nothing see through. Take water!!!
Must see!!!. The Emerald Buddha is an absolutely must see! It is unlike anywhere else and the feeling you experience here is wonderful. Do not miss it!
Emerald Buddha. This temple is in the Grand Palace grounds. You cannot take any pictures and the emerald buddha is jade. It is about 2 feet high. It is crowded and hot.

A most venerated sites!. A beautiful Buddha statue. The Emerald Buddha is enshrined on a golden traditional Thai-style throne made of gilded-carved wood , known as a Busabok,in the ordination half of the royal monastery. I learned the Emerald Buddha was in fact carved from a block of jade and was discovered in 1434 in a stupa in Chiang Rai.It was sad to see tourists were trying to take pictures despite warning boards.!

one of the many amazing sites of Bangkok!. Simply go there. One of the five things to do when a firstimer in Bangkok. Mix this visit with a traditional massage afterwards to complete the experience. Try to come by boat from the river!!!

Small but perfectly formed. There is so much to see in Grand Palace, not just the Emerald Buddha, which (like the Mona Lisa) we thought would be so much bigger. You can't take photos inside the building but you can through the window so take a zoom lens! Lots more to see in the surrounding area too: Combine with Wat Arun and Wat Pho (Temple of Dawn and Reclining Buddha) But be aware that some temples etc close at 4 or 5 pm.Also there so much gold it can be hard to take when you then think about the poverty outside the palace grounds in the rest of Bangkok and Thailand.

Small and bijoux. Surprisingly small for a Buddha as it was located very high up, at the top of a very high pedestal. No photos allowed but could take from outside looking in. Shoes had to be removed, so I suggest bringing socks so that you don't walk barefoot where thousands walk every day.
Don't skip. This is one of the many temples inside on the grounds of the Grand Palace. Do not pass it by without a stop as it has a sense of mystery and old Thailand to it.
Same as every other temple. I got too bored to actually stay, you literally don't want to spend more than 10 minutes, you just take pictures and get out of there.

Pointless. This temple is within the Grand Palace complex. It is busy, you are herded in one door and out of anohter. You can't take photos and the emerald buddha itself, not emerald, tiny and extremely high up! Just a waste of time in my opinion

its the size of a child!. how they made it I have no idea, it even has 3 gold outfits for the different Thai seasons, has travelled all over Thailand and was stolen by the people of Laos at one point. beautiful and adds to the grandeur of the Grand palace area, the earlier you go the better as you'll be swarmed by toursits. no pictures...unless your sneaky with no flash and quick. make sure you do the traditional 3 floor bows to add to the athentic moment, you'll feel like you are in the "King and I"
Another good spot to enjoy. This is another spot to enjoy when you are in Bangkok. I almost lost my words when I see it on the spot
neat and tranquility. well maintained temple. very peaceful inside and can have a effective relaxing time. can get flowers if wish to leave inside the temple.

Breathtaking!!!. Most beautiful temple in Bangkok.... A must!!
The Buddha is spectacular!!! And all the different buildings and statues around the temple are beautiful, you even get to see a replica of Angkor Wat

Palace, temple and tour guide = AWESOME! *Gem store scam at end...almost ruined it*.. PROS: We booked the "Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha) and The Grand Palace Complex" tour together through TripAdvisor/Viator.com. The temples and palace are beautiful and really can only be appreciated in person. Pictures just don't do them justice. PROS: "Yelly" our tour guide was great. Perfect English and she knew everything and more and obviously has an appreciation for history. We did the AM tour during the week and we had her and the courtesy van/driver to ourselves. Temple and palace are PACKED but "Yelly" went out of her way to keep us out of the people traffic so we had plenty of space to enjoy ourselves and hear what she had to say. TIPS: Try to go with as few people as possible!!! Wear long pants, shoes and t-shirt. You are outside in the sun for almost whole tour so wear hat, sunglasses, sunscreen, or umbrella!!! Insist that you want to go straight back to your hotel at end of palace and temple tour.CONS / SCAM: ** Instead of driving you straight back to your hotel as advertised...they will take you to the "Gems Gallery". It's a very safe, very large, modern jewelry store BUT it's a scam to get you to buy things. Then when we finished our tour guide sent us in a courtesy van provided by the jewelry store...not our original tour van and driver. I'm sure our tour guide gets some sort of pay-out for delivering us to the jewelry store. My husband was really angry about the forced scam at the end it ruined the morning for him :(

Oustanding. such a beautiful place, wonderful experience and amazing memories to take away. nice to learn about different cultures around the world. the rest of the complex (grand palace etc) was also worth a visit.

beautiful with history. This was the first temple i visited when i was there. it was beautiful. before entering the temple, i saw the some soldiers marching from the palace. as it was near by. they have beautiful structures and very delicate hand craft of the building. visited on Aug 2012 (Again here they do not allow me to select Aug 2012)
Wonderful. Although it is remarkable to see the emerald Buddha, the entire complex is astounding. It is worth the many!

Awesome visit.. The Emerald Buddha is a must see while in BKK. One person told us that if you didn't see the Buddha, you didn't visit BKK. I don't totally agree, but it was special. It is within the Grand Palace complex. The complex itself has amazing architecture and is worth dressing modestly to get in.

Elephant ride. Learned so much of their history, our tour guide was friendly, the weather was absolutely beautiful. At one of our tours, we took an elephant ride, it was great. (I don't know why that the elephant handler hit the elephant on it's head during our ride with a metal rod, it was only walking, didn't misbehave or anything, that seemed cruel and uncalled for. These beautiful creatures are working hard and don't deserve to be mistreated like that.

Enjoyed looking at the little Buddha. He is much smaller than expected. There are many crowds, but once you get in you are allowed to sit as long as you like and look at him. They do have fans going so that is bonus if you need a few minutes break.
Remarkable!. Fantastic rolling History of the ancients in Thailand, including astounding architecture of the Temples.

Emerald Buddha. There were many people praying to Buddha in this temple. What beautiful paintings on all the walls and ceilings of this temple. Emerald Buddha was in the far back part of the temple but two other Buddhas were up front and easier to view.

Dont miss this one if you are in Bangkok. This temple is inside the Grand Palace complex and considered sacred. Both the interior and exterior of the temple is beautifully designed. The sculpture of Buddha is a treat for the eye and the mind.

Remember - This in Grand Palace.. This is a misconception taken all over the minds of everyone. I thought this temple was elsewhere when I suddenly realized, This was a part of the Grand Palace.It's not better or worse, but I wouldn't visit this again. It's really crowded and there is absolutely no order in the temple.One thing I hated the most, YOU cannot take a picture? Why is that?It upset me. I think there are other temples in the cities which can provide you with more peace and excitement.If you have others in mind, visit them, not this.

Full all the time!!!. Its horrible to get to this temple. Its inside the Grand Palace, but is always crowded!!!. There´s no order put by the offcials or military (considering that is a military place) To get to the Emerald Buddah is a mess. Dont waste your time. I think that the Reclined Buddah is more well apreciated and his arounds that this circus place

Very emotional moment!. It was a very emotional moment... I set front of the Buddha and I meditated for some minutes and I left that place very emotional, it is a very special temple which brings you very special feelings :-)
Interesting Temple. the emerald Buddah is different and has an interesting history to it, invest in a tour guide to understand history. really enjoyed myself.

Small but what a site!. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is beautiful - gold and glittery! The Buddha itself is small!! No cameras inside the building, but if you stand at one of the doors you'll be able to take a decent picture of it. Once in stand in the back to view everything. If you go towards the front, you must kneel. Shoulders and knees must be covered and shoes removed!
Great to see, but very small Buddha. Worth the trip but wear long pants and light weight sleeves shirts to save the hassles.. Not suitable with small children
grand palace terrific. the day was stinking hot, but they had plenty of cold water and seats in the shade, the palace is a sight to see

Wat Phra Kaeo - Cultural experience. Don't believe the 'scams' about the temple being closed -- they are just trying to get you to use them as a tour guide. The temple tour guides are good, but you can get around find on your own or even better -- take a Thai friend. No shorts! Take a lot of pictures and share them with your friends who need them for their friends and family back home.
a must see. Gorgeous, It's a must see - don't buy anything (it's expensive) - It was very cool to see artists working on the temple while we were there.

First Temple, well worth it. A beautiful place, stunning architecture, gorgeous reliefs and marvelous views. Did not go into the temple for my own religious beliefs, but that was not a bad thing, as it gave me more time to walk around and see the fantastic statues that line every inch of this place. Certainly well worth the visit no matter your beliefs. Spine chilling.

Amaging place. within the Grand Palace this temple is really great place for everyone visiting Bangkok. The buddha is far off and looks great. Sitting within the main hall of temple gives soothing feeling to all senses. Very nice architecture and work in and around the temple.
A must visit. While in Bangkok you must visit these temples and see how beautiful they are. Very hot so try to go early or in the late afternoon. Must wear long pants also no shorts.

Delightfully lost in translation!. Wonderful , even I do not get a real clear picture of what represents the characters represented on their monuments and figures, so my advice:
Get a guide or a book about the temple and make at least a half day to enjoy it!

Not the best experience on a warm day. Let me start of by saying that I am not a big culture fan. But I was in BKK so I had to visit this complex. The entrance fee was 500 bath which is quite expensive for BKK standards. At the beginning I was given some pants because shorts aren't allowed inside. Once inside there are a lot of temples which you can visit. Since it was very warm and crowded we went straight to the most important temple, the one with the emerald green buddha. This golden coloured temple was nice to view, the Buddha is actually quite small though. The guards in a temple nearby were also quite cool, not moving at all, kind of like the guards at Buckingham palace. We took some pictures of the other temples and went for the exit. Since it was very warm, we decided that we had enough culture for the day!

Get there early - 8.30am. We benefited from getting there at opening time and missing all the tourists as you can take lots of photos of the beautiful architecture without people in the background and it's much more peaceful (we went the day before at 12.30pm and it was heaving so we walked away to return the next morning). It takes about 2 hours to get round the Wat, the Grand Palace and the new textile museum (very interesting) at a leisurely pace.Price had gone up to 500 Baht when we went, but I won't say it wasn't worth it.
Stunning!. Very, very busy and photographs aren't allowed. Stunning architecture and decoration. A very special place for many. Glad I experienced it.
Tourism. Worth a visit to this magnificent monument. Th King has the emerald Bouddah dressed up according to the season
So so. I was underwhelmed by this. The Buddha is up really high and you really can't see it well. I thought it would be showcased more obviously. It is nice to sit in front and meditate though.

Very crowded. The place is very crowded especially with huge groups of chinese tourists making it a very claustrophobic experience. While it is a must-see it really is a case of hold your breath when you go there.
Great temple. This temple, situated in the palace complex is beautiful! the emerald buddha is simply gorgeous and the temple itself has lovely colorful carvings. Truly a feast for the eyes.
Well worth the entrance fee. A site of much appreciation - wonderfully detailed. Very impressive part to the Grand Palace. A massive shame people think it's acceptable to answer calls inside!

Much Ado About.... I think the Emerald Buddha is overdone as a tourist platform. It is revered by the people but I found it over-priced and rushed. We were herded along, no stopping, no photos and allowed through once. Buddha was barely visible under the clothing he was wearing. The rest of the grounds are much better.

Overall good experience. Overall, its a good experience and a must watch once.
The emerald buddha and the architecture of the surrounding buildings is a treat to eyes.
Do keep in mind that its a long walk. If its sunny, it could be really tiring. Do carry water and umbrella.
Fantastic. Great place to spend a few hours. Remember to wear long pants and cover your arms otherwise you have to borrow clothes with a returnable deposit.

A lot smaller than you're expecting. It's in a very pretty setting but it's likely that you'll think it's quite small but it is made of green jade which is a very hard stone to cut. It's set up high and so you may not get the best of views of it. I find the Reclining Buddha at Wat Pho is more inspiring.

Impressed. I'm not religious in any way but spent around ten minutes sitting inside whilst people prayed around us. A very calm, almost inspiring place. The Buddha sits at the top of a huge golden structure. So much to see and take in.

Beautiful. Well worth seeing. The building the Buddha is in is incredible both inside and out and the gold outfit the Buddha is dressed depending on the season is a lovely quirk. All the family including 3 teenagers (15, 17 &19) loved it.

A 'must see' when visiting Bangkok!. An amazing piece of architecture and culture ~ make sure you visit! Not suitable for young children. Remember to dress appropriately as in all temples ~ no tank tops, spaghetti straps, or skimpy clothing. Socks needed and shoes are left outside the temple.
A Must see in Bangkok. Make sure you get a guide to show you around here...there is so very much to see and you will have questions!

A rich Buddhist temple. The grandness and rich interiors is certain to impress the visitors. The sight of the Emerald Buddha on top of a meticulously designed platform has a spiritual effect. One of the must see while in Bangkok.

Small Buddha, but great place. The buddha is small, it is a tourist trap and you cannot make pictures (so why they ask you to pay then?). Otherwise it is a nice place. I took some pictures when the guard was looking elsewhere so I didn't felt too frustrated.

thailand 2013. we went there and people were praying i think it was buddha day or something so we didn t get to see the emerald buddha very clearly but the temple is very big and covered with mosaic or something like that . the climate was hot that day so we didn t get to see every thing clearly because of the tourists and the heat

loved this one the best. I recommend you take the tour that take you to 3-4 major temples and a guid explains it all...types of Budda's new to me 4 differerent types plus possible 5th more feminine version of Buddah

Emerald Buddha. Have seen other Buddhas on my first day in Bangkok (the ones in Ayutthaya) but I still loved this place because of the emerald buddha. Have heard interesting bits of historical info from our tour guide about the emerald buddha and about the whole place (Grand Palace). It's a great experience to go inside and kneel/sit for a while inside.
Must see. Highlight of Bangkok, the complex is so beautiful-bring a camera. Expensive (500BHT) but worth the money as the ticket includes the grand palace. I absolutely loved this!

You've seen one Buddah,. You've seen them all. However, Wat Phrathat Doi Suthep in Chang Mai is much more impressive. Admission to Wat Phra Kaeo is surprisingly expensive. The sight is crawling with tourists.

BANGKOK. While in Bagkok it is a must visit location. The guides give proper details of the place. It is crowded most of the time but it has charm one will remember for many years. One day is not enough to cover all the areas

Serenity in Grandeur. I know it sound conflicting but believe me, this is the truth. The temple is a royal temple inside the Grand Palace complex. I believe it was the temple where the King of Siam used to pray. So obviously it is grand. At the same time, the statue of Buddha has a serene gaze and the temple has a very peaceful and calm atmosphere - as if time has slowed down - thanks in part to a prohibition on photography inside the temple - so no flashes to disturb you.Outside the temple, you can buy the candles, lotus flowers, incense sticks and gold foil to offer to the Buddha if you are religious. If not, well still worth a visit.
top destination. This temple must be the top tourist attraction in bangkok. The architecture w as just amazing. Be careful about the proper dress that you must observe.

A must-do. No matter where this lands on the list of "top attractions", this is a must-see for any first-time visitor to Bangkok. Despite the crowds, the architecture is incredible and it is a top memory of my trip.My advice is to get the audio tour--it helps to drown out the other tourists, and adds a lot of context to the visit.

A must see place. A must see place in Bangkok. An elegant architecture and interesting sculptures. Loved the giant guards! :)Remember that there is a strict dress code (long pants/skirts, long-sleeved shirts for men and women). You can rent appropriate clothing items at the entrance for free (although THB 200 deposit is needed for every rented item of clothing), but it's better to bring your own light clothing to cut the queues.
Beautiful. A place to visit & remember.I love to see the statutes & the marvelous buildings. The grandeur of the place is astounding

nice and grand temple. It was one of the main attraction at Grand Palace. There were mixtures of many styles, not only from Thai, but also from Europe. Many hot spots for us to take pictures. Although it was a little difficult since there were so many people around. I also like the history of the Rama and Sinta that painted on the wall.
visit to the emerald Buddha. The temple is really majestic with many gold decoration, the buddha itself is smaller then we expected.

Very peaceful. Though mounted on a high platform and a smaller image, very good and peaceful ambiance. The entire temple has an awe of its own, though it was told that the green colour is not from emerald, it is magnificent and spectacular

Interesting Color and Design but too Crowded for Comfort or Prayers. This was the only temple that I remembered vividly because of the facade's colors. Super crowded. Had to take off shoes to go inside. No photography allowed
Great temple, tiny Buddha. Every temple in Bangkok is lovely. This one is no exception. It is surprising to see the size of the Buddha though! Worth a stop if you're nearby

Fascinating. This is just beautiful. The Buddha statue is quite small in comparison to others. The murals and decorations are wonderful. The Buddha has different outfits that he wears for different seasons, it was fascinating.
Awe-inspiring. The sheer scale of the place took my breath away, and it feels almost like a pilgrimage as a Buddhist, but people from all religions will be able to enjoy it as well.

So...BEAUTIFUL!. Dazzling gold, gem and jeweled temples and lots of things to see and admire! I love the details that goes into the buildings of these temples. The Emerald Buddha statue is small but pretty to look at. Me and my mother went to look inside the "Pavilion of Regalia" thinking to take only 30 minutes but we ended up spending almost an hour to look at everything since it was so interesting (I read some of the labels and watched a video clip, too! Not just looking at the items on display). I liked seeing the different swords - Thai, Japanese, Korean, etc. We didn't go into the Queen's Textile Museum though because we'd just be looking at dresses, fabrics, and textiles - which is not to my interest. It's really one of the best temples to visit in a short time frame. By the way, I read that girls must wear dresses or long skirts but not pants so we came wearing skirts. But we saw there there were some girls wearing jeans and pants, too. So it doesn't really matter weather girls wears pants, dresses, or skirts as long as it's not revealing.
glows from afar. I saw the glow from outside and turned out its the emerald Buddha. Lots of people come here. Dress appropriately before coming though so once can enter.
Don't waste your time. Expensive and boring (but free to Thais) Last time I took friends it was about 350 baht entrance and that was 3 years ago - about £7 per person

Beautiful place!. Inside of the temple you will can not take photos, but you can take a shot from outside the temple.Don't expect to see a big Buddha, he is quite small, but really beautiful, stunning, glowing covered in gold. It is a must to see.

Crowded, not cheap but a MUST. We were traveling on a strict budget. This costs us 1000B each, not cheap and mega crowded but WORTH IT. It is splendid. You will be amazed by every detail and corner of the place. You will also get to know more about Thai history and culture. Remember:- Come before 3.15 as they stop letting people in after 3.15- Dress properly!! Seriously strict this one is, no shorts/skirts/short pants whatsoever. You can deposit and borrow their pants or buy outside of the Palace though. They keep checking on until you get inside so don't be lazy. I saw a guy being refused to get in at the main entrance (ticket check) because he was wearing sporty pants which is just a little bit shorter than the normal pants.- No photos in prohibited areas. I saw 3 people were asking, even begging for their cameras back. The guards were really serious about it.

Most wonderful Buddha!. What phra Kaeo is the most wonderful temple I have seen.Beautiful emeral Buddha as well as many small Buddha around the temple. Tip must dress up with long pant no short otherwise u have to get change at the entrance.
Amazing place. Definitely worth to visit. Entrance fee is 500baht. This is just a magical place, amazing architecture, amazing amazing.

Beautiful Buddha. This is a lovely temple with a really beautiful Buddha statue made of jade not emerald, the nearby museum which details the history of the restoration of the temple is well worth a visit too.

Very busy place!!. The emerald Buddha is within the grand palace! I found it to be a little expensive per person and when I was there, the amount of tourists and the queing systems they have in place made it longer than I expected!! Can't take pictures inside the temple, but if you have a good zoom camera, you can take a picture from outside! Well worth a visit.......but take some water with you! All the heat reflects off everything and gets extremely hot!! Just watch your belongings round the grand palace as it is very populated with locals and tourists and wouldn't want the worst happening!!

Great place, greater crowds.. Beautiful place and one of the main attractions for tourists. Come dressed appropriately. By that I mean covered up but well-ventilated as it is HOT on the palace and wat grounds! Crowded with tourists, so watch the kids and your belongings well. You can't take photos inside the shrine of the Emerald Buddha. Please respect that. Not even smartphones, not even non-flash cameras.

Beautiful. It's within the grounds of the Grand palace but make sure you don't miss the Emerald Buddha. It is actually Jade but still exquisite. No photos from within the enclosure but if you have a decent lens on your camera you can take a photo from the outside.

Nice place!. I didn't like the fact you can't take pictures, but what to do... Also I read that the this Budha Image is very small but it's really smaller that I though. However, it's beautiful and very interesting. The place is clean, well maintained and suitable for tourists.

A wonderful place to visit but don't forget your camera.. I really liked this Temple, it is an amazingly beautiful spiritual place. Go see it. Take your camera as there are so many photo opportunities, early morning or late afternoon is the best time.
Dont miss it!. We went as tourists but sat inside as pilgrims. The inner sanctum is so peaceful and beautiful you could spend hours there.

Another Buddha???. It's easy to become overwhelmed in the visit to the Grand Palace and the surrounding temples and to minimize the beauty of any single temple, but this one if standing alone would hold anyone in awe. Usually crowded by tourists and confining in space, but a real gem (pun intended) to see.

dress properly. It’s a visit that I did not find very interesting, as there were too many people inside the complex. It was suffocating. The temple gives you an understanding of how Thais give significance to Buddha. Make sure you wear the right cloths when you enter the Temple complex. Take a cruise to Grand Palace, and it’s easier to reach, if you take the river route.
Great. Beautiful and spectacular. The place, however, is over-crowded with flocks of tourists. General cleanliness in toilet and public area can be better

Crowded but beautiful. Be careful as this attraction is very crowded and we were warned off pickpockets. You must take your shoes off first outside and women must dress modestly (cover shoulders, no shorts etc). There is no photography allowed inside, but you can take a picture from the outside. The buddha itself is very small but the room inside is wonderfully ornate and well worth the visit.

Must go. The biggest "wat complex" we went to in Bangkok. Went to visit this and the Grand Palace. Extremely crowded, watch for pick pockets as our guide would say. Cold towels for sale near the exit going to the grand palace, nice for a hot day.

Hugely overcrowded but a must on the Bangkok tour scene. Tour groups have over-run the Grand Palace complex where the Emerald Buddha is located. Entrance fee of 500 Bts for foreigners is not over the top, but Thais get in free. I recommend engaging a guide who will help to navigate the crowds. FYI, the small Buddha that you see is in fact a replica, not the real one that is kept elsewhere. Lots of gold though.
Worth the visit. We saw many temples in Bangkok, but few made the impression that this one did. Well located next to the river, the temple has many interesting aspects that make it well worth a look.

I love temples, especially beautiful ones like this one. I love temples, especially beautiful ones like this one. The place was so sacred, and serene. Plus they let you take lots of pictures, so you get some real good shots.

One of the key "Asian tourist sites" to see. If you are in Bangkok you sort of have to do the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. The entire site is ornate to the point of gaudiness, but cannot really be adequately described or even really photographed. You just have to go and see it.

Magnificent. Our group visited the Emerald Buddha within the Grand Palace complex in June. Be careful of scammers –which are the worst in Bangkok. Scammers here are dressed in official uniforms. Just avoid them – ignore them.Make sure you are well dressed for the temple. Once inside the Emerald Buddha you must remove your shoes outside. Although the Buddha is very small and hard to see it is set amongst a fantastic array or jeweled and gold artifacts. I was surprised with the 500 Baht entrance fee just to see this but it was just worth it.Wanted to spend longer time here but it was just too hot!
great with buddhist tour guide. as we wanted to learn more about buddhist temples etc, our tour guide an ex monk organised through Tong Tours was exceptional

Emerald Buddha Temple. Another beautiful temple in Bangkok. The beautiful Emerald Buddha sits very high. We could only take pictures from the outside, which I was able to do. A good stop on our private tour with Thai Private Tour.
Another Great Site. Visited this place on our tour to the Grand Palace and is a super sight to see. Recommend this place highly to visit at least once when you are sightseeing in Bangkok.

utter rubbish. we paid 500 baht i think to enter the grand palace and started wandering around. clearly a mistake. the whole place is one way so if you don't see something you want to see and walk past a guard you can forget going back. we did this and missed the emerald buddha. the guards were really aggressive and threatening when we asked if we could go back. hideous.

Another temple, pretty!. After a few temples, it really does seem like you have seen them all. This one is beautiful and has some history behind it, however it is just a temple. The hand painted walls and the beautiful buddha are great to see, but it as about comparable to the reclining buddha or maybe the gold buddha or temple of dawn. They run together in my mind.

No words to describe. If you only have one choice to do one thing in Bangkok, this would be it. It literally took my breath away. There are no words to describe the magnificence! And when you step inside, the murals are so intricate but the Emerald Buddah made me feel like He was really there surrounding me with His love. I was so overwhelmed, I cried.

Unique but.... We were excited to see the Emerald Buddha since my mom's favorite color is green. When we saw it we were kinda disappointed because photography was not allowed inside and the Emerald Buddha sits high up so we cannot really appreciate it up close. But I like that the Buddha was clothed in gold and the clothes change depending on the season.

Emerald Buddha in the dark. This is my second time to visit the Emerald Buddha. Last time,, in 1999, it was easy to see. This time, there lights were out and no photography allowed. I do not know why it was darkened. Too bad, I did not have the same feeling when seeing it.
Beautiful place. Красиво.. Можно взглянуть на одну из тайских красот.Beautiful place, if you want to see something thai culture, you can go there.

number one place to visit. amazing temple complex.....its a beautiful reflection of the thai culture.... a very revered place for the locals too....the colours and the architecture of the place is beautiful...and its very well maintained...a little on the expensive side..a ticket costs 500 baht...but with the required maintainence i am sure its justified

not interesting. This is the most famous temple to visit in Bangkok. However, there were too many tourists and the enviornment was overwhelmingly crowed and noisy. It was too hot in the daytime and there was no shade at all, so it was not a pleasant trip and not good value for money.

This is in a temple a short distance away from the emerald buddha. We went to this temple in the midst of a very hot day, and hence could not spend much time here, in the palace complex. there is a 500baht entry fee, and you are required to cover up your knees and sleeved shirts are preferred. if you are not having these, like i did, then wait to enter the compex where you can rent FREE OF COST, a track suit for wearing.
Amazing. Incredible piece of art, very different from the Western architecture. You should definitely see it.

Excellent piece of art. This temple is located in the Grand Palace of the Thai King. The King does not live here anymore.The temple has a very beautiful jade statue of the Buddha. It was presumed to have been made of Emerald therefore it is called Emerald Buddha. The Temple complex has the palace, the Coronation Room, The Throne Room, the Funeral Place also of the Royal family.The Temple has different stupas made in the Thai, Cambodian and Burmese style. The art work, the work on the walls, the statues of the Apsara and the door keepers are very well made and add to the beauty of the place.There are lotus flowers in different colors in the complex. The Blue lotus looked very exquisite.The gardens are well maintained. One has to dress properly to visit this temple. No off shoulder dress, no shorts, are allowed. They do provide a sarong and shirt free of charge on returnable basis.The entry to the Complex shuts at 3.30 pm. The place is quite crowded and one is warned to take care of one's belongings. the entry fee is 500 Bhats, which is quite expensive, but I consider a visit to this complex a must.One must take the services of an Official Guide , so that one can see all the places properly.While in the temple of the Buddha, while sitting, one must not point one's feet towards the Buddha.
Everything made of gold!. Fantastic experience. Heaps of history in this place and the free tour was absolutely great. Pretty much everything was made of gold!

Another must see!!. This is definately another must see in Bangkok!! Do not forget to dress appropriately ,by that I mean that men/women should wear trousers /three quarter shorts and shoulders should be covered.Inside the temple where the emerald Buddha sits you can not take pictures standing up or lying down on the carpet.You are supposed to be sitting down at all times.Fantastic photos can be taken at this temple!!!
Book the massage first then tour. The massage is a major highlight especially if you have visited the grand palace before this. Its another huge place, the big buddha is impressive but thats it.

This is such a cool Reclining Buddha.... This is much easier to get in to see if you are short on time. Very impressive monument/religious site. Still lots of people there, and terrible traffic if you are trying to go by car. So save time for this.

great and tiring. first is that we had an experience riding their boat so just going there you already see different places and shopping areas.when we got there they dont allow shorts or leggings for women so you have to rent like a sarong for the day to wrap your legs. 130bhat then after using it they return you the 100bhat.overall, looking at temples all wrapped in gold was unforgettable i think it was around 10 temples in there so from morning till afternoon walk so wear your most comfortable shoes. but overall experience was great
visit with toktok. me and my friend went their with toktok by optional tour, our toktok driver drove us over 3 hours for optaional sales.

Opulance!. This place just floored me! I was hot and tired and jet lagged, but once I stepped into Wat Phra Kaew, I was totally in awe. This place is one of the most oppulant places I have ever been.
