The temple just sparkles and shines from every angle, such incredible, intricate decorations. It is a very popular temple and can get crowded, but you will be too busy picking your jaw up off the ground to really notice the crowds. There is a little cafe here, too. I recommend picking up a refreshing Chang beer before heading back out into the city.

A Must-See in Bangkok!. We went here as part of a day touring the Grand Palace, the River, and Wat Pho. It was soooooo hot everywhere that we were glad just be inside. With our shoes off, we marvelled at the ornate decor on the walls and the grandeur of the room. Several large fans help keep people cool as they visit, some -like us- just looking, but others sitting to pray.We visited many temples and holy sites in SE Asai and this is definitely the most impressive. The Buddha himself is not that big, but hey, he's made of jade, and that's always pretty cool.One caveat. When leaving the complex we tried four taxis - but couldn't find one that would switch on his meter. They all wanted to rip us off with a flat fee. In the end we negotiated a tuk tuk. It was cheaper, more fun, and the driver was a 1000% more friendly.

A very old and magnificent temple. Temple of the Emerald Buddha is within the Grand Palace compound and this attraction is included in the ticket entrance to the grand palace. You have to queue up to enter the temple as there is always a big crowd everyday and must wear long pants to enter the temple. The lighting inside the temple is a bit dark but can see the Emerald Buddha in the center clearly. Very special and very woth the visit.

Interesting temple and grounds and must see. The budda is actually jade but very interesting site. You cannot take pictures inside the temple so I stood outside and zoomed in to take one and was promptly pooped on by a bird. I guess I should not have done that either.
Nice...... It's a great place to visit. A very good experience. I spent a great time there. Totally recommended...

The Most Revered Site in Thailand. If you have some appreciation of Thai culture and Buddhism, this site will be awesome. Have been back three times, and have enjoyed just sitting and taking it all in. Impressive.
A must!!. A nice and a interesting place of Bangkok, really sugget.And more other attraction are there around ... so you can easily rich Grand Palace or China Town
Worth a stop. A smaller temple than some of the others in Bangkok. But still worth seeing. It can be crowded. Just plan for a quick stop there.

Worth Seeing as Part of your Tour. Like others have mentioned, it is worth seeing as part of your tour. The building is very pretty and the inside is very artfully done. For what it is, I think it is overcrowded. Lots of people in a small area of the room shuffling by the Buddha. It is neat to see.
Stunning!. Beuatiful temple, worth to see it! Just be carefull with people trying to "help" you get in. They are just trying to get your money. Always find the main entrance by yourself.

Popular Place. It is worth seeing the Emerald Buddha as part of your visit to the Grand Palace. The Buddha itself is rather small, and sits high on a throne. It's adornments change with the season. During the week, you are likely to see school groups visiting the site. Photographs are not allowed.

Gorgeous!. Loved: temple itself, amazing architecture.
Not-so-much: Ended up costing me about $25usd round trip, it's a bit far away, and the trip will take you about 2 or 3 hours overall.

Emerald Buddha. This is inside the grounds of the Grand Palace and is therefore included in the Grand Palace ticket and is worth doing if you are there. It is the most sacred Buddha in Thailand, and is cut from a single piece of jade (the green colour giving it it's name) and wears gold adornments that are changed by the King three times a year, one for each season (dry/cool, hot. rainy). It is quite small and placed quite high up, so is slightly difficult to see - although that does mean you don't need to push your way to the front of any crowds (and there will be..!)

Beautiful but busy. A popular temple to see, you can expect a lot of tourists at this temple. The Emerald Buddha is beautiful, although smaller than one expects. Don't forget your glasses if you are like me!Be careful when visiting this temple as there are loads of touts outside the main entrance who will attempt to charge you for entrance a guiding. Ignore them and head through the main gate to find the actual ticket office.Remember to cover up legs and shoulders (men and women), we saw loads of people "renting" trousers and scarves before being allowed to enter.

Superb preserver of art. This emrald buddha idol was found from thr ground in some excavations and the King then made a temle for it in Grand Palace, before it was Just a royal temple but now a days regular people can visit it, you can visit this temple once you get inside the Royal Grand Palace.

Royal Shrine - Jade Buddha - The Nation's Buddha. You gotta know the story to enjoy this one. What made the Jade Buddha so special to the Thais is its history. Legend said, that the Jade Buddha has been the symbol of kingdom in Thailand for hundreds of years. So it's like a power symbol for the kingdom, despite of its relatively smaller size compared to other Buddha statues in the country. It is also serve like a welfare amulet for the Thais. On several occasions, the Jade Buddha is paraded around the city. It is believed that the Jade Buddha can cure the sickness and bring luck to the people.That's also why, it receives "special" treatment from the royals. King of Thailand takes care the statue with his own hand. The most well-known ritual is the cloth-changing ritual, when the King replace the sheath covering of the statue with his own hand. There are three kind of covers the Jade Buddha has, and each depends on the season in Thailand. Since Thailand has three seasons (summer, rainy, and cold), there will be three cloth-changing rituals in a year. You can see a brief video exhibition of this ritual in a small museum called "The Pavilion of Regalia", located between the ticket locket and the entrance gate to the main Grand Palace complex. The Jade Buddha's clothings are stored in this pavilion. From outside, the Pavilion of Regalia (a small museum) looks like an ordinary souvenir stall, so many visitors do not recognized it. Ticket to enter Grand Palace complex is bundled with three exhibitions, the Grand Palace complex, the Pavilion of Regalia, and the Queen Sirikit textile museum. So make sure you don't skip any of them. To save your time the best sequence after you purchase the ticket of Grand Palace Complex area would be like this:0. Purchase the ticket --- only one locket in this complex.1. Visit the Pavilion of Regalia (I put a picture of it), in about 15-20 steps from the locket.2. Grand Palace complex.3. Go to the Queen Sirikit Textile Museum on the way back.Hmmm... I think I should post this info at the Grand Palace section too.Wonder how many visitors skipped that Pavilion of Regalia.Cheers!

The Little Green Buddha. Despite its relatively small size (compared to other Buddha images in other temples), the Emerald Buddha is deemed to be the most revered in Bangkok, and for good reason: it is the holiest since only the Thai King has the right to touch it and change its robe thrice a year (according to the season). It is said to be cut entirely out of a single piece of jade (not emerald as the name suggests), and is probably about a couple of feet tall, but sits in a golden altar probably 10 feet high. Try to come here as early as you can; you don't want to be here around noon time when there are lots of tourists already and everybody is sweating like a pig amid the city's humidity. The combined smell of different people's body odor and the dampness of the air within the temple is just nauseating.

Emerald buddha. This temple is not all that big and the Emerald Buddha is not as big as I thought, after seeing huge statues of Buddha I was surprised to find that this one is about 300 mm or 1 foot high. Still very beautiful ad interesting.

Looked Incredible. We wen't to the Temple and really enjoyed it, my biggest gripe is that there was no one explaining what happened, there was also no english translations of the history of the temples and all the art that surrounded it. I'm sure we could have paid extra to get that information, but at 500฿ you would have at least expected something to read. but apart from that visually it was AMAZING the architecture was incredible.

Crowded. Because this temple is located at the Grand Palace, it is typically very crowded and difficult to get in and see anything. The Grand Palace is a must see so you might as well take a quick peak inside and see the Emerald Buddha while you are there. If you go in the museum near the entrance to the Grand Palace, there are the different golden clothing that the Emerald Buddha wears and it tells the history of this Emerald Buddha (which is actually Jade).
Beautiful. This was within the Grand Palace grounds and a very sacred place . The Buddha is beautiful and holds a lot of significance to the Thai people. Well worth viewing and enjoying the beauty.

Emerald Buddha. Place was average ambiance. The Buddha statute looked elegant but the rest of it was ordinary. You have a plain area where you can stand and watch the Buddha. Nearby you have people selling the Buddha statues.
Serene place. The Emerald Buddha is pretty small and you are not allowed to take pictures in the temple. It gets pretty crowded with tourists too.
Fascinating temple but too crowded. Fascinating temple but very crowded and emerald Buddha very hard to see. The rest of the complex was beautiful as well.
Not to Be Missed. This is one of those sites in Bangkok you don't want to miss. We made a special trip and yes, it was so hot. Remember to carry water if you go in the rainy season.
Go after 2:30pm. Crowds will disappear 1 hr before closing. Best time to view... even the street vendors are gone by the time we leave the grounds.

a nice temple - but just another nice temple. a temple - after visiting a million temples - all start to look the same, some more sparkly than others, and some with dragons, or people or animal statues and buddhas. This temple is nice if your temple hopping around the area, although if i was not in the area, or had just so happened to be walking past, i wouldnt have bothered visiting it.
very crowded. very hard to see the emerald Buddha. The day we went it was very crowded but managed to get some good photos.

A must see. Most important temple in Bangkok. We hired a private guide (who took us to this temple as well as the Grand Palace, Wat Pho and Wat Arun) and think it was well worth her 1000THB daily rate for the information she provided. Absolutely beautiful temple, very special place.

Humbling. This temple made me feel very humble. Even though the actual jade budda is not huge, the respect it is given in a hall lined and filled with gold objects is awesome. Everyone must remove shoes, stepover threshold and sit with feet behind them. feel very grateful to have seen this.

To see and visit without doubt, beautiful!. The Wat Phra Kaeo is called the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. It is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple in Thailand. It is located in the historic centre of Bangkok within the precincts of the Grand PalaceWat Phra Kaeo has a plethora of buildings within the precincts of the Grand Palace, which covers a total area of over 94.5 hectares.Take attention to ollow a dress code, which is strictly followed. Men must wear long pants and long-sleeved shirts and shoes; women must wear long skirts. It is compulsory to remove the shoes before entering the temple, as a sign of respect of the Buddha, as is the practice in all other temples in Thailand.
Day tour. This was part of the palace complex and was very busy but well worth the visit. You are not allowed to take photo's in there but can get a shot through the entrance if not to crowded.

Emerald Buddha. A very respected religious temple. The emerald Buddha is small and ou are not able to take photos inside, local Thais visit to worship, although a major tourist attraction within the grand palace

Just take it in while you're there, you can sort it out later.. I didn't have the opportunity to exhaustively research the Temple compound prior to my visit, but I was completely captivated by this collection of buildings and monuments from a range of styles. I took as many photos as I could and then went online to cross reference my photos with a map of the complex, such as the one found online at Wikipedia.Yes, I would have preferred better signage -- even if it were just a numbered key code one could cross reference to a printed map, and yes, it's too bad that photography is not permitted inside the Temple itself, but if the requirement of an excellent attraction is that it is not to be missed, then this compound belongs at the top of any list.P.S.: An excellent photo of the interior of the temple may be found at http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/i/MSNBC/Components/Photo/_new/pb-110121-buddhist-ceremony-eg.jpg

~Wat Phra Kaew!!~. About 7 years ago, I visit Wat Phra Kaew with my friends in school vacation. For Thai people ,Wat Phra Kaew is the most impotance place in our countryWat Phra Kaew or full official name is Wat Phra Si Rattana Satsadaram is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple in Thailand. It is a “potent religio-political symbol and the palladium of Thai society”.It is located in the historic centre of Bangkok (district Phra Nakhon), within the precincts of the Grand Palace.Wat Phra Kaew begin contruction in 1782 and complete in 3 years later This marked the beginning and raise of the Chakri Dynasty of the present Kingdom of Thailand.At first after get into Wat Phra Kaew, you must go to Ubosort and the Emerald Buddha (number 1 in map).You’ll see the most beautiful of image of Buddha.Phra Kaeo Morakot or official name is Phra Phuttha Maha Mani Rattana Patimakon is the palladium of the Kingdom of Thailand, a figurine of the sitting Buddha, made of green Nephrite , clothed in gold, and about 45 cm tall. It is kept in the Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew) on the grounds of the Grand Palace in Bangkok.ContentsWhile legend traces this statue to India, its rich historical records dates its finding in Cambodia in the 15th century, moved to Laos in the 16th century and then to Vientiane where it remained for 215 years, and finally to Thailand in the 18th century.After seeing Phra Kaeo Morakot, you have to walk around because this place is not only beautiful that you can’t estimate but also precious in Thai history.
Crowded but "MUST". Try to make your visit early, (nothing much) but its the No:1 tourism spot of Bangkok. Conected with the Kings palace will need 2 hours for an easy way.
Family vacation. We were pleasantly surprised that there were bags to put our shoes in so that they were not lost among the thousands of other shoes removed before entering the temple.

religious site. I could see the locals lined up to witness and worship. I was on a visit to the Grand Palace, and so it just happen that I passed it along the way. I did stop to have a close look. The structure though old, still has a architecture to marvel at.

The Emerald Buddha. High above on a splendid pedestal is the small statue of the Emerald Buddha. Part of the Imperial Palace, this temple is dedicated to this exquisitely carved statue. One is struck by the devotion displayed by the visitors, a majority of the m being Thais. The Thais are devoted Buddhists and this can be seen in their behavior.The only precaustion when visiting this temple is that photography is not allowed inside the Temple.
Shinning Golden Palace. Woooo is the first word when I saw it. And those shinning golden roof almost blind my eyes......Sun glasses are very necessary buddies :)
Amazing experience. You must see the Grand Palace so you won't be able to miss the Emerald Buddha, a bit crowded but a fantastic experience.

Interesting, would be better if I had a guide with me. This is near to the entrance, one of the first few buildings you will enter. But I was surprised to not find an obvious sign outside to tell me this is "Temple of the Emerald Buddha". I kind of had to guess it. The shrine that house the Emerald Buddha is rather small. Upon entering, no photos are allowed. Most people inside will sit for some minutes, in silence, to either pray or just take in the sights within the temple. Make sure you are dressed in proper (cover limbs, tee shirt with short sleeves is fine, just that you have to cover your bottom such as wearing jeans or long dress).Would be good if I have some guide with me, as there is not many signs in English to explain history and background.
Mesmerising.. I have seen this awsome structure on so many many books and TV programs but nothing beats seeing it for the first time. It was unbelievably beautiful.

It's Jade not Emerald. The emerald Buddah has a nice name but is just one solid piece of jade not really emerald at all. Worth a peek though, but so very small up on his mound that you really can't see and aren't allowed taking photos.

Too crowded for a temple. This is really too bad. I am a big fan of ancient art and enjoyed cultures very much. I remember about 20 years ago when I first visited this temple, the atmosphere was very serene. The sight of the emerald Buddha was so calming. I remembered clearly how my guide told me that the monks change the robe's of the Buddha image according to the seasons. But last week, all of these beautiful memories came to abrupt end because the temple was so crowded and very noisy. I made the same comment on The Grand Palace. The government should make a better tourist management and make limitation on how many people can come and visit the temple.
A must see. At 500 Baht it's one of BKK's most expensive temples but it's undoubtedly worth it and will hardly break the bank. It's mind blowing how ornate everything is - definitely worth a visit.

Go with a guide to get the most of it. This temple is stunning!
Go with a guide though (we went through my time who were partners with out hotel)
It's hot though!!! Hot hot hot!
Drink water and wear a hat

Charming!!. One of its kind with the dazzling miniature statue of the emeral buddha sitting atop on a height. The golden structures around the statue are stunning and you can feel the peace and aesthatic charm of the place if you give some time inside the temple. A must visit!

out of this world. the story is intresting and the place is out of this world. however Emerald Buddha is really small. located really high so you will not get a chance to see it close. is it really Emerald?

The history enhances the experience. It is one of the highlights of the Grand Palace visit. I had read about the history of the Emerald Buddha. So, this made the visit more interesting. As I was standing in front of the statue, the history was running through my mind. When you read so much about a particular attraction, just standing in front of it is a numbing experience. Do spend some time here and watch the priests performing their religious rites.

Awesome place!. I really enjoyed exploring all the temples in Bangkok, and this is one of my favourite!! I recommend you spend some time inside and observe all the people adoring Buddha. It's magical...

One of the MUST-SEE temples of Thailand. The Emerald Buddha at this location is Priceless!. This temple is very well appointed and maintained. A MUST-VISIT location for visitors, irregardless of yr religious orientation.

Amazing Sight. My husband and I visited the Temple along with the Grand Palace. For us Europeans, eager to learn about Thai culture, the temple was a superb introduction!Here's a tip: To really understand the history and culture behind it, get a tour guide.

It's smaller than I thought. Okay, I knew it was small. And I knew it wasn't emerald but actually jade. And I knew that when it was discovered, they thought it was clay for a long time until somebody rubbed the clay and found the green jade underneath which is a pretty good story. And I'd seen photos of it and knew it was on the top of a stupa (??). But I didn't know it was SO small and that I couldn't get close enough to it to see it properly. But I can say I've (almost) seen it so that's okay. What I do find really amazing is the reverence that people feel. I have a photo of the Emerald Buddha which a woman standing before it, just staring at it. To me, that's the experience.

Beautiful Wat complex. Various temples in the same complex, including as well the Great Palace. Watch out for they do not show the opening days of the Palace at the entrance and charge you full price (Palace and Wat) even on the days when the Palace is closed to visitation.
One word......amazing.. There is nothing to dislike. This was fantastic. Don't forget to use the lotus flowers outside to wet your head.

Amazing History. I went to the Temple of the Emerald Buddha in February 2012. Very crowded with tourist but definitley worth going. You get to see the Emerald Buddha which is smaller than what I had expected but amazing non the least. The clothes that the emerald Buddha wears is worth Millions of Dollars and is made out of Gold, Diamonds and other very precious stones.
Beautiful temple. This is a must see in Bangkok. The temple is in the grand palace, best to go in the morning to avoid the crowd and heat. The beatiful temple and beautiful emerald buddha.

A bit under-whelming. Mentally one expects a very large emerald Buddha. The reality is much smaller. How can one have such a large emerald to carve a Buddha!The other downer is that photography is not allowed inside the temple!

Breathless!. Entering the temple ground will leave you breathless, both literally and figuratively. The lines of people waiting to buy tickets (THB 500) and waiting to go in are endless. Watch out for the fashion police at the turnstiles making sure your attire meets the dress code. Some were turned away and had to rent pants. The temple grounds is a vast complex of beautiful structures, statues, monuments and murals. It's a photographer's dream location! Take your time to go around and admire these attractions before you enter the main temple building. Visitors are required to remove their shoes before entering, and you'll be awed by the grandness of the temple's sanctum. It takes your breath away!
Good. A must do at the palace. It was rather busy and much smaller than expected. Allow plent of time lots else to see

Beautiful temple. This is a very nice temple.This is in big complex, where there are more temples. Prepare for the huge mass.Generally the ticket includes the Throne Hall and the Vimanmek Mansion (at the Dusit Park) as well, and this ticket valid for 7 days after purchase (for these two sights).

Simply Breathtaking. The energy, expense and lavishness gone into this Temple is an indication of the devotion and deep seated belief in all the ancient myths of a bygone age. The English speaking free tours that run 3 or 4 times a day ( just close to the temple itself ) is worth waiting for. Resist the touts at the entrance who will "guide" you for a fee.Make sure you allow 2 to 3 hours to take it all in.
A glimpse of the old world. The temple is located in a massive complex that is explored with a tour guide. It is impressive with a great amount of gold and precious stones.

Kinda small. Well worth the visit to this beautiful temple but the actual buddha himself is a little bit smaller than I expected! This really is just picking hairs though, it's a must see destination if in Bangkok.

You should come very early in the morning. Although taking pictures of the Emerald Buddha is not allowed, the others are okay, so spend at least 2 hours there. And you should come very early in the morning for better experience, I guess. We came there in the early afternoon and gosh, jam-packed of tourists.
Really a sight to Behold!!!. It's within the premises of the Grand Palace, It is very beautifully placed... i wish they would have allowed photography over there...

Yes, go. Yes, go see this temple along with the Grand Palace. Go early, dress for the conditions, no pictures, but take mental ones and keep them for yourself. Don't even try to take a picture, I saw a guy do it, and he got thrown out of the temple. Give yourself ample time to do it right. A must do and see while you are in Bangkok.

A little wonder. An interesting story behind the Buddha. Bit difficult to see atop a great display the temple.This is a sacred site but you'd be hard to tell from the lack of cultural awareness by some visitors. Come on guys, have a bit of respect.

Amazing. I really love the whole area and the amazing architect's work. Did my prayers in there and its an amazing experience with other devotees in there. However one thing i disliked about the whole area is tourists who are not so well mannered making the whole event a joke.

WOW!. My first visit to a Thai temple and what an experience. This one has lift acces if you cant negotiate the stairs not the Golden Buddha temple in another review..sorry my mistake. This is a very large temple and once again included in a half day tour is a must to see when visiting Bangkok. At all temples you need to be prepared to take off your shoes before entering. Try and avoid lace up shoes like I did as you get plenty of practice doing up your laces each time. Also men must wear long pants and at least a short sleave shirt...t-shirts and singlets and bare skin are not permitted entry...so if you have tatts cover them up...you can hire long pants and shirts at these locations...you can always tell the ones who dont read the tourist literature or take the advice from the tour company.Also at this temple was this young guy taking photos of people stopping to have a photo taken. I found out why when I returned back down the stairs as he presents you on a tray with your photo on a badge/fridge magnet with Bangkok and the year...how could I resist 200 baht for 2 then he offers you another 2 for 100 baht...well I thought gifts for the staff to remember their boss. so I ended up with 4...great fun and great momento of your visit. so clever to make in about 20 minutes.
It was ok. As there are so many temples in Thailand this seemed to me as another temple. Still nice but there are nicer ones around.

Nice but Much Less than Expected. As much as I was a little disappointed by the emerald buddha - I still believe this is a Must Do! I could not believe how small it was based on how much it was discussed. But the history of the Buddha alone between Thailand and Laos makes it something worth seeing as well as how important it is to the Thai people. Just make sure you prepare yourself for the steep price of admission (500 baht) and also that the area closes by 4:30 - make sure to walk around the rest of the Grand Palace as well.

very crowded. Beautiful Wat, but very crowded. Fantastic sights, but not typical of a Thai temple, so please do not make this your only visit to a temple. Find an ordinary wat, and feel the Thai experience, but the ornateness of this temple is amazing
Very crowded but great to see. It's amazing heritage to see and obviously famous so worth the trip. The crowds are at times over wheeling, especially with our young kids with the humidity on top!
Interesting. Like everything in Bangkok, too many people, too crowded. Nice facility, worth the visit, just keep that in mind.

Temple within grand palace. Located in the grand palace (entry fee 500bht - so high!!), the emerald Buddha is a nice place to visit, however honestly it is very similar, more busy and less impressive than the other temples (eg reclining Buddha/wat pho), furthermore, a very strict sitting policy and no photo policy is enforced. However since it is included in the grand palace ticket and you have paid the whooping high entrance fee, you might as well see it and enjoy it anyways, and a good place to rest from the sun.To enter you are required to dress modestly (no shorts or sleeveless tops (even if covered by scarf), and you are required to take off your shoes so apply the same rules as in skiing and place your two shoes separately to deter people nicking them.

Emerald Buddah. The emerald Buddah is made of jade- it is small but absolutely beautiful. it is easy to imagine why it was moved so many times and wanted by so many cities. It has found a beautiful home here in Bangkok.

Beautiful.. Don't miss this. Spend the few dollars for a guide, so you know what you are looking at. It felt a lot like being in the Sistine Chapel, and I have to say, even more beautiful. Get someone to watch your shoes outside, or put them in a bag and bring them with you, so they aren't stolen while you are inside.

Expensive, strict dress code. Awesome. 500 Bhat per person entry. Minimum half sleeve shirt, ankle covered bottom and covered shoes. Closes at 3:30pm. Best to do this first then go to wat arun and then wat po
Very peaceful. This was amazing. Three Buddhas in a row like green stone .the Buddhas have coats on with the seasons, like summer winter autumn and spring

Beautiful!. This temple is within the Grand Palace. Be sure to take water to drink, wear a hat and sunscreen, and sun-glasses if you go here. It is very hot, and no water available for purchase until the exit. Plan 1 - 2 hours for this tour.

Great free English tour. We were surprised at the 500 baht per person entry fee but of course we were going to pay a visit to Bangkok's most important temple and palace. Once there though we didnt feel like shelling out for the audio guide, and just as well we didn't because just to the left of the ticke gate, there was a desk where you can sign up for a free English guided tour (10am, 10.30am, 1.30pm and 2pm). The tour was great, whilst scripted, we managed to get our guide off script with a few questions. It was also fast paced and she gave us a high level overview of the important monuments rather than an indepth history lesson, and a bit of time for photos too. All in all it was a good experience.

Good place with grandeur, religion and culture. The Grand Palace complex, including the Temple of Emerald Buddha, is a nice place. Despite the high price of 500 Baht, it is teeming with tourists and hence best to go early and preferably with a guide to get some information. The dress code is strict especially for women needing to wear full length trousers /skirts etc. But half sleeves shirts were ok. The temple ambience was wonderful - especially for religious Indians like us. The statue per se was small but is on top of a wonderful golden pyramid.

Worth the trip. The place was packed. It was great to see the emerald Buddha and its seasonal outfits. We placed our shoes on a rack before entering the room. The staff moved the rack without knowing. It took us a few minutes to fine our shoes.

The best wat in Thailand!. This is next to the Grand Palace and both are a must see when you are in BKK. I took more pictures here than anywhere. We were here for over an hour but could have easily stayed two or more with all the things to see. Be sure to dress appropriately for the temple - slip on shoes and no bare legs. Also the area is mostly outdoors so bring an umbrella to help protect from the sun. The area is also quite crowded so be careful with scams. There was a man trying to detour us from the entrance saying it was closed to tourists. This is a huge tourist attraction because it is fantastic, but it also attracts questionable people and high taxi rates. Verify price before you get in tuk tuks.

Must see. Like the Temple of the Reclining Buddha, this is a must see. The temple area is beautiful and I love the fact that they dress the Buddha in different clothes depending of the season of the year. Quite amazing to see all of the incredible buildings. This is a must see when visiting Bangkok.

It is very small, you have to see at The Grand Palace. It is in the compound of the Grand Palace; since it is very small, if you are really interested in observing it, don't forget your binoculars as photos are forbidden. The Emerald Buddha takes its name from the beautiful precious stone but it is NOT made from it.
Morning Visits. Needless to say, its beautiful. You have to go in the mornings to avoid the evening sun or rain. Be careful of pickpockets, the place is super crowded.
REAL EMERALDS ???. A bit of a worn out Buddha and covered in glass.The Real Buddha is either hidden somewhere or the emeralds have been sold

Magnificent setting.. We visited the Emerald Buddha within the Grand Palace complex on a very hot day in June. Crowds were not too bad once you got inside past the scammers - worst encountered in Bangkok so far, blatant scams - Palace closed til 2pm, come visit large Buddha elsewhere ! No foreigners allowed, Thai only until 1.30, come visit large Buddha elsewhere! Scammers dressed in 'official' looking uniforms claiming to be government reps. LOL. Anyway once inside the Emerald Buddha is housed in a magnificent temple, you must remove your shoes outside and dress appropriately.Although Buddha is small and hard to see it is set amongst a fantastic array or jewelled and gold artefacts. It was worth the 500Baht entrance fee just to see this. Would have liked to spend longer visiting more of the complex but it was just too hot!

Beautiful architecture, a must see!. This is within the Grand Palace grounds and the entrance fee is 500 baht per person. The easiest way to get here is by taxi and try to come in the morning before the crowd gets heavy as this is the top tourist spot in Bangkok. Also, the weather was very very extremely hot with limited areas of shades and indoors are not air-conditioned. So be prepared with sun screen, hats, sunglasses to cover up. As you need to cover your legs and shoulders in your dressing, at the entrance you can lend long skirts/pants and shirts for a deposit of 200 baht which you get back after returning the clothes, thus do not bother to buy at the shops opposite the road.The temple grounds are huge and a free map will be provided to walk through the different halls and temples and the grand palace of course. Give yourself around 1-2 hours at this place to fully appreciate the wonderful architecture that is done up for their religion.
Tourist Attraction. Lots of fuss about this but a bit of a fizzle in the end. I skip this on my tour with friends. One time is enough, so many to see in Thailand that are much more worth the visit.

A must see while in Bangkok. Well if you come to Bangok, this is a must see. The olde Grand Palace plus the Emerald Buddah. Im not Buddhist myself but am a spiritual person, again Respect is the key to a happy and embarrasment free visit. Tip, ask yourself, do you really to take a camera here ? The sights you will see you will never forget anyway, beautiful, and very open minded venerated historical place to go. Tip, wear long pants as with any Wat. The Thai governement provides loan pants you can borrow for free (on downpayment of a small security bond) so you dont have to get fleeced by touts selling them outside the venue, and you don't have to trek ther in jeans or the like and arrive all hot and sweaty. Nice touch.

Amazing to view. I didn't realize the significance and importance of Buddhism to so many until I visited this site. I had a local guide which made it all that more enjoyableIt was busy, but not so much as to impact my visit. The key is to keep an eye out for the large groups, and try to follow after them, or before them not in the middle!So much history, ritual and important symbolism, it's hard to take it all in. I'm not a religious person, but I can appreciate the beauty and importance of this site to others. Well worth a visit even if your time is limited in Bangkok
Beautiful!. An amazing visit to one of the holiest (if I can say so) places of Buddhism. Just take time to be one of the silent visitors and observe what is going on around you.
Little gem. Its in the Grand palace complex and like the rest of the complex, it is spectacular looking. Be prepared for large crowds and dress light -- you need to cover up or entry is restricted

Difficult to View. The Emerald Buddha has conflicting history per our guide, legends say on thing while historical sources indicate another story, the history is interesting however it is difficult to see and the only reason we got a good view was due to the telescopic lens of our camera! It is on the grounds of the Grand Palace so worth the visit.

Good but Small. Another nice temple on the must-see list in Bangkok. Main attraction perhaps slightly overrated but I believe it's the history of it which makes it so significant to the Thai people.
The complex is nice and worth an hour of your time at least.

Obviously a big draw card, but be careful.... Within the grounds of the Grand Palace, this large temple houses the Emerald Buddha which draws crowds from around the world. The Buddha statue itself is relatively small and is perched on top of a very ornate alter. hard to get a good view but worht all the effort. Unfortunately the staff are under some kind of mission to make it even harder for the multi-national tourists who queue and shuffle through the doors. You are warned about pickpockets and thieves and yet are expected to leave good hiking shoes outside for the taking. the inner guard exploded at me and ranted on and on about rudeness and ignorance because I carried my shoes inside the temple.Sad occurrence but I was not alone in being on the receiving end of a blast from these over worked, stressed staff.

Go in the Morning. We went on the hottest day (we think anyway) and on a public holiday - many, many people and very, very hot, but it is worthwhile seeing. If you are visiting the King's Palace, ensure that you visit this Temple.
liked. This famous temple was very satisfying , best to go in the morning before the real heat sets in , a lot of tourists but well worth seeing

Small but beautiful!!. Was expecting a bigger Buddha, closer to the one in Shanghai, but it was absolutely beautiful and gorgeous in every aspect!It was a bit crowded but an absolute must when visiting Bangkok!
Serenity. Beautiful place. Go early and avoid the crowd. There is a lot of detail to see here. Make sure you look around.

The only place worth visiting in otherwise filthy and hot Bangkok. the only place really worth a visit in this terribly hot all year round, filthy and noisy Bangkok. A Kitsch temple with an "emerald" Buddha stolen from Vientiane last century..... Allow 1 1/2h that s it. the adjacent wat pho is interesting too. the Palace is nothing interesting at all. Now, as generally thailand has gotten more agressive, people are less interested in tourists, only money seems to count anymore, smiles are NON EXISTANT most of the time and beaches are filthy almost everywhere, full of russians and their mafias unless you go in the extreme south national parks. Go to Laos instead for nature, Cambodia for smiles, Myamar for buddhism and maldives for clean beaches!

Place of peace. The whole shrine was very attractive. Very nicely maintained, there were lots of people sitting in pin drop silence inside the temple. The emerald image of Lord Buddha was worth seeing.
OK. Not as impressive as other temples, the buddha is quite small, could be that by this temple had already seen many other better ones
What a Beauty. I love temples, especially beautiful ones like this one. The place was so sacred, and serene. Plus they let you take lots of pictures, so you get some real good shots.

Wonderful place!! This is a MUST see. If you only have time to do one cultural thing in Bangkok visit the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and hire a guide. The guide will cost you less than $20 and it makes all the difference in the visit. The temple buildings are spectacular and they represent Thai, Cambodian and Sri Lankan styles.The paintings depicting Thai mythology in the gallery are gorgeous, you could sped hours just looking at them. The building where the Emerald Buddha is housed is beautiful, and the Emerald Buddha is made from a single piece of jade and wears magnificent solid gold outfits.The guided visit will last one hour.The dress code is very strict but they will lend you additional clothing is yours is not up to code.Beware of the tuk-tuks outside and people telling you the temple is closed and offering you other options. From here is a 12 minute walk to the Temple of the Reclining Buddha.This is a MUST see.

Don't Miss. This is my favorite site in Bangkok. While the reclining Buddha is spectacular, take some time to turn around and check out the incredible murals that cover the walls and ceiling. They are worth the visit. The grounds are beautiful. The amusing statuary will catch your attention. Compared to the Royal Palace, which can get overrun by tour groups, this is a much more intimate place to visit.

Magnificent but expensive. This is a place of much grandeur. The temple and the grounds are beautiful with rich and intricate designs. It is 500 baht per person to get in, which is much steeper than other temples which are free or around 100 baht at the most. The place is completely packed and hard to get around due to the crowds. It's also not marked as well as it could be. Overall, if you have time and money, go ahead and pay a visit to this beautiful place. If not, head over to Wat Pho around 8:30-9 am and you will still have a rewarding experience minus the crowds and the cost.Also, make sure you are dressed in temple appropriate clothing - long pants/skirt, no sleeveless shirts. You must also remove your footwear as well as a hat before entering the temple itself.
must see. This is one of the must see things to do when visiting Bangkok. Along with the Grand Palace it is so lovely, along with the thai people

Loads to see here. This is a huge place, so come well prepared with your umbrella or hat as the heat can be rather merciless. There were loads of people swarming the place when we were there, and it felt rather chaotic. So much so, that we actually missed seeing the Emerald Buddha! The beauty of the place is overwhelming. I must say that when it comes to temples and architecture, Thailand is the place to be...

Price increase for foreigners. The price for foreigners is now 500 THB while it is still free for Thais.If you want to see a temple there are a lot of other free options in Bangkok that are equally beautiful (Wat Saket with its nice view of the city). Wat Pho next door with the reclining Buddha is 100 THB entrance (at you get a free water).
worth a look. Located next to the grand palace, but a bit disappointing in relation to the reclining Buddha and the golden Buddha.

gems overload. we went to Wat Phra kaeo amidst the scorching heat of Bangkok. but the heat did not diminish the grandeur of the place. It was a visual overload of thai culture and no photos can truly capture the beauty of the place
Huge. a big temple and worth to visit and know about Buddhism in Thailand. nice architecture too. but there is fee you need to pay at the entrance counter which is TBH 500.

A must see while in Bangkok, popular tourist location for locals and internationals. This is the royal temple in Bangkok and a definite place to stop by and see. Everyone does. There's beautiful architecture and you can see the emerald buddha. We also saw the young buddha's walking on the grounds often.One of the rules of visiting this temple is that men must wear long pants and women long dresses. So if you go there with shorts, there's people there that will provide you with some proper garments. Also there's people selling water before you walk onto the grounds. It's much cheaper to get water bottles from them rather than inside, which is recommended since it's really hot in Bangkok most of the year.

Prepare to be Dazzled. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha (actually spelled Wat Phra Kaew, not Kaeo) and its many surrounding buildings/structures are simply one of the most stunning sights/sites you'll ever lay eyes on. Soaring spires, glittering gold, religious reverence ... pure magic.Arrive early, right when the complex opens at 8:30am. Then, make a bee-line right away to the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and you'll have some temporary peace and quiet to reflect on the star attraction himself, the 'Emerald Buddha', sitting high atop his multi-tiered, gloriously golden throne. He actually does seem to have an ethereal glow. Part of the magic is being able to observe reverent Thais paying their utmost respects to the Emerald Buddha who represents the very soul of Thailand.You can't take pictures of the Emerald Buddha while inside his temple which makes sense to maintain some semblance of peace and decorum. However, when you're standing outside the temple, the window in between the 2 side entrances gives you a nice vantage point with which to use your camera's zoom to snap a very nice pic of the small-in-size, mighty-in-stature Emerald Buddha (please see my pics below).Having paid your respects to the star attraction, you can now more leisurely stroll the grounds, admiring all the dazzling architecture and exquisite attention to detail. Be sure your camera's battery is fully charged because you will be snapping away madly. Definitely wander over to the north side of the complex to see an amazingly detailed scale model of Angkor Wat which will prompt you to book a side trip to Cambodia to see it in person!Then, as the touristic wave begins to wash over the whole scene and the sizzling heat begins to intensify, you can make your graceful exit before 10am and wander towards the south to drop in next door at Wat Po (Temple of the Reclining Buddha), once again a step ahead of the big crowds.TIPS: easiest way to get there is taking the Chao Phraya Express Boat to Pier #9 (Tha Chang). Walk straight away from the river and keep walking thru the food market due east, you'll quickly see the high white wall surrounding the complex. Do NOT listen to anyone trying to tell you the Temple is closed (it's open EVERY day). Easiest way to get to Chao Phraya Express Boat is to take the BTS Skytrain to Saphan Taksin Station and take very short walk to Central Pier (Tha Sathorn). DRESS MODESTLY! Tops have to at least have short sleeves, covering the shoulders. Strictly NO shorts ... or you'll have to rent some dirty, sweaty long skirt-like thing to cover your bare legs. ENJOY!
Beautiful sight. This was great but had to look at it through my camera zoom to get a good look as it is very small. Very crowded as its very popular in bangkok. Well worth the wait to see:)

very big campus with small precious green Buddha. Emerald Buddha seating on top of a high thrown. But there are many other places and court yards to see in the same complex. You feel peace and spiritual there. Even they gave free small bottle of cold water and it is a blessing in very hot weather of May.

Cheaper and Great Photo Opportunities!. After paying double for another temple we were pleasantly surprised here! It was very similar to the other one we looked at so this is worth going to as it is half the price. Ignore anyone at the entrance who tells you the temple is closed due to a public holiday (my friend nearly fell for it) just don''t talk to them at all! Great photo opportunities here. I thought I was well dressed and had a big scarf to cover my arms but this wasn't accepted so make sure you wear a tshirt and don't be rude if you are forced to hire clothes (some woman were screaming at them). We heard chanting so went in a temple and the monks were chanting - not sure if this happens regularly but it was a nice touch!

So many temples, so little time!. The Emerald Buddha was not as big as I expected it to be, but then again, I had just seen the Reclining Buddha. That is until i realized that it is an Emerald Buddha. It is such a metaphorical item, traveling to places that are religious really makes you understand how their deity really is a jewel to them. As in the rest of the Grand Palace, Wat Phra Kaeo is filled with astonishing detail, you can admire from afar or a few inches from the wall.
Another impressive temple. One of the must-see stops on the Bangkok temple route. It gets very crowded so try to go early. I went with Tour with Tong and definitely recommend both!

A Bangkok icon. Beautiful temple in a wonderful location! Packed constantly by all manner of people, one still can be moved the intricate and exquisite paintings and carvings. Beware of the touts! Before I entered the grounds, several people told em that he grounds were closed to a function, or it was the day to be closed, or... the result is as always, they want money or take you somewhere else in the overpriced tuk tuks... Smile and keep walking, just follow everyone else.. be prepared to either dress appropriately or hire a bit of cloth to cover the shoulders or the legs, the Thai people frown on too much skin in this holy place.Yes, and please show respect when taking photographs to the regular worshippers,monks and fellow travellers.. Good karma!

Pretty :-P. So the Temple of the Emerald Buddha (which is located inside the Grand Palace Complex) is a beautiful building. The actual Emerald Buddha statue is made of jade (not emerald) and is rather tiny. However, the entire temple is beautiful.
It's an excellent visit for those interested in Thai culture and art.
wat phra. if you fond of huge structures and esp temple this is the place to go. its a great temple with awe inspiring statue of the buddha. the other temple architecture is also worth a dekko.

My favorite temple in Bangkok. Not only that this is the Royal Family's official Buddhist temple to change the robes as required on the Emerald Buddha - which is fascinating to view up close - but also the small replica at the side of the temple of Angkor Wat. Plus of course the entertaining mix of tourists from many, many countries.

Tourist trap - but you have to see it once. Outside there are so many people just wanting to scam you. You will be told that the Grand Palace is closed for so many reasons (Buddha's birthday, Buddha Day, the princess is visiting are the three I heard this time), and then suggested you go for a ride in a Tuk Tuk. It's so sad. Then you will be stung 500 THB if you are not a Thai national. That's expensive compared to most other temples, but meh, It's really not that much money. Inside the Grand Palace the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is wonderful. Go, but watch out for the scams.

Exquisite, exotic, stunning!!!. Probably the most famous and revered Buddha in Thailand. See it at the Grand Palace/Wat Po tour. Actually made from a large piece of solid jade. Wat Po and the Grand Palace are two adjoining areas seen with the purchase of one ticket. A must see in Bangkok.
Interesting. A tiny Buddha, but an interesting and popular place with great atmosphere. Easily reached by river boat. .
Stunning details and lovely small Buddha. Beautiful temple, with stunning design and detail. Crowds not too bad when we visited. The Buddha itself is surprisingly small.
tkt cost not included in cost of grand palace visit. entry ticket cost 100 thb which is much higher as we already spent 500 thb per person for grand palace entry.

If you miss this, you have missed Bangkok. The most beautiful and revered of the temples of Bangkok. Take your time and just absorb the beauty. The Buddha may not really be "emerald" (it's actually jade), but it is definitely the emerald of the Bangkok temples.

Emerald Buddha. We were so lucky to actually be allowed in to go and visit, Thai Buddhists are lucky if they visit once a year. The emerald buddha is small and on a pedestal up high you can take photos through the window from outside but not allowed inside, if you do go in and sit and soak up the atmosphere remember shoes off and offer a donation no matter how small it goes a long way

Gorgeous and Grand!. To visit Wat Phra Kaeo you need to buy a ticket which costs 500THB and it also includes the Grand Palace and Queen Sirikit Museum. Wear full trousers or else you need to 'rent' a pyjama for around 30 THB and a refundable deposit of 100THB. The temple and the entire premises of the palace is huge and its hot so take water, cap, sunglasses and in case if you don't mind an umbrella which really helps! The place swells with tourists but you can't help it. Its so grand and beautiful that you won't mind the heat or the crowds. Photography is not permitted inside the temple though. The other temples of Wat Arun and Wat Pho are also nearby. Buses are easy to get if you want to save money.

G R A N D is the only word I can think of!. This one is bundled with the Grand Palace ticket (@ 500 Baht!) and is located within the Palace premises, being almost the first structures one comes across. It is not so much the emerald Buddha per se that captivates, as the general ambience, the gold glitter all around and the fine details in each and every wall, statue and emblem in this temple. The Buddha himself is a small idol perched right on top of the foundation (sorry if I didnt get the Buddhist terms right) and it may well be only after you come out that you realize you had just been to the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, unless you are glued on to the Map they give you with the ticket. No photos inside, but sitting for a while not just lets you escape the fury of the Thai sun, but lets you contemplate what surrounds you, with a thought on the amount of patience, skill and eye for detail that must have gone into creating this marvel.
Very nice.....shud visit once. really a beautiful buddha idol full of emarlds & gold..... near by the grand palace.. a must watch when u r in bangkok

Must See in Bangkok. This temple is within the Grand Palace. It is a beautiful structures with golden roofs and huge golden demons guarding the entrances. Its a highly respected temple for local thais.....

Beautiful treasure. This Wat is located within walking distance of the royal palace. Very clean, and the architecture of the various buildings is very worthwhile, as there are Thai, Cambodian, Chinese buildings on site. The Emerald Buddha itself, surrounded by gold is beautiful.

Temple + Palace. This is part of the Grand Palace exhibits. The ticket is bundled for both temple and palace building. The temple is very Thai style building. There are many stupa along the temple. However, I do not know the actual meaning on it . There is a replication of Angkor Wat, however, I am not sure. It looks like Angkor Wat. I am also not sure whether I saw the Emerald Buddha or not. It seemed that it is too small hosted in the main hall. Once you leave the temple area, you will not be able to enter. Therefore it is usually starting to visit the temple before going into the main area of grand palace.

A must do in Thailand. I noticed people complaining about the price...hello people you are on vacation, I'm sure you can afford the $15 bucks. There's a lot to see on the property and worth seeing unless you have no appreciation for culture. The high fees for tourist is what pays to maintain the grounds which brings tourism and money into the thai people's pockets. In the most sacred temples photos inside are not allowed but you can cheat and snap one from outside the doorway

Expensive, tons of people, no photos inside temples. If you're not Thai, it's 500 Baht to get in, which I thought was extremely high considering you can't take photos inside of the actual temples. 200-300 Baht would be a fair price (the temple on the mountain in Chiang Mai cost 20 Baht, including an elevator ride to the top). I expected it to be busy, but not thousands of people busy. It appears you can bring in a tripod for long super exposures with an ND filter (saw somebody with one), but other than that, not much of a photo op unless you don't mind tons of people in your photos. Definitely a tourist trap raking in the money.

Awe inspiring. As soon as you enter the Grand Palace and admire the beauty of the temples, the details of craftmanship, the stunning surroundings you will quickly forget about the heat, the crowd and the high entrance fee. Don't skip this one!

Wow!. Huge temple complex. Quite costly to get in, but well worth it! The build detail is beautiful. It's really amazing to see what people talk about. The Emerald Buddha is the most significant in Thailand. And there's a story around it - research a bit and you'll discover.The Buddha himself is perched high up on an enormous platform. Regrettably, the actual Buddha is quite small but given it's elevated position you'll definitely be able to see it.And in the complex there is a traditional Thai massage place. I strongly recommend to go there. Thais and foreigners all go there for a massage, which is entirely different to the western idea of a massage. And afterwards you'll feel amazing!

Waaaaay Overpriced. If you want to spend 500 baht to look at some pretty buildings, great. I felt ripped off. Oh, and definitely don't wander out any of the exits, as they will NOT let you back in. Thai tourism Profiteering at it's finest.
good to visit. if you have time then you can visit this temple also since all palace, wat arun n this temple are in vicinity.
Expensive for Tourists!. Thais charge 400 Baht in for Tourists and free in for Thais. Seems pretty expensive compared to other more beautiful temples in Thailand. Tourist trap!

A great experience of Bangkok - Wat Phra Kaew -The Royal emerald Buddha temple. Thai Tour Guide -Ms Aom was there to pick us up and we started our day by our visit to this Grand Temple . This was perfect introduction to Thailand's Architecture , Culture and Tradition. We were so impressed by the large area of the temple with so many Pagodas , particular mention has to be made of the Thai architecture. Very imposing they were and some gold colored and some antique finish and some filled with gold foils and glass chips. The Museum is a must and this helps us understand the Thai History better . There is a portion in the premises where there are 108 Murals which depicts the story of Ramayana . Beautiful paintings and took us some time to see it all . Then to the actual Temple where The Emerald Buddha is mounted on a golden pedestal . The Idol of Buddha itself is very small and the Temple is fully decorated with gold carvings and paintings and very peaceful and silence maintained . Total peace existed in this temple. Our Tour guide Ms . Aom , explained the different stories and history of this Royal Temple. It was great experience here and our guide was very friendly and we became good friends . She was very patient with us and we shared lot of stories . Enjoyed the trip to the Buddha temple.
Temple of Emerald Buddha. Very hot but worth a visit, beautiful presentations and royal jewelleries, only negative is not allowed to take photos of the Emerald Buddha.

Gorgeous temple and amazing statue. The temple, Wat Phra Kaeo, is beautiful, grand, georgeous, it's housed in the same premises as the Grand Palace and share the granduer of the decor with the Grand Palace. There's excellent colorful, golden embossed carving work on the walls and the roof, and the emerald buddha inside is mind blowing. Photography is not allowed inside the temple and hence couldn't click the statue.

It's a Temple. It is another temple, it has a green JADE buddha. Don't get me wrong the whole experience is great but you are there with 1000's of others clicking pics to prove they were there. Pity you can't be there on your own watching the sunrise and soak up the serenity.....
Best Time to visit in the morning. Before many tourist group coming to this temple better if you coming before 9 am because the place is not so crowded and not so hot.

Nice place, far too busy. Nice Temple, get the official guide to take you around, the tour is free. Beware that guys have to have long pants on and ladies must have on shirts, and have their knees covered. A shawl is not good enough!

Gorgeous temple. Can get very crowded but the experience is worth it. There is a dress code to enter. So remember to wear long pants to avoid having to rent ridiculous looking pants at the spot. The dress code suggests long shirt sleeves but don't appear to enforce it.

A must visit temple. Very well maintained , clean . All toursits must visit this temple while you are visiting Bangkok . It is related to story of Indian Hindu Religion , must get tour guide to understand the photos painted all around the temple .

Incredible detail, richly ornamented. The whole complex of the Royal Palace, Emerald Buddha Temple and many other temples and statuary is incredible to see. Clearly popular both with tourists and local worshippers. Take the time to visit if you can, the height of Thai religious architecture.

Nice temple. + Emerald Buddha and the temple is really nice, must visit.
+ Within the Grand Palace area
+ Inside this temple you will find a model of Ankor Wat temple and a few other Pagoda's of wonderful architecture.
+ Please do take water bottles if you are going by Noon.
worth a visit. A must do (I guess) since you're here and you paid your entry to see it. It's become iconic and quite beautiful. Far too crowded for my liking.
Loved It. The feeling in this sacred temple is so beautiful it brought tears to my eyes. The emerald budda is surrounded by years of devotion.

Nice temple. This temple have a unique and nice design. the design totally looks like a Thai feature. the ornament were great, I can guess that the designer is a person with high artistic soul. there are so many tourist came to this place. they took a picture, specially when there are an event in this temple

Beautiful Temple!. The buddha is very small but it is surrounded by a beautiful and magnificent altar. They put different clothes to the statue depending on the season. Since I visited during summer is when it has less cloth and you can appreciate more the material of the buddha which is not emerald but jade. Worth the trip to see it if you are already at The Grand Palace. Be prepared to take your shoes off and be seated and silent in front of the altar. Photos or video are not permitted inside the temple and don't try because they are watching!!

I ALWAYS COME BACK HERE, HAVE BEEN HERE MORE THAN 20 TIMES OVER THE YEARS SINCE 1972. There is so much to see here, not to forget "to feel" here. A most important historical site in Bangkok. The "Emerald Buddha statue (small) is a must to see too!

amazing grace. We were lucky to have a friend who new most of the stories depicted in the 400 metres mural surranding the temples complex. It made it worthwhile to know what the pictures meant in their mythology. We suggest you get yourself a good guide. it makes the whole differnece. And dont' forget to visit the queens textile museum. A real gem.
Enjoyable Day. My family, being Thai, enjoyed seeing the Buddha and sharing, as a family in the opportunity to make merit.

We should have hired a guide. To be in this area, walking around and enjoying all of the ornateness, is an experience that I will not soon forget. We arrived too late in the day to hire a guide or even rent the audio guide, which I regret. I wished we would have known some of the historical significance of all of these structures but instead we just wandered around in magical amazement. This is definetly a "DON'T MISS" while in bangkok.When we left we needed to grab a taxi but none would use the meter. When we finally figured out that the difference in cost was about 5 bucks, we jumped in the next air conditioned taxi and headed back to our hotel!!The whole "must use the meter" issue was at first frustrating but I see the taxi drivers point of view. The meter goes by distance and if there is alot of traffic (which there is!) they don't make any money. Another tip...seek out the new modern restrooms. The old ones are not up to a westerners standard!! Also, take water with you....

One of the most venerated Bhuddhas in Thailand. Is not as big as golden one or reclining one but definitely the special one.Actually his size may be disappointing,however one has to remember it is one big piece of jade.
Nice. The emerald buddha temple located inside the grand palace is nice and peaceful. The fees for entering the gran palace 500 baht is a bit high though.

Hectic for a temple. Beautiful sight to behold- but the crowd is crazy...one temple is more than enough to see. Very strict and very busy, plan this tour with a guide- it will be easier for you to navigate!

Must see, spiritual place to visit.. Awe inspiring, a visual feast. Spiritual feeling. Impressive. Allow a lot of time to enjoy, take lots of water and remember to dress appropriately. Is crowded but movement around is easy. We had a guide Natt Opasanon which made the visit easy and provided a good commentary on the history and significance. We had a large group of 12, 6 adults and 6 kids. The guide enabled us to cross the language barrier and insight into cultural nuances.

Awesome experience. You will be in awe when you explore Wat Phra Kaeo. Upon arrival I was not prepared for the magnitude of how large Wat Phra Kaeo was and the stunning architecture throughout. Many times, I caught myself just staring with my mouth open, lost in the beauty that surrounded me. There is such historical significance at Wat Phra Kaeo, that you will want to ensure that you allocate at least a few hours to explore.

Must to see.... It is really wonderfuul place. Even there are a lot of people (what really can you expect from place like this), but it worth going. Just imagine that all these built and decorated by hand. Trully history place. Visit the little museum before the entrance to the palace (inside the gates, just right after the ticket counter); it is included in your ticket. It will give you some history on Thailand and its Royal family, as well as history of Emerald Buddha. Once you inside the palace grounds you will see Buddha himself. You will require to take your shoes off before intering temple. We just took out shoes in plastic bag, or you can leave them outside like all other people do. Please be respectfull to Thai religion and do not take photo in the temple. Sad to see tourists from civilised countries ignoring rules.Entrance to palace territory is 500 BHT per person. Buy tickets only inside the gates ( about 50 miters after the security point). Do not listen to anyone who says that Palace is closed or that you have to pay for ticket to them. You can skip the paid tour guide if you do some research in advance and just print some information of Internet. When you are on your own you have freedom of walking anywhere anytime you want. Its a holly place, so gents are required <no short; no open shoulders>; for ladies <knees covered, no open shoulders>. Guards are strikt and will not let you in. If you still forgot to cover up, you can rent sarong right there (on the right after security point) .If you need to ask anyone for assistance, approach guard in uniform or policeman.Its hard to take taxi from there. Two taxies did not want to take us to our place " too much traffic". So good luck with that. Have place you want to go writen in thai language, as most of taxi driver do not speak english.
made of pure gold. made of pure solid gold weighing 5,500 kilograms. atmosphere at the temple is quiet and calm. not very crowded.

Another must visit place in Bangkok. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha (actually made from Jade) is one of the most stunning temples in Bangkok! Though the Buddha itself is smaller than many others, it is exquisitely carved and is hosted on top of glittering gold structure! Do ensure you visit the museum before you get to the temple. The museum has so much history to tell, it all falls into place when you visit the temple after. The main sanctum is an extremely peaceful place to sit and meditate. Its a world of its own. A cannot miss sight!!!
magical. One of the best places we visited in Bangkok, teaming with people and a gaudy exterior but the inside was magical, beautiful and atmospheric. A great experience

Awesome temples and architectures. Many many Thai temples and architectures with various style of decorations. Must visit, really! The Thai deities who guard the whole temple area are also attractive.

Magnificent. Art, history, culture and architecture all in one. The Grand palace was stunning, the detail in the craftsmanship was absolutely amazing. Loved the Jade Buddha who they dressed according to the season, pity pictures weren't allowed inside that temple, but we got some fanatic shots regardless, including some of a miniature Angor Wat from Cambodia. Lots of tourists in here, easy to get lost so be wary. Tourists need to wear appropriate clothing (ie cover arms with a shirt and pants or long skirt). We would definitely return when we get the chance, it was just magnificent. Of course the cherry on top was the old man with the food cart outside the entrance selling BBQ'd crickets... you just know you're not in Kansas anymore ToTo...

Really nice complex, but really small Budha. This complex is really very large and interesting. Good advice is to have long pants/skirts and etc. to enter there. Beware of the people in front of Temple telling you that today is close - they are trying to catch you for shopping.
Crowded but impressive temple complex. This is a must see attraction in Bangkok. Of course the emerald Buddha is beautiful but the buildings and statues are worth the entry fee as well.

Amazing Complex!. This is such as special place, for the amount of temples and buildings, the detail the statues....It's a massive master piece!When you go where long trousers (I was wearing cargo shorts and I had to hire some trousers inside for 200 baht (Which is refunded when you return the trousers!), don't listen to people outside trying to sell you them, just hire them inside and return them for your money back...no hassle and very clean!

another must see in Bangkok. this is in a temple a short distance away from the emerald buddha. we went to this temple in the midst of a very hot day, and hence could not spend much time here, in the palace complex. there is a 500baht entry fee, and you are required to cover up your knees and sleeved shirts are preferred. if you are not having these, like i did, then wait to enter the compex where you can rent FREE OF COST, a track suit for wearing. don't get fooled by the touts outside, who will sell you something at 30-100 baht and scare you. the temple complex has this facility, just as you enter from the main entrance on the right hand side. the statue is in a central hall, which is surrounded by a few buildings, all of which are richly decorated and give a fairly good idea of the wealth and splendour of the Thai Kingdom.
We missed it!. We did know that it was in the area of the Grand Palace until we left.Be more careful than we were! The Grand Palace is spectacular. Get there early and somewhat avoid the crowds.

OMG. Just incredible. The emerald buddha itself is relatively small, but it's the temple & the artistry & the surrounds that take your breath away.We visited independently & (unfortunately) during Songkran (Thai New Year). The place was absolutely mobbed.Guides are worthwhile having, so if you're not on an organised tour, there are plenty of registered guides once you get inside- ours spoke good English.Men must have long trousers & covered shoes- you can hire out there. Women must have their knees & shoulders covered. Thongs are a no no & sandals must have an ankle strap.If you are travelling independently, be aware that the taxis out the front turn their meters off for the return trip & may try & charge you double what it cost to get out there. We paid 150BHT on the meter to get out there from our hotel & the taxis were trying to charge 400BHT to get back. We hired a tuk tuk & agreed on 200 BHT. The alternative is to public transport it- ferry from Saphin Taksin plus a ferry plus a walk, but to be honest, it was so FLIPPING hot, the walk bit was not at all attractive!Anyways, despite the crowd, despite the transport hassles, this is a must see.

Great place if you can avoid the masses. It is a special place. There are thousands of temples all over Asia that offer many of the features seen here, however everything here is bigger, better, cleaner and even more colorful.Downside is that it's busy, extremely busy and if you are going with a guide ask him to take you at a time when the crowd is at a minimum. We found most photographs we made need serious "Lightroom" work to eliminate dozens in every shot.

Could Have Spent All Day Here!. We only had a few hours before we had to check out and leave for the airport so we decided to take the sky train to the river ferry express boat (40 baht each way) up to see the Grand Palace and the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Easily could have spent 4 hours just looking at all of the intricate murals filled with demons, battles, and seductive women but there were also all of the glittering buildings covered with bits of hand-cut mirror in various colors, sparkling in the sun like jewels and the gilded temples and ornate giant demons guarding the grounds. It was one of the more expensive things to do at 500 baht entry, but that also included a visit to the Grand Palace. Next time I plan to bring a hat for the sun was blazing on my head and to spend more time in the mural galleries. It really was quite glorious and worth the price. Just remember to wear or bring along clothing the covers your knees and shoulders and pants that are not tight. They heavily enforce proper dress here and if you don't bring anything they do have loaners available for free (though just outside some locals have seen fit to capitalize on people by charging them 30 baht to borrow clothes even though there is a sign clearly pointing out inside it's available for free). Just bring your own. I wore a long dress and threw a t-shirt over it to cover my shoulders and took it off when I left. My boyfriend had pants with zip-off legs which he zipped on to enter, and zipped off to exit.

Gorgeous. This was an amazing experience. Seemed to be the largest to me. Everything here is decorated so beautifully and intricately. I highly suggest visiting this site. It was incredible, and easily accessible.

Tiny Green Buddha. As I am not a Buddhist, the impressive element of this temple is the amazing architecture and elaborate and ornate relics. It's a beautiful placebo see during your visit to the Grand Palace.

Great...a must see.. Loved our trip to thailand, the people were beautiful and friendly and we enjoyed all the sightseeing..if your going to this part of the country you should definately include this as part of your trip

Another magnificent Buddhist Temple!. The Emerald Buddha is something beautiful! Once more the religious environment was peaceful and relaxing for body and spirit! In spite it was crowded with tourists it was very easy to walk and see everything without any problem! Most of tourists were from Asian countries and they were very polite and respectful!

Enjoyed wandering the temple area.. This is definitely a must see in Bangkok. Make sure you bring a shirt to cover your shoulders and pants as a shawl will not suffice. You can rent clothes for a refundable deposit if you forget but they're a bit frumpy and will be in all your pictures if you forget (like I did). I loved the painted walls, guardian statues and the miniature version of Angkor Wat. The emerald Buddha, itself, was not that impressive as it is small and very high up on a pedestal. Don't expect too much in that regard. But I still found the temple grounds to be beautiful.

Beautiful and ornate. It was refreshing to see people actually worshipping in a temple. The Emerald Buddha was a little smaller than I expected but the building is beautifully decorated. Very interesting stop.

Scams everywhere spoil visits to Bangkok. Be aware if someone tries to steer you to an alternative entrance! You will be told the temple is closed and someone will try to take you on another tour! This happens at other attractions too. Do not believe anyone who tells you that the place you are going to is closed.
impressive. very impressive gold statute located insife the grand palace. worth visit as part of a tour in the grand paace

A little bit over-rated!. Once you're in the Grand Palace you will hae see the Emerald Buddha. Its actually made from Jade and came from Chiang Mai and is quite small,sitting atop a large altar its almost invisible. No cameras allowed inside the Temple building. Make sure you make use of the Lotus flowers to sprinkle water on yourselves prior to entry as it's considered good luck.

overwhelming temple. the temple is overwhelming being full of gold, coloured mosaics, artworks and statues. the buddha looks small in the middle of all this splendor, but there is something special about him.

love the murals inside the temple. you can't take pictures inside, but the murals inside the temple are amazing. it can get a bit crowded so you can't take too much time inside. The emerald buddha is definitely a sight to see.

My first temple. Words can't describe the intricate art work, the architecture and the atmosphere that surround Wat Phra Kaeo. You just have to go there, ignore the heat and the crowd, and absorb everything this place has to offer.
Wear appropriate clothing (no shorts and tank tops).
This temple is located right next to Grand Palace. Don't miss their "real" entrance. It's open daily; don't believe the scam signs/messages/advices on the way.
Was Expecting More. Emerald Buddha is much smaller than I thought it would be. The Grand Palance and Wat Phra Kaeo were extremely busy especially with guide lead tourist groups who seems overly rude!

A small but very impressive and important Buddha. Embedded in the Grand Palace complex, this temple houses a Buddha that you will find rather diminutive at first glance. Not made of emerald at all, it is small and housed amid lots of gold and decoration. Bu do take a couple of minutes to sit down, feet always pointing away from the Buddha, and just look at it. It will soon come to you why this is a revered statue.The surrounding temple grounds are very beautiful and graceful, providing some shade against a relentless sunThe crowds are of course very large, but as everywhere where we went, the organization of the whole experience was excellent!
just very hot but amazing. At this time of the year, visiting this temple was a bid too hot for us with the long line waiting grom tourists. Ageed that this is the top destination for anyone.
Horribly crowed !. Disneyland for chinese group ! Very expensive fee for this. Really not worth it. Emerald Buddha quite small , very disappointed ! Over crowded !

Majestic but overcrowded. This temple is amazing but the horde of tourist groups ruin everything. The Thais that go there to pay homage to the Emerald Buddha can't even pray in silence as it is anything BUT silent and even though there is a big sign that says photography is prohibited people still take pictures - with FLASH!This temple is part of the Grand Palace complex and you will need to pay 500THB to get into the complex itself.Beautiful, beautiful temple a must see. Make sure you go in cooler months. I went with my partner this month (the hottest month in Thailand. The heat was almost unbearable.

Well worth a visit.
