Make sure to get there early (they open daily 8:30am) to avoid the crowd peak. also make sure you dress appropriately - they won't let you in with a vest top on and a scarf over your shoulders. Your top needs to have sleeves. There are shirts available to borrow free of charge though (by a refundable deposit). An absolutely stunning place and well worth a visit despite overcrowding.

Beautiful but small. No photos allowed in the temple, and the Buddha is only 2 feet tall and pretty far away. I say "only" 2 feet tall, but this thing is made of solid jade. Amazing, but you can't really appreciate its beauty from afar. You'll be at the Grand Palace anyway, so you have to go see it.

Lots smaller than expected. The Bhudda is stunning. But reeeeally little. Much smaller than expected. As part of the Palace complex you have to go see it but I would have been disappointed had we made a special journey. The Reclining Bhudda 2 mins away was far more spectacular...
must see!. very beautiful temple next to the Kings Palace. Beautiful traditional designs of Statues and Temples. Make sure your camera is charged.

Disappointing. It is located on the same site as The Grand Palace and Wat Arun. But I must admit I did expect to see a large emerald Buddha. It was just a large hall with a sparkly mount with an extremely small Buddha statue sat on the top

Incredible. Be careful and check that this will be open - 3 times a year, this area and parts of the grand palace is cosed due to the King changing the clothes of the Green Buddha (spring/easter time, Autumn and winter) as they shut off these areas and so you would be disappointed.
must visit. very beautiful Emarald Stone big size well guarded and well maintained be careful of some of the pimps outside they say it is closed but i believe it is open till 3.30 pm everyday

SERENE ATMOSPHERE. Only regret was that they did not allow the camera or photography so had to fill up this beautiful sight in our eyes. Life time experience to see this kind of magnificent architectural marvel. The Buddha idol radiated aura all around
Enjoyed the set of Wats here. Bangkok was a place we did a lot of regular touristy stuff and visiting Wats was one of those. This one was a good place to go to. Nothing great though.

Busy, Busy, Busy. This is the centre of the Grand Palace's offerings and is not to be missed. The sheer size of this temple is jaw dropping and the ornate architecture is something that needs to be seen to be believed

What a Package of Temples!. We reached the Wat just around noon in blazing hot Sun. We had travelled thro' the previous night and were sleep starved. So we were in terrible shape as we reached the temple complex. Being vegetarians, finding food was a trick too. So we consumed a lot of fresh fruit and went for buying Temple entrance Ticket. It was a stiff 500 Baht per head and I was wondering why a temple entry shoud be so costly. Anyway, we not only bought entry ticket but also hired a 200 Baht Audio guide ( on a hand held computer). The audio guide put pressure on us because it was supposed to be returned in 2hours.Armed with Audio guide we stepped into the temple complex which was so glorious that we soon forgot our sleepless night and heat of the Sun and started visiting 20 plus temples one by one and each one was a beauty. The highlight is no doubt the Emerald Buddha statue with a Golden Shroud. The statue was glowing magically and was some sight. Only "sight" because no photography allowed for the statue. The temple complex is followed by a visit to Royal Palace, where even Obama was hosted, it was said! The palaces were great pieces of architecture and were followed by a few museums, which were more of commercial ventures. One museum of the Queen however was impressive, with exquisite Royal ward robe. The Thai style silk dresses of the Queen were pieces of Art ,and the cut and stich was fascinating. So in all we spent 2 hours in hot Sun and clicked hundreds of photos. My wife kept clicking almost non stop!

Tiny but Grand little Guy. The Emerald Buddha is worth a visit especially if you are already in The Grand Palace area. True that the Emerald Buddha is quite small compared to the Reclining Buddha but still impressive in itself. I recommend you go early in the morning to avoid the huge crowds that begin to gather later in the day and to avoid the possibility of them closing the temple that houses the Emerald Buddha earlier then the other temples. Worth a visit.

worth the visit!. It is a sublime place to visit. the temple is inside the Grand Palace.
there is a dress code to visit the temple, shorts, short skirts and sleeveless tops are not allowed.
if you visit Bangkok, it is a must visit place

Amazing temple. The temple located in side the Grand Palace. It is the biggest ancient construction in the complex. I love the way it was decorated with beautiful details and colors. A must see place in Thailand and don't forget to take picture.

Be respectful. The decoration of walls / ceiling; the gold; the tiny but amazing Emerald Buddha high above; the offerings given by others.
Shame some tourists did not respect the no hats, no photos, no standing, no talking rules.
Stunning. We feared temple overload...but this place was just as amazing as the others. Highly recommended for all to visit.

very pretty!. We toured this temple on our tour of the Grand Palace. The next day the Emerald buddha was going to have it's winter clothes changed on the statue. Very neat place. Tons of photo opportunities abound in the outside areas but you are not allowed to take photos inside or talk while you are there. Our guide told us if you stand outside looking into the temple there is an area you can see the emerald buddha at and take a photo of it from the outside area. When you walk in the temple, the small emerald buddha is placed up high and is draped with a gold cloth depending on what season it is then. Many people will pray while they are in the temple to show respect to the buddha. After we left the temple you could put holy water on yourself if you wanted. There was also a place to give an offering before you went into the temple and that was neat to see what people left - flowers or beetle nut I think it was called were mainly the offerings left. Must see this if you visit the Grand Palace. Book a private tour guide for more information and you won't regret it!

"very impressive". Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaeo) has an amazing detailed architecture on the outside that made me spent 5 hours to appreciate and to look around it. I took so many pictures from all angles but it is a pity that photo taking was not allowed in the main hall where the Emerald Buddha which is made of carved Emerald and is kept in highest platform in the most sacred shrine. I have been told that even the robe of the Emerald Buddha is changed 3 times a year according to the season, very impressive.
Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Was closed - so check before you pay the entrance fee. Remember girls must have covered shoulders and guys coverd legs.

Take off your shoes and take in the beauty. This is the highlight of the temple. Great detail to the inlaid gold and the amazing paintings on all sides. After just a few short moments you realize why this is one of the most sacred of all Buddha images in Thailand. The feel of the room captivated me, don't miss it!

The tiny one. Was a bit disappointed with this Buddha as everyone talks about it been the 'emerald' buddha! But it is tiny compared to all the others that you see. It's still beautiful, don't get me wrong but just so small. Go see and look for yourself, it's still a must do thing though.

Amazing and yet awkward. As beautiful and impressive as this Buddha was, I found it a bit awkward that the tourists walked amongst the worshipers, and the poor guards were in a tizzy, shouting for everyone to kneel (but only in Thai, which the tourists didn't always understand). This is apparently the most sacred shrine in the country, and it's fantastic that they let anyone in, but for their sake, I do wish they had separate hours for onlookers and believers. It just seemed disrespectful. For the rest, the Buddha is beautiful, but small and set rather high and far back. No photos allowed. Strict wardrobe checks are made at the entrance to the massive grounds, but they are tolerant and generous enough to loan appropriate clothing to those who need it.

Crowded but totally worth it. Crowded, but gorgeous. The architecture, beautiful details and history are all apparent. While crowded and noisy on the temple and palace grounds, the inside of the temple is shaded and reverent. Totally worth the trip!

One time visit. Worth visiting once - its pretty and time u spend depends on how much u want to delve into the history of thailand. If so inclined, there r guides available- however we were able to manage without a guide pretty well. Be wary of dress guidelines - no open toe, no shorts, no sleeveless tshirts. If u forget,dont worry -u can hire the same at the entrance

Exellent. Yet another 'must do' place to visit on any Bangkok itinerary. In the grounds of, and included in the tour of, the Grand Palace. We went on a hot Saturday which made it a bit hectic but still well worth the visit.

Interesting, but less so than other temples in BKK. The Emerald Buddha is small (compared with Reclining Buddha and Golden Buddha) but location is compelling and a quick stop was all that was necessary. Focus more time on other parts and structures around the temple proper and lower expectations to an appropriate level for seeing a jade carved buddha.

Do not miss!!!. The most sacred place in Bangkok. A bit expensive to get in compared to other temples (Wat Arun, Wat Pho), but definitely worth it! It's in the same place as the grand palace, so it's 2 birds in one shot.

Very busy as you would expect. I enjoyed visiting here but was bus as you would expect - the dress code is strick. I wore knee length dress which has my shoulders covered and was told this was fine. Really stunning & worth a visit, Think it was 500 baht as a foreigner to visit.

Impressive. This temple is situated inside the Grand Palace. The temple structure is huge and very ornate, kept very clean as well. The inside is all gold!! Buddha statue is made of emerald (hence the name) and sits atop a very high platform. So you do get to see it from afar. Good experience overall though. In case you want to bow and offer prayers to Buddha, sit in a way that your feet are away from the statue (best tucked under you, look around for examples). Being an Indian, I am so used to historical, old temples that all the newness was altogether a different perspective. I am from Kushinagar in India, where Lord Buddha took his last breath. There we have a very old Buddha statue, which might not be as expensive, but in its presence you feel humbled. Worth a visit, but if you are a sucker for history would be a little disappointed :)
A must see while in Bangkok. Elaborate and colorful buildings decorated in the most amazing colors. Spectacular Budda and rich in Thai history.
Really beautiful. We loved the ornate decorations around this Buddha but were surprised at how small it was, maybe 1-2 feet high? But very beautiful.

A Must-See If You Dont Have Far To Travel. A stunning artefact overshadowed by the quese, throngs of people, hustlers and the time it takes to get there through the nightmare traffic of Bangkok. Beware of rip-off taxi and tuk-tuk drivers. Use only metrered taxis and insist that you dont want 'stops'. If you dont you will not be taken where you want to go but to shops where the drivers get commission for taking you.

big place with lots of history. We enjoyed looking round and did it without a guide. this meant we probably didn't get the full history, but we got enough from the guide book. The entry signs explain what you can and can't wear to get in. I was wearing sandals, and got in as i was wearing them with trousers. Too much flesh;and you're not allowed in, or given something to cover up with. Lots to see and photograph; allow a few hours there at least.
take your camera. just superb, another amazing temple in a City of many. The place is just lovely and very calming. sit and listen and watch other travellers as part of the people watching

Buddha with a wardrobe?. It was incredible to see all the people coming to visit this temple?! Most interesting is Buddha's wardrobe for the seasons...he wears one & the others are on display in the museum.
Beatifull temple inside Grand Palace. beautifull thai temple, beautifull paintings on the surrounding walls. you need to bring long pants or you'll have to stay at a long line to borrow pants.

Grand Temple. What a grand temple to visit! Wished that there could have been a time to appreciate the suroundings more but the number of visitors and the noise was a distraction. Glad to have seen such a beautiful place.

Majestic. The temple was really, really crowded the day and time we went. On top of it, the day was really hot. But the Emerald Buddha, perched high and far away on a platform, was simply majestic. And beautiful. Even though the statue is not a big one - unlike the reclining Buddha - the temple was filled with devotees praying and making offerings. From what we could gather, local people come here in large numbers to mark special occasions and present some really expensive stuff as offerings.We sat on the floor for about 15 - 20 minutes, not only as a mark of respect but also to fully observe and absorb the scene. The temple is obviously very rich and opulent, what with a non-stop stream of devotees.For tourists it naturally is a big attraction because of its beauty and fame. Also the fact that it is inside the Royal Palace, which I guess every tourist to Bangkok visits, makes it extremely popular.A reputation fully deserved. Go experience it.Remember - footwear is not allowed inside the temple. Neither is photography. Sit and immerse yourself in the peace for some time. Do not point your feet towards the Buddha while sitting.

Insight into another religion. Along with Wat Pho, this is the other must-see temple. Provided a good experience into a holy shrine of another religion. Also heavy on the tourist trail so just be prepared.
Great place. i liked it very much, it is not crowded and offers great insight into history and culture of Thailand.

The most beautiful temple, but also the busiest. A very impressive religious site. You can only stare in awe at the artistry and splendour of the place, with all its gold statues and buildings (real gold!), as well as the ceramic and mirrored tile décor. The upkeep, which must be incredibly costly and time consuming, is evident everywhere, as the site looks like new. Very inspirational to watch devout Buddhists pray in front of the Emerald Buddha. Quite a story as well! I would suggest you either take a guided group tour, at the least, or hire a private guide, as it is impossible to understand the significance of everything if you are not a local, or a least a Buddhist. Look up and around at the details, there is something to see everywhere you look.  There is a beautifully painted wall as you exit the temple area into the Royal Palace grounds with the story of Buddha which is very interesting, but if you take a group tour they don't spend enough time here, so plan accordingly. Be prepared for crowds! Holy cow! We went on a Sunday, which was probably a mistake, so go on a weekday if you can. Be advised, they are very strict about dress code, especially for ladies, so dress appropriately. Don't rent clothes outside the site, as it is free inside, you just need to put down a security deposit. It is very hot inside the grounds, with little air circulation. Bring water, as you cannot purchase any until the end of your visit.One unfortunate thing did happen to us: we were told by the tour guide that we could come back through and take pictures at the end of the tour, but that turned out to be false. It is a one time entry ticket only. So take all your pictures while inside! Plan on between 2 to 4 hours, depending on the crowds and your level of interest, to visit both the Temple and Royal Palace grounds.

If you only have the time to see one temple this is it. There are beautiful temples in and around Bangkok, but this one is spectacular. The buildings are ornate and gorgeous and the buddha statue itself is unique in that it is made entirely of jade and displayed very reverently. Just seeing it is an experience, and as a bonus, you are in the same complex as the Grand Palace, so you can see both in one morning/afternoon.
Beautiful temple. This is one of the prettiest temples in Bangkok. The jade buddah itself isn't that impressive. It isn't that big and sits high up on an altar. Still this is worth a visit.

a little disappointing. Don't get me wrong, the temple is beautiful and so is the buddha it is just that he is small compared to his oppulent surroundings. Lots of gold and adorned alter. Be prepared for heat in March which is when we visited. We were more impressed with the 5.5 ton buddha at Wat Trimet

Magical place. Magical place It is definitely worth visiting this place in Bangkok and you can just ask the local taxi to come here as its not that expensive I would recommend people come visit this place worth the effort
Small. this was not as big as we thought it would be you are not allowed to take photos inside but if you stand by the door you can get the Buddha in view.

Beautiful. A stunning temple with a great history. We were lucky enough to tag on to the free tour guide who was great. The site is busy and when we visited the weather is choking hot. I would have enjoyed it more on an over cast day

Most Famous Buddha. This is a must see. Beautiful temple and the most famous Buddha statue in the world. Interesting history. In the main temple complex with many other temples near by. Easy to get to in downtown BKK. Surrounded by many restaurants and market stalls. Cost for foreigners to enter the Grand Palace an temple complex is under $10.00.
Go early to beat the crowds and heat. Gets crowded by noon. Lots to see and many many temples around it. ALso check out the palace. The gardens are very beautiful.
Emerald Buddha by colour only. This Buddha is really carved out of one piece of Jade but is emerald green in colour and of great importance to the Thai people. I enjoyed visiting these temples.

Good cultural experience spoiled by others. The temple cannot be faulted. It looks amazing and the architecture and cultural influences are breathtaking. The staff, however, are unenthusiastic towards tourists and rather disinterested in interacting save for telling you to change your pants or take off shoes (it WAS over 40 degrees so it's completely understandable). What spoiled that day for me was a group of tourists who openly criticised the Buddhist religion commonly practiced in Thailand and had formed a prayer circle in the temple grounds to "save the souls of those worshiping false idols". Advice to other tourists: Ignore the conversations of other groups. Makes for a happier time for all.

MUST visit. Recommend going early in the day so you have plenty of time to tour the entire compound before it gets too crowded and hot. It's almost overwhelming with the multitude of gold temples and idols. But if you only see one temple, this is the one to visit.

Emerald Buddha. You have to hire some tour guide, there's so much content and history. Beside, Buddism have a lot of meanings for everything. I would reccomend you to take the tour with some guidence.

Spectacular Wat - the must see site in Bangkok. Even in the rain, this was a most spectacular sight. The workmanship on the structures is awe inspiring. You can't imagine the detail until to see it. Pictures just don't convey the immensity and depth of the carvings, stone work and mosaics. If the sun had been out it might have been blinding. Remember to wear conservative clothing. My son had to rent long pants at the gate as shorts are forbidden.

Must do in Bangkok. Its definitely one of the Must-Do's. We went there after lunch and it wasn't crowded but I think it's worth going early in the morning not only to beat the crowds but also because it's incredibly hot ! The entrance fee is BHT500 which is quite expensive for BKK. I recommend taking the audio guide (you can share one for 2) as it really helps structure the visit and understand the history of the site. We spent around 3 hours there but would probably have spent 1 hour without the guide. There is a free app you can download with more information around the palace which can maybe replace the audio guide/map.As in every temple, you will have to dress appropriately - no sleeveless shirts/visible shoulders or shorts/skirts above the knees. You will have to remove your shoes several times and leave them unattended so make sure to take comfy shoes that are not too valuable.Getting there by taking the boat and going through the small local market adds to the charm of the visit. The amulet market is close-by as well.

Too Crowded. Major recommendation is to be on the grounds as early as possible. The crush of tourists was unbelievable and you have to wear eye protection to avoid an inadvertent jab from an umbrella. The main exhibit with the Emerald (jade) Buddha was closing early. The grounds of the temple were a sensory overload. I would recommend it on a first trip to Bangkok but I wouldn't need to experience it again. The admission price was on the high end at 500 baht.
Thought it would be bigger. That it was going to be huge. It was beautiful though and was advised that the monks changed the robes of the Emerald/Jade Buddha for the different seasons.
wonderful with Thai art. when you come to Thailand the first your trip i prefer you go to see the emeral bhudha and beatiful thai culture art at Grand Palace.

Definitely a Bangkok must!. The temple grounds themselves are a sensory overload (in a good way). To the eye - just the kaleidescope of colors (golds, greens, blues, reds, yellows) from rooftops, 20 foot tall guardian sculptures, wall murals, walls, ceilings, benches, fences... Truly - everything glints in the sun and catches your eye. The emerald buddha (made out of jade) is in itself much smaller than one would imagine, but he too, sits on a gilded platform, and commands a presense, where worshippers lay fresh lotus flowers at his feet and come in to pay their respects. There were a ton of people, but it was still a friendly crowd - most folks smiling and showing every courtesy to keep from making a hot day, uncomfortable. This was definitely a "must-do" when visiting Bangkok. Just remember the proper etiquette must be followed -- shoes off before entering the temple and no sleeveless shirts or shorts (coverings should be worn around the shoulders and at least down to the knees).
Amazing!. Really worth going there! Very nice temple complex. Gold shines in the sunlight, but be aware of scam from tuktuk and "nice strangers" next to the Grande Palace!
Really busy, get there early. Fascinating temple complex, but was very busy and getting close enough to see the 'emerald Buddha' was almost impossible after 11am... Get there early

You've got to go.. Sure, you will be one of 4000 people who visit that day, but you're in the middle of Bangkok, so its almost required. The Buddha itself/himself is quite small, but the Wat is worth going to.

beautiful. Without visiting this one, you have not seen Bangkok. Its one of the main attractions. Go early in the morning. It does not matter when you are in Bangkok, this place is always hot! Around the Buddha you have all around wall paintings. Fun for kids to guess what the story is about etc.

Superb. Greatly enjoyed the visit. The buildings are exceptional. You must wear long trousers if you are male and must have your shoulders covered. Emerald buddha is a bit underwhelming but the site is fantastic and I would say this is unmissable
He's a little guy. After the reclining Buddha this guy is only about two feet high, no cameras allowed and a different, but equally good, experience.

Stunning Thai Temple, a must Visit in Bangkok. Stunning Thai Architect all around. There is a dress code, Semi formal, female must wear long skirts, no shorts, no low cut blouse. This is a way Thai show their respect to temple. Lots of Kodak moments. Plan for morning tour otherwise, may get too hot to walk around. I visited Thailand once a year for the past 3 years. ach year I have to visit this temple. For all thai people, this is how they receive their blessings and have good luck. There is a foreigner fee, No fee for Thai. Watch for scammers around the temple. Warning : DO NOT DO ANY TUK-TUK TOUR OFFERED AROUND THERE. Use Taxi meter only

A must see but crowded. The temple of the Emerald Buddah is in the same complex as the Grand Palace and attracts every visitor to Bangkok (some days it seems every visitor to Bangkok is in the temple complex at the same time!). The temple is a truly awesome sight with its brightly coloured pagodas, wats and stupas and is a 'must see' if you are in Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha is actually quite a small Buddha image but has a spiritual significance to Thais (avoid the temple on Thai holidays because the place is even more crowded than normal!). The temple is more crowded in the mornings when the tour buses decend (watching the tourist hoards is also a good way of spending 15 minutes) and I would recomend visiting after lunch as there seems to be less people about. The entrance is often packed solid but once inside the grounds are so big that you don't actually feel claustrophobic. If you are short of time I'm afraid an expensive tourist tour is your best option but if you have the time catch the express ferry from Central Pier (next to a skytrain stop) to Pier 9 and walk the 200 yards to the temple (ignoring all the chancers who try to persuade you the temple is closed in order to take you 'shopping'). If you can stand the heat and are up for a shortish walk the visit to the temple can easily be combined with a visit to Wat Pho which is about 400 yards away.

Great place, terrible atmosphere. During the last 34 years of my life I have been several times in this temple but for sure this time was the last visit :First they charge now 500 Baht entrance and the place is crowded. I think they can charge what they want and the tourists will still come. Inside you have no time to let the wonderful place overtake you with his atmosphere because the atmosphere are screaming, photos taking and pushing people. I found it terrible.Terrible is also that you see many poor people in the streets and than you pay about 17 Euro entrance here I started calculating : 17 Euro and estimated (low estimation) 20,000 people per day are more than 300,000 Euro or 400,000 USD per day. Where does that money go to ? Let me guess.....

Amazing but a quick look is all we needed. This was really neat to see but it takes about 5min as there are so many people trying to get in and see the Emerald Buddha and to watch as people kneeled and prayed. This only takes about 5-10minutes but is worth a visit.

Great Place...but too busy!. It´s surely an impressive temple, but it was extremely busy and it wasn't really a relaxing visit. Based on comments from friends that have also been there, I have the impression it is always that busy, regardless of the time of the year. Nevertheless, it is a must go since it´s an essential part of the Great Palace.
You have not been to Bangkok if you have not visited the Grand Palace. So beautiful in everyway although and you have to go into the Grand Palace to see this and the price to enter now BHT500

Beautiful restoration. This temple is beautiful and well maintained, but extremely crowded. No photos allowed, but still people tried to sneak in cameras and made a disruptive fuss when the guards asked them to put cameras away. It's a small temple for the number of people who visit, and removing shoes = smelly feet! All in all, it was a restorative oasis in the chaos around the Grand Palace. The jade Buddha was only partially visible due to a gold cloak around it, but still a stunning display and beautiful temple.
Amazing but so crowded. It's a amazing destination but with so many tour groups and tourists jam packed in the morning, I don't know anyone can really enjoy the experience.

luxurious. inside of the temple is very big compared tho the size of the statue..
not being rude, yes it is a really sacred temple and yes it worth a visit but i cannot really see the statue because it's really high and far..

Maybe had seen too many buddhas at this point!!. Very nice paintings, carvings, smaller statue than expected- also Bangkok crowded with tourists from China/Korea etc-noisy and too busy after calmer Cambodia. Sites more indoors which probably exacerbated the feeling. Some may consider it magnificent.

Part of Grand Palace. Get off at Tha Chang(pier 9) via Chao Phraya express boat....walk to Grand palace. once you buy the ticket (500baht),the first place you will reach is Temple of Emerald Buddha.It a nice wat but no photography allowed. Dont expect a huge green buddha as you see in lots of other temples.The place is really crowded so try to visit early.
Good. This place is interesting, however I must say that lot of other attractions in Bangkok are better! But for sure every visiotr should see the Emerald Buddha!

watphra kaeo temple. This was one of the temples that we could not enter. i would like to ask evey one shoul go to see them The Buddha is actually made of jade, but they call it Emerald because of the green color.

Not what expected. The temple itself is great to walk around and look at. The Emerald Buddha was not what I was expecting. It really small, and located far and high back into the temple. Don't expect to get to have a close look.
Another awe-inspiring Wat!. Another beautiful Wat in Bangkok. Worth a visit. Best go early - avoid the crowds, and miss the heat!

Beautiful Temple. *) Located inside the Grand Palace, Na Phra Lan Road.*) Temple of the Emerald Buddha or Wat Phra Kaeo occupies one corner of the Grand Palace complex. It houses the Emerald Buddha, the most revered Buddha image in Thailand.*) Very near Wat Pho. After The grand palace you can walk to Wat Pho (temple of reclining buddha) just behind the complex.*) Opening Hours : Daily from 08.30 hrs. - 15.30 hrs.*) Admission Fee: Free of charge for Thais and 350 baht for foreigners. Included in the ticket for Grand Palace.*) How to Get There : SkyTrain to Saphan Taksin Station (S6) (Silom Line). Leave via exit 2 and take a Chao Phraya Express Boat to Chang Pier (N9).Buses that go there : Bus No. 1, 3, 25, 32, 33, 59, 60, 70, 82, 91, 201, 203, or air-conditioned bus no. 2, 3, 6, 25, 32, 59, 60, 70, 82, 201, 203 and 512*) No pictures inside but a good picture can be taken from out front through the doors. Note photography is not allowed and a lot of tourists still seemed to take photos freely.*) The grounds are beautiful... remember to take of shoes to enter the wat. And there is access to enter the palace grounds.*) Very poor maps & directions.*) Take water to drink as it does get very warm, refreshments are available and a gift shop is next to the ticket office.*) Don't forget that you shouldn't point your feet at the Buddha. It is definitely a must see.*) My verdict - Must-see. But the actual Emerald Buddha is too small at the top.For a detailed trip list feel free to visit http://bangkokandpattaya-itinerary.blogspot.in/

Stunning site. The sheer opulence of the temples and the surroundings will blow you away. Take your sun glasses as you will need them. It is a fantastic place if you want to see Thai culture and is worth reading up about before you get there so you know what things are. Please ensure that you dress modestly as it is a place of worship. This was easy to get to on the tourist boat.
Very Crowded But This Is The Best. Amazing Temple, palace and history. Very crowded so come early and plan on 90 minutes. We arrived at 10 am and saw the parade for changing of the guard.

Small but impressive. The Emerald Buddha is set back in the temple and can be seen from a distance. This was one of the temples that we could not enter. The Buddha is actually made of jade, but they call it Emerald because of the green color. Even though you can't go in the temple it is worth the vista to look at the Buddha from a distance.

Go to other wats. It's not worth waiting in the heat and getting crammed together with other people to see this tiny buddha. Thousands of sweaty people. The guards are really strict so if you are not dressed properly, you will get turned away. The entrance fee is pretty high at 500 baht (about $16US). There are other wats that are prettier and are not as crowded.

Must see, but with a guide. This temple is simply amazing we hired an excellent English speaking guide who gave us the history and interpreted the religious meaning behind all of the bedazzling art and buildings. Go late afternoon or early to avoid bus loads of tourists.

Kind of a let down. After all the beautiful and breathtaking Buddhas we had seen the emerald Buddha was kind of a bummer. You can't take pictures and honestly we got to the end of the grand palace looking for the emerald Buddha and then finally realized we had already seen it. He is super small and I know made of emerald which is awesome but compared to many of the others just not as impressive!

Take the tour!. My wife & I took an afternoon tour of the Grand Palace & Wat Phra Kaeo.We happened along at a time when a free, english speaking guided tour began so we joined it. Mr Kam was a very good guide. he was very knowlegable, engaging & entertaining.The buildings & the emerald buddha are all beautiful to behold.We thoroughly enjoyed our tour of the Grand Palace & Wat Phra Kaeo.

Beautiful. Awe Inspiring beauty. The respect and the belief the Thai have is truly something special. The beauty inside the temple and the surroundings are gorgeous but be warned there is a lot of walking and it gets hot!
Can skip if in Bangkok for a short period of time. This can be skipped if you have a limited time in Bangkok, long lines and just too much of a hassle to see a reclining Buddha

TEMPLE DAY TOUR BANGKOK XMAS 2012-13. Crowded the day we were there but still got great commentary on Lord Buddha. Work in progress upgrading this and other temples. Hats off to the Thai government for restoration of these international treasures.

niecest budhist temple in the world. Together with other temples, statues, artefacts in area is this the nicest temple place in the world. Stil is there many people for visiting of this very popular temple of town.

Peaceful place at the palace. Amazing temple with the famous Emerald Buddha to gaze upon while you sit on the cool marble floor, fans whirring nearby...a nice respite from the heat and the crowds outside
Busy beautiful temple. This temple is inside Grand Palace and is really beautiful and also busy. But it's good to stop and watch the buddha for a while. remember to cover yourself before going there.

excellent but crowded. loved it! advice: men make sure to wear long pants, women make sure to wear longer skirts or pants and shirts with sleeves. you can rent shirts and pants for a 200 bhat deposit which you will get back once you return the clothing. you are not allowed to take pictures inside and must leave your shoes at the bottom of the stairs.
Very nice temple. You need to going to this temple. It has nice architecture of Thailand and it be respectable temple of Thai people. Very nice view .. prepare your camera to take photos!

Over-rated IMO.. The emerald buddha is small, the site is very crowded and the charge to get in is rather expensive. There are many beautiful wats in Thailand that cost a little or nothing and which I prefer.
Precious. No pictures allowed inside. No problem with that, you will keep that image in mind. I've never seen a place with so much devotion. It's impressive!
Exquisite. Beautiful temple, and shouldn't be missed. We went early in the day and were still overwhelmed with the heat and the crowds. Be prepared with sun hats, water and patience.

huge buddah. what an awesome place a huge buddah to visit it looked amazing.there are gold elephants which you have to walk under 3 times to give you good luck..the grounds were spectacular with a lake behind with some huge fish in to look at..the grounds were very tranquil....

Emerald Buddha. A fantastic buddha, one of the most religious buddhas that the Thai's have...Be mindful of this when entering, shoes off and ladies cover up.There will be many people praying and you will have to be content with seeing teh buddha from a distance.If you do over step there are attendees that will correct you.The Buddha does have hise clothes changed depending on the season, of you want to see the other designs, they are available in teh small museum.

Wat Phra Kaew. The Wat Phra Kaew - Temple of the Emerald Buddha is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple (wat) in Thailand. It is a "potent religio-political symbol and the palladium of Thai society". It is located in the historic centre of Bangkok (district Phra Nakhon), within the precincts of the Grand Palace. The main building is the central ubosoth, which houses the statue of Emerald Buddha. The Emerald Buddha, a dark green statue, is in a standing form, about 66 centimetres tall, carved from a single jade stone (Emerald in Thai means deep green colour and not the specific stone). It is carved in the meditating posture in the style of the Lanna school of the northern Thailand. Except for the Thai King, no other person is allowed to touch the statue. The King changes the cloak around the statue three times a year, corresponding to the summer, winter, and rainy seasons, an important ritual performed to usher good fortune to the country during each season.
A Smaller Buddha. This Buddha is small in comparison to others, but very beautiful. No photos are allowed and it is enforced.

Beautiful to see. This is usually part of the Grand Palace tour and shouldn't be missed. The temple and grounds are stunning and offer lots of beautiful photo opportunities. There are pictures of the other outfits that the Buddha is dressed depending on the season.One thing to note, the crowds, especially the many group tours with umbrellas, to be a bit overwhelming. Just be aware of the dress code, and no camera inside the temple. If you are part of a tour group don't expect to spend much time wandering around. There are very few places to buy drinks and not many places to sit in the shade.
Cultural must see. Just be ready for heat, oppressive heat and lots of people. I was fascinated with the faith, art and architecture, so different, wonderful opportunity.
Nice complex. Very hot in the sun though.. My only complaint is that water was hard to find. So bring it in with you. The complex was very nice and I would suggest getting a guide to show you around.

Sublime experience!. The Temple of he Emerald Budha (actually made from Jade) is one of the most stunning temples in Bangkok! Though the Buddha itself is smaller than many others, it is exquisitely carved and the way it is hosted on top of glittering gold structures is amazing! a not-to-miss sight!
Amazing. would have loved to take pictures inside, a must visit for all the tourists. the architecture and decor is great

Busy but worth seeing.. The statue itself is very impressive, jade rather than emerald but still beautiful. Quite a line to see it but worthwhile. No photos inside but you can take a photo from the front of the building

Another Must-See in Bangkok!. This temple is part of the Grand Palace Tour and it needs a review of its own.Make sure you hire a guide or be a part of a guided tour. The story behind the Emerald Buddha is extremely interesting. However, the statue is made of jade, not emerald.Dress properly, since a dress code is strictly enforced. Otherwise, loan or borrow proper clothes at the entrance.Budget half a day for this temple. It is awesome to be inside and you feel the devotion of believers and the respect shown by visitors. Not to be missed, indeed!Drink lots of water and take your breaks accordingly.Enjoy!

A Jewel. The temple is a must see. Remember that you are in front of the most revered Buddha statue in the land and therefore behave accordingly. Spend some time admiring the murals (the life of Buddha) and the regal hats.

Buddhist Bank Holiday. As per my review for the Reclining Buddha (Wat Pho) this is a must see in Bangkok and was all the better for visiting during a religious holiday. The Emerald Buddha is much smaller than expected and unlike others you cannot take pictures but still worth the visit.
wonder how much its worth lol. a little disappointing as u cannot get too close to it, although we like how they change it into different outfits
A beautiful temple. The place is amazing but crowdy, it worths but you can be there just some minutes before get tired of the people
Not what we expected. The Buddha was too high and could not be seen properly which was disappointing as we were looking forward to seeing it.

Grand Palace. Don't forget to dress appropriately - legs covered (to the ankle) or women may wear a skirt (that covers the knees). The temple was beautiful as were the other buildings and the grounds of the Grand Palace.

A very good introduction to the Thai kingdom history.. Although called Emerald, the Buddh'a is actually made of jade. This does not however lessen the magnificence of the Temple where the Buddh'a sits, currently in his summer robes. The reverence shown by both Eastern and Western visitors are contagious, and hopefully makes the Thais more proud of their heritage and way of life. The entrance fee also includes the Grand Palace, Vimanmek Mansion Museum, Abhisek Dusit Throne Hall, Sanam Chandra Palace, Anantha Samakhom Throne Hall, the Weapons and Arms Museum, and the Pavilion of Regalla, Decorations and Coins and is therefore worth every bhat paid for.
overrated. Buddha was very small, hard to see & wearing clothes. And no photography! They should at least undress him so we could see more.

Still worth visiting. Although it is getting more and more crowded each time I have visiting this place, it should be on the list of what to see in Bangkok.Just be aware of the dress code, and no camera inside the temple.Furthermore, be aware of all the so called guides outside, who want to make some quick money on the tourists.

Just the best!!!. You just need to go! no doubts about it! the most beautiful and peaceful place on Earth... It always seems to be full, but you can stay there for a while (feet away from the Budha, of course...)

Beautiful but crowded. The temple and grounds are stunning and offer lots of beautiful photo opportunities. However, I found the crowds, especially the many group tours with umbrellas, to be a bit overwelming. It might be better to visit as soon as it opens or later in the day. We tried to arrive for the opening, but underestimated how long it would take us to get there by a combination of skytrain and water taxi.Tip : Bring lots of water with you as it was extremely hot when we visited Wat Phra Kaeo and the Grand Palace between 9-10am. Once inside, there seems to be only one place at the far end of the grounds (past the Grand Palace) to buy drinks. All the other shops are outside which are only available before you enter or after you exit.
Impressive frescos. The walls are all covered with paintings, the atmosphere is very special, but be aware that there are always flocks of tourists there.

Enchanting. Lovely, eye opening, beautiful, sacred place.
Must wear clothes to cover your shoulders and below the knees.
Not cheap to enter.
Not allowed to take photos of the Emerald Buddha
Wonderful place. The paintings, statues and all the beautiful and colorful designs are so amazing. Dont miss this one when you are in Bangkok.

Intricate designs and interesting history. Well worth a trip if you are into history and architecture. The free brochures given at the entrance to the temple give a detailed (albeit difficult to navigate) guide to the various sections of the temple. Intricate designs and especially interesting to see the paintings representing the Ramayana.

Crowded And Crazy and Still Worth It. This temple complex is arguably one of the most important places in Thailand. It houses the Emerald Buddha, yes. A buddha carved of a single piece of jade that stands almost 18 inches tall and has attired made of gold that is changed according to the seasons. With a long and storied history of possession--it's been captured back and forth between the Lanna kingdom of old Thailand, the Lao and Cambodian nations and it's final capture back to Thailand was the founding of the current, or Chakri dynasty--it's a fascinating piece of living history one display. Remove your shoes and don't take a camera: it's not allowed. But be prepared. It doesn't seem like much, back there by the back wall, but work your way forward and really study and then feel the devotion the Thai people around you feel. And then, when you are done there, walk around the perimeter of the temple proper and follow along with the "Ramakien" or the Thai national epic. Also, pick a bit of knowledge about syncretism when, after some reading, you realize that the Ramakien is in many ways almost identical to the Ramayana, a Hindu story. But the Theravadan Buddhist Thais still have markers and images in the story that resonate with their own ancient animist beliefs. Besides, the places of the narrative are in Thailand, Sri Lanka and South Asia. And the entire thing is illuminated in the form of intricate paintings, epic in scope, running hundreds of feet along a continuous alcove covered wall. I can't recommend all of this highly enough.

Serene. Try to slow down and spend some time inside the temple. It is a magnificent and spiritual place even with a few hundred people swarming in and out. I put it high on the list of things to see in Bangkok.

Always a treat to visit and revisit!. This was our 2nd visit to the Grand Palace & Emerald Buddha complex...and we were still in awe of all the amazing sights there. From the macro to the micro, everything is a joy to the senses. We did not get the chance to loiter longer because of the huge crowds that day as it was a religious holiday. Lesson learned: try to schedule your visit on other days not on a Monday, as the Vimanmek Mansion(entrance fee included in the B500 in the Grand Palace&Emerald Buddha fee) will be closed on this day, Unless you plan to come back on another day to visit the Teak Mansion.

Nice Place to Pray. Well this is the imperial wat... it's bond to be beautiful. Last year I went here, it's not crowded so it's nice place to pray. But I came here as first troop as I came at 08.30 just when the palace just open. the buddha ruppang is way up there and rather small, but it's beautiful. But this feb when I went there it was closed (the entrance are blocked although you still can see the buddha ruppang) since they're going to have ceremony for Magga Puja. so I just can show my mum this wat from outside. What a pity since the dhammasala is also very beautiful with all golden decoration. And if I'm not mistaken, there are a stage on the left side of the dhammasala for Bhikkus when they're having ceremony.

A must see. Different and very interesting. It is definitely touristy place, but the whole temple is very well kept. You will need to take of your shoes which was not a problem since everything is clean. Don't worry about your shoes, nobody will take them. There are security guards around and they know what are they doing. Photos are not allowed although people were taking photos through the window. This Temple has to be seen to be experienced the right way.
Beautiful but very crowded.. Beautiful but very crowded at least in the middle of the day. It was difficult to enjoy stay there and admire.
Nice but crowded. Grand Palace - one of the top 5 things to see in Bangkok. Little bit expensive but totally worth of it. The architecture and artwork are amazing. Little bit crowded but still OK.
Unnoticeable. Considering that it is inside the Grand Palace and the place is so big I think a signage is needed in every temple. The temple seems to be the same that's why it is a bit confusing

Well worth a visit. The splendor is overwhelming. The disrespectful tourists not so much. I tried to stand to the side and not disturb those who were kneeling but the hordes stepping over people trying to pray was very distracting. It would have been nice if there was a roped off viewing area - they try to route the crowd but it turns into a bit of a free for all. Note: you are required to remove your shoes before you enter the temple.

A must visit when you are in Bangkok. Great historical palace and truly beautiful at eh same time. Pagoda, Thai buildings, bells and mytholical creatures every. Gold, gold and the Emaral Budda itself. Take the time, line up and go see the Emerald Budda !Useful advise - the is a dresscode to enter. Ladies/Gents have to wear long pants/skirts. If you to not want to wear long pants in the Bangkok heat, the souveniers shops across the street rent our pants/skirts for BHT 30 !

Hot and crowded but do see it. I am not a Buddhist and I hate crowds but I could not visit the grand palace complex and not see this. Unfortunately you cannot take photos inside the temple but just seeing a carving from a large piece of jade was interesting in itself. I expected the Buddha to be bigger than it was. Still see it - it doesn't take long.

unbelievable. What an unbelievable Buddha, and to hold such high regards to the Thai people and be on display is a true honor to visit. You must remove shoes to enter the temple Wat Phra Kaeo and must NOT take any photos inside the temple. I saw a rude tourist disobey this request and the police handled the situation promptly by deleting her memory card: ALL PHOTOS!!! That did give me a giggle- As some people are just so disrespectful. It was very crowded in the temple, but the people seemed to flow better and you were able to see the most sacred Buddha.

Heart of the Nation. The most sacred place in all of Thailand, one simply must visit. It touches so many aspects of the city and the country although it is not a modern edifice I think Thai people identify very strongly with this temple
Hot but worth it. It was very hot when we went there last week. However, the temple is grand and totally worth the effort. Don't forget your camera and carry water, umbrella and sunscreen!

Superb. The emerald Buddha ( which is made of Jade, by the way) is placed high up on the top of an altar in a serene Biddist temple.The walls are covered with paintings which can be missed because of the crowds. The Buddha itself seems to be shining with an interior light. I was very moved buy it.

Just one stop on the Palace tour. The grounds here are huge. Allow several hours if you are interested and there are many photo shots here. Crowds are huge and we were there during the work week! The Emerald Buddha is staged pretty far from where you get to stand. Take a long lens for photos (not allowed inside) through the open panel back in the front of the building.

Most sacred object in Thailand. It’s the most sacred object in Thailand but the setting is rather pedestrian. The statue itself is not that large and is not that artistically impressive as a Michelangelo.The object has regular ceremonies where the clothing on the statue is changed according to the seasons.However there is the infamous “double-rate” charge, one rate for Thais and a much higher rate for foreign visitors. It was around $20 last time I went in 2011. It’s a gray area on whether this is worth a look.

Not able to see. National holiday so we could not see, closed at 12pp. What a shame and they did not tell us as we entered the site, never mind next time!!! But it would be helpful before you pay the 500 Thai baht.

Small but perfectly formed!. OK, the Emerald Buddha is very, very small but the setting is unbelievably beautiful. Try to get there first thing in the morning before the crowds begin to build up, especially if you're a photographer and don't want Japanese tourists flipping the inevitable V sign in every shot you take.

Beautiful, ornate, breathtaking. My husband and I visited the Temple of the Emerald Buddha in the heat of late afternoon, and were therefore not planning to stay very long.We were blown away, however, by the buildings in this complex. It's amazing to see just how intricate everything is.We were less interested in the emerald Buddha itself, and more in the architecture and murals surrounding the temple. Definitely a sight worth seeing when in Bangkok, just make sure you wear long pants or skirt, or you'll have to rent or stand in line to borrow a sarong before you enter the complex.

We should have paid for a guide.. This is a very beautiful temple and surrounding area. For some reason we decided not to hire a guide so we really didn't know much about what we saw. If I ever got back to Bangkok, I would tour this again with a guide. I'm sure we missed a lot!The buildings were beautiful! I loved the colors and patterns! We weren't comfortable with leaving our shoes outside the temples because we didn't have spares, so we carried them in our tote bag! No one else seemed concerned! With our admission price, we received a coupon for a bottle of water. It was very hot and humid so the water was great!I had a Thai Massage at the massage school. It's supposed to be the oldest and best in the country. It's on the grounds of Wat Pho. (Wat Phra Kaeo) I didn't what to expect, but signed up for a 30-minute massage. I learned you only remove your shoes. You lay on a mat and the Massage Therapist kneels on the mat beside you. In the open room I was in, there were 3 mats lined up together on a raised platform. The Thai massage is a pressure massage. It felt great! She seemed to spend extra time on my shoulders, which is my weak area. None of the Therapists spoke during the massages.
Spectacular monument. A must see. Remember its a temple so act accordingly. Only understandable disapointment is no photography.

A place to see. but so crowded that after 10 minutes you just want to escape. But of course a must see in Bangkok, it's a nice temple and don't forget to dress properly ( long skirt, long sleeves ..) because they are really strict with the dress code.

buddha tour. Very impressive but gave up trying to see this buddha due to sheer amount of people visiting on the day we went. Combined with the heat and humidity I settled for looking at the building from the outside. My partner beat the crowds and ventured in with our guide and was most impressed.
Crowded. This and the grand palace were so crowded!! They were great but it was hard to appreciate everything with the large crowds...

The most revered Buddha in all of Thailand. Located within the grounds next to the Grand Palace. Many devout Buddhist will make this pilgrimage to this Buddhist icon. Tho not made of emerald but of jade and only 2 feet tall, it is housed in an immense hall. Please respect the prayers of the many Buddhist praying here and not converse inside the building. No pictures of the Emerald Buddha should be taken even from the outside through an open window. Single flowers may be purchased or a full pot in an adjoining building (100/300 baht). If you purchase the full pot, a guard will escort to the front of the praying area in the hall. But be aware of the eiquette if you do....Do Not point your feet at the Buddha or any Buddha image or of any person. Place your feet behind you as you kneel or squat. Also bring an umbrella for the sweltering Bangkok sun when touring the outside grounds, it will save you! A must stop in Any Bangkok visit.

Live this place but the other tourists can ruin the experience. Have been here a few times and still admire the awesome architecture, the history and most of all the emerald buddha. The other tourists can dampen the whole experience though by the shoving, pushing, and very loud talking. Better to arrive first thing when the temple opens.
Must see. If you can muscle through the bus load of picture taking Asians give it a go, just very hard to get photos without a million people in them

Busy, Busy, Busy!. Like most of the Temples in Bangkok this is beautiful, however the Emerald Buddha is very small and you can;t get very close to it, so you won't see a great deal. No photos aloud and this is a very popular Temple so be warned the crowds are a little much!

Beautiful!. It's really a beautiful looking Buddha despite its diminutive size. A must see given it's importance in the Thai culture. The grounds around the Buddha are also incredible impressive with a massive gold plated Wat and a miniature version of the Angkor Wat. There are a lot of nice gardens as well.

A temple with no monks. I often bring foreigners to visit this temple to see how beautiful the emarald buddha is. The architecture is incredibly beautiful. However, the girls and women need to wear skirt, otherwise, you're charged to change into traditional Thai skirt. The men and boys should wear trousers. It is called an official temple where the king often comes for the events. Therefore, every Thai respects this place and wears proper uniform to enter this temple. If you don't wear a proper dress, you're charged to rent one and wear it while you're there.

high frequentated magical place in the center of the grand palace. the temple of the emerald buddha, which protects the royal family, seems like the most visited place in bangkok. unfortunatelly it is not allowed to take photos inside the temple. further it is necessary to take attention for the own feet, because it is forbidden to show the emerald buddha the foot soles. the atmosphere inside is restless, because poeple come in and move out everytime. the price for entree is included the price for the grand palace.

Overcrowded and too obsessed with no photographs. Rather than a place of worship, it was more crowded than St Peter's Basilica in Rome on a bad day. There seemed to be an overabundance of officials shouting "no photographs" (photos could be obtained by standing outside the door)
Wonderful Temple. You get taken to too many temples in Thailand but this is one of the best. It is crowded with tourists and a guide is a must. Go early to miss some of the crowds

Beautiful - but incredibly crowded. Part of the Royal Palace complex, Wat Phra Kaeo was easily one of the most beautiful temples we saw in Thailand. The scope and detail were amazing and definitely worth a look. Having said that, this was easily one of the most crowded tourist attractions I have *EVER* been to. The Forbidden City had NOTHING on Wat Phra Kaeo in terms of visitors - at least when we were there. We were literally elbow to elbow in some places. Bring your camera, lots of patience and be mindful of your belongings.Before you go, take a second to review the dress code. Remember it's a place of worship and be respectful. Definitely cover your shoulders and make sure not to wear short shorts - many people had to "rent" clothes (available on-site) so that they would be suitably covered. We read that open toed/heeled sandals were not allowed, but saw many many people with flip flops, crocs and other sandals on.

Amazing. This is a beautiful temple. Pictures can be taken from outside, but the ability to do so inside would help enhance the visit. The Buddha is dressed in different clothing depending on the time of year.

Beautiful; Thailand's holiest of holies. Part of the Royal Palace complex. No bare legs or bare shoulders permitted - and they mean business!The entire area is dazzling before you even get to the temple. Dazzling is an understatement. Make sure your camera's batteries are fully charged - you'll need them!The temple itself is a holy place so act respectfully - bare feet only and for heaven's sake ! - don't point the soles of your feet toward the Buddha; If you do a very polite security guard will come over and firmly correct your behavior.The Emerald Buddah itself is really quite small compared to all the ornamentation within the temple. Don't forget to take time to admire the murals on the walls. The theme's are quite similar to European court scenes (with a Thai twist) When we were there the monks were chanting, which added a more reverent feeling. Just sit down (on the floor) and quietly take it all in. Enjoy the lovely shade while you can because it's HOT outside! To avoid being pushed out (if it's crowded) sit down on the floor somewhere (watch where those feet are pointing!)
Has to be seen. The Emerald Buddha is really beautiful, but because of its placement and size is hard to see. Still this cannot be missed.
Crowded. This place was so crowded with tourist. I was looking for people that were actually Buddhist. A few worshipers came in, but mostly tourist not understanding how to behave.
Stunned. I was in awe from the start. Seeing as this was one of my first Buddhist temples, I'm partial to their beauty. This was at the top, for sure!

WOW!. The main tourist attraction. Do it with a tour guide. We used a personal tour guide for about $50 US for all day, we covered this with good guidance, she has a tour pass and knew how to navigate. In the same day we did the floating market, reclining Budda, and China town well worth it. This was a WOW. There are so many people there too. But the temples are well worth the visit.

Get a guide. We were there in November 2011, just a few days after Buddha got his "clothes" changed. He has got different clothes depending on the time of year. The buddha is quite tiny but the history is very interesting. Definitely worth paying a guide to hear all about it though.

Full of tourists but beautiful anyway! One of the Bangkok symbol. Never miss this place if you travel to BKK! Although taking pictures of the Emerald Buddha is not allowed, the others are okay, so spend at least 2 hours there. And you should come very early in the morning for better experience, I guess. We came there in the early afternoon and gosh, jam-packed of tourists. Bonus, we came to the Red Sky Bar 55th floor of Centara hotel, and well, at night, you can see the Wat in stunning golden light! Awesome!

Smaller then I tought but still beautiful.. After seeing big buddha's everywhere around Bangkok I was expecting this one to be bigger than that. But it was not disappointing. Really beautiful temple and buddha!!!

A Must see!. Take time here! Don't come in those tours where they'll spend an hour. Spend a half day and take time in advance to read about the temple, its history and all the site/objects/artifacts you will see.

Just to have a look. Before visiting you may imagine that it is something grand. In reality it is very small sculpture on the top. Better pay and go to numismatic museum, there are three copies of this, each in another seasonal dress. And you do not need a binocular

Magnificent. Beautifully decorated- exterior and interior, the ornate carvings and pillars, and the most serene Buddha statue, after the Wat Pho ( Sleeping Buddha).Take some time to take in the sights and experiencing the pure calm… it will soothe your senses … get lost in the tranquility….Part of the Grand Palace, this is a must visit, if you are visiting the Grand Palace. Top on the list.
Most beautiful thing ever. It is ridiculously busy, but it is so worth it. I have been watching the wall paintings for almost 40 minutes. Make sure you go with a tour or buy an information booklet.

no pic. the temple itself was really nce but taking pictures of the emerald buddha is prohibited.
just wear proper clothes and bring water and you are good to go
oxford tailor. Very nice temple when we there with my family we fell really better inside the temple. We fell very lucky we have change to go there. strongly recommended to go there thanks you.
very nice. I would try to get there early, popular temples get crowded. Hard to take pictures, but a must to check in BKK.
Sparkle.. a Great high, after we were so pissed off to pay 500Bht to enter the palace grounds. It's beautifull (Green and serene.) Soo peacefull to be there.

Outstanding. Date visited 12/02/2013Entrance Fee - included in 500 Baht fee for the Grand Palace, unless a Thai national then freeDress code - should already be fine to enter temple as in the grounds however not allowed to wear hats in the temple its selfI was careful not to expect too much incase.....You remove your shoes before walking up a couple of steps onto the temple surround, then walk around admiring the craftmanship on the outside of the temple, take some photos, put your camera away and walk up another couple of steps into the temple its self.It is stunning. The detail of the workmanship all round inside the temple is beautiful. The shiney glittering gold that is everywhere. And there sits the Emerald Buddha in his gold cloth cape (it is changed 3x a year with the seasons) on a high throne. The atmosphere was hushed and respectful even with all the crowds wandering in and out of the temple. Thankfully they had the fans on so it helped with the heat. We sat quietly near the front and just looked.Totally worth the effort and time to visit.

Crowded temple. . Crowded, crowded!!! We went to Grand Palace first then to Temple of the Emerald Buddha within it. The whole area was flooded with tourists. This was the second visit for me. Nice temple to visit except that it was too busy. It became quite unpleasant after a while during hot weather
Serene. This place is just the most beautiful temple that I have ever seen. So beautiful and mystic. Emerald Buddha sits so high with his beautiful coat on.. Different coat for different seasons

A lot of crowds. I understand why people flock to this temple it has this aura about it. There are a lot of people that visit this temple so be prepared for crowds and for the room where the emerald Buddha is to be hot as well. It is much smaller than I thought it would be, it sits at the top of this shrine in this giant room and there are a lot of people in front of it praying. The first time I walked through I didn't even see it because I was moved through the room so quickly I went back for a second go around and I saw it. It is beautiful but small. It is the most well known attraction in Bangkok so it is worth a visit I just warn you that it is hot and crowded.
Beautiful & spritual. No photos allowed, but the Emerald Buddha is quite a sight. The grounds are amazing and the whole "auora" of the temple area is wonderful. A must see when in the area.

Go there just to see Thailands most important temple.. Be prepared to be swarmed by the number of tourists to this temple. While very beautiful and large, I dislike the fact foreignors have to pay a steep 250 baht entrance fees.This is the only temple in Bangkok to be guarded by a whole detachment of army soldiers, armed with even a GPMG at the main entrance.Well, my advice, dont go there more than twice. It gets boring after that.

Good to see. We took an express boat here, then a short walk through an interesting street market. Be careful if you have small children as some of the cooking pots are low down close to the walk way and could be a danger for small children. The Emerald Buddha was a lot smaller than I imagined but the buildings are amazing. Go early and aim to be out by lunch time as it can get very hot walking around. Make sure you are wearing long sleeves and trousers or skirt. Dont wear tight fitting leggings or they will make you hire a wraparound skirt. Which they refund on the way out.
Exquisite temple. In spite of the way too many tourists making it quite hard to get around and take decent photos this is definitely a MUST see for any tourist
green with envy. Emerald Buddha was a refreshing change from all the gold buddhas. They're all beautiful, including this one. Can you spell "temple fatigue"?
Great history. Impressive history behind this temple and I enjoyed seeing it and walking around the Temple. I would definitely include this as one of the top three must see Temples in Bangkok,
Enchanting. The Grand Palace is a must see in BAngkok. It has a jewel, the emerald Buddha, something that has to be seen, an amazing piece of religious art. I could stay in front of it for ours.
Impresive. Very impressive although very crowded, we went quite early in morning and already there were lot of people. When we left after few hours ques were everywhere

Well worth the crowds. Go early to beat the crowds and the heat. Better still is to arrange for a private car, driver and guide to assist in the overall experience of this historic site. This amazing compound filled with various temples and palaces is not to be missed when visiting Bangkok, but be warned: the crowds can be overwhelming as can the traffic...ensure that your means of transport is air conditioned and obtain your bottled water that is a portion of your ticket price. You will not be disappointed in seeing the Emerald Bhudda (which is really jade) and the other statuary located throughout the former royal palace grounds...the current king and family reside in another large compound in Bangkok which is not available for touring.

Must see. This is a must see stop for any visitor - BUT go early...this is located in the Grand Palace grounds and gets crowded early. No photos allowed! PS Buddah is of green Jade. not Emerald. The Grand Palace venue is incredible - as long as it isn't overrun by "clickity, clikity" posing tourists. Wear socks!

very average and over crowded. this temple is inside the grand palace and barely notice it if you didn't already know about it. it feel like just one of the building inside the palace and not a so eye catching one. you will notice it because an army of human will go inside to pray and such, its very hectic (as everywhere inside the palace is) the actual emerald buddha is a very small statue in the middle of the hall far from tourist grab, and you barely notice it and there is no photography allow inside the hall

The Emerald Buddha. We anticipated seeing the Emerald Buddha all morning. The sheer magnitude of all the gold and opulence is impressive. Unfortunately you cannot get close enough to take a picture but with a good camera you can zoom and get one from outside.

price for beauty.... Yes, it is a bit pricey, but very beautiful! If you're traveling with family it could get pricey....500 baht is roughly 15 USD. I traveled with a group of girlfriends and we all enjoyed are time spent at the temple :)
Opulence at a price. Stunning and opulent.. Very crowded though. Baht price was too steep. Good for first visit but probably one time is enough.

Expensive and far too crowded. This (with the combined entry to the Grand Palace) was actually not as enjoyable as I expected it to be. True, the temple is lavishly decorated. But it is also extremely crowded with some jostling involved. It was also by far the most expensive site we visited (500 Bht per person) to the point where I was not sure it was worth it. I enjoyed the much quieter and more relaxing Wat Pho (adjacent block) much more. If you do visit Wat Phra Kaew, I would definitely go as soon as it opens in the morning.

Amazing. A must visit. There are so many temples within. And the Queens attires are also displayed, amazing and beautiful. They have restrooms and a cafe to suit your needs. Women and men have to be properly dressed.
Crowded!. Inside the temple its very peaceful but it gets overcrowded. The Buddha on top of all the emeralds was just so beautiful to see.

temple. Bangkok is city of temple, there are hundreds of them especially in old city however 6 of them is too important especially if you have limited time. Wat arun is the most important one for Thai people also. tour will take at least 2 hours when you enter. you have to start with it and grand palace because they closes at 15.30. dressing is important they do not let short skirts, shorts, capri,t shirts without arms, skinny jeans. and they do not let with scarf if you use them to close somewhere on your body. if you do not want to dress properly you have to wait a que to borrow proper dress (200Baht, when you give back the clothes, you can take your money. (keep in mind, que can take 30 minutes and you have to wear the clothes which were dressed by thounds of others), in all temple you have to take your shoes, so choose easy take off shoes and I can advise to have injection against Hepatit A.when you see emerald buda, you may be suprise because it is too small but it worth. Thai people shows great respect to it. grand palace and wat arun is the most amazing temple in Bangkok.

Worth the visit. Very interesting in that the buddha is jade and not emerald - but is dressed according to seasons - we saw winter took - not bad gold woven cloth. Pictures not allowed inside but zoom in from outside gives foot shot

The most sacred place.. No Photography allowed inside the temple.The dark green statue is in a standing form, about 66 centimetres tall, carved from a single jade stone and not from Emerald as the name suggests. The King changes the cloak around the statue three times a year, corresponding to the summer, winter, and rainy seasons and only the King is allowed to touch the statue.

crowded. compare to my visit in 2012, this place is really crowded....This place is inside the Grand Palace (that Grand Palace itself is already crowded).take off your shoes and wear appropriate dress. dont worry about your shoes, its very secure in this area. actually this temple has beautiful architecture. Maybe if there is less people it will be more comfortable.

Another fantastic Buddah. This is a really fantastic Buddha to go and see, probably my favourite of all that we saw whilst away. It is quite small, but beautiful. The interesting thing about it is that they quite frequently change the scenery etc dependant upon the time of year and have a big celebration to mark this, so if you do go, you should see if you can time it right for such an occasion,

Emerald Buddha is smaller than pictures might suggest, but still a wonderful experience. A very nice spiritual experience. Aside from seeing the emerald statue, make sure you take time to see the wall paintings and understand the story behind them.
Surprisingly small. This Buddha is a must see and I was surprised to see just how small it is. It's a very important Buddha and is neat to experience the Buddha and the temple.

A Special Place. After great hype we finally made it to this temple. It was very nice but not nearly as great as we had been led to believe, The statue was no more than three feet tall, elevated greatly from eye level, and it was difficult to get a close up. It was dressed in the winter clothes. While it is called the emerald Buddha, it is actually made of jadeite. There was a good space for prayer and making offerings. We enjoyed the visit but wish it hadn't been built up as much as it was.
Wonderful place. I really love this place. This temple is very make me impress. Architecture's amazing and i would like to reommend traveller to visit this place.
Beautiful. Great Thai architecture and intricately made structures. The face of the Buddha is made of Jade, very beautiful. Must-visit when in Bangkok!

Beautiful Temple.. Well worth a visit. They are open until 18.00 at night. Women need to cover shoulders and legs. Men legs (flipflops are fine o walk around in). If you dont remember you can borrow an item to coverup with for Bhat200 at the Temple (a guard will direct you before you are allowed to enter). Leggings are considered not good enough as too tight! Make sure you have water with you and a hat (which of course is taken off when you go inside). And then just thoroughly enjoy wandering around this huge place, but remember it is a Temple so be respectful. Always take a camera ;0)

Magnificent. A place where you can see the history of this magnificent civilization. With a little bet of imagination, you can see the real characters of the movie “The King & I” come alive. A visit to Thailand with no visit to Wat Phra Kaeo is a sin!. A bet expensive but worth every penny
Get there early.. It was difficult to take photos because there were so many people there. We arrived before 9.00 a.m on a Saturday morning.
Amazing!. Well worth a visit the architecture and ambience of this place is in a class of its own . Very peaceful although a little crowded.
Great Touristy Thing to Do. It was a fantastic sight to be seen, but beware that they charge you even more money to actually go into the temple on top of what you have to pay the boat to get there!

Cultural experience. The area around this temple is rich in history with monks quarters and excellent views. The site is a sensory overload of sight and most interesting. I love teh idea of taking off yoru shoes to enter buildings and Hawkers took our pictures and put them on fridge magnets and approached us for sale, which is an excellent keep sake.

Quite expensive but very beautiful. We visited yesterday it was very expensive 1000 baht for 2 of us (free for Thai people) but once inside it was lovely. Beautiful buildings and antiquities but lots of people.

So small you could bearly see it. The Buddha is so small you could barely see it, but the Temple is magnificant. It is adjoined with The Grand Palace, so a ticket to one gets you into the other. Beautiful buildings and sculptures.
Fab. We were very lucky to see the Princess come in and pay to Buddah whilst we were there. It is good to see. Very busy but worth the wait.

Dazzling!. Yes, that is the only word. It is sheer beauty. Even though the Buddha idol itself is quite small and perched very high up on the altar, the entire altar is just beautiful. Unfortunately, it is always crowded, so that takes away from the experience.
Amazing experienc. Emerald Buddha was so beautiful..words cant describe. The downside is too many tourists all try to get in to the temple but most were very respectful and not taking photos

A truly beautiful Wat. Wat Phra Kaeo and so many of the other wats in and around Thailand are truly mystical, you are mesmerized by the true architecture of the buildings and i love watching the Monks wander thru for prayers

The Grand gem. When in Bangkok, visit the Grand Palace and its gem, the emerald Buddha. No words can describe this tiny, but oh so grand thing. Somebody once said that the only person he could call You Holiness without a grin is the Dalai Lama. Well, the Emerald Buddha has that kind of effect. It is something very holy and silencing - even to such an atheist as myself.

Obviously good, but expensive. This is obviously very important in a religious context. But if you are more inclined for sights, I liked the Temple of reclining Buddha. The architecture is same and the Reclining Buddha entry fee is lot cheaper. Plus that is a real sight.

Pointless unless you're devout. If you're a devout Buddhist you'll already know about this and simply want to be in the presence of thsi beautiful idol.If you're a tourist and want to see the sights, this is pointless - it's just too small and far away to see in any detail. No photos allowed. Since you have to get into the very expensive Grand Palace to even get close, it's definitely not worth it.
