Must see!. This is a standard destination when visiting Bangkok. Excellent value. Try to avoid the crowds by visiting very early or late afternoon.Do not forget to cover your shoulders and knees, otherwise you will not be aloowed to enter.

Magnificent Temple&Palace in Thailand. More than 90 percent when the tourists come to Thailand. They intended to go to the Grand Palace and Temple of the Emeral Buddha or Wat Phra Kaew.The area of approximately 60 acres is divided into three parts: the outer court, the central court and the inner court.There are 15 doors, but the doors to allow the tourists to have only. (Notice: The main entrance opposite a coffee shop Au Bon Pain)******There are many visitors to the Tuk-Tuk and Taxi waiting to take to the track, to take to the store with low quality.After pass the check point, the first thing you see 3 building, Golden Pagoda, building is rectangular shaped spiers and cross building above a corn cob. East side of the building with a cross and a Golden pagodas shaped recess around pagoda is 16 statues of a giant 4 statue2 of Hanuman in the Ramayana story, all the more beautiful. Chapel of the Emerald Buddha is enshrined on a throne decorated with exquisite pretty flawlessly. Costume of Buddha Image made of real gold with diamond and gemstones, but the Buddha Image made of green jade.This is just as much a part of the visit there were 3 buildings, such as the Throne Hall, Chakri Throne Hall and the funeral Hall, all the buildings are beautiful, but it's not hard to go through.The dress. T-shirt or a short sleeve shirt. Pants to the ankle if women should wear long skirts assumes the knee. Any shoesOpen daily from 8:30 to 16:00. (Ticket office closes 15:30).Admission fee 500 BahtChildren up to 120 cm high.must pay
Lovely, but fairly far away.. We couldn't miss seeing the wonderful buddha. Of all the Buddha's, this is definitely a must see, but I was disappointed that it was visually restricted.

wat?. There are few famous wats in bangkok. These are not places where tourists are forced to pray the local way. Whatever your religion is, you should visit this wat if you're in bangkok. Please take note, there's a dress code, and wear a cheap slipper. No one will steal your shoes, but taking off and putting on is quite troublesome esp when you're wearing socks.

Awe inspiring heritage. The Thai heritage represented by the buildings and statues around this temple has been wonderfully preserved. The whole area is awe inspiring. You are not allowed to take photos inside the temple, but there is a large open window through which you can see and photograph the Buddha if you wish. Look at the detail in the carvings - and how all the broken china (shipped from China) was used to decorate the buildings.
A nice Golden Statue. A huge golden statue. Nothing much to see around other than the statue. Its about 10mins drive from tuk tuk from the grand palace area

Insights into Thai Culture. Loved the complex; hated the crowds. This is a classic example of a facility being loved to death. I am not sure what the solution is, but the crowds freaked me out a bit and detracted from the experience. We're all children of the same world and it's great to see so many people interested in gaining some insight into Thai culture....but the crush was a bit much for a hillbilly like me. Still worth seeing but be prepared for the crush.
Nice temple. Very nice and beautiful temple. But there are many renovation out there, not all other temple can be visited.

Superb Example of a True Asian Culture!. Liked everything here! A MUST for every tourist. The Jade Budha (not emerald as it is popularly known) is majestic and the temple itself, a colourful representative of trues Thai culture and art.
Beautiful. This is a beautiful temple. The lying down budda is stunning but beware of pick pockets who are white people who you might think are tourists.

Don't miss it. You visit the Temple of the Emerald Buddha on the Grand Palace Tour. The statue is much smaller than you would expect but you still get the sense of being in a very special place. After all it is one of the most precious relicts in the Buddhist religion. Be respectful, you should never stand or walk upright.

Thai baroque. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is located in the Grand Palace complex near the Chao Phraya river and consists of not only the temple in which the Emerald Buddha, perhaps the holiest Buddha statue in Thailand, is housed, but also a number of other religious buildings and libraries. The art work is colorful and impressive. Not to be missed

Most sacred temple in Thailand...just Beautiful!!!.... Despite usually crowded -- we had to spend a lot of time in a huge line to watch the most sacred Buddist temple and Buddha image in Thailand--it trully worth the line...Don't miss theWat Phra Kaeo visit!!!...Located within the Great Palace huge area, is a very elegant Bangkok old style contruction, housing the most famous and venerated Buddha image in Thailand, the small Emerald Buddha, flanked by 2 other Buddhas on the main altar. Everything around is highly mystic and amazingly elegant as for both arquitecture and decor.Not to forget the strict dress code similar to all Thai temples: long sleeves long pants or shirts, shoes to stay outdoorNot to forget the cap too, sun is too much!!!...

Wonderful. A must do in Bangkok, and it was fantastic to see people respect the spirit of the Temple. We found that there was something fantastic to look at around every corner. And whilst crowded you were able to find quiet places. We found stret food not far away, but if arriving by ferry make sure you get on the local express one I think it was yellow, not the tourist one that's more expensive.

You can't come to Bangkok and not come here. You can't come to Bangkok and not visit the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaeo. Simple as that. It is... the center. It is just, well, so over-the-top. It is an event just to visit it along with everyone else. That is part of the experience. People are there from all over the world along with you, some worshipping, some gawking (like me). The buildings are so, it is just so... Just go.
The Must - see place of Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha and the Grand Palace are located in the same place. It is the must see place when you visit Bangkok.
Very humbling. I've grown up with Buddhist beliefs and to see all the locals with so much devotion was a very special moment to remember. A very small Buddha but so much detail around it too.

Palace grounds are impressive.. You aren't allowed onto the palace grounds unless shoulders, cleavage, & legs are covered. You can wait in a very long line inside the palace to rent clothing , or for 130 baht you can rent a sarong outside the front gate. When you return the sarong they give you 100 baht back. The emerald Buddha itself is much smaller than I expected & draped in a gold wrap. The grounds are ornate with gold spheres & inlayed glass mosaics. Its very hot, wear a hat. They also give you a small bottle of water with your ticket, but you may want to carry more. People try to tell you its closed because they want to take you shopping. I read about this trick on Trip Advisor so I knew not to fall for it, but I met up with 2 other couples that fell for it. I would definitely recommend seeing the Palace grounds if you are visiting Bankok.

Great into to Thailand. I came here four years ago, when I first moved to Bangkok. Excellent spot for some culture and a massage - this is one of the major training locals for Thai massage. Its easy to get here, just a short boat ride up the Chao Phraya river from the BTS stop Saphan Taksin. I've since been back a couple of times to take visiting friends, and have always enjoyed it.

Small and nice. This temple is part of the Grand Palace and is considered to be one of the most spiritual places in Thailand, consisting of a small but beautiful statue inside. As a general issue, I warmly welcomed the fact that all these temples are always open for foreign tourist (notwithstanding the fact that there were often higher admission prices for these foreigners). Please note that tour guides like to bring you to the Grand Palace and the “three best Bangkok temples”, but these three temples are often Wat Pho (reclining Budha), Wat Traimit (golden Budha) and Wat Phra Kaeo (Temple of the Emerald Buddha). Given the fact that this last temple is in fact no more than a temple inside the Grand Palace, these tour guides often mislead unaware tourists. In fact the third temple which should be included should be Wat Benchamabophit Dusitvanaram (marble temple).

Breathtaking. Stunning but make sure you dress appropriately. Otherwise, you can borrow a sarong there. Make sure you check that everything you want to see is open on the day you are visiting. We were there on a Sun. and many things were closed.

Stunning image of Buddha - must see. We did the combined ticket which includes the Royal PalaceWhen I travel to the Far East I do get a bit of Temple fatigue. However, I found the Emerald Buddha to be quite mesmerising. It is a truly beautiful work of art, give a prime place within the fabulous Royal Monastery. I have to say that I found myself going back in to see it and viewing it from outside several times before eventually moving on to tour the rest of the Monastery and the adjacent Royal Palace. The Emerald Buddha is worth going to see all on its own. However, the sites around the Royal Monastery are also very interesting. We were scheduled to head to Angkor after Bangkok and so enjpoyed the fantastic model of Angkor Wat. The building the Emerald Buddha is located within is beautiful designed and decorated and the entire area of the monastery is really impressive. Be sure to come appropriately dressed. You will be able to borrow clothing which is helpful and it is perfectly clean but not really ideal and time consuming.The Emerald Buddha is a must visit in Bangkok – probably the must visit.

small but powerful Buddha attracts millions. the argument has been "who owns the emerald Buddha, Laos or Thailand?" History aside, size aside, it is worth seeing as it is highly revered and you will observe hundreds paying homage.

Good experience, but too crowded. The temple itself is unquie, so is the Emerald Buddha. It is a place worth visiting, but I don't like fact there were just way too many tourists. For experiences, it is a place must visit when you are in Bangkok.
hard to find serenity with the crowds. if you want to appreciate this place go early...1000s of ppl visiting, in order to enjoy the peace the temple should offer, beat the crowds by going before 9.

Magnificent; must see. This is the must see in Bangkok. I bought entrance ticket that combined palace and this temple. I felt it was overpriced for palace but this temple make it all worth. Very vibrant architecture and sample of Thai theology mixed with Hindu's. It is worth spending a full day there understanding each image, symbol and its theological context and meaning. Dont just look at the good/bad looking image and take photo. Each of those images have name or reference in their "biblical" history; ask you guide about it. Highly recommanded.

The Emerald Buddha is beautiful but tiny!. You must visit The Temple of the Emerald Buddha if its your first trip to Bangkok. The Temple grounds are breathtaking - so pretty! The Emerald Buddha is very beautiful but he's tiny!!

Worth The Visit. Amazing. Like all religions the Emerald Buddha is a very sacred and special Icon to the Thai people. It is quite amazing to see and gives a very real feel for the importance of the Buddha.
Clothing. Make sure that you have long pants and short sleeves as you will not be able to get past the guards. Also make sure you go early as a number of the museums on site close doors around 3:15.

Disappointing. On the same site as the Grand Palace. Comparitively disappointing after the splendour of all the magnificent buildings of the palace.
You are unable to get anywhere near the small statue of the Buddha (it is roped off), so were unable to really see it well.
Honestly?. I was a tad underwhelmed. The Buddha itself is very small, although pretty. It seemed like many tourists congregated there for little reason.

Make sure you are appropriately dressed. This was our first Temple in Bangkok and we were blown away - there is so much to see and the sun glinting on the gold and glass is amazing. The Temple gets very crowded and you need to keep an eye on your belongings. The dress code is very strict and my husband had to get long trousers even though he had long 'shorts' on. Getting these takes quite a while as, with lots of things, in Thailand, there is a lot of queuing and form filling to do

Beautiful Wat within the Grand Palace. If you are in the Grand Palace, do come to this part of the attraction first when you enter the palace. This Wat gets very crowded so you might as well at this part over with it. Photography is prohibited and also the Buddha is placed far, high and out of reach from locals so it may be hard to really see the details the Buddha. However, there is a another museum within the palace that describes the different jewelries and clothing the Emerald Buddha is clothed when the season changes. The details of the Wat is beautifully decorated.
Worth seeing. Despite the huge crowds on December 31st, this was definitely a sight worth seeing, especially as part of the Grand Palace.

I picked a bad day to see the beauty.... New Year's Eve was very crowded with the pushing and shoving I'm used to on NYC subways -- not in a temple. This Buddha needed time to be admired, but that wasn't possible because of the crowds. Despite many, many signs -- some having to be waved by personnel from the alter -- clearly showing/reading NO PHOTOGRAPHS, the number of rude people blatantly disregarding the sanctity of the temple was disappointing. The temple and Buddha were beautiful. The crowd was not.
Really Crowded. Gorgeous, but you have to literally push through people to get in. The crowds take away from it. We went on a Sunday, it might be better on a different day?

the thing to do in Bangkok. There is not enought words to say how wonderfull is grand palace. I think it will be a shame to leave bangkok without doing it.Go early in the morning because it's a bit less busy and at 10h and 10h30 there is free english guide very interesting.
Not to be missed. A work of art....really beautiful...not to be missed!! Do be prepared to spend some time here. Do come with a guide!!

So very... green. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is on the Grand Palace grounds. It is located at the center of one of the temples and unlike the golden buddha which was majestically big, this one was rather small. Maybe it was just me, though, since you cannot really come up close (due to the number of people and the fact that it is located on an "altar"). No photos allowed and people, please respect that.
Fascinating. What an amazing place! I never wanted to leave. It has so many beautiful structures that I just want to keep looking and looking at all there is to see!

A little too well protected!. Very pretty but no photos allowed inside and enclosed in case up high.
Use telephoto lens from outside doors if photo needed.

On the Bangkok To-Do List. This is one of the top tourist sites, can be done with the Grand Palace. After a lot of Wats, they all start to seem the same, but this one, Wat Pho and Wat Arun are all unique enough that they should be visited.

Good, but worth seeing before The Reclining Buddah!. We saw the emerald buddah alongside The Grand Palace as it was included in the ticket. To be honest, I wasn't overly wowed by this as we had been to The Reclining Buddah (Wat Pho) first which is incredible, so this didn't really compare for me. Might be best to see this first and then go to Wat Pho after....

Gold, Gold & Jade. Loads to see, mostly gold inside and out.Allow for a couple of hours for a reasonable visit.Don't talk to the guides outside, go and check it out for yourself.Taxis in Bangkok are reasonable, agree price before getting in and don't take his friends boat because of a traffic jam.Make sure you cover up to visit the Buddha and wear clean socks please as shoes need to be removed!

Small Buddha but worth a look. This temple is one of the most beautiful and even though the Buddha is small, the temple is beautiful and well worth the visit to remove your shoes, and file through to see one of the most revered Buddhist statues in Bangkok.

Commercial exploitation. 500 baht to see a small statue on top of a multi-tiered throne. The temple complex is as dazzling as Wat Phro but it is difficult to see how the inflated admission charge can be justified
Beautiful. A must see when in Bangkok! Also, make sure to go to the small museum at the entrance to see the seasonal "outfits" that the King adorns the Buddha with.

Small Buddha but impressing WAT. Nice place to visit together with the Royal Palace. The WAT and the Palace are marvolous.You can spend several hours there and it is very cheap to hire one of the (unauthorized) local guides who you find standing everywhere - be sure to take one who can speak eg english in an understandable manner.

Not as impressive as i expected. I went here after the reclining buddha next door and i found it to be less impressive. the crowds were just as intense but the site wasn't. Go here first so you can be wowed by it.

Shiny!. Tons to see; the Grand Palace and the Emerald Buddha are in the same complex and are really beautiful with lots of gold and colors. Dress appropriately unless you want to wear the loaner pants (you don't.). Save your ticket for admission to Dusit Palace Park.

More calm, strict dress code for women. There are many beautiful Wat's in Bangkok, this one was much more calm than Wat Pho. Beware though ladies, they mean business with the covered arms and legs - NO Capri pants! It's worth the visit for this place, along with the Grand Palace in the same area.
temple to visit. if you visit bancok you must do the temple tour as thay r all fantastic.some r in prime locations some you think were not ,same as all the others take plenty of water and camera

Do it!. So beautiful! The whole area is so detailed, it amazing. I'd recommend going with a tour guide, helps getting in and is really nice having someone there educating about it all if you're not familiar with the area

Stunning temple. This is reputed to be one of the 6 great temples in Thailand and it lives up to its reputation. Best of all I liked the 46m long Reclining Buddah, but the Bot of the Emerald Buddah is fantastic.

The Thai Cistine chapel. This was a reverant and exquisite temple with the Emerald Buddha at its centre. Also a lovely cool respite if you kneel down and enjoy the cool quite of this place for a few moments
Motto: endless wealth and prosperity. This appeared to us as the most visited temple in Bangkok - and with a reason. It is really beautiful.
its grand. The temple is a part of the Grand Palace, the overall tour takes about 2-3 hours, make sure you start early. Being covered (no shorts, no sleeveless clothes etc) is a mandate.

The Holiest Thai Wat. I found this Temple and Buddha a very beautiful experience. The small green jade Buddha is high on a golden throne and is highly revered by all entering the temple. Both the inside and exterior of the temple are very impressive. If in Bangkok this is one site that everyone shoud visit.

Must watch!. Visit this place if you believe in God, or visit it if you don't for you shall end up believing, for the peace and serenity that one feels is definitely worth the visit, topped up with a cultural and mystic flavor of the religious history of Thailand and all the folklore that ancient monks have written about !

A view of Emerald Buddha. This is one of the main attraction in side Grand Palace. The statue of Buddha made by Green Emerald. and covered with Golden cloths. There is very peaceful atmosphere inside the temple.

Beautiful, but crowded. If you really need a lot of personal space, this is not the place to go. The Emerald Buddha, though, is a remarkable sight. Though not very large, it sits atop a massive structure of devotional objects. And the Grand Palace in which it is contained is breathtaking.
Extra luck!. A bird pooped on me while entering this temple - is this extra luck? Large complex and lovely temples.

Interesting visit. There are many things to see in Bangkok but I would put this on the "if I have time" list. Fascinating history to be observed and definitely worth a visit if part of tour or you have extra time.
Amazing!. Glittering and peaceful, if it weren't for the hundreds of mass tourists. But such beautiful palaces and grounds. Amazing Thailand!

Recommend the headset. It was extremely crowded, so I'd likely recommend going early and on a weekday if possible. Definitely a must-do when visiting Bangkok. I definitely recommend the headset, or perhaps a guide to gain a full appreciation of the architecture and history. The two-hours allotted for the headset rental was just adequate. I did notice that they ran out of headsets fairly early on...so another reason to start early.
Absolutely Beautiful!. A must for any visitor to Bangkok. Go early, because it can get hot and crowded. Keep in mind, that it does close at 3:00pm and you must wear long pants to enter.

Large buddha statue made of pure jade. Contrary to the common perception, the statue is made of green jade and not emerald as believed by many. The name is a misnomer and I got to know the truth when I visited the temple and read the information about the temple there.

Such a beautiful ,elegant,and impressive .. If I have time I will go to Temple of the Emerald Buddha ,becauseevery time when I go there I feel relax,and come down.Happy and feellike a I am in the heaven.I can do meditation and pray too.I am so proud that Thai people do a great thing for every body.

A must-see if you go to the palace. Fascinating place, although you might be overwhelmed by the colours, forms, sights and all the ... well bling. Can get crowded so make sure to visit shortly after opening times.The Emerald Buddha is a bit on the small side but still highly revered and carriers a special feeling across.
You can't go wrong!. Located in the Grand Palace, any Wat is worth seeing, this being no exception to the rule. Ensure a visit!
amazing place. this is an amazing place to go visit. We spent the day exploring china town and then went to visit. Lots of little temples and buildings - the intricate details leave you in awe....
Amazing. Well worthwhile going to. You learn a little more about Buddhism and can also get blessed by a monk.

Overwhelming. The temple and its grounds are overwhelmingly beautiful and a must see on your Bangkok visit. Make sure to enter the temple to see the gorgeous buddhas inside and the wall murals. Also definitely worth exploring are the wall murals along the whole inner courtyard wall.

Great Temple. The Budda is impressive and the crowd was very organised. It's in the mid of the Grand Palace and even though i'm not a Buddist myself yet, it's great to learn this religion from this temple.
Really loved the emerald work.. The emerald pillars, the amazing work of the temples was the star attraction. Went with my family and really loved our visit. Didn't enjoy the king's palace though.

beautiful. this was a very busy tourist attraction. But you can also see how much this means to the local Thai people. shoulders must be covered and shoes to be taken off, as is the custom. a guided tour will make sure you understand what the meanings are for each temple you visit.
Impressive complex. Amazing temple and palace complex. A must if you visit Bangkok, be ready to be amazed. It gets extremely crowded, so be sure to get there early.
Awesome. amazing temple- worth going to as part of a city/temple tour. Good to have a guide to give you the history of the place
Impressive. Hired a guide for £12. Money well spent as it saved us an hour getting tickets and we understood far more history than we'd have gleamed from any book.

Serene. I think I expected a larger Buddha after visiting the giants in Vietnam and Wat Pho. Our guide, Bank, from Tours with Tong gave a beautiful explanation and showed us the proper customs as we visited the temples and the palace.

don't miss it!. I think it is definitely worth it to come to this temple, if you are in Bangkok. the entire palace complex in which it is located is awe-inspiring. you have to take off your shoes to go in the temple - i recommend flip flops or anything easy to remove.
Breathtaking. The glow from this little Buddha was enchanting. It was surrounded by golden riches and the idea that its robes were changed every 3 months by the King is just brill!

Wat Phra Kaeo. Of course if in Bangkok this is a Yes.. amazing and did you know there are 3 seasons and 3 outfits for this buddha!! Steady on the photos it is so amazing I had a hard time keeping the focus!! awesome..
Interesting Shrine. This Buddha is made of jade. The temple has interesting artwork. You must wear long sleeves and pants.
Holistic. It is very calm inside the temple and I was awed by how majestic it can be inside such a small space. The caretaker can learn a little more about being courteous as well.

One unigue Temple and the Bhudda Image of the world. If you are going to Bangkok the most not to miss is this temple, this is the Siam heritage and for the world,The most beautiful emerald Bhudda Image placed here as one of the symbol of Thailand and Bangkok, charming and glorious with hard to explain, you have to visit yourselves. Also the surround are the other religious Buildings, and also the palaces.
Beautiful but touristy. Make sure you bring plenty of water and maybe a snack, there's not much around for parched tourists (of which there will be MANY) - make sure you go early - 9am-10am

A bit disappointing.. We had expected to see a big idol of Buddha made out of Emerald. But it is actually a Jade Buddha. It is situated in the same premises as the Grand Palace. The Grand Palace is actually very huge and saps a lot of energy.One warning - People are expected to wear full length clothes on the premises. Beach / Party wear clothes are not allowed and in that case visitors are made to wear shirts and / or full length wrap arounds.The fee for the Palace and temple is around 400 Bath (per person).

Serene... peaceful... sit and collect your thoughts.. Upon entering the temple I was overcome by a sense of peace and comfort... I sat there eyes wandering around the room where the walls were painted with stories of days gone by, and where people were meditating and praying to Buddha. I'm not the most religious of people, but it was such a different feel to the craziness that was just outside the doors, that it was hard not to wonder if there was something more at work than just our own minds. A wonderful peaceful place, remember to wear long pants and cover your shoulders.

Definitely Worth It!. Don't let anyone out front tell you it's closed. The architecture is so detailed! It's one of the best temples I visited on my trip. Also, you will have to wear full sleeves and pants. They will rent you the pants but you might as well buy your own long sleeved shirt for the rest of the trip.
very impressive & rich culture. Need to prepare your energy approximatly 4 - 5 hours walks, and never leave Bangkok with out visiting Grand Palace..

Great architecture. We visited Temple of Emerald Buddha, it was memmorial. Transferred by Tok Tok from our hotel, We had an aewsome experience to one of the most beautiful temple in this country. We are not buddhist however, we love things here.

Actually a Jade Buddha!. The emerald buddha is actually made of jade and is a very small statue. It's within a closed space and you can't go very close and get an exceptional view. Its worth seeing on a first time trip t Bangkok and doesn't take very long.
Another majestic buddha temple. Bangkok and its series of buddh temples reminded me of ujjain where every stone is a shiv ling. This is another beautiful, majestic temple that one must see!

might as well. Located inside the Grand Palace, the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is just one of the stops along the way. I have to admit that it looks a lot like the other temples we saw yesterday, but we did it. Wear appropriate clothes or you'll be forced to wait in a LONG line for your cover ups.

Serene!. Beauty of an unbelievable aspect
Buy the ticket with your palace ticket, be prepared to queue
Dress appropriated
Take water!!!!
Well worth seeing. Together with Grand Palace and Wat Poh this captures some the richness of Thai culture. All three can be done in one day if you are pressed for time.
Must see, but you need to cover up. A uniques and interesting experience. Due to religious sensitivity, they make you cover up. No shorts or tanktops. They give you cloth to cover yourself though.

Mesmorizing. It is a moving experience to see devoted Thai Buddhists quietly worship in this temple. The Emerald Buddha is dressed in one of 3 gold garments depending on the season. The whole temple inside and out is splendid with character. It's a must see for all who visit Bangkok and what's nice is that it is inside the Grand Palace where other temples can be visited! EM

more glitter. you probably already know it is best if you were shoes that are easy to take off and on, as all the shrines and temples require you to take off your shoes to enter. once inside the palace wall, the glitter is everywhere - enjoy.
the entrance fee you pay for the palace covers this temple.

Well worth a visit. Inside the grand palace, which is a wow experience. This small but beautiful Buddha sits on a high plinth in the temple. You must wear trousers and a shirt that covers your shoulders or they give you a robe. You remove your shoes / hat before you go in. Remember not to point your feet at the Buddha. You can't take photos inside but there is a spot out side where you can see it, also a good set of postcards is available very cheaply.

Emerald Budha. I like the temple itself because it's very amazing to look at it in person and very very grand although a bit dissapointed because not allowed to take pictures of the Emerald Budha. The annoying part was actually when we want to enter the Grand Palace & Wat Phra Kaeo, a person tried to scam us by saying the temple is closed because of Budha's Day and he claimed that he works as security in there and offered us to go to someplace else by tuk tuk. Luckily we already read many different kind of scenarios scams :) I hope the REAL security can clean up the gates of grand palace of such people

Crowded temple but definitely worth seeing. The whole area was very crowded and it was extremely hot when we visited. It might be better to visit this area in the afternoon. Dress appropriately (i.e., no shorts or tank tops).You are not allowed to take photographs inside the Temple of the Emerald Buddha.
Nice temple. Very interesting temple with beautiful design. A must visit temple with no regrets where you can see the Emerald Buddha.

Temple of the Emerald Buddha Experience. Costly - THB 400 per person for the whole grand palace experience is not very cheap. Not allowed to take photos inside this temple and advised to keep silent throughout.

better come after lunch time less tourist. slightly costly for the entrance fee but its great with the history and the views inside buy only one ticket which is combined to the grand palace as well, buy at the proper counter never fall into trap of any guide or person saying it is closed for something and has to pay costlier, I noticed these people tend to go for westerners, so if you are, be smart not to fall on their trap, dress properly, so you dont have to spend on buyin or renting saroong/pants. No sleeveless outfit, dress up till knee lenght or pants till ankle. No leggings
Pretty impressive!. Phenonomenal details on the bling and beauty of this important Grand Royal Palace destination. Place is mobbed.

Beautiful Temple. We visited the Temple of the Emerald Buddha on the last day of our holiday and it was fantastic, the incredible tiled exterior walls were stunning, they were an amazing work of art, the grounds surrounding the temple were full of visual delights and it was a joy just wandering around staring at everything.Inside the temple was incredible, there was an overwhelming sense of peace which was odd given the craziness outside, yet as soon as I walked in the door and sat down I felt comfortable and calm, I could honestly have sat for hours staring at the hand painted walls, they were amazingly detailed and told hundreds of stories.A fantastic temple to visit and an enjoyable day.

A place to spend a whole day. Full of nice temples and structures! Make sure you have enough space in your camera! We spent there 2 hours and that was not enough. The craftmanship on the temples are amazing!

Can't Miss a Visit to This Temple!. I live in Japan and have been to many temples in Japan, Cambodia and other countries, however, they are different by country and usually purpose. In this case, it was wonderful just exploring all of the grounds and various areas. Definitely don't miss the emerald (jade) Buddha, though he's much smaller than I expected. They change his clothes depending on the season which is kinda cool. Also, your ticket includes admission to a museum...fairly interesting, but most important it's air conditioned! Ticket also includes admission to a park/area several minutes drive from this temple; not sure why as it's a bit inconvenient and I'd rather just pay for this. Be sure to bring a sarong to cover your shoulders (if wearing sleeveless) or your legs (if wearing shorts or capri shorts/pants). Otherwise you can pay to rent one.

Worth a visit. I've been here twice now, once in the summer and now in the winter. It's much more crowded this time of year (December). An interesting fact is that they change the buddha's clothes for the different seasons. The outfits are on display near the entrance to the palace where you buy tickets. The temple is gorgeous.
Nice place. Nice place. In fact it is not an emerald Buddha, but a jade one. Photographies are prohibited. A must see in Bangkok. I do recommend it.

Great, but dont go in afternoon. The crowd is crazy heavy. Too many people, hot.. Go late afternoon, just before closing. Taxis wont take you back on taximeter. Just walk around the corner and search for honest taxi driver. You will find it..
Another great Temple. If you are a fan of Temples, you should do this one too, though you might think they are all the same, if you have a good guide you will be able to realize the difference.

Absolutely stunning!. This was the highlight of the Grand Palace complex. The Emerald Buddha sits on his throne in the middle of one of the most beautiful rooms with mother of pearl set walls and millions of tiny crystals adorning the steps towards the Buddha. He even has different 'outfits' for different seasons which can be seen in one of the museums on the Grand Palace site. Totally beautiful and breathtaking! Don't miss this!

wonderful. The Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha) is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple (wat) in Thailand. The main building of the temple houses the Magnificient Statue of the Emrald Buddha , carved from a singlr piece of Jade. The legendary history of this Buddha image is traced to India, five centuries after the Lord Buddha attained Nirvana, till it was finally enshrined in Bangkok The Emerald Buddha, a dark green statue, is in a standing form, about 26 inches tall, carved from a single jade stone (Emerald in Thai means deep green colour and not the specific stone). Except for the Thai King, no other person is allowed to touch the statue. The King changes the cloak around the statue three times a year, corresponding to the summer, winter, and rainy seasons, an important ritual performed to usher good fortune to the country during each season. It is located within the Grand Palace of Bangkok on Na Phra Lan Road. It can be reached by more than 20 bus routs (A/c and Non A/c) from all over Bangkok. It is open from 8.30am till 3.30pm. You must take out your shoes and wear long trousers/skirts; long sleeve shirts covering your shoulders. Appropriate dress is available at the entrance of the temple free of charge, with refundable deposit. Entry is included in the Ticket of 400 Baht for Grand Palace. Photo of The Emrald Buddha Idol can be taken only from outside of the temple.

Exquisite place. Absolutely beautiful, incredible painted walls, but be warned, make sure you are wearing long trousers and a long sleeve shirt or be prepared to pay. You will also pay quite a hefty entrance fee (about 300 baht) which the locals do not have to pay. This is because it covers the wear and tear caused by tourists. Locals pay tax which covers this and are generally coming for religious reasons. I know many foreigners were bothered by the 'farang fee' so there it is explained.

Its fine, visited with kids. We took our 4 and 8 year old with us to visit this. It was fine, but it was crowded and hot. Might have had a different experience if we had visited early morning but that wasn't possible with our schedule. I can't say I'd go out of my way to do this again.

Flamboyant Thai temple buildings. The #1 Must-See in Bangkok. You get a condensed view of various styles of Thai temple architecture in one convenient location. Take along some cold drinking water, as the sun is blazing. The Emerald Buddha itself is of more religious significance to the Thais than it is of interest to the traveler

Divine Place... As u go inside you feel the positivity of the place and dont feel like getting up. Can sit for hours together and u get peace of mind. A place where the locals believe and come to pay there respect and prayers.
Awesome!. Go early in the morning before it gets too hot. Bring lots of water. It was amazing! Also, wear comfortable shoes.
Amazing Temple. I love this temple, much better than any other in Bangkok. It is huge and majestic and the Emerald Buddha is just amazing.

Busy but beautiful. It pulsates with the influx of tourists but the grounds of the Grand Palace are worth it. The temple that houses the Emerald buddha is stunning. You will need to cover your shoulders and legs here, bring a sarong if wearing shorts, otherwise you will need to hire one. The rules are enforced here rather strictly. Comfortable shoes that are easy to slip on and off are also the order of the day. i also recommend bringing lots of water as its hot and you will get thirsty.

beautiful. We went to this temple as part of a tour with the Grand Palace. It was useful having our guide's commentary to really bring the temples alive with background information and history. For example explaining how the Emerald Buddha has different clothes depending upon the seasons. But even if you don't have a guide, there are loads of photo opportunities in front of the beautifully decorated temples, statues etc.and it is surely a must-visit site in Bangkok

I'd avoid it. I know this is a popular place to visit in Bangkok, but there are just so many people visiting it at any one point in time, it is not a great experience. Most amusing at this location is the security guards yelling at people to sit down and not take photos. They take their job very seriously.

Amazing Temple. Due to Dual Pricing I Will Never Return. Great and peaceful. Home of THE most revered image of Lord Buddha in Thailand. However, the Thai Government institutes a dual pricing system which charges admission for Thais and non-thais. And this isn't the only place that does it. I've seen the temple and will not return based on that principle alone. Not to mention the scumbag touts that hang around the entrance attempting to scam tourists by telling them the temple is closed.
Great ambience. Located next to the palace, this temple has important significance. Though small in relative terms but the statue of Buddha still comes across as impressive.

Beautiful place.. Visited this place as part of a 'Tour with Tong' day trip & is inside the Grand Palace complex & is included in the admission price. Our guide Nang's knowledge of the history & custom, brought the place to life.

Another great visit to the fantastic place.. I use to work in Bangkok many years ago as a tourleader, so I took the groups to Grand Palace many times. This time, I think it has become even more beatifull. Maybe it is because they repaint it due to H.M the King´s birthday.When you come to Grand Palace and has never been therebefrore. Make sure you get a good guide. There are many guides around the temple area, just make sure they have a licens. If you go alone, the go the places where the groups don't go. Spend some time, sit down and enjoy this fantastic area. See the painting on the wall. It is the Ramajana Story, and it is a very good artwork.The only thing i noticed was the the price has gone up to 400 baht. Well compare to many other things, it is not much. I remember, it used to be 150 baht, but that is also many years ago.

A must see !. FANTASTIC!!
All except their obsessive need to cover the women already welll covered, which at a scorging heat fells like a tourist genocide, more than meeting the local cultural standards
Tourist discrimination is also potentiated by a clear sign that locals enter for free,while tourists are charged a hefty $14

A little expensive for some, but great picture opps. You have to go see the palace/facilities, so dont sweat the price. Its a tiny buddha, so dont blink ... the temple and others buildings are amazing.

Emerald Buddha. I was kind of expecting something bigger, it's probably about 50cm high, although having read that it was discovered back in the 14th century it's pretty amazing really, worth seeing if you are visiting the palace
temples. interesting :-),if your into that kinda stuff and cultural heritage,never the less a must do when you are here.

No Pictures Inside this One!. The inside of this Temple is absolutely AMAZING! There is jade and gold everywhere and tiny mirrored mosaic walls. The colors and displays will astound you. It was disappointing not to be able to take pictures here because it was so incredibly beautiful. Another Temple you should NOT miss when visiting Bangkok.
nice. It was really nice but please remember to continue to drink plenty of fluids as its really hot and avoid the toilets as its disgusting!

Smaller than I expected. It was a little like seeing the Mona Lisa for the first time....it was way smaller than I thought it would be. It's interesting in that they change the buddha's garments a few times a year (and I believe that's done by some members of the royal family in conjunction with monks)....but he's smaller than expected and also sitting way above human height - so not so easy to see!

Crowded!. Out of all the temples, this one was so over crowded, it was actually un-enjoyable. We went the day after President Obama visited (so they closed the Palace down for him), so I think there were 2 days worth of tourists in the Palace that day, it was just so overwhelmingly crowded. The Emerald Buddha is tiny, so it was just missing the WOW factor, but since its in the Palace ground, it should be visited...just hopefully with less crowds! :)
Grand.. Despite being really grand, it is also peaceful. I was amazed with patience it must have taken to decorate this temple. Colorful and alive.

nice. The Wat Phra is a nice visit but bagpack travellers will prefer avoid this visit (400BHT!!!!! and so mluch crowed it's awfuk)On the tourism leaflet you can find in teh entrance you see on the map ALL the different stuffs to see inside the Great Palace. It's just a joke as only 4/5 things can be seen instead of the 15/20 spots pointed: everything is closed......So I think it is a very nice place but absolutely too much expensive. And I don't like to be tolkds or driven by military guardians when I visit things !This visit is nice of groups, standards tourist enjoying to be told where to look and walk.... but not for individuals who like to decide where to go and where to look !!!Better to do the Wat Po, close to this place, more quiet & not expensive (100BHT)

Lovely place. This is one of those places that everyone goes to and with good reason. Unfortunately you can't take photos once inside the temple of the Emerald Buddha however there is a gap outside from which you can although you may well need a camera with a suitable zoom. Barefoot is a condition of entry and shoes are left safely just outside the temple.

Pretty Cool!. The Emerald Buddha is very cool and the temple itself is gorgeous. The Buddha was much smaller than we expected so it wasn't quite as spectacular as we had imagined but still worth checking out - it's in the same area as the Grand Palace so you can see them both at the same time.

Very beautiful. I visited this 25 years ago, and was very pleased to see that little had changed in this time, except it was MUCH more crowded, but we did go on the weekend. I took my partner and my brother, who had both never been, and they loved it. The whole temple grounds were wonderful, and some parts are being restored, so i'm sure it will maintain it's beauty. Oh, and do visit the little Thai markets around the temple grounds, they are pretty amazing, and a great way to see the "true" Thai way of life....

Over the top but worth it. You will see so much gold leaf it's astonishing! The mini Angkor Wat structure is fun and the buildings are overwhelming. The Emerald Buddha is small but worth seeing...the garb changes with the season so check it out....
The Emeral Buddha is special as all Buddha;s are.. It is worth seeing. But no pics inside. The Temples are impressive as always. Its a good place to be when the rain kicks in.
Beautiful. This is aprt of the Palace visit....very ncie and beautiful...the tenple is worth seeing...photography is not allowed inside...

Nice place. A good place to visit, especially if you are fond of temples. Beware you need to wear proper clothes when you have to visit otherwise you end up paying an extra 100 Bhat to vendors as rent for a wrap around or shirt. Try and visit as early as possible, since it gets very hot and difficult to walk around the temple.Also if you a normal tourist who is going along with packages it would cost you around 1100 Bhat per person, but if you could be a little smart, try and hire a taxi on meter rate basis (only on meter rates, it costed me 100 Bhat one side for 2 people) go their but tickets worth 400 Bhat per person, see the temple and come back and it would not cost you more then 1000 Bhat for 2 people.
Excellent temple. Very busy as one of the most visited sites in Bangkok, but great Temple to visit. Emerald Buddha is one of the most important famous artifacts in the SE Asia area.

Enjoy Thai Architecture. Temple which provides a good view of Thai architecture / style. Went to the museum and good a good perpsective of the temple, its significance in Thailand and the effort put into restoring and maintaining it. Worthwhile to see if you have time and want to get a glimpse of Thai design/architecture.
Crowded but beautiful. So great to see, but hard to get a good picture of. Definitely check this out when you are at the Grand Palace

Less impressive than its name. Located within Grand Palace. Intricate fittings and furnishing, but a little let-down as statue was a little small. Tourists were told to sit down, hence we expected something to happen soon eg prayers, but nothing did. Quite a let-down.
Wonderful. The emerald buddha is something to see - he had his winter jacket on when we visited - made of the finest gold - really something to behold

Amazing to see so much gold in one place. As with all temples in Bangkok, you have to remove your shoes before entering. Also worth noting that there is a strict dress code for all temples (no off the shoulder clothing or skin tight for women, no shorts). This temple is very lavish in it's design and it's interesting to see that the buddah is dressed in differnt robes, depensing on the season. Well worth a visit

Must see!. Been to Bangkok a few times during my travels, however never get bored to see the emerald Buddha! The entire area is very interesting and make sure you either have a private tour guide rather then being part of a tour group as you definately get more to see and experience.
Beautiful but overated. I like the Emerald Buddha but it's crazy touristy, expensive and a bit of a let down after Wat Po. If I had to chose I'd pick Wat Po everytime.
exellent. can u imagine 5500kg gold just in front of u.that is emerald buddha that many wont get chance to watch this much gold in one streatch.pay taxi 100 batt.u can easily reach there
Visual sensation. What a place. So hard to know where to start of what to look at. Numerous small & large structures all stunningly decorated within a small area next to the Grand Palace.

Okay.. Very gold. Not a bad place to spend your day. But it is very crowded, and I recommend hiring a trip guide when you get there, so that you can learn more history, instead of just walking aimlessly and seeing.

Buddha is dressed by Seasons in Gold designs. We went to the museum first to appreciate even more the details of the actual room and meanings of temple. Bring a fan to deal with the humidity and heat!
A must. Even though you cannot take pictures inside the temple, its a great life altering experience. Take a tour bus and they will take you to a few of these locations in a day tour.

Amazing!. Whoa!
Amazing temple/s.
Amazing history.
Amazing Bangkok!
What else can I say with this amazing country that rich in history and culture!
Amazing. Amazing, worth the walk in the blazing sun.The Emerald Buddha was a sight although we could not get a close view.

Too Many People!. Well, the temple is good but it was so, so many people there that it lose the beauty of the place.
I went to a lot of temples in thailand and they allways let me in with shorts till the knee, here you have to go with long pantaloons.
Amazing place. Historical place, a must to visit while in Bangkok. Arrange some time to reach there unless you are in Bangkok for nightlife.
BUDDISTS FROM THE WORLD COME HERE!. If Buddists from everywhere in the world come to see the emerald Buddah before they die, you should too. He's really made of jade, but that's OK.

Impressive but hectic temple. This small statue is extremely revered and obviously had a great meaning for a lot of the visitors. There was much bowing and weeping going on which was kind of cool as it obviously means a lot to the people.I don't really go for all that stuff though and while it was impressive and a very beautiful temple, it was so busy there that I wouldn't bother going again. I don't know if there is ever a quiet time but if so that would be the time to go. It was a zoo in there.This is true for the Grand Palace in general, it is obviously a massive tourist draw card. Definitely worth seeing but beware the crowds.

Nice and sentimental. It is important place for the locals and from that perspective it is a must when in Bakgok. However it does not much differ from other temples. Yes, the statue of Buddha is really tiny, especially if compared with the Golden or Reclinning Ones

it worth the visit plus it is in a marvellous sourrounding!. this is another temple it is better if you go early in the morning. Do not worry about the clothing, because they lend you whatever you may need to get inside. Go prepared to walk and take a lot of pictures to the palace and amazing places in this huge place!

pristine. if you visit the temple of Emerald Buddha in Grand Palace, Bangkok, you will instantly understand that this is the most revered thai temple. everything about the place is so pure and lovely.. the beautiful buddha statue was smaller than I had imagined .. what is nteresting to know is the fact that depending on the season, the buddha wears a different attire (i saw the rainy season attire) and that the king of Thailand changes these attires 3 times every year - summer, rainy and winter.. photography is prohibited inside the temple, so i took a few pics from outside the entrance and I did get a few nice clicks.. do visit this on your trip to bangkok. totally worth it, and highly recommended!

The Revered One. From a block of Jade a spectacle of Buddha's image was born. The temple , though looked crowded-in within the Grand Palace grounds, is fitting to hold the most revered image of Buddha. The thousand garuda's lining the walls of the temple is just beautiful ! I liked the serene atmosphere inside the temple, a must see place in Bangkok !

WOW!!!. You cannot fail to be impressed by this building. Stunning from the outside, and just unbelievable inside. You go from madness to serenity and calm. No photo's, but you need to just look!! The ceiling is amazing, as are all the images. A beautiful place.

Magnificient inside and out.. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is linked to the Grand Palace and when most people say we must visit the Grand Palace this is what they have in mind. First getting there can be a nightmare if you go by road. Most taxi drivers do not speak English therefore get your hotel reception to write down where you want to go in Thai and show it to the taxi driver. Secondly the traffic in Bangkok is a nightmare any time of the day so be prepared to wait. The easiest way and the nicest is to take the Skytrain to Saphan Taksin stop, keep to the right when you get off and head towards the ferry terminal underneath the bridge. Here the local ferry taxi will take you along the river to the nearest stop by the Wat and Grand Palace. You may be asked to take a private ferry taxi and if you do bargain for the price. They always ask high but do not accept the first price they offer. The ferry takes you along the river and past the expensive hotels for about a 15 minute ride. When you get off you will see in front of you a white washed wall which is the perimeter fencing of the complex.Keep to the left to walk around the wall as this will take you on the shortest route to the entrance. Do not listen to anyone who tries to tell you that the complex is closed for lunch. This is just a scam to try and get you to waste your time and money in a restaurant across the road. The complex is open until 3.30pm every day. There is a dress code that is rigorously enforced (no shorts or bare shoulders). However inside the entrance you can hire (200 Baht deposit which you get back) long trousers which are clean and not ridiculous. Buy water before going in as you will be walking around in the hot sun. Photographers paradise as the buildings are very opulent. You cannot take photographs inside the Wat itself which holds the Emerald Buddha. A fascinating place to visit and of great attraction to locals as well as tourists.

part of grand palace complex - must do!. The temple complex is made up of many other buildings, murals, statues, mosaics.No photos allowed inside the actual temple but you may go in and view the Emerald Buddhaand take photos from outside.

ไหว้พระเพื่อความเป็นศิริมงคล. The Wat Phra Kaew (Thai: วัดพระแก้ว, RTGS: Wat Phra Kaeo, Pronunciation, English: Temple of the Emerald Buddha; full official name Wat Phra Si Rattana Satsadaram, Thai: วัดพระศรีรัตนศาสดาราม, IPA: [w?t p?r?? s?? r?t.ta.n?? s??t.sa.da?.ra?m]) is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple (wat) in Thailand. It is a "potent religio-political symbol and the palladium of Thai society". It is located in the historic centre of Bangkok (district Phra Nakhon), within the precincts of the Grand Palace.The main building is the central ubosoth, which houses the statue of Emerald Buddha. The legendary history of this Buddha image is traced to India, five centuries after the Lord Buddha attained Nirvana, till it was finally enshrined in Bangkok at the Wat Phra Kaew temple in 1782 during Rama I's reign (1782?1809). This marked the beginning and raise of the Chakri Dynasty of the present Kingdom of Thailand (the present head of the dynasty is King Rama IX. The Emerald Buddha, a dark green statue, is in a standing form, about 66 centimetres (26 in) tall, carved from a single jade stone (Emerald in Thai means deep green colour and not the specific stone). It is carved in the meditating posture in the style of the Lanna school of the northern Thailand. Except for the Thai King, no other person is allowed to touch the statue. The King changes the cloak around the statue three times a year, corresponding to the summer, winter, and rainy seasons, an important ritual performed to usher good fortune to the country during each season.While legend traces this statue to India, its rich historical records dates its finding in Cambodia in the 15th century, moved to Laos in the 16th century and then to Vientiane where it remained for 215 years, and finally to Thailand in the 18th century. Considering the long history and Nagasena's (a Brahmin who became a Buddhist sage and lived about 150 BC) prophesy that the Emerald Buddha would bring "prosperity and pre-eminence to each country in which it resides", the Emerald Buddha deified in the Wat Phra Kaew is deeply revered and venerated in Thailand as the protector of the country.
A sight to behold. This is a beautiful place one has to see when they are in Bangkok. Its very very beauitful and mystique.
Very beautiful. We really liked this experience. You walk from the hussle and bussle of tourism madness in the grounds of the palace into a surreal quietness. Most amazing structure and decoration.

Jade Buddha. You will find the Emerald Buddha on the grounds of the Grand Palace. No pictures inside but a good picture can be taken from out front through the doors...once inside take the time to sit down and absorb your surroundings. I have been to many "holly" sights but no place other did I feel so calm and connected to my inner self.
Worth a visit. Try to arrange for a private tour instead of big groups. It makes it just so much more worth the visit to explore these gems on your own time and at your own pace.

Stunning. No other way to describe other than stunning. Worth the price of admission and the rush of the crowds. Huge amounts of tourists there when we went on a Sunday. We are moving to Bangkok and will bring all guests here
Stunning. Do this after Wat Pho, it is the icing on the cake, very impressive and large grounds combined with the Grand Palace, a highlight of the trip
The one by excellence. He is the symbol as well the heart of Thailand in matter of Buddhism. A must to see. Cannot miss it at all...
Little guy. The story is quite interesting and this Buddha is worth seeing. I wasn't prepared for how small it is. But, you should include this on your tour of the area.

If you could only see one thing in town, this is it!. Wat Phra Kaew is the Vatican, the Blue Mosque and the Taj Mahal of Theravada Buddhism. Oversized, overwhelming, tesselated structures require you to adopt a new physical perspective: grand, with attention to detail. It is the most challenging tourist attraction in the world - densely packed with eye candy, crowded, big, historical, hodge-podge layout and always hot! Spend at least two hours and be respectful. I've been back many times, and never see it all. Humbling, inspiring, awesome in the best way...maybe even life-changing.

Impressive but very busy. Very large set of temples which are very ornate - Emerald Buddha itself is a little disapponting and whole site is very busy. Also watch out for scammers outsdie saying site is closed til later so they can take you to various shops (this in itself isnt a bad experience to be fair and can get some really good stuff)

No 1 attraction of Bangkok. Verry busy, over 10000 visitors per day. Even when you visit the temple as early in the morning it is crowded. But the devotion entering the temple is impressing. Take care of proper clothing when you visit the temple, and don't complain as the same is obliged visiting churches or mosks. Don't believe when people tell you the temple is closed. This is only on very few moments on buddhist religious days when the king brings a visit to the temple. After looking around by ourselves we took the free guide. We can really recommend this.

Well....not really impressed by the Buddha, but lovely Wat though. The Temple complex is a masterpeice itself and it well deserves its attention and praise. The hype for the Emerald Buddha is way bigger than the impact that the statue has to the "foreign tourist or begger". It is still considered the Holiest of the Buddha images by most of the Thai people and that fact has some historical backgrounds. The temple is part of the Grand Palace buiding complex, so it is a great Aperture to the Thai art, religion and buddhist athmosphere in general.

Very interesting, but very crowded. as I said in the review for Wat Pho beware the traders on the other side of the street that will tell you that Wat Pho and Wat Phra Kaeo are closed (we were told it was for Budda's birthday) and to spend time there or that they would arrange transport to another Wat so you can wait for them to reopen. When we pointed out that the other Wat's should be closed too if it was the Budda's birthday they immediately changed tack and tried to get us to meet their friends for a guided tour of the very Wats that were meant to be closed.leaving that aside, the wat itself is very intesting and the fact that the jade Budda's raiment changes with the season, changed by the king himself was an interesting touch. The grounds are beautiful... remember to take of shoes to enter the wat. And there is access to enter the palace grounds.The downside is the crowds are massive
Awesome. That is definitely the most amazing temple I've ever seen. We visited it on Tuesday and the were not so many people and we were able to see all details without any problem.

Highpoint of the city tour. Golden temples soaring to the sky, monks in orange milling with jeans and visors, busses and cabs dropping off crowds, and praying pilgrims amid gawking tourists from every land. The paintings, sculptures, plants, and history offer a view of a rich past. It's a vibrant living museum of a culture deeply steeped in religion and royalty. Everything was in wonderful condition. Walk a lot and be ready to take off shoes. The place dazzles.

Awesome. If you have never done any temple visits this place is awesomeSo many traditional paintings telling stories of war and other historical eventsLoads of statues and then the emerald budda itself is beautifulThe only downside of this place is it's SUPER hot but it's Thailand so what can you expect!

A beautiful temple. If its your first time In Bangkok then go check out the emerald buddah which also lies within the grounds of the royal palace. The art work around the temples is amazing and could take up to half an hour following the wall. Temple is decorated well. Note photography is not allowed and alot of tourists still seemed to take photos freely.
Amazing site but overcrowded & poor signage. Stunning temple but incredibly overcrowded, with very poor maps & directions, too many staff but very little help.
Lovely to see. The statue of the emerald Buddhais lovely to see and the temple it is hosed in is stunning. A little disappointing that you couldn't take photos inside.

The ongoing story is as amazing as the statue. I'm pretty sure this is part of the Grand Palace. So a must see if you are in the Palace. Check out my notes on the grand palace. Get a guide, no shorts or skirts. Wear sunscreen.

the most important temple in thailand !. the place where you make a wish and your wish will come true in one day.... you might not believe but i do because it happened to me twice after i made a wish with this temple ! anyway if you wish for being millionaire, then maybe your next life.
Too many tourists!. Entrance tickets were doubled since 2 years back, crowd was crazy! If you can find a place to sit and pray, you are lucky!
Worth the time. Extremely good... Try to catch the English guided tours at 10 am or 10.30 am. Makes a lot of difference to listen to the guide and so the whole experience can be enjoyed.
Beautiful Temple. A very beautiful place to visit, lots of people visiting and worshipping. Lots of fine detail to finishing in all these Temples, was very surprising.
Must see. Inside the Grand palace. Entry is free with grand palace ticket which is about 400Bhat. Emerald Buddha statue is really amazing.
Must see!. Must see this temple, adjacent to Grand Palace. 400THB for entry to both. Spectacular buildings, beautiful, ornate and opulent.
Yes see it!. You must go to see the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. It was quite beautiful and amazing. Plus you have to take a picture with the Monk who is sitting next to a Buddha!
Beautiful Wat Phra Kaeo. I enjoy greatly to admire this amaIng structure, composed of many buildings, nicely decorated, which represents more than 200 years of Thai royal history.

Stunning. It's about £8 to get in to see this and the palace, a musuem and other temples/monuments. Although nearly over the top in quite a few places, the size, intricacy and colour is very impressive. If you just want one afternoon of temple sight-seeing then this is the place to go.
very crowded. the complex is very big and grand must visit for tourists, buildings have intricate designs and the statue of Buddha is made of a single Jed stone.
A must go!. Emerald Buddha is worth a visit! Very beautiful. But this place is overly crowded and admission fee is required.

A Very Worthwhile Experience. There is just so much packed into a very small area. All worth seeing. It is amazing to see how these buildings were conceived and constructed. From one being built out of broken Chinese cups and saucers to buildings made from very fine mosaics. The actual "Temple of the Emerald Buddha" (which we were told is actually Jade) is a must see. A very peaceful place (if you can shut all the tourists out) to contemplate and ponder your thoughts. Guys remember to wear LONG Trousers - ladies too or you will be refused admission by the trouser police. There is the option of hiring Pantaloons at the main entrance gate - not expensive but I ended up wearing bright orange and black ones - it didn`t bother me but it may not please others.I would give this tour a 10/10. Really enabled me to soak up the Thai culture - Very Kool.EnjoyC :-))
Amazing. Very popular with all walks of life. The Buddha is a fantastic site. They put a cardigan on him in the winter so that he does not get cold!
Another must do in Bangkok. This temple and the Royal Palace you have to see in bangkok! In Highseason can be quite busy there and can get really hot there if its not a cloudy day!

The disneyland atmosphere around the wat detracts.... The wat itself is impressive, although its surprising to see how small the jade statue is from a distance. However, the surround palace environment is a disappointment, and is mobbed with tourists...giving an overall unpleasant disneyland atmosphere. If you have time for only one wat, this should not be your priority.

WOW. This site is huge, the temple itself, smaller shrines and the official state buildings and museums. It is a little more expensive than other sites but there is a lot to see. Dress code is enforced here, no tight trousers/leggings/shorts/sleevless tops/seethrough material. The don't are clearly displayed at the gate and items can be rented from the building just inside the main gate for a 200 baht refundable deposit. Take water to drink as it does get very warm, refreshments are available and a gift shop is next to the ticket office.

Ver interesting.. Was a nice temple, but we were a little disappointed we could not take photographs in the Wat.The place was packed on the day we were there, but it was ok as we had planned the whole day to see the Grand Palace and the Wats in the area.The presence of armed guards was unnerving, as we dont often see that in Australia, but it was also a little reassuring I guess!Definitly a must see in conjunction with the Grand Palace.
Nice Quiet Temple. There are no pictures aloud in this temple. Dress properly. Don't forget that you shouldn't point your feet at the Buddha. It is definitely a must see.

Dont Miss It. The Emerald Buddha is small and perched on top of a stupa like pillar...it may be small but its emerald, dont forget. And it was kept hidden by a monk in another monastery, covered in mud to look unappealing and out of reach of the warriors who invaded Bangkok in another century.

My favourite temple when in Bangkok. Cannot really describe why, but since I have been at the Emerald Buddha in 1984 I love this place, it is so peaceful inside - tranquility around you, you might easily get into a state of meditation. Definitely relaxing your mind and forget for awhile the outside stress.This Emerald Buddha will always remain my favourite.

Grand local temple. Located within Chao phraya river walking distance, is a local temple that you do not want to miss. Intrigue by its huge size, golden Buddha statute and variety of temple buildings open for visitors to pray and take pictures. Architecture, colors and the building structure makes this place look special, take a slow walk and the temples building and Buddha statute that it offer to you, don't rush things here or you will miss a lot of in this temple. Traveler, do remember that you need to wear "decently" to cover your legs and shoulder especially for ladies who like to wear short pant or skirt, as this temple is a spiritual place for the local, do show your respect and things will be fine for you. To get to this temple, take the Chao Phraya river boat and stop at Maharaj pier. Take a few minute walk and then you will reach the temple in a short period of time, if you do get lose ask the local who man shops or stalls nearby the temple and they are more than willing to help you.

Absolutely stunning Grand Palace. I just loved the Grand Palace. We opted to get the head phones and do our own walking tour so we could do it at our own pace and I really enjoyed this. This allowed us to go back, if we wanted, and look at things again and hear the commentary (which was quite good) a second or third time if needed/wanted.The buildings are just fantastic. The architecture, the colours, everything about the place makes it very special and unique. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha was really lovely. The mother-of-pearl inlay is so intricate and thinking back to how old it was and how it must of been made and put together is just amazing. But all of the buildings are amazing.Allow yourself plenty of time to do this tour. It isn't something you can whizz through in 1-2 hours and really appreciate. We were there for nearly 3 hours and rushed the final buildings because it was coming up to closing time.Remember that you must have your shoulders and legs covered if you go here. Men cannot wear shorts - they need long pants. Similarly women need to cover up as well. There are places close by where you can hire or purchase appropriate clothing if needed.
Beautiful!. Amazing...and crowded.This temple is inside the Grande Palace complex.It's worth the visit and you must get inside to see the Emerald Budha.
Don't carry your camera inside. Nothing unusual, one time visit. Temple is big and is present inside the palace. There's a TBH 400 entry fee for The Grand Palace.
Good But too crowded. The template is good and unique situated in Golden palace. this is not to e missed place in Bangkok but its too crowded in mornings visit at later than 10 is good.

The one place you must visit in Bangkok. If you are visiting Thailand for the first time and are in Bangkok, this is probably the best place to get your fill of Thai temples :) It's almost overwhelming--there's something to see in every direction you turn. I find it also amazing that it is still very much a place of active worship. Don't forget to dress appropriately and not point your feet at the buddha or monks.

Worth seeing. One of the temples on the Grand Palace complex, the Emerald Buddha is in Wat Phra Kaeo. the Emerald Buddha is much smaller than I expected but it's definitely worth seeing. My only disappointment was the inability to take photographs inside the temple. You still see tourists doing it but there are signs everywhere asking you not too as a sign of respect.

Green and Gorgeous. This is one of the most unusual Buddha's that you will see in Thailand. It is green while the great majority are in gold. This Buddha is a big tourist draw as well. Remember to wear long pants and ladies need a long skirt and no short sleeves to enter the temple and do not forget to take off you shoes.

Gorgeous. The grandeur and the opulence of the 3.5 ton giant golden buddha floors you...the compound, though situated in the middle of city, is neat and clean...the traditional Thai umbrellas are a must try for shopping
Beware of scammers. Like : the architecture the templeDislike : The friendly (thai) people who always guide you somewhere else..
very tiny. As others have written before, the Emerald Buddha is very small, especially sitting up so high on such a large pedestal. But still, go see it.

Serenity!!!. Very peaceful. We never get bored of going to this place..there is also a palace inside.....interesting history and architecture. It is a free of charge for Thai only. They have tourguides that can show you aroud as well..

A must see!. Quite frankly you cant visit Thailand without seeing the Emerald Buddha. Wat Phra Kaeo is a remarkable place to visit and I would consider the key points to a vacation in Thailand. Put it on the top of your list of things to see while you visit.

Outstanding !. Don't forget to check the rules on what you can / can't wear. I thought I had dressed appropriately but the Fashion Police thought I was showing bare shoulders so I had to wear a very nasty (hot and sweaty) nylon blouse over the top. Horrible! But just loved this temple - absolutely fabulous.
Fantastic. It is one of the Grand Palace wonders. Not a greate view to the Statue itself as it is not huge, only 60cm, but inside you will find excellent artwork and craftsmanship.

Amazing architecture. Beautiful and well maintained, worth a visit and to listen to the history, colors given etc. Toilets smell from distance is the only set back. Have always have good impression of toilets in shopping areas in Bangkok but rather disappointed with the amount of tourists visiting the facilities is bad.

Heavenly scale. The complexity, beauty and scale of Wat Phra Kaeo must take your breath away. This is fantasy fiction meeting reality. Don't miss out the Emerald Buddha's other two outfits on display in the museum

Beautiful. the temples in Bangkok are a suprise as they display alot of wealth and craftsmanship are very well maintained, there are many tourists so it pays to go early (also to avoid heat) and avoid weekends if you can.
Emerald Buddha. A major attraction that shouldn't be missed when you visit Bangkok. But expect crowds, and bring your camera.

Small but a Must See!. For Buddhists, this is a must see experience. Before entering, you must remove your shoes and leave then outside the entrance. The Jade Buddha itself is very small but the altar upon which it is presented is impressive and ornate. Visitors may sit in front of the altar that has many floral offerings in front of the altar.. Photos are not allowed inside, but you can take photos from the entrance with a power zoom (20X or more). It can be very crowded. Be sure to explore exterior grounds.
Emerald Buddha. Nice but I wasn't wowed. It was smaller than I would have thought. Morning might have been a better time. We went mid afternoon and it was really hot.

Wow...what an incredible Buddha !! A must See!!. You can do this trip quickly as the Emerald Buddha is a small temple and it can be viewed in about 30 minutes. The location is right on the river banks of the Chayo Phraya river and you may combine it with a river tour.
A Must!. Touristy and may get a lot a scams outside the area. Do not believe Thais saying that it is closed. Go inside the building and ask the main office.

Crowds!. We visited this whilst seeing the Grand Palace. Pretty impressive temple-but most of them are. Go mid-week if you can- weekends are a battle with lots of tourists taking photos of lots of tourists!

Put your shoes in your bag. The temple was beautiful! unfortunately, there are no photos inside the temple, and you are required to take off your shoes. Unfortunately one of our group came back to find her shoes missing. My suggestion is that you put your shoes in your bag, and carry them with you. Otherwise it was an amazing experience, once you got past the extreme overcrowding.
Must see. My definition of sensory overload, lost to see, a few things lack the authenticity of a real craft or hand work, but it compensate it with lots of sparkles.
impressive temple, must visit. the place is amazingly nice, is impressive the buddha, dont forget to do an offering for buddha, is beyond words can describe, the richness of the decor is amazin

Breathtaking. What an amazing example of Thai opulence. The temple and Buddha are beautiful, gold everywhere, vibrant colours at every turn. Always busy so be prepared for crowds. We were fortunate to see the change of the guard which was very interesting. Definitely one to put on your must see list.
Fantastic architecture. An amazing sight. A bit pricy, but a wealth of really great architecture. Connected to the Royal Palace, entry fee gets you access to both. Definitely worth your time.
Amazing site. Well laid out - very affordable and simply superb location. The staff was very friendly and just a wonderful place for kids and adults.
Beautiful. very spiritual and moving temple - a must see, take shoes, hats off, must be respectful at all times
Great place..!. this is a temple of peace and the name of color’s, very beautiful place, I really love this place, and the statue of Buddha is great, Royal, I’m speechless, really great place.

Solid grounds to visit. This temple complex is part of the Grand Palace and it all is a site to see. I have been here a couple of times in the past and I was a bit surprised to see that they had raised the price to 400baht. Not alot of money, but it used to be around 200, so doubling it seemed a bit much. I have always been happy to pay as a foreigner, because the Thai people don't have to pay, but I don't know that I would do it again. I personally feel like Wat Po is just as nice and not as expensive. The grounds here are much bigger and the history is rich. A must to do first thing in the morning or you will be crushed by tour buses. We actually were there un knowingly during Thai holiday, so it is not fair to say, but there was literally 1000's of people fighting there way around the place. When you finally get to the emerald buddha it is a bit of a letdown after the Reclining Buddha image. I only mean to say this as a constructive view point. It is a fantastic image and the pure jade statue twinkles, however is is less than a meter tall and it is placed like 10 meters up on the alter, so by the time you view it, it is just a little buddha high up in the wat. Now to be fair, it is surrounded by several golden guilded buddhas and the imagery from that standpoint is a bit more impressive.
