Its probably a must see for a first timer to Thailand/BGK, but go early is my thought or just blow it off and check out the other 1000 Wat's instead.

Amazing sights...but beware of crowds. Beautiful architecture and amazingly decorated temples and buildings will make this a special stop on your Bangkok tour. Also be sure to check out the mini model of Angkor Wat behind the temple. Can get busy, go early.

nice. this is a temple in the grand palace complex which has got a great colourful architecture that will really catch your eyes but beware that sometimes it is closed for tourist visits if they have got praying ceremonies.

Amazing. We had a guide with us to show us around and so we discovered a lot that we would not have known otherwise. To go inside this temple you have to take off your shoes and leave them outside. You are not allowed to take photos once you are inside, but you can take photos from the outside, looking through the large open windows. Inside the temple is adorned beautifully and well worth just standing there and taking it all in, so take as long as you need, there is so much to see. The emerald buddha is made of jade and is quite small but a great sight to see. The temple is a place of worship and be mindful of the strict dress code. There was a long lines to rent clothes at the front entrance.
Must-visit on your cultural trip. A must-visit if you are keen on admiring Bangkok's cultural side. Explore the history and stories behind Bangkok with all these different temples and statues.
interesting. I did not know I was in the emerald buddha temple until I saw it up very high. it is very small, and the place was packed with people.

Awe inspiring. Unbelievable, definitely worth a visit and make sure you have a good look around the whole complex. Don't be put off by the guys at the gate telling you it's "closed" for some reason, they just want to get you onto one of their tours. GO IN.

Good place. The tiny statue is not made of emerald, but of jade. It's very small and cannot be seen from a distance. But you will like the peace, quiet and holiness of the place. No photography allowed.

Wow awesome place, real gold building!!. I felt in love this place from the first time i had been. Thai art building so completely neatly
Ps. entry reminder : wearing long plats to get in there cause they do not allow to enter. Otherwise you must take off your short ( to rent a plats ) at the entrance:P.

Taxi do not like to go cause of traffic. Been to the Royal Palace which has the Temple of the Emerald BuddhaYou pay over 200 baht to get in but that includes going into one of the museums.The is lots to see ;).The taxi do not like to go because of the traffic in Bangkok's Chinatown which is always congested until very late in the evening.
great temple; be wary of scammers!. the grounds and temple are great! but like you read in the travel books, the scammers are everywhere! be aware.

A Tip for Women and Girls. At most temples and churches throughout the world there is a dress code. Thailand is the same. I live in Bangkok and have been to the Wat Phra Kaeo countless times. Like most reviewers I think its a beautiful must-see temple in Bangkok.But, on my most recent trip with my young nieces I made a dicovery about its dress code and what it can cost: Its not sufficient for a woman or girl to be in a skirt/dress (length is not an issue) and with her arms and shoulders completely covered. The shoulders must be covered by a stiched garment (however short the sleeve!!!!)One of my nieces was in a decourous but sleevless collared T, but she had a HUGE and beautiful scarf that completely covered her shoulders and arms. The guards at the ticket collection point actually man-handled her, yanking her scarf off her and jabbed her (now bare) arm. Anywhere else this would be assault! My niece had the maturity and sense of humour to see it for what it was, pointing out to me that it was an odd sort of thing in a country where traditionally women did not wear stiched garmets :-)
Nice temple. Temple was good for taking pictures & walk friendly, Nothing to dislike. Everything was to my liking/

A serene and tranquil visit. Wat Phra Kaew is on the grounds of the Grand Palace in Bangkok located at Thanon Na Phra Lan Phra Borom Maha Ratchawang, Phra Nakhon Bangkok 10200. Visitors are required to confirm to strict dress codes for entry : No sleeveless shirts/blouses and no shorts. Clean shirts and trousers are available on loan upon a modest deposit. There are three different sets of gold clothing for the 45cm tall jadeite buddha which are changed by the King of Thailand in the 1st Waning of Lunar Months 4, 8 and 12 (around March, July and November). The three sets of gold garments correspond to Thailand's summer season, rainy season, and cool season. The two sets of gold clothing not in use at any given time are kept on display in the nearby Pavilion of Regalia, Royal Decorations and Thai Coins on the grounds of the Grand Palace, where the public may view them.

Go by Boat. Avoid the crowds by going mid-week. But note that some of the complex is closed on Mondays. Travel to and from the Grand Palace by boat from the many river piers - only 40 Baht per single trip - to avoid the taxi scams. Totally ignore the persistent hawkers. Keep your belongings safe. Take note of the need for conservative dress - even if the heat and humidity is high!! BTW a small booklet is worth purchasing there at about 20 Baht. It tells the history of the Emerald Buddha. Note that there are no monks working at this Wat / Temple - so you wont see a working Temple. Better jade / emerald Buddhas can be seen at the Jade Temple in Chiang Mai.

Tourist Scam Paradise. I do not know if we were scammed, or if there was an actual ceremony/practice last Monday, October 22. But we were not able to enter the grand palace, but instead just marvel at the emerald buddha. It was small, but the details surrounding it were so intricate. It is a must-go to in Bangkok, but goodluck because of all the tourist traps surrounding the area. We got there at around 1230 and were told that the entrance to Emerald Buddha is at 1. The temples around the main temple are nice as well, good for photo ops. Be sure to wear pants and sandals/shoes, because they will hound you. They are strict with these things, and the rentals are unhygienic.

So Very Cool. I really enjoyed our time at the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. The temple was so amazing, and, of course, the Buddha is a site that shouldn't be missed. We were there in November, and even at that time of year, it was pretty warm. Even still, we had no issue renting the required long pants needed to see the temple.

Pretty small buddha. You go for the history and mysticism, not the size or impressiveness of the buddha. You are not allowed to take photographs here and when you enter make sure you find a place to sit unless you are standing at the very back.
Emerald Buddha. The Emerald Buddha is revered by the Thai people. When visiting you have take off your shoes and get it back only outside the temple. Lighted incense is everywhere.

Grand palace, impressive. The grand palace is nice, its unbelievable how much work had gone into such a place. Its also a lot bigger than you first think, it seems to go on and on, you could spend all day there if you wanted. Plenty of tour guides if you are really into the history of it all, but we never used them.

amazing!. This is within the Grand Palace complex. We had a guide with us to show us around (we were on a private tour) and so we discovered a lot that we would not have known otherwise. To go inside this temple you have to take off your shoes and leave them outside. You are not allowed to take photos once you are inside, but you can take photos from the outside, looking through the large open windows. Inside the temple is adorned beautifully and well worth just standing there and taking it all in, so take as long as you need, there is so much to see. The emerald buddha is made of jade and is quite small but a great sight to see. Early in the morning to visit is better than later as it gets so busy (and so hot!)

Stunning!. Do not miss this place while in Bangkok. One of the most beautiful temples i've ever seen. The temple itself is small, but the surroundings are amazing! Beautiful architecture, rich coatings (gold, emerald, sapphire etc.) The dress code is strict to get inside the temple, so wear long trousers or something lower than your knees and no sleeveless tops. Otherwise you have to line-up to borrow some clothes, and it can take time.

A richly decorated and grand temple.. Set withing the Grand Palace and it's main attraction is this temple. The temple is rich in decoration with great detail. Although busy, still a peaceful place to wonder about and enjoy. If for no other reason visit the Grand Palace for this temple.

Beware of taxis!. I came back with my husband to have a look at the exterieur of the Grand Palace and so on as he has already visited the inside. Beware of the taxis and tuk tuk who refuse fares if they consider you are not going far enough, either that or they dont want to use the meter or they quote hideously high prices. We have travelled quite a bit in South east asia and this was the first time we have experienced this! There are also a lot of people milling around the outside of the palace who try to con you into buying things and all the rest. Be warned that you should wear long pants though to go inside.

No excuse not to visit.. If you only have time for one historical / cultural place in Bangkok, then this is the one! It's normally swarming with tourists, so your best bet is to get there at 8.30am when the gate opens.

gorgeous. The Buddha statue is actually quite small, but the building and surrounding areas are stunning. The temple is mobbed, so come early. I recommend a sanctioned guide. We turned down a couple whose English did not seem too good. Then we happened on a gentleman who spoke impeccable English and who gave us an outstanding tour. he gave us the back story on this building as well as the other buildings on the grounds of the palace. The whole complex is more impressive when you know the history behind it.
Impressive Buddha. We came early in the day when it wasn't as crowded. The reclining Buddha is massive - takes up a whole building.
Beautiful statue. This statue is not as well-known as the Wat Pho but it is worth seeing it. Just be sure you have appropriate clothes.

emerald temple. it is amazing it is must visit temple beutiful worth in this temple there is a green emerald buddha great i was there in the temple for about four hours you cannot visit if you are wearing shorts pls note or you have to hier a of them so pls wear long pants and dress properly

Nice place but beware of cheats and touts. Our visit was spoiled by the touts at the main entrance, who were in some kind of dress and told us that temple is closed for 1 hour and you can go arround for 1 hour .He guided us to one of the taxis there .Then it was a ride to different shops and shops and..shops.We stopped after 3 shops and told the taxi to come back .We never expected that this thing can happen at such high profile place under the administration nose. and yes place is not closed ..obviously any time(closed after 4.30 PM.Otherwise place itself is great and worth visit.

Sparkling Gold. It is beautiful temple with much to see and remember to say a prayer and wish that it be true. We need to get sarong because one of us were in shorts, and had knees showing. This is not acceptable. Worth a trip.

Tour rip offs. The Emeral budha and the grand palce are magnificent and well worth a visit. Watch out for the tours though, you end up being rushed though the place you paid to see so they can take you to the government shops.

The holiest place in Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha is really beautiful, as is the temple. Make sure you wear appropriate clothing and take your shoes off before you go in - there are also no photographs allowed inside.

See history of Siam. This temple and its other buildings is a unique display of Thai history and architecture. The statue itself has a long history and involvement with the Siam Kings, and today it is enshrined and worshiped in this temple. The murals on the temple walls have a lot to show for lovers of art and history. It is truly a treasure of Thailand
A must in Thailand. Very impressive. Peaceful. A little crowded though. I hated being the tourist where as some locals were actually praying.

Okay but not a must-see. First I have to confess that I don't know much about Thai culture and religion, so my visit of the green Buddha was not planned at all and I didn't know what to expect. So, buildings around the temple with the Buddha are very interesting, there is much gold to see... The Buddha itself is very small and not that impressive. For me it was much more interesting to watch temple guardians supervising ignorant tourists.

Wat Phra Kaeo. We visted the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaeo yesterady and had a great time! Modest dress code is enforced, and should be respected. Ladies, cover your shoulders and wear long pants or a sarong. My fiancee was told only women could wear sarongs so he wore long pants. I had seen online that only closed toed shoes and socks were allowed as well, however saw many people wearing thongs so it doesn't look like footwear is enforced. The complex gets quite busy and crowded but is worth a visit - the buildings are so ornate and grand. Getting into the actual temple gets loud and cramped, shoes must be left outside. Inside are many people praying to the Emerald Buddha, who is up high overlooking everyone. It's meant to be a place of prayer and peace, but some people are quite loud and this was annoying. Make sure you have a few hours set aside to see everything - and make sure you pick up the guide/map leaflet so you know where you are!
crowded. to many people in to small a space , need to have more control over the number of people in the place at one time

An Antique Buddha Statue. To see this Buddha statue, you have to visit Grand Palace because the Emerald Buddha is on the grounds of the Grand Palace in Bangkok. The statue is very historical because it was made thousand years ago. However, when i visited the Emerald temple, it was not allowed to take picture. I don;t know. However we can take picture for other statues in the Grand Palace area. For the entry fee to the palace, u have to pay 300 baths..

Temple to visit,If you are for a short stay at Bangkok. First of all I wont say this is a must see or anything.I have seen much more beautiful temples.Cant say I am very much impressed.Who Should go:If you are for a very short stay and want to visit a temple then you can choose this temple inside the palace grounds.Added advantage is that the temple of Reclining Budda is just around the corner,So in one stop you can cover both places.What to Expect:1.It is Big2.It'sgood looking (from a distance).But when you go near you will feel like it is all made up of some colored glasses sticked together.May be because I have seen better architecture, where they have took the pain to carve in wood ,marble ,stone and many other things i didnt find them particularly attractive.3.There is a display of arms and ammunitions used by the kings which was kind of ok.But other couple of museums (like textiles )were not much to look at4.You can see the Emerald Budda inside the shrine(it is very small and you cannot take photos inside.)5.There is a dress code to follow.They have clear instruction placed everywhere(like your arms should be covered)and dresses are available free of cost in case your dressing is inappropriate.6.Much of the palace is not accessible since the royal family is actually staying there.7.There is a building where the kings are anointed.the throne here looked nice.8.Authorised guides are available and I think better to get one if you are interested in knowing the history.Or you can always go with the brochure provided.9.And as with else where in Bangkok it is very crowdedWill I recommed this?..Yeah maybe... one time see...
Fascinating place. Excellent place with loads of interesting history. We had a private guide which made all the difference in getting the most out of the visit.
Gorgeous. Beautiful sight, but cannot take pictures inside the temple housing the Buddha nor in the museum where artifacts of the temple are kept.

Beautifully crafted. the temple estate is vast and beautifully maintained. Several Jedi's and Chupa's, lots of gold and an interesting mural. The emerald Buddha itself is not the only one of its kind, we saw another one later in our trip, but still beautiful.
excellent. something unseen... and something one might not see elsewherequiet and peaceful... though no photography allowed

wow!. All this place is a "wow". Once i was inside i regret to not hire a guide!... i had so much to ask... and the books they sell inside don't say anything different than Wikipedia so hire the Guide!

Biggest emerald i've ever seen!. The Temple and it's surroundings are remarkable like the other temples the art is unique and the colors are alive. The inside room of the temple where the emerald buddha is has an old caretaker who poked my back and shouted at me when i took picture of the emerald statue. He is so rude! I think he just have to come closer and reprimand the person in a civilized manner, The emerald stone is worth seeing but do not take picture of it!

Peacefull. A very sacred and a colourful temple. There are seveal sites to see within the temple. Sitting in front of the Emerald Buddha is a very peacefull experience. Better to obtain the services of a guide understand the various aspects at the temple complex. Go early morning so you can walk about before it becomes hot outside.Also ensure that you are properly dressed since this is a religious site. There are strict guidelines - tops with sleves, long dresses/trousers and covered toes are a must for entry. Although a visit to the next door palace is included in the ticket we found that you cannot really go inside the palace and can only see it from a distance

Highlight, must see this when you are in Bangkok. Always very busy, but this is the most important Temple all visitor should visit. See that you have a good guide who can explain many things to you. All travelbooks are incomplete, you will miss the most important things. A good Thai guide with good language skills is the best way to learn about this temple.. Be carefull for some guide for hire at the entrance (don't pay to much). Test them first on there language skills, make good agreements, and how long the tour will last. You need a minumum of 1 1/2 to 2 hours. Don't agree on a price per person, agree on price for service.

Amazing to see but the crowds are drawback. Of course you have to queue up and fight the crowds to see this very unique complex and shrine but because of the crowds, I found the experience not very pleasant. Too many people inevitably shake up what would otherwise be a very peaceful and serene atmosphere.I also got e portable audio guide which was very helpful. Take a credit card with you to leave with them in exchange for the electronic guide (its that or your original passport, copies or driving license are not accepted).Beware as your walk around to find your way to the main entrance ( the complex is huge so depending on which direction you come from, you will likely have to walk around it) at you will find many people telling you that the temple is closed for some reason or the other and to save you the walk there and the disappointment, they wanted to inform you. They will then tell you about other sites to see instead and handily have a tuk tuk pull up to offer you a ride. Ignore all such BS. Watch your pockets and just make your way to the entrance. It's the biggest draw in BKK so it's always open.
Beautiful.... we had tour guide to show us around...interesting history, not to mention the beautiful architecture the weather was a plus -- cool with a bit of a drizzle :)

Nice place but.... It might be a must see place in Bangkok but after I've seen a few temples before, I wasn't so impressed to visit here. It was extremely crowded and strict dress code too. good experience but it's not my cup of tea.

fantastic and magnificient. This is situated inside the grand palace. Though the entrance ticket is 400 Baht, the whole experience of visiting the temple of emerald buddha, museum of various items used in those days and painting and drawings on the walls which are exquisite. Tour organisers avoid this place. you dont miss it.
Green. Yeah. He’s green but amazingly small. I guess it’s worth a lot of money--priceless, really because it’s not for sale. But you’ll still be surprised how small it is.

One of many highlights.. The temple is magnificent, spread over a huge space and attached to the Grand Palace with lots of history attached. We were lucky as we had a local tour guide who was very knowledgeable and passionate about her history and culture which made the experience extra special and helped us understand the importance. Was a little more expensive compared to other temples but I thought it was well worth it. Most temples you can take pictures inside but this one you can't and remember to wear appropriate clothes no shorts or vests. The grounds and other structures in the surrounding area are also amazing.

Truly magnificient statue.. A truly enchanting meditating place. Serene and calm.
The emerald buddha is quite stunning. The entrance fee is quite steep though. And the place is poorly marked with signs. No use getting a guide nor the audio piece to learn more about the complex.

beauty and supernatural power. I am surprise when witness temple of Thailand. woa! it very beautiful and supernatural power as you imagine as a Palace. It is huge and wide more than 945.000 square metre. I feel weary in my leg because of wide Palace. I'm intersed and want to come again!!!

Great place, but too crowded. The amazing stupas and wats alone deserve this place a 4 rating, but the crowds made it not worth the steeply priced entrance fee (450 baht). If you are no good with crowds, i suggest going south a bit to Wat Pho for a more relaxed and spiritual experience for a fraction of the price.
Amazing place !. Very interesting spires , same as all Buddhist temples, the carvings and paintings depict very stange winged animals.

Become part of it!. We loved this temple and all the surrounding temples. The emerald buddha is so unique - actually made of jade! We blessed ourselves with lotus flowers and waters, at the end and felt we were in a very special, spiritual place. We appreciated why the Thai people are so happy!

Unbelievable. You have to see it to believe it. Absolutely beautiful. Price has gone up again to 400 baht, but it is worth it. 400 baht is about $13. Can easily be accessed by river express boats. Also close to Wat Pho which is also outstanding. No visitor to Bangkok should miss Wat Phra Kaeo (Grand Palace)
Must see - esp. for worship! ^^. It is connected to the Grand Palace, so you will save your time to visit 2 places together by using the same ticket.

quiet serene place. come before 10am, ideally not on wkends. The crowds have swelled in the last few years, esp on a Sunday morning. DO COME EARLY to avoid the crowds. Ideally get there before 10am.Bring sunglasses, a cap and sunscreen. And a small backpack to stash your stuff. Also bring a small umbrella in case it rains. Get a guide to explain what you are seeing inside the main Emerald Buddha hall, as it'll make your trip even more meaningful when you understand the history of the place. I'd also bring a small handtowel to wipe away sweat - BKK weather is hot :)

Amazing. Beautiful place, excellent value for money. We found it ver busy but we really enjoyed it. Please be aware hat hiss a religious place and you will be expected to wear mid length sleeves and below the ankle trousers/ skirts/ shorts. Overall a great experience.

Incredible Area. While the emerald buddha is defnitely something you need to see, the palace area leading up to it is simply amazing. We recommend going with a tour guide so you gain insightful explanations of the various plains of existence.
HHmmm. Not sure about this one. It was beautiful, no doubt. But for my money I found it a bit over rated. Very crowded so you couldn't get to see a lot of things. Not my cup of tea at all really.

A must see in Bangkok. As our tour guide said, if we told people it was jade, no one would come. Massive altar with Emerald Buddha on top, very glorious. No pictures are allowed inside but very impressive to see

This place was amazing. This was such a beautiful place. Make sure you are covered up as it will save you waiting in the Q for half hour to get clothes! a girl behind me was wearing leggings and they didnt let her in unless she got changed (they check at every entrance point). I had a maxi dress on which was fine, but it was sleeveless, so I had to get a shirt from there (you pay a deposit, you get it back on return of the item). Must see place!WARNING!!!!! If you are approached on your way to the temple, by someone saying you can't go in until after 3, because there are paryers going on... It's a SCAm to get you to go to a shop "to kill time"...and they will make you go far on a tuktuk to a "cheap jewellry store" which is about £300 for the cheapest pair of earrings. Then they will make you stop at every shop on your way back to the temple - they must get paid by the shop owners!! The temple closes at 4pm so don't fall for this! the temple itself is so peaceful and lovely!!!
Magnificient. Grand in true sense . Its a beautiful and must place to visit in bangkok. take a leisure time to see through the entire palace .

Love the temple , watch the Con outside. We arived outside were told by the street hawkers the temple was closed till one and only Thai people were allowed in early . So we started walking around the street as we noticed a big market further down , we were accosted by lots of street traders telling us they were going to take us to the real lucky Temple and the real Buddha, then we decided that we were lied to and they were hustling us , so we went back and entered the Temple and ignored the hustlers. Please we're short sleeves or you have to put on one of theyre not so glamorous shirts . Loved the Temple and the arts and crafts in the shop of the Queen. Inside the Temple is lots of warnings about the hustlers outside bit late. The temple is totally amazing and we loved it .
Expensive + dress problems. Too much troubles with dress code. Different interpretation at the main gate and tickets checkpoint.Unpolite staff with no English language.Big money for big place anyway.

Beautiful temple complex. Very pretty buildings in the complex. The intricate carvings and gold coverings make for a fantastic show. It also has a scale model of Angkor Wat :) and a full scale mural in the cloisters telling the Ramakina (Ramayana). Definitely take a guide to understand better. If you must visit only one temple in Bangkok, make it this one.

Crowded but worth it. Make sure you're covered up when you go otherwise you won't be allowed in- no leggings, cover knees and shoulders. This site is beautiful. There is so much to see, and it's crowded, but it's worth it!

The most important Temple in Bangkok. This is the most important Temple in Bangkok, it is always the first Temple of the 9 Temples, I visit on Birthdays or special occcasions.Please note that Ladies are required to wear appropriate clothing. This is not an issue, as sarongs can be rented at the entrance to the Temple. If you don't want to rent a sarong, bring along a big scarf or wear a long skirt, or loose pants.
The emerald buddha. Beautiful temple and surroundings.The emerald Buddha was a lot smaller than I thought though :DVery worth while visiting this place.
Interesting - and moving.. Not religious personally, but it was lovely to watch so many people offer a quick, heartfelt prayer. And the dancers are a treat!

Not Emerald, but an Iconic Destination. The small "emerald" Buddha is actually jade, but it is situated in a magnificently decorated temple. Your eyes won't know where to look next. Remember you will need to take your shoes off before you enter and when you sit down on the floor of the temple, point your feet away from the Buddha. A nice place to stay and reflect for a while.

Expensive for foreigners. I made my second visit in July 12. The Emerald Buddha wasn't on show last time I went. So I thought I'd make another journey as it wasn't far from Sukhumvit. The first thing was that we arrived at lunchtime and the temple was closed to foreigners, but not Thais, so we had to wait an hour and a half to be able to enter. Then we had to hire long trousers and leave a returnable deposit. No shorts or skirts allowed. Finally, the entrance fee was expensive for foreigners, but free for Thais, a Thai trait which always annoys me. But this isn't England, so you have to accept that foreigners are cash cows.We eventually got in and it was very hot and very crowded. It is a beautiful temple area with some impressive thai architecture and a stroll around is quite pleasant. This time I did manage to see the Emerald Buddha, perhaps significant religious-wise, but very disappointing otherwise. I had to look hard just to find it and then when I did, I couldn't take a photo.....I took my allowable photos and we headed for the exit, only to find it wasn't the one that we'd come in at and our 'long-pant' hirer was on the other side of the temple. The different hirers wouldn't accept each others trousers. When we did find the lady (make a note of what the hirer looks like and exactly where they are in relation to the entrance you choose) she rudely snatched the trousers off us and tossed the bahts back at us. To add further unpleasantness, all the taxi drivers increase their fares dramatically when heading away from the temple and would not barter at all. Be warned.So, I've done it and seen it twice and that is enough. I won't be going back. The temples are worth seeing, but the local thais are ruthless in their quest for a few bahts and also a few were unusually unpleasant and rude. There are nicer temples to visit which are equally impressive and have polite and friendly local thais.

Awesome. Everything about this temple is awesome. The temples are colorful and nicely maintained. A must see on ur trip to Bangkok. Loved the pagoda in Combodian style. The miniature Ang Kor Wat looks fantastic. Recommended to hire a guide.
Beautiful. A really beautiful temple, although in itself it is not that interesting, per se, it is still worth seeing while your there.
Good experience. Even during peak hours it's nice to travel in the sky train but you feel the lack of knowledge of local language and not many people speaking English incase you need any explanation.

An amazing sight. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha, or Wat Phra Kaeo in Thai, has to be one of the most beautiful sights I have ever seen. I was truly in awe and will remember it for a long, although I will probably go back to have another look.
Wonderful. we visitied this temple whilst on a temple crawl for the day, admittedly you get very templed out but this place is great!!!! worth the visit

Wat Phra Kaeo. Don't just go in and come out just to say that you've been there. Try to appreciate every single detail inside and outside the temple. You would be amazed with how much effort they've exerted for the place.

As a thai...at least you must see...sign of thai buddhist. It's national temple that every thai would like to visit at least once. i visited there few times since i was young, huge crowded but not heard about taxi cheating if you wanna take taxi to go there as foreigners, so better check information.

The Emerald Buddha. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is located within the grounds of the Grand Palace. It is considered to be one of the most sacred temple in Thailand.The Buddha is in fact not made of emerald. It is carved from a single block of jade. In front of it are several Buddha images each of which is of high importance the Thai people.The four walls inside the temple are decorated with murals of astounding detail portraying events in the life of the Buddha and the Buddhist Cosmology.Taking photos inside the temple is prohibited so all photos that you will see of the Buddha will not do it justice. This is one sight that has to be seen in real life. People, even those not of the Buddhist faith, have been moved to tears upon entering this temple. And that includes me.
excellent experience!!!!. so beautiful,never seen anything like it!!!!!so many colours and so much work for the decoration...really liked the respect people show to monuments like this!!!!
Fascinating!. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha provides a visual sensory overload. So much to look at! A great cultural experience for the whole family.

Be quiet! Syhhhh. take off your shoes before you enter to this Wat Phra Kaeo, and be quiet right after you enter as monks and some sincere buddhist are performing their prayers here. you may have your meditation here or have some inner-heart speaking with the buddha if you are a buddhist.

Nice temple. The Temple of Emerald Buddha is a nice temple inside the gardens of the Grand Palace... it is quite spectacular and if you are going to the Grand Palace, make sure you spend some time having a look at it.

Majestic. When you go to visit the palace there are so many golden temples, buddhas. The palace needs a good part of the day to be visited and the emeral buddha is on a closed temple so you can only see if from the outside main door. Remember that to visit the all complex you need to to ware short or T Shirt you need to have cover up. They rent cloths at the entrance
Free Tour Guide. This was made even more enjoyable by the fact that they had a FREE tour guide who spoke English and brought us around.

A temple.... It s awesome if it is the first time you see a temple otherwise if you already travelled in asia, it has nothing special... It s "OK" and soemthing to see in BKK but probably too expensive for what it is... Some people have to cover their legs and shoulders but some others (Thai, very wealthy caucasian) dont have to (...Quite confusing...)

A must see. Definitely worthwhile seeing this temple as it is in the grounds of the Grand Palace. The gardens and the buildings themselves are truly spectacular. The Emerald Buddha is small and is enshrined in an ornate temple surrounded by amazing statues. The decorations & tiles appear hand-made and are impressive in colour and design.You leave your shoes behind to enter the temple and if you sit on the floor to admire the beautiful decorations and the Buddha itself, you must not point your feet towards it. This is seen as a sign of disrespect. Also, dress appropriately – no shorts or singlet tops for both men and women. Both sexes must have their arms and legs covered to enter the grounds.

Beautiful Wat Phra Kaeo (Emerald Buddha). The Buddha statue made from Emerald.The Emerald Buddha it self not too big, rather a bit small statu actually and u cant take photo inside. If u have a long tele camera than u can take picture from outside building, becouse inside the security always forbidden for people taking picture of Emerald Buddha.

Don't miss!!!!!!!!!!!. Brilliant! Awesome! Great!
Really a great experience to be there.Don't miss it. Inside is really calm & quite with a spiritual serinity. Peace will come automatically in your mind.

Like from another world. Absolutely wonderful place, nuber one from the must visit places not only in Bangkok or Thailand, but I think that also on the world. The entrance fee is very high (400B), but the ticket is also valid for the Dusit museums - where it is also very worth to visit - also very long time to spend there..

Crowed and hot but beautiful. The day we went it was hot and humid and this was made worse by the crowds. Tips: 1) There is a dual pricing policy for Thais (free?) and non-Thais. 2) Make sure you step over the thresholds in the doorways as opposed to onto the thresholds themselves 3) Dress fairly conservatively - there are people telling you off if you show too much skin. The Emerald Buddha itself is small (about 15-20 inches high) but held in reverance bhy the Thais and the whole complex is beautiful.

WOW. Although the Buddha is not really emerald and is smaller than what I had expected I would highly recommend seeing this site. The grounds and buildings are breathtaking. You will need a tour guide with you to give you the history and insightful information. You should plan on taking drinking water with you (it is hot and not shaded). You will also be required to wear appropriate clothing (long pants or skirts and covered shoulders for both men and women).

Worth a visit. Is an interesting place to visit but guys take some long pants with and ladies wear a skirt below the knee of you will spend time geting something to wear that means the appropriate dress standardBest visit early before the tour groups arrive as then the place is packed

He is small but the reverence is high by all visiting. Unlike most other temples, this one is so adorned you may spend much more time admiring the walls and other accents in this temple. It is a cacophony of colors, textures and dazzle. All obvious by the reverence of all in attendence
A temple not to miss,. It was extremely crowded and so difficult to contemplate the marvellous statue in peace, There were signposts throughout warning of pickpockets which made one very wary.

True beauty. We went there on a weekday afternoon and this place was so peaceful and calm. right in the middle of the hustle and bustle of bangkok but 1 hour n this temple soothes the mind and the body. The architecture is beautiful as like the other temples in bangkok.Definitely worth a visit.

A must go Place in Thailand. It's very hot during this time and suddenly raining. Prepare your umbrella and a bottle of water. Easiest way to go hear by local public boat.NEVER TAKE TAXI OR TUK TUK arround this area

Magical. I love to visit this place whenever I'm in Bangkok, sit and admire the beauty of the temple and the silence, usually there are monks chanting which gives it a great atmosphere. However you cannot take photos inside the temple.

Beautiful and curious. It's not as big as the other Buddha, but it's curious (it's not in emerald, ut in giada stone - a single piece!). Curious because the King himself has to get this Buddha changed every season (they have 3 main seasons) with different dress! It's worth it visiting once!

Wonderful Thai Architecture. Visited the Grand Palace and this temple in one day. Exotic designs everywhere- you will spend all day picturing all the amazing stuff. A few minutes inside the temple was really peaceful.The only downside is that as a tourist, I got a feeling that we have been looked down upon. 400 baht for all 'foreigners' (as they have it on the sign boards) was downright expensive (while it was free for locals). Rubbing salt on wounds was that the 'foreigners' were not allowed to come in via the main entrances and were asked to walk all around the palace to exit which was downright silly and hard for folks especially with little children. No, I don't think Thai people are hospitable. Maybe they are just tired of tourists. On another note, Things like this don't happen in America. All tourists are treated with respect and are provided with basic conveniences no matter where they are in the USA. One more reason to be a proud American.

temples are ok. same same, but different. On a warm summer's day.. man alive this place is busy and hot. the temple is grand. i guess they tried by giving out free water. Really difficult getting a metered taxi outa here. it took us about 45 mins to get one, even though we walked some distance away from the temple area. they all want to charge extra or take us to a factory. shame.

Stunning, intricate and well maintained!. Take your time to enjoy the stunning and intricate work of art. This temple and the surrounding ones are distinct from many others in the country in terms of how well it has been maintained along with the murals which can be found depicting the history. I, however, strongly recommend hiring a guide as it will definitely prove valuable. It is hard otherwise to fully appreciate all of the detail and symbolic significance.

The Royal Palace beckons.... Located inside the Royal Palace Grounds, this is a beautiful Temple ! Both the exterior architecture and the interiors of the temple are breathtaking !Dress code- Full length trousers for men, bottoms at least below knee level for women and no sleeveless tops for either men or women.Ticket price: 800THB / foreign national

Within the Grand Palace. Once in the Grand palace, and ensuring you have the correct clothing, long trousers and covered shoulders, the Emerald Buddha is a must see, quite busy but you can sit down at the front and soak up the architecture and the beauty of the temple.
Just lucky. We just happened to be there when the king came to change the Buddhas clothes. A little crowded but exciting.

Stunning - if rather packed!. This place is beautiful and an absolute must in Bangkok - the architecture is such a feast for the eyes. We went early (arriving just after it opened) so luckily there were no queues to get in. Having said that - it was still packed, which does slightly mar the experience. Remember you must be appropriately dressed (long trousers / shoulders covered). Use the Chao Praya Express Boat to get there - extra sight seeing and probably quicker than a taxi depending on your location.
Emerald buddha. This is located in the grand palace,look for the time/dont preferre weekend as its really bussy.Proper clothing is a must.

Beautiful temple. Beautiful temple but so touristic. However, since it is so close to the Grand Palace and the temple of the Reclining Buddha, you can't miss it.Loved the Angkor Wat miniature and all of other small temples around the central one housing the emerald Buddha. Careful if you're there in August, might get caught up in the rain and thus stuck inside a temple.

The Emerald Buddha. The most revered buddha image in Thailand and the garment wear is changed three times per year by Royalty to reflect the different seasons.
Absolutely jaw dropping experience for first time visitors to Thailand.

Only go to look at the Emerald Buddha. You've been to one Wat you've seen all the same stuff. Seriously the Buddha is amazing. Don't waste your time on anything else though. If you've been to other wats, (which I was) it is basically all the same stuff. You can hire someone (independant) to give you a tour but you can haggle the prices. I think 1-300 baht is more than enough. There are a lot of smiling scammers there though too. so be careful.

Part of the grand palace. This temple is within the grounds of the grand palace. The emerald buddha itself is not as obvious and you may need a guide to point it out. Alternatively, do some reading about the temple first. Well worth seeing while in the palace.

Magnificent. Make sure you have your arms and legs covered to avoid entry problems and don't listen to anyone on the streets telling you its closed. They are just touts trying to get you to go somewhere else.

A madhouse on holidays. We were there on a holiday (beginning of Vassa) and it was a zoo. While I can't blame the facility for attracting a large mixture of tourists and worshippers, they were ill-equipped to handle it, with people pushing at the gates, no room to move inside and guards shouting instructions contradicting one another.We could not get anywhere near the Emerald Buddha, as there were crowds kneeling (I assume in prayer) and blocking the pathways to that part of the complex. Nonetheless, there is some very intricate and beautiful artwork in the more minor buildings we were able to see.We didn't have much choice of when to visit -- it was our only full day in Bangkok -- but if you do have a choice and this attraction is important to you, avoid holidays.

A must. Last time we were here (August 2012) a tourist in the queue saw us marching away and asked us if it was interesting. I told him that it was the tenth time we visited it: that's how much we find it interesting. Please, come here as early as you can in the morning, because you will need time exploring every detail and the heat is terrible at noon. And, please, do not miss the galleries with mural paintings of the Ramakien (Ramayana).

Busy but worth a visit. It is the one place in Bangkok you really have to visit. Although my husband's trousers were not full length, they had been accepted at every other temple but not here. My son and I waited 40 mins while he queued for long trousers so if you are going make sure you have the right clothes or expect a long queue, which isn't fun in Bangkok heat.
too busy, dont go. its great temples, but its so packed with tourists. There are so many temples in thailand im sure you can find somewhere better at a cheaper price.

Green Buddha. Green Buddha is a unique one because of its color. taking pictures is not allowed their so better follow instructions before the guards approach you. there is a free guide for one hour so just sign up near the entrance.

Lovely Buddha, although quite small.. Worth visiting this Buddha which holds a lot of significance for the Thais. You can't take pics inside but if you stand outside and have a decent lens you can take one through the window. Like most other temples you can visit and appreciate without having to spend too long inside.

Must see!. The Temple is part of the Grand Palace complex and must be visited as such. The site itself is a collection of several pagodas and templex, each one more colorful than the other. Bordering on kitsch, it offers visual spectacle and is everything you believe Thailand to be.
Simply breathtaking !!!!. A must see when you are in BKK. Beautiful, elegant, serene, peaceful. My girlfriend and I enjoyed the visit to this temple along with the palace tour.

Nice but small. The site is nice and the experience is good. Once again, we travelled by boat and that is the best way to get to a number of temples. the emerald Buddha is small - not what we expected.

Magnificent mirrored mosaic-covered monument. Just go see it for yourself. One of those architectural/cultural marvels you must see once in this lifetime.The grandeur of this temple is on par with that in the Sistine - not a surface unadorned, frescoed (or perhaps this is just a regular paint job) wall-ceilings everywhere on the interiors, and a vital spiritual vibe. No Bermudas allowed for men, nor sleeveless garb allowed for the ladies - you will have to rent a sarong or pants from vendors around the entrance. I wld recommend bringing your own sarong to wrap around yourself. It's kinda disgusting to think abt how many sweaty bodies had gone in the pants on loan. Eww

Place not to Miss.. Part of Grand palace tour. You can get here easily through boat. N9 pier, get down and walk straight out and you can see grand palace you cannot miss. Inside grand palace there is a FREE guided English tour ( two or 3 times a day). Its worth waiting for that. Whatever you want to know about the Wat phra Kaeo will be explained in that and also about the grand palace. You dont have to go with expensive guide or package tour to visit this place. Must go

Worth the Time. Because this is coupled with the Grand Palace it is a pretty good deal. Make sure you bring long pants or prepare to rent them and don't listen to anyone outside the grounds because they will be trying to scam you. You can not take pictures of the Emerald Buddha form inside the temple but there is an open door and with a zoom lens you can get decent pictures. The ground surrounding the temple are very nice.
wow. it is just amazing how old these temples & artefacts are & how well they are kept, I think australia needs to have a good look at its poor keeping of its history

The Seasons. Research where the "Emarald Buddha" (Phra Kaeo) came from (was it Laos?)...Important in Thailand: The King (or his son/daughter if he is not able) must change the "clothes" of the Emerald Buddha as the seasons change...This is a pilgramige that any visitor to Thailand must make (and hopefully get a blessing).
The Temple !. No wonder there is such people wants to see this templeit's like the Eiffel tower , if you get to bangkok without seein it , it would be a crime

A window into Thai culture. A must see. So much history and symbolism here that it helps to have a guide. Watch out for the clothing restrictions which are strictly enforced - long trousers for men and covered legs and shoulders for women. We were fine, but others were buying sarongs and robes. Apparently they will lend, but saw no sign of that when I was there.
Small Buddha but excellent. VERY important Buddha to the Thais and well worth visiting and watching the HUGE respect the Thais give the Buddha.
stunning. the day we visited the temple the royal family were visiting to change buddha's clothes for seasons. the temple is stunning.

Amazing Place. A must see in BKK. Great to see the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaeo. Amazing sights. Be sure to bring your camera. A bit of a tourist trap, stay away from getting a taxi there. They will charge you flat rate, try to walk a few blocks and get a metered taxi.
Another must see!. If you travel a long way, make sure you take this in. A solid piece of jade never looked prettier. Thailand is known for Temples and there are over 400 in Bangkok alone.

Okay-ish. Lots of history here, but other than that, just nice architecture so you snap a few pics. Wear comfortable shoes and remember to take them off before you enter the temple. Also, bring an umbrella, sunglasses, hat, etc. Don't het sun burn!

Fantastic!. This Wat is absolutely stunning and a must if you are visiting Bangkok. Beautifully maintained. But remember to wear long trousers/skirt otherwise you will need to hire one (free of charge).

A temple in the middle of a palace.. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is located in the middle of an antique royal palace. The palace features 100ft high structures and statues 30ft high with a images telling a story that run for at least 400 yards. The temple itself is definitely worth visiting.

Hectic!. The Emerald Buddha – a jade figurine of the Buddha 45 cm high – is regarded as Thailand’s most sacred relic, with a long and interesting history of capture and residences. Its temple in the Royal Palace enclosure in Bangkok can be regarded as the Thai “Chapel Royal” but is open to the public when official ceremonies are not taking place. The wat and adjacent palace are probably the country’s most visited place – even during the "quiet times" you can expect huge crowds. You can also expect to be a bit disappointed by the sight of the image itself, especially given the lavish and impressive surroundings of the temple - it's small and set high up. While it's almost obligatory to visit these linked sites if in Bangkok, I much preferred the less frenzied atmosphere at the Temple of the Reclining Buddha and (my favourite) the Marble Temple.Tip for photographers - While you're not allowed to take a picture inside the chamber housing the Emerald Buddha image, you can from outside, and there's a well-placed window beside the entrance...
brill. It is so colourfull your eyes are every where, the Jade on the Budda OMG liked everything about all the temples we visited,

The whole place is a rare piece of art. A tribute to Thai aritecture ,,and art,,of all forms ,,paintings also adorn the inner courtyard walls ,,this is religious art as well as a place of active worship ,,please take note modest attire in clothing and respectfull footwear is strictly followed lady's wear covered toe shoes ,,that are walk able and have a wrap around sarrong or shirt in your bag if your wearing pants of any sort ,,or you will have to rent one to see this site,,,respectfull photos can be taken ,,,the best way to get here is by a river boat the tourist riverboat goes to the port closest to this site ,,catch the sky train to the pier that connects you to the river boats ,,,and don't fall prey to taxis that tell you the temple is closed ,,till later they may take you on thier own tour before you arrive at the temple ,,,
a must see. Even if you're temple-tired, it's a must-go destination. A top-sight in bangkok, not as overcrowded as The Grand Palace
Mystical place. Lot's of people but lot's of food energy. The temple is beautiful - full of colours and details. Take of your shoes, sit down inside the temple, close your eyes and ... enjoy.

Exquisite beauty. First impressions: From the outside, the ornate decorations and the intricate gold-green patterns of the temple's facade is like a wonderful gift-wrap containing an exquisitely beautiful gift inside.While the actual statue is made of jade and not emeralds, it attracts huge crowds who come to pay their respects to the memory of Buddha and his teachings. The tiny (between 60 and 75 cm) Emerald Buddha, is located high above the heads of the worshippers and tourists. The image is considered a talisman and holds tremendous significance for Thailand and the Thai people. The 'robe' that it wears is changed three times each year by the King himself at the start of each season: A diamond encrusted gold robe during the hot season, a solid gold robe in the cool season and a gilded monk's robe in the rainy season. So choose your season.Pros: This temple is part of a large complex of "buildings" inside the Grand Palace so you can hit all the attractions in one visit. Take the whole day. (And it is close to Wat Po, the Temple of the Reclining Buddha.) Although the lines getting in might be long, you can spend as much time inside as you want.Cons: Did I tell you about the crowds?! Come early. You are competing for space with both worshippers and tourists alike. Like in many temples, there is also a dress code. You do not want to come unprepared. As it is strictly forbidden to take pictures inside, you may want to take pictures of the statue outside from an open window. A telephoto lens would help (It is slightly dark inside and it's a small statue, after all).Verdict: One of the "must see" attractions in Bangkok. Highly recommended. Just come early and dress appropriately.

A must go but doesn't wow. The Temple is incredibly ornate and very beautiful. Our trip was slightly spoilt by how busy the temple was and also by all the touts outside doing their best to con you. You need to make sure you dress "modestly" otherwise you have to borrow appropriate clothes!
Astoundingly beautiful. The hand-craftmanship is really amazing and the Buddha and surrounding grounds are almost breathtaking, especially when considering how painstaking the work must have been.

place of beauty and wonder. there was nothing to dislike.. the place has plenty to see in it, just beware of the hawkers and touts out the front as they will try to extract money under false pretense. and they are convincing

Lovely, unique Anklor style Pagoda with China plate decorated. If you notice, Buddha immages, temple wall and pagodas in Thailand follow syle of Sukhothai, Ayuthaya and also Ankor style. But the Vihar (hall) of this temple decorated with ceramic pieces from China, the Khmer style pagoda decorated by pieces of China plates and bowls. The view of Chao Phraya River and the city from the top of the Pagoda is stunning. You may go at Sunset or Sunrise (not sure when it opens though). Giants are the gate keepers to this vihar, your children will love them as much as they will love the Chinese figures in the Vahar area. Visiting Wat Arun before the Emerald Buddha Temple will enhance the knowledge of those who are interested in history of early Krung Thep. The temples have the same architectural style and also decorated with items from China. It's just lovely, a fun temple for the family :) Climbing up the Pagoda is challenging. It's almost as high as climbing up a pagoda in Angkor Wat. I think this is a collective culture that should be promoted for the solidarity of the region and humankind :)

Chaotic Tourist Masses. The (actually Jade-) Buddha is a must see, the grounds are beautiful, however be prepared for large tourist crowds.Remember that is a temple and you have to cover shoulders, midriff and legs to below the knee or rent appropriate clothing outside (men and women alike).
One of the most famouse and important for thai people tampls. This is the tample that you should also visit in Bangkok! It is really famouse and important for thai people tample!

expensive, hot , crowded and nothing worth to pay a visit. the price increased, paid a lot without even given a bottle of water, many cheaters around trying to rip your money, very strict at outfit requirements, crowded and no idea what t o do inside if you have no tour guide(extra charge), nothing to eat around/hard to find eateries, no benches for visitors to rest. worst to worst: foreigners pay 400baht where Thais enter for FREE!!!!!

Crowded and well-policed. Given that this is the most revered Buddha image in all of Thailand, it's no surprise that the Emerald Buddha is one of the most crowded wats in all of Thailand. Also, there is a strong police presence. Photography is not allowed. It's hot, humid, crowded, so go early in the day and you might have more fun.
part of grand palace. beautiful temple worth watching, inside the temple photography is not allowed. but buddha is made of jade not of emerald. Craftmanship is beautiful. well kept place.

Small but beautiful statue. You have to go inside the temple to view the emerald Buddha. It is on top of a golden dais. It is fairly small, but then again it is made from solid jade. I actually felt a bit guilty for taking photos of the emerald Buddha in this serene place..but the Thais don't mind at all.There is a lot to see here, many many golden and colourful statues. Still, my favourite thing was an old monk in the orange robes using an Iphone to take photos! Priceless.

Ornate!. This was not one of my favourite temples, I preferred Wat Arun or Wat pho, but it was still very beautiful and so ornate. I must admit I went back inside a second time, I had not seen the emerald Buddha the first time, it is a lot smaller than I thought it would be. I would not have missed this experience it was still an amazing place.

It's actually jade. The building itself is very ornate with beautiful gold painted pillars and the typical pretty tiled roof with different colours and levels. Crowds of tourists flock here and it can be difficult to see the 'emerald' Buddha which is not very big and is actually carved jade. Wear shoes you can easily take off as you are not permitted to wear shoes in the temple. OUtside the entrance you can spot various offerings to the Buddha - lotus flowers, fruit etc.

Magnificent. This is the one site in Thailand not to miss. Located on the grounds of the Grand Palace this Wat (Buddhist temple) is only one of the many temples and chedi (reliquary) at the Grand Palace. It holds a magnificient green jade Buddha (the emerald name was a 18th century transliteration mistake that has sadly stuck) and is the Royal and most revered Thai worship site. Wander around the grounds and see spectacular statues and chedi (also called stupa) and then, removing your shoes, enter the Wat Phra Kheow carefully avoiding stepping on the raised door frame (bad luck and in the old days boobytrapped). Even if you are not Buddhist show proper respect by staying low, crouch, do not disturb others, DO NOT TAKE PICTURES, and do not allow the soles of your feet to show towards the Buddha. Enjoy for a moment the jade Buddha and the extensive wall and ceiling pictures in the "primitive" art style.Remember before embarking on your visit that as this is a Royal Palace and grounds you will not be permitted to enter unless you are properly attired, no shorts, t-shirts, exposed shoulders or failing to cover your knees. A royal guide will greet you on entering the grounds to suggest appropriate dress if you don't meet their standards. These suggestions are law and you will note the fully-armed squad of Thai soldiers nearby. Take them seriously. And if you're not properly dressed you will be directly to a building providing you with cotton coverups.

Gears to the spirtual and followers.. If you are a Buddha followers or admirer this is a must. The place is crowded, people praying, lots of rules to look at a Jade buddha that is so far away from view. Not worth it, unless it were free which it is not. I was not impressed at all, not pleasant visit because of the crowds and the followers.

Elegant and mesmerizing. The structures in the compound are decorated with beautiful colored glass, gold leaf, and ceramic tiles/designs. Some have mother of pearl inlay. I loved that there is an accurate miniature model of Cambodia's Angkor Wat on the temple patio. Inside the hall where the emerald buddha is enshrined is an amazing collection of golden buddhas. The paintings on the walls of the high-ceiling chamber are gorgeous as well! Around the temple are gigantic guardians stationed at the entrances, angel and demon statues that depict the rich culture of thailand. The walls around the courtyard depict the history and epic stories of thailand. Beautiful paintings! They register well in photos. I also loved the pyramid with the monkey God. Quite charming.I didn't like that it was just so hot!!!! Pls. bring water to drink and a hat or an umbrella. Dehydration and heat stroke are possibilities.

Crowded. I have been here several times in the past 30 years, but this time it made me don't want to return, there is people every where, you can't take pics and examine art works properly, entry fee is 400bath, emerald Buddha hall is very nice and peaceful but people keep tripping over me while I sit there for 30 mins. Recommended just once if you haven't been but that's enough.
Very Good. I like the Emerald Budda but You couldnt get to close to see it and had to take a picture from the doorway

Emerald Buddha. one has to capture the Emerald Buddha in the mind's eye only as photography is not permitted in there.
The stunning gold work and the Green Buddha makes you realise how miniscule and little you as a human being are.
Serene. A place of quiet in a busy city. Do not worry about leaving your shoes out front - they are safe.
Beautiful, ornate. Very beautiful temple in the palace complex. A must-see if you are in Bangkok

Beautiful. Really intricate complex, leave a couple of hours for it at least. There's also the Grand Palace and Queen Sirikit's Silk Museum on the same site too, whose entrance fees are included in the ticket. Lots of pretty photo opportunities!

Pretty, sure, but overrated. The place is beautiful. Know before you go that there is only one entrance. People are told that feet must be covered, but I saw women throughout the wat and the palace with open-toed shoes. It was extremely crowded. Wat Pho is much more enjoyable, less chaotic, and there is a wonderful massage school there.

Nice temple. Its slightly differnt temple , but again if you have seen a few more before this , you might not spend so much time around. but overall its a good visit....
This is also seen from the chao praya river cruise in the night and is very well lit , looks beautiful .............

A quick visit for a lot of $$. Relatively speaking, you will pay for the privilege of being herded to kneel before the Emerald Buddha. It's pretty, but how much can one see from the forced floor position? If you don't want to kneel, you have to keep moving as you look, and you spend less than 60 seconds in the room. No photos allowed.
Worth the Trip. I liked this temple, but would rather have spent my time at Wat Pho or the Grand Palace. This was very serene and nice, though

Nice temples, but not unique. First if all this Place is really crowded, we had hundreds of Chinese around us (like in the Vimanmek Mansion too). The temples are great, although Wat Po or Wat Arun are similar and have a much better athmosphere. And this attraction is not a must have seen - I think I won't remember this Place that much in some years.

Temple of the Emerald Buddha. you can go this temple (wat) on bot and enjoy the very pretty places over that this travel is cheap but nice then you can enjoy thai food near temple from river to temple you must pay 400 bat for enterance but thai people didnt pay any it close at noon for 2 hours place is very nice very clin e and you can see very pretty trees there you cant take a picture of budda but we must respect thair belives see the pictures i take

Amazing!. Located in the Grand Palace and an amazing temple. The Emerald Buddha is smaller than I thought and you cant take pictures but it is really cool. I recommend getting the free guided tours as I learned a lot from the guide that I wouldn't have normally!

Emerald Budda. One of my first encounters with a Thai temple
There was a group of young Monks entering the temple at the same time we were arriving and their chanting need s to be heard
Very impressive
Part of the grande palace. This is a must see part of the grande palace, which is a must do day trip whilst in Bangkok! If you are only going to see one palace make sure this is the one!!

It's the Heart of Thai Buddhism.... This temple is so special that they have no Monk live in the temple. becasue it's a Royal family's temple which is situated inside the Grand Palace. I can not elaborate in details be cause it's so much to talk about ,you have to see with your own eyes. All I can say is " Oh, my God...WOW "....

Beautiful and majestic!. I knew the emerald buddha was quite small so that didn't come as a surprise. But the small size seemed to add to the enchantment of it. So different from the recling buddha and in some ways more emotional to see it as it is viewed from a distance.
Stunning. If you visit Bangkok, you must visit this Temple inside the Grand palace. This was my second visit to it & I was still in awe of how beautiful & how peaceful the temples are.

Great place,. If you are interested in Thai culture and history, it's a must do. You get to know more about Budhism as well.If you would like to take nice photos, it's a must do.tips:Men and women, they have to wear long pants and short sleeves (shorts and cut shirts are not allowed). If you can not or you forgot, you can even buy or rent from outside the temple. (40 to 50 THB

Great experience. After you worm your way around the Grand Palace you will come across the Emerald Buddha. Use your map that you receive upon paying a 400 baht entry fee to the Grand Palace. There are plenty of signs around the area. You may wish to pay for a recorded device to get you around the area. The Emerald Buddha is not very big itself but the Temple that it is housed in is spectacular. Men must wear long trousers and women must cover their shoulders and wear a long dress or similar (sarong). You are required to remove your shoes prior to entry into the Temple (no responsibility taken by Management for lost shoes- wear an old pair). Please be careful with your money and belongings- there are signs up everywhere giving you warnings. Enjoy the experience and take lots of photos from the outside- no photos permitted inside of the Temple.
15 minutes by speed boat. You can take a walk just 5 minutes to Wat rachasinkorn port. and take a speed bost to be there. Or another way by take a taxi just 20 muniutes to reach Emerald Buddha.

Stunning temple. This is one of the things everyone should see in Bangkok. A. because it's so famous and B. because it is so beautiful. You can really appreciate Thai religious art and architecture when you visit a place like this. Remember to dress and behave appropriately because this is a living temple still used every day for practising religion.
Part of The Grand Palace Complex. One of the main reasons for visiting Bangkok. If heading for Chiang Rai or Laos, learn the history about the Emerald Buddha and it all falls into place

Well worth a visit. I'd suggest definitely taking some time out to visit this temple. The architecture of the buildings in this complex is great to see with fantastic attention to detail. And it's inside the Grand Palace area so you can do it all one trip.

you have to see the Emerald Buddha.. If you’re in Bangkok, you have to see the Emerald Buddha.
We had a great time and it makes a lot of difference if you have a good guide with you. Learning about the cultural history and seeing he place is a geat experience
Tiny Gem. Make sure you pay attention to the small green lovely Buddha.....

A must see in Bangkok. To try and describe the Emerald Buddha would be like trying to explain how ice cream tastes... You need to make the time and go and see this absolutely beautiful Emerald Buddha for yourself and learn about its history. Simply ''one of a kind'' and amazing!

A Must See in Bangkok. If you’re in Bangkok, you have to see the Emerald Buddha. The rest of the grounds too are worth a visit. You will get a lot more out of it if you have a good guide, particularly if you’re interested in that sort of thing.Be warned, there are heaps of people, and you will have to jostle a little to get a look at the Buddha. Of course, be respectful as it’s religion rather than tourism for most. There’s also a dress code, so make sure you’re covered up. We had an American muppet in our tour group with three quarter length pants who held us all up for half an hour while she negotiated with the staff at the front gate about which sarong they’d make her wear. Seriously?The Emerald Buddha itself is quite small, but when you consider it’s emerald, it’s very impressive. Tick it off your bucket list.

Superb. Out the front you might be persuaded to take the 20 baht took-took deal. It takes you all over the area to visit one temple (Standing Buddha) and then a half dozen jewellery shops and tailors. I loved cruising around Bangkok in the back of a took-took, but it's not for everyone. Lovely driver. I bought some silver, earrings, and mementos and it still only cost me 800 baht (AUD26) all up.Wat Phra Kaeo was unlike anything I've seen. Take it slowly, savour it. Be sure to wear something with sleeves and long pants/skirt. They will hire you the gear (good easy system and deposit returned) but easier with your own. Sit for a moment to take in the full glory of it all.
Beautiful. but very busy - not really enough time to see it all and no photos allowed inside.
Marvelous. The temple is so peaceful and quiet. It is a marvelous cultural experience.

Feast for the Eyes. This is a must see when you visit Bangkok. Although the Emerald Buddha itself is quite small, but the temple itself is amazing! The intricate artistry of the ceiling and the walls is just awe inspiring. I was speechless when I went inside the temple. It was really a grand feast for the eyes, and the soul.

Great Architecture. All is good and a great experience, the people around the place as well monuments there. We had a great time and it makes a lot of difference if you have a good guide along with you. Knowing the history and culture of the place is awesome in itself. A must visit if you around the corner.
Awesome Temple. The surroundings are special and when you get to the actual temple, the quietness and mistic is special. No pictures insode the temple for good reasons
time with citizens. read about buddism and Hinduism before you go there, then look around the walls, it will make you more interesting!

My first Wat of many... :-). This was the first Wat I experienced in Bangkok & was amazed! This is a wonderful place to take pictures & it’s located on the grounds of the Royal Palace. You must wear long pants & shoes. Because of the heat; I would suggest visiting here first thing in the morning. If your hotel isn’t too far you can return & change to shorts OR take a pair of shorts in your backpack. (visited Nov 08)
Beautiful, peaceful place to visit!. Great place to visit...much history and culture here. Very well maintained and beautiful!

Must see. A great wat to see, large, with a variety of things to explore. The temple of Emerald Buddha a must (dress appropriately, or they will supply modes clothing for you). Well worth the trouble getting there and the visit.

Attractive place!. Lovely place where you could easily spend couple of hours if you are interested in History and appreciate the beauty of century old structures. A Guide will definitely help you to get up-close with the importance of this place. I found free Guide service in English every half an hour and utilized it. Its about 40 mins.I was told that i have to dress appropriately (as per temple rules) to enter inside and did so. But to my surprise i still saw many visitors who were against the dress code of the temple.

Such elegance. The Emerald Buddha is located at the Grand Palace. My husband and I thought we would "quickly" walk throuhg but we were off by a couple of hours. The palace is beautiful and the Temple of the Emerald Buddha was spectacular. We were completly inthrawled and lost time as we walked the grounds.
Wow. The emerald Buddha was a lot smaller than I first thought, but very beautiful. The grounds were so pretty. Just remember to put a light cardigan on.

famous temple. this one is famous for the golden buddha made completely out of gold (claimed to be 99% pure). the temple structure is slightly different from others and it is located slightly on a higher altitude. Lot of steps to walk but it is worth doing. there is a small temple within the premises which is worth a visit.

Another must-see. A most beautiful Buddha among many other beautiful Buddha statues. I will echo another reviewer: please be respectful and dress appropriately (shoulders covered; no shorts; long pants or ankle-length skirts).
small but well formed. respect at all times on this visit and you can see why the atmosphere is reverent and even though the jade Buddha is really small it is so beautiful.
What a sight!. Huge, straight up, hard to get good pics as you are so close to it and it goes straight up! A must see!
Must see bring little binoculars. Very interesting story behind this Buddha this was one of the 4 temples in our tour beautiful.

Enjoy, but be respectful. Do not bypass this as you walk the palace grounds. Just follow the simple requests regarding your clothing and shoes. I saw one woman trying to argue what she was wearing wasn't bad. It was. If you want to be ready for Saturday night, go out on Saturday night, but not to a shrine. While you are in there do take a look around at some of the bequests people have left for Buddha (grandfather clocks!).
nice but look like.... this place is nice to visit but look like tourist trap .

very respected. the emerald buddha image is actually made of jade. but the ambiance and reverence inside the temple is very calming and peaceful.the complex is wonderful.a must see attraction in bangkok. other temples inside the complex is a great statement for thai architectural style. the depiction of ramayana on the walls is good.i am from india, the original land of ramayana,so feel very close to thailand

Small but impressive.. You will find this little guy within a temple located in the grounds of the grand palace. Admission to see the Emerald buddha is included in the ticket price that you pay to get into the grand palace. You need to cover your shoulders and wear long trousers or a skirt (ankle length) otherwise you can hire appropriate clothing at the entrance.
Still wonderful place. Wonderfull feel everytime to visit hear.Landmark of Bangkok. Must visit when you visit Bangkok.

A Really Cool Experience. Definitely put this location on your touring plans for Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha is certainly a sight to see. It's likely to be very, very crowded here. And, if you're not a Thai citizen, you might have to wait in line a bit longer than the locals. When I visited, foreigners had to wait until the top of the hour to get in while Thais were allowed immediate access. I wasn't concerned about that. Also, if you're a female, you will need to wear a long skirt to cover your legs. Men will need to wear long pants to do the same thing. If you arrive and you're wearing shorts or a short skirt, there are folks outside who will rent these garmets to you for a small amount of money.

enthralling. for 400 baht you can see Huge and magnificent temple, dedicated to Buddha. Explore Thai culture with a free guide in English, see works of art up close and hear fascinating stories from Thailand (Siam) history.

Spectacular. The tourist spots,temples palaces of Bangkok are well worth a visit and leaves one dazzled with the rich culture and histroy of the country.But a word of caution the people in around these spots are mostly petty crooks and make the entire experince unsavoury,really surprised that the authorities are taking no steps at all to control this menace.

A must see. This was a very good visit my only problem was the heat and the shear amount of people site seeing. the Buddha is an amazing sight as is the the whole temple take plenty of water as you will need it as it gets very warm

colorful wonder. this wat is in the vicinity of the royal grand palace.architectural splendour with plethora of colours along with lush green lawns with neatly trimmed trees... what can i say more!!! its absolutely superb!! though one has to dress conservatively for the temple and the grand palace... bare legs and bare shoulders are a strict no... though the shops over there provide covering!!
Amazing. As with everything in Bangkok this was just fantastic. A very special place and amazing to see.

MUST SEE for traveller. i always stop and visit Wat Phra Kaeo, the located within the Royal Grand Palace compound, you can easily go either by express river boats or private longtail boat (after klong tour) then get off at Tha chang pier and walk to visit local market or amulet market before walk up to the main entrance of the Royal Palace and visit to Wat Phra Kaeo

Unbelievably beautiful. This was one of the most beautiful temple complexes that we visited during our time in Bangkok. The architecture is amazing, and the decorative detail is spectacular – especially the use of gold and mosaic mirrors on the outside decoration. This is a large temple complex with many different sights in different architectural styles, but the highlight is the temple containing the Emerald Buddha image – the gold decoration work on the outside of the temple is breathtaking to see.The architecture and decoration of the entire temple complex is a photographers dream, however photography is not allowed inside the main temple, but it is possible to take a photograph of the Buddha image from the outside if you zoom in. The Emerald Buddha image is extremely beautiful and the gold clothing the Buddha is dressed in is very elaborate and intricate. One thing to remember is that as this is a royal premises, you need to dress respectfully and long trousers are a must as you will not be allowed in wearing shorts etc. (for both male and female visitors) You will also need to remove your shoes before entering the temple.
Beautiful. good value for money great Thai experience would probably only go the once though!
