Stunning - requires adequate clothing. A must see in Bangkok. Great beauty.Remember long trousers and adequate clothing as it is a holy place.And it gets very very hot, so bring lots of water.The cabs outside the temple charges overprices (many times more than in other places). Instead use the waterbus on the river. It's cheep and also a very authentic experience.

The kinga palace. Wow ... one word describes it all. The palace is rich and the workmanship is even richer. There are a number of smaller temples , model of angkor wat and ramayana drawings scattered around the compound. Dont forget to take a guide though as its worth every baht.
Emerald Budha. Best to get there early say at 9 am and be prepared to walk a lot. It can take almost 2 hours to see the whole temple and palace its in
A Must Visit Place. Magnificent architecture & breath taking deign. Simply majestic

Temple of Emerald Buddha. Another beautiful setting.Our tour guide was able to put the various ages/meanings of these Buddhas into context and it may be worth your while getting someone or some info to really put these marvellous places into context.
Certainly to be seen. and combine it with a visit to Wat Pho, which is within walking distance
Make sure to wear pants. Otherwise you have to rent them... The temple is amazing and well worth it. Everything is in this area so wearing pants expect to sweat a lot.
Emerald Budda. Truly a wonderful sight. Thai history there for all to see and be amazed.

Humbling experience, beautiful site.. If you are into ancient history this place is a must-see, the entire grounds are beautiful and steeped in Thai history. The Emerald Buda and the building it is in was as if the world went into slow motion, it was a fantastic day. Be aware of scam artists if you make your way there on foot.
Interesting. It's a pity you cant make photos inside of the Wat
Grand and beautiful. Very beautiful built, very delicate details. If you are into different culture arts and architecture then this is a must visit for you!

Eye Candy. This is one of those things where words can't describe the grandeur and beauty. Too much to even describe. Bottom line - have lots of time on your hands, a good camera, and a couple bottles of water. Also, make sure you go with long pants - if not it's no biggie - they give you a pair of comfortable linen pants to wear for deposit of 200 baht. There are people on the outside trying to make money by selling things to you - can't blame them - we all have to survive. I bought lots of good stuff from the street hustler's outside the palace. I still envision the place in my head.

Lovely. I was actually quite impressed. The whole palace sight is brilliant, straight out of the king and I. The temple was a really spiritual place, actually felt quite touched, don't know why, but there is something about that place.
Fantastic. The statues of the Buddhas were a sight to behold.
Nice temple. This place is a must to visit and very culturally enlightening I recommend the visitors to go there
Wow! Highlight of trip to Bangkok. This is an amazing place to visit. Beautiful, well kept and interesting.
Don't miss the Emerald Buddha. First class temple. It is a holy relic and a tourist attraction which can not be missed in Bangkok. Appropriate dress is required and good behavior expected.

A must see while visiting Wat Pho. Located quite close to Chao Phraya River, this temple hosts the famous Emerald Buddha. Situated inside the complex of Grand Palace, this place is highly secured will huge temple walls and security guards all around. Entry is bit expense but worth the visit. On one side is Bangkok exhibition center and huge park, on other side is Wat Pho (the temple of reclining buddha). Visitors are expected to strictly follow the dress code. Would recommend everyone to visit at least once.

always attracted. this is the 4th time for me to Thailand also the 4th time to Wat Phra Kaeo and Grand Palace. but it is so unique and decent so it is still not boring to see again. i took a big group of friends this time and everyone can't help to see and take photos all the time.you also can feel how sacred and special it is when you are walking in it

Expensive. 800 Baht Expensive for palace visit. Also people wearing inappropriate cloths were restricted entry and this left many tourists to wait in a queue for change of cloths. The beauty of the Temple was amazing, the Buddha carved in emerald is amazing. It is a lot smaller than I expected, but is carved from one large piece of emerald. This place is overcrowded with many tour groups going in and out of the area.
See it while also visiting Wat Pho. If you go here to see the Emerald Buddha you might be disappointed, but you shouldn't be disappointed with everything around the Emerald Buddha.

Special place. I liked just being there in such a special place to so many people and the importance of this wat. I dislike the tourists that do not have respect for the NO PHOTOGRAPHY rule and Wearing inappropriate clothing.
decent. temples everywhere - this one is just another one to see, nothing extraordinary but enjoyable - a good sized complex made this a worthwhile stop off
Beautiful little buddha. This little emerald buddha has seasonal golden clothing and sits on his throne in a stunning room within the Grand Palace and is definitely worth a visit

Ok. Adjoining palace is nice. But expensive. Expensive for an hour's worth. TB 400 for adult. Children above 120-cm (literally) are treated as adults. Weird that in most countries children below age of 12 are treated as "child" category for pricing.
beautiful. Smaller that I thought but the Emerald Buddha is beautiful and worth the visit.
The only temple, you can't be missed.. If you have a chance to visit Bangkok, this is the first list of temple you must visit.
Lots of gold!. I loved learning about the history of this Buddha, and how his attire is changed according to the seasons
Small but impressive!. This representation of the Buddha carved in emerald is amazing. It is a lot smaller than I expected, but is carved from one large piece of emerald - awesome!

awesome. The entire place was gold gold gold. the management did a good job protecting their visitors. hahahha... there was a repeated announcement warning visitors of those tuk tuk swindlers who might 'delay' your visit to the grand palace. there was an entrance fee of 400 baht and you could get appropriate clothing for free. (long pants for men, sarong for ladies). it was very hot so remember sunblock, hats and fans. the temple of the emerald buddha was at the heart of the grand palace. actually it was a little overcrowded with many tour groups going in and out of the area. but it was definitely worth the visit. just avoid the crowd ://
so small!. You can't photograph this from the inside but you can right outside the door. Better bring your telephotolens because it's a small statue.

It's not Emerald but still breathtaking. Leave your camera at the door. Sit down. Enjoy the atmosphere and the true prayer that is going on in this temple. It's hard to remember because of all the tourists trying to get photos that it's a shrine, but it is. Soak it in and say a prayer.
Amazing!!!. A must see whilst in Bangkok!!! It was an amazing place.. You must cover your shoulder ladies and no shorts
No photos inside. Very calm within the temple. Found removing shoes annoying, so would suggest you wear sandals that slip off easily. Colours are amazing.

Very small Buddha but in the Grand Palace.... The Grand Palace was very impressive, lovely architecture, a mixture of Thai, Chinese and Western. The Emerald Buddha is very small, only two feet and you cannot take pictures inside the temple. You can try to take one from outside but it is rather tricky.
Emerald Budda is a Historical Sight. Located in the Palace area, the Emerald Budda has historical significance but it a secondary sight.

£10 to enter/careful of misguiding info. it was pretty and probably worth the £10. main thin you have to be careful of people on the streets that tell you that you cannot enter as it is closed or give you wrong directions. there is separate entrances for thai nationals and tourists but dont follow strangers advise when visiting the palace.
Excellent. Very good blessings for visiting this temple. Avoid the tour guides though, they are very expensive and highly unneccesary perhaps even irritating...
A must. Just go there, its amazing. Remenber to dress appropriatly, but if not its possible to borrow some clothes on location. Beautiful place

Peaceful and beautiful temple. We visited this temple as part of the much bigger Grand Palace complex of temples. The actual Buddha is quite small but set in amazing plinth. Highlight was being able to sit down on the Temple floor in front of it and watch worshippers nd appreciate the whole temple interior. It was a peaceful and beautiful place. Only stress is ensuring you don't point your soles towards the statue which is very disrespectful. Also interesting is that the Buddha is "dressed" in different types of wraps depending on the season. A very worthwhile place to visit in Bangkok.
A gem!. Very beautiful! Don't forget to wear something long otherwise you going need to rent some clothing at the entrance.

Worth a visit. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is worth a visit. It is an impressive shrine & and important spiritual space for Thai Buddhism. Be aware that it sometimes closes, as it did the day we were there. But, there were plenty of signs letting us know that fact and we got in before it was closed off by re-arranging our plan to visit the Grand Palace. It was sunny & really hot, plus 35 C without the humidity, so bring water. be prepared to cover up out of respect. They can provide the attire if you do not want to bring it.

Must visit .... We took a free conducted tour inside the temple and it was just excellent. The lady was very knowledgable and witty, giving us time to ask questions and sharing fascinating stories about the complex. The main temple was lovely, with a very small Buddha statue on top ... beautifully decorated overall. Must visit with a guide to understand and enjoy the history

Small but great Buddha. With my experience from Myanmar, I thought Emerald Buddha will be big. But, it a small Buddha image. When I visit there I cannot see the image closely as it small and place in high place.
Lots of worshippers, beatufil peaceful place. Many people come here daily to worship, it's got quite a mystic draw. Also the Grand Palace is really grand. Be carefule in hot weather, it's really hot.

One of the main areas to visit along with the Grand Place, Wat Po, Wat Arun. I would rate as a traveler, After the Grand Place, Wat Arn, Wat Po. No pictures allowed in the Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaeo) Sold in a separate area. Worth seeing a treasure to the people of Thailand.
Emerald Buddha. Wow. I was impressed with the dedication of the people in Thailand to their God and King. This was part of the day trip we did with Wandee Tours and it was great.
Wat Phra Keo, the beautiful Emerald Buddha Temple.. The most important Buddhist temple in Thailand.Buddha image in the meditating position - Thai people most respectfully.
Combined with Grand Palace great place. Must visit. Some restoration work ongoing but huge complex and something amazing round every corner. Very special place.

Absolutely Amazing. its stunning, be prepared to walk and climb many stairs, lots to see on the way, the Buddha is visible from outside on the top level if you don't want to pay the extra to go in, they change the clothes he is wearing regularly, unlike the golden huge statues this one is smaller but truly remarkable, a must see, remember to dress in a respectful way and remove your shoes if you enter any inside area, take in the wonder of a past era and feel the calm
A bit a Thai attraction point. But as part of the all setting of the Grand Palace it is beautiful.
Respect the praying visitors!. You're not allowed to take pictures of the Emerald Buddha, yes. so show some respects to those who are praying there.
Great experience. The sheer opulence of the palace, then to see the emerald buddha and witness what it means to the people of bangkok

Best Tour Guide Ever!!!. Dec 2009Disclaimer: Make sure you are dressed appropriately to go to the Wat! If not, you can rent appropriate clothing once you get there for a minimal price! I had already researched it, so we were ok, but many people were not.The Wat was AMAZING! We had the best guide (provided at the Wat) and were awe struck. There were many artisans working various restoration projects and that was really cool to see. We did go inside the temple building that houses the Emerald Buddha. No cameras or photos are allowed... but, I have a nice zoom on my camera so, I was able to get a photo from outside of the building. LOL. Interesting fact: the Buddha's clothes are changed to match the season! Who would of thought?! Anyways, it is a must see. Expect to spend some time here. It takes a nice long stroll to truly look at everything ( and take photos) ! Enjoy!
What a beautiful palace. It is gorgeous. There's nothing like it. Worth a visit

Really very touchy place!. I have been reading the books about Buddha and i loved to be find more about Buddha! that is why i visit the temple. If you're in thailand and you are suppose to be the follower of fan of Gautama Buddha then you should visit the temple.
My favourite temple in BKK. Loved it here; the intricate and detailed work on the temple buildings is fantastic. So soothing as well, even with the big crowds. A definite highlight for me

Temple of the Emeral Buddha. This was very interesting as I had not expected the buddha to be so small. There were crowds and one felt that you couldnt stay too long as you were holding up everyone else wanting to visit but all the visitors were polite and interested to go inside so the overall feeling was expectant.Beautiful and the surrounding carvings are also very beautiful.
Palace Wat. Always a great experience to visit the Grand Palace and see this Wat. This is the most important Wat in Thailand

Amazing. Shining, Shimmering Splendid. There are people who are trying to divert you to some place and try to make money from you never listen to the local people outside the Temple. Never wear reavealing clothes no tube / no sleeveless dresses, men should wear pants no shorts.

Quite a experience. Beautiful to see. Felt so good to sit in silence inside the temple. It was a hot day and we were kind of feeling bad. But a few minutes in front of the buddha and we felt so much better and energised. Magical.
Beautiful. All the temples are amazing, this is one of the better ones.
Great to see.... I forced my wife and toddler around the sites and this one was worth it too! What a history - and what culture. Worth it!
happy buddha. It was fantastic to see something so old but so well preserved, but the crowds are spoil the experience a bit.
Tad disappointing. expected too much...what i found was a small buddha statue hoisted on a large stand in the distance. however, overall serenity of the place is very good

One of the more spectacular temples. The Emerald Buddha in itself is quite little - even though I knew it was small, I was still surprised by just *how* small. You actually have to look quite hard to find it at first! It's still well worth the effort (and the crowds) for it's cultural and religious significance. The temple complex it's located in is also very spectacular with beautiful detail on the buildings. Make sure you dress appropriately - women must wear a skirt or dress, or full-length trousers, men must wear shorts than cover the knees, and everyone must have covered shoulders. You should actually follow this dress code in all temples (women can get away with long shorts everywhere but at this one, never short shorts though), but it will be enforced here. If you forget, you can hire clothing inside the entrance. Don't get the overpriced stuff from the vendors on the street outside.
Amazing. I felt amaze with the beauty and work of the whole temple, Its cravint, ceiling, painting walls, The outside and the inside of the temple.Gorgeous.

pretty. It was a little underwhelming considering the heat and the size of the structure itself. the internet pictures make it look much larger. also photos are not allowed inside. We also found out that the emerald Buddha isn't actually emerald but Jade.That was a little disappointing. WE had to take off our shoes before entering which I thought was pretty cool since the temple was so clean. We took lots of amazing pictures and it was a generally amazing trip

Wat Phra Kaeo. Home to the most revered Buddha image in the Kingdom, this green jadeite is clothed in golden finery. The clothes are changed three times a year to correspond with the change of seasons, Ho, Cool and rainy. The garments are usually changed by the King or his representative. The small museum located in back of the image is another hidden jewel that is owrth the trip. Although usually crowded with a mixture of tourists and local Thais, the exquisite temple is well worth the wait. Included in the admission price of the Gtand Palace.

quite amazing. It was incredibly hot so take a lot of water, wear cotton(you must cover your arms)& take an umbrella for shade. Take an extra memory card because we took SO many pictures! You cannot take pictures of the actual Buddha but of everything else, including the palace, the guards, the surrounding temples etc. The history is amazing - you should have a guide, we did and he explained a LOT we never would have found out had we gone on our own. His name was Tao and he worked for Tourism Thailand.

Get a Guide and go early, well worth it. We only went to this, the most holy and revered temple in Bangkok and loved the experience, as an insight to how much the Thai people love their royal family and Buddhism. Our guide was great, taking us under the model of Angor Wat as this is perceived as lucky by the Thai people - explaining the links between Hinduism and Buddhism and explaining the wonderful mural that goes along the cloisters... loved it - the emerald buddha himself was tiny, perched high above so much gold you are quite dazzled....

Crowded, not high on my list. Bangkok has a lot of temples and I tried to see most of them. This one was highly recommended and with the expensive ticket price, I was hoping to be amazed. I was not. The place was packed with tourists and they came in large groups. It was chaotic. I tried to avoid the crowd to appreciate the Temple of the Emerald Buddha but I was not successfully because the place was really packed. The Emerald Buddha is really small and visitors were not allowed to take pictures inside. I spent a lot of time outside on the grounds looking at the structures. They were magnificent but not mind-blowing. Not worth the money.

Tour guides. We hired a private guide to take us around. Cost around £40 for the both of us but it was well worth it. He was extremly knowledgable & interesting & really enhanced the trip. Also acted like our personal photographer.

Interesting place to visit. It was interesting to see the connection between religion and government while at this temple. There were many devout Buddhists there offering praise to the Buddha and even more tourists to see the sights. Certainly worth seeing once for a tourist.
Bangkok must see. its a place to see. Crowded by day try to visit as early as possible as it gets hod near midday
Wonderful. What a privilege to be able to see this beautiful Buddha. Its smaller than I expected and further from view, but still wonderful.

Busy tourist place. Despite this place is super busy it is part of the Grand Palace complex and well worth visiting. Dress covering shoulders and knees is OK, long pants for men...or there is a free hire with deposit you get back when you return your pants. 350 bath entrance fee covers the entire Grand Palace plus entry to Vimanmek Mansion.

Packed, but worth it to check it out. As others have said, the Emerald Buddha is not very big but it still huge in terms of being made of solid emerald. The crowds get pretty big - go in the morning or evening rather than the middle of the day. Be sure to dress modestly.

Keep it clean keep it green. It was great, as I always say, the wow factor is there with ancient Thai architecture and the awe.
Must visit
Magnificent architecture. Located in the same premise as the Grand Palace. Beautiful architecture.
Busy but worth a look. Very busy and smaller than many expect but worth a look

Beautiful and Super. Very nice place and a must visit for a tourist. 400 bath entry for tourist. Guide can be taken for 200 bath. But we went alone and saw the places inside.
There is a app for iphone which have all the audio files with description download before you go.

Not as big as I thought. A beautiful temple inside the Royal Palace. I was surprised at the size of the Emerald Buddha, for some reason I expected it to be much larger. That being said, a visit to the temple with the accompanying visit to the Royal Place is a must when in Bangkok
So neat. We went to this Wat first, and were a bit overwhelmed-soo much to see and learn about but well worth it!
loved it. We visited the temple of the reclining buddha and absolutely loved it. I particularly like the giving of coins.
A Very beautiful temple. It is a very beautiful temple, from outside as well as from Inside. The efforts that have been taken to maintain these cultural sites are really appreciable.
Great. The Emerald Buddha is a must see, but as it is small in size it won't take your breath away. However the whole complex will so it's worth visiting.
Beautiful temple. The Budha is small and crowds are large but when in Rome..

Wat Phra Kaeo- Emerald Buddha temple. Nice Ambience, Nice & Calm atmosphere, In Grand Palace Complex , Now the timing for Grand Palace is till 4.00 PM. The enterance to Grand palace includes Entance to the temple
Chaotic. It was hot and chaotic and not even high season. Women must wear sleeves and long pants or be stuck wearing rental clothes. Can't be sanitary. Worth a visit but not #1.
Great place to visit. The temple is beautiful. The buildings/sculptures surrounding this temple are really nice.
worth the sight. the temples are great. the experience is like something we have never seen

You have to visit this at least once. This is worth the entrance price the first time you go which is now 400 baht, but I remember paying only 150 baht when I went for the first time. The hall of the Emerald Buddha is beautiful. Check out the murals! In fact, most of the walls of the buildings there have been hand painted. It is nice to have a look at the different styles of architecture around the Grand Palace. TIPS:1. You can visit the Grand Palace, Wat Pho and the City Shrine in about three hours or so because they are all right near each other on the East side of the river. If you want to add one more hour or so, Wat Arun is on the opposite side of the river across from the Grand Place. You can take a ferry from Tha Chang to get there. 2. You can avoid the traffic by taking the BTS to Sapan Taksin and then get off and go down to the water's edge to take a cheap boat ride (great scenic views) to Tha Chang. This will put you behind the Grand Palace and Wat Pho and right across from Wat Arun. (Take a ferry across the river to Wat Arun. Ignore the touts who will try to get you to buy their boat service rather than the very cheap ferry service that the locals use.) 3. The City Shrine where you can see the city's pillar is just across the street and to the left of the Grand Palace. This attraction is free. 4. Make sure you wear formal clothes and that your feet are covered or Thai guards will not allow you in as you are. There are clothes to "borrow" but other tourists have worn them before you. However, bring lose fitting shoes that will properly cover your feet because you will have to take your shoes off to go inside most of the buildings there.5. Take your picture with the elaborately dressed guards who have to stand at attention at various places. The locals do it so so can you. 6. You will get a coupon to go and visit the Teak Palace so make sure you visit the temples in the morning and then hail a taxi to head over to "We-wan-make" to see the world's largest teak palace for free. The teak palace will close around four or so and is definitely worth the visit.
Emerald Buddha. Don't be like some other reviews I heard and expect a large Buddha. It is a single stone, put that in context of what you would expect to see. It is beautiful.

Small Emerald Buddha but ornate temple is a must see. Take off your shoes and point your feet away from Buddha. I was not impressed because the Buddha was so small but the whole temple made it worth while
Beautiful. Very beautiful...do a private tour and do not go ut in the stifling heat

Crowded but a must. We thought that going in the morning was a good idea to beat the heat...but everyone was thinking the same and the place was crowded. And the temperature was so HOT! Still, a must in BKK.Ladies, cover your shoulders and knees, you don't want to be stuck for half an hour in the blouse and skirt rental line up. And don't bother bringing a sarong as I did, this is the only shrine/temple where the sarong was not good enought to cover my shoulders. I had to rent an UGLY blouse, happily I didn't had to wait to rent it, but when we were leaving the temple at about 1pm, the line up was huge.

Stunning blink blink building;). Thai fancy with shiny gold color and this grand palace really good at it. The sun ray that shining on BKK almost the entire year is really helpful to create that goldie blink blink looks. Entrance fee is 400 baht for foreigners per May 2012 (free for local Thai). Bit pricey than other attractions. U can find green emerald Buddha in this place too. Make sure u see it properly because it is mounted high on top of the altar and the statue is not that big as expected. Located near Tha Chang pier. Always take 'orange flag' boat for flat fee of 15 baht only to any piers. Easy to remember n no need to think about other boat with different flag or taking more expensive tourist boat.
Quick stop worthy. Interesting statue and madly ornate interior of building housing, but as a stand alone site, quite average.

stunning detail!. the temple is so beautiful that the camera doesn't do any justice! is a shame that you cannot go inside the temple, to visit this site has a small fee that is included with the Grand palace and a guide map is given for free. oh well is recommended that you go with a guide(in the entrance of the grand palace). Take the guides that are INSIDE, because are the official ones, there's many languages available.
very beautiful temple. it is must a visit to this beautiful Buddha temple

One of my favorite attractions in all of Thailand!. Beautiful place w/ lots of history. Be ready to fight the crowds & take lots of pictures. Beware of Tuktuk drivers & cabbies in this area. They all have agreements w/ tailor & gem stores to bring in tourist...regardless of where you want to go. Every twenty paces on the sidewalk brings another scam. Arrange your transportation ahead of time...this is a good place to use a tour service.
A must visit. Great visit and make sure you have a reputable guide to show you around and share the little inisghts
cannot take pictures. the place is very crowded and you can only use your eyes to look but cannot take any pictures

Breathtaking beautiful temple complex. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is one of many on the temple complex, The whole complex is breathtaking beautiful. All statues etc are inlayed with colored little mirrors and everything flases and shines where ever you look. The emerald buddha had different clothing which are changed with the season. I loved this temple and the green buddha...

Guided tours are worth it. Very interesting but very very busy and hot so be prepared and take water in with you. We got a guide from just inside the gate (about £12 for 90 mins) and was well worth it to get more information about Thai history and culture and the building, architecture and design.

Nice. It's worth visiting, but it's quite expensive (400 bath) compared to all the other temples.
In order to get in, you need to dress properly.
A scarf to cover up your arms isnt enough.
I would advise to visit it in the morning, since it gets really hot between 11H & 14H
History and beauty. This temple houses the gorgeous Emerald Budda and whilst the Budda is small, it is beautiful and the history so interesting

Jade Buddha actually. Inner peace, a beautiful statue, the grand palace is great but entry closes at 3.30 pm. Ensure you slot at least 2 hours, the architecture, paintings and walls are beautiful. Carry extra batteries and bottles of water as nothing is sold inside
must see. An important part of seeing Bangkok... should go with a local guide... we loved Ms. Pu from Chob Private Guides... she is very passionate about her country's culture.

Great historical and cultural attraction. Visit earlier in the day before the tour groups arrive. No shorts. It is a unique historical and cultural attraction. Lots to see and appreciate in the grounds.
True beauty. The age and beauty are remarkable. To see such a specimen of jade and workmanship..

Great displays. While one goes to this temple to see the Emerald Buddha, there is also much to see in the displays of artefacts in glass cases around the walls. You could spend an hour or here rather than rushing in, having a quick look and going out again.

Got Me Interested.... I visited Wat Phra Kaeo on my last day in Bangkok, by the time I was leaving I didn't know whether I had much sight-seeing left in me, however the temple (Inside of the Grand Palace) is wonderful. If you can ignore the swarms of other tourists and appreciate it, the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a great place and a very fitting end to my travels!

Quite small, difficult to see. While I imagine the Emerald Buddha is quite nice, I am not able to make an assessment, as the Buddha sits quite high above the floor, and is far from the viewing area.For worshippers, this is likely a must-see. However, if you are simply going to have a look at the Buddha as a sculpture, this is less ideal than visit to Reclining Buddha.
excellent. Stunningly maintained, wonderful temples and Thailand culture at it's best, certainly "the must see/do in the capital
Green. Stunning to see, but busy, go early in the day and ignore the comments from those outside saying it is shut. Worth getting a guide for the full understanding
Most sacred site. Inside the Golden Palace is this temple with a tiny jade buddha inside it but it is the most sacred site to the Thai people

Not sure this should be "THE" temple to see first. Obviously most tourists would want to visit it. The first time it is pretty impressive, but if you visit other smaller temples in Bangkok, you realize that the place is a bit over-rated (and they also charge you 400TBH to get in!!). Now saying this you might still want to go there, and I would understand. But try to go there early to avoid the crowd and most important thing: DO NOT BELIEVE ANYONE IN FRONT OF THE TEMPLE WHO TELLS YOU THE TEMPLE IS CLOSED BECAUSE OF BUDDHA DAY. THIS IS A SCAM!!!
a good visit, but not a must. oner ayan. it is a nice touristic place, but not a must if you're short of time. oner ayan
Worth the time and admission fee.. Part of the Grand Palace complex. Can be crowded, but manageable. I'd suggest wearing appropriate clothes to avoid the "borrow" line and hassle.

You must visit. War Phra Kaeo is a must see in BKK. The whole temple is beautiful, and even close up it look amazing.Its also next to the royal palace, which is worth a visit too.If it is your first visit, please remember you need to wear trousers/jeans, and you need to cover your shoulders.
A bit disappointed. I though the Buddha was bigger, and I had hoped for some pictures, but no
Its amazing.. As i love temples visited many of them. I like this place very much.
A must see!. Part of the grand palace tour... its a huge temple. Definitely a must see.
Spectacular temple. The Emerald Buddha is smaller than I expected but impressive.
A must See. Go very early in the morning or as late in the day as possible. April temperatures reaching 38 degrees and very humid. Knees and shoulders must be covered

Beautiful place worth a guided tour. Visited in April together with the Royal palace.
Beautiful temple with so many historical treasures !
A guided tour is highly recommended if you want to make the most of your visit.
Tiny little man. Too many rules and the buddha is not even made of emerald.
Magnificent. Shame you can't take photos inside, only from the doorway, but building is great.
Wats up with that?. Just like the other wats, with an emerald buddha. I tell ya, once you've seen a wat, you've seen em all!
Amazing Temple. One of the cool.est and most intricate temples I've ever seen. Definitely worth it!
Must see!. The statues are stunning. Plan to spend a few hours to absorb the culture.
Now that's a small Buddha!. Only 66 cm tall and you can't get very close even with a 200 mm zoom... cute though especially with it's 'barbie' change of outfits for each season.

Incredible - but take care. An amazing place to visit, but beware even people with an official tourist guide uniform on do not tell the truth, visitors use your common sense! If you feel unsure then you probably have good reason too.
Jed buddha. Buddha statue made from jed. It look very beautiful and it have different dressing in 3 different season.
Elaborate and Beautiful. The temple is beautiful, but the Buddha is small and unimpressive compared to the elaborate decor of the rest of the temple.
Excellent Cultural Experience. The archetecture and area around the temple are exquisite. The detail in the buildings is very ornate. Even with daily crowds, the atmosphere is peaceful.

should be in the list. as it had been the royal temple for many kings. Great structure building with fine decoration represented each era can be seen. It is a mix of times, you can see it from the diversity of styles. Inside wall are painted to depict ancient tales.

The nost spectacular sight in BKK. Buddha itself is quite small - but very reverred. Blessings out the front with Lotus Buds, Shoes off, and inside to pay your respect. Dont point your feet at Buddha, no pictures, just a pure amazing experience.

Huge reclining Buddha. The complex is very crowded and can get a little hectic, but you shouldn't miss this. The grounds of this temple are loaceted adjacent to the Grand Palace. The size of this buddha is incredible.

Must See!. Definitely don't miss this temple, it's amazing. Try to go early in the morning as soon as it opens. We went at around 9:30am (caught the Chao River Express boat - in hindsight, probably get a tuk tuk, it would have been cheaper and more convenient, the Chao River boat only comes every half hour) and it was absolutely packed with people.

Smaller than I thought. It was such a hot day that we went, and very busy. The Emerald Buddha is so small and very high up, you are not allowed to take photos inside the temple, but can take some from the outside.

Busy & buzzing must-see temple. Wat Phra Kaeo is full of tourists and locals going about their devotions. It is busy and buzzing with energy just like Bangkok and has to be seen to understand. We used a local guide and got a lot more out of our trip as a result (Thai Tours)

An absolute must see!!. One of the places that you should not miss out on your first visit to Bangkok. Absolutely gorgeous place with lots of traditional thai architecture. It can get pretty crowded with lots of travel groups visiting the place daily and its is advisable that you go with a professional guide. And also its good to hold on to your wallets as there have been incidents of pick pocketing.

lovely for a view. Another lovely temple in Bangkok. Candidly, after a awhile, they all seem the same. However, the Wat Phra is definitely worthy of a least one visit. The design and architecture is ornate and amazing.
temple trip. great structure . good architecture but need a great zoom lens to actually see the emerald buddha

Worth a look!. The Emerald Buddha sits on top of lots of gold and when we were in Bangkok it was just before New Year and a holy day so everyone was giving offerings and it was really nice to see. The Emerald Buddha is impressive and should be included on any tour of Bangkok.

Very serene, spiritual place, beware of noisy husbands!. We went here with out Thai guide, it is obviously a very special spiritual place for them and felt very serene and peaceful. Have to take care to put feet behind you (advice from guide), shouldn't point towards Buddha. The Buddha is very tiny, no photos allowed but our guide took one through the doorway for us. Supposed to be very quiet while in there, unfortunately my husband found something someone said funny and has a very loud laugh - few stern looks were received.
Do not miss it!. With all the people inside quietly praying this temple has a special atmosphere.
Picture walls. The temple walls and surrounding arcade walls all have the most amazing pictures.
Amazing. I like the painting on wall is so beautiful and somebody tell us that it is a story of Ramayana, it's AMAZING.
Yes, yes, yes. Give yourself at least an hour here, it's a tiny thing but completely enchanting, very revered, lovely sanctuary.
Spiritual place. I always have too much curiosity about Buddhism I studied a lot about Buddhism and I like Buddhist because they are real peaceful fellowmen. This was real spiritual connect for me.

Emerald Buddha. The Emerald Buddha is historically significant and worshiped by Thais because of its history and the tale of its discovery. The Buddha itself cannot be dated, being discovered by accident after a plaster coating had been shattered. It occupies the most revered position in the Temple and is visited by millions each year.
Beautiful Emerald Buddha. Emerald Buddha was indeed busy but beautiful! The whole building itself is so intricately built with glass and mirrors.

We came, we saw, we left. We are not Buddhist, so we really didn't get a lot out of this excursion. There were quite a few rules to follow and it was hard for us to appreciate the historical significance.
A famous Buddha statue. This a very religious site and the emerald buddha has a strong religious significance to the Thais. Do be respectful.

Stunning temple, a must see.... As I have previously said in other reviews of Bangkoks temples, get there early to truely experience it...buses on buses of tourists arrive within a few hours of opening..It's best to hire a tour guide, we used tour with tong, or you will walk round aimlessly with no idea what everything is about or represents. One of our favourite temples in Bangkok, make sure you make time to visit.
Underwhelming. The emerald Buddha is tiny and missable... As in, you wouldn't know you'd seen in.

must see. must visit if you like to see different king of architecture. fee 400 bath. open 365 days apart if the king is visiting. very beautiful. take river taxi to N9 walk out. don't talk to any one. when you come on the main road, you will see it. it is located vitin the complex of the grand palace. go in the morning as there is less heat

One of the top ten of Bangkok. This is inside the Grand Palace (pronounced as Wat Pakyaw - sounds like that Filipino boxer) Some Thais do Not know wht Grand Palace means, but they do understand Wat Pakyaw.

First Temple Visit in Thailand. Incredible. We're glad we came to this one first, it absolutely blew us away. We arrived around 10am, which was a little late for my liking. It was very busy, and very hot, going earlier would have been better. Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the Grand Palace are in the same complex and can be done in a few hours. Simply mind blowing, the most impressive temple we saw in Thailand.
good to see. take water , hat or umbrella as walking through the palace in the heat is unbearable.
Worth a visit. But found other temples to be more impressive. Buddha was a bit small
Awsome. Next to the Grand Palace and near Wat Po. You have to go here if you go nowhere else in Bangkok. Absolutely stunning. Again take a guide as you will enjoy the experience much more.
this is unreal. Like i mentioned in all temples visited you have to be religeous or even have a belief just open your eyes and take it all in

Went by skytrain and got down at sathorn and took a boat to the temple. Very easy to do by yourself.. beautifull emerald buddha one piece of emerald, this was advised to me by the hotel reception staff of S Sukhumvit Suites the staff there were very helpful

An Amazing Sight. A must when you visit the Grand Palace, it is situated in a wonderful golden temple, and if you think the outside is grand, get yourself inside and see the full story it will be the icing on the cake
Please be respectful. This temple is gorgeous and serene, but please follow all of the instructions and leave your cameras off. Remember, this is a place of worship so act accordingly.

The Emerald Buddha (bows). In the middle of beautiful castle grounds, surrounded by fascinating shrines and memorials, lies a masterpiece of jewel artwork. Skilled guides walk around it, ready to tell the story in any language you want, each with his different aspects- religious history, royal family, magic and mistery, military. Just dress up modestly (you can rent a shirt at the entrance to the grounds) and enjoy the trip. Just bring lots of water, because Thailand is hot, and they don't sell any at the peremises- only near the exit.
A visit to Bangkok is not complete without. I have been to this temple 3 times. I would go again. A pity the statue is a little distance away.
worth it!. This was by far my favorite site in all of Bangkok! Worth the trip!

Small jewel!. Aside from this beautiful Buddha made of a single piece of green jade, the Temple itself is worth a visit. Also worth visiting is the small gallery at the right of the entrance to the palace (just before going through the ticket checkpoint) where you can see some imperial treasures, including two of the three gold outfits used by the emerald Buddha, according to the season.
A MUST SEE. Spectaular - this was truly something to be seen and remembered
Smaller than you expect. The Emerald Buddha is perched very high but is very small. There were a lot of people there but plenty of room to see. Dress appropriately
Very interesting place. You can see the Emerald Buddha, however you can not take photos inside.

Don't fall into the tourist traps. Please be careful when visiting this Wat. Our taxi driver dropped us off at the wrong entrance (on purpose), and the so-called "tourist police" tried to convince us that the Wat was closed, and that they could take us to a nearby Wat, instead. We quickly ignored them, and found our own way to the main entrance of the Wat.Once we got inside, it was absolutely beautiful and breath-taking, although very crowded with tourists. Definitely a sight to see....although I would highly recommend visiting the Wat Pho, as well. I preferred the Wat Pho to the Wat Phra - less touristy, and a big quieter and more serene. If you have time, spend about an hour at both.Don't forget to bring a longer skirt, and a pashmina/shawl to cover your shoulders.Also - extremely hot in April, so stay well hydrated.

Culture Shock - in a good way. The buildings and statues are beautiful. The Emerald Buddha itself is amazing. On our visit to the Emerald Buddha and the Grand Palace we engaged a tour guide. Jeremy was very knowledgeable and made our visit more interesting as he was able to provide historical and cultural perspective we would not have learned by just walking around.The area is crowded and the sun is hot. Much of the tour is outside so use sunscreen, or, like many locals, use a parasol.

combine with the grand palace. as this temple is in the grounds of the Grand Palace it makes sense to visit them both together. The temple is and impressive buiding with gold domes that stand out even amonght the highly decorative buildings around it.The emerald buddha is so named because of the colour and not the material as the statue is made of Jade. Disappointingly this was the only Wat I encountered where photos were not permitted inside.

Beautiful temple. Decked in gold, the temple houses the Emerald Buddha. Very beautiful color and the images on the walls depict the Buddha story. Remember to take shoes and hats off, keep quiet and keep feet away from Buddha in all temples.
Great Trip to Grand Palace. Well worth a visit to the Grand Palace. We got there by stytrain the water taxi which was really fun.

Cultural experiance. We did not have alot of time to visit the Cultural sights of Thailand and chose to see this and the Grand Palace. We went with World Travel Service Limited and really enjoyed it!!
The architecture and decoration is incredible and I felt that it was a wonderful glimpse into Thai culture.
One of the "must see" tempels. Often crouded but in my view absolutely worth a visit.
great. Typical thai temple. AAmazing craftmade. As other temple in Thailand, make sure wear a proper entire.
Crowded but beautiful.. Gorgeous craftsmanship. Always hot and crowded, but a feast for the eyes - and don't forget to say a prayer/make a wish at this most sacred site.

Even though it is not emerald, it is beautiful and the temple is still in use.. This is part of the Royal Palace complex so entry ito the temple is part of that ticket. Shoes must be removed and, as for the palace, you must be modestly dressed. No shorts or short skirts or sleeveless tops, but at the palace entrance they herd sheep (modestly dressed) one way straight into the complex and goats (the others) to a queue to get sarongs and long pants. Come prepared and it is quicker! At the temple shoes are removed. There ain't a lot of space inside as there are worshippers and so it gets crowded and hot. Way up high is the Emerald Buddha which is in fact jade and beautiful and worth the hassle to see it as is the rest of the interior, but do not miss the exterior detail.

Dress correctly.. Stupidly forgot to dress correctly so had to borrow long trousers from the temple, great service just pay a deposit and when finished return clothes and get deposit back and no other charge. Other than that what can you say the whole temple complex is just so beaytiful.

Very Nice, But No Pictures. I visited the Temple of the Emerald Buddha in February 2012 as a part of my visit to the Grand Palace. The entrance fee to the Grand Palace includes entrance to this temple. I was most disappointed that they do not allow photographs inside. A couple of other things to keep in mind: 1) you must be properly dressed, meaning no exposed shoulders for women, and no shorts for anybody, you must wear long pants, and 2) the grounds of the Grand Palace (including the Temple of the Emerald Buddha) close early in the afternoon, so make sure you get there early enough in the day to give yourself time as the Grand Palace is very large and includes many buildings.
Emerald Buddha. Have been there on previous occasions and well worth a visit

Part of the Grand Palace. Very interesting although the Bhudda is very high up and a little difficult to see. No photographs inside the temple but stand outside and photograph it from there on telephoto!

I'll call it "mini-buddha". After seeing the grand size of so many other buddhas the emerald budha is very tiny but sits on a huge pedestal of jewels and gold. It is draped in different gold outfits depending on the season. We were happy he was wearing his "summer" clothes so more of it was exposed.

Temple of the Emerald Buddha. I have visited the temple three times and always find something new to look at, it is within the grounds of the Grand Palace and along with other parts of the Palace makes for a very interesting day out. The murals on the walls are absolutely amazing, especially when you consider that they are all painted by hand and contain pure gold leaf.

A true wonder to see in Bangkok. The Emerald Buddha is a must see in Bangkok. It is housed in a very beautiful Wat <Check out the ceiling>. The Buddha has a rich history in Thai culture the Royal family changes its vestments every season. Originally from the Lana kingdom up north this Buddhas original home was in Chiang Rai. If you ever wanted to see the Emerald Buddha up close there is an exact replica in Chiang Mai <The Wat has the same name>. It was replaced by the Chinese community when the original was moved to Bangkok. One of the great things I like about this Wat is the Buddhist mural that runs along the entire length of the Wat. I think it is one of the longest in the world <Angkor Wat being the longest>. It delves into the rich tradition of Buddhist theology and is full of all kinds of colorful images. When you visit the Emerald Buddha please remember to show utmost respect for this site. Remove your shoes, Don't talk loudly, don't take pictures inside and whatever you do Do not point your feet at the image this is considered disrespectful.
Temple of the Emerald Buddha. This temple is located on the grounds of the Grand Palace. Everything at this site is worth the visit and is an absolute must when visiting Bangkok for the first time.
Worth a look. This temple, like all those in Bangkok, is impressive not least of all because of how well it is kept. You will see bigger Buddhas though!

Very small. You think with all the large Buddhas around that this would be huge..no this is the smallest one..you have to take off your shoes and cover your legs and shoulders in all the temple so wear easy to remove shoes and no shorts
worth seeing. combined trip with Golden buddha and Grand palace and reclining buddha.

beautiful sculpture and daeity. The Buddha was made in india one belives and was brought to thailand by an indian princess, the emerald bddha is made from jade priceless and a masterpiece of workmanship, the Bhuda is always dressed in one of the three sets of gold garments the king himself changes depnding on the season, by the way india has opaque emerald pices big enough to make an emerald buddha.
Amazing. This was one of the best temples I've visited in bangkok.Truly a remarkable site. Come prepared with proper clothing. ( Covered )

Amazing architecture. This place is very, very busy but with good reason. Make sure you have a large memory disk in your camera . Around every corner is another beautiful photograph waiting to be taken. A must see for Bangkok . Take a hand fan as it gets so humid .If you can only see one thing in Bankok this is it !!
Disappointing. Very busy, couldn't get close enough to actually see anything and no photography allowed.
Beautiful!. Wish we could have gotten closer. Unbelievable workmanship!

Glorious Temple. No idea what to expect upon entering this temple and was amazed with the ornate detail and beauty. The murals painted around the temple were so pretty as were all the temples and then the Emerald Buddha itself. A must see!
My favorite place. It's the best temple and great value in my opinion.

He sure is green!. I couldn't believe how tiny the Emerald Buddha was, but he's great! He has three different outfits they dress him in according to the season. A camera with a zoom lens is a must to capture this buddha.
so beautiful. Amazingly beautiful, very different. Do not surrender to sellers around and buy long cloth, you can always borrow them from the reception

Worth a see. Once in the Palace take a look at the Emerald Buddha - he will be wearing 1 of 4 seasonal outfits. If you go to the Museum (near the coffee shop) it tells you all about him.
No photographs allowed, & gets very very busy.
Valuable visit. Worth a visit. You are taken aback upon sighting the worthless Emarald Buddha statue. Very holy and unforgettable place.

Impressive. The temple is located within the grounds of the Royal Palace. The jade Buddha is the highly revered Buddha image in Thailand and is a Buddha statue in the meditating position, carved from a single block of jade. It is not very big and stays raised high on a series of platforms, so it is not easy to see the details, specially because it wears a seasonal cloak that they change three times a year in summer, winter, and rainy season. Our guide explained that the changing of the robes is a very important ritual, performed only by the King to bring good fortune to the country during each season. The temple of Emerald Buddha is beautifully decorated and is a peaceful place, although it is always crowded. Stay there for half an hour. It's a shame, but it is forbidden to take photographs inside the temple.

Very pretty. This temple is located in the grand palace . it is very beautiful to look at and has a lot of detailed hand work done on the building. probably once of the most beutiful temples i have ever seen - the inside was all right and you cant take pictures in there however the temple from the outside is actually a really cool building

Interesting to see.. The emerald buddha once you got into the temple housing it was lovely to see. There are so many tourists though, you almost miss the tranquility of what a Buddhist temple should be. There were some Monks meditating in the room though which helped get a feel for what the true meaning was, rather than just being another tourist destination.
The Emerald Buddha. So glad to have seen this and every glad to had a wonderful English speaking guide to enhance our experience. The guides are at the entrance, use them!
Wow. This was a great place. The details and architecture are a must see.
Not to be missed. Everything you would expect of a South East asian temple
Sacred feeling in this temple.. All nations doing our own meditation!!! Emerald Budha is small and actually not gold but Jade!!! Wall and roor panelling in this temple detailed in the finest!!!

Thai architecture at its best!. This temple is inside the Royal palace compound and is a main attraction in Bangkok, lots and lots of people but is great to see and admire the work, the buddha is small but nice
Must see in Bangkok. Part of the tourist circuit, must see places. It has a nice history behind it and part of a huge grand palace compound
Beautiful!. Even though the Buddha itself is small and placed really high up on an altar, it's worth seeing. Just be respectful of those who are there to pray to the deity.
Bangkok's absolute must see. Crowded but marvellous, take your time to enjoy and marvel at the temple and the emerald Buddha.
interesting. just the size of it and the detail and work that has gone into it

Wordless. It is amazing to watch the Thai royal opulence, colors, materials, size, if you love architecture will impress like this set is Built temples with gold. The emerald budda, you always imagine it bigger but overall you run out of words

Do it on your own with a guide book map. You can see three styles of stupas in one location. Has all kind of architectural delights but guides will want to rush you to see the Emerald Buddha, scoot you past the galleried Ramayana story and maybe take you into one other building. With a good map from a travel book, you can do it on your own! Well worth it.
very nice. visit definitely, the story how they found his and of how many pieces is made is fascinating
Great ambience. There's a really nice atmosphere here. The décor, aroma and surroundings are all incredible.

Emeradl Buddha. I am not sure it is emerald. Might be jade. Bu, hey, it's another Buddha and you really can't have too many especially when just about everyone in Thailand is bowing down to them and trying to solve life's problems in the process.

A good afternoon. The temple is gorgeous. We got their fairly late in the day and were still able to see everything. Some of my favorite pictures came from here. Be careful of the tuktuk drivers trying to scam you outside the entrance. Anyone that seems too helpful is trying to scam you. Walk away from them, don't even try to be polite.
memorable and spiritual. fantastic wore a lovely scarf from alex mc - however i wouldnt advise wearing new collection. if you want something different go to thescarfboutique.co.uk
Beautiful. Thailand is about temples, there are more than 400 in the city. Pick the most important ones and you can do 2 days tours around different temples.Remember to dress properly.
Amazing architecture. Having lived in Thailand for many years, I often get visited by friends from overseas and this is one of those places that has to be on the must see tour, enjoy.

Tiny little Buddah in grand temple. I really liked the peacefulness of the temple. I enjoyed doing as the buddists do and paying my respect to the buddah. I just thought it was funny that the actual emerald buddah was so small compared to the temple it's housed in.
A must-visit in Bangkok. Along with a visit to The Grand Palace and Wat Po, this is the third "must visit" place in town.

One more temple.. The Emerald Buddha is of course, made of jade. It has an interesting past, as it was moved around the country. It's clothes are changed from season to season. The temple is nice,but uless you are a real church and temple fan, after a while they tend to look alike. In the Grand Palace complex.

Inside the Grand Palace - no. 1 site in Bangkok. This temple is located in the middle of the Grand Palace, and is not a site in itself, but rather viewed as the highlight of the grand palace visit.The grand palace is, in my opinion, the no. 1 site in Bangkok. A must see for every tourist visiting Bangkok. The best part of the palace that is worth visiting is the temple of the Emerald Buddha.Important to note – come to the palace wearing long pants and skirts, or else you will need to rent covering from a booth inside the palace entrance (or from one of the vendors outside – But I recommend to do it inside).The palace is best seen with a tour guide. A one hour tour is not expensive (400 baht). I suggest going to the tourist information office, next to the ticket booth (they are very friendly) and have them recommend a guide. The guides await at the entrance to the palace, and the ticket booth is inside, but the walk back and forth is worthwhile to get a good guide. Allow at least 1.5 hours for a visit of the palace. It takes about 1 hour to see the temple, and another 20 minutes to wander outside around the other buildings of the palace, which are closed to the public.The temple itself is not big, and photography is not allowed inside (this is strictly enforced by a guard standing inside forbidding photography and ensuring that photographs taken are deleted.). You can attempt to photograph the emerald Buddha through the window, but better have yourself photographed there by someone standing on the outside.

The vibe here is peaceful and beautiful, even when packed with people. A massive, bejeweled altar holds a golden Buddha high up in the temple, with masses of people praying...it's hard not to be awed.
Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Must-visit, with plenty of stories to learn about Thailand. There's a free tour with English speaking guide at 10.30am.

AMAZING BUT YOU NEED SOCKS!. He is only small and made of jade (and not emerald) but the feeling when you enter the temple is amazing as is watching the devotion of others. You have to take your shoes off and as the ground outside the temple is very hot, you should take a pair of socks to put on!
Not to be missed. This is the holiest of the Buddhas in Thailand, the statue is tiny but the temple is breathtaking. Dress modestly and be careful how you behave in the temple.
Don't miss.. The first place when you arrive at Bangkok. Please don't miss the Emerald Buddha or Wat Phra Kaeo. It's a must to visit here.
Must See. Beautiful ;o) make time to see it, u won't regret it!
trip to thailand. everything great for photos and a great historical and cultural experince
A must see!. This is the must see of bangkok along with the Wat of the reclining buddha nearby. not to be missed and the only two really interesting attractions in Bangkok!

Go here instead of Gran Palace. This place is much more relaxed than the Grand Palace, the reclining Budda is amazing, and the whole place is very cosy with places to get out of the sun, truely lovley.
Worth a look. It was smaller than expected but worth a look if you are there.

Manage your expectations...and your shoes!. First, don't expect the image to be big like the Reclining Buddha nor the Golden Buddha. The Emerald Buddha (actually, not made of emerald but of jadeite) is very tiny but still impressive. The temple where this is housed is immense but almost always packed! You are required to remove your shoes upon entering by leaving them at racks outside the temple but beware as any shoe can easily get lost in the sea of footwear strewn around the area - especially if there are shoes that are alike!No photos are allowed inside but you take them from outside (making sure you avoid the many heads that block your view).

Beautiful!. Very cool - the buddha is smaller than we thought. You can not take photos of it inside, but it has a huge opening and you can stand outside and take your photo over many heads. Place was packed. But it's on the grounds of the Palace, so easy to fit in with your trip to the Palace.
Incredible. Together with the Grand Palace, you can spend few hours looking at those breath-taking buildings.

Nice to see. This is a huge Buddha but can be a bit difficult to photograph as there many pillars between you and the Buddha. The outside building was under construction but that did not affect us. Go early to ensure less of a crowd. In the same plot there are many more buildings, statues and buddhas so take your time.
The Emerald Buddha. I 'm always on this place for pray and sometime i show this temple for my friend or my guest to unseen this place .
very rich ,worth seeing. good ground , well kept area, lots opportunity for nice pics
Inside Golden Palace. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is a part of the Grand Palace and it is really interesting to see all the "stuffing" they have in the temple. It proves that more is MORE!
Impressive. Great visit, a lot of tourists, but please include it in your itinerary.

Impressive Mosaics. We visited the Temple on our first day in Bangkok. My wife and I are 30 and 27 and we walked from Khao San Road. We didn't find the dress code to be particularly restrictive, but make sure to get the free clothes inside and not the 30 baht clothes outside.If you've ever completed a mosaic project by yourself you'll probably have a greater appreciation for the artwork. There was mosaic tile everywhere. We also enjoyed all the statues and artwork as well.The Emerald Buddha itself was extremely crowded and is in fact a very small statue. I understand that it is a very holy Buddha but as a tourist site it is not incredibly impressive. I almost wish there was someway they could keep it off limits to non-worshipers, but not sure how they would do that...I definitely visit as a main attraction of Bangkok, but if you only have time for one temple I'd probably visit the nearby Wat Pho.
Simply beautiful!. Really beautiful and peaceful inside. You can sit there for a while together with all the monks who are praying. Beautiful calm feeling

It was less than i expected. the temple is situated in the middle of the grand palace so you don't need to pay additional fees and the Buddha is made of pure Jade and is considered to be the most famous Buddha in Thailand. so obviously i expected something big and impressive. in reality the Buddha statue has around 50-60 cm and it is located very far so you can not see to much. especially if you are in winter season when Buddha is dressed up - you can hardly see any parts of it. it is still a must see in Bangkok - so go to the Grand Palace and see both of them.

The must see in Bangkok.. Elegant, stunning and amazing sacret place. It expresses how rich Budhism & the faith of Thai people. Next to it is the Grand Palace which is the most grand and beautiful palace in Thailand. Dress politely (no sleeveless tops, no shorts above knee level, else you will need to rent a cloth there)

Must do in Bangkok. I have visited this temple a couple of times and the last times it was open on the Kings Birthday on the 5th of december in the evening time. It was completely different than in the daytime and had some very amazing pictures. It is getting a bit pricey now when you go there in the daytime but I still recommend the visit as one of the highlights in Bangkok.
Amazing Story. The entire story of the discovery of this Buddha is amazing. It is truly beautiful and certainly should be on one's agenda.
Well worth seeing. The most interesting of all the temples we saw during our visit to Thailand

A truly eye=poppinhg place and the atmosphere inside is moving. I have been here at least twice. Very emotional place and wonderful adornments to the building exteriors and interiors ; It is very hot so take an umbrella. You must cover your arms and legs and be very respectful.Cameras are allowed outside only. Remove shoes before entering the temple.
do it. big q's wen we went but we went ova xmas new yr's time but was worth the wait 2 get in 2 c it
One of the Top Must See's. Can't go to bangkok and not see the emerald buddah, part of the grand palace complex so dont miss it!

Very interesting but no photography allowed. The temple is very well kept but they do not allow photography which means you are hassled by people outside trying to sell postcards. The Buddha itself is much smaller than I expected but extremely beautiful.

Beautiful if you can see around the other tourist. The buildings and architecture were brilliant. Such a lovely way to spend a day. However, be warned that there are thousands of other people who will be there with you.
Impressive. Beautiful cultural buildings. The massage school gives wonderful foot massages.
Lots of worshippers, buzz. Impressive though I am not a regular temple visiting fan as part of my tourist itinerary. Architecture is quite historic and well-maintained.

A must see. This temple is the royal temple. It is a must see on your tour. Every tour guide will take you there. The Emerald Buddha (which is made our of pure Jade) is actually quite small, but the temple and the grounds are gorgeous.
Tiny Buddha. When at the Grand Palace you'll have to see this tiny Buddha who sits up high and mighty on it's perch. No pictures allowed.

Worth seeing. The temple complex surrounding the temple of the Emerald Buddha is astounding. A mural greets the visitor on entering the temple complex and the colors are still vibrant. The intricately sculpted figures and the designs on the exterior walls are amazing. A good camera is needed to get a decent photo of the Buddha because of its diminutive size and having to shoot from the outside of the temple.
Facinating.... ... for the hive of activity that the temple generates. Discrete guards manage the crowds very well and make sure that westerners do not commit any errors of etiquette.
Many things to see. However, what I dont like is that once you went to the Royal palace accidently, there is no way to get back to Wat phra Kaeo except paying an additional 400 Baht.
Unique but not impressive. It's crowded, but colorful, I enjoy the paint. I guess because I'm from China, so it didn't impress me...

Magic, Beautiful, Impressive.... Don't miss it. No words can describe this place. Just beware of scams when you arrive, don't trust strangers that will tell you that the Temple is closed, they will try to sell you another touristic attraction and take you to jewlery stores, etc.

Get there the quiet and calm way. Not much more needs to be said about the "Emerald" Buddha and the surrounding wonderland but if you don't like negotiating the manic traffic of Bangkok, try getting there from your hotel by taking the water taxi - regular, cheap, quiet and you see a lot of the city from the boat.

Nice story about this one. The Emerald Buddha is made of Emerald. So what is he made of?
You'll have to go there to find out!
This is one of many Thai sites of cultural significance and interest.

peaceful and great history. For those going the first time, the emerald buddha is a must see. Its a temple which has a history in line with the Indian Ramayan. A lot of Hindu influence can be seen here however, depicted in thai form. Quite interestingVisitors should also know that you have to be well covered to go there. Men should be in trousers or full pants and cannot be wearing sleeveless shirts. Women no skirts/tights or sleeveless tops. They will not let you go in if you are not properly dressed. You will have to borrow clothing from the counter at the entrance if you are not properly dressed.If you are well versed with hindu history especially the ramayana then you need not take a guide else guide is helpful. The architecture has 3 influences i.e thai, combodian and indonesian. The royal palace is located in the same compound but you can see only a part of it.

No photos allowed. No photos allowed inside. What a pity. You have to take off your shoes to get in. However as there are hordes of people going in & out, it is easy to have your shoes stolen. So make sure you go in quickly & come out quickly or else your day will be spoilt if you can't find your shoes. Beware of touts (Thai-looking) who offer to help you take a couple shot outside the temple. They charge unaware tourists for it. I saw the Thai couple in action. They blend very easily into the crowd. So beware of friendly "photographers'.
Beautiful Buddha statue. Very impressive giant gold Buddha! Crowded with sight seers but worth a visit!

Interesting. Very nice place and beautiful. This temple is part of the Grand Palace compound. When I visited in December 2011 it was 400 Thai baht to go inside --- that is a bit expensive by Thai standards. But, very nice. Quite a huge place, so leave a good amount of time and usually very hot --- so, you'll need water. Also, you cannot enter unless you are dressed very modestly.....so shorts, etc.
Epitome of serenity. Immensely peaceful and serene location. I have never seen such calm environs around a buddhist temple.
Wearing a scarf. Really stunning, worth the trip. He changes clothes depending on the season - his gold scarf for winter was really beautiful.

Wonderful!. The Grand Palace is sensational. A good tip though wear light clothes as it can get really, really hot! Even if you don't look your best in the pictures you'll be pleased you remain as cool as possible. You also need to take shoes off and so if you are concerned wear socks.Final tip buy water for going round. The stalls outside are quieter and cheaper than inside.
Awesome. I really enjoyed seeing the Emerald Buddha. We paid for a guide to take us around and I felt that this was worth the extra money to us ( 500 Baht ). This is a must see in Bangkok.

A big deal that is small in stature. There were a lot of people and we walked all the way around the palace till we found the entrance when you get off the ferry make a left at the main road where the palace is. This is nice but small and only worth going to say you've been and no pictures allowed.
Emerald Buddah. Fantastic setting and well worth a visit ; whole of the Grand palace was good. Need at least half a day to see it- we got there early and avoided worst of crowds.

Overrated top say the least.... The first item that rubbed me the wrong way was the admission fee. 400 Baht per person seems to be an outlandish amount of money in the Thai culture to view the temple and grounds. The average Thai makes 400 Baht a day, so they are essentially charging a full day's labor to get in, which is probably why admission is free for those who are Thai.There is a lot of history surrounding the emerald Buddha from its inception to its travels amongst India, Sri Lanka, Cambodia, etc. Needless to say, you could spend a bunch of time just reading about the story behind the emerald Buddha. However, when you see it in person, it is quite small and rather unassuming. If you see the reclining Buddha first, you will be left wondering why there is a lot of hype surrounding the emerald Buddha.The grounds and building surrounding the emerald Buddha are very decorative and impressive. I unfortunately did not go on a guided tour of the grounds (lots of folks standing outside offering tours for money and then there are 4 free tours in English every day). I think you would probably need to go on a tour to understand all the details and history of the buildings.All that to say, I left feeling like it was an overpriced tourist trap. However, it is one of those things that you kind of need to see, so that you can check the box. There are a lot of other temples that are far cheaper and just as impressive, however, they do not have the famous emerald buddha.

a classic not to be missed. Very busy, but worth it. Pay no attention whatsoever to the official looking staff who tell you it's closed, or that there is a delay, or that you need conservative dress, and they can help etc etc. The last point is true, but you can borrow suitable clothing (deposit necessary, but no charge) once you are inside the complex. Gets hot in the middle of the day of course, so go early!
Must see. watch out for street dealers trying to con you out off your hard earned cash
you cant see it. they call it temple of the emerald buddha but its actually made of jade. no one is allowed to take photo nor even some close to the image. its located inside the grand palace

Pride of the Thai - A Must Visit. Co-lolated within the grand palace, this temple is a must visit even if the stay in Bangkok is for a shorter period. This 14th century marvel is a pride of the Thai people. The Emerald Buddha was much smaller than expected.

Overwhelming and worth it!. This is a must see in Bangkok...expect to be overwhelmed and awed. First, know that you will be told by very official looking people (dressed in "police" uniforms) outside the temple grounds that the Grand Palace is closed for a political meeting and will reopen in a few hours... NOT TRUE! Despite being warned by many people my husband and I fell for it...duh! Also be appropriately dressed..sleeves, long pants, or run the risk of waiting in line for clothing to be lent to you. Once inside, walk about a hundred yards to the ticket desk..shorter lines there. Of course you will want to see the Emerald Buddha...but make sure to pay attention to the elegant and beautiful apsonsis on the upper tier, and make funny faces and arm positions to mimic the ramakien figures....have your picture taken doing this..it is tradition! Be sure to see the small scale Angkor Wat, it is pretty surprising to see it there and interesting. Know there will be lots of people...and just savor the beauty!

Must see!!!. If you have only one day in Bangkok, you must see this Wat! It is absolutely beautiful... do me, and the Thai people a favour and don't take gold tiles and pieces of the temple. I noticed quite a few places where gold tiles and fine porcelaine was obviously removed by curio collectors. The Emerald Buddha is sacred and please respect this as a place of worship... I was thrilled to see this Thai treasure but a bit put off by the behavior of some of my fellow travelers.
Amazing. Beautiful!!! Too bad cameras are not allowed inside!

Gorgeous but packed with people. It's indeed a very beautiful place and I like the fact that they dont allow you to take pictures, since it would be impossible to go inside. It's a shame that the visit is not exactly controlled and it gets quite full and some people are not really respectful when indoors.
Pretty. The Emerald Buddha was much smaller than I expected, though I'm not sure why I expected anything else. It was very pretty though.
a must see.. Just a small part -but most sacred part of the Royal Palace. remember to dress appriately or you will have to rent some expensive clothes
crowded, but worth the trip. crowded with both tourists and Thai students. Remember to wear long pants or long skirt, no bare shoulders, so skip the tank-top. Tour the Grand Palace at the same time.

Another tourist must-do. Another excellent place to visit in Bangkok. You must ensure you don't get there too late though as the temple tends to close reasonably early (if you expect to see it at 5pm you may well be disappointed).
Do not miss this place. If you visit Bangkok, please come to this place. The Buddha is well maintain and place is clean.
Charming and Peaceful. Loved the way the Thais worship here. Absolute silence! Spend some time here and meditate if possible.  :)
Another must see temple. I was struck by the peace and serenity as I entered this wonderfull temple and in fact visited it 3 times whilst in Bangkok this time despite having been here before

Opulence. This truly is an amazing experience. The Emerald Buddha is itself quite a small statue, but it is mounted above a very tall ediface. encrusted with goldleaf and jewels . It is housed in a very sacred temple (no photograghy allowed) and tourists enter to a strict regime. 3 times a year the Buddha is taken down for a seasonal change of apparel. Only the KIng is allowed to do this task.The temple grounds house many other temples, all magnificently encrusted with gold and jewels.

In the entire palace, only this Temple is open . the emerald buddha is located on a very high pedestal, so you don't close up view, unless you have telescopic glasses. taking photos is prohibited. in the entire grand palace, only this temple was open, all other p(a)laces were simply closed for visitors - Just a view of the exterior front! that was a bit disappointing for 400 THB. the other thing that was open was the Museum.

Very cool!. The Emerald Buddha was neat to see. We were surprised how small the Buddha was. It's interesting to learn the history and customs (such as only the King is allowed to touch the Buddha and is the only person who changes the Emerald Buddha's seasonal robes). Unfortunately you can't take pictures of the Emerald Buddha however you can buy souvenir pictures outside afterwards.

Beautiful temple. It was a bustling area, obviously, and the Emerald Buddha was so beautiful and glowing. The traditional ceremonial candles, insence burning, lotus flower dipped in holy water and tapping it on your head, all was a unique experience to have. A worthwhile visit.
Impressive. Beware of pickpockets here. Had my cell phone stolen from my bag!

Amazingly moving and beautiful. This is a really wonderful Buddhist temple. The reclining Buddha is wonderful in itself but the murals detailing the life/path of the Buddha are really quite extraordinary. The merit bowls add a lot to this as the sounds of people placing donations in them make for a pleasant aural compliment to the rest of the experience. Definitely a must see.

SURPRISED. Was a little surprised here as the buddha is so small and unfortunately you cannot go into the area to get a closer look. It is placed very high up on an apex but it certainly looks good. There are plenty of photographs and post cards to show you close up what it looks like.
a dream. must be seen is very impressive and beautiful take some hours and enjoy
