Tacky... .. Well, while I realize this IS a religious site, I couldn't help but feeling as if I was in a china store and loads of tacky statues were on sale.Beautiful, if you are into this, but for me - way way waaay too much.
Beautiful. Can't go to Bangkok and not see it! It is part of the Thai culture :)
It in the complex of GRAND Palace a must for travellers tobangkok. It is the first in the must see LIST for travel Bangkok
Interesting. It was an interesting part of our day out. We had a good personal guide. Not wheelchair accessible.
A very impressive sight.. The Emerald Budha is a must see whilst in Bagkok. It is very impressive.

Not what we expected. This Buddha is not made of emerald - its made of Jade and is 60cm in height. No photos are permitted to be taken in the temple which is heavily guarded. The buddha is clothed in gold coverings depending on the season you visit in. The temple is okay though and quite 'blingy' if you like lots of shiney stuff that sparkles...

I like the ornament. Temple of the Emerald Buddha is a part of Grand Palace complex.We have to put our sandals or shoes outside, and walk barely to see Emerald Buddha.I can't tell a lot about the statue. I just remember that the dominant color of this place is gold. And so many people sat and looking around this place. But this place is quiet.I love the outside decor of this place.I love to walk around and sit there, enjoying seeing the wall and ceiling ornament, i found it interesting.It's my fave place in the Grand Palace complex (besides the garden)
Beautiful and solemn.. Beautiful and solemn. In the Grand Palace. No photos allowed. One of the most holy places in Thailand.
Inspiring. History at its best , well worth a visit , take a trip by Tuk Tuk

Must see attraction in Bangkok!. The whole area is amazing! Have been here often (I'm a student and get in for free), and I love to walk around and take photos. Can highly recommend it as a number one thing to do in Bangkok!
Sublime experience. All good - but look out for the ceramic flowers on the roof of one of the buldings. Take a telephoto lens - they are amazing.

Experience the calm and beauty. Considering the sheer number of people visiting the temple, it is hard to say that the experience is calming but the reverence embraces you and you may sit on the floor and take in the splendor of the space. Depending on the season, the Buddha will be dressed for rainy, warm or cool seasons. You have to see it, though. Rain wear does not include a slicker and galoshes! Your shoes remain outside as you don't enter a home with footwear. Oh, and always step OVER door treads.

Nice but..... To be honest I was a little let down by this temple - sure the outside is quite literally unreal but the emerald buddah itself rather well should we say small...the way they advertise it I was expecting this huge statue where in fact it is rather small. Go early in the morning as later on the crowds are horrid!
Worth It. The entire complex is beautiful. The emerald Buddha is different from the other Buddha's. Very interesting history.
Emerald Buddha. It is a bit underwhelming but you must take in the whole property.
Big temple complex. This is a big temple complex, with a lot of gold and mirrors. It is quite overwhelming. This is not a place I would revisit

A Must-visit Place for EVERYONE. It is a really fabulous place that I can promise you won't be able to find anywhere else in the world. Thai and Chinese sophisticate arts reflect the culture and the way of life in the past. One day is not enough to see everything. But be prepared, because the weather is pretty hot, so wear polite but not too thick clothes here.

Grandiose temple. Incredibly intricate with a fantastic mural. Very touristy, but still used as a real place of worship. You can spend hours there or as little as 45 minutes and still get a sense of it. Very important place for Thais.

Fabulous temple. This is a very sacred place for Buddhists and it's easy to see the care that is taken in keeping the place pristine. The lavish decoration in the temple is wonderful. Very busy but still calming in a strange sort of way.
in Wat Po. In the Temple of Wat Po. Make sure you take all day to visit the temple. it is also free
The heart of Bangkok. A must see if you are in Bangkok.. Tranquil and and very spiritual
The Most Revered Buddha In Thailand. A magnificent temple housing the most revered Buddha in Thailand, althought the Buddha it self is quite small.
Emerald Buddha. A must see if you are in temple mode.......very nice space to sit and reflect.

Must see while in Bangkok. This was one of the buddhas we HAD to see while we were in Bangkok and we were so happy that we did. It's a really awesome experience to be in the temple with all of the people and to see the little Buddha in person. Definitely worth the trip to the Grand Palace.
Very beautiful. Very beautiful temple. This is inside the Grand Palace and worth going in to see. Also a kind of blessing outside.
amazing temple recommend to visit. we like very much will come back for the next year all design very beautiful.

“A must-see in Bangkok”. If u just arrived in Thailand/Bangkok you should have a look at this amazing temple and the story behind the emerald Buddha!
This temple is truly a Must See. Very worthwhile to visit, both interesting from an architectural and a spiritual angle. Apart from being a breathtaking sight it is also a quiet oasis.
Gorgeous Place. We were bowled over when we saw this place it is extremely beautiful the people of Thailand are very lucky to have such a beautiful place to visit.
A Special Buddha. Beautiful temple, a truly unique Buddha. It's a part of the Grand Palace and you'll find many people worshiping here.
Amazing. If u just arrived in Thailand/Bangkok you should have a look at this amazing temple and the story behind the emerald Buddha!

A must-see in Bangkok. It is overcrowded, over-regulated and too touristy - but it's still one of the great Buddhist temples of the world, and spectacularly beautiful and awe-inspring. Going top BKK and not seeing Wat Phra Keao would be like going to Paris and not seeing Notre Dame.

Temple of the Emerald Buddha compound simply magnificent. Bangkok visit needs much planning, especially getting to town from Laem Chabang. Do pre-arrange pick up with return - costing US$100 one way and another 1000 BHT for 4 hours of driving around the sites.. Our driver demanded a huge port fee at the last minutes which we paid and found out from other groups that there is none. So beware. Local taxi drivers i.e. waved down by the road side do not understand English and therefore it is better to make arrangment beforehand to keep the car for the whole site visits.The Temple of Emerald Buddha compound is huge and so much to see. Do allow for more than an hour to cover the numerous places inside.Visitors must not wear shorts and guys who did so bought sarong on the spot to wrap around the waist. - the only alternative. So be prepared.
well worth a visit. Truly breathtaking place. It is beautiful and full of so much detail. Definitely has to be at the top of your list of places to see in bangkok.

Another great temple. Whilst I'm not a particularly religious person, I do have a fascination with the architecture of houses of worship. This definitely rates as a must see for all tourists, religious or otherwise.

Be prepared to climb. A lot of stairs to climb but worth seeing the buddha. Although if you are elderly and handicapped they do have elevators to the top. Tip is to wear comfortable shoes and remember there's a dress code i.e. dress politely.

A must in Bangkok. This is a place you shouldn´t miss at the Thai capital. An enormous site filled with chedis, stupas, shrines, sculptures and the most adored Buddha image in Thailand, the Emerald Buddha. The site is just beside the Grand Palace where the royal family used to live a few years ago and where royal meetings still take place. There is a very good audio guide available in many languages.
A Must see. This temple is truly a Must See. Very worthwhile to visit, both interesting from an architectural and a spiritual angle. Apart from being a breathtaking sight it is also a quiet oasis.
Impressive. An impressive array of temples at this site including the Emerald Buddha andespecially the Golden Temple the name of which escapes me

A must see in Bangkok.. Very touristy but lots of thai people around. Dont forget to take off your shoes... and not to take any photos inside. Beautiful temple and building adjacent to the main temple are also breathtaking.
fasinating. great late pm to wander when all the main bulk of the tour parties have left. So much to see, and great to wander about for hours.

OUSTANDING Buddha temple in Bangkok. This is part of Grand Palace tour, to visit Emerlad (green) Buddha, which in inside a niche in the main Temple; you can't take picture and videos to respect thai religion, either outside and inside there are lot of dragon staues, offerings bowls, and many golden stuff. Either this visit you must do it, to watch aslo main towers, tipical oriental warrios, protecting the entarnce door, a golden Stupe and other warriors that are sustaining others monuments inside. Get there because you can miss it.
very busy. Definately worth the visit, but very busy with tourists, dress appropriately but also with regards to heat, loose shirt thin trousers to avoid melting!!
Must see. This is the most amazing place and must not be missed on your visit to Bangkok - don't forget your camera has it has the most photogenic buildings are in this place.

Tranquil beauty. The temple of Emerald Buddha demands a visit on two counts - the simplicity and magnificence of the temple rolled into one - see it to experience it and secondly inspite of being in the same compound as the Grand Palace, the moment you step in, you feel the peace and tranquility like never before. Amazing experience. Must visit!

Beautiful "Frescoes" - Bring change so you don't get ripped off!. Loved:-The art and architecture-The history and culture-The storytelling of the frescoes on the walls around the temple were absolutely my favorite.Didn't like:-The Government Employee who took my 1000 THB gave me 10 THB in change. When I challenged her, she finally gave me the remaining ~600 THB of change. How sad is it that the person at the ticket booth actually tried to cheat me?-Clothing rental line was very long when I came ( go across the street and spend about the same amount for a shorter line)-Salespeople lying and saying that everything is closed for the day, only to sell you another tour, even though the temple is still open.
Holiday in Bangkok. Fabulous temple. I did not like the huge crowds because it was a holiday. One of my friends had his wallet stolen.
Interesting. The figures and decoration are a must see and the size and intricate tile work amazing.
Nice. It was lovely, but busy in the time we were there. The line to borrow appropriate clothing was long, so bring long pants and a cover up. Even children can't have their knees showing.

Amazing!. You cannot visit Thailand without seeing the Emerald Buddha!It is quite small, and depending on what season you visit, it is adorned with beautiful garments that reflect the seasons, Spring, Summer and winter. Make sure your shoulders are covered and you cannot show your legs. You can actually hire a sarong to wear if you are not appropriately dressed.

Another amazing place to see. It was incredible to see the intricate pedestal and the Buddha, though this was even more crowded than the rest of the Grand Palace complex. It is frustrating though that this is one of the few places in the city that pictures aren't allowed. In comparison to the rest of the Wats and Buddhas found in the Palace complex and nearby, there are more impressive things to see, though you shouldn't miss this Wat.

Very good but.... Just to let you know that cameras and video recording is banned here! Plus be prepared to be told to hire clothes as a scarf is not good enough! Wear a long sleeve shirt and trousers!
Really wonderful. Best to go after the hordes of tourists. A magnificent experience.
many buddhas to see. Lots of crowds lining up to see the emerald buddha. Worth the wait. In addition in te monastery there are other buddhas to see. A must do when touring the grand palace.

Amazing. there are a million reviews on this so, I will add one bit for fun. The Thais believe that only a true believer will see the emerald Budha. So see if you see it without it been pointed out. :-)

Impressive. The temple is so impressive. Really beautiful! Don't even try to take a photo...the guards will see you no matter how sneaky you think you are being and delete it from your camera. Also be sure to wear a top with sleeves/t-shirt...putting a scarf around your shoulders is not acceptable.

If you're at The Grand Palace do see this Buddha.. The Emerald Buddha is worth a look since you've paid the admission fee but it's not the neatest thing in BKK. It's set back and visitors look at it from a distance. Still, worth checking out.

Too many people!. Yes, it is famous and yes the grounds, temples, gardens.... are wonderful, golden, noble and large.... but I did not like the crowds of people. We had decided to be "first", that is to be at the entrance at 8:30am in the morning, but we were just sucked in with large tour groups and it was "work" to find quieter places. It is loud and I cannot help: nearby Wat Pho is much nicer, more local.The entrance fee of THB 400,00 for Farangs is VERY high.
Must see. Located in the same area as Grand Palace. Outstanding architecture. Very nice emerald buddha.Dress properly to avoid clothes police.
A little overrated and so many crowds. We saw much better temples in Thailand. Go to Wat Arun across the river instead.

Not to be missed. This is a 'must see' for any tourist visiting Bangkok. Dress very modestly - sleeves on tops and long skirts or trousers. Then you can avoid the clothes police. The architecture is truly amazing and, for someone like me who has not traveled in the East before, this was stunning.
It's an emerald buddah.. the buddah itself is what it says on the tin, emerald. The buildings and things that surround it are impressive. Box ticked.
huge. big budda, worth a visit but if you dont have time thats fine
Marvellous Architecture. There is a replica of Angkor Wat in this temple and the architecture of the whole temple is amazing, with statues, large shiny stupas, etc.

A must see Temple. Going to Thailand without seeing this, is like visiting Sydney without seeing the Opera House. Avoid unsolicited 'guides', but sample the richness of Thai Buddhism at this Temple. A great place for contemplation.

Well worth a visit. The temple of the Emerald Buddha is within the grounds of the Royal Palace. I found the outside of the temples more interesting than the contents inside. The sheer number and character of each temple is amazing and, in my opinion, far better than the main attraction of the Emerald Buddha. There are long queues to borrow appropriate clothing, as there is a strict dress code within the Palace complex. The Emerald Buddha was much smaller than I imagined, which was disappointing. No photographs or video are allowed inside the temple.
It's the place u should visit when u r in Bangkok. everyone comes here to see something distintively different from their own countries i think ;)

Worth a visit. The emerald buddha itself was very high and distant, so you could not see it well. From a distance it looked very small. However, the temple complex is worth a visit with some beautiful buildings.
Unbelieveable fine art. Never miss.. Thai Fine art both interior in the temple and sculpture out side te temple. Should not miss.
Absolutely beautiful. Do not believe anyone until you have seen with your own eyes.
Impressive but crowded. Very strict dress code and long queues to borrow suitable clothes. Officious man at the entrance was rather off-putting.
Must go, awesome. Fantastic, go the early morning because is very crowd. Don't miss this temple. The Grand Palace is incredible. Go with apropriate clothes ( the religion must be respected ) .

Wonderful!. 400 bahts per person to go in. Take a map it's a huge place.Get dressed properly, no naked legs / arms for women. Can't take any pictures inside the temple, wait to be outside. Before to go in take a flower put it into the holly water and place the flower above you head.It's just beautiful, don't forget to be generous there is a box donation. (The monks help young poor students to go to school.....)
An amazing architectural sight!. Lots of crowds, but well worth seeing. Try to take a guided tour if you can.

so much detail. my wife must have taken 100 pictures. so much history, so much detail. we are here in January so crowded and hot but it is one of those things that would be ashamed to miss. we did quick walk through and moved on to another temple (by taxi) which are inexpensive like $1 or $2)

Beautiful!. The outside of this temple always blows my mind when I visit. It's covered in all these tiny, colored mirrors and looks so intricate and busy (in a pleasing way). I can't imagine the time and effort put into decorating the whole thing. The emerald buddha himself (he's actually made of jade) is much smaller than I imagined, but I guess he's cool. He sits way up on a pile of what I think of as his treasure, and you're not allowed to take pictures inside, so you can't even get a good look at him through your camera lens. I find the outside of this temple to be more impressive than the inside.

Emerald Buddha. The touting outside the gates is getting worse , just find the entrance and go in , buy a guide book . There are times when you cannot go into the main temple due to prayers but you can see everything around whilst waiting . WEAR THE RIGHT CLOTHES when you go - saves being shouted to one side by the clothes police and having to queue for respctful outfits . On the way out its difficult to find a metered taxi - but there are some just persist .
It's made of jade!. Beautiful buddha that the King dresses four times a year! Lots and lots of tourists.

Anticlimactic.... Within the compound of the Grand Palace, where everything is so grandiose and ornate, this tiny Buddha was not what we expected. However, the inside of the temple is very detailed and full of offerings...worth a look. It was packed with Thais so it has significance.
Disappointing. The temple was fabulous but difficult to find and the Buddha was tiny. If time is short, give it a miss.
Emerald Buddha. A beautiful, ornate temple, the Buddha is actually made of Jade. The temple was crowded, but worth the visit and is included in the visit to the palace.
marvellous. The temple and its surroundings are just great. And even though I was expecting a bigger buddha statue, the decor of the place where it is set is very elaborate and lavish.

Must see when in Thailand. It's a very small statue actually, but is is surrounded by so many decorations, you don't know where to look first. And of course it is special because it is the most worshiped Buddha in Thailand.
Worth the trip. A beautiful temple and quite tranquil, even with all the people! One of the better temples, but the Buddha is hard to see.

beautiful but overrated temple. Very touristy temple.Crowded .The entrance fee is steep.The actual buildings inside are fantastic in terms of architecture and grandeur.The buddha itself was not very impressive.I personally found the chiang mai temples and wat arun much calmer and more spiritually uplifting.The Ramayana paintings on the walls surprised me- I was happy to find that the indians share common mythology with the thais.

Don't miss it. A beautiful temple, part of the palace complex so do mot tempt yourself to skip it after you've seen the palace simply because its wonderful. Everywhere you turn your eyes will encounter fabulous structures and ornamentation. Be ready to take off your shoes which is general practice in all Thai temples so easy slip-ons are the best solution for you;). There are also special rules for dressing but do not worry if it is hot you can rent it just for the visit.It will take you around 2-3 hours to visit the whole complex of the palace and Emerald Buddha temple and it is worth it the fee of 400 Baht
amazing. It's the most beautiful place a have ever see. We were in shorts, we had to rent a skirt to enter the temple, women must be in skirts, even in mini skirts.

All I expected. The God of the whole world grants his peace in this place to those who pray to him, even if they do not know his Pre eminent son. Hmmmmmmm! You have to take your shoes off inside Buddhist Temples so wear a slip on arrangement. I reminded myself not of the glory of the adornment of the object (as that would have been pagan) but of the loving worship these people have and their intent in giving glory to God. Is it not a shame that that the buddhist God has no identity except of a river of life or energy? How can one love a God who has no personal identity. Thank God I know my Heavenly Father, His pre eminent Son and The Holy Spirit who guides me daily.Christopher

Stunning golden temple .... It's going to be HOT, whenever you visit this temple. But, to allow time to appreciate it all take a hat, an umbrella maybe and stick to the shade where you can. No photos in the main building, but you can buy pictures and a guide book. Also, you may be put off by having to pay when Thai people don't, but remember they pay local taxes - you don't !
Just Peaceful.... It's a really unique temple with lots of history and so nice and claiming inside.

So much to see. Just watching the people visiting the Temple is so interesting. It was more expensive on this visit 400 Baht but worth it. Watch out for the conmen dressed in uniforms who will try to tell you that the temple is closed and take you away in a tuk tuk!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Got to see it. Part of the Royal Palace complex this temple is a must see. PLEASE read up on a few points of respect though, it was quite frustrating the amount of people pointing their feet at Buddha and taking photos....
Must See in Bangkok!. In addition to Wat Pho and Wat Arun - you must see Wat Phra Kaeo - and the Grand Palace. Incredible history. Beautiful religion.

Overwhelming. My advice is to take some time over visiting. I found I did not really spend enough time here. I would describe it as sumptous, fabulous but there were a lot of tourists aroundAlso be aware that there is some fake? tourist police man loitering around who informed me that the Wat was closed until later. He recommended me to take a tuk tuk to see the White Buddha (and yes I was daft enough to do this) and then of course the tuk tuk man tried to persuade me to go around numerous factories. I was not daft enough to do that, but wasted time on this little adventure. The tourist police man appeared to look the real thing, he had a badge and was sitting on a chair. Well yes maybe I am naive!
Emerald Buddha a must see!. I loved going inside with shoes removed and have a quiet moment to reflect, I also enjoyed the blessed water bowl outside.
Impressive Complex. Whilst the complex was very impressive, the Emerald Buddha statue, which is the main attraction, was hardly visible under the multiple golden shrouds it was wrapped in.
Nice. But nothing that different...kinda similar to other temples in Thailand and if I remember correctly kinda pricey.
Stunning. Unlike anything else on earth, must be seen! You must cover for Temple and remove footwear so bare that in mind. A day of temple tours is best and then you see it all.
Fascinating History. That Buddha has been around. The temple is on the grounds of the Grand Palace, which on a whole was very impressive.

Underwhelming. I'm not sure that reviews matter very much for the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. If you go to the Grand Palace you're going to go see it. We did, and we were pretty underwhelmed by the experience. The Grand Palace is a crowded place, and the Temple of the Emerald Buddha is the most crowded building within the Grand Palace grounds. The day we were there you really had to jostle to make your way inside. The temple is attractive enough, though there are plenty of attractive temples in Bangkok, but the real disappointment was the Emerald Buddha itself. It was sitting up very high and far back, and it's actually surprisingly small. So after all you've heard about it, and after the effort of getting inside to look at it, it's just not much to see. If you want to see a cool Buddha I'd recommend the Reclining Buddha or the Golden Buddha, both of which were far more impressive and far more pleasant to visit.

Small part of Grand Palace but worth it.. The palace is incredible and so worth visiting. The gardens are beautiful and the areas you can visit are very interesting, there are museums as well as the main areas.

I visited yesterday....100 Baht entrance fee was well worth it.... GREAT GIFT SHOP. After visiting the Grand Palace this was a short walk or Tuk Tuk ride several blocks to Wat Pho and the Recling Buddha. I've been there before and it was just as impressive. The gift shop there has inexpensive items that are very responably prices. My brother bought an impressive hand painted mask that was only 350 baht (@ $12) and a wonderful souvenier. All profits there go to the Temple. My Thai daughter-in-law said the prices were very good.
Another Buddha. Ended up on temple trip so one Buddha ends up looking like another
Temples. Go to all the Temples you can, they are out of this world - I couldn't go to Great Wat as it was under water when I was there, but I shall visit it in February.
Do visit. Lovely place to walk around, takes you back in time. Worth it. Entry charges for foreigners. i guess its 10 pounds

Very important to see this while in Bangkok. This is the holy of holy temples. I've seen this Emerald Buddha during different seasons and I love they way they actually put a different cloak on him depending upon the time of year. If not with a tour guide, it's worth it to listen to the audio of the palace to provide information on all the intricate details you will see.

Splendid. This is part of the Royal Palace. So this is a combined visit. The Emerald Buddha is not made of real gem. It used to be at That Luang in Vientiane and was shipped down to its present location. It is one of the holy Buddhist sanctuaries in Thailand. And like the rest of the Royal Palace, it is simply magnificent.
A must see as part of the temples tour. A must see as part of the temples tour, make it a day and include the Grand Palace.
A beautiful temple.... Very crowded and it's a shame that we cannot take picture up and close.

Never get bored even though I'm a frequent visitor!. The architecture is stunning! Also another landmark of Bangkok besides nearby Wat Arun. This landmark is photogenic and I spent more than 3 hours in this landmark. To be honest, I will visit this temple everytime I reach Bangkok.
Must see. This place has all the splendor you may expect from Thailand. They close early but the temperature and the crowds are more bearbale after 2pm.
Ok. Not much to see except all the Budhhas in various poses!
Amazing. If you go to Bangkok then you have to go to the Emerald Buddha, it did take us more than a morning to do and alot of walking but worth it
Emerald Buddha. I thought the Buddha was bigger after standing in lines and walking in crowd...............
Wee Buddha. He's only a little fella, but the place is really worth seeing.
Fantastic. Well presented and very impressive again though be aware of touts outside of temples etc
one of my favorites. Really enjoyed this spectacular Wat, a must see when in bangkok

Crowded. Too crowded, but still worth going? They have free water in tanks but I don't know its quality (also sell bottled water). Wear sleeved shirts and trousers or long skirts (you can borrow them for 200 baht deposit but you will lose at least 30 minutes for all these procedures).
Astonishing. Also very crouded but it should be better out of the top season.
A Must see for tourists. This is one of the places that you must visit in Bangkok. It's very close to the Grand Palace. Very clean and well kept.
Bling bling. The whole temple is so dazzling that you almost miss the emerald buddha.

Thailand's most Holy site. To visit the site you have to buy a combined (expensive) ticket which gives you entry to the Royal Palace. That ticket also gives you cost free entry to two other sites. As in all the sites in the old city, access can be a little tricky unless you can take a Tuk-tuk which includes a visit to a couple of shops, where they give the driver fuel coupons, which subsidise your trip. We arrived in the morning only to find the palace was closed for an official function, so negotiated a 2 hour round trip to the Golden Mountain, and the Wat In (with a 32 metre high Buddha), as well as two shops. Cost 20 baht. Anyway... when we arrived, the Wat Phra Kaeo was worth the fee and the wait. As I said, it is Thailand's most holy religious site and as such is filled at all times with people praying. The Buddha is small, but beautifully formed in so far as one can see, The temple itself is worth spending a good time to look at, as are the surrounding buildings.the Royal Palace, on the other hand was something of a disappointment. One major building was closed - under repair, and another was closed for a function. But nothing could detract from the Wat. A must see, NB knees AND ankles MUST be covered to gain admittance, and no exceptions are made. If you arrive improperly dressed you can rent suitable clothing for a monstrously inflated price. Be warned.
Mystical. It was a beautiful temple in the middle of the grand Palace compound ..the emerald Buddha was enchanting.
Amamzing Stuppas. Its a bit of a walk into the palace / temple area, but well worth it, the archtiecture is amazing. Go before 4pm when it closes.
Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaeo). Amazing is this temple for everywhere that you walk around the temple. Even you don't have your own guide but you can understand how is beautiful.

Another must see. This is such a significant part of Thai culture that you better go see it. It's close to lots of other important landmarks too! Don't forget to always kneel when taking a picture with a buddha statue

Emerald Buddha = Fantastic!. This temple is within the complex of the Grand Palace so you see both for the price of one! The Emerald Buddha sits atop a mountain of gold and jeweled stairs in the temple for all to see. My husband's cousin told us the monks change the Emerald Buddha's clothes for every season so you may see a different outfit each time you go. Be sure to wear a long skirt/pants and bring something to cover your shoulders out of respect. Also, we brought a pair of socks because you have to take off your shoes to go in to the temple and the pavement is VERY hot in August. :) Enjoy!

Golden. The entrance fee to the temple and Grand Palace is quite expensive, but it's worth the price and even worth battling the crowds. I suggest turning into the less explored byways of the temple, the wall murals surrounding the temple are fascinating.

Worth Seeing. We went to Wat Phra Kaeo inside of the Royal Palace. Photos aren't allowed inside and it is suggested you sit with your feet facing away from the Buddha. It can be very crowded so if you want a lot of time inside go early. The walls and ceiling are painted in small and intricate scenes which are extremely beautiful and overwhelming.

It's cool but nothing spectacular. Do go if it's something you want to check off your list. It's not too expensive and doesn't take very long. If it's something you really want to see, then definitely go. Just remember when I said to keep your expectations within reason or else you'll leave disappointed.

so busy!!!. there were so many other people there! it was a little too crowded for our taste.i wore a long cotton halter dress and had a large silk scarf covering my shoulders and back and still had to "borrow" a shirt.
a different way of tradition. one of the best in temples around Bangkok, interesting ritual also for that Budda

good temple, bad arrangement. temple is great, with lovely interior, but no clear cut directions as to where to open the shoes, what places to visit, makes it not the top one you would like to visit. it is too crowded outside, making it look unpleasant.
Very cultural. Well this place represent culture of thai intone old day and you can not mss as the visitor

beautiful and breath taking. Be respectful when in the Temple area and dress appropriately.. Like everything- culture and rich history.
Can be a bit crowded with tourists who some of them are not respectful when in the Temple area and very annoying at times.

Like a scene from a fairy story. Thais get in free bur others have to pay. however it is one of the highlights of Bangkok. It is how you imagine Thailand. By the way ignore the people who tell you "it is closed today - visit this gift shop instead"

Make sure to cover shoulders and knees!. Lovely day out - loads to see, observe and read about in the free handout. Amazing architecture, loads of gold and sequins.
The reclining Buddha is located about 10 minutes walk away so worth going there too!

A sight to see. The Emerald Buddha is something you must see if you visit Bangkok. You cannot take pictures or videos inside the temple building itself but you can see into the temple from outside and you can take pictures from there if you have a camera with zoom lens.
~*~ Stunning ~*~. Spiritually amazing, calming and a must place to visit, we enjoyed ourselves throughly!

Great!!!. Wat Phrasrirattana Sasadaram (Wat Phra Kaeo), or the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, situated within the Grand Palace, near Sanam Luang, is a sacred symbol of the Rattanakosin, or Bangkok, Dyansty and the most important temple in realm. It was built by King Rama I, the founder of the Chakri Dynasty, at the same time as the Grand Palace in 1782, when he established Bangkok as his capital, in order to serve as the palace chapel, in which traditional royal ceremonies would be conducted. It thus has a sanctuary for the performance of Buddhist rites, but no residences for monks.The temple is richly endowed with fine art and architecture. The Emerald Buddha image is enshrined in the phra ubosot, the exterior walls of which are covered with beautiful designs in gold leaf and glass, while the interior walls bear murals depicting the life of Buddha and other subjects.The phra mondop, or library, is set on a high base surmounted by a stepped pyramid. Inside is reserved a chest containing the Tripitaka, the Buddhist sacred scripture.The Royal Pantheon, or Prasat Thepbidon, has a high spire. Inside are enshrined statures of the eight previous kings of the Chakri Dynasty.Next to phra mondop is a miniature replica of Angor Wat, which King Rama IV had constructed.The walls of the cloister are decorated with murals showing scenes from the Ramakian, the Thai version of the Ramayana. These were originally painted during the reign of King Rama I and have been restored several times.
Great viewing. Able to get up close but buddha was smaller than others

Must do for tourists. You simply must go if you want any credibility with other travelers. Please note - ANYONE WHO TRIES TO TELL YOU THE WAT IS CLOSED IS TRYING TO SCAM YOU! Beware the wily speaker of English! (so warns the Thai government about Wat Phra Keaw.)
Inexpensive impressive.. Grand palace and surrounding area well worth time.

Get there early. Unmissable part of the Grand Palace. Men and women have to have long pants/skirt, covered shoulders. Bring water with you and patience for the crowds or get there early. Express boat stop: Tha Tien or Tha Chang. Don't miss the amulet market close by, starting already from Tha Chang stop via Th Maharat street.
Big Crowds, Small Buddha. It was a let down for me. So small and so far away from where we sat. The short-sighted like me should remember to bring their glasses.

Very impressive. Definately worth visiting. If people outside tell you it is closed, continue walking, they are trying to scam you. Please note the dress code, depending on who is working the door, they will not allow sleeveless shirts or shorts for men or women. They were supplying clothes the day we were there but I'm not sure this always the case. Entrance we is cash only, but there are ATMs near by. The structures are impressive to see, as well as the art surrounding them.
beautiful Wat. go at night, open, no other visitors and still a special, interesting place with mosaics, statues and wall frescos clearly visible
Awesome!. This is an awesome place, but the emerald Bhudda is very small and on a high pedestal.
impressive. Right next to Wat Prah Kheo. Included in entrance fee. Impressive set-up inside.

Beautiful and Amazing. The words can not describe enough for the value and beauty of this special place. Once you there you will never forget and you'll want all of your friends to experience like you too.Just Amazing and Excellent. Is the gem of Asia.
Quite a marvel. Not cheap to get in but very impressive and beautiful.
The middle of Bangkok is here!. The most special temple in Bangkok..only one word "GO!!"

Fascinating!. We have seen a lot of Buddha temple in BKK. All of it were great... You may take a photo of the Emerald Buddha, just outside from where you can still see it. However, if you go inside the temple. No taking photos allowed.
Just good.. good but not unforgettable. The emerald Buddha is actually made of jasper and it's sooooo tiny. As usual the complex is beautiful though, I think it's better than the statue itself.
a must. without seeing it, it is like you never went to Bangkok.

Nice temple but a bit of a tourist trap. It was nice to look at the emerald buddha, but it is about 100 ft away and you can't take pictures from the inside. The temple and its decorations are absolutely stunning.
really special. This may have been one of my most favorite temples because of the history it holds and so many Thai people really cherish the Emerald buddha. Gets crowded - be there early!
New Year Luck. January 1,2012 too many people there, do not go there during any festival or ceremonies

awesome. Solemn, despite the crowd, even more amazing once you learn the history of the statue.
Very cool, a definite must-see
Gem of a temple. No pictures allowed. The serenity is breathtaking, lovely place to sit down, meditate and observe

Excellent with a Palace Guide!. This was our fourth visit to The Grand Palace and the only time I felt that we really walked away with a good understanding and appreciation for it. We planned on doing the the audio tour but ended up hiring an official palace guide instead. The audio tour costs 200 baht per person and the guide's cost was 600 baht. We had 4 people in our group so we decided to go with the guide. This guide was hired inside the palace gates (not outside) and was wearing an official name tag. (Khun Tui was his name and you could ask for him personally just outside the door where you would rent clothing). The tour was fairly comprehensive for a day visit (just under two hours total). The only down side was that we felt just a bit rushed to go on with the tour, just remember that this is a private tour and go at your own pace. The tour includes two different sections of the palace, once you leave the first section, you cannot go back! Your guide will tell you this as well and give you extra time for photos if you need it. We started out tour at 2 p.m. and by 4:00 p.m. (around closing time) the crowds were gone and we could enjoy ourselves more. I liked that I could ask questions and get answers where as with the audio tour you cannot and without either you're just reading out of a book the whole time or not learning anything. FYI: If you finish the Grand Palace just before closing, head over to Wat Pho which is open until 6 or 7 and you will pretty much have the place to your self. See my review on Wat Pho for more info on that!
Inside Grand Palace - peaceful break in the shadow. nice place to enjoy a place of peace and quiet while walking around the grand palace
Blissful!. We had a great guide (Ms Jacky). Look for her when you are @ the Palace.

A spectacle to be seen. Grand Palace was great. It was very crowded but we went on the last holiday vbefore everyone returned to work in the New Year. Don't believe what anyone tells you about it being closed. Its not. They are just trying to con you!

Also known as Emerald Buddha Temple. This famous Royal temple is within Grand Palace Premises... so if you wish to visit this temple, make sure to enter from Grand Palace entrance cause then you wud be able to visit the Grand Palace too as there is an entry fee of Bht 500.00 per person.

Been there Done that.. now.. This is one of the "Main" tourist attractions of Bangkok. It may be important to locals but the Buddha is a bit disappointing,very small and hard to see. The Wat is interesting but with thousands of people there it is hard to get arround. Again the tour guide points out all the things that we cannot see either because it is the wrong time of the year or because it it not a working day.
Don't miss if you are in grand palace. Well worth seeing - it's a very holy site so you have to dress appropriately.
Emerald Buddha. Thought it would be bigger but obviously a must see as part of the Grand Palace tour

Place U must go when in bangkok. Beautiful Pagodas, temples, historic pictures on the walls, Emerald Bhuda in the temple, free English speaking guides at 10 and 10:30 am and may be afternoon for 1 hr.No store to buy food or water.Easy to reach by boat from many piers to Ta Chang Pier # 9 and a little walk, than by car or taxi with traffic jam

behave nicely. It is true in general in Thailand that they highly expect that you recpect their religion - Emerald Buddha temple was the place where I noticed some locals, approaching tourists who sat down to call their attention: it is not allowed/preferred to turn your barefeet towards the Buddha - so be careful how you sit and enjoy the atmosphere and rich decoration of the temple

oh, the crowds. We got here what we thought was early in the day in March. It was very, very crowded. Difficult to see Buddha because there were so many people. Heads up...be aware that in the temples you have to remove your shoes
Must see. Great place to visit. Beatiful and exotic.Dont miss it
A masterpiece. The Emerald Buddha is really a masterpiece of art and culture.

see on your tour of the Grand Palace. again another fab aged religious monument that is a must-see when in BKK, you combine the ticket with the visit to the Grand Palace, photographs are allowed from outside which make great momentos through the open door of the temple

Extremely Extravagant. Temple of the Emerald Buddha. So much to see, so many spires, so many statues, so many tiles and mosaics and detail. It's so colorful and "over the top" in so many ways it's magical. It's also very crowded and you can't take pictures of the emerald buddha. Easily takes a couple hours to see everything.
Have to see. Amazing temple and decoration, need half a day at least. closes at 3pm so come early.

We have expected more.... It's the most importnt temple for buddhists, but we were quite disappointed: we've expected the Buddha statue to be bigger - in fact it is quite small and we were told it is actually not made from emerald ;-) Additionally, you are not allowed to take photos inside the temple.

Very detailed. It is a beautifully made it is great to see with the sun shining down. To save time pick up a wrap skirt if you are planning to wear shorts otherwise be ready to wait in line and borrow.
Don't miss it. Stunning creation with great views when you've climbed the very steep steps - not for the faint-hearted but worth it ! The surrounding buildings and grounds are well worth exploring.

Such architecture. This place is huge but well worth a visit even tho getting the can be a bit of a hassle. We had to take the metro and then. Tuk tuk, Void the offer of a very reasonable 20 baht as this will involve trips to shops and sponsors that will want to sell you things and waste Lot of your time. These sponsors pay the tuk tuk drivers to take you there. Once you do get Tyne wat it is a very reasonable 50 baht to get in and you can wander around for hours as the place is huge and there is so much to see.

Breathtaking.. In the sun, the exterior of the temple looks like a jewelbox, with glittering colourful glass on the walls, as well as painted pictures. The size and height of the temple is astounding, mostly due to the colour it gives off. The inside of the temple is quiet and reverent, despite the tourists. Many Thais as well as tourists visit the temple, and you'll see monks and other Thais praying in the cool interior, giving the whole temple a much more 'real' feeling. The Buddha himself is smaller than one might expect given the size of the temple, but it and the decorations around it are lovely. Definitely a must-see in Bangkok!

Wow !. We spent a good amount of time inside the temple of emerald buddha ! The entire room was full of so many inticrately carved wood, beautiful lighting, peaceful and had a vibrant energy !!! A sure shot visit if traveling to bangkok !

Absolutely Beautiful!. Worth the trip. It can be unbearable hot in the summer, but pick an overcast day, and you'll have no problem! (plus there's an Au Bon Pain across the street :) Also, in order to avoid the long lines to borrow clothes (long pants/skirts) bring some pieces of fabric to wrap around yourself! easy peazy!
Magnificent. Go early in the morning! Costs approx 10 euro to get in. But totally worth it.
Very busy but part of the grand palace ticket. There are always hundreds of people here but it is an impressive site.

Shows the Thai attitude towards tourists. I can't understand why there are three listings for the same attraction:- Temple of the Emerald Buddha- Wat Phra Kaew- Grand PalaceNote to webmasters: combine these three as they are just one attraction!These are all located in the very same compound and are covered by one entrance ticket priced a rather hefty 400 baht (as everything is relative and comparison may be needed, the minimum daily wage in Thailand hovers around 150-200 baht a day and is due to go up to 300 baht in 2012 - that's about 10 US dollars).BTW, this complex shows the essence of Thai temple architecture indeed, as well as the insidious dual pricing policy slapped on all foreigners: free for Thais, 400 baht for tourists.Still, this wonderful temple and palace complex is not to be missed, but don't give in to touts, tuk-tuk drives or other scam artists who have ruined many a holiday by luring unsuspecting tourists away from genuine attractions into overpriced city tours and gem shops.

Still amazing yet rather expensive at 400+ baht entry fee. One of the highlights of Bangkok, but unfortunately authorities in charge are trying to milk this attraction for all it's worth. Entry fees used to be 150 baht a decade ago, but are now at 400 baht and likely to go up even more (BTW, Thais go in for free).Thais seem to have this bizarre logic that if tourist numbers go down, prices shouldn't be made more attractive to lure new customers, but rather go up to make up for the lost income.Don't believe the touts and scam artists outside the complex who tell you it isn't open for the day and want to take you on an overpriced trip instead.Dress appropriately (no short, tank tops, flip-fliops etc.).

Interesting statue, beautiful room. That statue has an interesting history and is very unique, but I've seen many Buddha statues throughout Asia. I was very impressed by the room itself, golden statues and decoration, beautiful walls and ceiling. Very quiet and peaceful inside, super crowded right outside to get in.

Wonderful, crowded, and expensive for foreigners. Although I have only spent a short time in Bangkok, this is my top Bangkok sight to see. Amazing design and architecture (especially for a first trip to Thailand), great opportunities for pictures, and interesting culture and history. Of course it was very crowded (on a Saturday) in some areas, but there was a bit of relative peace and quiet to find here and there. 400 Baht for foreigners. That seems very high, while Thai nationals enter for free. I strongly disagree with the 'foreigners pay more' trend in Thailand. I suppose there are claims as to why it's necessary, but I think it's shameful. Amazingly, some travelers still fall for the tuk tuk tour scams, be careful.
Worth the visit!. Its a must in Bangkok, definatly worth the time and the money. Dont miss it!
Beautiful. But crowded. Try to go off peak hours. Definitely a must see. And dress properly. And no, it is never closed, despite way all the touts are telling you outside.

A nie tourist experience. A bit expensive to get in. Be sure to wear conservative clothing. Impressive architecture & designs. The Emerald Buddha is far away enough that you can't see much detail, but it's still worth the experience.

Hot hot hot. This is a must see - but do remember to dress modestly - ie, ladies a below the knee skirt, or long trousers, men wear trousers and no sleeveless shirts. We wasted some time renting clothes!
A bit disappointed!. Expected a bigger statue for the size of temple and so!
A must see. Wonderful taste of Thailand and it's culture, a place where serenity can still be found among the crowds.
gold all over!!!!. not to miss. such architecture!!!!! the 400 bath was steep but worth it

Must-See Site... The Best of All Temples in Thailand!. Wat Phra Kaew (or the Temple of the Emerald Buddha) is a must-see site for any trip to Bangkok. It is the premier Wat in all of Thailand. The architecture is beautiful and extravagant. After you see Wat Phra Kaew, all of the other temples (and there are a lot of them) are unexceptional to a non-Buddhist tourist.
good. It must take a century to get to build this pagoda as its complicated designs

The Soul of the Thai people. One of the most if not the most reverie temples in Thailand. a spiritually moving experience no matter what your religious believes. warning they have a strict dress code no shorts or sleeveless shirts/blouses. It you are not dressed properly you can borrow clothes at the entrance. Beware of people approaching you outside the temple telling you it is closed, they just want to divert you to an high pressure sales establishment
The most beautiful Temple ever!!!. This is the most beautiful temple i have seen in life, decorated by vaieties of jewelly in Traditional Thai Style. Must see!!!

Biggest Emerald Buddah in the World. The tour is basic (after all the Temple tours we had in the same day), but it's interesting to see a real emerald buddha too.. This will take about 20-30 minutes max..

Interesting History behind it but still just another statue. The story behind the emerald buddah is interesting but at the end of the day it is another buddah statue. Great if you are into buddah statues it is located in the grand palace.
Lovely temple. Its my preferred temple, also called the temple of Dawn. Small and intimite, made of recycled porcelain. Its on the other side of the river but easily accessible with the boat

Very Interesting. The architecture is mind blowing. The detailing is very intricate and just amazes me.It is a cultural visit in BKK, the view from the temple across the river is something that reminds me of the place.
Thai Culture and History. This was an amazing site- far better than I expected. Definitely worth a visit if you wish to see authenthic Thai culture. One of the wonders of Bangkok.

a must see. a must see at least once when visiting Bangkok. No taking pictures allowed inside. There is ritual in front of the temple doors that shows water with the use of a lotus on the head of the people which i think should bring good luck.
nice temple. This temple is a nice temple to visit ,good to have excellent memories from Bangkok. You can shoot your camera full with the most beautiful pictures
Very interesting temple. We enjoyed our visit to the Grand Palace complex.

Magnificent temple! Should visit this place which is located at the beautiful Grand Palace.. During my 3 day visit to Bangkok, I visited this temple which is also called Temple of the Emerald Buddha. It's very convenient as it's in the same location where the Grand Palace is. Take BTS and stop at Saphan Taksin, take exit 2 to central pier, take Chao Phraya Express boat & get off at Maharaj Pier which is the closest one to Grand Palace. Please note that most info available on the internet says to get off at Tha Tien Pier (N8) or Tha Chang Pier (N9), however the staff at Chao Phraya Express boat explains that Maharaj Pier is the closest, they're right. Once I got off at Maharaj Pier, I was lucky there were so many tourists too, I just followed their ways, LOL.
Nice emerald boucddha. Nice site not my favorite but still nice to see...better to do a fee sites the same day with private guide.cheap and pro call eddy at thailand voyage.com
Lovely. A must we did go to all mjoratrctions and tmples by privat tour with eddy at thailandvoyage.com
It is smaller than I though but beautiful. It is inside of the Grand Palace, very nice. Don't forget to use long skirts or paints and covered shoulders.

Amazing pictures. Without doubt the most beautiful tourist attraction of Bangkok. Temple of Thai culture very interesting. One of the best programs I've done while traveling around the country. The audio guide is not the most organized, often hindering understanding. If you are wearing shorts or something short, get a free long pants at the entrance.

Make sure you check the times (and then it still may be closed). Traveled to the Grand Palace twice during stay. Both times it was CLOSED. Two wasted trips. It is not close and not on any MRT or BST lines - only the water taxi. Normally closed at 3:30 and when you go around Christmas it may close for special Thai only times.Have your hotel concierge VERIFY the times it will be open - you cannot just "stop by". It does not follow the normal hours of every other place in Bangkok.

could not believe in my eyes. Special building to learn about buddism in Thailand. Teriffic architect with all the single detailed decoration. It must take a century to get to build this pagoda as its complicated designs. I will definitely be back to see this building next time visiting Bangkok.
Part of Temple complex. A beautiful temple that holds a special place among Thais. Even non-Buddhists will sense the special nature of this temple.
Bangkok Icon. This whole temple complex is a feast to the eyes. Great souvenir pics, reasonable crowds. Worth the visit.

The only Must-See Temple. Thai temples are beautiful. They're historic. They're interesting. But after the first 20, they start to get a little boring.So Wat Phra Kaew is the exception... It's vast, interesting and breathtaking. There's so many incredible works of art here you can easily spend more than half a day wandering around the grounds.Entrance is 200 baht (I think) unless you are a Thai Buddhist. I recommend getting the tour guide, which is a little recorded tour that leads you around and provides information on what you are seeing.Also the Grand Palace is connected to the temple, so you get to visit both places AND there's a bonus as the entrance fee includes entrance to the Vimanmek Teak Mansion.Two important things to note...1 Wear appropriate clothes for visiting an important religious building.and2 DO NOT LISTEN TO THE PEOPLE WHO TELL YOU IT'S CLOSED!!! As you walk towards the temple, well-dressed, polite Thais will inform you that today is a Buddhist holiday or an election or construction work being carried out... blah blah blah... They are lying.... YOU ARE ABOUT TO BE SCAMMED.This happens all day, every day, right in front of the police and temple authorities. Ignore them. Don't worry about offending them, smile and say, "OK Thanks" and keep walking... Check it yourself. I've never seen it closed.If you stop and talk to the scammers, you will be taken by tuk tuk to a gem shop, or a scummy temple, or a tailors, or a boat ride... All of which will waste your holiday time and almost certainly cost you money.It's a blight on Thailand and one which needs addressing, but if the Thai government won't do anything about it, YOU have to make sure you don't fall prey to them. If the scammers didn't make money out of it, they'd give up and get a proper job.
Opulent. The Emerald Buddha is amazing. Look and don't think it is another form of idolatry
Emerald Buddha. Beautiful Thai piece worth seeing in all it;'s glory

Inside the Grand Palace. Very calm and clearly the focal point of the religion and impressive inside. Shoes have to be removed and you must not point your feet towatrd the Buddha as it is an insult. Hence all the kneeling.
a must. Fir first time visitors in Bangkok this temple is a must. Nobody would regret going there. Beautifull and interesting.
See my comments on the Grand Palace. Don't be conned by the people at the gate - go just inside and get a guide there
Amazingly ornate temple. Beautiful temple with rich wall decoration and ornate paintings and sculpture. Access is via the Royal Palace.
stunning and worth the visit. The grounds were beautiful and for as many museums, forts, and palaces I've seen, I still found this one beautiful. Well worth the visit when in Bangkok.
Emerald Buddha. This is the Most Honoured Buddha in Thailand. During the different seasons it will change the clothing.
Gold all the way. It is amazing to see all these lovely temples and the beautiful Grand Palace. Do go early or in lunchtime to avoid big crowds.

Glitzy and camp. Be aware of the dress code. Legs need to be covered. They will provide you with long pants. Touts outside will tell you if you have shorts that you cant get in and that they will show you other things.
Don't miss.. We are making our probable last trip to Thailand (after visiting here more than a half dozen times) and this is the place we had to see again. Go early---it opens at 8:30.
Unbelievable. The splendour and spirituality of this place really overwhelms you.
Amazing. We were on a guided tour and some of the things that the guide pointed out were just incredible.

One of the great sights of Thailand. The amount of gold is so over-whelming and the number of buildings so extensive that you keep turning your head around every few seconds to see something else. It's an amazing place that must be seen to be believed. Truly one of the great sights in the world it cannot be missed. Please dress appropriately as this is both a religious and royal sight.
Beautiful. Liked entire visit, thought entry prices to high for foreigners!

Beautiful and very exquisite architecture. Join the free tour after the entrance to learn more about the history of the Temple and National Palace. The detailed designs that were hand crafted and built represent the passion and respect the Thai people have for the Emerald Buddha.The thing people need to watch out is at the entrance, there are people trying to divert foreigners into other sights by telling them that the temple is only open to Thais at the time of the visit and that they recommend you to visit something nearby. Watch out for the scams unfortunately

Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Our guide explained the protocol when visiting this temple and we were grateful for his guidance. A beautiful Buddha, suitably dressed for the season, in a wonderful setting.
Breathtaking. Miss this at your peril. It is not like so many of the other temples and should not be missed.
Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Inside the Grand Palace and well worth a visit. An amazing collection of temples. Too many visitors with digital cameras all trying to take the perfect photograph!
Hail Buddha!. The Emerald Buddha is within the Grand Palace. It is very holy and very beautiful. They change his outfit three times a year to suit the season. Don't miss it.
Emerald Buddha. Well worth seeing. A lot smaller than led to believe, but still truly delightful. He was wearing his winter coat in 34 degree temp.

Simply unbelievable. I've been to some of the world's greatest religious sites and this may well be the best of them all. It is breathtaking and not to be missed if you are in Bangkok. Words cannot describe the beauty of the temple grounds.
beautiful temple. The detailes work and colours of the temple are amazing! Well worth seeing.

totally awesome and incredible architecture. must see attraction when you're in bangkok. its an ancient woth incredible architecture - totally awesome. no need to take the tour guide available outside - i regretted it. because you can just read the history from the flyers and able to spend more time taking pictures when you inside the compound.
Little Emerald Buddha. I love visiting all the wats and going to see lots of buddhas!

Inside photography is not allowed but the Emerald Buddha is worth watching. We went this place while visiting the Grand palace as it is inside the grand palace premises. This is also very beautiful as other temples, statues in the grand palace premises. The Buddha idol is made of Emerald so it is green in color.. and any one can imagine it is too expensive as such big statue made of emerald.

The Grand Palace. The place is packed with travellers but definitely worthwhile.
There's no air condition, so it is very very hot.
Very interesting. Spectacular but the Buddha itself is very small and photos can only be taken from outside, so you need a good zoom.
Spectacular. A must see. You won't believe the beauty of it all until you do.
Cultural without being commercial. Very well run and informative. We were able to go around at our own pace, the only thing I regret was not getting one of the guides from the front gate.
National Treasure!. You can miss is gem of a royal temple when you are in Bangkok. Watch out for the Tuk Tuk and Taxi Scams!

Beautiful. The temple is very impressive and it is surrounded by the vast green fields. We just love the scene when we were on the road turning around to the temple’s gate. There were some guys dressing in traditional clothes try to hook us for some tour on tuk tuk while the rest of them stayed behind our backs. Luckily the tour guide knew how to deal with these guys and we’re safe for the rest of trip. Many many many thanks to Mr.Hiep from Asia Tour Advisor company for your safe and sound trip.

A scene from fairytales. Golden spires and with jewel like stones adorning the walls. The Grand Palace complex is a gleaming memorial to Thailand's royal heritage. It was like being in the land of fairytales.

A Sight to Be Seen. When we heard of the Emerald Buddha, we thought we would see a gigantic Buddha. The Emerald Buddha is much smaller than we anticipated, but a beautiful sight. The temple is a sacred place, and those visiting should remember this. Temple etiquette was not observed by many while we were there (heads up to those that are searching this), but it did not ruin our visitation.

Small and impressive. The actual buddha itself is quite small but very impressive. You can go in different times of year and see different garb. Also be sure to soak in the people making offerings, the wonderful murals, and the great exterior.
WOW. Everyone should visit the Themple of the emerald Budha while in Bangkok!!! It is very interesting and should not be missed!

worth going to see. This was one of the things I really wanted to see. A Buddha in emerald. It was quite big but I could not get very close. There are lots of things to see at the Grand Palace and you cannot get through everything. This is definately one of the things I would try to see
Emerald Buddha. Another excellent Wat with stunning detail and a beautiful carved buddha.
You will love this tiny, but so important Budha :-). Really impessive Wat to visit. An absolute must see, this Wat is one of the most important, historic and religious ones in Bangkok! Don't miss it!
Good. I liked the grand temple and the serene atmosphere, did not like the fuss over covering the tourists legs and arms while visiting the temple as many localities went in shorts and vests ..
So much gold. Very busy but overall an extraordinary place, lots of guides but easy to walk around on your own

a must see. Thai people get in free (or very cheaply) while farang pay $10 each.
I've been twice--first time in 1989--it's stunning. If I was in Bangkok with someone who'd never been I'd go again.
A must. See above description. Green buddah that is dress according to the season. If you are lucky, watch the changing of his clothes
A must. The little green buddah. A must on the tourist circuit.

A learning experience. Too much to type but you should not miss this. There is a mini Angkor Wat on display along with several structures of mixed cultures. When you go into the Emeral buddha temple you must take your shoes off and no pix were allowed - when we were there
amazing temple. a very beautiful well maintained temple, lots of amazing buildings and statutes- very old indian culture moving from cambodia to laos and finally to siam - highly recommended

It's worth visiting but...... Warning to tourists... avoid those crooks who are nicely dressed who are bound to approach you to say that the establishment is CLOSED FOR THE TIME BEING/ WILL REOPEN AT A LATER TIME. They will suggest a non-famous tourist attraction via tuktuk for only 40 Baht. Sounds cheap? Maybe, but their real intention is to take you to a shop where drivers can get commissions through gas coupons. Once you said yes and ride the tuktuk and then realize that you've been scammed before the whole trip is over, the tuktuk driver will charge you 100 Baht. Poor tourists -- they do become victims.

Amazing - but beware of tuk tuk drive lies. Went up by tourist express ferry. $5 for all day. last ferry at 4.30 pm. Beware of lies from Tuk Tuk drivers. One told us that the Grand Palace & Emerald Buddha were only open today from 1 - 3 pm for Thai nationals. He offered to take us on a 2 hour tour of other attractions + a tie factory and bring us back at 3pm. This was complete bull.... and the Grand Palace & Emerald Buddha were open only until 3.30 pm. This is the 4th ruse we had been told by tuk tuk drivers. Stick to Taxi Meters cabs who will put the meter on. Air conditioned, $1.20 flag fall and half the price of tuk tuks. Also in tuk tuks unless you are very short you can't see out from under the low canopy to sight see... or you have a cricked neck.
Most sacred Temple in Bangkok. No photos allowed inside. That was the only draw back, but it is a sacred place.
Interesting place. Interesting place. Is part of the royal palace complex, so don't get confused. Make sure you are properly dressed. Can't take photos of the Buddha

BANGKOK'S NUMBER ONE DESTINATION. Wat Prah Kaeo adjoins the Grand Palace, both a must-see in Bangkok. While a solemn, sacred, religious center, it immerses the visitor in the ancient, mystical, magical, real, surreal backdrop that makes Thailand so enchanting and captivating. WIthin the wat is "Bot" Phra Kaeo, housing the emerald buddha, its center piece. Outside Bot Phra Kaeo, scattered throughout the grounds are a maze of religious buildings/structures along with an army of magical, mystical figures guarding and protecting the sacred grounds. Extensive portico's displaying complex Ramakien murals surround the grounds. It is a beautifully designed and maintained and is a serious destination worth serious study before visiting. The cacophony and complexities of modern life lie just outside. It's at this spot, one begins to reflect on how Thai's so comfortably marry and integrate ancient religious traditions with modern life. Paradoxes of past and present coalesce providing a deeper, richer understanding of today's Thailand.Proper dress is to be observed. (nagging) Guides are available at the entrance and likely worht hiring. Foreigner's pay entrance fees while Thai's rigthfully have free entrance.
Excellent!. Temples were amazing, we spent all day here, definelty a must see on your visit to Thailand.
An amazing sight. This was an amazing temple - very intricately and beautifully decorated, a fascinating sight and well worth the visit. Make it a priority - you won't regret it.

Magestic temple - beautiful Jade Buddha. I have visited the Temple of the Jade Buddha 4 times now and this this was the first visit that I have actually gone inside and sat on the floor - just so that I could take in all the beauty that is this temple. On every visit to the temple, I make sure I immerse a long stemmed lotus flower into the holy water outside the temple and dab this on my head for good luck. Hope you enjoy this temple experience, as much as I do each time.Happy and safe travels!Sean

Beautiful!. This beautiful, ancient Buddha is amazing - and to think it was disguised with a white covering, until it was chipped, revealing the gorgeous colour underneath! Stunning display. We paid extra to go through the Museum, which was worthwhile, and very informative. The only annoying part of the tour (as is the case with many tours in Thailand) was the amount of locals trying to sell you souvenirs, postcards, etc. We even had a man who had taken our photos (without our knowledge), trying to sell us a badge with our pictures on it! Worth a visit - and don't forget to cover up in the Temple, or use one of the shawls provided as you enter.
Amazing sight and one that shouldnt be missed when here. Was just great to be able to enter the temple and gaze at the sights

Permanent resident? Pay tourist price, thank you. Don't expect to get in for the same price as a Thai if you are a permanent resident and clearly non-Thai (white). Caucasian means full tourist price, even when accompanied by your Thai family. Differential pricing is still alive and well in Thailand.
Beautiful!. the place is amazing! Take audio-guide to explore the palace ant the temple!
Can't visit Bangkok without Emerald Buddha!. Quite an interesting temple! Largest emerald buddha in the world and the king/prince changes it's clothing every season.

Very beautiful - and it IS open :). Very beautiful and breathtaking! Like others have said (and like we read in our guidebook), beware of touts outside the complex telling you it is closed. Our taxi dropped us off right outside the entrance (well, just behind it so that we couldn't quite see that that was it) and a man immediately told us that was not the entrance and to walk about two hundred yards to another entrance. We looked at him like "What are you talking about?" He kept pushing us in that direction, claiming he was security (dressed in plain clothes? Ha! Yeah, right!). So we walk down to the other "entrance" only to be met by other men who told us the palace was closed because it was a Thai Buddha holiday. UGH! We knew we'd been had and walked back to the first entrance and got in just fine. It just makes you so mad that people will blatantly lie to you when you are just trying to enjoy your vacation.It was the most expensive place we visited at 400 baht per person. But the complex is massive and there is so much to see. It was very hot, even here toward the end of November, and the sun was unrelenting. Which can make the throngs of people all vying to snap the same picture you are a little frustrating. But relax and enjoy it! There are plenty of shaded places to take refuge :) We only wish we could go in the beautiful buildings. You can go inside the Bot of the Emerald Buddha, but you can't take pictures! Oh well. Still a very worthwhile way to spend a couple of hours.
spend hours! A beautiful place, very peaceful. They have kept the palace in such good shape. I would be very proud of it.
Nice temple. I think this is very beautiful temple, will recommend anyone to go there.

A very nice buddhist temple. I like all Thai buddhist temples, I find them fine, elegant and still bright and colorful. The emerald buddha is made of jade, not emerald but Thailand is renown for having fine jade.The statue is sitting on top of a mountain of gold ... a golden stage, golden decorations, golden flowers.... I love the wall decorations which are antique and well kept.The temple is peaceful and beautiful.

Bangkok will be incomplete without the grand palace. This palace is very beautiful and impressive. At 400 bahts per person, It is the most expensive attraction site in Bangkok but well worth it. (wat pho and wat arun are 50 bahts each and are must see). Everyone is required to cover up their bodies before entering. They will rent you different articles of clothing (each at 200 baht refunded upon return of the clothes). At first it’s difficult to realize how big this place it. At one point I asked myself why was it called the grand palace? it isn’t so grand after all! but I was wrong. This thing goes on forever. It is worth noting that is very easy to miss the emerald Buddha even if you are in the grand palace. I missed it. a) I didn’t know that the emerald Buddha was in the grand palace and b) there was little to no sign with good direction. This is one place to exhaust your camera's battery. I did! you may want to make sure its super charged before you go there or bring a spare. You might need it. Make sure your memory card has plenty space on it as well, it will be a shame to have to delete other pictures.One last but important thing to note is that there are people standing around the palace saying that it is closed and offering to take you to another destination. BEWARE.... the palace closes at 4pm. I was told by tuk tuk men and other people that I shouldn’t bother with the palace because it wasn’t opened. Big lie, I got to the palace and walked right in and once i got to the real official workers I was told they close at 4pm. Too many people in Bangkok will readily lie to you to get your money. I'M SORRY TO SAY BUT THERE ARE NO GOOD SAMARITANS AROUND THE BIG SITES IN BANGKOK.Overall, this place is impressive and I highly recommend it. I will post pictures ASAP.

Less-heavily promoted places are more enjoyable to me.. Yes, it's impressive. But the Golden Mount and several other temples in Bangkok, Schwedagon in Yangon, Doi Sutep in Chiang Mai, the Nakhon Phatom Chedi, the temple at the Royal Palace in Phnom Penh, were all more impressive to me. It's no fault of the place, or the temple builders. It's just an after-effect of the hyped build-up, compared to the reality.

One of the three must-see sites in Bangkok. You've probably seen your share of temples or religious sites in your time, but Wat Phra Kaew is in a league of its own. Magnificent, colorful, opulent, serene, exquisitely detailed, words are not enough to describe it, this is just one of those places you must have seen to believe it. So many details, statues, wall paintings, spires, giant guardians and of course the piece de resistance: The emerald Buddha. Take at least 2 hours to be able to see everything, and an hour more if you want to take in all the sights in detail. Keep in mind that the temple and palace close at 3:30 pm! Also: to save time, make sure you're dressed properly (shoulders, legs and feet fully covered and no cleavage) or you'll be redirected to the long line at the "dressing room" where you'll be issued with a loaner sarong, scarf or long pants.Once inside, there are enough options to get some help and explanation along the way. - First option is to just pay the entry fee (400 THB) and walk around with the help of the provided brochure.- Second option is to hire a guide (prices vary) who will happily take you around. BEWARE: only take a guide if he's waiting close to the ticket booth (well inside the palace grounds). The ones outside of the main gate with the photo folders are usually too expensive and will try to rush you through the grounds. Don't be scammed into buying tickets from them or them telling you you need a different entrance.- Third option is to hire an audio-guide (200 THB for 2 hours, credit card or passport needed as deposit) that will tell you about all the sights in a language of your choice. If you're solo or with just two, this is probably the best buy.With all these tips in mind, bring your photocamera or handycam along and marvel at the splendour of the temple grounds and the Grand Palace. It's not just the Emerald Buddha you want to see, check out all the different Guardian Giants and what's probably the biggest comic book in history, painted along the entire inside of the temple's outer walls.

Good Temple Visit in Bangkok. Took in conjunction with Grand Palace tour. Very nice Buddha image for a meaningful viewing when combined with the deep faith of the other visitors. I am not Buddhist, but the temple itself gives you an awe-inspiring experience when others of faith are there. Good sight to see, do not wear shorts/short dresses or you may have to "rent" some long pajama pants for 30 Baht before you are allowed in.

The King and I!. First of all, go to this temple with someone that knows about art and architecture. The murals were outstanding and told a beautiful story. The architecture was intricate and awe-inspiring. Make sure your camera is geared up for some outstanding photos. We walked around the grounds for a few hours. Our guide informed us that scene from the King and I had been filmed there. There were elephant mounting stands and perfectly groomed trees! Amazing!You are technically not supposed to take photos of the Emerald Buddha, which is very small, especially after the reclining Buddha. Try to go at an off time of the day. It is crowded and gets very hot.And if you have time... walk around the mural and hear the story!

Serene and Beautiful. First sight I visited in Bangkok. The Buddha is beautiful and it was silent except for some fans circulating the breeze. The building is spectacular. You enter and it is so serene. I sat there for about 20 minutes in contemplation. It is very spiritual. You must see it if in Bangkok.

A must-see in Bangkok. Any visitor to Bangkok must include a visit to this this temple. Located within the Grand Palace complex, it houses an image of Buddha carved from a large solid piece of green jade. Very interesting too are the other buildings with their colored mirror tiles or finished in bits of Chinese porcelain. Lots of nice photos here!
It was just like seeing the others... Sorry - maybe the trip had just gone too long, or maybe I should have done more research to understand the importance.

Fantastic Design and Architecture. Intricately designed and well-maintained, Wat Phra Kaew is the home of the Emerald Buddha. It is within the Grand Palace so you won't have to pay for a separate ticket to see it. Your eyes will light up with the beauty of the place.
Unusual. The temple was very unusual and beautiful. It was not quite as wonderful as expected since the Buddha was high and not that big.
Must see. cant compare to grand palace temple. But really good place to visit
beautiful. So much detail and work has gone into this, we could've sat for hours taking it all in - amazing
Breathtaking. Be prepared to ber overwhelmed - simply magnificent. It can be very hot and sticky -take lots of water
