Impressive - all of that gold. I loved the wats we visited and Wat Phra Kaeo was beautiful. Remember to wear clothing that covers your knees and shoulders. My daughter had to leave a deposit and borrow proper attire, so you will want to avoid that.
A different world. An amazing compound of sinuous dragons, sweeping temples, gold, colors - my camera's memory card filled far too soon!
majestic. Sitting gazing at the revered artefact was further made worth the visit by monks who arrived and were chanting, what a serene and calm feeling they invoked.
tranquility at its finest. I enjoyed walking around the ornate, rich, tranquil space and then to sit in front of the most revered artefact in Thailand was again majestic.

Nothing Prepares You. Unless you are an experienced Asian traveller nothing will prepare you for the scale, glitter, ornament, and genuinely astonishing delight of the place.Don't be tempted to miss it because it's difficult to get to.And once you've see it, every poor an grimy little bit of decoration you see in the city will have a different significance for you, and consequently so will the city.Cautionary word; You may encounter 'helpful officials' - nothing fo the sort, near the gate saying the main gate is closed for a festival/prayers, and they can show you into a side gate. Don't know how it works. Ignore them.
Another must see in Bangkok. We hired a private guide for the day to m make sure we got the most out of our visit. They know everything there is to know and when to go to avoid the crowds

A must see. inside the grand palace, this is a must see attraction! Watch out for the giagantic gem's seasonal costume changes. Get a guide at the entrance to the Grand Palace, or hire one in advance - looked for licenced guide as they are very informative and not too expensive.
budda is small :). if you think is a big statue you may be dissapionted
Truly Amazing History. The only one in the world like it, a must see for all tourists and nationals.

wat phra kaeo. Simply amazing. So beautiful and with such a detail, you could spend hours looking at it and the other temples arround and you would still find something new and interesting... although very busy when you get inside you still have that feeling that you are in a very special place.

Beautiful to see, though no photographs inside allowed. Really stunning to see, best advice is dont forget you can photograph it from the outside in which can deliver awesome memories as photography is strictly forbidden inside the temple where it resides
Very special. Not to be missed. Worth the wait to get in. Can be a problem finding your shoes afterwards
Not to be missed. Take your camera and good walking shoes. You will be amazed.
Stunning. A must if you are travelling to Bangkok. Remember to cover up.

AKA- Grand Palace. The home of the Emerald Buddha is stunning. One of my favorite buildings in the world. The Buddha himself is beautiful too.
If you want to know more, check out my review of the Grand Palace...
Wow. the temple is a must see. Emerald Budha is WOW. it is very pretty and serene. the grounds are peaceful. you cant go to bangkok without stopping here.
Historic. With so many wats to visit, this one could seem a bit underwhelming because of the small size of the Buddha. But when you understand the history behind it, it's quite amazing.
Emerald buda. It is actualy ad from jade and surprisingly small.
Amazing. The Buddah is actually jade, but the story is amazing. If you sit on the floor, as we did, make sure your feet bottoms are not facing the Buddah!
well worth having a couple of hours walking round. Went with my wife and kids (5 & 7). Amazing architecture, beautiful artefacts stunning history.....

not too big. this is part of the grand palace located near where the royal family live and and where the hold the state banquet. i was expecting a gigantic statue, but i suppose its pure jade, i cannot complained. very hot so make sure you have plenty of water

Truly Beautiful !!. If you are going to visit a Temple in Bangkok you need to visit the Grand Palace complex. I must have taken more than 100 photos that afternoon the gold, mosaics and glass are dazzling. Apparently best to do a morning tour for the light.

Worth paying to see. Definitely thought this was worth seeing. I'd already heard about it's history but there are also pamphlets provided that have information in English (i.e. it has three changes of clothing which only the Royal family can dress it in).

It's small and not really made of emerald. The emerald buddha is not really made of emerald. It is jade or an agate I think. It is also very small and this temple is a bit of a let down after you see some of the other temples.
Beautiful. Brillant. Cannot take pictures of the Emerald Buddha but can get a feel of how sacred it is to Buddhist. Abide by the dress code!!
excellent. everything the guide was amazing some of the Temples just blow your mind away,amazing things to say you have seen with your own eyes

A Spectacular Site. Ornate trimmings, superb mastery of colour, pictorial representations of history. A history second to none.
You can't afford to miss this one.

Emerald Colour. Only Asia could give you History and Religious culture like found in Thailand.
A true representation of religious commitment of the people.
It's tiny!. Absolutely unmissable but bring your binoculars - the Emerald Buddha is tiny! Worth the visit though, and the temple provides a nice bit of shade out of the blistering sun.
Fabulous Temple!. Wat Phra Karw is vary fabulous of the temple in Bangkok as well as the design, fantastic of thai culture. Makes our mind calm down during walking around the temple.

The Grand Palace. No trip to Thailand is complete without a trip to Wat Phra Kaew. It would be like going to London and not seeing the Palace, or Paris without the Eiffel Tower. It's hot and steamy and completely overwhelming but a must. Wear long pants and shirt sleeves otherwise you wont get in without having to rent some at the gatehouse. I have taken many tours here and never tire of it. If it all becomes too much just go and have a nice massage. Enjoy.

Stunningly Beautiful Temple Complex.. NOT to be missed. We spent hours here taking pictures... This temple is amazing.. As you approach the Tiles on the roof glimmer and shine. Its just the beginning of the sensory overload of this temple. Their is a dress code to enter this temple, However, there are clothes for rent at the main gate if you need them. Just make sure your knees and shoulders are covered. Be respectful in the temple and you will ENJOY! Shoes are taken off before entering any temple. I just put mine in my pack so I wasn't leaving them with hundreds of other shoes. This temple is extremely ornate. Every wall is painstakingly coated in tiny bits of coloured glass. You will need lots of room on your cameras memory card. Come prepared to be amazed.
A WoW Factor.. Located in the historic center of Bangkok. Very elegantly decorated and rich with Thai culture and architecture.

Must See!!. The complex of Wat Phra Kaew and the grand palace are simply magnificent. The golden temples, statues and paintings are awe inspiring. Even our 6 year old boy was thoroughly entertained exploring the temple grounds. Coming off the chao phraya river express people will try to point you in the wrong direction which is very annoying. Follow your map or the other tourists to find the entrance.
Emerald buddha. liked - the temple look very grand from inside to outside. emerald buddha are unique as dorn with 4 season gold clothing

Beautiful. The temple of the emerald Buddha sits within the Grand Palace, and is considered the most important temple in Thailand.The temple itself is beautiful and very ornately decorated. The Emerald Buddha sits on an elevated pedestal within the temple. The statue itself is not made of emerald, but of a single block of Jade. It is clothed in gold, and only the King is allowed to touch the statue. The hall where the Buddha is, is gorgeous with frescoes on the walls and ceilings depicting the life of the Buddha.Please note that this is a working temple and photography is not allowed inside the temple. You will have to take your Pictures from outside and then go in. Spend a few minutes inside taking in all the grandeur. Beautiful. A memorabl experience.Tip: It would be good to have a guide with you to explain all the things that you see within the temple, like the fact that the Buddha has 3 sets of clothes - One for each season and much much more.

the palace was more impressive. as i said in my grand palace review, i don't know why such a small statue commands such attention. then again, i am not a buddhist...i really enjoyed the architecture and decor of the temple so much more. the doors had inlaid mother of pearl that was so detailed and impressive! the lights in the long outer corridors were a nice accent to the height, color and detail of the corridors. beautiful, just beautiful.

Awesome. The temple is really beautiful and serene and despite the noise in the nearby grounds, the temple premises was peaceful.The entrance fee is included in Grand palace ticket (400B) as this is a part of Grand palace. Take care of your shoes as I saw a few distressed tourists because their shoes were gone.

Spirituality through the crowds. Visited for the first time. Arrived mid morning amongst many crowds of people but still managed to find some space for reflective moments. We donated a tile to the restoration of the temple roof with written messages of love for our recently departed family member Roger, it just seemed a fitting thing to do in his memory. We had a foot massage for one hour which was magical the best I have had anywhere in the world, including China. A must do visit when in Bangkok.

Superb. No many things to write, just go and see the magnificence of all these temples! Only the small Angkor Wat model is something completely off key as Angkor wat is something in a context (lost in the jungle for centuries) completely different from these temples in the middle of a capital city.

Watch out for your shoes at the Temple. Yep, the emerald Buddha is worth viewing..... Take your shoes off to enter .... Read the signs outside the Temple. "We take no responsibility for your shoes". Heaps of security people around.
Great. Took off my shoes and that was the last I saw of them.....

Have never seen so many Buddha's in one location.. Before you go ensure that you are dressed correctly. Ladies and Mens legs must be fully covered by clothing and women must have their shoulders covered by clothing which is not see through or skimpy. When you arrive, enter through the main entrance and ignore any persons telling you to use an alternate entrance or that the temple is closed. These people just want to take you on a shopping journey (disguised as a 20 baht tuk tuk sightseeing trip) instead! We avoided this scam, entered the temple, paid 350 baht entrance fee and joined a free tour inside the grounds, which was well worth it. We had never seen so many Buddha's in one location. Ensure your camera has room for lots of photo's. Before or after, take advantage of a visit to the nearby reclining Buddha and the adjacent pier for a long tail boat trip.

Interesting in the total setting. The emerald Buddha itself imho is not too impressing. It is not big to start with and it is situated a good distance from the spectators so it is hard to get a good view to it. What is far more impressing is decoration around the statue and the building around it which is vastly decorated and the direct surrounding which reveal tons of mythological and architectural findings. The other thing is that especially for Thai this is a most sacred place and you can learn a lot about their religion as well. There are some things which I noted on my visit which might be useful.The first thing os to dress properly, this is a holy place so long trousers for men are a must and decent wardrobe for women as well (no bare knees for example). The second thing is to drop off your shoes before you enter and to never put the soles of your feet into the direction of the Buddha. And lastly, photography is strictly forbidden inside the temple (though not strictly enforced). As a part of the whole grand palace it would be a shame to miss it.

interesting architectural attractions. you could easily spend a whole day.interesting architectural attractions as well as photo opportunities. there were many interesting legends related to this temple, which is really amazing. I think it’s so beautiful and colorful is one of my favorite temple in Bangkok . I was there on Sunday and the temple was full of Thai people praying and making offerings. The surrounding buildings and complex are also incredible. there is a museum in the complex so you can read a few signs about it.

Fantastic but don't fall for the scam that it is not open. This place is wonderful, as long as you get through the front gate. Don't fall for the people outside who tell you it is closed, it isn't, they are just trying to get you to go somewhere else. A terrific sight to experience

Get there early, go straight for the Emerald Buddha". So much has been written about this incredible place, but I would like to give a few key tips which made my visit here memorable. As crowds are large and intense (and LOUD), I most strongly recommend arriving at the site as early as possible, even BEFORE it opens and be the first one inside the gates. When you enter, go straight fo the Emerald Buddha...so that you can experience it in utter silence. I will not reveal my own experience, but let us say that amidst all the grandiose and bravura of many of the sites, the utter modesty and grace of Emerald Buddha deeply moved me. But it must be experienced in silence! Likewise for most of the site complex.....You will experience the stark contrast an hour or two later when droves of tourists arrive, and like cackling chickens (plus our new Western nemesis: cellphones) give an intrusive ambience. When this happens, I suggest moving on to the Wat Poh massage area, and if you are lucky, you can strike up a conversation with one of the local monks---or treat yourself to a classic Thai massage. Highly recommended--at the right time of day!

Very Intriguing Architecture, A Majestic Buddha Statue. The entrance fee to both Wat Phra Kaeo & Grand Palace is THB350/person for non-Thai, as of July 2011. It's definitely worth it, there are just too many interesting architectural attractions as well as photo opportunities. I think this place can be very crowded but it was not so bad in the early morning, we started about 9am. At the entrance, a brochure with write ups and detailed map is given (available in few languages).The main attraction is of course the Emerald Buddha, which is quite small in size but it sits high up on the altar, and looks really majestic. Please take off your footwear (as in all other temples).Do go around the walls from the entrance, as the wall paintings are really nice. I believe restoration work was done recently. The details are really interesting.

Cannot take pictures of Emerald Buddha. Only the King is allowed to touch the Emerald Buddha. The clothing is changed on the statue 3 times a year for the season. The statue is much smaller than we originally thought and not as impressive but glad we took the opportunity to see it while in Bangkok. You are not allowed to take pictures of this piece of history.

Visually stunnning. Deserves its place as top of the tree in the Wat 'hierarchy'in Bangkok. 350 bht gets you access this plus the Grand Palace. Much more to take in relative to other Thai temples but you do need to compete with the hoardes from the buses.

spectacular. the opening hour of this temple is in the morning and in june it was very hot,if u want to visit this or any outdoor attraction in summer you must wear comfortable shoes and an umbrella is a must.entrance fee is 350BHT,and i think its too much.

Very pretty temple. This was my first trip to Thailand and I was so surprised by the beauty of the temple. It's a great architecture, I think so. there were many interesting legends related to this temple, which is really amazing to me. If you have a chance to travel to Bangkok, let's include this temple in you travel list.

Very pretty but smaller than I imagined.. As mentioned by other reviewers, this is a joint ticket admission so it is advisable to get there in the morning. This will enable enough time to see all of the attractions using the one ticket (NB: The teakwood mansion can be done on another day with paying for another ticket.). As I have seen Wats from all over SE Asia the whole affair only took me 2-3 hours, but you could easily spend a whole day. The amount of intricate detail and the vast array of structures and statues on offer to see could take more time than anticipated.As for this actual wat and it's emerald Buddha, it is very pretty and usually very congested with people. No shoes and no photography or video footage is permitted inside, however you can get a photo shot from outside - though dodging the unsuspecting and downright rude people is hard and can be time consuming. A decent zoom and lens is required to get a good shot (Mine is only from an Olympic 850 waterproof camera, so only very average.)It is a must see, but I found there was more hype to it than a spectacular wow factor. Nonetheless it is very pretty as to it's environment and the outside building and it's surrounds. (Lots of gold, shiny and glittery colours etc) Also the crowd was quite substantial and had to be endured which can lessen the enjoyment factor. Therefore, to me it's a "been there, done that" attraction and would only revisit if I was travelling with someone who hasn't see it, and they wished to.

Jaw-droppingly gorgeous, don't miss it. It's easy to get "over-Watted" in Bangkok, but don't even *think* of missing this when you are in Bangkok. The ticket that lets you into both Wat Phra Kaeo and the Grand Palace also gets you in (but only on the same day, so start early) to see a tour of the Teak Palace near Dusit Zoo, some considerable distance away. Even without that, however, the 350 Bhat admission price is worth it. In fact, add another 200 TBh and rent the audio-guide rather than joining a huge group tour with a guide leading you around. That way you can dawdle gawking at things that most appeal to you rather than following the timing someone else prefers. It's hard to know how to begin to describe the incredible excess that is shown in this Temple complex. The Emerald Buddha (perhaps the most revered in all of Thailand) is housed here, and each Rama (King of Thailand) over the years has added yet a new grandiose feature to the surrounding area. (One, for example, built a scale model of Angkor Wat near Siem Reap in Cambodia in this complex.) The result really is incredible, with new features to see around each corner you turn. If you are a photographer, however, the hardest part of your photography is likely to be finding a time to take a picture of your favorite figure that does not have other tourists mugging for photos in front of it. Getting there when the place first opens might be worth a try, but a few hundred other people are likely to have much the same idea. Still, it seemed to get worse close to noontime when I was there, so an early start is still advisable. Really, though, do spring for that audioguide. When they say that if you go beyond the 2 hour limit to return it you will be charged another 200 Bhat, that two hours sounds short, but you can probably do all you want in that time. Much of the space of the area of the tour is taken up by the Grand Palace. There you are pretty much restricted to looking from the outside (unless you want to spend time in the "weapons museum") so the last part of your tour goes pretty quickly. Dawdle in the Wat where there's wonder around every corner, then move more quickly through the Grand Palace.
beatifull decorations. This temple is so beatifull and colorfull is one of my favorite temple in Bangkok .

“Glitter and Gold “. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is glittering gold and incredibly stunning. This temple is inside the Royal Palace complex.I was there on Sunday and the temple was full of Thai people praying and making offerings to the Buddha. This temple is spectacular but you have to remove your shoes to go in there. No photographs are permitted inside the temple and is definately worth a visit.

If you only visit one Temple in Bangkok - make it this one!. It was unfortunately fairly rainy when we visited, but still definitely worth it! We paid about $5 Aust. each and hired a guide to give us the downlow on the site - and he was worth every penny!We learned about the various Yak (demons) guarding the temple and the 4 different types of architecture on the site - from Cambodian to Thai - it's all here. Along with how it's all maintained - from the extensive gold leaf to unending mosaics - it's truly a gorgeous labour of love.The story of how the Buddha was found to where it is as a showpiece today is pretty incredible. Each year, the King visits 4x and changes the raiment according to the seasons.And although called Emerald - this refers to colour only - the Buddha is made from Jade.No photos can be taken inside the temple but it's still easy to get a good pic from outside through the windows. No shoes worn inside either - so if you can take some slip ons, it will save time. Thoroughly worth a visit to tick a lot of cultural boxes without traipsing all over town.

It was Okay, Exhausted. Okay, I guess its one of those thigs to do in Bangkok, like see the Eiffel Tower in Paris but there wasn't anything spectacular about it for me. It seems very commerical unlike other temples in Asia. For example, the Kandy Temple in Sri Lanka (where the Buddha's tooth relic is) had a real feeling that it was being used as a temple, lots of monks, lots incense, lots of worshipers etc. At the Grand Palace, it was just a bit touristy and lots of buildings with nothing amazing to look at inside them.It is nice however, one can get over it very quickly. Go during the early morning as I went at about 1230 and it was very very hot and uncomfortable.It is 350 Bhat entrance fee. I wouldn't waist money on a tour guide as there isn't much to talk about and the people I looked at on lots of different tours weren't really all that interested in the guides. I think they just wanted to get into the shade and take photos.
A must see. The most famous buddha in Thailand - what else needs to be said?

A Must See in Bangkok - Spectacular.. The Temple of the Emerald Buddha is part of the Royal Palace complex in old town Bangkok, so if you see one you'll see the other. Make sure to make it a stop on your itinerary - it is glittering gold and spectacular. The Emerald Buddha Temple is the holiest temple in Thailand, and you will see Thai people doing offerings here and praying to the Buddha. The buddha image itself is small, but sits atop a magnificent golden throne - it is really amazing. The surrounding buildings and complex are also incredible. Your trip will be enhanced by using a guide who can explain to you the importance of the structures, their meanings, and the history of the Emerald Buddha and Thai Buddhism. Without a guide, they are just a lot of beautiful buildings - still cool to see, but you won't have the same understanding and appreciation of the significance of this site. At the very least, there is a museum in the complex so you can read a few signs about it.

Amazing!!. We went to the Grande Palace. During the Lent period 7th July 2009. what an amazing place. Wat Phra Si Rattanasasadaram, generally called the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, is a temple purpose-built to house a Buddha image carved from a large solid piece of green jadite (jasper). Chaophraya Chakri, who went on to become King Rama I, brought the image from Vientiane when he captured the city in 1778. King Rama I built the temple and enshrined the Emerald Buddha there as a symbol of Siam's regained nationhood. To enter this area you have to take your shoes off and store them in shoe cases outside. It is very important that when you visit the temples you are correctly dressed eg no shorts, bare shoulders and low cut tops. It is a sacred area and must be respected. You are not allowed to film or take pictures inside the enclosed area where the Emerald Buddha sits. It is such a calm, detailed, beautiful area and a must see when visiting Bangkok.

Wonderful Place to Visit. We started at the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew - Temple of the Emerald Buddha, which was a very short walk from the pier. We visited with Get - one of the guides from Tour with Tong. Entrance was 350 Baht / person, but there is no charge for the guide (there was no charge for the guides at any of the sites either). Both were spectacular in terms of colors, the intricacy of designs and the amount of gold used. We were lucky enough to explore these sights on a clear day and the photos turned out beautifully! It was great to explore with a guide because it allowed us to ask questions and understand what we were seeing. It was also interesting to see the ongoing restorations required to keep everything looking new and fresh. The murals on the walls were beautiful, and Get was able to help us understand the story from the Ramakien that was illustrated. That part was definitely something we would have missed on our own. The other part that we probably would have missed without her guidance was the Wat Phra Kaeo Museum. It gives you a much better understanding of how the temple and palace have changed over the years, as well as the number of restorations. It’s definitely worth a few minutes to explore.

Dazzling!. This temple is a huge incredible riot of glittering gold and color. Pictures on the internet cannot do it justice. Definitely a must-see in Bangkok. I think admission was 200 bahts (free for Thais) and that includes tickets to the Vimanmek Mansion and Abhisek Dusit Throne Hall (in the Duist area of Bangkok near the zoo - I can't comment on these however since we ran out of time.), as well as the next-door Grand Palace (but you can't go inside).

Bling Bling at the Palace grounds. Okay, this must be said,I was in Bangkok for three days, and on all three I tried to visit the Royal Palace and Wat Phra Kaeo. On the third day it finally came to it, and I wouldn't have missed it for the world. I found that sightseeing in Bangkok was not at all as I thought it would be. You can make schedules all you want of were to go and when, but I bet you wind up being somewhere else and loving it. I'm glad to have visited the Palace and Wat Phra Kaeo at the end of my trip to BKK, because it was the icing on my cake. There's glitter and gold everywhere you look, you can't even imagine if you haven't seen it with your own eyes. There's a million details not to be overlooked. It's grand! The temple of the emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaeo) itself is very beautiful and peaceful. The Royal Palace is around the corner, not as splendid, but worth the time to visit while you're there anyway...

Emarald Buddha. Part of visiting the Grand Palace is seeing the emerald buddha definately worth visiting but nothing exceptional in itself, although the number of tourists would seem to suggest otherwise. Lots of Thai people seem to be on a pilgrimage to see it and your not supposed to take a photo inside the temple - of course theirs always one!
